summary: The patient presented to orthopaedic trauma clinic on ___ and was evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found to have a wound infection of his left above the knee amputation (AKA) stump and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. On admission, his coumadin was discontinued, and he was started on a heparin drip for operative procedure. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ and ___ for left AKA stump irrigation and debridment and wound vac placement, both of which the patient tolerated well (for full details please see the separately dictated operative report). Patient was started on vancomycin on ___ and Infectious Disease was consulted. Culture data revealed MRSA and enterococcus, both sensitive to vancomycin. . On ___, the patient was taken to the OR by Dr. ___, Plastic and Reconstructive surgery, for debridement of left above-the-knee amputation stump wound, including skin, subcutaneous tissue, and muscle, local advancement muscle flap for coverage of exposed femur, local advancement flap of posterior thigh skin, greater than 30 cm2 and split-thickness skin graft to left above-knee amputation stump site. Patient tolerated the procedure well. A wound vac was kept ___ place over skin graft site until ___ when it was removed and revealed a healthy skin graft site with 100% take. Patient was maintained on heparin drip during the entire hospital stay and PTT was maintained between 60-80. His coumadin was restarted on ___. . For all procedures, the patient was taken from the OR to the PACU ___ stable condition and after recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. Following operative procedures, the patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications. At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is non-

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abdominal Burning <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with HTN, hx of tachy-brady syndrome s/p PPM ___ (per report), presents with 4 days and abdominal burning. The pt reports her abdominal burning is throughout her abdomen and she does not describe it as pain. Pt does report occasional reflux. Denies nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. No black stools. No increase in NSAIDs or ETOH. Pt has been tolerating POs. Denies fevers, chills. No colonoscopies in our system. The pt also notes a history of bilateral lower extremity edema left slightly more than right. No calf tenderness, long flights, cancer, recent surgeries or prolonged immobilization. She states that this occured around the time of her initating her Norvasc. Per report the pt had a pacermaker placed 1 month ago for tachy-brady syndrome Upon arrival to the ED intial vitals 98.6 108 136/87 18 96. Exam notable for clear lungs, soft abdomen, 2 pitting edema. Labs notable for unremarkable CBC and Chem-7. The patient underwent an initial ECG with no ischemic findings. CXR with no acute process and a CT Abd/Pelvis with diverticulosis and an endometrial cyst. The patient received. Vitals prior to transfer to the floor 97.9 72 150/74 23 94RA Upon arrival to the floor the pt had a episode of mid-substernal sharp chest pain ___, lasting approximately 1hr in duration (the pt did not tell anyone for the first 45 minutes). She described it as sharp, non-radiating with mild diaphoresis but no nausea. The pain subsided on its own. Review of Systems: () Per HPI (-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath, or wheezes. Denied nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rashes or skin breakdown. No numbness/tingling in extremities. No feelings of depression or anxiety. All other review of systems negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> # HTN # s/p pacemaker placed for tachy-brady syndrome at ___ ___ on ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-Contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 97.9 72 150/74 23 94RA Gen: NAD, AOX3 HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, MMM, sclera anicteric, not injected, no exudates Neck: no thyromegally, JVD flat Cardiovascular: No reproducible CP. RRR normal s1, s2, no murmurs, rubs or gallops Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales or rhonchi Abd: Soft, non-tender, non distended, no heptosplenomegally, bowel sounds present Extremities: No cyanosis, clubbing, edema, joint swelling Neurological: CN II-XII intact Integument: Warm, moist, no rash or ulceration Psychiatric: appropriate, pleasant, not anxious <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 08: 40PM WBC-9.2 RBC-5.40 HGB-16.2* HCT-46.6 MCV-86 MCH-30.0 MCHC-34.7 RDW-13.7 ___ 08: 40PM CALCIUM-9.7 PHOSPHATE-2.7 MAGNESIUM-1.7 ___ 08: 40PM NEUTS-67.8 ___ MONOS-5.7 EOS-4.6* BASOS-1.4 ___ 08: 40PM PLT COUNT-228 ___ 08: 40PM cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 08: 40PM LIPASE-21 ___ 08: 40PM ALT(SGPT)-11 AST(SGOT)-16 LD(LDH)-213 CK(CPK)-34 ALK PHOS-89 TOT BILI-0.3 ___ 08: 40PM GLUCOSE-129* UREA N-29* CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-142 POTASSIUM-3.5 CHLORIDE-107 TOTAL CO2-24 ANION GAP-15 ___ 09: 20PM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-7.0 LEUK-NEG ___ 01: 15AM ___ PTT-29.1 ___ ___ 06: 05AM cTropnT-<0.01 Imaging: CT abd/pelvis ___: IMPRESSION: 1. Moderate-to-severe pancolonic diverticulosis but without definite acute diverticulitis. 2. Abnormal endometrial fluid and 3-cm left adnexal cyst, abnormal for patient's age. Recommend workup with pelvic ultrasound. 3. Bilateral simple renal cysts, without hydronephrosis or hydroureter. CXR ___: IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality. Pelvic US ___: FINDINGS: The uterus measures 6.8 x 3.8 cm, with a small amount of fluid within the endometrial cavity. The endometrial stripe measures 7 mm. The right ovary is not visualized. In the region of the left adnexa, there is a 3.3 x 3.5 x 2.7 cm cyst, also seen on the prior CT examination. No internal vascularity is seen within this lesion. IMPRESSION: Transabdominal ultrasound examination of the pelvis reveals a left adnexal cyst and a small amount of fluid within the endometrial cavity. The patient has refused the transvaginal examination. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Metoprolol 50mg BID Amlodipine 10mg Daily olpidem 5mg ASA (occasionally) <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Metoprolol
summary: Ms ___ is a ___ year-old female with hx of pacer ___ presenting with four days of malaise and abdominal burning, found incidentally to have a left adenexal mass. # Abdominal burning: The patient was without abdominal burning by the morning after admisison. She states she has had reflux in the past which had improved a medication given to her by her PCP (which she only took for a short period of time). She had a CT abd/pelvis which revealed a left adenexal mass and some endometrial fliud, but no other abnormality. She was started on omperazole 20 mg po daily and asked to follow up with her PCP. # Chest Pain: After admission, she had am episode of chest pain that lasted approximately 1 hour and resovled on own. Per ED resident pt with potential hx of unstable angina however pt denies having similar episodes of chest pain before, although she does admit to left shoulder pain in the past. CEs negative x2. EKG without ischemic changes. She stated that the pain may have been related to acid reflux. She was started on omeprazole as above and asked to discuss the possiblity of an outpatient stress test with her PCP. # Left Adnexal Cyst: 2.8cm x 3.2cm x2.9cm left adnexal cyst on CT. She was sent for a pelvic US, but refused the vaginal US. She was scheduled to follow up with gynecology as an outpatient for further evaluation. # Ta___: Pt currently in NSR. Has a PPM in place. Telemetry was unremarkable. # Hypertension: She was continued on her home medications (amlodipine and metoprolol).

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Depakote <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Hypotension <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ yo M w/ h/o epilepsy, non-epileptic seizures, PTSD, cognitive deficits, and recent diagnosis of C. difficile infection who presents w/ AF w/ RVR and hypotension. The patient was seen in ___ where he was found to have pressures in the ___ in AF w/ RVR and was sent to the ED. The patient has had numerous recent admissions including one in ___ for seizures where he was diagnosed with C. difficile in setting of nearly one year of chronic diarrhea. He was started vancomycin and switched flagyl, which he was instructed to complete for two weeks of treatment as an outpatient. The patient did not do so until he saw his PCP in ___ two weeks later (___). He was subsequently admitted on ___ to ___ for possible seizures after being found down in his bathroom. His flagyl was not restarted during this admission. Today, while seen in neurology clinic for routine follow up, it was discovered that the patient has continued to have diarrhea and has not taken flagyl since ___. He also has had difficulty keeping up with his PO intake and self care, and was noted to dehydrated, more disheveled, despondant and w/ more memory deficits than his baseline. As a result, he was sent to his PCP's office, where he was found to be hypotensive w/ SBPs in the ___ and a thready pulse. An EKG showed AF w/ RVR. The patient was sent to the ER for further management. In the ED, initial vitals were HR 140 60/42 18 98%. He received 4L of IVF and converted to sinus rhythm with transient response of his blood pressures. He received vancomycin, cefepime, and flagyl for empiric coverage after blood and urine cultures were sent. Labs were notable for creatinine of 3.0 up from baseline 0.7, WBC 14.4, lactate 2.0, and UA w/ numerous hyaline casts He is being admitted to the MICU for further management. Access was 18G and 20G, no central line was placed as patient was felt to improve w/ volume. On transfer, vitals were: 97.5 75 74/50 12 99%. On arrival to the MICU, the patient appears comfortable, denies chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain or any fevers at home. He points out an erythematous rash near the site of the IV where vancomycin had just completed infusion. The rash resolves within a few minutes. Review of systems: () Per HPI and for chronic R arm and shoulder pain, occasional dysuria (-) Denies fever, headache, shortness of breath, or wheezing. Denies chest pain, chest pressure, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, constipation, abdominal pain, or changes in bowel habits. Denies urinary frequency, or urgency. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> ANEMIA CATARACT GYNECOMASTIA OSTEOPOROSIS POTENTIAL FOR INJURY PTSD DEPRESSION EPILEPSY HYPOGONADISM NONEPILEPTIC SEIURES MISSED APPTS MEDICATION MANAGEMENT FATTY LIVER LEFT VENTRICULAR HYPERTROPHY CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE ENTEROCOLITIS H/O TESTICULAR CALCIFICATION H/O TOBACCO ABUSE H/O PANCYTOPENIA H/O ELEVATED LIPASE H/O RIGHT DISTAL RADIUS FRACTURE H/O HYPERTENSION H/O CAROTID CALCIFICATION H/O CHRONIC BACK PAIN <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Denies family history of seizures. Mother died at ___ of CAD, had glaucoma. Father died at ___ of skin cancer, also had inflammatory bowel disease and dementia. Brothers have history of skin cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress, increased latency of speech, tangential HEENT: temporal wasting, sclera anicteric, extremely dry MM, oropharynx clear, EOMI,  cataract Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no organomegaly GU: Foley in place Ext: poor capillary refill, but warm, well perfused, 2 pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema Neuro: CNIII-XII intact, ___ strength upper/lower extremities, grossly normal sensation, gait deferred Discharge Exam Vitals: T: 98.2 BP: 87/58 P: 66 R: 18 O2: 97% General: oriented, no acute distress HEENT: temporal wasting, sclera anicteric, moist membranes, oropharynx clear, EOMI, Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Lungs: Clear
summary: ___ yo M w/ h/o epilepsy, pseudoseizures, cognitive deficits, C. difficile, and PTSD presenting ___/ hypotension in setting of new AF. #) C. difficile infection: Pt has a history of chronic diarrhea for nearly one year. He was recently diagnosed with C. diff during admission in ___. Has failed to complete his original antibiotic regimen of Flagyl or vancomycin. Would meet criteria for severe C. diff given elevated creatinine (>1.5x normal) and ICU admission. Abdomen has been distended and focally tender in LLQ on exam. He was treated for severe C. difficile with vancomycin 125 mg q6hr with plans for a 14 day course, which he has tolerated well. He had a Flexiseal apparatus in place which was removed on ___ and reduction of bowel movements. On the day of discharge he was down to approximately ___ loose non-bloody stools per day. --> Continue oral vancomycin till ___ #) Seizure Activity: Pt with history of tonic clonic epileptiform seizures as well as non-epileptiform (pseudo) seizures attributed to conversion disorder. He is followed by Dr. ___ these issues and has been maintained on Clobazam 30mg though has had some issues with compliance in the past. Per neurology clinic note, has been having more frequent pseudoseizures and  seizures which could be attributed to numerous stressors including upcoming birthday of sister who was murdered. Dr ___ Dr ___ emailed regarding his hospitalization. Flagyl does low the seizure threshold and was thus avoided. During the hospital course, he had one episode of seizure activity with falling during ambulation. He was evaluated via head CT for intracranial bleeding which was negative. After discussion with Dr. ___ changes were made to his medications. --> Continue Clobazam 20 mg qam and 10 mg pqpm #) Hypotension: He originally presented to the hospital because of low blood pressure. Likely due to hypovolemia in setting

Mental Status: Clear and coherent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> MEDICATIONS: - Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians at discharge. - Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed to stop by your surgeon. - Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers. - Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener (colace) to prevent this side effect. summary: The patient presented for an elective ORIF of right calcaneal fx that occured on ___ when he fell from a ladder. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for ORIF of right calcaneal fracture, which the patient tolerated well (for full details please see the separately dictated operative report). The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given perioperative antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patients home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient was transitioned to a bivalve cast on POD#1. It was noted that he continued to have some oozing from two areas on his incision starting POD0. It was carefully watched and after continued oozing on ___, 3 simple stiches were oversewn on the incision at the sight of the oozing. The wound was rexamined on ___, and a betadine swab was applied to it and allowed to dry to help with stop the oozing. After the oozing had stopped, the wound was evaluated by Dr. ___ it was determined that the patient could now be discharged with the recommendation of a 10 day course of Bactrim DS. The patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is non weight bearing in the right lower extremity, and will be discharged on lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up in two weeks per routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course, and all questions were answered prior to discharge.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> abdominal pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Colonoscopy Procedure: The procedure, indications, preparation and potential complications were explained to the patient, who indicated ___ understanding and signed the corresponding consent forms. The efficiency of a colonoscopy in detecting lesions was discussed with the patient and it was pointed out that a small percentage of polyps and other lesions can be missed with the test. A physical exam was performed. The patient was administered moderate sedation. The physical exam was performed prior to administering anesthesia. Supplemental oxygen was used. The patient was placed in the left lateral decubitus position.The digital exam was normal. The colonoscope was introduced through the rectum and advanced under direct visualization until the cecum was reached. The cecal sling folds were seen. The appendiceal orifice and ileo-cecal valve were identified. The cecum was palpated. Careful visualization of the colon was performed as the colonoscope was withdrawn. The colonoscope was retroflexed within the rectum. The procedure was not difficult. The quality of the preparation was good. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no complications. Findings: Mucosa: Normal mucosa was noted in the entire colon Protruding Lesions A single sessile 4 mm non-bleeding polyp of benign appearance was found in the sigmoid colon. A single-piece polypectomy was performed using a cold forceps in the sigmoid polyp. The polyp was completely removed. Impression: Normal mucosa in the colon Polyp in the sigmoid colon (polypectomy) Otherwise normal colonoscopy to cecum Recommendations: - Will contact you with biopsy results - Repeat colonoscopy interval pending biopsy results ___ Flex Sig Findings: Protruding Lesions A few sessile polyps of size 3-5 mm visualized in sigmoid colon. These polyps were not removed. Other No mass noted in rectum or sigmoid colon. No external compression noted. Impression: Polyp in the colon No mass noted in rectum or sigmoid colon. No external compression noted. Otherwise normal sigmoidoscopy to splenic flexure Recommendations: - No intrinsic mass or extrinsic compression noted till sigmoid colon - ___ serial KUBs and exam - Replete lytes with K>4, Mg>2. - Needs colonoscopy given polyps visualized on flexible sigmoidoscopy after discussing with HCP. HCP denies that pt has any pain, headache, dizziness, cough, CP, SOB, abdominal pain, n/v/d/c, dysuria, urinary difficulties but has baseline incontinence. Given improvement in symptoms will try PO repletion on ___. --magnesium 400 BID until ___ with PCP # ___ poorly controlled HTN has been attributed to potentially poor absorption of meds. summary: Brief Course: Ms. ___ is a ___ w/PMHx triple negative breast cancer with mets to bone, liver (w/ascities) and with bone marrow involvement with pancytopenia who returned to the ED after CT scan on ___ had findings suspicious for perforated diverticuli. #. Diverticulitis/perforated diverticuli: Pt was asymptomatic, but called in given re-read of CT abdomen done ___ with concern for diverticulitis with perforation. Pt has loose stool but continues to have no signs/symptoms of acute peronitis. She was evaluated by surgery, but clinically stable without need for acute intervention. Pt was treated with IV cipro and flagyl and transitioned after 24 hrs to PO cipro/flagyl. Blood cultures showed no growth, but were pending at the time of discharge. She was initially made NPO and given IVF's. Her diet was advanced her exam remained benign. On discharge, her loose stools improved and she continued to have no abdominal tenderness. She was afebrile with no leukocytosis throughout entire admission. #. Ascites: Most likely secondary to mets to liver visualized on CT ___. She underwent ___ re guided therapeutic paracentesis on ___ without complications. Roughly 2 liters of fluid was removed. Fluid had normal protein and albumin levels but increased WBC and RBC. Cytology was not sent. #. Breast Cancer: Patient dx with triple neg breast c in ___. Now with extensive mets including bone marrow and liver. Her primary oncologist discussed she was moving towards hospice and would not be continuing Xeloda. Her counts were monitored, and she required no transfusions during this hospitalization. She was continued on Ativan for symptomatic management of anxiety and compazine for nausea. Patient decided she would prefer to go home at discharge and consider hospice at a later date. TRANSITIONAL CARE: 1. CODE: DNR/DNI 2. Contact - Husband ___ ___ on Admission: 1. benzonatate 100 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO QID (4 times a day) as needed for cough.

summary: Pt is a ___ y.o male with h.o ESLD ___ ETOH cirrhosis, anemia, ARF who presented to ___ with HCT drop, transferred to ___ for further care. . #right chest wall hematoma with acute blood loss anemia-On arrival to ___, repeat imaging documented progression of right axillary bleed was performed. CTA was not diagnostic of source of bleed, so he underwent tagged RBC scan which implicated R T9 intercostal artery bleed, for which pt underwent ___ cauterization/embolization on ___. CT also showed acute rib fracture which is the likely etiology of injured intercostal artery. He recieved more blood products while here including prbc, ffp, cyro, amicar, Vit K. Liver and hematology were following closely. Initially he was stable and transferred to floor. However, he developed increased back pain and a HCT drop. Next, a repeat CT showed ongoing bleeding around ___ and subsequently he was transferred back to the ICU. He underwent a repeated ___ procedure, which showed generalized oozing, no focal bleeding, and recieved some cauterization of oozing. Once hemodynamically stable, he was transfered back to floor once HCT stable, however had some bleeding from R groin site where ___ threaded a catheter for the embolization procedure. He had a HCT drop for the third time around ___, with CT again suggestive of ongoing bleeding, however Tagged RBC was negative for significant bleeding, thus he was managed symptomatically with transfusions, ffp, amicar to treat the underlying coagulopathy. At this point, transplant was also consulted to consider liver transplant while here given it may be the only definitive option for his bleeding diathesis/coagulopathy. By the time they saw him, his HCT had remained stable X4days, thus they did not feel if was urgent indication. In total, he recieved 18U prbc (total 31), 31U ffp

summary: ___ year old woman with a history of longstanding labile hypertension, transferred from ___ with chest pain. . # CHEST PAIN/CORONARIES: Patient transferred from OSH with substernal chest pain, with EKG changes on ETT. She underwent cardiac catheterization that showed clean coronary arteries. Chest pain likely musculoskeletal, as tender to palpation. On fluoro, patient was also found to have abnormality in lung parenchyma that may account for pain. The patient underwent chest x-ray that showed calcified nodules, consistent with possible prior granulomatous infection. She should follow up for CT chest as an outpatient to further evaluate lung parenchyma. . # HYPERTENSION: Patient with longstanding history of hypertension. She was hypertensive to SBP 200 in the cath lab requiring a brief nitro drip (discontinued prior to leaving the cath lab). However, blood pressures improved to SBP < 140 upon transfer to the floor. She was continued on home labetalol 200 mg BID, amlodipine 5 mg daily. . # RHYTHM: The patient remained in NSR throughout admission. . CODE: Full code =========================================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: # The patient should follow up with her PCP for CT chest to further evaluate lung parenchymal abnormality.

Throughout the week, she continued to have fevers and a variety of symptoms including joint pain in distal extremities, abdominal bloating and epigastric pain, and headache with some neck pain and eye pain but no confusion and no vision changes. Just yesterday, she developed a cough occasionally productive of white/clear sputum, sore throat, but no dyspnea. Had mild rhinorrhea at beginning of the week that has resolved. At baseline, the patient has chronic abdominal pain and bloating whenever she eats and chronic loose stools, which have continued this week. She reports no new recent exposures, no recent travel, no new foods or meats (did have farm eggs), no sick contacts. She has been taking her medications. New sexual partner since ___ but they have both been tested. No IVDU. Did have 2 beers last weekend which is very rare for her. She thinks that she may have overstressed her body last weekend by staying up late and going on a long walk. She returned to her student clinic this morning where lab tests showed a new mild transaminitis to ALT 105, AST 139. Tbili 0.4. She also had a CXR which per reports, showed a retrocardiac opacity. She was sent to the BI for RUQ US which showed inflammation of liver and gall bladder but no cholecystitis. She presented to ED after receiving a phone call from her doctor who was aware of the lab results and recommended she be admitted. summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with bilateral renal dysplasia s/p living related renal transplat ___ who presents with fever of unknown origin and poorly localized flu-like symptoms. After an extensive workup (given her immunocompromised status), she was discovered to have a high titer of EBV and diagnosed with Infectious Mononucleosis. As her transaminitis peaked, care is supportive, and she and her family are reliable, she was discharged home with close followup without antibiotics or changes to immune-suppressing medications. ACUTE MEDICAL ISSUES: #Infectious Mononucleosis due to EBV: Patient remained in hospital for workup of fever in an immunocomprimised patient, as well as transamnitis. She initially had diffuse symptoms including joint pain, epigastric pain, headache, and cough. Her labs showed LFT abnormalities but RUQ US showed only nonspecific inflammation, thus there was no clear localizing lab result. Given immunocompromised state (from taking immunosuppressants) and recent trip to ___, she was tested broadly for EBV, CMV, monospot, anaplasma, lyme, parasites, cryptococcus, respiratory viral panel, and hepatitis A, B, and C. Eventually, her symptoms became more localized to the upper respiratory tract with lymphadenopathy and tonsillar exudates (negative for strep). On day of discharge, EBV viral load returned positive despite negative IgG and IgM antibiodies and despite negative Monospot. She was discharged with instructions to avoid contact sports, to return if LUQ pain, and to continue supportive care. # Transaminitis: Likely due to EBV viremia. Alternative was considered that doxycycline (which she had been taking in week prior to admission) provoked acute cholestatic liver injury, which is a rare side effect. Her atorvastatin was held given elevated LFTs and her LFTs were monitored. Hepatology was consulted and a myriad of studies to evaluate for liver injury were otherwise unremarkable, except for fain

summary: Hospital course by problem: # Herpes oster (disseminated): Hepes oster in right C3 and C4 /- C2 dermatomes and possible spread to V1 (pinna ear - ___ syndrome). Multiple dermatomal involvement qualifies as disseminated zoster. In addition, patient has parathesias on L inner thigh suggestive of zoster crossing midline, which is also a criterion for disseminated zoster, although there are no vesicles present and may not appear now that patient is being treated. He has no lab abnormalities to suggest hepatic involvement. Creatinine mildly elevated, but this may be related to dehydration in setting of acute infection. As mentioned, he has possible involvment of R pinna, suggesting ___, which is concerning for progression to herpes ophthalmicus. Patient did endorse some R eye pain this AM, but difficult to decipher the pain/headache he has from the other lesions and specific eye pain. Patient denies changes in vision. No neck stiffness and he has no meningismus on exam so herpez meningitis unlikely. Patient was started on IV acyclovir 10mg/kg for 7 days. Ophthomology was consulted for possible eye involvement given symptoms of eye pain and lesions on pinna - per ophtho, patient cleared by them for unlikely eye involvement with instruction to call them if patient developed lights, floaters, changes in vision and will follow up with ophtho as outpatient. ID was consutled given disease progression and the fact that acyclovir was started as an outpatient (with reported compliance). Per Dr. ___ saw patient as outpatient directly prior to admission and started him on acyclovir as outpatient, his clinical picture appears to be the same. For that reason, the patient was kept on IV acyclovir regimen. On day of discharge, patient was transitioned to PO valacyclovir with improvement in lesions and no new lesions.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> encephalopathy <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ ___ M with h/o HTN, HLD and IDDM (with h/o multiple hyploglycemic prior episodes secondary to self-injecting insulin) who was admitted to ___ from ___ for encephalopathy. He is now transferred from outpatient ___ at the requests of Drs. ___ ___ who are requesting further inpatient workup and treatment of his encephalopathy. History is provided by patient and his sister who accompanies him to the ED, also from ___ electronic records. At baseline, he is a high-functioning individual, a retired ___ who lives alone and performs all his AADLs independently. On ___, he was found at home by his cleaning person: confused, oriented only to self, and aphasic with word-finding difficulty. He was naked, with stool and possible blood seen throughout the house. He had last spoken with his sister one week and five days earlier (on the phone) who did not not any problems, so timing and chronicity of the event was not clear. He was BIBA to ___ for further evaluation. In the ___ emergency department, vitals were 98.0, 147/72, 68, 20, 98% RA, FSBS 68. He was noted to have knee bruising bilaterally. NCHCT was unrevealing. He was unable to give an initial history so it was provided by a friend. ___ was consulted to guide his inpatient workup and treatment. Their initial exam was notable for a transcortical global amnesia: multiple neologisms, phonemic and semantic paraphasias, and decreased comprehsnsion to simple and complex commands, and impaired naming. Per the initial Neurology note: He is unable to describe anything meaningful although he keeps saying that feels being in a dream-like state, has had some kind of visions, with faces appearing and disappearing and he is using complexed words to describe the symptoms. He denies any clearcut headache. The following day, his family states he was talking about nonsensical things like being beaten up by a gang of men. He underwent two MRI brains (with/without contast) which were inconclusive (except for diffuse leptomeningeal enhancement as it had been performed following LP). LP showed normal cell profile: prot 46, glu 114, RBC 84, WBC 2. CSF HSV PCR, RPR and Lyme were all negative, CSF ___ is pending on discharge. EEG showed mild L>R slowing over two days. Psychiatry consult was obtained, and they felt that his symptoms were more attributable to delirium than a psychiatric condition. He was thus started on Valproate for encephalopathy vs. delirium vs. structural process without seizure activity. His mental status very gradually improved while at ___ but he ultimately required discharge to assisted living facility ___ at ___. Currently, patient and his family acknowledge that he is continuing to very slowly improve from the initial insult, but he remains far from baseline. Patient notices that he is very easily distracted and slow to process information: for example, when he visited his house today he couldn't find any of his passcodes and was having difficulty figuring out how to pay his ___ ___. When he got into the passenger seat of his sister's car, he kept on using the incorrect door handle to close the door. His sister also notes that he is still having word finding difficulties in that it takes him a long time to come around to reach the word he was intending to use (circumlocution). He has significant trouble remembering names or people and places. He stutters at baseline, and notes that this is back to normal for him. Today Mr. ___ saw Drs. ___ in outpatient clinic for follow-up. They felt that his encephalopathy had been incompletely worked up and sent him to the ED for admission and definitive workup and treatment of his symptoms. Specifically, they are interested in looking for Hashimoto encephalopathy, paraneoplastic etiologies, or Creutzfeld-Jakob. I had a superficial discussion about depression and mood disorders with the patient and he denied any significant issues. However, of note, in the ED he had a routine depression screening performed by one of the nurses. ___ am told that he told them he has thought about suicide but would not consider doing it. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - HTN - HLD - IDDM (with h/o multiple hyploglycemic prior episodes secondary to self-injecting insulin, inculding an episode of encephalopathy in ___ - Depression <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No
summary: The patient is a ___ year old man w PMH HTN, HLD, IDDM c/b multiple hypoglycemic episodes (including one in ___ in which he was reportedly encephalopathic), who presented to ___ ___ on ___ after being found confused, wandering, naked and covered in feces and noted to have a transcortical global aphasia vs acute confusional state. He completed an extensive workup for altered mental status including two MRIs, an LP and two EEGs, yet the etiology of this episode remained unclear. He was started on depakote at ___ although his EEG did not show any epileptiform discharges, although they did have some L temporal slowing. He was seen by his outpatient Neurology who was concerned that the patient was not yet back to his baseline (a high functioning mathematecian). Original plan was to get an LP to look for ___. However, during admission, the patient looked well, and was doing crossword puzzles and sudoku. There was no aphasia or other focal neurological findings. He had some mild word finding difficulty, but overall seemed to be improving with time. CJD would not be expected to gradually improve in this fashion, so we deferred LP (since other relevant studies had already been sent). We did she thyroid panel for further eval. Overall his picture is most consistent with a severe acute confusional state, possibly ___ hypoglycemia (the patient has a history of hypoglycemia and has only been on oral anti-diabetic medications until late ___, when he was switched back to insulin injections shortly before the incident described). Seizure less likely given no epileptiform discharges on EEG or focal findings on MRI, and no report of seizure activity. Thus we started a depakote taper with plan to DC depakote. This may also help with the patient's mental status, as depakote can cause mental slowing. We reassessed the patients mood upon admission. While he says he does have some

summary: ___ PMH of DLBCL (on R-CHOP) who was admitted with hyperglycemia, new diabetes mellitus, started on C4 of R-CHOP during admission and started on new insulin regimen which was titrated inpatient. # Hyperglycemia # New type 2 DM Patient presented with polyuria/polydipsia found to have new onset type 2 DM (A1c 13%), likely exacerbated by steroids in chemo regimen, which required insulin gtt at outside hospital prior to transfer, now much improved on glargine and lispro insulin regimen which was titrated under guidance ___ consult service. Patient received diabetic education and proved reliable to inject at home on his own and follow contingency protocols for hypoglycemia. #DLBCL: Patient tolerated his ___ cycle of R-CHOP (ordered by ___ oncologist) without complications besides hyperglycemia. #HTN: Was switched to stand-alone losartan without HCT given increased risk of polyuria and dehydration #Hypophosphatemia: Likely secondary to refeeding syndrome. Was monitored and repleted. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ===================== #NEW Type 2DM // Insulin: Diagnosed in setting of steroid (R-CHOP) induced hyperglycemia. Started on insulin and titrated while inpatient. Requiring metformin 500mg bid, 35U of glargine and 12U TID novolog (SS). Needs endocrinology appointment within next ___ day to adjust as insulin requirements likely to decrease. 90 minutes were spent coordinating and formulating this patient's complex discharge plan

summary: Mr ___ is a ___ with h/o hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, and ESRD on HD (___), who presented with thrombosis of his RUE AV graft. # Thrombosed Graft: Third episode of graft thrombosis in the last three months, the most recent treated with ___ thrombectomy 10 days ago. Etiology of recurrent thromboses unclear, but no other h/o clotting, such as ___ DVT or PE. Had Interventional Radiology thrombectomy on ___ with venous stent placement and received dialysis afterward. Per renal, there was no need for systemic anticoagulation for purposes of unclotting graft. No recommendations were made by ___ regarding stent prior to discharge. However, after discharge, ___ contacted evening covering team to inform them that pt should be given a plavix load of 300mg and started on plavix 75mg daily along with aspirin 81mg daily for stent. Attempts were made by covering team to contact pt overnight but were unsuccessful. Primary team then contacted pt the morning after discharge to inform him of the change in plan and the Rx was called into his pharmacy, which he received and verified that he would take. See OMR note for additional details. Pt should follow up with transplant surgery for recs on long-term mgmt of graft. Consider hypercoagulable workup as outpatient. # ESRD (___). Was not uremic, K stable; did not require urgent dialysis. Continued Cinacalcet 30 mg. Pt reports being on calcium acetate for hyperphosphatemia. # Vomiting: On day prior to discharge, patient had nonbloody nonbilious emesis x2. Given patient had no bowel sounds and last BM was 1 day prior to admission, presumed to have ileus from percocet with possible contribution from mild uremia. Started on standing senna and colace and sent for dialysis. #Anemia. Known anemia related to ESRD, Hct 9.8 on admission (improved from discharge of 9.1 on ___. Continued EPO with dialysis. # Hypertension. Continued home medications

summary: Ms. ___ was transferred to ___ in the early morning on ___ after presenting to an OSH with severe headache. Head CT was negative for hemorrhage, and LP was performed for further evaluation, and results were inconclusive; from OSH records, only 1 CSF tube was resulted ___ RBC, no mention was made of xanthrochromia. On arrival to ___ was performed and unfortunately was suboptimal due to timing of contrast bolus. A repeat LP was performed, with elevated RBC across all tubes and trace xanthrochromia. She was admitted to the ICU for close neurological monitoring and further workup of subarachnoid hemorrhage. She proceeded to diagnostic angiogram on the afternoon of ___ without any evidence of intracerebral aneurysm. Given this information, xanthrochromia present in second LP likely secondary to traumatic tap at previous institution. Keppra and Nimodipine were discontinued. She remained neurologically intact throughout hospitalization, and was transferred to the floor in stable condition. Her headache improved and she will follow-up with Neurology as an outpatient. She was discharged home in stable condition on ___.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to the gynecology service after your procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below. General instructions: * Take your medications as prescribed. * Do not drive while taking narcotics. * Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to prevent constipation. * Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol. * Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs. * No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment. * Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 4 weeks. * No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks. * You may eat a regular diet. * You may walk up and down stairs. Call your doctor for: * fever > 100.4F * severe abdominal pain * difficulty urinating * vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr * abnormal vaginal discharge * redness or drainage from incision * nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food or your medication To reach medical records to get the records from this hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
summary: On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after undergoing Anterior Repair with Mesh, Sacrospinous Ligament Suspension, Perineorraphy and Cystoscopy for vaginal vault prolapse. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately post-op, her pain was controlled with IV Dilaudid/Toradol. Her blood pressures were controlled with her home medications. On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate and her Foley was removed with a voiding trial, the results of which are as follows: 1. Instilled 300 mL, voided 250 mL with 102 mL residual. 2. Instilled 300 mL, voided 250 mL with 168 mL residual. Her diet was advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to PO oxycodone/ibuprofen/acetaminophen/flexeril. By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to ___ on ___ for an elective left total knee replacement. Pre-operatively, she was consented, prepped, and brought to the operating room. Intra-operatively, she was closely monitored and remained hemodynamically stable. She tolerated the procedure well without any complication. Post-operatively, she was transferred to the PACU and floor for further recovery. On the floor,she remained hemodynamically stable with her pain was controlled. She progressed with physical therapy to improve her strength and mobility. She was discharged in stable condition.

J point and ST segment elevation in leads V2-V3 with lateral T wave abnormalities. Since the previous tracing of ___ ST-T wave abnormalities are new. Clinical correlation is suggested. Consider anterior ST segment elevation myocardial infarction. ___ ECHO: The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal
summary: ___ year old female with PAF not on coumadin due to prior GIB, CAD with previously normal MIBI and EF in past, DM, presented to PCP with EKG concerning for acute infarct and transferred to the ___, where patient ruled out for MI by CE but had an ECHO demonstrating left ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal inferior and infero-lateral akinesis and mid to distal septal, anterior and apical akinesis. Paroxysmal A fib was noted throughout her stay. Her course in brief is described below: # R/O MI: Cardiac enzymes revealed a mildly elevated troponin (0.05-0.08) but normal CKs. ECG showed isolated STE in V2 but was otherwise unremarkable. She had an ECHO performed this admission which showed moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal inferior and infero-lateral akinesis and mid to distal septal, anterior and apical akinesis with EF 35-40%. We have no prior ECHOs in our system for comparison ( prior normal ECHO). She was in and out of AF during her hospitalization with HRs ___. During her admission, she had one episode of SOB in the setting of hypertension (170s-190s/110s-140s). She was treated with IV metoprolol, SL NTG, and IV lasix. Her metoprolol was uptitrated to 50 mg TID (from 25 mg TID) and she was started on 10 mg of lisinopril and Imdur 30 mg daily. Her HRs improved to the ___ and BPs improved to 110s-130s/70s-80s. Patient was thereafter asymptomatic. She was discharged with home ___ and close follow-up. ASA, metoprolol and ACE-I continued at discharge. Ultimately the patient was discharged with the following recommendations regarding medication changes: 1) We have INCREASED your Metoprolol Tartate from 25mg TID to 50mg TID 2) We have INCREASED your Aspirin from 81mg to 325mg 3) We STARTED Imdur 30mg QD 4) Because you have hypertension, we have STARTED Lisinopril 10mg Daily

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> ___ <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Intubation/Extubation <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ M w PMHx of HTN, HLD, and recent aortic valve replacement and mitral valve repair ___ at ___ on coumadin who presented to ___ around ___ with right sided weakness. He was transferred to ___ after ___ showed larged L BG bleed with extensive IVE. Mr. ___ wife accompanies him at the bedside and provides the below history. Per her report, Mr. ___ was in his usual state of health on ___. He went to physical therapy from ___ and came home at 6PM. Per his wife and family, he had no deficits whatsoever. At around 9PM, as the family was sitting and watching television, Mr. ___ began to complain of weakness in his right hand. His daughter promptly called ___. Before EMS arrived, however, the weakness worsened and he slumped over towards his right side in his seat. His wife states that he was awake and alert throughout this. They sat him back up, but he was unable to speak to them. EMS arrived shortly thereafter. Per report, Mr. ___ has some vomiting en route to ___. When he arrived there at 2200, his VS were as follow: BP194/129 HR65 RR22 Sat99%RA. INR was 1.9 He was given IV labetolol 40mg, IV vitamin K 10mg, and 1U FFP. A ___ was performed showing: 6x4x4.5cm IPH centered in L BG and thalamus. There is continuation of the hemorrhage into bilateral lateral ventricles (L>>R), and nearly filling the third and fourth ventricles. Midline shift of up to 8-9mm. Per report, at around ___ Mr. ___ became increasingly lethargic, diaphoretic, vomited, and was unable to follow commands. He was intubated at ___ prior to transfer to ___ ED for further evaluation. During the medflight, EMS noted him to have an irregular shaped left pupil and started 3% saline (recieved 200cc). On arrival, Mr. ___ was noted to have asymmetric pupils (L>>R) with poor reactivity. A nicardipine drip was started to maintain sBP<140. Mannitol 75g IV was also bolused due to concern for herniation. FFP and K-centra were given to correct INR. A repeat NCHCT was performed at 0030 showing apparent interval increase in the size of Mr. ___ hemorrhage causing increasing midline shift with concern for subfalcine herniation and entrapment of the horns of lateral ventricle. Neurosurgery was also consulted for possible surgical managment. After discussion with attending on service, who reviewed the relevant images, surgical intervention was felt to be futile due to the extent of Mr. ___ injury. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - HTN - HLD - mitral valve repair (___) - aortic valve replacement (___) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> NC <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Exam: VS afebrile HR65 BP143/87 Sat100vent GEN - intubated, no spontaneous movements observed HEENT - NC/AT, MMM NECK - supple, no meningismus CV - NSR RESP - intubated ABD - soft, NT, ND NEUROLOGICAL EXAMINATION (off propofol x4min) MS - does not wake to voice or deep nox, no spontaneous eye opening or other movements CN - R pupil is 2mm and NR, L pupil is ovoid (8x5mm, non-surgical per wife) and NR; weak corneals B/L; vestibulo-ocular reflex is not intact; cough SENSORIMOTOR - no movement to nox in BUEs; RLE w weak triple flexion to nox (R great toe extension); LLE w L toe flexion to nox, some weak wiggling of other toes REFLEXES - 2s in BUEs, 2s at patella, 1 at ankles B/L, toes are mute bilaterally <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ CT Head 1. Large intraparenchymal hemorrhage centered in the left basal ganglia and thalamus measuring 7.1 cm causes mass effect, shift of the midline structures to the right, subfalcine herniation and downward herniation. 2. Extensive interventricular hemorrhage with enlargement of the frontal and occipital horns of the right lateral ventricle raises concern for entrapment. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> - carvedilol 25mg BID - warfarin 2.5mg MWFSaSun, 3mg TTh - atorvastatin 40mg qD - ASA 81mg qD - lisinopril 40mg qD <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> None <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Expired <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Left basal ganglia intraparenchymal hemorrhage with intraventricular extension, midline shift, cerebral edema, and uncal herniation <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Expired <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> None
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ M w PMHx of HTN, HLD, and recent aortic valve replacement and mitral valve repair ___ at ___ on coumadin who presented to OSH with a large L BG IPH with significant extension into the thalamus and left frontal/parietal lobes and intraventricular extension. He was intubated and transferred to ___ for further management, and his clinical exam deteriorated during transfer. Subsequent imaging on arrival to ___ showed worsened hemorrhage, worsened edema, and worsened midline shift with subfalcine and bilateral uncal herniation. He was initially treated with mannitol for cerebral edema, nicardipine for elevated SBP>140, and propofol/fentanyl for sedation and pain. Initial family discussion established that the patient was DNR. Further discussion with the family regarding the nature of the neurological injury and poor prognosis for good functional recovery resulted in the decision to focus on comfort care. The patient was terminally extubated and died shortly thereafter.

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F with NICMP with prior LVEF 25% with recovery on neurohormonal blockade to 50%, poorly controlled HTN and type II diabetes, hemorrhagic CVA from severe systolic hypertension ___, fluctuating EF along last year, transferred for further evaluation given CHF and concern for amyloid on echo. #Acute on Chronic systolic heart failure, EF now 55%: The patient presented volume overloaded on exam, unclear trigger but with pulmonary edema, BNP elevated, s/p diuresis at outside hospital. This may be in the setting of gastroenteritis as well as medication non-adherence. The patient was diuresed to euvolemia with a Lasix drip and she was discharged on Torsemide 20 and 40 on alternating days. She had a right-sided thoracentesis with 500cc of transudative fluid which was negative on cytology for malignancy. Her hydralazine was increased to 75 TID. She had a cardiac MRI that showed low-normal global systolic function without evidence of cardiac amyloid, iron deposition, or late gadolinium enhancement. She was found to have a pericardial effusion but had no hemodynamic compromise. She should follow-up with cardiology for management of CHF with adjustment of diuresis as well as resistant hypertension. The patient remained hypoxic despite diuresis and thoracentesis and she was discharged with home O2 at 2 LPM via nasal cannula. #Lower extremity asymmetry: The patient presented with asymmetric lower extremity edema, dyspnea, and intermittent hypoxia. She had a lower extremity ultrasound without evidence of DVT. #Nausea/Diarrhea: Initially appearted to be most likely viral gastroenteritis, has had healthcare exposure, non-toxic, no reported melena/hematochezia, stable WBC. ALT slightly elevated along with alkaline phosphatase, likely from hepatic congestion. This downtrended during hospitalization. C. diff was negative. Her diarrhea resolved but she continued to have intermittent nausea, especially with position changes. She consistently declined anti-emetics. She should follow-up in

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Convulsion. <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed man presenting with Convulsion on a background of melanoma, hypertension. Went to bed 9: 30 after about five beers. He typically drinks a little less, but was happy to finish his large set of orders for graduation ___ shirts (his home business). Atypically, he woke spontaneously at 3 AM. He felt wide awake, and therefore exrecised for a while before returning to sleep, then waking at 7 AM - late for him. He felt in his usual state of health. He ate breakfast and had coffee - he was planning to make a trip to shop and get supplies for his ___ work. He was getting ready to go out at about 9: 30 AM. He remembers going into the bathroom to clean his teeth. He remembers finishing cleaning his teeth. His wife was in an adjacent room. She heard a series of bangs - the noises of other things falling - perhaps three sounds. His wife was sitting at her desk and walked around the corner to look and saw him on the floor in the hall. He had hit the chest and items had fallen off of this. Her impression was that he had collided with this while falling. He was 'dramatically convulsing' on the floor, arms and legs were moving. He had bruises and an injury to his external mouth with blood - she thinks that the blood was clearly coming from the external injury that must have been sustained with his fall. His body was over the carpeted floor and his head was over the non-carpeted floor. She called ___ while continuing to walk him convulse. The ambulance came in a few minutes - she cannot be more accurate. She thinks that she was on the phone for a minute with 911. They told her to roll him on to his left side. His eyes were open, but it was as if he wasn't there. Convulsive movements were waning and gone by the time EMS arrived. EMS was at his side 9: 52, estimating during of seizure at ___ mins. See below for prior episodes of mutism/confusion/inappropriate laughter. One in ___, another 6 months ago. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Melanoma removed ___ years ago - Basal cell carcinoma, checked every 6 months, ___' surgery - Hypertension - Osteoarthritis - Two spell with confusion, last six months ago, mild, lasted 30 minutes - patient thought funny, did not speak, denies feeling ill, odd taste/smell, no perceptual disturbance. Prior event in ___ (see by Dr. ___: When he got back [from a 2.5 mile run, short for him], one of his employees talked with him. From that conversation it appeared that he did not remember that he worked with her earlier that morning and he had forgotten that he had gone for a run just minutes ago. The duration is unclear. - Prostate cancer <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother - heart problem and stroke in ___. Father - does not know. Siblings - half sister has MS, one brother died as infant - unknown, another at ___ years - rheumatic fever. <PHYSICAL EXAM> At admission: Vitals: Afebrile; 80 BPM; 148/p mmHg; 20 breaths General Appearance: Comfortable, no apparent distress. HEENT: NC, OP clear, MMM. Neck: Supple. No bruits. Normal ROM. Lungs: CTA bilaterally. Normal respiratory pattern. Cardiac: Regular. Normal S1/S2. No M/R/G. Abdominal: Soft, NT, BS. Extremities: No edema, warm, normal capillary refill. Peripheral pulses normal. Skin: Bruises to backs of hands, no bruising/injury to head, left lateral knee with abrasions, left arm abrasions. Neurologic Examination: Mental status: Level of Arousal: Awake. Normal level of arousal and alertness. Attentiveness: Trace inattentive: Able to recite MOYBW with one mistake and registration of items to remember ___. Language: Normal fluency, comprehension, repetition, naming. No paraphasic errors. Orientation: Oriented to name, BI, day/date/month/year, context of presentation. Memory: Recall good for recent and remote events. ___ at 5 mins. Knowledge: Appropriate fund of knowledge - vocabulary and recent events. Praxis: No apraxia/dyspraxia - can mime common tasks. Proverbial Understanding: Abstract
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old right handed man with a single generalized convulsive seizure without aura. Two episodes of confusion in the past are poorly described and not clearly seizure. His neurological is normal. MR head is unrevealing. Routine EEG was planned as an inpatient, however the patient feels strongly that he wants to leave the hospital. We encouraged him to stay for routine EEG as it is most sensitive when performed within 24 hours, but he decided against this. We do not think he needs to be treated with a seizure medication at this moment, but should have a routine EEG; maintain adequate sleep; and cut back on alcohol to no more than 2 drinks / day to minimize risk. The patient reports that he and his wife have been discussing that he should cut down on alcohol intake. He was instructed on MA driving law and knows he cannot drive for 6 months. He no longer flies, so this is not an issue. General seizure precautions were also advised. He was instructed to call for follow up in neurology clinic after discharge as well as the EEG outpatient office for outpatient scheduling. Additionally, given his CXR showed 2 small nonspecific nodulules, it should be either repeated or compared to previous exams. This will be communicated to his PCP.

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with a PMH notable for recent ICU admission with thyroid storm, right hemiparesis secondary to CVA, CAD s/p PCI, and chronic lymphedema, who presented from her nursing care facility with continued fevers and tachycardia likely secondary to thyroid storm. #Fever; thyroid storm: Most likely ___ thyroid storm given improvement w/ treatment of hyperthyroidism and not on antibiotics. DDx otherwise included superimposed infection, but no localizing signs of infection, no left shift or leukocytosis. CT chest/abdomen/pelvis was deferred since contrast should be avoided in setting of thyroid storm. Galactomannan was negative and beta-d-glucan was pending at time of discharge. Urine and blood cultures were negative/no growth to date. DVT was considered and ultrasound revealed L axillary DVT encasing mid-line (discussed below). Initial TFTs were T4 6.7, T3 273, free T4 2.2 and TSH <0.01. Endocrine was consulted and goal T3 is under 80. Treated with radioiodine stopped ___, methimazole 20 BID, and hydrocortisone taper (completed on ___. Fevers resolved with treatment of hyperthyroidism and TFTs improved to T3 110, FT4 1.5, T4 5.2 on ___. ___ Endocrine will continue to follow thyroid levels and make adjustments to doses while she is in rehab. #Tachycardia/Afib/flutter: During admission, flipping between aflutter and sinus tachycardia. On last admission, noted to have intermittent a-fib with RVR managed w/ IV metop. Arrived to ___ in a-fib/flutter, likely related to hyperthyroid state. Soon went into RVR responded to 5 mg IV metop; not anticoagulated and PE is on differential; CHADS is also elevated. Initially attempted esmolol, but blood pressure did not tolerate. Therefore, loaded with digoxin and started on propranolol with good response. Was started on anticoagulation for DVT below. Heart

No peripheral edema, wearing compression hose. No swelling, erythema, or lesion on posterior left knee or left thigh. Tender to palpation over left thigh posteriorly, non tender behind left knee. summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ female with no PMH, with a number of subacute symptoms including non-bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, heartburn, left leg pain after an insect bite on her left leg, who was found to have new anemia (which is unlikely to be related to her other complaints), likely ___ dapsone use. ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: # Hemolytic anemia: Per hematology, this may be secondary to Dapsone, as smear showed diffuse bite cells and also Heinz bodies, concerning for oxidative damage. Had negative G6PD testing prior to starting Dapsone, but can cause hemolysis even without G6PD. Coomb's testing was negative. There were other considerations for etiology especially given recent insect bite, including Lyme, anaplasma, and G6PD, which were pending on discharge. Since her hemoglobin improved to 10.4 on day of discharge, decision was made to hold her dapsone and discharge home with plan for heme follow up. #Latent Tb: recent positive quant gold. Saw Dr. ___ in ___ clinic on ___, he wants to review her outside hospital data prior to initiating latent TB treatment. CXR this admission with no evidence of old or new TB. # Abdominal cramping/Diarrhea: Unclear etiology. She's been afebrile. Denies hematochezia or melena. No recent travel. No recent antibiotics or hospitalization that would increase risk for C. difficile. No diarrhea while admitted. She requested that she see a GI doctor as an outpatient to discuss ongoing abdominal pain (non-concerning, likely functional). # Heartburn: Apparently new over past 1 week. Not had nausea/vomiting. Recommended OTC zantac # Left leg pain/insect bite: No evidence of rash in popliteal area or on posterior thigh. She isn't having pain behind her knee anymore, but left thigh pain. Follow up

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ - Cardiac catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with a significant cardiac history notable for CAD status post multiple stents (seven in total) and CABG (___), COPD, HLD, type II DM, anxiety, GERD, and recent pneumonia diagnosis for which he is currently on antibiotics, who initially presented to Urgent Care on ___ with chest pain, subsequently referred to ___ where he was found to have a troponin elevation, concerning for NSTEMI, now transferred to ___ for coronary angiogram given complex anatomy. Patient was recently diagnosed with PNA, for which he is currently taking Augmentin and doxycycline. Continued to have shortness of breath associated with this, but had not worsened since starting antibiotics. However, this morning when he was preparing for work he developed substernal chest pain, burning in nature, radiating to his back and bilateral arms, which persisted and worsened with minimal exertion. Took two sublingual nitro with minimal improvement in pain, prompting presentation to Urgent Care. Given significant cardiac history, patient was referred to ___ for further evaluation. While there his chest pain spontaneously resolved, ECG did not demonstrate any ischemic changes, and troponin I was elevated at 1.6, consistent with NSTEMI, most concerning for type I NSTEMI. Patient was transferred to ___ for coronary angiogram given complex anatomy. Received 243mg of aspirin and enoxaparin 80mg prior to transfer. With regards to his cardiac history, patient has significant coronary artery disease, and has undergone multiple stents and five vessel CABG in the past. Last admitted in ___, when he presented to ___ with chest pain, radiating to neck and back, and associated diaphoresis, shortness of breath, and nausea. This occurred in the setting of missing ten days of ticagrelor. Troponin peaked at 3.23. Coronary angiogram at ___ revealed three vessel disease, stable chronic total occlusion of grafted diagonal, proximal LCx, and distal RCA, patent SVG-apical LAD supplying just the apex with collaterals filling distal diagonals, with severe restenosis of the apical LAD stent. It also showed a patent LIMA and late stent thrombosis of LAD stent with long bulky thrombotic occlusion of the old ostial stent and also of a recently stented SVG-diagonal with poor outflow of the recent mid graft stent with significant clot burden. Medically managed with prasugrel, aspirin and warfarin. Imdur was added for symptomatic management and metoprolol was continued (at reduced dose given soft BPs). Warfarin was discontinued in ___ given issues with supratherapeutic INRs (per patient), but all other medications were continued and titrated to achieve better symptom control. However, patient has continued to have intermittent episodes of shortness of breath and chest pain, especially when climbing stairs, which resolve with SL nitro. Upon arrival to the floor, patient repeats the above story. Currently he is chest pain free. Denies shortness of breath, palpitations, light-headedness, dizziness, orthopnea, PND, or lower extremity edema. Understands he will likely not undergo coronary angiogram until ___. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - CAD status post multiple PCIs (7 stents) and five vessel CABG - HLD - HTN - Type II DM - COPD - GERD - Anxiety <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Brother died secondary to brain aneurysm. Father died aged ___, and ha three MIs during his life. Mother with MI later in life. Sister with history of stroke. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAMINATION --= VS: Temp 97.9 BP 120/78 HR 90 RR 18 SaO2 94% RA GENERAL: sitting comfortably in bed, no distress HEENT: AT/NC, no conjunctival pallor, anicteric sclera, MMM NECK: supple, non-tender, JVP not elevated CV: RRR, S1 and S2 normal, no murmurs/rubs/gallops RESP: CTAB, no wheezes/crackles ___: soft, non-tender, no distention, BS normoactive EXTREMITIES: warm, well perfused, no lower extremity edema NEURO: A/O x3, otherwise grossly normal DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAMINATION -- 24 HR Data (last updated ___  1130) Temp: 97.9 (Tm 98.7), BP: 120/78 (107-125/67-79), HR: 78 (69-83), RR: 18 (___), O2 sat: 93% (93-95), O2 delivery: RA, Wt: 175.04 lb/79.4 kg Fluid Balance (last updated ___  545) Last 8 hours Total cumulative -200ml IN: Total 0ml OUT: Total 200ml, Urine Amt 200ml Last 24 hours Total cumulative 494ml IN: Total 1224ml, PO Amt 880ml, IV Amt Infused 344ml OUT: Total 730ml, Urine Amt 730ml GENERAL: sitting comfortably in bed, no distress HEENT: AT/NC, no conjunctival pallor, anicteric sclera, MMM NECK: supple, non-tender, JVP not elevated CV: RRR, S1 and S2 normal, no
summary: TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ==================== [] Consider increasing metformin to 1000mg BID, and adding jardiance for improved diabetes control for Hb A1c of 8%. [] Consider adding ezetimibe for improved cholesterol management [] Patient should follow-up with ___ Cardiology for complex CAD [] Uptitrate lisinopril as tolerated SUMMARY STATEMENT ================= ___ with a significant cardiac history notable for CAD status post multiple stents (seven in total, last stent to SVG-D1 restenosis ___ and CABG (___), COPD, HLD, type II ___ A1c 8.0%), anxiety, GERD, and recent pneumoniadiagnosis for which he is currently on antibiotics, who initially presented to Urgent Care on ___ with chest pain, subsequently referred to ___ where he was found to have a troponin elevation, concerning for NSTEMI. He underwent coronary angiography, which showed triple vessel disease. No intervention was performed. The patient was medically optimized, and discharged. He should follow-up at ___ Cardiology. ==================== ACUTE/ACTIVE ISSUES: ==================== # NSTEMI Patient had significant coronary artery disease with most recent cath in ___ demonstrating a long tail of thrombus in the stented proximal SVG graft. His warfarin was stopped in ___ due to difficulty supratherapeutic INR (per report.) He underwent coronary angiogram, which showed three vessel coronary artery disease. Mid-LAD occlusion, supplied distally by patent LIMA and patent SVG to distal LAD. Anomalous circumflex arising from right cusp with moderate ostial disease. Interrogated with FFR and found to be NOT flow-limiting (nadir FFR 0.90.) Patent RCA to distal segment with 100% occlusion with right-right collaterals CTO of SVG-Diagonal. No intervention was performed. TTE showed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global biventricular systolic function. No valvular pathology or pathologic flow identified. The patient's metoprolol was uptitrated to metoprolol succinate

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Right third digit injury <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ORIF Right ___ digit middle phalanx Nerve autograft from index finger to middle finger Revision amputation of ring finger Adjacent tissue transfer ring finger <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a R handed ___ with r middle and ring finger trauma via lawn mower. He has a history of myasthenia ___. At 2 ___ he was cleaning him lawnmower, when he tried to clear debris, and the blade impacted his long and ring finger. He presented to ___ emergency department where he received Ancef, tetanus. X-ray demonstrated multiple fractures dislocations. He had digital blocks performed, and at the time of arrival to our emergency department his pain was well-controlled. Last meal was 1 ___. He does smoke. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> denies <FAMILY HISTORY> non contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> <PHYSICAL EXAM> Right upper extremity: He has moderate swelling through the digits, but no erythema or signs of infection. With the exception of a small area on the volar aspect of the revision amp, there are no signs of skin breakdown. And this 1 small area there appears to be superficial necrosis, but again no signs of infection or other complication. There are 2 K wires protruding from the long finger, and there are no pin site complications. <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> INSTRUCTIONS AFTER HAND SURGERY: - You were in the hospital for hand surgery. It is normal to feel tired or washed out after surgery, and this feeling should improve over the first few days to week. - Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times. ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING: - NWB RUE MEDICATIONS: 1) Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is an over the counter medication. 2) Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean off this medication in 1 week or sooner. This is an example on how to wean down: Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day. Then continue with Tylenol for pain. 3) Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic medication. 4) Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 5) Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy. 6) Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers. 7) Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians at discharge. 8) Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed to stop by your surgeon. ANTIBIOTICS: - Please take Keflex for 5 days WOUND CARE: - You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks. - Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out at your 2-week follow up appointment. - Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape. - Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless otherwise instructed. - Do NOT get splint wet. DANGER SIGNS: Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the emergency department if you experience any of the following: - Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications - Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning changes in your incision - Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation - Fever > 101.4 - Shaking chills - Chest pain - Shortness of breath - Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, medications down - Any other medical concerns

summary: On ___, Mr. ___ was admitted to ___ with 1 week of right foot rest pain. On ___ he was started on a heparin drip, due to his elevated creatinine CT angiogram was deferred to avoid contrast load. On ___, Patient underwent arterial duplex and ABI's in the vascular lab. Testing revealed decreased bilateral ABI's and no posterior tibial or dossalis pedis waveforms in the R ankle suggestive of occlusion. Vein mapping was also performed finding: Patent right great saphenous vein and small saphenous vein with measurements as above. Left great saphenous vein is not visualized. Left small saphenous vein with distal thrombus. On ___, Patient underwent diagnostic angiogram of the right lower extremity showing right common femoral artery and external iliac occlusion. In anticipation of a left to right femoral bypass his heparin drip was continued. His PTTs remained in the therapeutic range overnight. ___ was uneventful. Right femoral bypass procedure had to be cancelled due to scheduling issues. ___ also uneventful. Yesterday we had a conversation with the pt explaining possibility of d/c home and have him return for his procedure on RLE sometime next week. Pt. decided to stay in house as he felt that this way he could get procedure performed earlier. We explained that due to scheduling issues we cannot guarantee a time on a specific day this week. On ___, the patient was having loose stools. C.diff ordered. Patient wants to either have surgery as soon as possible or to go home. Will have surgery with Dr. ___ on ___ was having stable PTTs on heparin gtt. Ischemic pain stable. On ___, patient went to OR for right iliac artery angiogram with right iliac artery stent placement. He recovered well, was medically cleared, and discharged home on ___.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). partial weight bearing R foot <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ ___. You were admitted to the hospital after a peripheral angiogram. To do the test, a small puncture was made in one of your arteries. The puncture site heals on its own: there are no stitches to remove. You tolerated the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the hospital. Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful recovery. Peripheral Angiography Puncture Site Care For one week: -Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot tub. -Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around the puncture site. -Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. -Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the puncture site. You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the procedure. You may leave the bandage off. You may have a small bruise around the puncture site. This is normal and will go away in one-two weeks. Activity For the first 48 hours: -Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure For the first week: -Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 pounds -Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles. Take care not to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, or moving your bowels. After one week: -You may go back to all your regular activities, including sexual activity. We suggest you begin your exercise program at half of your usual routine for the first few days. You may then gradually work back to your full routine. Medications: Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all the medicine you should take at home. If a medication that you normally take is not on
summary: Ms ___ was admitted from rehab for her planned RLE angiogram. Please see the operative note for details. Postprocedurally, she underwent HD and also was evaluated by orthopedic surgery for her chronic knee pain and evaluation of the ankle fracture. She was noted to have degenerative changes of the knee without evidence of fracture. She was kept flat for 4 hours postoperatively and foley was dc'ed POD0 at midnight. On POD1, she was out of bed, tolerating a diet, voiding, and her distal pulses were at baseline with no evidence of hematoma at her groin puncture site.
