summary: ___ yo F with a history of chronic back pain, found today with altered mental status, hypotension, acute renal failure, and hyponatremia. 1. Altered mental status: Anion gap of 17 on admission. Concern for Intoxication vs. CNS process. Patient has positive tox screen for methadone and tricyclics. Takes tricyclics at home and this dose has recently been increased. Overdose would result in tachycardia, hypotension, and urinary retention, which she has demonstrated. CT head negative. Neuro exam non focal. No ketonuria. Patient received supportive care with IV fluids and supplemental O2. Her outpatient medications were all held. Overnight patient was restarted on a lower dose of MS contin. She was not discharged with any prescriptions for her outpatient medications. She was instructed to stop her amitryptilline and trazadone until speaking with her outpatient psychiatrist. Psychiatry evaluated her and agreed that her medications should be held and she should follow up with her outpatient psychiatrist. . 2. Hypotension: Concerned for hypovolemia vs. tricyclic ingestion vs. methadone ingestion. Afebrile. No focal signs of infection concerning for septic physiology. Culture data was negative to date. Hypotension resolved overnight with IV fluids. -please follow up on blood cultures and viral cultures that were pending on discharge . . . 3. Acute renal failure: Baseline Cr 0.6. Cr 3.9 on admission. Renal was consulted on admission. Likely prerenal given history of poor po intake over prior week. However, patient had 1L retained urine in ED, more concerning for ingestion. Creatinine was trending down to 1.1 on discharge. Renal US negative for hydronephrosis. . 4. Hyponatremia: Na 132. Hypovolemia given poor po intake and acute renal failure. This resolved overnight with IV fluids. . 5. Urinary retention: Likely secondary to ingestion. Likely ingestion given overall cinical picture and positive tox screen for tricyclics and methadone. Foley was placed in the ED. This was discontinued 6 hours prior to discharge and

summary: ___ with hx of diastolic CHF, CAD s/p CABG, AFib not on coumadin (due to recurrent falls), CKD (baseline Cr 1.4-1.7), right renal mass (concerning for RCC), and total right hip replacement who presented with a mechanical fall at home in the setting of increased ___ edema and pulmonary edema concerning for acute on chronic CHF exacerbation. CT-head on admission showed no acute intracranial abnormalities and hip xrays showed no fracturs. Pt was diuresed with IV lasix with removal of a significant amount of excess fluid and discharged to rehab on a maintenance dose of oral torsemide. #Acute on chronic diastolic CHF Pt presented in volume overload and was diuresed with IV lasix during the course of his admission. The aggressiveness with which he was diuresed was limited by his elevated Cr in the setting of CKD. His Cr level was maintained within the upper range of his known baseline. Pt was discharged on 20mg oral torsemide daily as a maintenance diuretic to be titrated per outpatient follow-up. #Ileus Pt experienced acute onset nausea and emesis upon admission. A KUB showed bowel gas patterns consistent with ileus. He was treated with ofran prn and a nasogastric tube was placed for decompression. His symptoms improved overnight and a repeat KUB showed resolution of his ileus. NGT was removed and he did not have a recurrence of ileus. #Hyponatremia Pt presented with a Na of 125 likely secondary to hypervolemia and free water excess. He may have been symptomatic with some word-finding difficulty that was noticed. With ongoing diuresis during his admission, his Na level increased in response to diuresis. His mental status and speech improved to baseline per daughter's assessment. His Na on discharge had improved to 134. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== -Pt's dry weight on discharge is 82.8kg (182lbs). Please continue to monitor his weight daily and adjust torsemide dose as necessary. -Pt's previous maintenance oral

Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO BID Duration: 3 Days RX *sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim [Bactrim] 400 mg-80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*6 Tablet Refills: *0 7. TraMADol 25 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Moderate Hold for sedation or drowsiness. RX *tramadol 50 mg 0.5 (One half) tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp #*15 Tablet Refills: *0 8. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 500 mg PO BID <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Steroid Secreting Microadenoma. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Transphenoidal Excision of Tumor: - Take your pain ___ as prescribed. - Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, or excessive bending. - Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain ___ can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while taking narcotic pain medication. - Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and Ibuprofen etc. - Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit. - Continue Sinus Precautions for an additional two weeks. This means, no use of straws, forceful blowing of your nose, or use of your incentive spirometer. - If you have been discharged on Hydrocortisone, take it daily as prescribed. - If you are required to take Hydrocortisone, an oral steroid, make sure you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, Protonix, or Pepcid), as this medication can cause stomach irritation. Hydrocortisone should also be taken with a glass of milk or with a meal. CALL YOUR DOCTOR IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE FOLLOWING: - New onset of tremors or seizures. - Any confusion or change in mental status. - Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities. - Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not relieved by pain medication. - Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, tenderness, or drainage. - It is normal for feel nasal fullness for a few days after surgery, but if you begin to experience drainage or salty taste at the back of your throat, that resembles a dripping sensation, or persistent, clear fluid that drains from your nose that was not present when you were sent home, please call. - Fever greater than or equal to 101 F. - If you notice your urine output to be increasing, and/or excessive, and you are unable to quench your thirst, please call your endocrinologist.
summary: #Pituitary Microadenoma Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o female who presented for elective endoscopic endonasal resection of pituitary microadenoma on ___. The procedure was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Please refer to the full operative report for further details. Post-operatively she recovered in the PACU and was then transferred to the ___ for continued close monitoring. On POD#1, ___, the patient underwent a post-operative MRI which showed expected post-operative changes. The patient's cortisol level was monitored closely post-operatively. On ___, the patient's cortisol level dropped as expected and the patient was started on Hydrocortisone twice a day, 20mg QAM and 10mg QPM. The nasal packing remained in place which was managed by otolaryngology and the patient remained on IV Ceftriaxone while it was in place. The packing was removed on ___ by ENT. On ___, the patient remained neurologically stable on examination. Her urine output stabilized. They foley catheter was discontinued. The ENT team removed the nasal packing. The patient was discussed with Dr. ___ it was determined she would be discharged to home on ___ with close follow-up with ENT, Neurosurgery, Endocrinology and her primary care physician. #UTI The patient was noted to have a positive urinalysis and was started on a three-day course of oral Bactrim upon discharge as she was receiving daily IV Ceftriaxone during her hospitalization while the nasal packing was in place. #Hematuria The patient was found to have hematuria on multiple urinalysis studies. This was discussed with ___ resident ___, MD who recommended follow-up with her PCP ___ 1 month for a repeat UA. It is believed the hematuria is secondary to irritation from the foley catheter. The patient will see her PCP ___ ___. The PCP office was contacted prior to discharge with request to order a repeat UA at the time of the appointment. #Diabetes The patient's glucose remained controlled on her home regimen throughout the hospitalization. She will

summary: ___ year old male with no known history and no recent contact with medical care, who was referred to the ED from his PCP's office for frequent falls. Imaging was concerning for pancreatic malignancy, s/p biopsy that returned as pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, WHO grade I. # Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, WHO Grade I # Transaminitis: Mr. ___ was recently admitted after being referred from the outpatient clinic for frequent falls and unsteady gait. Here, on initial work up for the fall, he was found to have transaminitis and RUQ revealed a concern for pancreatic malignancy with hepatic metastases. CT abd/pelvis confirmed a pancreatic neck mass. A GI consultation was performed and an endoscopic biopsy was obtained and returned as pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor, WHO grade I. The tumor cells are immunoreactive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, and Ki67 stains. Dr. ___ surgical oncology and Dr. ___ ___ ___ oncology evaluated the patient and the case was discussed extensively during tumor board to determine the best treatment approach. This lesion was considered unresectable by the surgeons and the most optimal ongoing management would be determined by ___ oncology in the outpatient setting. The transaminitis was likely due to metastatic liver lesions and have remained largely in the same range during the hospitalization. # Hypoglycemia: At the time of presentation, patient initially was hypoglycemic and there was a concern that this was possibly related to the pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor/insulinoma. However, his sugars have remained normal during the remainder of the hospitalization and the initial low was likely due to poor PO intake. We measured his insulin level and it was within normal range. # Psychiatric evaluation: During this hospitalization, patient strongly desired to go home and not attend rehab and was not able to demonstrate proper insight/judgment/capacity. We obtained a psychiatry consultation who further concluded that he lacked the capacity to leave AMA. However, ongoing discussions have been successful and

She denies fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. She notes a non productive cough but denies any chest pain or shortness of breath. She also notes difficulty with urination over the past several days but denies blood in her urine or frank dysuria. She states that approximately 1 week ago she developed pain and swelling in her R eye. She was seen by her eye doctor who prescribed moxifloxacin drops and bactitracin ointment. She states eye has not improved and is very painful. She does not remember getting anything into her eye but notes a foreign body sensation. Around the same time she developed unilateral swelling of her R ___. She reports the leg then returned to normal size after it leaked a large amount of yellow fluid. . In the ED, initial VS 98.3 F (36.8 C), Pulse: 90, RR: 14, BP: 128/67, O2Sat: 95 on room air. Patient had CXR which showed no pneumonia. Patient has UA notable for > 182 WBCs. She was noted to have swelling of her LLE with some associated weeping. ___ was negative for DVT. She was seen by optho who felt her eye exam was consistent with corneal abrasion. She was given vancomycin for possible cellulitis and ciprofloxin for a UTI and admitted to medicine for further management. . Currently, patient complains of pain in her right eye. She denies chest pain or shortness of breath and is resting comfortably in bed. . summary: PRIMARY REASON FOR ADMISSION ___ yo female with a history of afib, COPD, R ICA stenosis who presents with a ___ day history generalized weakness. Subsequently found to have a UTI. . ACTIVE ISSUES # UTI- Patient with UA significant for 182 WBC in addition to urinary symptoms. She was started on IV ciprofloxacin in the ED. On admission she was converted to oral cipro to complete a 3 day course. Preliminary urinary culture grew enterococcus. . # EKG changes- EKG notable for TWI in V4-V6 with associated ST segment depressions. ACS was unlikely as the patient is currently chest pain free. Trop and MB were negative. Repeat EKG was stable. . # Leg swelling- Patient notes history of unilateral leg edema with some clear discharge c/f past cellulitis vs abscess. ___ was negative for DVT. Exam was without signs or symptoms of active cellulitis. As above the patient was given IV vancomycin in the ED. This medication was not continued on admission. The patient afebrile with a normal WBC without any exam finding concerning for current cellulitis. . # Corneal abrasion- The patient was admitted with a erythematous irritated R eye. She was evaluated in the ED exam felt to be consistent with corneal abrasion/ulcer and concern for superimposed infection. She was continued on Vigamox drops and Bacitracin/Polymyxin B Sulfate ointment. She will follow-up with ophthalmology on ___. Pain was managed with PRN proparacaine drops. . STABLE ISSUES # Afib- patient has history of afib currently anticoagulated on pradaxa which was continued throughout her admission. Rate was well controlled on her home metoprolol. . # COPD- Her respiratory status was stable throughout admission. She was continued on her home advair. . # Hyperlipidemia- Patient was continued on her home atorvastatin . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - Full code - Blood cultures and final urine cultures were pending at the time of discharge - CXR shows unfolded and tortuous aorta with prominence

He denies any trauma to the left hand. He also reports bilateral knee pain with ambulation; there is no pain at rest. He has noted ascending rash on both arms and legs. He has also noted fatigue, myalgias, poor appetite. Of note, pt was on vacation last week and reports sexual activity (but not anal sex) with ___ male partners in the setting of taking poppers. Neuro: CNII-XII intact, ___ strength upper/lower extremities, gait deferred. MSK: Left palm diffusely erythematous and edematous with limited ROM at wrist. No evidence of trauma. Pulses intact. Skin: diffusely scattered variably sized blanching erythematous macules 0.5 mm to 1 mm, well-circumscribed, no surrounding excoriation or secondary change, extending from feet and hands up extremities, and DOES involve the right palm, no involvement of back, chest, face, groin. Left foot with palpable dark 1cm lesion at medial aspect of heel. No ___ lesions ___ nodes. Walking around attempting (with moderate success) to floss using his left hand. HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, EOMI Neck: Supple, JVP not elevated CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present GU: No foley Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2 pulses. Neuro: EOMI, face symmetric moves all extremities equally aside from distal left upper extremity. Range of motion in left wrist and fingers improved, can now touch thumb to fingers. Wrap is removed. Fingers and hand still notably swollen compared to right, mild erythema.
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ yoM with no significant PMH, who presents with a 2 day history of hand pain, polyarthralgias, body aches, and rash suspicious for tick-born illness or rheumatologic condition. # Polyarthralgias and rash: His presenting symptoms were suspicious for infection (Gonorrheae or vs tick born) vs rheumatalogic. RPR with prozone negative. Leukocytosis to 14 dramatically improved to 6 with antibiotics and CRP of 239 improved to 135, suggestive of an infectious source being adequately treated. At this point tick-born disease is favored and he was discharged with an emperic 14 day course of doxycycline (___) with plan for close follow up. Anaplasma titers pending at discharge. HIV antibody negative. # Left wrist and hand pain: Likely inflammatory secondary to primary inflammatory process, as suspcicion for cellulitis or septic joint was low. Hand surgery was consulted. His pulses were intact, no disproportionate pain with finger movement or other sign of compartment syndrome. Doxy per above. # Rash: Resolved. VV immune, MMR immune. He had a distal extremity rash on presentation which resolved within 12 hours. RPR with prozone negative. - CODE STATUS: FULL (confirmed) TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ================================ - NEW MEDS: Emperic Doxycycline 100mg PO BID for a total of 14 days (___) - STOPPED MEDS: None - follow up anaplasma send-out - consider rheumatologic work up - check LFTs - follow up urine gonorrhoeae and chlamydia test - follow up MMR and lyme serologies

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted for a scheduled pancreatic necrosectomy. Intra-operatively 17L of ascites was drained, 2.3L of crystalloid and 1L albumin were given. Of note, there was significant trouble placing a foley. We initially consulted Urology, however after approximately one hour of manipulation, we were able to pass a ___ Foley catheter gently into the urethra which was noted to have hypospadias and also a potential stricture. 3 large JP drains were placed in the pancreatic bed. Please see operative note for further details. He was transferred to the ICU post-op for hemodynamic monitoring. He was quickly transferred to the floor on POD2. His JP drains continued to drain large amounts of ascites along with necrotic pancreas. He was placed on aggressive IVF resuscitation with adequate urine output and no hemodynamic issues. His pain was well controlled with an epidural which was removed on POD3 without any issues. He was transitioned to oral pain medications. His foley was also removed and he voided successfully. His tube feeds were restarted on POD1, his NGT was removed on POD2 without any signs of nausea or vomiting. His TF were advanced to goal and he was started clear liquids without issues. He was advanced to a regular diet by POD3 and a JP amylase was obtained from drain # 3 on POD4 and amylase level was high (1254). On POD 5 patient was tolerating regular diet, but reported increased nausea. On POD 6, patient became oliguric and Foley catheter was placed for urine output monitoring, he vomited few times and NGT was placed. Patient developed diarrhea and TF was held. He was transferred in ICU secondary to hypotension, tachycardia and oliguria. Patient was started on Flagyl for possible C-diff. CTA abdomen was obtained and demonstrated decrease in pancreatic necrotic fluid collection, large ascites, and splenic vein thrombosis, but mesenteric venous phase was not performed. Patient's urine output and BP improved with hydration. TF was restarted

summary: Assesment: This is a ___ year-old male with a history of squamous cell carcinoma of lung and pneumonia who presents with syncopal episode. . Plan: # Syncope - Mr. ___ was monitored on tele with no events. His vital signs were orthostatic and this was felt to be the most likely cause of his syncope. Per his report, he was going to great effort to take good PO with fluids at home. He continued to take good PO and he was given IVF resuscitation with almost no improvement. He was polyuric but his urine lytes did not suggest DI. He was started on florinef 0.1mg qday on ___ after failing improvement with fluid resuscitation alone, and his florinef was then titrated up. His cortisol level did not suggest adrenal insufficiency and his TSH was WNL. Cardiology was consulted, who suggested ___ of Hearts monitor, which he was given upon discharge. An ECHO was obtained, which showed mild global decreased contractility of the LV with mildly depressed EF. Cardiology felt this could be due to recent stress/illness and did not initiate CHF management. He has follow-up with Dr. ___ cardiology. He should have a repeat ECHO as an outpatient. Leading theory for now is that recent illness may have left his vessels temporarily vasodilated. Alternatively, it was considered that he may have some autonomic dysfunction from chemotherapy. He may benefit from further titration of his florinef. . # Polyuria: likely from polydipsia given urine lytes inconsistent with DI. Other possibility includes prostate symptoms, although history not particularly consistent with prostate problems. Prostate exam shows mildly enlarged though symmetric prostate. No PSA in past. PSA WNL during this admission. I doubt that his slight enlargement was causing his polyuria, which was probably from increased PO. Suggest outpatient follow-up. . # Pneumonia - He was given levofloxacin 750mg, course completed on ___. . # upper respiratory

Gallbladder is distended probably due to fasting state. A few hepatic cysts are identified. Small calcification in the left lateral segments of the liver, as before. There is no biliary dilatation. The pancreas appears normal. The spleen is normal in size and appearance. Each adrenal is again mildly thickened. There is no evidence for stones or hydronephrosis involving either kidney. Renal cysts are identified in the left kidney that appear simple and benign. Nearly the whole stomach is in the chest. Short segment of the transverse colon also herniates into the chest without obstruction. This visualized small bowel is unremarkable. There is no ascites or lymphadenopathy. There are no suspicious bone lesions. Bones appear demineralized. Mild compression deformity of the L3 vertebral body appears unchanged. IMPRESSION: Chest is reported separately. No significant abnormality involving the abdomen. ------ ___ CT CHEST W/O CONTRAST ----- FINDINGS: Tracheostomy terminates shortly above the carina. Feeding tube terminates in a large hiatal hernia. Heart is mildly enlarged with mild coronary artery calcification. Patchy calcification is also found along the aortic valve. Thoracic aorta is normal in caliber and mildly calcified. Central pulmonary arteries are mildly calcified. There is no lymphadenopathy in the chest. There is no pericardial effusion. Trace pleural effusions are found bilaterally. This study shows a large hiatal hernia containing essentially the entire stomach with an air contrast level. The hernia appears somewhat less distended, although mostly full. The transverse colon enters and exits the hernia sac without obstruction, as before.
summary: ================= SUMMARY STATEMENT ================= Ms. ___ is a ___ ___ female with recently diagnosed late onset Alzheimer's disease and recent falls who presented with epigastric/Left upper quadrant pain and coffee-ground emesis. She underwent CT scan that was consistent with a gastric volvus with large hiatal hernia. She was treated for aspiration pneumonia and was intubated for an EGD showing the hernia and no significant other abnormalities. She was not considered a surgical candidate for her hernia. She was converted to DNR/DNI. Speech and swallow recommended the patient remain NPO based on multiple bedside swallow examinations. On ___ she had a video swallow study that showed no aspiration with pureed food and thin liquids. She was recommended to have a modified diet, frequent small meals, and to remain upright for at least 1 hour after eating due to risk of late aspiration with her hiatal hernia. =================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== [ ] Patient is at risk of aspiration and should have close supervision of all meals and should remain upright at 90 degrees for 60min after every meal due to risk of late aspiration [] will need ongoing discussion with family about goals of care however, PEG tube/J tube is not an options for her given her complicated anatomy [] Holding home donepezil 5mg daily, buspirone 10mg TId, quetiapine 50mg BID, and mirtazapine 15mg daily due to strict NPO status. New Medications -----> Lansoprazole 30mg daily -----> Acetaminophen 650mg q6hrs PRN pain Code Status: Full ============= ACTIVE ISSUES ============= #Aspiration Concern Patient presented with epigastric pain and was found to have a large hiatal hernia. She was also hypoxic and in respiratory distress and was treated for an aspiration pneumonia, after which time her respiratory status improved. She failed multiple bedside swallow examinations and was therefore recommended to be strict NPO given concern that her anatomy was leading to aspirations which ultimately cause her respiratory failure. She was maintained on maintenance fluids while

summary: Reason for Hospitalization: Unable to access fistula for hemodialysis . Active Conditions: Access for Hemodialysis -- On admission, LUE U/S indicated patency of the AV fistula, but HD was unsuccessful. The ___ service attempted ballooning of the fistula, but on HD#2 HD was still unsuccessful. He went to the OR for exploration of the fistula. A thick amount of dense scar tissue was noted between the skin and the fistula, which was dissected. Good flow was observed, but given the multiple unsuccessful attempts to obtain access for HD a L IJ tunnel line was placed. He successfully received partial hemodialysis that evening. On HD#3, it was felt that he could resume his normal HD schedule as an outpatient (next HD to be scheduled for ___ and he was discharged home with services. . Hyponatremia -- On admission, his sodium level was slightly lower than his baseline (129, baseline is in mid ___. After dialysis his Na corrected to 136. . # ESRD: He was evaluated and followed by both the renal dialysis service and transplant surgery service. He was continued on his home renal meds (darbepoietin, renvela) and received partial dialysis on ___. He was scheduled to resume his normal schedule of dialysis at an outpatient dialysis center. . Inactive Conditions: Anemia -- Hct on admission 28.2, appears to be consistent with his baseline, likely ___ renal failure. He was continued on his home dose darbepoietin. . # DM: FSBS with ISS. . # CAD: He was s/p CABGx5 in ___, did not experience any symptoms of cardiac ischemia during his stay. He was continued on his home statin and ASA. . # HTN: He was continued on his home doses of metoprolol, lisinopril, amlodipine, and his blood pressure remained stable. . # GERD: He was continued on his home dose pantoprazole. . Transition: On discharge, he was asked to resume

summary: Mr ___ was transfered from ___ with the above mentioned complaint. He was admitted to the ___ for close monitoring and in preparation for surgery. On ___ he went to the OR with orthopedic surgery and tolerated the procedure well. He was kept in the ICU postoperatively where he was persistently tachycardic. This was controlled with an increased dose of lopressor. A TLSO brace was ordered from NEOPS for stabilization of his lumbar spine fracture. On ___ he was transfused in total 3U PRBCs for a 4pt HCT drop and his HCTs were followed. He began to take some nutrition by mouth. Pain was controlled with IV dilaudid. He began to be intermittently disoriented and delirious. There were no focal neuro deficits. On ___ he received his TLSO brace and began to work with ___. He was seen by Geriatrics for his delirium and in addition they mentioned the benefit of beginning Fosamax therapy for osteoporosis. On ___ he was transfered to the floor where he continued to be intermittently disoriented and did in fact have some visual hallucinations which were noted by Geriatrics. He had a number of small bowel movements. On ___ he is being discharged to rehab with a TLSO brace and on lovenox 30mg SC bid for prophylaxis. He is instructed to follow-up with Neurosurgery, Orthopedic Surgery and with his PCP.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamides) / Novocain <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The Patient is an ___ year-old, ___ male with Coronary artery disease s/p CABG x 4 in ___, sick sinus syndrome, and metastatic melanoma on clinical trial with Temozolomide who presented ___ with history of two episodes of br___ chest pain over the last month. He denies any other symptoms, no Shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diaphoresis or palpitations. He had this sensation once before, which occured approximately one month ago. He states that he did not feel anginal pain during his MI several years ago and that he had a silent MI. . In addition, he also reports dyspnea on exertion with climbing more than three flights of stairs. He states that he first noticed this after he started chemotherapy. He also thinks this is worse with the weather changes. He denies pleuritic chest pain, palpitations, nausea with this and his dyspnea is releived with rest. He denies any increase in peripheral swelling or high salt in his diet. . Of note, his last echo was ___, (LVEF 50-55%). In ___ he underwent catheterization of his grafts which showed occluded SVG-Dm SVG-RI, and patent SVG-PDA, a BMS was placed in the proximal LAD. He recently had a thallium stress test one month ago which showed no anginal symptoms or objective ECG evidence of myocardial ischemia, and resting and stress perfusion images revealed a moderate fixed defect in the mid and basilar inferolateral wall. No reversibility was identified. . The patient went to see his PCP who is ___ cardiologist yesterday (Dr. ___, and told him about the two episodes of CP. His doctor asked him to come to the hospital for evaluation. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> CAD- S/P CABG ___ GI polyps- post polypectomy w/Bleed ___ years ago Adenoma (abdominal  site)- s/p resection ___ syndrome Syncope- vasovagal; negative holter testing Paroxsysmal Atrial fibrillation Sick Sinus syndrome Cervical spondylosis Chronic renal insufficiency (baseline since ___ Nephrolithiasis Hyperlipidemia Glaucoma Essential tremor Liver hemangioma s/p resection of left plantar melanoma ___ s/p Prostatectomy s/p Amputation of right toes secondary to frostbite in WWII. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No history of malignancy, heart disease, GI disorders. Persistent blunting of the right costophrenic angle, may relate to a small pleural effusion versus pleural thickening. 2. No focal consolidation. Please note that the pulmonary nodules seen on prior chest CT are not as well appreciated on the current study, as CT is more sensitive. ___ Echo: The left atrium is moderately dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___. The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with borderline normal free wall function. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is mild mitral valve prolapse. An eccentric, anteriorly directed jet of moderate to severe (3) mitral regurgitation is seen. summary: Mr. ___ is an ___ year-old, ___ male with CAD s/p CABG x 4 in ___, bare metal stent to LAD ___, sick sinus syndrome, and metastatic melanoma on a clinical trial drug who presented at the request of his PCP ___ 2 episodes of breif nonexertional chest pain and increasing Dyspnea on exertion over the past month. . # Chest pain: Given the patient's significant cardiac history which included CABG in ___ and stent to LAD in ___, he was admitted to rule out acute coronary syndrome. Since he recently underwent thalium stress test one month ago that showed a moderate fixed defect in basal and mid inferolateral wall but no reversible defects, he was thought to be low probablility of having angina. His initial EKG showed old Q waves in leads II, III, and avF, which was thought to represent his previous infarct, but had no evidence of ST changes indicating ischemia. Repeat EKG was stable with no changes. He ruled out with three sets of negative troponins. He was continued on his plavix, statin, and beta blocker. He did not receive daily aspirin due to his GI side effects. He underwent cardiac echo which showed new mitral regurgitation (see below) that was thought to possibly have contributed to his atypical chest pain. . # Dyspnea: The patient's story for progressive dyspnea on exertion over the past month as well as elevated JVP on physical exam was worrisome for new CHF. His previous echo in ___ was normal, but there had been no echos performed since. During this hospitalization he underwent echo which showed EF 45% to 50% and an eccentric, anteriorly directed jet of moderate to severe (3) mitral regurgitation. It was thought that this may have contributed to his atypical chest pain as well as his dyspnea. He was started on lisinopril 5 mg for the new CHF. His ambulatory saturations were 100% and he denied ongoing chest pain. He should follow up with his cardiologist next

No dyspnea or wheezing and cough has resolved since the initial presentation. No rash on any body surface that he has noticed. No pain with urination or defecation. He also endorses prior photophobia but no neck stiffness. Per ED report, he is sexually active with 3 partners in last year. He uses condoms occasionally. Reportedly had STD testing 1 month ago that was negative and no prior history of STDs. No smoking. Occasional EtOH. No illicit drug use. summary: ___ year old otherwise healthy male presents with conjunctivitis, oral ulcerations, leukocytosis and fevers concerning for viral mucositis vs. SJS. Derm consulted and feels c/w Fuch's Syndrome. # Mycoplasma pneumonia-associated mucositis: On arrival, patient was noted to be toxic appearing with copious oral secretions and shaggy white ulcerations throughout the oropharynx. Vital signs were stable and exam was otherwise notable for an erythematous red papule on the glans penis as well as mild conjunctival erythema without exudates or ulceration. Based on multiple mucous membranes of involvement, Dermatology was consulted immediately for concern for ___. No drug history with the exception of ibuprofen. Previously swab negative for HSV and worsening on acyclovir. Based on clinical history and exam, he was felt to have mycoplasma pneumoniae associated mucositis, a variant of SJS without cutaneous involvement. He was started on empiric IV azithromycin, dexamethasone mouthwash and maintenance IV fluids with workup pending (HIV/mycoplasma serologies). No indication for empiric systemic steroids or IVIg based on extent of involvement. ENT was also consulted given concern for airway protection and he had a CT neck which ruled out retropharyngeal/peritonsillar abscess. Per their recommendations, he was started on PPI for laryngeal irritation along with viscous lidocaine and saline nebulizers for comfort. ID was consulted and recommended seven days of azithromycin and further workup with RVP, ___ serologies, HSV oral swab, urine gonorrhea/chlamydia, HIV viral load and RPR which were all negative. Ophthalmology was consulted given ocular involvement and recommended artificial tears, azithromycin drops, and dexamethasone drops. Mycoplasma IgG and IgM titers returned positive supporting the presumed diagnosis of MPAM. The patient was maintained on the above therapies and maintenance fluids as diet was advanced as tolerated. Afebrile with stable vital signs and no new lesions during admission. His symptoms steadily improved and tolerated a full soft diet by

summary: Acute sickle pain crisis: Pt with sickle cell disease and recent decrease in Hgb F associated with multiple pain crises over the last few months who was admitted with leukocytosis, diffuse pain and anemia. She was treated empirically with aggressive IVF, O2 and morphine PCA with mild improvement. Hematology was consulted for recurrent pain crises over the last 4mths and pt was transfused slowly for a total of 3units prbcs and goal hct of 20. She was treated with Folic Acid 3mg and initiated Hydroxyurea 1000mg daily to help decrease risk of further crisis. Pain control improved and pt was transitioned to NSAIDs alone for pain control. She was discharged on Hydrea to follow up with hematology and to monitor her CBC q 2 weeks. . Fevers/Leukocytosis due to UTI, complicated: Pt developped fever on hospital day 2 and initial blood/urine Cx were unrevealing. CXR was read as possible RUL infiltrate and pt was treated empirically with Cefriaxone/Azithromycin. However, these Abx were stopped due to the absence of any respiratory symptoms. CXR findings thought most likely due to vascular congestion in setting of sickle crisis. Pt then developped tender subcutaneous nodules over upper and lower extremities suggestive of erythema nodosum. Both Rheum and Dermatology were consulted given her history of small vessel vasculitis. Echo was ordered given concern for possible blood stream infection and known valvular abnormalities. This showed no vegetations. Etiology on nodules remains unclear and pt refused biopsy due to poor healing from prior biopsy site. Urine culture returned  for enterococcus resistant to ampicillin and fever curve resolved after starting Vanc for UTI. Pt denied flank pain and was treated for a total of 7 days with vancomycin which was switched to Linezolid on discharge to complete her course . Small vessel vasculitis/Rash: Pt had been followed by derm prior to admission for recently diagnosed small vessel vasculitis. She was on an active prednisone wean at 40mg daily when she presented with the sickle crisis and

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ with embryonal extragonadal germ cell tumor with mets to pelvis, liver, lungs, and brain. He had been admitted for syncope and discharged on ___ but experienced another episode of lightheadedness that required him to lie down while he was in the lobby of the ___ on the way to his car and he was readmitted for further workupand resolutions. Please see the discharge summary from admission ending on ___ as well. The dizziness was felt to be vaso-vagal vs orthostatic and resulting from deconditioning. He improved after NS IVF, blood transfusion and more intensive ___ with assistance. He also underwent a more extensive workup including an ECG, ECHO which were normal and a CTA which was negative for PE and additionally showed significant response of tumor to chemotherapy with approximately 50% reduction in size of some nodules after just one cycle of chemo. An am cortisol was also within normal limits. Radiation oncology was consulted to see if XRT to brain would be helpful if it was felt that the brain mass was symptomatic but he did not receive radiation. Keppra was continued.

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: # Nausea # Abdominal pain Likely ___ adrenal insufficiency and hyponatremia, resolved with treatment of both. EGD at CHA showed chronic inflammation. Initially treated with standing metoclopramide but with treatment of adrenal insufficiency as below, this resolved and no longer requires any medication. # Adrenal insufficiency: had been on pred 5 BID for 8 months, stopped in ___. Now with adrenal insufficiency. Per endo, likely secondary and hopefully temporary. Did not respond adequately to ___ stim, ACTH pending. Was initially put on hydrocort 20mg qam and 10mg qpm but this was changed to prednisone 5mg po qd per endo to facilitate o/p follow up and testing since they anticipate it will be temporary. A repeat cortisol and ACTH were sent on day of discharge prior to prednisone dose (having held the ___ hydrocort dose the night before) in order to better assess ACTH levels, which is pending at time of discharge. He was counseled extensively about adrenal precautions, bracelet need, sick day precautions, need for IM stress dose prn. # Hyponatremia: improved with IVF, but suspect that adrenal insufficiency playing the major role. Rapid improvement with steroids, but not so fast that would be worried about ODS. # Groin pain: unclear what is causing this, but given his new constipation (which seems most likely med related) and h/o prostate ca w bone mets, underwent MRI L spine. No evidence of cord compression, but with persistent diffuse vertebral mets as well as pelvic mets. Testicular u/s without lesion. #CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS: # Metastatic prostate cancer - With bony

Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills: *0 3. Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC DAILY RX *enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL 40 mg SC at bedtime Disp #*30 Syringe Refills: *0 4. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for similar severity RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q4hr prn Disp #*35 Tablet Refills: *0 5. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID use while taking narcotics <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Lisfranc fracture <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (crutches). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY: - You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal to feel tired or washed out after surgery, and this feeling should improve over the first few days to week. - Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times. ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING: - Non-weight bearing in splint MEDICATIONS: 1) Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is an over the counter medication. 2) Add oxyocodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean off this medication in 1 week or sooner. This is an example on how to wean down: Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day. Then continue with Tylenol for pain. 3) Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic medication. 4) Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 5) Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over the counter andmay be obtained at any pharmacy. 6) Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers. 7) Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians at discharge. 8) Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed to stop by your surgeon. ANTICOAGULATION: - Please take lovenox daily for 4 weeks WOUND CARE: - You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks. - Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out at your 2-week follow up appointment. - If you have a splint in place, splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless otherwise instructed. Do NOT get splint wet. DANGER SIGNS: Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the emergency department if you experience any of the following: - Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications - Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning changes in your incision - Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation - Fever > 101.4 - Shaking chills - Chest pain - Shortness of breath - Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, medications down - Any other medical concerns Physical Therapy: NWB RLE, elevation as tolerated Treatments Frequency: To remain in splint until follow-up
summary: The patient presented to the emergency department and was evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found to have multiple metatarsal fractures and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was allowed to elevate and ice over the weekend prior to OR to allow swelling to resolve. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for ORIF ___ and ___ metatarsals, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to home with home ___ was appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is NWB in the operative extremity, and will be discharged on lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. An extensive discussion was had with the patient prior to discharge regarding the indications for post-discharge anticoagulation. It was his strong preference to continue on lovenox given concerns of stomach ulceration. A thorough discussion was had regarding the relative risks and benefits and standard practice, and the patient was provided a prescription for lovenox injections. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

Gently pat the area dry. *If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up appointment. . JP Drain x 2 Care: *Please look at the site every day for signs of infection (increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody discharge, warm to touch, fever). *Maintain suction of the bulb. *Note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. Call the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount increases significantly or
summary: The patient with newly diagnosed pancreatic mass was admitted to the HPB Surgical Service for elective resection. On ___, the patient underwent radical pancreaticoduodenectomy, which went well without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor NPO with NGT, on IV fluids, with a foley catheter, and epidural catheter for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable. Neuro: The patient received epidural analgesia with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. His Coumadin was on hold, prior to discharge patient was started on therapeutic Lovenox for anticoagulation secondary to history of atrial fibrillation. Pulmonary: He required supplemental O2 immediately post op, which was weaned off during recovery. The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirrometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV fluids. Diet was advanced to clears on POD 5 and was well tolerated. He received full liquid diet on POD 6, but felt nauseous and was downgraded to clears. On POD 7, patient's nausea subsided and he was transitioned back to fulls. On POD 8, patient's diet was advanced to regular low fat diabetic diet on POD 8 and was well tolerated. Patient's JP amylase was checked on POD 3,5 and 7. He was discharged with two JPs in place as his amylase and output remained elevated. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary. Electrolytes were routinely followed, and repleted when necessary. ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were closely watched for signs of infection. Wound was evaluated daily and no signs or symptoms of

summary: ___ yo female with Type 1 DM who presents with nausea/emesis/weakenss, elevated blood sugar, anion gap acidosis with ketosis, and dysuria. Admitted to MICU and treated for diabetic ketoacidosis. Discharged from MICU. # Diabetic Ketoacidosis - pt is a recently diagnosed Type 1 Diabetic with history of multiple prior DKA admissions ___ ___. FSBG on arrival 356, with elevated anion gap. Venous pH 7.23, urine with 150 Ketones. Although odd that she would develop ketosis and acidosis while taking her home insulin regimen as prescribed, though home insulin likely inadequate. Initially thought to have UTI given dysuria, but UA and UCx negative. Treated for yeast infection per below. Her DKA was initially treated per protocol with insulin drip, IVF, and electrolyte repletion. Her gap closed by hospital day 2, but kept an additional day as still hyperglycemic. ___ was consulted and followed her closely, and insulin was upitrated per their recommendations. By hospital day 3 eletrolyte abnormalities resolved, gap remained closed, sugars still elevated but at a controlled level. She was discharged home from the ICU on ___, with ___ f/u the following ___. # Dysuria / yeast infection: history of yeast infections previously. Initially on ceftriaxone (for 3 days), but UA and Ucx were negative, so abx course not continued on discharged. Her symptoms were consistent w/ prior yeast infections, and given she is a poorly controlled diabetic, we treated for complicated yeast infection with fluconazole 150mg x3 doses every 72 hours (she will need to take 2 doses at home). Better glycemic control important for her to prevent further yeast infections. # GERD - continued home omeprazole # Anxiety - continued home fluoxetine # Code: Full Transitional issues # She was given Rx's for all insulin, and fluconazole # Follow-up with ___ in 4 days # Monitor sugars closely at home # Improved diabetic diet # repeat labs in outpatient setting on ___

summary: ___ y/o F w/ small cell lung cancer (presently w/ Y stent in place) who underwent chemotherapy 3 days PTA who p/w hemoptysis, s/p bronchoscopy with no evidence of active bleeding. ACTIVE ISSUES: #. Hemoptysis: Pt presented with complaints of 1 day of small volume hemoptysis. Her hct was lower than baseline in our system, though this was difficult to interpret in the setting of recent chemotherapy. She underwent bronchoscopy, which reassuringly, did not show any evidence of active bleeding. It is likely that her bleeding was secondary to bronchitis, so she was treated with levaquin, to be continued for a 5 day course on discharge. She has follow up scheduled with IP in 6 weeks for ongoing monitoring and she was instructed to follow up with her oncology on discharge. CHRONIC ISSUES: #. SCLC: Pt is currently undergoing treatment at ___, last chemo dose was ___ prior to admission, most likely with etoposide and carboplatin, though pt is not sure. Unfortunately, pt missed dose of neulasta scheduled while she was admitted. She did receive dose of Neupogen and was instructed to follow up with her outpatient oncologist. Primary team left message with oncology answering service on ___. #. HTN: Continued on losartan. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: Pt was instructed to follow up with her oncologist regarding ongoing treatment. She will need repeat CT chest in 6 weeks with IP follow up. Pt will complete a 5 day course of levaquin.

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to Dr. ___ service after bipolar transurethral resection of prostate. No concerning intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. Mr. ___ received ___ antibiotic prophylaxis and the postoperative course was uncomplicated. He received intravenous antibiotics and continuous bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1 the CBI was discontinued and Foley catheter was removed with an active vodiding trial. Post void residuals were checked. His urine was clear and and without clots. He remained a-febrile throughout his hospital stay. At discharge, Mr. ___ had pain well controlled with oral pain medications, was tolerating regular diet, ambulating without assistance, and voiding without difficulty. He was given oral pain medications on discharge and explicit instructions to follow up in clinic.

summary: #Thalamic Bleed with IVH: -Patient initially was brought to ___ and received K-centra for INR reversal. NCHT was done which revealed bleed. Patient was transferred to ___ and repeat Head CT was done. In addition, NSG was consulted, no EVD was placed at this time as no hydrocephalus was seen on scan. Patient was admitted to NICU for closer monitoring. Repeat imaging revealed stable size of hemorrhage. He underwent MRI which showed no underlying mass. He remained somnolent but arousable, with dysarthria and left sided weakness, which remained stable. A repeat MRI to evaluate for somnolence did not reveal significant changes apart from interval development of left punctate infarcts likely in the setting of holding anticoagulation and critical illness. His somnolence was attributed to the location of his hemorrhagic lesion. #HTN: The patient was started on captopril with PRN labetalol and hydralazine for goal SBP <150; this was uptitrated to 75mg TID. Captopril was converted to Lisinopril 40mg daily. Home amlodipine was also reintroduced at lower dose at 2.5mg. #Atrial fibrillation: INR was 2.5 on admission from Coumadin use, which was reversed with IV vitamin K, and drifted down toward 1. He had serial imaging which showed stability of hemorrhage, and aspirin was started for prophylaxis, with plan to resume anticoagulation with apixaban on ___ (2 weeks after presentation). He was started on 2.5mg on ___, with a repeat CT on ___ stable in terms of his hemorrhage. Apixaban was increased to 5mg BID. It was later held on ___ due to concern for elevated INR and restarted on ___ at 2.5mg BID per Heme/Onc recs. #Hypoxic respiratory failure Patient transferred out of ICU to step down unit on ___. However, became acutely hypoxic, requiring transfer back to ICU and intubation. Repeat head CT unchanged. Etiology felt to be due to mucus plugging and apnea. He did receive prn Lasix. He was quickly extubated the next day to room air.

summary: The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: None Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1. The patient received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. He is discharged to home with services in stable condition.

summary: ___ yo with COPD, morbid obesity, now p/w with COPD exacerbation, likely triggered by URI. . # Hypoxia: admission exam c/w with COPD exacerbation. ABG with PCO2 at baseline. No evidence of pulmonary infiltrate suggestive of PNA. Trigger for COPD exacerbation could be recent URI, also influenza, although patient received vaccine. DFA neg. Low probablity of PE. Patient's respiratory status improved with ipratropium Q6h, albuterol Q2h prn, Q4h standing, prednisone, azithromycin. . # Afib: with episodic RVR. Patient was transferred to the cardiology service for rate control of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. His rate controlling regimen was changed to diltiazem 120mg po q6hrs and lopressor 125mg po tid. The high dose of beta blocker did not worsen his breathing with his COPD flare and in fact his breathing had improved likely due to the effect of steroid / abx / bronchodilators he had been on. His outpatient EP fellow was contacted and agreed with the rate control choices, the patient should follow up with EP as an outpatient. Rate controlled to a range of 90-110 on the cardiology floor and patient was transferred back to medicine service for further management of COPD flare. . # Recent fever: likely due to URI. Unlikely to be due to rectal abscess. Cultures were negative. Fever resolved. . # Diabetes mellitus: Continued on metformin and insuline regimen. . # Coagulopathy: on warfarin for atrial flutter, goal ___ INR 5 on admission with no sign of bleeding, and warfarin was held. His INR gradually decreased to 1.9 and warfarin was restarted. . # HTN: was continued on diltiazem and metoprolol. Lisinopril and furosemide were initially held due to signs of dehydration but were then restarted. . # FEN: Regular; Low sodium / Heart healthy, Diabetic/Consistent Carbohydrate, replete lytes . # Code: Full

summary: Mrs. ___ underwent a cardiac cath on ___ and then was admitted post-cath for pre-operative work-up. On ___ she was brought to the operating room where she underwent removal of an aortic valve mass. Please see operative note for surgical details. Following surgery she was transferred to the CVICU for invasive monitoring. Later this day she was weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and extubated. By the following day she was transferred to the floor. Beta blockade and lasix therapy were initiated. Coumadin therapy was added for paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with goal INR ___. She was seen in consultation by the physical therapy service. Chest tubes and epicardial wires were removed per protocol. Final pathology was reported as papillary fibroelastoma, benign per discussion with Dr. ___. By post-operative day 6, she was ready for discharge to home.

summary: SUMMARY/ASSESSMENT: ___ with hx afib on warfarin, lung and esophageal cancer on hospice, HTN, dementia, parkinsonism, IDDM, esophageal CA, frequent UTIs with chronic foley, ongoing UTI that started ___ weeks ago, was evluated at PCP office for UA with UCx that showed MDR organisms (per ED note), c/b elevated D-Dimer ___, ProBNP 1862, chronic anemia ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: #UTI found outpatient with MDR per report, pt with hx ESBL He was intiailly treated with meropenem, but ID consultation was obtained and determined that this was most likely just related to colonization, and antibiotics were stopped. His family was advised to watch for fevers, abdominal pain or suprapubic pain as signs of infection, given the indwelling foley. Vitamin C, for urine acidification, was started at ___. Foley was changed. #Acute encephalopathy He developed mild acute encephalopathy in the setting of his hospitalization. This improved throughout. #Back pain, history of kidney stones He developed back pain and left flank pain on HD #3. Given his poor ability to recount his history, he underwent CT to evaluate for kidney stones. This showed RIGHT hydroureternephrosis, concerning for a UVJ stone, but follow up ultrasound was negative. #Afib on warfarin He had daily INR, but he dropped to 1.5, on 2.5 mg po daily. He was reloaded with 6 and 5 mg of warfarin, and then dishcarged on alternating doses of 2.5 and 5 mg. His PCP office was notified of the change in the dose. #Type II diabetes mellitus- Blood sugars were low on his home insulin, which was decreased to reduce the risk of hypogylcemia. #Constipation. CT of his abdomen showed fecal loading. Miralax was added to his bowel regimmen CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS: #Lung and esophageal cancer - diet as per wife, nectar thick liquids with normal consistency

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old lady with DMT2 (resolved with CKD), PVD s/p R BKA, CKD stage V on HD, and gastroparesis who presented after missing HD with general malaise, N/V, and elevated WBC. Found to have MRSA bacteremia, treated with IV vancomycin for a total 3 week course per ID, TTE negative for any sign of endocarditis. Tunneled line removed and then replaced once blood cultures were negative for 72hr. ACUTE ISSUES ============ # MRSA Bacteremia Mostly likely due to infected HD line. BCX with MRSA on ___/ ___. Blood cultures negative from ___ onward. Line removed ___ and replaced ___. She is being treated with vancomycin, HD dosing. Plan for a total three week of treatment(last dose ___ to be given during dialysis session. # Nausea/Vomiting # Malaise Unclear etiology. BUN not high enough to suggest uremia as the cause. Probably in response to Staph bacteremia / systemic infection. Does have a history of gatroparesis, but states this is not similar to her previous flairs. Resolved with abx treatment. # ESRD Renal consulted, line removed and replaced as above. Per transplant surgery, plan for permanent access on right arm. Patient continues to refuse sevelamer and nephrocaps CHRONIC ISSUES ============== # DMT2 Sugars have normalized I/s/o CKD. Takes glipizide at home only if BS is >150 in AM. Discussed that this ___ the appropriate way to take this medication, but the patient insisted that this is her preferred regimen. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== [ ] Follow up with OPAT for IV Vancomycin projected end date ___. Patient does dialysis at ___ in ___, who do administer this. LAB MONITORING RECOMMENDATIONS: NOTE: For lab work to be drawn after discharge, a specific standing order for Outpatient Lab Work is required to be placed in the Discharge Worksheet - Post-Discharge Orders.

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted following Video-assisted thoracoscopic right middle lobectomy and mediastinal lymph node dissection. She was extubated in the operating room, monitored in the PACU prior transfer to the floor. Respiratory: incentive spirometer, ambulation she titrated off oxygen with supplemental with oxygen saturations 94% on room air Chest tube: Right ___ drain to suction while in PACU, water-seal on floor with small amount of serosanguinous drainage. The ___ was removed on ___ with residual small right apical pneumothorax. Chest-film: serial chest films showed right lung volume loss consistent with surgery, resolving left effusion and atelectasis. Card: immediate postoperative she was in sinus rhythm. On POD2 she had a brief episode of atrial fibrillation which responded to beta-blockers. GI: bowel regime and PPI Nutrition: tolerated a regular diet Renal: normal renal function with good urine output Pain; Dilaudid PCA transition to PO pain medication with good control Neuro: non-focal Disposition: ambulated in the halls continue to make steady progress and was discharged to home on ___ on beta-blockers. She will follow-up with Dr. ___ as an outpatient.

summary: She was admitted on ___ and was taken to the operating room. She underwent off-pump coronary artery bypass grafting x 3. Please see operative note for full details. She tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. She weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and was extubated on POD 1. She was weaned from inotropic and vasopressor support. She remained hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery. Beta blocker was initiated and she was diuresed toward her preoperative weight. She was also started on Plavix given that her case was performed off bypass and she will need to continue this for 3 months post operatively. She had a radial artery graft and was started on Imdur for this and will need to also continue this for three months. She was weaned off oxygen, however she was noted to have bilateral pneumothoraces on CXR requiring her chest tubes to remain on suction for a few additional days and remained in the hospital due to this. Thoracic surgery was consulted for aid with management and recommend clamp trial which was performed. Chest tubes were removed on POD 6 and post pull CXR shows Bilateral apical pneumothorax, moderate on the right, small on the left. No appreciable pleural effusion. Normal cardiomediastinal silhouette. Diffuse interstitial pulmonary abnormality unchanged. Repeat PA/ Lateral on ___ is unchanged. Case was discussed with thoracic surgery and they felt that as long as the CXR was unchanged, she would be stable for discharge. She was anemic and required blood transfusion post op with one unit of packed red cells. There were no bleeding concerns and she remains on aspirin and Plavix. She was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 6 she was ambulating freely, the wound was healing, and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. She completed a week long course of Lasix and will not require this on discharge. She was discharged to ___

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> prochlorperazine / erythromycin base / latex / morphine / Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / aspirin / heparin / magnesium <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> weakness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old right-handed woman with a history of COPD, a-fib on Coumadin, IDDM, diabetic neuropathy, pulmonary embolism, obesity, chronic back pain on opioids, bilateral knee replacements, and multiple other conditions; who presents as a transfer from ___ for tremor and progressive weakness. She was admitted to ___ ___ for a COPD exacerbation and treated for pneumonia with IV Levaquin and steroids for 3 days, and discharged on ___ with a course of PO Levaquin and a prednisone 40mg taper. A few days later, ___ she began to develop stuttering speech and tremors in her face and upper extremities. She also began to have weakness in her legs which, along with the tremors, progressively became worse. Reportedly, she had intact sensation to light touch, but her gait continued to worsen. She was very wobbly. There was no incontinence. She went back to ___ on ___ (admitted ___ primarily for inability to ambulate and stuttering speech, though she still complained of some shortness of breath so was admitted for possible COPD exacerbation. She was still taking Levaquin and was down to 10mg prednisone at this time. She has a remote history of pulmonary embolism so they repeated CTA chest, which was negative. She underwent head CT then MRI, both of which were unremarkable. Concern was raised for GBS due to increasing upper extremity weakness as well, so transfer to a facility with a neurologist was sought. Reflexes upon transfer were noted to be intact at both knees and ankles, despite her history of diabetic neuropathy and bilateral knee replacements. Neuro ROS:  Neck ache  Stuttering, dysarthria  Bilateral arm and leg weakness  Gait difficulty - No recent headache, loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, dysphagia, lightheadedness, or hearing difficulty. No comprehending speech. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. General ROS:  Recent pneumonia (treated)  Semi-recent fever  Possible shortness of breath but I haven't gotten out of bed in 2 days - No recent weight loss or gain. No chest pain, palpitations, cough, shortness of breath. No nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No arthralgias, myalgias, or rashes. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - paroxysmal atrial fibrillation on Coumadin - CAD - CHF - COPD - asthma - Hx pulmonary embolism - obesity - IDDM c/b peripheral neuropathy - DJD, chronic back pain on chronic opiates - fibromyalgia - anxiety/depression - congenital malformation/absence of b/l fingers - GERD - Bipolar disorder - Goiter - seizure disorder ___ years ago I had 4 seizures in one day) - hyperlipidemia - hiatal hernia <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father died of congenital heart disease (reversed valve) at ___. Sister with asthma. No family history of strokes, seizures, cancers, autoimmune diseases. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: -General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. Morbidly obese. -HEENT: NC/AT. No scleral icterus noted. MMM. No lesions noted in oropharynx. -Neck: Supple. No nuchal rigidity. -Cardiac: Irregularly irregular. No M/R/G. -Pulmonary: Distant breath sounds due to body habitus, but no adventitious sounds noted. -Abdomen: Soft, tender to percussion due to soreness from abdominal tremors, but then able to tolerate deep palpation. No organomegaly noted. Normoactive bowel sounds. -Extremities: No cyanosis, clubbing. 2 radial, DP pulses. -Skin: 6 raised erythematous bug bites on right lateral leg (spider or mosquito bite). NEUROLOGIC EXAM: -Mental Status: Alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attentive, able to name ___ backward without difficulty. Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension. Severe stuttering, though normal prosody underneath it. There are no paraphasic errors. Able to name both high and low frequency objects. Able to read without difficulty. Speech is not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Able to register 3 objects and recall ___ at 10 minutes. There is no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: II: PERRL 2 to 1.5mm. VFF to confrontation and no extinction. III, IV, VI: EOMI intact in all directions, though with high frequency irregular movements closer to impersistence than nystagmus. Normal saccades, though eyes oscillated irregularly after accurately reaching target. V: Facial sensation intact to
summary: #tremors/weakness - ___ year-old right-handed woman with a history of COPD, a-fib on Coumadin, IDDM, diabetic neuropathy, pulmonary embolism, obesity, chronic back pain on opioids, bilateral knee replacements, and multiple other conditions; who presents as a transfer from ___ for tremor and progressive weakness. Many of her symptoms and abnormalities on examination were observed to dramatically improved after receiving Ativan, which she requested and stated improved her symptoms. Specifically she stated that Ativan improved her tremors greatly. On examination there was a number of functional components: she had an intentional stutter that resolved with distraction, intentional eye avoidance exam (EOM still intact). She had diffuse profound giveway weakness that was absent with distraction and when not being tested confrontationally. Her tremor was absent with distraction. Her reflex were present and normal in the upper extremities. They were 3 at the knees bilaterally and absent at the ankle. She reported no sensation below the knees but pain sensitivity was intact below the knees and at the feet. Her history and exam were inconsistent with GBS, myopathy or other neurologic disease. She had a previous T6-7 fusion, there was very low clinical suspicion for cord compression, a MRI C/T/L spine w/ and w/o contrast was performed to rule out any cord pathology. There was no evidence of cord compression or other spinal cord abnormality on the preliminary radiology read. The final radiology read was pending at the time of discharge. She has some diabetic neuropathy which does not require any treatment modification at this time. Conversion disorder is on the differential, as she mentions one of her large life stressors is not being able to get a ___ floor apartment for several years. She agrees that there are many stressors in her life currently. Physical therapy saw her and had recommended rehab. # afib on Coumadin: INR

summary: This is a ___ year old female with PMHx liver transplant x two, situs inversus, vascular issues including IVC atresia and azygos vein stenting, who presented to ___ with fever, nausea, and abdominal pain, found to have new left renal vein thrombus, now transferred to ___ for further management of fever in immunocompromised host. #Fever: Patient has had several days of fever, maximum recorded fever of 103 at OSH. She was given a single dose each of vancomycin and cefepime. There was high concern for infection given her immunosuppresion; she therefore underwent pan-CT which revealed large thrombus extending from azygos stent to IVC and left renal vein with adjacent wall thickening and stranding concerning for thrombophlebitis. Patient remained afebrile off antibiotics and blood cultures remained negative. In consultation with infectious disease antibiotics were not continued. #Renal vein thrombosis: Large thrombus extending from azygos stent to IVC and left renal vein thought likely due to stent and no anticoagulation. No nephrotic syndrome, multiple renal hypodensities suspicious for cysts but no evidence for malignancy. Patient thought possibly predisposed to clots due to her azygos stent without anticoagulation and possible underlying anatomic abnormalities given history of IVC atresia, biliary atresia, and situs inversus. She was initially started on a heparin drip which was then changed to warfarin with a lovenox bridge. For associated abdominal/back pain she was treated with tylenol and prn oxycodone and transitioned to tramadol as outpatient. Vascular surgery were consulted; they did not recommend revascularization but will follow up with CT imaging in 3 months. #Biliary atresia s/p liver transplant x2: Tacrolimus level adequate at 3.0 on admission. She was continued on her home tacrolimus dose of 2 mg bid as well as bactrim SS daily for prophylaxis, ursodiol 300 mg bid. # Seizure disorder: Patient has history of seizures, with one resulting in permanent frontal lobe injury. She was continued

summary: Patient is a ___ male with PMH of chronic low-grade anemia, and asthma who presented with a 5-day history of a growing scrotal abscess and two day history of facial abscess. Active Diagnoses: #. Facial and scrotal abscesses: Patient's facial abscess located ___ the skin over the left mandible was drained by needle ___ the ED. Some fluctuance of the skin remained indicating remaining fluid collection. The option of having it drained on the floor was explored with the patient but he expressed concern over scarring over the area. It was decided that antibiotic treatment would be pursued with incision and drainage if antibiotic therapy alone failed management. The scrotal abscess was drained by urology and a wick was placed ___ the cavity for drainage. Gram stains revealed gram positive cocci as the main organisms and empiric vancomycin was started with good effect. With interval improvement, patient was discharged home on Bactrim DS with final wound culture results pending. He was given three doses of oxycodone 5mg tabs for pain around the time of scrotal dressing change. The dressings are to be changed at home daily with ___ assistance and he is to follow up with urology and his PCP. To investigate the etiology of this pair of synchronous infections, HIV, Lyme, and Mumps serologies were sent with results pending Chronic Diagnoses: #. Chronic low-grade anemia: stable ___ this hospitalization . #. Asthma: Patient reports no inhaler use at home and there were no exacerbation of this condition on this admission. . #. GERD: Patient does not take medications for this at home and did not require any on this admission. . #Osteoarthritis: no complaints of pain on this admission. Transitional Matters: Patient is to follow up with the results of culture sensitivities, HIV serology, Lyme serology, and mumps serology with his PCP and follow up with urology for his scrotal abscess.

summary: Mr. ___ presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset abdominal pain with associated nausea and vomiting. A gallbladder/ liver ultrasound was suggestive of cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis; lipase was elevated concerning for pancreatitis. Intravenous fluids, pain/nausea medication were administered and the patient was subsequently admitted to the Acute Care Surgical Service for further observation and management. On HD2, the patient underwent an MRCP, which was suggestive of acute cholecystitis without evidence of choledocholithiaisis or pancreatitis; lipase trending downward. Therefore, the patient was brought to the operating room where he underwent a laparascopic cholecystectomy; please see operative note for details. Post-operatively, the patient remained afebrile with stable vital signs. Pain was managed with oral oxycodone and acetaminophen. He was able to tolerate a regular diet, void adequately and ambulate independently. He was subsequently discharged to home on ___ and will follow-up in the Acute Care Surgical clinic in 2 weeks.
