summary: Ms. ___ was admitted on ___ for pre-hydration with IVF given her known CKD for her planned angiogram on ___. Her creatinine was 1.7 on admission and trended down to 1.6 on the morning of the procedure. She underwent a right lower extremity angiogram with selective balloon angioplasty of the right anterior tibial artery. The procedure was uncomplicated and the reader is referred to the operative note for further detail. She tolerated the procedure well and was extubated and transported to the PACU in stable condition. Following this she was maintained on bedrest for 4 hours with close monitoring of her groin and neurovasuclar checks. A podiatry consult was consulted to examine the non-healing wound on her right greater toe. They felt there was no need for debridement and the only local wound care should be applied. They also recommmended keeping a waffle boot on the left foot for protection of her heel blister. On POD1 she was discharged home. She stated that she did not need home services or physical therapy due having a sitter 24 hours of the day, 7 days of the week. She is non-ambulatory at baseline due to her prior CVA. She was tolerating a regular diet, her pain was controlled, she was neurovasculary intact. Vital signs were stable and she was afebrile. She was discharged with clopidogrel for 30days.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain, Dyspnea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Thoracentsis ___ Thoracentsis <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a new diagnosis of stage IIIa lung cancer  left lower extremity DVT (on Eliquis), who presents from ___ clinic with one week of chest pain  dyspnea. Patient has had a workup for her lung cancer over the past two months. She initially presented with hematuria and had a CT A/P on ___ that demonstrated a 1 cm RLL nodule. She had a chest CT on ___ that demonstrated a 3.7 cm speculated posteromedial RUL mass c/w primary lung malignancy with associated hilar and pretracheal LAD. She had a CT-guided biopsy of the mass that demonstrated  CK7, napsin, and TTF-1, consistent with a lung primary. Patient underwent EBUS with TBNA of station 4R lymph node on ___ with pathology demonstrating malignancy. She has not begun chemotherapy. Her symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath worsened two weeks ago. She has been taking oxycodone with improvement in her pleuritic pain, but still has pain in her right thoracic back with deep breathing. She has had progressive dyspnea since that time. Associated with orthopnea  PND. During this time, she has also had worsening swelling in both legs, left more than right. No fevers or abdominal pain. Today in clinic, she had crackles to midfields of her lungs, and was sent to the ED for evaluation of heart failure including ECG, TTE, and CTA chest. In the ED, initial vitals: 99.6 102 125/62 22 95% RA - Exam notable for crackles in bibasilar lung fields  edema - Labs were notable for: BNP 619, trop<0.01 x1 - Imaging: POC U/S showed no effusion or RV strain; good contractility; CTA chest showed tumor progression encasing the R main stem bronchus, pleural effusions, but minimal pulmonary edema In the ED, patient triggered for HR 190s acutely, sinus tachycardia. She was given Dilt 15mg IV, followed by a Dilt gtt. HRs improved to 100s, and BP remained stable. Her breathing got progressively worse, and she was desatting on 6L nc, so placed on a non-rebreather. - Patient was given: ___ 12: 40 IV HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) .5 mg ___ 15: 58 IV HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) .5 mg ___ 17: 48 IV HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) .5 mg ___ 17: 48 IV Diltiazem 15 mg ___ 17: 50 IV CefePIME 2 g ___ 18: 10 IV LORazepam .5 mg ___ 18: 30 IV DRIP Diltiazem ___ mg/hr ordered) ___ 18: 57 IV Vancomycin 1000 mg ___ 19: 46 IV Azithromycin 500 mg ___ 19: 46 IV MethylPREDNISolone Sodium Succ 125 mg ___ 21: 00 PO/NG Apixaban 5 mg - Consults: IP, who will follow along inpatient - Prior to transfer, VS 100 108/52 22 98% RA On arrival to the MICU, patient continues to be anxious and wishes to speak to her husband what she would want to happen should her breathing get worse. She confirms the above history. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - new diagnosis of stage IIIa lung cancer * Patient initially presented with hematuria. CT abdomen/pelvis was obtained as part of this workup on ___. This revealed a 1 cm right lower lobe nodule, for which dedicated CT chest was recommended. This was obtained ___, revealing a 3.7 cm spiculated posteromedial right upper lobe mass consistent with primary lung malignancy. Hilar and pre-tracheal lymphadenopathy were also noted. CT-guided biopsy of right upper lobe mass revealed adenocarcinoma positive for CK7, napsin, and TTF-1, consistent with a lung primary. Patient underwent EBUS was TBNA of station 4R lymph node on ___, pathology from which was positive for malignant cells. - DVT, on anticoagulation - Atrial flutter after biopsy, resolved - Hyperlipidemia - Anxiety - Osteoporosis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Both father and mother with CVA. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM - Vitals: 97.7 74 103/48 22 91% 5L HEENT: AT/NC, EOMI, PERRL, anicteric sclera, pink conjunctiva, MMM, good dentition NECK: nontender supple neck, no LAD, no JVD CARDIAC: difficult to appreciate heart sounds under diffuse transmitted airway sounds but RRR, S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs LUNG: diffuse transmitted upper airway sounds with associated rhonchi. No marked audible wheezing. Some decreased breath sounds on R side. ABDOMEN: nondistended, BS, nontender in all quadrants, no rebound/guarding, no hepatosplenomegaly EXTREMITIES: 1 Left lower extremity edema. moving all 4 extremities with purpose PULSES: 2 DP pulses bilaterally NEURO: CN II-XII intact. anxious but able
summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with a new diagnosis of stage IIIa lung cancer  left lower extremity DVT (on Eliquis), who presents from ___ clinic with one week of pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and orthopnea, and was found to be mildly volume overloaded with new right-sided pleural effusion on chest imaging, and was admitted to the ___ for management of new SVT to the 190s requiring dilt gtt  hypoxemia requiring non-rebreather. # DEATH: ********** # HYPOXEMIA # HCAP #SEPSIS: Hypoxemia is likely multifactorial. Initially, presentation sounded consistent with an acute heart failure exacerbation, with orthopnea, dyspnea on exertion, and lower extremity swelling. Patient was treated for pulmonary edema as well as a pneumonia, given possible partial airway obstruction. Additional contributors were suspected to be secondary to malignancy and pleural effusion. Her initial dyspnea and hypoxia improved and she was transferred to the floor, however returned after acutely developing tachycardia and dyspnea, at which time she was found to have a new pulmonary embolism. # Progressive LUNG CARCINOMA w/ right mainstem bronchial encasement: Newly diagnosed, has not had treatment prior to admission. Extent of progression is markedly impressive since the initial scan obtained in ___, with new features concerning for Stage IV disease including a lytic bone lesion and pleural effusion c/f metastasis. Bronchial encasement is not clearly obstructing flow, but interventional pulmonology was consulted, and was considering a possible stent placement in addition to right thoracentesis which was completed. Outpatient oncology team was consulted and met with the patient throughout the hospitalization. Given her progressive dyspnea and pain, she was not felt to be a candidate for chemotherapy during admission, though future chemotherapy was initially discussed before goals of care shifted. # SUPRAVENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA: On admission, patient had HRs in the 100s. In the ED,

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old lady with history of with stroke ___ ruptured aneurysm ___ s/p coil at ___ with recent admission for worsening baseline deficit in the setting of left MCS stroke who presented from rehab with new onset altered mental status (somnolence, less verbal) that was due to a UTI and recovered with antibiotics. She is discharged back to ___ to complete her UTI treatment. # Altered Mental Status: resolved. Most likely etiology of AMS is delirium. Possible cause of delirium that were considered include infectious source, prolongued hospitalization/immobolization in setting of recent ___ injury or seizure. Based on recent history of aneurysm concern for new bleed ruled out by CT head. B12 normal. LFTs are elevated but trended down and RUQ U/S was negative for acute process. CXR negative for pneumonia. Overall, her AMS was felt to be from UTI (see below) and sedating medications (she is on alprazolam, baclofen and vicodin). With UTI treatment, holding Vicodin, and holding Alprazolam, she is now alert and interactive. On discharge, she is back to baseline per discussion with staff at ___: she is pleasant and conversive. # UTI: Klebsiella pneumoniae. Though she was asymptomatic, her altered mental status could have been a manifestation of her UTI so it was treated. Culture revealed that bacteria was resistant to oral agents. She was started on Meropenem and will complete a 7 day course (___) for a complicated UTI. PICC line was placed on ___ and should be removed at the end of her UTI treatment. # h/o ruptured aneurysm/stroke: stable. Neurosurgery evaluated patient in ED, recommended admission to medicine as problem felt to be non-neurological in nature given clinical picture and negative CT head. She continues on Levetiracetam 500 mg PO BID for seizure prophylaxis. She should follow up in clinic with Dr. ___ in one year. # Anxiety: stable off benzos. Holding

summary: ___ with history of asthma presented to OSH with left-sided chest pain and orthopnea, found to have nonspecific EKG changes, troponin-T of 0.167, BNP 3558, and CXR w/cardiac enlargement, as well as questionable pericardial effusion on U/S. She was transferred here for evaluation for urgent cardiac catheterization, found to have normal coronary arteries and significant LV systolic dysfunction (EF 35%) consistent with Takotsubo syndrome. # Takotsubo cardiomyopathy: The patient had an echo with EF 30% with moderate-to-severe hypokinesis of the apical two-thirds of the left ventricle, indicating new-onset heart failure consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She did have slightly elevated troponins, but cardiac catheterization was normal and EKG showed no signs of infarct. She was started on lisinopril, metoprolol and a heparin gtt. She diuresed well with IV lasix which relieved her shortness of breath and chest pain. She remained hemodynamically stable throughout admission. She was discharged on warfarin, lisinopril, and metoprolol. She was discharged with follow-up appointments and will likely need a repeat echo in 6 weeks as an outpatient. # Life stress: The patient endorsed having problems with stress, depression, and anxiety. She had several stressful life events prior to this hospitalization. She was continued on home fluoxetine. Social work was consulted and provided her with materials for outpatient therapy, to which she agreed. She denied homicidal or suicidal ideation. In the interim, she was discharged with 5 tablets of lorazepam for her anxiety. # Asthma: Patient takes singulair at home, hasn't had an exacerbation in years. She was continued on home montelukast.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Right face and upper extremity numbness, tingling and warmth <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M with a PMHx significant for prostate cancer currently undergoing chemo and hormone treatment who presents to the ED with headache and sudden onset right sided discomfort including numbness, tingling and warmth. Patient reports he was lying in bed when he started to noticed an warm feeling over the right side of his scalp which progressed to his right upper extremity. He also noticed discomfort in his right upper extremity with associated numbness and tingling. He told his wife who recommended they go to the ED. Of note, patient also reported a ___ headache, right sided which was best described as pressure. He reports he never gets headaches so this is very unusual for him. The headache had been present for the past few hours prior to onset of symptoms. In the ED, initial vitals were 6 98.5 90 138/78 16 100%. A code stroke was called given last normal within 2 hours from arrival. His exam was notable for increased pinprick sensation over the right face and right upper extremity. NIHSS scored 1. Patient was taken to radiology where ___ and CTA head and neck were performed. Prelim read showed no acute intracranial process. CTA head and neck showed severe calcified atherosclerosis of the right common carotid artery with intact cervical and intracranial vasculature. Given patient's mild symptoms without obvious thrombus on imaging, tPA was not given. Patient had already received home aspirin and statin that morning and the decision was made to admit to neurology for further work-up. On neuro ROS, the pt denies loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending speech. Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait. On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or chills. No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Prostate cancer Diverticulosis Cervical disc disease Osteoarthritis Colonic adenoma <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - Non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T= 98.4 82 122/100 18 99% RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. Pt. was able to name both high and low frequency objects. Able to read without difficulty. Speech was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Attentive, able to name ___ backward without difficulty. The pt. had good knowledge of current events. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: PERRL 3 to 2mm, both directly and consentually; brisk bilaterally. VFF to confrontation. III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus. Normal saccades. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch, increased perception of pinprick on right side compared to left VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric and ___ strength in upper and lower distributions, bilaterally VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes in midline -Motor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. No pronator drift bilaterally. No adventitious movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis noted. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ L ___ ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 R ___ ___ ___- 5 5 5 5 5 -DTRs: Bi Tri ___ Pat Ach L 2 2 2 2 1 R 2 2 2 2 1 - Plantar response was flexor bilaterally. -Sensory: Increased sensation to pinprick on right upper extremity, lower extremities equal. No deficits to light touch, proprioception throughout. No extinction to DSS. -Coordination: No intention tremor. No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally. -Gait: Good initiation. Narrow-based, normal stride and arm swing. = = = = = = = = = = = = ----
summary: ___ yo male, who presented with sudden onset, tingling/numbness sensation on his right face and arm. His admission exam was notable for increased sensation to pinprick on R face and RUE. Further exam on admission was notable for additional deficits in direction sense, proprioception, agraphesthesia of R face and RUE which had resolved by the second day of his hospitalization. His exam was otherwise normal. An MRI was done, but was negative for an acute infarct. He may have had a TIA, which is less likely given the numbers of hours it lasted or he may have had a small stroke in possibly the lateral thalamic from which he recovered quickly. In terms of management, he was continued on aspirin and changed from lovastatin 20 mg to atorvastatin 80. He should have an outpatient TTE To reduce his risk of recurrent TIA or stroke, we continued aspirin and switched lovastatin 20mg daily for atorvastatin 80mg. He should follow up with his PCP for an outpatient TTE, for neurology followup at Atrius and to follow up with lipid panel, TSH and A1c that was pending at time of discharge.

summary: ___ y/o ___ speaking male with past medical history of colon and rectal cancer and chronic constipation, currently being treated with XRT and home infusion of ___, who presented with abdominal pain and no bowel movements for 3 days. # Abdominal Pain: Differential diagnosis included obstruction from solid tumor burden which could be the cause of his constipation as well. KUB on ___, showed a large amount of colonic stool extending from the cecum through the sigmoid colon. There was no free air. Pt was recently admitted with similar symptoms, which resolved with aggressive bowel regimen therefore pt underwent aggressive bowel regimen with daily miralax, mag citrate, fleets enema with standing Colace/senna. After bowel regimen, pt reported having up to 14 small bowel movements daily. Pt's diet was advanced to clears and pt tolerated it well. Repeat KUB two day later on ___ showed increased stool burden in the descending colon and rectum with mild dilatation of the transverse colon, which could represent large bowel obstruction secondary to fecal impaction. Colorectal surgery was consulted and took the pt to the OR on ___ for diversion and colostomy. On ___, the patient's foley was discontinued and he was able to void appropriately. His diet was advanced from sips to clears and he tolerated this well. On ___, the patient was passing lots of gas into his ostomy bag, and was able to tolerate solid food by dinner. On ___, he remained on a regular diet and continued to pass flatus but was not producing much stool from his ostomy. We continued to monitor his output, which began to increase on ___ with small amounts of formed stool in the ostomy bag. He had ostomy teaching with both an interpreter and the ostomy nurse present. On ___, he remained on a regular diet and was passing increased amounts of stool per ostomy. The patient was seen inpatient on ___ by Dr. ___ his home chemotherapy was ordered by this provider. ___ services received all forms necessary to give the patient home chemotherapy per Dr. ___.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> PSYCHIATRY <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / lidocaine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Can't get my medications <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old woman with reported history of Schizophrenia and Anxiety, followed at Mass Mental, presents via EMS reporting medication non-adherence due to being locked out of her home. Patient states that she has not been able to take her medications because she was locked out of her transitional home. Patient reports staying in ___, but was unable to get inside of her home last night. Unable to elaborate further. When asked if she is experiencing any symptoms given that she recently skipped her medications - she reports vivid dreams, and anxiety, but denies perceptual disturbances or affective symptoms. Denies SI/HI. On interview, patient describes she is here because she was looked out from her roommates. She states she lives with 11 roommates in a single house in ___, but that these people looked her out of their apartment and she has been unable to get her medications. She states she spent the night at a train stop with a friend, they took turns to sleep in order to protect each others safety. She states during this time she felt safe but was unable to eat, she is not mad a her roommates and states these things happen. She states that with out her medications she is unable to think clearly, but otherwise she feels fine. She hurt her right knee a few days ago as is unsure why, she has felt cold in the past few days an suspects that she may have caught the flue during the time she was living in the streets. She denies any symptom such as fever, soar throat, SOB, headache, muscle or joint pain. She states she just wants to take her medication. She denies symptoms of anxiety, denies feeling depressed, denies changes in energy, sleep, racing thoughts, flight of ideas, denies auditory or visual hallucinations, denies paranoid or persecutory delusions, denies ideas of reference, also denies current SI or HI. Collateral obtained from ___ home coordinator ___ at ___ ___ patient had a recent admission at ___ for SI and received ECT during her admission from mid ___ to ___ when patient was discharged. Patient did well during the first few days after admission but then began to behave bizarrely. Patient has baseline delusions, however she began to have visual hallucinations of her dead granddaughter, and delusional thoughts of her ex-husband and family members whom she believed were all killed in a violent car accident. This delusional content was new for the patient. summary: #Acute gastritis - The patient was admitted to the ICU overnight for observation given reported hypotension prior to admission. Blood pressure was readily fluid-responsive and the patient remained hemodynamically stable. Melena resolved after admission and hematocrit remained stable, obviating the need for blood transfusion. He was treated with PPI gtt in the ICU which was changed to PPI BID on the floor. The patient underwent EGD showing erosive gastritis and ___ esophagus but no active bleeding. Continued to hold coumadin. Aspirin was restarted in the setting of BID PPI and carafate therapy which will be continued after discharge at the recommendation of the consulting GI team. He will follow up in GI clinic, in part to schedule surveillance endoscopy for the monitoring of ___. . #Candidal esophagitis - EGD also revealed candidal esophagitis which had been present on endoscopy 6 months prior and perhaps inadequately treated with a 10-day course of fluconazole. HIV Ab test was negative at that time. A 3-week course of oral fluconazole was started with LFT's to be rechecked 1 week after discharge. He was counseled regarding the proper use of his corticosteroid inhalers including rinsing thoroughly after use. . #C. difficile colitis - The patient was started on a 2 week course of flagyl. He was placed on contact precautions. He was counseled not to drink alcohol while taking metronidazole. . #Abdominal/back pain - This pain reportedly had been present for several years but had subacutely worsened over the past ___ months. Paraspinal muscle tenderness on examination was suggestive of musculoskeletal pathology. CTA abd/pelvis showed sigmoid diverticulosis but no evidence of mesenteric ischemia or AAA. Lumbar plain film showed only chronic degenerative changes but no compression deformity or lytic lesion. Stable hematocrit made a RP bleed unlikely. Urinalysis, LFT's, calcium, and SPEP/UPEP were normal. Pain was well-controlled with tylenol. . #Chronic systolic CHF - The patient appeared euvolemic without signs or

summary: The patient presented to ___ on ___ for evaluation of right ___ toe wet gangrene. He was evaluated by the podiatry service, who performed a bedside right ___ toe amputation; please see the operative report for details. The transplant nephrology team was consulted in order to provide ongoing recommendations for immunosuppression. He was started on broad spectrum antibiotics on admission (vacomycin, cefepime, metronidazole). His toe amputation wound was left open, and he underwent a right lower extremity angiogram with right popliteal stent placement; please see operative report for details. He was observed and continued on IV antibiotics; on ___, he underwent a right ___ metatarsal head resection and wound closure. He was restarted on his home warfarin on ___. He was evaluated by the inpatient physical therapy service, who recommended a short course of ___ rehab. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation when possible, and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. GI/GU/FEN: The patient was kept NPO as appropriate for procedures. He otherwise tolerated a regular diabetic diet. He had a foley placed prior to his angiography on ___ this was removed on ___ and he was able to subsequently void. He was given gently IV resuscitation per nephrology recommendations and his torsemide was held on the morning of angiography. He had some transient nausea and abdominal pain that resolved with expectant management. ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of infection, of which there were none. He was placed on empiric antibiotics which were converted to PO Augmentin at the time of discharge. HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs of bleeding, of which there were none. He was continued on his home aspirin and started on clopidogrel after stent placement. His warfarin was restarted on ___. Endo: The patient was found to have persistently elevated blood glucose levels

Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please keep your wounds clean. Continue warm water soaks with betadine three times daily. Pat dry and cover your wounds with a dry sterile dressing after soaking. You may shower starting five (5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at least four (4) weeks. Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out at your follow-up appointment. 7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 8. ACTIVITY: Continue splint and elevation at all times. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment.
summary: The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Pain was well-controlled on oral pain medications. Wick placed at the time of surgery was removed on POD 1 and betadine soaks TID were initiated. The surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen by occupational therapy and a volar resting splint was provided. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. Mr ___ is discharged to home in stable condition.

summary: ___ yo F with chronic back pain admitted for delirium with positive tox screen for alcohol, benzos and opiates. . # Delirium - Assumed to be due to alcohol and opiates, with possible addition of benzos. The alcohol was apparently wine and the opiates are prescribed. The benzos may be related to systemic absorption of clonazepam mouthwash, or possibly due to ativan left at home. On the floor, she was calm and comfortable and no longer confused. She remained AOx3. She continue to be severely depressed, but denied suicidal ideations. It's unclear if there is a component of dementia, or if she simply has pseudodementia from depression. Her family was contacted and they agreed to go to her home to assess her medications. Home ___ was also contacted to do medication reconciliation in the home. . # Depression - She appeared to be very depressed on admission. She is sad about her daughter living on ___, and per family, also has trouble with some of her relationships. She has increased sleep requirements, poor appetite, and anhedonia. She had previously taken fluoxetine but it is unclear when this was discontinued. We recommended that she talk to her PCP about restarting this medication and possibly speaking with psychiatry. . # UTI - Seen on urinalysis, but asymptomatic. Unlikely to contribute to delirium, though possibble. She was treated with 3 days of cipro. # HTN - continued lisinopril

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Subsegmental pulmonary embolus retrospectively seen on CT angiogram from 1 month ago <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr ___ is a ___ y/o M s/p lumbar fusion and laminectomy (___) who has since been immobilized in TLSO brace and ___ admitted for further management of an undiagnosed subsegmental PE. He presented to his primary care physician ___ ___ at which time he was found to be dyspneic and tachycardic. Further investigation revealed that he had an elevated D-Dimer as well as EKG showing S1 Q3 T3. He was subsequently sent to the ED where he underwent a CTA which was intially read as normal. He was subsequently sent home. In the interim his CT scan was re-read and reconfigured with new reconstruction CT software and as result showed a small sub-segmental pulmonary embolism. The patient was thus called back to the emergency department for further evaluation. In between these ED visits, patients denies subjective dyspnea, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain or palpitations. Upon re-presentation to the ED, initial VS Temp98.4 HR108 BP153/95 RR18 98% RA. Labs showed baseline leukocytosis, Hct of 34 (similar to prior) and normal Cr. Patient was documented as guiac negative and started on heparin gtt with bolus. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Chronic lower back pain: s/p compression fracture with T12 L1 L2 laminectomy and T10L4 fusion in ___ - Chronic knee pain thought due to steroid-induced avascular necrosis of knee - Hypercholesterolemia on statin - Colonic Adenoma - Pulmonary nodules seen on CT - Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (baseline WBC 13- 15) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of illnesses. Mother is ___ years old, alive and in good health. Father died from natural causes at age ___. <PHYSICAL EXAM> GENERAL: Well-appearing man in NAD, comfortable, appropriate. summary: ##Subsegmental Pulmonary Embolism: Presented to PCP with signs and symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolus including tachycardia, tachypnea, subjective dyspnea, positive d-dimer and S1Q3T3. However emergency department imaging read as normal. This read was later amended after the scan was reassessed using reconstruction software. Reconfiguration of the scan showed a small subsegmental pulmonary embolus (PE). On presentation, patient did not endorse any symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain or other symptoms suggestive of chronic PE. On exam he was hemodynamically stable with blood pressure 130/68, heart rate was 92 (ranged from 92-106) with a respiratory rate of 18 saturating 98% on room air. His electrocardiogram was normal and his telemetry was only significant for tachycardia with movement. We proceeded with anticoagulation given that patient had with a modifiable PE risk factor (in his case prolonged immobilization) and are typically anticoagulated for a 3 month duration, and he would be currently anticoagulated had the PE CTA been read as positive for PE back in ___. Thus patient was started on Enoxaparin 60 mg SC Q12H with bridge to Coumadin and was set up in the ___ clinic. We did not perform a repeat CT-angiogram as this would not have altered our management of this patient. Per discussion with the radiology coordinator, the attending who read the original CTA was contacted and requested to add an addendum documenting the positive PE. It had not been added by the time this discharge summary was signed. The new read on the positive PE has been documented in the ED admission note, the patient's PCP note at ___ in Atrius Web, and in this discharge summary. ##Tachycardia: Patient has been noted to be tachycardic in the past and has persistent heart rates of ___. Etiology of his tachycardia is unclear. It is unlikely to be due to a pulmonary embolus given that tachycardia in pulmonary emboli is typically accompanied with other hemodynamic manifest

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ w/T1DM c/b gastroparesis, ESRD on HD presenting with abdominal pain, N/V and found to have glucose >1300. #HYPEROSMOLAR HYPERGLYCEMIC STATE: By glucose >600, pH>7.3, bicarb>15. Trigger was thought to be most likely volume depletion and oral intolerance leading to non-compliance with treatment. She was addditionally worked up for an infectious etiology of her HHS, which was unrevealing. An EKG demonstrated no ischemic changes and she had no chest discomfort on presentation. She was initially treated with an insulin gtt which was ultimately stopped on ___. ___ Diabetes specialists were consulted for assistance and recommended increasing her evening ___ dose to 7u. They continued to follow her after she was called out to the floor. Glucose was difficult to control during her time on the medicine floor with finger stick glucose levels ranging from 37 to >500. She did develop a gap although there was no evidence of any serum ketones. ___ continued to follow Ms. ___ and ___ dose continued to be increased. At the time of discharge her ___ dose was 8 units with breakfast and 10 units with dinner. She was also advised to continue the insulin sliding scale with 4 units of Humalog with meals and use of a correction scale of 1 unit of insulin for every 50 over 150. At the time of discharge, her finger stick glucose continued to be in the 400s. Her last serum glucose obtained in the hospital was 363. She was advised to follow-up with her endocrinologist at ___, Dr. ___ for further follow-up and management of her diabetes. #TROPONEMIA: Likely reflects demand ischemia in the setting of frequent hypertension compounded by poor renal clearance, with low suspicion for ACS. Cardiac biomarkers downtrended without further intervention. She did not have any chest pain, chest pressure, or shortness of breath during hospitalization. #

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with recent cocaine and heroine use who presented to the emergency department with chest pain. While in the emergency department cardiac enzymes were negative three times. Her chest x-ray was negative for pneumonia, and her CTA did not show evidence of a pulmonary embolus. She was admitted overnight to monitor her chest pain and for an exercise stress test. However, given her negative studies and the pleuritic nature of her chest pain, it was not felt that her chest pain was cardiac in nature. Given her complaint of chest pain and her blood pressure of 140/90, she was started on 12.5 mg of Metoprolol and 81 mg of Aspirin. She was also monitored on telemetry without any events. Ms. ___ was also experiencing heroin withdrawal symptoms and was treated with Ativan and ofran PRN. The ___ day of admission, the patient no longer had any chest pain and metoprolol was stopped given possible risk with cocaine present in urine. In addition, it was felt that the exercise stress test was not urgent in nature and could performed in the outpatient setting. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

summary: ___ with ___ disease and recent initiation of infliximab with persistent abdominal pain, imaging concerning for active disease and possible stricture formation. # ___ Disease Patient was admitted with abdominal pain after starting infliximab infusion. She underwent CT scan with findings concerning for active ___ disease. CRP was checked and was 32.9. The patient was seen by colorectal surgery who felt surgical intervention was not needed. The patient was also seen by the gastroenterology team. She was initally treated with IV and bowel rest. Stool studies were not sent as the patient was having formed stool which was unchanged from baseline. Despite concerning CT findings, she improved quickly and was tolerating a low residue lactose free gluten free diet prior to discharge. She will continue her outpatient infliximab. #Anemia History of anemia. HCT now at baseline prior to discharge.

summary: The patient presented to the clinic and was evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found to have left ___ humerus fx and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for ORIF left ___ humerus which the patient tolerated well (for full details please see the separately dictated operative report). The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given perioperative antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patients home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is nbw in the left upper extremity, and will be discharged on aspirin for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up in two weeks per routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course, and all questions were answered prior to discharge.

summary: The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where the patient underwent coronary Artery Bypass Graft x 5 Left internal mammary artery -> left anterior descending, reverse to diagonal, ramus, marginal and posterior descending artery. Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and breathing comfortably. The patient was neurologically intact and hemodynamically stable. Beta blocker was initiated and the patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight. The patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery. Chest tubes were left in an additional day due to high drainage but POD 2 chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without complication. He was transfused 1 unit RBC for post op anemia. The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 4 the patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged home with visiting nurse services in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

During ERCP was found to have choledocholithiasis and sludge. Sphincteroplasty was performed, stones extracted, and stent placed. Pt developed post-ERCP fever, chills, and abdominal pain. He was placed on antibiotic therapy post ERCP with good effect. Blood cultures were drawn and are NGTD at the time of discharge, but still pending. Pt should continue cipro and flagyl to complete a total of 7 day course of therapy for cholangitis. Bilirubin and LFTs were normal on the day of discharge and he did not have fever or leukocytosis. Pt was advised that he will need a repeat ERCP in 1 month's time for stent extraction and reevaluation. HE was continued on his home dose of urosdiol. His diet was advanced to regular low fat gradually without complicated. Per ERCP, it was ok to restart pradaxa the day after ERCP and this was done. . #fever/rigors-likely related to early cholangitis vs. post-procedure bacteremia or bacterial translocation. No other localizing source to suggest PNA or UTI. As above, he was placed on cipro and flagyl for a 7 day course of therapy. BCX thus far negative. . #atrial fibrillation-s/p AVR. ALPRAolam 0.5 mg PO TID: PRN anxiety 7. Cephalexin ___ mg PO ONCE <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> left hip osteoarthritis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by your physician. 8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox daily for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). 9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks. 10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after surgery. 11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated with walker or 2 crutches at all times for six weeks. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Mobilize frequently. Physical Therapy: WBAT LLE Posterior hip precautions (x 3 months) Assistive device x 6 weeks post-op
summary: The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: On postoperative day 1, the patient was complaining of very poor pain control. His medications were adjusted accordingly. The patient discussed this with the ___ and eventually admitted to illegally using drugs up until the present admission. As a result, his medications were not continually adjusted upwards. Overnight on POD1 the patient was noted to be having intermitted fevers with a Tmax of 102.1. He refused any acetaminophen secondary to his history of hepatitis C. A fever workup was initiated, and UA and CXR were negative for acute infectious process. Blood cultures x 2 were also sent and were pending at the time of discharge. He was noted to have some bloody staining on his dressing and was instructed to call our office if this persisted or worsened. Immediately prior to discharge the patient was noted to have a heart rate in the 140's. Despite this, he was fully dressed and proceeding to leave the unit. His heart rate was discussed with him and it was recommended that he delay discharge so that a thoughtful workup of his tachycardia could be performed, however the patient refused any further intervention and proceeded to leave against medical advice. He expressed awareness and understanding of the risks of leaving the hospital with such profound tachycardia (including MI, PE, other potentially lethal conditions) and he demonstrated full capacity to make this decision, so he was not prevented from leaving the premises. Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral pain medications. The patient received Lovenox daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The surgical dressing was changed and the SIlverlon dressing was removed on POD#2. The surgical incision was found to

A right- sided chest tube appears unchanged. The patient has been extubated and a nasogastric tube removed. There is associated decrease in the lung volumes with increased bibasilar atelectases. However, no edmea, pneumothorax or effusion. IMPRESSION: 1. Status post extubation with associated increased bibasilar atelectasis. 2. No pneumothorax. <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1) Monitor wounds for signs of infection. These include redness, drainage or increased pain. In the event that you have drainage from your sternal wound, please contact the surgeon at ___. 2) Report any fever greater then 100.5. 3) Report any weight gain of 2 pounds in 24 hours or 5 pounds in 1 week. 4) No lotions, creams or powders to incision until it has healed. You may shower and wash incision. Please shower daily. No bathing or swimming for 1 month. Use sunscreen on incision if exposed to sun. 5) No lifting greater then 10 pounds for 10 weeks. 6) No driving for 1 month. 7) Call with any questions or concerns What is warfarin Warfarin is the generic name for ___ (brand or trade name). ___ belongs to a class of medications called anticoagulants, which help prevent clots from forming in your blood and or keep grafts open. Why am I taking warfarin You are taking warfarin because you have a medical condition that puts you at risk for forming dangerous blood clots, or to keep open vessels that have stents and or vessels that allow blood to flow for ischemic leg symptoms. How do I take warfarin Warfarin is taken once daily at the same time every day, preferably in the evening, with or without food. If you miss ___ dose of warfarin, take the missed dose as soon as possible on the same day. If you forget, do not double up the next day Write the day of your missed dose on your calendar and let your health care provider know at your next visit. Why is warfarin use monitored so carefully Warfarin is a medication that requires careful and frequent monitoring to make sure that you are being adequately treated, but not over- or under-treated. If you have too much warfarin in your body, you may be at risk for bleeding. If you have too little warfarin in your body, you may be at risk for forming dangerous blood clots. Medications, food and alcohol can also interfere with warfarin, making close monitoring even more important. What is INR INR, which stands for International Normalized Ratio, is a blood test that helps determine the right warfarin dose for you. The INR tells us how much warfarin is in your bloodstream and is a measure of how fast your blood clots. A high INR means you are more likely to bleed (your blood does not clot very fast). A low INR means you are more likely to form a clot (your blood clots very fast). All patients will have an INR goal depending on their medical condition(s), yours is ___. What are the possible side effects of warfarin The major side effect of warfarin is bleeding (especially when your INR is too high). Here are some symptoms of bleeding to look for and to report to your health care provider: ___ bruising or bruises that won't heal Bleeding from your nose or gums Unusual color of urine or stool (including dark brown urine, or red or black/tarry stools) What do I need to know about drug interactions with warfarin Many drugs can potentially interfere with warfarin and may cause your INR to change, putting you at risk for bleeding or a clot. These drugs include prescription medications, over-the-counter medications (like aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen), and dietary and herbal supplements. They should be avoided unless otherwise directed by health provider. You should take your Aspirin as directed. What role does my diet play The amount of vitamin K in your diet may affect your response to warfarin. Certain foods (like green, leafy vegetables) have high amounts of vitamin K and can decrease your INR. You do not have to avoid foods high in vitamin K,

summary: Vascular Surgery Course: Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization; Given persistent and chronic pain, the chronic pain service was consulted on HD1. She was initially managed with a regimen of dilaudid ___ q4h PO, gabapentin 400mg BID, lidocaine patch, tylenol ___ Q8H, with IV Dilaudid for breakthrough pain. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. On HD3 patient had a short run of non-sustained Ventricular Tachycardia which was asymptomatic. An EKG was obtained and labs were drawn, and electrolytes were repleted as indicated. While at HD on ___, the patient became hypotensive to 40-50s, a code was called, but with  pulse and mentation. ECG demonstrated diffuse myocardial ischemia. 2.5L IVF and pressors were given. When her pressure improved she was transferred to the CCU. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. GI/GU/FEN: The diet was advanced sequentially to a Regular diet, which was well tolerated. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored ID: The was started on empiric antibiotic therapy with Vancomycin/Cipro/Flagyl. During the course of HD1-HD3, her Right great toe appeared to progressively become progressively even more discolored and tender from admission and on HD3, developed a small amount of drainage. The decision was made for amputation given concern for severe infection. Patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for toe amputation. There were no adverse events in the operating room; please see the operative note for details. Pt was awoken from anesthesia, taken to the PACU until stable, then transferred to the ward for observation HEME/Renal: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs of bleeding, of which there were none. The patient was continued on her normal hemodialysis regimen in consultation with dialysis nephrology. Prophylaxis: The patient was continued on her home ASA

summary: ___ M with CAD s/p CABG in ___ transferred to ___ for further evaluation after presenting to OSH with chest pain, found to have NSTEMI. ACTIVE ISSUES: # Acute Coronary Syndrome: Pt has a history of 3v CAD s/p CABG (RIMA-LAD, SVG-OM1, SVG-RCA) in ___ who presented with sudden onset chest pain responsive to nitroglycerin, diffuse T wave inversions on EKG, elevated cardiac enzymes indicating NSTEMI. Patient was high risk (prior CABG, TIMI score 5 for known CAD, ASA use in past 7 days, elevated cardiac markers, 3 or more CAD risk factors, severe angina in past 24 hours) and therefore, underwent cardiac catheterization on ___ which showed interval progression of his native proximal RCA disease since his CABG 2 months ago as well as extensive thrombosis of the SBG-OM1. Thrombectomy/Angiojet with adjunctive balloon angioplasty was attempted with removal of some thrombus, but significant thrombus was still present. The patient underwent additional catheterization on ___ for POBA of OM1 with stenting of his SBG-LCx-distal anastomotic lesion (2.25 x 12 Resolute) and proximal vein graft lesion (5 x 18 Ultra). The patient received Integrilin for an additional 24 hours post-op. The patient experienced no episodes of chest pain. He was discharged to continue Plavix 75 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg daily, full dose aspirin 325 daily, and his home metoprolol 25 mg BID was switched to metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily. # NSVT: Per report, patient with multiple runs of asymptomatic NSVT at OSH (approximately 15 beat max, telemetry print outs not available). The patient did not experience any episodes of NSVT during this hospitalization. His electrolytes were monitored and repleted as needed. CHRONIC ISSUES: # Hypertension: per records. Patient was not on home antihypertensives. He was discharged on lisinopril 5 mg daily. # Hx cataract

He was re-started on a regular diet, pain was controlled with PO pain medications and he was started on IV then transitioned to PO antibiotics. We followed his culture and Mixed Bacterial Flora speciated. He was given a course of antibiotics to continue as an outpatient and scheduled for his outpatient follow up appointment. Due to his weekend discharge, we were unable to set up ___ services prior to his discharge. The patient was interested in caring for the drains himself and received the appropriate teaching for this. Prior to his discharge, the patient was independently ambulatory, voiding, passing flatus and pain was controlled.

The patient received IVF with improvement. Frequency and amount of diarrhea decreased dramatically during the hospitalization. No bloody stool or abdominal tenderness to suggest ___ flare. Stool studies negative for Cdiff, other stool cultures pending. Patient was tolerating clears at discharge. # Tachycardia - Pt was tachycardic in the ED, likely secondary to fever and dehydration. Resolved by time of admission. # ___ disease - continued ___, vitamin b12 and cholestyramine. Follow-up scheduled as outpatient.

summary: ___ y/o man with a hx of pancreatic cancer s/p Whipple (cancer believed to be cured, Ca ___ is flat), CAD/DM/HTN, DM2, CKD IV, anemia who developed a fever at home without localizing sxs. His dtr called ___, and he was transported to ED. In ED, w/u unrevealing but febrile to 102. Blood cx and urine sent. CXR negative. Admitted. He appeared well on ward, no recurrent fevers. In ___ of note, he had a similar presentation, and was found to have ESBL GNR bacteremia; given this he is being observed for further fever/clinical change. Active issues: # Fever: unclear etiology. Reassuring that duration was only one day, favor viral process. No other localizing symptoms. LFTs slightly elevated, but not cholestatic in nature, low suspicion for cholangitis; furthermore, pancreatic cancer has been in remission. LFT's have normalized. Received ceftriaxone in ED, further antibiotics held. Given hx ESBL, blood cultures were monitored for 48 hrs, and remained no growth to date at the time of discharge. # Transaminitis: ALT/AST slightly elevated on presentation. Pt was continued on his atorvastatin. LFT's subsequently normalized. Chronic issues: # CAD: continued metoprolol, statin, aspirin, Imdur # Pancreatic cancer: s/p Whipple in ___, no evidence of recurrence, continued Creon # Hypothyroidism: continued levothyroxine # Type 2 DM, uncontrolled, with complications: continued Lantus, held humalog sliding scale. - Continued gabapentin for neuropathy # CKD stage IV: stable, dosed medications for GFR ___ # Anemia: iron deficiency, continued iron and B12 Transitional issues: - Blood cultures remain pending x2 after 48 hours at the time of discharge. Please follow up results.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with recurrent metastatic ER breast cancer (started C1D1 Taxol on ___ who is admitted with chest pain in the setting of sternal fracture and small retrosternal hematoma. Of note, she was recently admitted ___ with nausea and vomiting a day after initiating chemotherapy with paclitaxel. She was treated for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting with ofran and IV fluids. She was discharged on ___ after having improved and no longer needing symptomatic therapy. On ___, patient called in the to the oncology office to report worsening severe chest pain over her right chest. Pain was worse with breathing and worse with turning/twisting her torso. She was referred in to the ED for further evaluation. Vital signs in the ED were stable, and she was on 4L NC. TroponinT was less than 0.01, D-dimer was 898, lactate 1.6, CBC and chemistries were WNL. from H and P: A CT-A was done that showed no PE but revealed a sternal fracture with small retrosternal hematoma as well as multiple compression deformities and a small right pleural effusion. The ACS service was consulted, with no intervention recommended. The patient received 4 mg IV morphine, and 1 mg IV dilaudid for pain control. Though she was started on a heparin gtt when D-dimer returned elevated, this was discontinued upon negative CT-A of the chest. Upon arrival to the floor, the patient endorses the above story. Her pain is currently poorly controlled and worse with deep inspiration. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> from H and P: PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: Her breast cancer history began in ___ when she developed a left breast cancer. This was managed at ___ where she underwent lumpectomy with two excisions and an axillary node dissection. She had 19 negative nodes. After successful reexcision, she had breast conserving radiation administered at ___. She had no adjuvant systemic therapy. In ___, a mammogram showed right breast microcalcifications which were stable. These were in the retroareolar area. On the left side, however, she had an asymmetry. This was superior and posterior aspect of the breast and an ultrasound was performed showing an ill-defined hypoechoic mass measuring about 1 cm. She had a core biopsy of this area in ___. Pathology revealed malignancy, so she underwent a left mastectomy, having had a prior excision and radiation therapy on the left side. Final surgical pathology showed invasive lobular cancer measuring 13 mm. This was histologic grade II. There was a single focus of invasion. There was no lymphovascular invasion. Both hormone receptors were positive while HER-2/neu was negative by immunohistochemistry. No lymph nodes were sampled given the prior lower axillary dissection. Her Oncotype recurrence score was 20. This corresponds to a 13% ___ risk of recurrence assuming ___ years of tamoxifen. We would expect somewhat better results for management of lobular carcinoma with an aromatase inhibitor. On the other hand, this was apparently recurrent disease after prior radiation therapy, which might have diminished tumor sensitivity to additional therapy. We discussed adjuvant treatment, both endocrine therapy and chemo-endocrine therapy. She favored endocrine therapy alone strongly and I felt this was an acceptable choice. Accordingly, anastrozole was started in ___. She recently presented to the ED on ___ with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. This was felt to be related to her gastroparesis. Her CT abdomen/pelvis returned consistent with numerous hepatic and osseous metastases. In the hospital, she underwent a liver biopsy which revealed a carcinoma compatible with a breast primary tumor. Estrogen receptor was positive. HER-2/neu was not assessed. text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Brought in by EMS after being found unconscious at the train station. <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year old homeless ___ male with a history of seizures since the age of ___, who was found unconscious in the train station ___) by EMS tonight. He was apneic with O2 saturation 89% on room air and given 2 mg Narcan with good response. His pupils were reportedly small at that time. On arrival to the ED, oxygen saturation was 97% on room air, BP 145/93, HR 100. ___ 142. Urine tox was found positive for opiates and cocaine, and patient had cocaine in his pocket, per ED record. Multiple pills of unknown identity were found in his pocket - given to police. Negative etoh level. While in the ED, however, the patient had two episodes of upper extremity shaking for which he was given Ativan a total of 4 mg IV. He subsequently became somnolent again with O2 saturation in the ___. He again responded to narcan. A non-contrast head CT was negative for any acute intracranial pathology. He was seen by neurology in the ED who recommended checking a tegretol level then restarting this medication at his last known dose, while using ativan for breakthrough seizures. Last progress note in OMR is from ___ at which time he was prescribed Tegretol 400 mg BID. Patient reports that he is actually on Trileptal (oxcarbazepine) currently, 300 mg in the morning and 600 mg at night. He is followed by Dr. ___ at ___ (probably ___ ___) who prescribes this medication for him. He denies any other medications currently. In terms of seizures, says he has had them since the age of ___ and isn't sure how often he gets them. He does snort cocaine every so often when he gets it from his other homeless friends, but does not do this frequently and seizures occur in the absence of any substance abuse, per the patient. Also has a history of heroin abuse in the past but denies using recently. Was on suboxone for a period of time but last dose was weeks ago. He denies alcohol use. Review of systems is positive for very mild headache, negative for nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or chest pain. He has chronic pain in his left shoulder. He currently can't see because the ED still has his glasses. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1) Seizures; seems to be a primary seizure disorder, despite intermittent substance abuse. Has had them for > ___ years on review of OMR. Has been on neurontin and Tegretol in the past but currently on Trileptal. Followed by Dr. ___ patient. ___) Substance abuse: Urine tox positive for opiates and cocaine. Patient reports infrequent use. 3) Psychiatric disorder: Dr. ___ note from ___ mentions racing thoughts and being on Risperdal 1 mg QHS. 4) Bilateral hernia repairs here in ___ <ALLERGIES> Penicillin leads to convulstions per patient, but itching is listed on prior record. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> He does not know where his family is, or their history. <PHYSICAL EXAM> 98.6, 124/85, 98, 18, 95% on room air. GENERAL: Comfortable appearing ___ male, responding appropriately to all questions, though disoriented. He answers ___ to the year, knows he is in ___. HEENT: Pupils are equal and reactive to light, approx 3 mm. Left conjunctiva hemorrhagic from prior injury (someone punched me on ___ COR: RR, normal rate, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rhonchi, or rales. ABDOMEN: Normoactive bowel sounds, soft, mildly tender to palpation in the lower quadrants bilaterally which he attributes to having to urinate. EXTR: No edema. Left shoulder with limited range of motion secondary to pain, which he says is chronic. NEURO: Please see neurology note for full neuro examination. For me, patient has normal grip stength bilaterally and pupilary exam normal as above. <PERTINENT RESULTS> NON-CONTRAST HEAD CT: FINDINGS: No edema, masses, mass effect or intracranial hemorrhage is noted. The sulci and ventricles are normal in course and configuration. The bone windows do not demonstrate any fracture. Both ethmoid air cells demonstrate mucosal thickening. The left medial orbital wall old fracture deformity is noted. IMPRESSION: 1. No acute intracranial pathology including no intracranial hemorrhage. 2. Old fracture deformity of the left medial orbital wall (Lamina Papyracea). <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Trileptal (oxcarbazepine) 300 mg QAM, 600 mg QPM <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. onisamide 100 mg Capsule Sig: Three (3) Capsule PO at bedtime: Start at TWO capsules nightly for the first two nights, then increase to THREE capsules nightly. Disp
summary: ___ year old homeless male with seizure disorder who was brought in by EMS after being found unconscious in the train station, with urine toxicology positive for opiates and cocaine, and subsequently 2 possible seizures while in the ED characterized by arm shaking. 1) Seizure disorder: Unclear if arm shaking in ED was primary seizure disorder or provoked by likely drug use. Neurology consulted. Recommended pt. be transitioned to zonisamide instead of trileptal given longer half life, lower cost, and longer half life. They also recommended MR of the brain, but the pt. refused this. He agreed to have 24 hour video monitoring and EEG. This was completed, final read pending at time of discharge, however, there was no overt evidence of seizure seen throughout the admission here. Neurology recommended follow up with Dr. ___ as outpatient within twol weeks of leaving the hospital. 2) Substance abuse: pt. denies, but it appears that he is lying about this, as he was found unresponsive with pinpoint pupils, and was revived with narcan; pos. tox screen for cocaine and opiates on arrival to the ED. Addictions and social work consults were initiated, adn he expressed his wishes to have treatment, however, no inpatient treatment was available to be arranged. Additionally, no housing could be arranged. He was provided information about shelters where he could go to stay, however, he states that he has made some arrangements to rent a room, and that he has disability check, some money available for this.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> worsening ___ weakness and foot drop for past few months w/ associated L1 spinal stenosis <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Posterior lumbar decompresion and fusion T12 - L2 with instrumentation <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> REASON FOR CONSULT: pre-op clearance, HTN urgency . CC: progressive ___ weakness . HPI: Mr. ___ is a ___ yoM with right ___ weakness that has progressed over the last few months. He presented to the ED on ___ with worsening of his symptoms over this week. It is felt to be due to L1 cona stenosis, possibly congenital. He denies bladder or bowel incontinence. In the ED, BP was 210's systolic, which was thought to be from anxiety. He has no history of HTN. He initially received PO labetalol in the ED with improvement to 170's-180's systolic. He required doses of IV hydralazine overnight with minimal effect on his BP. He was scheduled for the OR today, but his blood pressure was too elevated and the surgery was deferred until BP could be better controlled. HR has been in the 100's to 120's. This evening, after the patient triggered for systolic BP's running in the 190's to low 200's conistently throughout the day. Patient has been asymptomatic, denying headache, chest pain, shortness of breath, or hematuria. After being triggered, patient received 5mg IV metoprolol and was started on metoprolol 50mg PO BID. He also remains on IV hydralazine Q6 hours standing. When he was seen around 10pm, his blood pressure was 165/112. Prior to this, his blood pressure range for the past 24 hours has been 170/96-200/100, and his HR ranging 103-126. . Patient notes he has been quite anxious since coming into the hospital. He is extremely nervous about the surgery and has a great deal of anxiety with regard to needles and other hospital procedures. He was also quite upset about the rescheduling of his surgery earlier today. His primary team feels that at least some component of his HTN is related to his anxiety. Following the trigger, he also received IVF and has been drinking PO's. His pain is under good control with PO percocets as per the patient. Patient smokes cigarettes, but states that he doesn't think he is having nicotine withdrawal- just that he would like a cigarette because of the stress he is experiencing at present. . Mr. ___ notes that he has been told he has HTN in the past. He states the highest he can remember his SBP ever being is in the 150's, and that it is usually borderline. His outpatient physician informed him that did not need to start on any medications for his blood pressure, and that they would just watch it. . summary: Assessment: ___ yoM with h/o worsening ___ weakness and foot drop for past few months w/ associated L1 spinal stenosis, borderline HTN, resolved hypothyroidism, and 1 episode of hypokalemia in ___ who presented to ___ for posterior lumbar fusion; course complicated by hypertension and hypokalemia #S/p Lumbar Fusion: Pt was referred for surgery after a long course of conservative treatment when he had worsening ___ weakness and foot drop. His surgery was initially postponed due to hypertensive urgency with BP 200/110's. His blood pressure was treated with IV medications and the patient underwent T12/L1 bilateral laminectomy and lumbar fusion on ___. Post-operatively, the patient again had hypertension and some ST changes on EKG. Troponins peaked at 0.57 on ___. The patient's post-operative pain was controlled with narcotics and Tylenol. He was discharged with prescriptions for narcotics as well as physical therapy support at home. #Hypertensive Urgency: The patient reported that he had a history of borderline hypertension but that he never required medications for this. On presentation to ___, his BP was in the 200s/110s. He was treated with IV medications and post-operatively required a nitroprusside drip. The patient was discharged on a regimen of Amlodipine 10 mg qd, Labetalol 200 mg TID, Lisinopril 20 mg qd. Due to the acuity of the patient's presentation, there is concern for secondary causes of hypertension. Renal U/S showed no renal artery stenosis. Plasma levels of renin and aldosterone were pending at the time of discharge as were urine metanephrines. Serum metanephrines, however, were elevated. He was seen by endocrinology, who will follow him as an outpatient. #NSTEMI: The patient's telemetry showed ST wave changes in the PACU. EKG showed changes concerning for ischemia. Troponins returned elevated and peaked at 0.57. The patient was started on aspirin 325

summary: The patient presented to the Emergency Department on ___ with a chief complaint of abdominal pain and nausea. On physical exam, the patient had a mildly distended abdomen with tenderness and bulging at the upper part of his recent incision. His labs revealed a WBC of 16K. Lact 1.3. Other labs were unremarkable. A Ct scan was obtained which showed a partial/early SBO with a relative transition point in RLQ and a 3.6 cm cystic lesion in the subcutaneous tissues underlying skin staples compatible with postsurgical seroma. The patient has no clinical SBO and his abdomen was soft. He had no BM on the day of admission. The patient had pain around what seemed clinically and radiologically as infected seroma (has air on foci of air in the seroma itself) and leukocytosis. The patient was admitted to the ACS service to serially monitor his abdominal exam and properly care for the seroma that was present in the area of incision from his recent operation. He was advanced back to a regular diet and his pertinent labs were monitored. Prior to his discharge, the patient complained of abdominal pain that occurred after he would eat. There was no objective evidence of pain, or a source of where the pain could be coming from and chronic pain was consulted. They recommended 2mg tizanidine q8hrs prn of which the patient was provided a prescription. Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization; pain was managed with oral medications. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Ambulation was encouraged throughout hospitalization. GI/GU/FEN: The patient was placed on a regular diet. The patient stated his pain comes several days after he eats. The patient was passing flatus. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored. Upon discharge, the patient still complained of pain but there was no objective evidence that this could be correlated
