summary: ___ otherwise healthy female presents with left preseptal cellulitis. # Preseptal cellulitis: Patient with preseptal cellulitis of left periorbital area. This had progressed on outpatient Bactrim. She had ID of fluid collection with plastic surgery with cultures which grew MSSA. She was initially treated with IV vancomycin/unasyn and then transitioned to nafcillin after cultures resulted. She was transitioned to dicloxacillin for outpatient treatment to complete total 2 week course. She will continue packing wound bid at home and follow up with plastic surgery. # Parotid nodules: On CT patient was incidentally found to have heterogeneous parotid glands with enhancing soft tissue nodules, findings suspicious for lymphoepithelial lesions concerning for Sjogren's versus HIV. Patient reported she had previously been told she may have Sjogren's or rheumatoid arthritis. HIV test was negative here. Recommend she follow up outpatient with dedicated MRI neck as well as with her rheumatologist to determine whether any further workup or treatment is indicated. # TRANSTIIONAL ISSUES: -CT with heterogeneous parotid glands with enhancing soft tissue nodules, findings suspicious for lymphoepithelial lesions, which can be seen in the setting of Sjogren's syndrome. Recommend MRI neck in next several weeks for dedicated evaluation. -Recommend continued outpatient rheum follow up for above. -Patient to continue PO dicloxacillin for total 2 week course.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Obstructive Jaundice <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ERCP Sphincterotomy Stent to CBD <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Patient is a ___ year old man with HTN, HLD, CAD (s/p MI ___ years ago, distal disease, managed medically), cholecystectomy ___ years ago), who was admitted for observation after ERCP. He initially presented to his PCP with several weeks of fatigue, pruritus, anorexia, dark urine and 8 lbs of weight loss. Denied fever/chills, abdominal pain, change in bowel habits or color. On ROS he does note that for the past several months he has had difficulty swallowing, characterized as feeling of food (both solid and liquid) getting stuck in his chest. Denies difficulty initiating or completing a swallow. His PCP has evaluated this with a barium swallow (which was normal). An EGD has been planned next week. He was referred to the ___ ER on ___, where he was noted to have stable vital signs and mild jaundice on exam. Labs indicating of obstructive jaundice: ALP 384, AST 80, ALT 151, Total Bili 17, Direct Bili 13. Otherwise normal WBC. An abdominal CT scan showed distal CBD stricture with proximal dilation to 16 mm and IHD dilation. He was referred for ERCP to ___ today. He underwent an ERCP and sphincterotomy. A short distal CBD stricture was found and a plastic stent was left. On arrival to floor, he was feeling well, VSS. Family at bedside. ROS otherwise negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Hypertension Hyperlipidemia Coronary Artery Disease Past Surgical History: Cholecystectomy (___) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of bowel disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 98, 143/88, 51, 16, 99% RA Gen: Pleasant, cooperative, NAD HEENT: MMM, NCAT, icteric sclera Neck: No JVD CV: RRR, normal S1 S2, no m/r/g Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally Abdomen: Soft, non tender, non distended, normoactive bowel sounds. No rebound tenderness or guarding. No organomegaly. Extremities: 2 DP pulses, no edema Skin: No rashes MSK: No joint swelling Neuro: Moves all 4 extremities grossly <PERTINENT RESULTS> Abdominal CT scan: Distal CBD stricture with proximal dilation to 16 mm and IHD dilation. ERCP (___): Impression: Scout film was normal. -A stenosis of the major papilla was noted. -Initial cannulation was attempted with a sphincterotome but due to the presence of very tight biliary opening, cannulation was not achieved. -A second cannulation attempt was performed with a 5,4,3 cannula -Using a smaller caliber cannula cannulation was achieved and we were able to pass the guidewire through the distal CBD tight stricture. -Contrast medium was injected resulting in complete opacification. -On initial cholangiogram a single shelf-like stricture that was 10 mm long was seen at the lower third of the common bile duct, the common bile duct and common hepatic duct were dilated up to 16 mm. -Based on cholangiogram finding a decision to proceed with placement of biliary plastic stent was made. -Due to the presence of tight opening of the major papilla and the high risk of post ERCP pancreatisis with placement of biliary stent without performing a sphincterotomy, a dicision to perform a very small sphincterotomy was made even though the patient is on chronic treatment with blood thinners. -A very small sphincterotomy was performed in the 12 o'clock position using a sphincterotome over an existing guidewire. -No evidence of post sphincterotomy bleeding was noted. -Post sphincterotomy brushing from the stricture was performed -A ___ biliary plastic stent was placed. -Post biliary stent placement a good contrast drainage was noted both endoscopically and fluoroscopically. (cannulation) -Multiple dodenal erosions <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Lisinpril 30mg Carvedilol 3.125mg BID Pravastatin 20mg ASA 81mg Plavix 75mg <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 4 Days RX *ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice daily Disp #*8 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 3. Carvedilol 3.125 mg PO BID 4. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 5. Lisinopril 30 mg PO DAILY 6. Pravastatin 20 mg PO QPM <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Biliary stricture resulting in obstructive jaundice <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure looking after you, Mr. ___. As you know, you were admitted with an obstruction of your bile ducts. You went for a procedure to look at your bile ducts, called an ERCP. You were found to have a narrowing of your bile ducts, which was treated with a plastic stent and a small incision to open the stricture and relieve the obstruction. You were monitored following the procedure and did well with a regular diet. By ___ you were deemed
summary: Patient is a ___ year old man with HTN, HLD, CAD (s/p MI ___ years ago, distal disease, managed medically), cholecystectomy ___ years ago), who originally presented with obstructive jaundice likely due to biliary stricture of unknown etiology. He underwent ERCP on ___, during which a single shelf-like stricture 10 mm long was seen at the lower third of the common bile duct with dilation of the upstream common bile and common hepatic ducts. A plastic biliary stent was placed, and due to tight opening of the major papilla, a very small sphincterotomy was also made. No evidence of post sphincterotomy bleeding was noted. Post sphincterotomy brushing from the stricture was performed, results of which were consistent with Adenocarcinoma. Multiple dodenal erosions were also noted on ERCP. The following morning he went for CT A/P pancreas protocol, which showed a 1.4 cm mass versus focal edema from recent ERCP at the level of the ampulla, and Minimal left intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation with expected pneumobilia s/p CBD stent placement. No pancreatic duct dilation was seen. Post-procedure pt was advanced gradually to a regular diet and tolerated this without difficulty. He was discharge to home and will follow-up with the pancreatic ___ clinic on ___.

The cardiomediastinal silhouette is moderately enlarged, unchanged. Athersclerotic calcifications in the aortic arch are unchanged. There is persistent enlargement of the main pulmonary artery. IMPRESSION: 1. Right chest pacemaker lead projects over the right ventricle. 2. Interval improvement in pulmonary vascular congestion and edema compared to ___. ___ TAVR Report (TRANSFEMORAL) Catheter Placement, ___ Fr Sheath right Femoral Vein Catheter Placement, ___ Fr Sheath right Femoral Artery Catheter Placement, ___ Fr Sheath Right Femoral Artery Aortography, Ascending Aorta Implanted Valve: 29 mm EVOLUT PRO The case complexity required a multidisciplinary approach with Cardiac Surgery and Interventional Cardiology. Vascular access was obtained in right common femoral using vascular ultrasound techniques. The right femoral artery was used to advance a ___ Fr Pigtail catheter to the non coronary sinus. A ___ Fr temporary pacemaker was placed in the right ventricle from the right femoral vein through a long ___ Fr sheath. Vascular access was obtained in the left femoral artery using vascular ultrasound guidance. A ___ sheath was placed Unfractionated heparin was given to achieve an ACT > 250 seconds. The aortic valve was crossed with a Straight wire and the AL1 was advanced into the ventricle. A Pigtail catheter was exchanged and positioned in the LV apex. Simultaneous left ventricular and aortic pressures were recorded and demonstrated severe aortic stenosis. Initial pressures Mean gradient: 45 mmHg The 0.035 exchange J wire was exchanged for a 0.035 Confida wire and the Pigtail was removed. A 29 mm Evolut Pro with proper fluoroscopic loading was then advanced to the aortic valve. The valve was deployed under TTE and fluoro guidance and using aortography and placement of a Pigtail catheter was used to demonstrate the position of the Evolut 3 mm below the non coronary sinus and 4 mm below the left coronary sinus. TTE showed moderate AI, dilation was performed using a 24mm True balloon with rapid ventricular pacing. After final deployment, there
summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with a PMH of HFrEF, severe AS, Hyperlipidemia, and Type II NSTEMI, who presented on ___ for elective TAVR which was complicated by annular rupture/VSD and complete block requiring permanent pacemaker placement. #Complete Heart Block: Patient developed complete heart block after TAVR ___. summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ with a PMHx of breast cancer, HTN, depression, neuropathy, LBP, gastritis, esophagitis, who presented from clinic to the ED, with complaint of epigastric pain; concern for acute pancreatitis. # Epigastric pain/Mild Pancreatitis She initially presented with epigastric pain radiating to her flanks and back, along with slightly elevated LFTs and elevated lipase, most consistent with acute pancreatitis. Her vital signs were normal and she appeared well ___ score 1, BISAP score 0). She was put on maintenance IVF and her pain resolved with PO hydromorphone. CT scan showed no evidence of obstruction, appendicitis, pacreatitis, or colitis. It did show pericholecystic fluid and gallbladder wall thickening with no evidence of stones, thought to be caused by the pancreatitis. There was some concern for biliary disease, but her pain resolved on the day after admission and her LFTs were normal. RUQ ultrasound showed gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and free fluid around the gallbladder, but no gallbladder distention or classic inflammatory signs. ___ sign was negative. The cause of her pancreatitis was unclear, but may have been due gallstone pancreatitis with the stone passing and her pain resolving. Other possible etiologies included medication-induced pancreatitis. DDx for abd pain included cholecystitis but there was no conclusive evidence of this. The morning after admission, her diet was advanced and all of patient's symptoms resolved. She was not having any pain at discharge. # History of breast cancer She was continued on her home anastrazole for her history of breast cancer. # HTN Her blood pressure was well-controlled on her home amlodipine. # Depression She was continued on her home venlafaxine and clonazepam for her history of depression. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: # CODE: Full Code # CONTACT: ___, ___, ___ - Please evaluate for recurrence of abdominal pain at follow-up - If abdominal symptoms recur, please consider repeat RUQ US (concern would be for cholecystitis) - If

summary: The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on ___ for continued fevers of unknonw origin. During this admission she was febrile to 103 with her temperature rangin from 99 to 103. She was started on IV vanc, cipro, and flagyl, and her cultures from an abdominal seroma that was drained by ___ came back as having no growth to date but having 2 PMNC. She was seen by ID while inhouse and they recommended having the patient stay inhouse for a thorough work up. The patient refused and will be discharged to home on a short course of antibiotics via a PICC and will follow up with both Dr ___ ID. Neuro: Patient's pain was well controlled with oral pain medications. CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. GI/GU: The patient was given IV fluids before her ___ guided drainage until tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, which was tolerated well. Intake and output were closely monitored. ID: The patient was started on IV vanc, cipro, and flagyl, then switched to PO cipro and flagyl on on HD 5. The patient's temperature was closely watched while inhouse and she was afebrile for 24 hours at the time of discharge. She will go home with a PICC line in place and on IV antibiotics. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. At the time of discharge on HD 6, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. Given her reluctance to stay in the hospital she will be discharged to home with IV antibiotics, with close follow up with bith Dr ___ ID.

summary: SSESSMENT  PLAN: ___ man with a history of panhypopituitarism, intracranial hemorrhage, erectile dysfunction, seizure disorder, and history of pulmonary embolism, who presents with pneumonia. # Pneumonia: Likely bacterial given high fevers, focal infiltrate on CXR, productive cough, and flu swab negative. Patient was treated with ceftriaxone/azithromycin with quick improvement of symptoms. He was transitioned to PO levoquin without recurrence of fevers while being monitored. Additionally, he was given stress dose steroids given chronic prednisone use (100 mg hydrocortisone q 8 hrs) then put on a 6 day pred taper upon discharge. # GPC Bacteremia- strep pneumo grew from ___ bottles. Received ___ doses of vancomycin empirically before speciation. Decision was made to transition to PO levoquin (given lack of data for IV antibiotics being superior for POs in S. Pneumo bacteremia) and he was monitored for over 24 hours on PO abx without recurrence of fevers, cough, or any signs of clinical decompensation. # Anemia- stable and no e/o active bleeding; however, seems worse from prior. Normocytic. Iron studies sent consistent with anemia of chronic disease. Of note, ferritin very elevated over ___. No signs of hemolysis # Hyponatremia: Acute on chronic. Likely hypovolemic on top of chronic chronic adrenal insufficiency. Legionella is also a possibility. Had volume challenge in the ED and on floor with resolution. # Panhypopituitarism -continued topical testosterone, PO levothyroxine -steroids managed as above # Seizure Disorder -not on any AEDs # Hx of PE: Thought to be from testosterone replacement. His dose was tailored down earlier in the year -hep sub q was given for ppx #Osteopenia -continued vitd and calcium TRANSITIONAL ISSUES -Pt reported a subacute onset of dyspnea on exertion (well before the pneumonia occurred). Despite his testosterone replacement and history of DVT, chronic thromboembolic disease seemed unlikely given a very low Well

Recent medication changes is that her metformin was stopped due to rash, losartan increased to bid and lisinopril stopped ___ cough) Admission Vitals in ED: 84 169/79 18 100; received 10 units of regular insulin in ED <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> #DM, type 2, complicated by retinopathy (s/p laser on left), microalbuminuria #HTN #Breast mass, removed in ___- benign #Colon polyps- hypreplastic and adenomatous, removed in ___, due for repeat in ___ #Right knee surgery (meniscal tear) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> mother, brother deceased, both had dm also has another living brother and sister with diabetes father died from pancreatic cancer no family hx of anemia or colon CA <PHYSICAL EXAM> T 98.4 bp 180/100 p 92 r20 100% RA, glu 196 wt 208lb Gen pleasant woman in nad HEENT somewhat pale conjunctiva, o/p clear, poor dentition Neck no ___, supple; no axillary ___ cta bil, no wheezes or ronchi CV rrr no m/r/g Abd soft nt nd nabs Ext no edema, no rashes Neuro alert and oriented, nonfocal <PERTINENT RESULTS> WBC-8.8 RBC-3.87* Hgb-7.3*# Hct-25.8*# MCV-67*# MCH-18.9*# MCHC-28.5*# RDW-17.7* Plt ___ Glucose-350* UreaN-22* Creat-0.9 Na-137 K-4.7 Cl-101 HCO3-27 AnGap-14 ALT-22 AST-27 LD(LDH)-196 AlkPhos-79 TotBili-0.2 Iron-19* Ret Man-2.3* calTIBC-562 ___ Ferritn-4.6* TRF-432* <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Losartan 50 mg po bid HCT 25 mg po qd Insulin levemir 18U q am and 6U q pm Insulin sliding scale ASA 81 mg daily Calcium 500mg vitamin B complex <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. losartan 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 2. hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 3. B complex vitamins Capsule Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily). 4. calcium carbonate 200 mg (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable PO DAILY (Daily). 5. Levemir 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: as directed Subcutaneous twice a day: 18 units in the morning; 6 units in the evening. 6. ferrous sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a day. Disp: *90 Tablet(s)* Refills: *5* 7. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day. Disp: *60 Capsule(s)* Refills: *5* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> 1. Anemia, iron deficiency 2. Diabetes, type II 3. Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted with after your blood counts were noted to be quite low, consistent with anemia. In addition, your iron levels were quite low, which is likely the cause for your anemia. You will need to have a repeat colonoscopy and likey upper endoscopy this week. Dr. ___ will call you to schedule. In addition, a prescription for oral iron supplements have been given. You should take this tablet three time a day to get adequate iron. Given that iron often causes contipation, a prescription for a stool softener has also been given. You may require additional constipation medications if this is a problem. Until you undergo your endoscopies this week, do NOT take your aspirin.
summary: 1. Anemia, iron deficiency. Presented with HCT 24, down from most recent normal value in ___. Given ferritin <10 and MCV in ___, this is iron deficiency. She reports no hematochezia or melena and her only abdominal pain is lower. Discussed with her outpatient gastroenterologist who will schedule her for an ___ this week. Prescriptions for iron and docusate were given. I asked that she hold aspirin until her endoscopies. Her indication is primary prevention in a patient with diabets. 2. Dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. Likely related to iron deficiency anemia. No chest pain. Treatment as #1. 3. Diabetes, type 2, uncontrolled with complications. Continued home regimen.

Pop, ___, DP: no signal ON DISCHARGE: VS: T: 98.9 HR: 80 BP: 100/64 RR: 20 O2Sat: 100%RA GEN - NAD, awake/alert ___ - RRR PULM - CTAB ABD - S/NT/ND EXTREM - warm/dry, 2 pedal pulses b/l; incisions C/D/I <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 01: 43PM BLOOD WBC-11.0 RBC-4.53* Hgb-14.3 Hct-41.0 MCV-90 MCH-31.6 MCHC-35.0 RDW-13.6 Plt ___ ___ 01: 15AM BLOOD WBC-15.8* RBC-5.25 Hgb-16.2 Hct-46.3 MCV-88 MCH-30.9 MCHC-35.0 RDW-13.7 Plt ___ ___ 01: 15AM BLOOD Neuts-73.4* ___ Monos-3.0 Eos-0.4 Baso-0.3 ___ 01: 15AM BLOOD ___ PTT-20.9* ___ ___ 01: 43PM BLOOD Glucose-233* UreaN-11 Creat-1.0 Na-130* K-4.2 Cl-93* HCO3-28 AnGap-13 ___ 01: 15AM BLOOD Glucose-219* UreaN-17 Creat-1.1 Na-138 K-5.1 Cl-98 HCO3-29 AnGap-16 ___ 01: 43PM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-3.4 Mg-2.0 Cholest-209* ___ 01: 43PM BLOOD Triglyc-180* HDL-40 CHOL/HD-5.2 LDLcalc-133* CTA ABDOMEN WITH RUNOFF (___): The abdominal aorta is normal in caliber and its main branches are widely patent. Accessory bilateral renal arteries are noted. Minimal calcified plaque is seen at the bifurcation of the left common iliac artery (3A: 104). The right common iliac, internal iliac, external iliac, common femoral, superficial femoral, profunda femoris, popliteal, peroneal, posterior tibial, and anterior tibial arteries are patent. There is a 3.8-cm segment occlusion of the left common femoral artery originating 1.7 cm distal to the takeoff of the left inferior epigastric artery (402: 42). Reconstitution of the left common femoral artery is seen at the level of its bifurcation into the superficial femoral artery and profunda femoris artery. The left superficial femoral, popliteal, peroneal, and proximal portions of the posterior tibial and anterior tibial arteries are patent. There is tapering of the left anterior tibial artery at a level approximately 6.5 cm above the tibiotalar joint (___: ___) with distal nonvisualization of the anterior tibial or dorsalis pedis arteries. Similarly, there is tapering of the left posterior tibial artery at a level 11 cm above the tibiotalar joint (3A: 410) with subsequent nonvisualization of the artery in the lower leg or foot. ABDOMEN CT: The superior portion of the abdomen was not included on this study. The visualized portion of the liver is unremarkable. There is no intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation. The portal vein is patent. The gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands, kidneys, stomach, small bowel, and colon are unremarkable. There is no free fluid or free air in the abdomen. No pathologically enlarged abdominal lymph nodes are seen. PELVIS CT: The bladder and prostate are grossly unremarkable. There is no free fluid in the pelvis. No pathologically enlarged pelvic lymph nodes are seen. BONE WINDOW: Aside from mild degenerative changes of the thoracolumbar spine, the visualized osseous structures are unremarkable. IMPRESSION: 1. 3.8-cm segment occlusion of the right common femoral artery originating 1.7 cm distal to the takeoff of the left inferior epigastric artery. There is distal reconstitution of the left common femoral artery at the level of its bifurcation. 2. Tapering and eventual nonvisualization of the anterior and posterior tibial arteries at the level of the lower leg, likely secondary to slow flow as opposed to distal emboli. <
summary: The patient was admitted to the vascular surgery service after CTA confirmed occlusion of the L CFA. He was immediately started on a heparin drip and prepped for the OR. He underwent an left femoral artery thromboendarterectomy and saphenous vein patch angioplasty. Please see the operative note for more details. There were no complications and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Postop, the patient was admitted to the ___ where he was closely monitored with frequent pulse checks. He received perioperative antibiotics. On POD1 he was allowed to get out of bed and he was allowed to have clears, which were quickly advanced to a regular diabetic diet. His foley was discontinued and he was able to void without issue. His pain was initially controlled with IV narcotics and he was transitioned to oral pain meds once he was tolerating adequate oral intake. His home medications were restarted. Given the unknown etiology of his thrombus, an echo was ordered. However, given that it was the weekend, it was not performed while the patient was in house. He was therefore given instructions to follow-up with his PCP to ensure he gets appropriately worked up. His PCP was called (Dr. ___ ___  ___) and a message was left. Additionally, a cholesterol panel was checked and his total cholesterol and triglycerides were noted to be elevated. He was therefore started on simvastatin. Although our preference was to keep the patient until after his echo was performed, the patient was impatient to go home. It was therefore decided to discharge him with the understanding that he should get an echo done soon. The vascular team will try to reach his PCP again ___ morning ___ to set this up.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Anorexia <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ERCP (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o M with PMHx of CAD, HTN, who presents for ERCP for evaluation of approximately 1 month of anorexia and weight loss. Patient also reports nausea and vomiting with any PO intake. He denies any significant abdominal pain, however. Labs have been notable for a marked cholestatic LFT pattern with alk phos ___. U/S reportedly shows extensive intra and extra hepatic ductal dilatation and probable pancreatic mass as the cause. ERCP today showed esophageal ulcers and mid CBD stricture. Sphincterotomy was performed, and metal stent was placed. Cytology samples were sent. Please refer to full ERCP report below for further details. On arrival to the floor, the patient reports feeling generally ill for several weeks. He is not able to provide further details. He does endorse feeling weak. ROS - As above. Denies headache, lightheadedness, chest pain, shortness of breath, diarrhea, urinary symptoms. A small blood clot was seen at one of these ulcers. Few small ulcers were seen in the distal esophagus as well - Normal major papilla - Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and deep with a sphincterotome - Limited pancreatogram showed normal main PD - A 1 cm high grade stricture was seen in the mid-CBD. The proximal CBD was dilated. The cystic duct was dilated. - Sphincterotomy was performed in the 12 o'clock position using a sphincterotome - Cytology samples were obtained using a brush from the CBD stricture - A 6cm by 10mm Wallflex fully covered biliary stent (REF ___; LOT ___ was placed successfully across the CBD stricture - Free flow of bile was seen after stent placement - Otherwise normal ercp to third part of the duodenum Abdominal Ultrasound (___) Diffuse severe intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation and pancreatic ductal dilatation, with double duct sign and Courvoisier gallbladder, secondary to obstructing mass in the head of the pancreas at the proximal pancreatic duct. Suggestion of loss of fat plane between this mass and the SMV. Recommend GI consultation for further evaluation. Common bile duct brushing: ATYPICAL. Occasional groups of atypical ductal cells in a background of benign ductal cells. No significant inflammation is seen. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires futher investigation. 1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q8H: PRN pain 2. Hydrocortisone Cream 2.5% 1 Appl TP APPLY TO AFFECTED AREAS TWICE A DAY 3. Erythromycin 0.5% Ophth Oint 0.5 in BOTH EYES QID 1/ 2inch ___ at bedtime 4. Labetalol 200 mg PO BID 5. Docusate Sodium 200 mg PO TID: PRN constipation 6. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY: PRN constipation 7. NIFEdipine CR 90 mg PO DAILY 8. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 9. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL PRN chest pain make take 1 sl every five minutes x 3 doses 10. TraMADOL (Ultram) 50 mg PO BID 11.
summary: ___ y/o M with PMHx of CAD, HTN, here for ERCP for evaluation of several week of anorexia and weight loss. # Anorexia, Weight Loss: Given cholestatic labs as well as abdominal ultrasound findings, very concerning for pancreatic malignancy. ERCP showed CBD stricture. Pt underwent s/p sphx and stent placement. He tolerated procedure well. His diet was advanced without problems on the morning after his ERCP. He was initially started on IV zosyn prophylactically but was transitionted to PO cipro once his diet was advanced. He was discharged to complete a 7 day course of antibiotics. Cytology was pending at the time of discharge but ultimately returned as atypical cells. This will need to be reviewed with him at his follow-up appointment. He was instructed to avoid blood thinning medications, including aspirin, plavix, NSAIDS, coumadin for 5 days. # CAD: No active chest pain. Aspirin on hold as above. # HTN: Continued home labetalol and nifedipine. Home lisinopril has been on hold per ___ records. # HLD: Continuted atorvastatin. # B12 Deficiency: Continued home B12 repletion.

She was admitted for initation of ___ round of chemotherapy with R-EPOCH (Rituxan, Etoposide, Prednisone, Oncovorin, Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin) for mediastinal grey zone lymphoma. # Lymphoma - chemotherapy was given with ___: rituxan, - Etoposide D1-4, - Doxorubicin D1-4 - Vincristine D1-4 - Cyclophosphamide D5. - filgrastim at home starts d7 (___) through count recovery to ANC > 1500 after nadir. summary: Briefly, ___ M with h/o AIDs, HPV with h/o perianal disease and carcinoma in situ; p/w rectal pain and bleeding. #. Rectal/anal pain: -The patient did not have any more episodes of BRBPR during this admission, and experienced near complete resolution of his rectal pain. His hematocrit remained stable throughout the hospitalization, and he did develop any new GI symptoms. He underwent a CT Pelvis with oral contrast and direct visualization with anoscopy in the ER. Neither showed any masses and no active bleeding was seen on anoscopy. Pt was then seen by GI Consult after inpatient admission, and they performed a flexible sigmoidoscopy the following day, which showed no active bleeding, no masses or lesions up to 25cm. Biopsies were taken and sent for pathology and culture, and the patient will be contacted by GI with the results. #. HIV/AIDS: As of ___: CD4 582, VL < 50. - Continue home kaletra and truvada. #. Pulmonary hypertension: Stable. - Continue home sildenafil. #. Depression / Anxiety: Stable. - Continue home citalopram and lorazepam. #. Insomnia: - Continue home zolpidem. #. GERD: - Continue home ranitidine. #. DVT Prophylaxis: Ambulation #. Precautions: History of VRE #. CODE: Full

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / doxycycline / erythromycin base / clindamycin / azithromycin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> syncope <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS: ___ female with a history of CAD, seizures, CVA, dementia, multiple falls presenting after an unwitnessed syncopal episode. To the ED patient reports that she remembers waking up in the middle of the night leaving her bed, next thing she remembers is being on the floor, unclear when she fell or how long she may been down for. She returned to bed and when she woke this morning she reported right-sided rib pain and pain in her left humerus. Upon my interview she reports that she remembers going to the bathroom and falling when she stood up because she slipped on urine. She says she was lightheaded after the fall, but not before. She does not remember if she lost consciousness but remembers screaming for help. No pain in her neck, no headaches no visual changes. Patient reports that she has been having persistent, intermittent chest pains for a while, but she cannot say exactly for how long. She says her CP is worse when she exerts herself. She does not think her chest pain has changed in quality or intensity. Reports she has seizures occasionally, cannot tell if this felt like a seizure or not, denies feeling obvious aura beforehand. She says her last seizure was about a month ago. She is not sure if the fall she had was related to a seizure. Denies urinary symptoms, had cough at baseline which has not changed in quality, no diarrhea. Was recently discharged on ___ for after having a hypoxic episode prior to an esophageal ultrasound and was admitted for workup. She was observed overnight and had one episode where her oxygenation dropped to the 80's for 10- 15 seconds. She responded well to ___ of oxygen via nasal cannula. On review of records from last admission in ___, she was found to have frequent episodes of oxygen desaturation at night. She was evaluated by pulmonary at that time who suggested a sleep study as symptoms were classic for obstructive sleep apnea prior to discharge, she had a sleep study arranged but has not gotten it yet. In the ED - Initial vitals: 97.4 58 150/58 18 98% RA - EKG: T-wave inversions in lead III, consistent with priors. No acute ischemic changes. - Labs/studies notable for: Troponin x2 <0.01 Lactate 1.3 143 100 32 ----------<92 4.3 28 1.5 8.4>11.6/36.8<273 UA bland UCx, BCx pending CXR: The lungs are clear without consolidation, effusion, or edema. Head CT: No acute hemorrhage or calvarial fracture. L Humerus Xray: No acute fracture of the humerus. - Patient was given: ___ 12: 10 IVF NS ___ Started 125 mL/hr 1L - Vitals on transfer: 60 145/40 18 94% RA REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations. On further review of systems, denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies exertional buttock or calf pain. Denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - PE (not on AC) - CKD - CAD s/p CABG ___ (single vessel LIMA-LAD), s/p PCI to RCA (DES to RCA in ___ - Type 2 DM on insulin - CVA - HTN - HLD - Polyneuropathy - Seizure disorder on AED - Glaucoma - GERD - Anemia - Depression - Anxiety - R eye blindness - C. diff colitis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father, ___, deceased: MI (___) and CHF Mother, ___, deceased: DMII, ESRD, Alcoholism Sister, ___, living: Depression, thromboembolic strok Sister, ___, deceased: Lung cancer, smoker Brother, ___, living: ___ Disease Son, ___, living: Polysubstance abuse Son, ___, living: Healthy <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: --= VS: ___ 1637 BP: 171/75 HR: 66 RR: 18 O2 sat: 94% O2 delivery: ra GENERAL: Alert and interactive. In no acute distress. HEENT: NT/AC. Surgical pupil on R. L pupil round and reactive to light. EOMI. Sclera anicteric and without injection. Moist mucous membranes. Oropharynx is clear. NECK: Supple. CARDIAC: RRR, audible S1 and S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops appreciated. LUNGS: Slight inspiratory stridor likely due to opening her upper airway when breathing. Otherwise clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rhonchi or rales. No increased work of breathing. BACK: No spinous process tenderness. No CVA tenderness. ABDOMEN: Soft, nondistended. Mild R
summary: ___ female with a history of CAD, seizures, CVA, dementia, multiple falls presenting after an unwitnessed syncopal episode. Likely mechanical in nature. Was found to have low oxcarbazepine levels and her dose was uptitrated. #Syncope #Fall: etiology is unclear, likely mechanical fall vs seizure since patient reports slipping on urine in the bathroom. Head CT and L humerus Xray with no acute fracture. Seizure is also a possibility since oxcarbazepine level was found to be low at 6 on ___. Cardiac etiology unlikely given flat troponins, EKG unchanged. Infectious causes less likely given bland urine, clear CXR, no diarrhea. A stress test was not needed as no cardiac symptoms and normal stress test ___. Given that the oxcarbazepine level was low, we spoke with Dr ___ seizure doctor) and she recommended going up on the dose to 600 BID but did not recommend an EEG. ___: Cr on arrival 1.5, baseline 1.0. Possibly due to low PO intake which could have also exacerbated the syncope above. s/p 1L fluids in the ED and one more fluid on the floor. Cr at discharge 1.2. #Seizure disorder: says last seizure 1 mo ago, but not sure if this episode related to seizure. Last oxcarbazepine level checked on ___ while taking 450mg BID. Talked to Dr ___ advised increasing her oxcarbazepine to 600mg BID. Continued home Levetiracetam 750 mg PO Q12H. Had patient f/u with Dr ___ on discharge #CAD: Continue home aspirin 81, atorvastatin 20 and Furosemide 20 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY #Sleep Apnea: recent admission for hypoxia to the ___ lasting seconds prior to esophageal US before spontaneously recovering with brief oxygen via nasal cannula. is supposed to get sleep study as an outpatient. Kept on ___ of supplemental oxygen with nasal cannula to O2 sat goal of 92-94% at night and during day time (especially during naps) as needed. Continue Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU DAILY

summary: ___ year old male with h/o chronic pancreatitis thought to be secondary triglycerides, pancreatic pseudocysts and CBD stricture s/p stent who presents with increased RUQ pain and elevated LFT's. . Pt initially presented to an OSH and given location of abdominal pain in the RUQ and elevated LFT's, he was transferred to ___ for consideration of ERCP. Of note, he did not have fever and his WBC was only minimally elevated at 11K. Following transfer, he was evaluated by the ___ team, and he was noted to have a positive ___ sign on physical exam, suggesting abdominal wall or MSK pain rather than intra-abd process. His LFT's further downtrended and his repeat RUQ US at ___ showed stable CBD. As such, the ___ team did not feel that there was active biliary obstruction and did not pursue further endoscopy. A CT Abd/Pelvis was obtained, given that the previous hospitalization at ___ had noted possible ileitis on CT scan. Repeat CT scan on this hospitalization showed no evidence of ileitis based on preliminary review of the CT scan. As such, patient was treated with just conservative and supportive measures with improvement in his symptoms. He was able to tolerate a full PO diet and passed a bowel movement. He is being discharged to home with no adjustments in his medications. He should follow-up as previously scheduled with the Hepatobiliary Surgery Clinic to discuss possible Whipple for his biliary stricture and pancreatic pseudocyst. . Transitional Issues: 1. f/u with Hepatobiliary Surgery next week to discuss possible Whipple. 2. PENDING STUDIES AT TIME OF DISCHARGE: ### ___ Blood culture x 1 set: NGTD, final PENDING ### ___ CT Abd/Pelvis: final read PENDING

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after undergoing total vaginal hysterectomy and vault suspension for cervical dysplasia. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course is detailed as follows. Immediately postoperatively, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid and toradol. Her diet was advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to Tylenol, ibuprofen, and oxycodone. On post-operative day #1, her urine output was adequate so her Foley catheter was removed and she voided spontaneously. By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with ___ in place for Lovenox injections (for family history of deep venous thrombosis), and with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

He presented to ___ where his Hct was 31.8 and was discharged for PCP ___. PCP was not ___ till next week. In the meantime, his frequency of stool decreased to daily and stools are now more formed. Abdominal pain is dull, epigastric/RUQ with intermittent sharp pains. He denies any chronic NSAID use, has sporadic EtOH use (2 drinks/month). Does use antac periodically for reflux symptoms and has been under increased stress at school. He has been able to take good PO. In the ED intial vitals were: 5 98.6 84 140/67 16 98% - Labs were significant for: Hct 31. WBC 3.5. normal coags, normal chem 7. normal UA. He was given pantoprazole 40mg IV x1. Stomach: Normal stomach. Duodenum: Single clean-based ulcer in the duodenal ulcer with surrounding edema/erythema. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. This patient is not taking any preadmission medications <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H RX *pantoprazole [Protonix] 40 mg 1 tablet,delayed release (___) by mouth twice daily Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary diagnosis: Upper GI bleed Duodenal ulcer <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ Deaconess You were admitted to the hospital due to black stools and concern for bleeding in your stomach. You had an endoscopy where the GI doctors looked in your stomach and they found that you had an ulcer in your duodenum (small intestine) which was likely the cause of the bleeding. They took biopsies of the ulcer and will be getting in touch with you by phone about the results. You will need to continue a high dose acid blocking medication twice daily for at least 6 weeks. Please avoid alcohol, NSAID medications (like ibuprofen), caffeine, acidic and spicy foods.
summary: ___ y/o M with no significant PMHx who presents with 4 days of dark stool and epigastric abdominal pain. ACTIVE ISSUES BY PROBLEM: # GI bleed: Patient with dark stools and melena on exam, thought to be from upper GI source. Hct remained essentially stable -- was 31 at ___ earlier in the week, 31 on admission, and 29.8 on day of discharge. EGD was performed and showed clean based linear ulcer in the duonedum that was no longer actively bleeding. He had no risk factors for bleeding -- minimal alcohol use, no recent NSAIDs -- so the lesion is highly suspicious for H pylori infection. Biopsies were taken and will be followed up by GI, who plans to call the patient with the results. He will need to remain on pantoprazole 40mg BID for 6 weeks. He will follow up with his new PCP and should have symptoms and CBC assessed at that time. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Please check CBC at visit with PCP to ensure it has remained stable - Biopsies pending on discharge, will be followed up by ___ GI

His pain was well controlled with a dilaudid PCA. He was hemodynamically stable with a GCS of 15 thereafter and was transferred to the floor on ___. On the pt's pain was aggressively controlled w/ tylenol/tramadol/and po dilaudid prn. IS was encouraged. On ___ chest tube was placed to water seal with no leak. Tube subsequently removed on ___, post pull cxr w/out evidence of ptx. ENT was consulted for L temporal bone fx. They recommended ciprodex drop to left ear bid x ___s outpt audiogram. Ortho managed fractures non-operatively. Pt's left arm was in sling at all times while out of bed, and ___ began pendulum exercises with patient.

summary: Mr. ___ was a same day admit, and on ___ he was brought to the operating room where he underwent a off-pump coronary artery bypass graft x 2. Please see operative note for surgical details. Following surgery he was transferred to the CVICU for invasive monotoring in stable condition. On post-op day one he was started on beta blockers and diuretics and gently diuresed towards his pre-op weight. Later on this day he was transferred to the telemetry floor for further care. Chest tubes and epicardial pacing wires were removed per protocol. On POD 2 he developed a fever to 103. Urine and blood cultures were sent. Both were negative. His chest radiographs were not suspicious for pneumonia and he was doing well with his incentive spirometry. By post operative day four his right vein harvest site became erythematous and warm. He was started on Kefzol and his white blood cell count, leg erythema, and temperatures all improved by the following day. He gradually improved while working with physical therapy for strength and mobility and on post-op day five he was discharged home with ___ services on Keflex for his vein harvest site erythema.

summary: Key Information for Outpatient ___ with NASH cirrhosis (complicated by esophageal varices/GAVE/portal gastropathy/ascites/hepatic encephalopathy) and IDDM2 who presented with cough and fatigue and was found to have influenza and a urinary tract infection, with course c/b pancytopenia. ACUTE ISSUES: ============ #Cough #Shortness of breath #Influenza B Patient presented with 1 day of cough and fatigue. CXR was notable for a mild left pleural effusion. Influenza B . Patient was initiated on renally-dosed oseltamivir and ceftriaxone/azithromycin for possible pneumonia. She remained afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and on room air. Given low suspicion for pneumonia, on ___ her azithromycin was discontinued and ceftriaxone was decreased to 1g daily (for UTI, see below). The patient's home diuretics were held given infection and slight creatinine bump on admission. Given her increased SOB when prone during admission, her large-volume ascites was likely contributing to her symptoms. Her SOB improved after therapeutic paracentesis on ___. Patient completed a 5 day course of oseltamivir on the day of discharge. #Encephalopathy Patient presented with asterixis on exam and mild confusion with no recent bowel movements. Thought to be due to infection (influenza B, UCx growing GNRs) plus possible hepatic encephalopathy given no recent BMs prior to admission. Although low platelets noted, no focal neurlogic deficit to suggest acute head bleed. Patient improved to her baseline mental status with antibiotics, rifaximin, and titrating her lactulose to 3 BMs daily. #Bacteriuria: Patient's urine growing >100,000 Klebsiella with UA suggestive of UTI, sensitive to ceftriaxone. She was initiated on ceftriaxone on ___ (initially at 2g daily, transitioned to 1g daily). She completed a 5 day course prior to discharge. #Thrombocytopenia: Chronically low platelets thought to be secondary to liver disease. summary: ___ former ___ officer with a remote smoking history and PMH of CLL, dCHF (EF = 60%), inferior wall NSTEMI s/p RCA DES, CAD, and CKD who presents with dizziness and vomiting and progressive DOE, found to have an O2 requirement with pitting edema, initially treated for presumed CHF exacerbation and PNA, subsequently found on CT scan to have pleural effusion and pulmonary nodules concerning for primary pulmonary malignancy. #Hypoxia: Patient presents with dizziness, nausea, progressive exertional dyspnea. Found to be volume overloaded on exam with crackles at bases and peripheral edema and CXR with pleural effusions and with elevated BNP. EKG and troponins cycled and reassuring. Initially diuresed with IV lasix for presumed heart failure, but not able to wean off O2 requirement. Repeat ECHO showed EF = 60%. Developed ___ during diuresis, so diuresis held. Afebrile throughout, with leukocytosis consistent with CLL. Treated with five day course levaquin for presumed CAP PNA. VQ scan negative for PE. CT scan demonstrated pulmonary edema with right sided pleural effusion, emphysema and two pulmonary nodules in right upper lobe. Hypoxia thought to be due to pleural effusion and pulmonary edema, potentially ___ to malignancy. Thoracentesis was performed and produced 1.4-1.5L of serosanguinous fluid with studies sent and patient reporting symptomatinc improvement. Patient deferred further workup as inpatient due to wishes to be with his family. Was discharged home on supplemental O2 with ___ assistance, plan to follow up with interventional pulmonology and oncologist as outpatient. Believe dry weight to be 84.4 kg but not measured on day of discharge and this was before thoracentesis. #Dizziness: Concern that presentation of nausea and vomiting was an anginal equivalent. EKG reassuring without ST changes from previous, negative for arrythmia and negative troponins. B12 elevated, TSH wnl. text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Right leg pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Right L5-S1 minimally invasive discectomy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a patient with right leg pain and going back of his leg and to the back of his calf approximately two months. He hurt his back ___ years ago, flare up in ___ another flare up, and in ___ another flare up. Since that last episode, he was left with his leg pain. Walking more than 100 feet is difficult. It goes to his posterior leg into his ankle. Occasional tingling outside of his foot. It is ___ ___nd ___ with activity. His intake form was reviewed. He has no significant past medical history. No previous procedures. He has taken and acetaminophen with codeine. No known drug allergies. He is an ___. He is married. He is ___ feet 6, 194 pounds. MRI from ___ was reviewed from ___, which shows on my read developmental congenital stenosis with short pedicles. He has multilevel spondylosis with disc degeneration primarily at L4-5 and L5-S1. At L4-5, he has a broad-based central left paracentral disc protrusion with facet arthropathy causing mild-to-moderate central stenosis. At L5-S1, there is a broad-based disc herniation centrally into the right subarticular region with slight inferior migration, which displaces the right S1 nerve root. Of note, it does not appear that the L4-5 level is consistent with his symptoms as he has isolated S1 radicular symptoms on the right side and therefore the symptomatic level is most likely L5-S1. On physical examination, this is a healthy-appearing male. Affect is within normal limits. Gait is within normal limits. He is able walk on his toes and heels without difficulty except he is unable to do a single heel raise on the right side currently. He has a positive straight leg raise approximately 40 degrees. Negative contralateral straight leg raise. No pain with internal rotation of hips. Reflexes are symmetric in the upper and lower extremities and hyporeflexic. No clonus. Sensation is subjectively decreased in the outside of his foot compared to the contralateral side. No atrophy. Distal pulses intact. This is a young patient with congenital stenosis with findings at L4-5, but symptomatic findings at L5-S1 with a central right paracentral disc herniation. The risks and benefits of conservative versus surgical management were discussed. Given his subjective weakness as well as persistent symptoms, he wished to proceed with surgical intervention. It would be microdiscectomy right L5-S1 with the goal to decrease his pain and possibly increase his strength. The risks of not doing surgery are persistent symptoms and weakness. Other options are physical therapy and injections. Risks include all those associated with surgery, but specific to this procedure, spinal fluid leak, recurrent disc herniation, and persistent symptoms, in particular weakness as well as numbness and tingling. I think the other risk factor for him is he has congenital stenosis. This is unlikely to be the last operation on his spine that he receives, particularly his L4-L5 level is destined at some point to have surgical procedure. However, at this time, I would like to minimize the amount of surgery that he undergoes and outpatient microdiscectomy I think is warranted at this symptomatic level. All questions were answered. He is given a surgical packet, and I asked him to visit our animations. I am happy to see him back before surgery if he has further questions or clarifications or his symptoms change. His family member was here with him as well and all questions were answered. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> see HPI <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> see HPI <PHYSICAL EXAM> see HPI <PERTINENT RESULTS> see HPI <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You have undergone the following operation: Minimally Invasive Microdiscectomy Immediately after the operation: Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more than 45 minutes without moving around. Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: ___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. Limit any kind of lifting. Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation after surgery. Brace: You do not need a brace. Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the office. You should resume taking your normal home medications. You

Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___. We are not allowed to call in narcotic prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy. In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the date of surgery. - Follow up: o Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been done already. o At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline X-rays and answer any questions. REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: Rule out fluid collection and/or osteomyelitis of the hip/pelvis/buttock. Please use IV contrast and NO PO contrast. CONTRAINDICATIONS FOR IV CONTRAST: None. Wet Read: ___ ___ 11: 58 ___ there is a heterogeneous collection with associated locules of air ___ the superficial soft tissue overlying the left gluteal muscles, most c/w abscess as suggested clinically. the measures up to 7 cm SI x 4 cm TR x 2.2 cm AP. there is no evidence of deep extension. edema tracks inferiorly ___ the posterolateral thigh eval is somewhat limited by gantry contact and resultant artifact. there is soft tissue induration without further fluid collection over the bilateral ischial tuberosities, c/w healing ulcers. there is extensive heterotopic bone formation about the bilateral tuberosities as well as right > left hips. no acute periosteal reaction or osseous erosions to suggest osteomyelitis. intrapelvic contents demonstrate no acute pathology. there are prominent left inguinal and iliac nodes. these may be reactive. Final Report INDICATION: ___ man with swollen and erythematous left hip/buttock. TECHNIQUE: CT imaging of the pelvis and upper thighs was performed following the administration of intravenous contrast. Due to difficulty with patient cooperation and administration of sedative medication, imaging was performed approximately 15 minutes after administration of intravenous contrast. Patient positioning was also suboptimal for examination. Multiplanar reconstructions were generated. COMPARISON: No previous CT imaging is available for comparison. FINDINGS: CT PELVIS: There is ossification ___ the soft tissues adjacent to the ischial tuberosities and the greater trochanters of the femurs bilaterally. No cortical destruction or low-attenuation foci are seen ___ the osseous structures ___ this area to indicate osteomyelitis. A 3.8 cm x 3.4 cm fluid collection containing small foci of gas is identified ___ the subcutaneous tissue overlying the left gluteal muscle (series 1, image 74), and appears to infiltrate into the muscle. The lateral margin of this collection is not fully visualized due to patient positioning on scan. The findings are consistent with an abscess. Several enlarged lymph nodes are identified ___ the left obturator area, and left iliac region, the largest measuring 1.9 cm x 1.0 cm (series 1, image 44). summary: The patient, who has a terrible fear of the hospital, was premedicated prior to arrival on Ativan and Diazepam. He arrived the evening of ___ accompanied by health aides and was agitated and frightened. He was started on Unasyn, and received an additional Ativan 2 mg IV, after which he was able to tolerate a CT scan of his hip and pelvis that showed fat stranding and a fluid collection ___ his left buttock area. . On ___ consent for procedure was obtained from proxy, ___ ___ (Emergency coverage). Patient was then taken to the operating room, intubated, and the fluid collection was evacuated with an incision and drainage procedure. Samples of the copious purulence were sent for culture and sensitivities. The patient tolerated the procedure well. . Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient had no pain. When tolerating oral intake, the patient was offered Tylenol. The patient was maintained on his standing dose of Lorazepam 1 mg PO/NG BID at 7 am and 2 pm for anxiety. . CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. . Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. . GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until tolerating oral intake. His diet was advanced when appropriate, which was tolerated well. He was also started on a bowel regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were closely monitored. . ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV Unasyn and showed good improvement. He was switched to PO Augmentin for discharge home. The patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. . Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. . At the time of discharge on POD#3, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating

summary: Mr ___ was admitted for increasing abdominal pain and drainage from his incision site. ACS was consulted in the ER and at this point the wound had stopped draining. The incision site did have some mild erythema surrounding the site and cefazolin was started as an inpatient with improvement in the patient's pain and physical exam. Hepatology was also consulted for the patient's increasing total bilirubin on presentation. The labs downtrending while being in the hospital and hepatology recommend he follow-up with his normal hepatologist without any further management. The patient tolerated a regular diet throughout his stay and was able to ambulate without difficulty. The patient denied abdominal pain on dimscharge. The patient was given PO antibiotics and has an ___ clinic appointment next week for removal of his staples.

summary: Assessment and Plan: This is a ___ year-old woman presenting after fall. . 1)S/p Fall 2)Shoulder Pain 3)Knee pain: 4)Osteoarthritis 5)Osteoporosis No apparent LOC, fall appears to have been because of confusion with bed controls. No acute injuries other than exacerbation of chronic shoulder pain. No fracture by x-rays. Has very severe arthritis of both knees and shoulder. Exam consistent with arthritis, not rotator cuff tear etc. Pain controlled with tylenol and patient's usual oxycodone dosing. ___ evaluation recommended rehabilitiation,, and they worked with patient throughout admit. . 6)Delirium: Patient initially at baseline on admit. Over first night of admission, ___, sundowning and then very poor sleep. Delirium secondary to hospitalization in this elderly patient with altered sleep wake cycle, hearing impaired, visually impaired. No other causes identified. summary: The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: 1. Acute urinary retention - Foley was d/c'ed on ___ at 1800, patient was unable to void after 8 hrs. Bladder scanned for > 500cc, foley was replaced. Started on Flomax which can be dc'ed after patient voiding independently. Please d/c ___ at 6am and repeat voiding trial. He was followed by infectious disease and he was placed on ancef and vancomycin empirically. Cultures showed coag negative staph in the broth which was likely a contaminant. Antibiotics were d/c'd. Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1. The patient received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior precautions. Abduction brace ___ flexion, 20 abduction) at all times when OOB. Walker or two crutches at all times. Mr. ___ is discharged to rehab in stable condition.

summary: Briefly, Mr. ___ presented to ___ on ___ for planned plication of the left diaphragm. He tolerated the procedure well, had a chest tube, epidural, and foley placed in the OR, was extubated, and was transferred to the PACU in stable condition. His post-op CXR was remarkable for a small left apical pneumothorax with chest tube to water seal and he was subsequently transferred to the inpatient surgical floor. He remained stable overnight into POD 1, and on POD 1 he experienced some leakeage of pink tinged straw colored fluid around his chest tube. On POD 1 his creatinine was noted to be elevated at 1.7, and his metformin was subsequently held. He continued to have adequate urine output and remained stable on POD 1 with chest tube to water seal continuing to have high output of pink fluid. Early in AM on POD 2, pt was noted to be agitated and delirious. He was placed on CIWA scale, a UA/UCx was obtained (UA indicating possible UTI), BCx were obtained, an ECG was obtained which showed no ischemic changes, and cardiac enzymes were drawn. Pt was subsequently started on empiric Bactrim for a suspected UTI and placed on IVF with supplemental thiamine, folate, and given a PO multivitamin. He recovered from delirium, and his chest tube, foley catheter, and epidural catheter were all removed on POD 2. His post pull CXR showed improved lung ventilation with no apparent PTX. His troponins trended downward and a repeat ECG showed no acute ischemic changes. He remained stable into POD 3, and his UCx showed no growth and pt was afebrile, Bactrim discontinued. On POD4 the patient was discharged home tolerating a regular oral diet, pain well controlled on oral pain medications, ambulating with assistance, and voiding without difficulty. All of his questions were answered.

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the ACS service at ___ with acute cholecystitis. She was taken to the operating room on HD2 for an uncomplicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Operative course was stable with mininmal blood loss. Post operatively, she did well, she was advanced to a regular diet which she was tolerating well at discharge. She was ambulating well. She had minimal pain that was adequately controlled on her oral pain medications, but she did report nausea on POD #2 and her narcotic analgesia was changed with a decrease in her nausea. She was able to tolerate a diet prior to discharge. Her vital signs are stable and she is afebrile. She was discharge home with instructions to follow-up with the acute care service in ___ weeks.

summary: ___ female with hypertension, chronic systolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease s/p CABG, and s/p aortic valve replacement was admitted with pneumonia. . * Streptococcal Pneumonia - On admission the pt was found to have a LLL pneumonia with associated hypoxia and leukocytosis. She was started on tamiflu, ceftriaxone and azithmycin. Her DFA was negative and so tamiflu was discontinued on the day after admission. Blood cultures were drawn on admission and these were positive for Strep pneumonia ___ bottles). Surveillance cultures were negative. Azithromycin was discontinued on ___. On ___, she developed respiratory distress and was found to have a new pleural effusion. A left lateral CXR revealed a small layering pleural effusion, too small to tap. She was continued on her home dose of lasix with improvement in her respiratory symptoms. Her strep pneumo was pansensitive, but given the concern for the addition of levofloxacin prolonging her QTc in the setting of being on sotalol, she should be on ceftriaxone x 7 days and can continue a cefpodoxime x 7 days through ___. She did require supplemental oxygen and will likely need this for discharge while her pneumonia continues to resolve. She will need to follow up with a CXR in ___ weeks to follow to resolution. . * Benign Hypertension: Well controlled. Norvasc was continued. . * h/o Aortic Valve Replacement: Coumadin was continued. She was subtherapeutic on admission, but on ___ was therapeutic with only her home dose of coumadin. Resume warfarin 2mg 6/wk and check INR as usual. INR 2.9 at discharge. . * Atrial Fibrillation: Remained rate controlled. Her home dose of sotalol was continued and she remains on coumadin for anticoagulation. . * Hyperlipidemia: Her home dose of lipitor and ASA were continued. . * Chronic Systolic Congestive Heart Failure - On admission appeared hypovolemic and in the setting of decreased urine output, she was given 250cc of gentle IVF. summary: She was admitted to Trauma overnight for observation. Her CT scans were negative for any acute injuries. An xray of her right hand reveled an oblique fracture of her proximal ___ phalanx. Hand was consulted for this injury; she was fitted for a splint and will follow up as an outpatient in Hand clinic. Her mental status has remained intact with exception that she remains amnestic to the events of her trauma. She complains of intermittent headaches and has taken Ibuprofen which helped. She is ambulatory and tolerating a regular diet. She is being referred to Dr. ___ Neurology as an outpatient.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROSURGERY <ALLERGIES> Pertussis Vaccine,Fluid <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> neck pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> c5-6 ACDF <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ year old female with neck and right arm pain. She failed conservative therapies and now presents for elective surgical intervention. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> obesity with 100# loss GERD depression <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family h/o biliary or liver disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> gen: lying in hospital bed comfortably resp: non labored neuro: - motor: ___ throughout ___ upper extremities. sensory intact in all distributions. 2 triceps reflex. incision: anterior neck incision with dressing c/d/I. c-collar in place. <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Discharge Instructions ACDF Surgery -Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery. -Your incision is closed with dissolvable sutures underneath the skin and steri strips. You do not need suture removal. Do not remove your steri strips, let them fall off. -Please keep your incision dry for 72 hours after surgery. -Please avoid swimming for two weeks. -Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like redness, fever, or drainage. Activity -*** You must wear your hard cervical collar at all times. You may remove it briefly for skin care and showering. -We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment. -You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once. -No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. -No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. -Do NOT smoke. Smoking can affect your healing and fusion. Medications -***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. -Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc for 2 weeks. -You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication. -It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. Pain medications can cause constipation. When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for: -Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision site. -Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit -New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

There has been no further evidence of bleeding and you are now preparing for discharge to home with the following instructions: High dose PPI (i.e. pantoprazole 40mg) twice a day for 8 weeks. Carafate three to four times a day for 8 weeks. You will be scheduled for a repeat EGD to assess your ulcers, and a colonoscopy in 8 weeks. Please call your surgeon or return to the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, pain unrelieved by pain medication, severe nausea or vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, or any other symptoms which are concerning to you. Diet: Home bariatric diet as tolerated Resume your home medications. Avoid medications such as blood thinners or aspirin until your follow up appointment. Refrain from drinking alcohol as it may precipitate bleeding and abdominal pain. You must not use NSAIDS (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) Examples are Ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, Nuprin and Naproxen. These agents will cause bleeding and ulcers in your digestive system. Activity: Activity as tolerated at home.
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old male s/p Roux-en-Y gastric bypass performed in ___ who presented to the Emergency Department following identification of a bleeding marginal ulcer which was clipped during endoscopy. Post-procedure, the patient received intravenous pantoprazole and oral sucralfate; hematocrit levels were stable x 3. Given ongoing hemodynamic stability and stable hct, the patient's diet was gradually advanced to a bariatric stage III diet, which was well tolerated. He did undergo a social work consult given hx of ___ drinks per weekend documented in HP, however, patient denied regular etoh consumption during consult and this appeared to be entered in error. He was subsequently discharged to home on HD2 and will follow-up with Dr. ___ in clinic.

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman w/ a complex medical history including post-menopausal bleeding s/p DC with normal path approx. 6wks prior to presentation who presented with heavy vaginal bleeding x ___ soaking through >1pad/hr. When examined on presentation she was not having active bleeding, but was orthostatic and was admitted for observation with pad counts and monitoring of Hct. Her Hct on presentation was 47.6 down from 51 on ___ (the pt has a hx of polycythemia). Overnight the patient's vaginal bleeding decreased significantly per her report. Based on pad counts and objective evaluation of her bleeding the patient appeared to be having moderate ongoing flow. Her vital signs were stable throughout her stay, and she felt well without symptoms of anemia on HD#2. The patient was discharged home with bleeding precautions and instructions to follow up with her primary Ob/Gyn Dr. ___ the next ___ for further evaluation and management of her post-menopausal bleeding.

He underwent EGD with Dr. ___ on ___, which showed proximal migration of two transpyloric metal stents (one within the other), with minimal tumor ingrowth but without obstruction. Stent trimming was initiated, with plan to repeat EGD in 1 week for further stent trimming. Patient reports that over the last week he has continued to have post-prandial abdominal pain and nausea. Presented today for repeat EGD, which again revealed proximal migration of the two metal stents with minimal tissue ingrowth but no obstruction. The proximal stent edges were trimmed (2cm from the proximal margin of the stent with metal fragments removed and jagged edges softened with biopsy forceps). On arrival to the floor, patients is hypertensive to SBPs in the 190s. He complains of R-sided headache that began this morning prior to his procedure, similar to his chronic headaches, without vision changes or neck stiffness. He denies abdominal pain or N/V, which he attributes to not having eaten recently. Denies CP or SOB. Last BM was at 9am this morning and was reportedly normal (in setting of chronic constipation). Followed by Dr. ___ at ___ and now on ramucirumab/paclitaxel (C2D15 on ___. Since ___ has had post-prandial abdominal pain and nausea. CT A/P in early ___ at ___ with known liver and node mets without evidence of obstruction. Underwent EGD ___ showing proximal migration of transpyloric stents, which were trimmed. He presented ___ for further trimming of the stents. Of note, the stent was traversable and less angulated without evidence of frank obstruction, calling into question gastric outlet obstruction as the cause of his symptoms. After further discussion with the advanced endoscopy team it was decided not to further trim the stent. ___ surgery was consulted to consider whether GJ bypass could be beneficial. The patient underwent a CT scan and it was felt based on initial review of the images that no surgical intervention would be beneficial at this time. His symptoms were also improved, without nausea or abdominal pain at the time of discharge. Also discussed with the patient that mild constipation could be playing some role in his symptoms. He felt well and had stable labs and vitals and was discharged home with plans to follow-up with his outpatient providers. # poorly controlled HTN: # sinus brady (50s) Hypertensive on arrival to SBPs in the 190s
