summary: ___ yo man who presents with malaise, productive cough, and nausea/vomiting x 6 weeks. 1. Lung abscess, right upper lobe: He was ruled out for TB with 3 negative AFBs. He was initially treated with cefepime, vancomycin, and flagyl. He also had a bronchoscopy; unfortunately, the bal did not grow any bacteria. ___ ___ had reported that his sputum culture grew pan-sensitive E. coli, so he was switched to CTX, vanc, and flagyl. However, his white count began to increase. He was switched back to cefepime and flagyl on ___ vancomycin was discontinued. He had a repeat CT scan on ___ that showed stable abscess but worsening surrounding ground glass opacities. Thoracics surgery was consulted for possible VATS for drainage; they will reevaluate after a longer course of antibiotic. He was sent home on cefepime and flagyl with close follow up. He has follow up CT scan with his next ID outpatient appointment scheduled. He will need a prolonged course of antibiotics to be determined by ID as an outpatient. If there is no resolution, he may require surgical intervention. 2. Acute renal failure: This was likely due to hypovolemia and resolved with IVFs. 3. Hyponatremia: This was likely due to hypovolemia /- SIADH from his pulmonary process and was stable. 4. DM2, uncontrolled: He was continued on his home insulin regimen with an extra sliding scale. 5. Fall: Patient had slipped on a wet floor getting out of the shower. He landed on his buttocks with his back against the wall. His legs had slid under his bed, knocking over the tray table, which landed on his shin. He complained of pain at his shin. He had no pain with movement of his ankle, knees, or hips. 6. Code: Full

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Oxycodone / morphine <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Unresponsiveness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Received tPA at OSH for suspected stroke (teleneurology) This is a ___ right handed woman with a history of dementia NOS, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and pacemaker implantation, together with other medical problems who is transferred from ___ after receiving tPA for a suspected stroke. The patient's family provided the bulk of the history. They report that her health has been generally well. At baseline, she is dependent on her family to help with showering, paying bills, taking her medications, etc. She used to get more services, but now she lives with family who has taken over the bulk of the physical support that she requires. She is able to safely walk with a walker, and uses a chair-elevator to get up to the main floor of her home. She has not had any fevers, diarrhea, vomitting, dysuria or any other symptoms recently. This afternoon, she had her breakfast downstairs in her room (which is unusual) and then took her medications that were scheduled to be taken. At approximately noon, she was with her husband who noticed that she acutely became unresponsive and slumped over to the right. There were no convulsive movements. They tried to wake her up by calling her name. One of the daughters thought that she had passed. She vomitted once and then slowly came to wake up over the course of the next ___ minutes or so. Following this, apparently one son noted right facial droopiness. EMS was called, and apparently, she appeared pale and not herself. She was brought to an OSH. There, NIHSS was calculated to be 7 (2 right arm, 2 right leg, 1 ataxia, 1 dysarthria, 1 aphasia) and a noncontrast head CT scan identified only atrophy. A CXR identified Progression of indolent right upper lobe airspace process, superimposed on COPD (she has known pulmonary fibrosis and is dependent on home oxygen). Routine labs including creatinine were unremarkable, and she was tx'd here for a higher level of care. By the time she arrived here, family reported that she was back to baseline. They explained that she has had this slumping episode once before, and has once previously had a frank convulsion after eating dinner at a restaurant. No concern for seizures had been previously raised. She does not take an aspirin daily, and the family could not tell why. Reviewing her chart online (___), it appears that she has had numerous previous admissions for syncope. Review of systems is otherwise negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> osteoporosis, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, s/p pacemaker implantation (for unclear reasons), h/o rod implantation in right leg, vertebral compression fracture. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> V/s HR 53, BP 137/76, RR 20, 100% 2L. She is a thin frail woman who appeared her stated age. She wore a nasal cannula. Neck was supple. A loud systolic murmur was heard over the left with radiation to the neck. Rate was slow. Lungs were clear. There were numerous hyperpigmented flat lesions the entire skin. Lower extremities were without edema. Neurologically, she was awake, alert, and knew that she was ___ or 92. She did not know the name of the hospital. She knew her own name. She could read and follow simple commands. She could repeat without difficulty. She identified all objects on NIHSS pictures except for hammock and cactus (that needle thing). Her speech was clear. She was quite hearing impaired however. No obvious neglect or apraxia. Pupils were equal at 1mm and not reactive. Gaze was conjugate and eye movements demonstrated saccadic intrusions. Visual fields were full to confrontation. Face was symmetric without ptosis or facial droop. Tongue was midline and strong. Bilateral trapezii were full strength. Motor examination was limited by numerous IV/lines, and patient was quite sensitive to pressure in her limbs diffusely. Within these limitations, I observed no subtle or obvious hemiparesis and ___ strength in all major muscle groups. There was diffuse muscle atrophy. Tone was slightly elevated with gegenhalten. Sensation was intact to light touch throughout. Finger-nose testing demonstrated intention tremor bilaterally without dysmetria. Gait/Romberg evaluation was deferred. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 10: 20PM CK(CPK)-42 ___ 10: 20PM CK-MB-2 cTropnT-0.02* ___ 07: 50PM URINE COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 07: 50PM URINE BLOOD-TR NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-100 GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.0 LEUK-NEG ___ 07: 50PM URINE RBC-1 WBC-2 BACTERIA
summary: ___ with dementia NOS (likely vascular dementia), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, pulmonary fibrosis on home oxygen who p/w slumping episode and decreased responsiveness afterward possibly c/w seizure vs stroke. s/p tPA at OSH. # Probable stroke: Admitted to ICU s/p tPA at OSH for slumping and unresponsiveness with a single episode of emesis. It was thought that this may have been related to vasovagal syncope vs seizure vs stroke. NIHSS was 7 at OSH (2 right arm, 2 right leg, 1 ataxia, 1 dysarthria, 1 aphasia), given tPA at OSH at 1PM on ___. Here motor exam was normal. Admitted here at ___ ICU for post-tPA monitoring essentially at her baseline per family. ___ 24 hours post-tPA was unchanged (calcification along the falx and tent cerebelli). Etiology questionable, s/p tPA on ___ at OSH. Slumping with subsequent confusion could be c/w seizure and post-ictal state. Malignant arrhythmia or cardiomyopathy seem less likely given troponins, TTE (prelim read). Tox screen negative. MRI not possible because of pacemaker. CT head on ___ stable. EEG showed no epileptiform discharges. In terms of risk factor assessment: LDL was 127 while on pravastatin 80 daily. She was switched to atorvastatin 80 daily. Her A1c was 5.8. SC Heparin started on ___, 24 hours after tPA. Patient was back to her baseline mental status and mobility on the day of discharge. She was discharged home with 24 hour care, home ___ and maximal service. # h/o pulmonary fibrosis on home O2. Patient is continued on ___ liters of oxygen and satting high 90's. # Probable hemorrhoids: patient was noted to have a small amount of bright red blood with bowel movement. Rectal exam revealed no active bleeding or external hemorrhoid. Patient's Hct was within normal limits. Patient should be further worked up as an outpatient

summary: Patient was admitted to neurology for further workup of symptoms, differential diagnosis including TIA, CVA, and complex migraine. Further history from patient elicited that she has previously had migraines, with an aura that involved numbness of her right face. She hasn't experienced these migraines since she started taking verapamil regularly. CT head was normal, as was CTA head. MRI brain showed no evidence of acute intracranial abnormality. Specifically, no evidence of acute infarction or intracranial hemorrhage. In the morning, patient's symptoms were gone and did not reoccur. Her physical exam in the morning showed no focal neurological deficits. She was counseled on the importance of taking her medications as prescribed. A follow up appointment was made for her with her neurologist Dr. ___ on ___ at 3:00 pm, at which point her questions regarding anticoagulation for an upcoming long flight will be addressed.

INDICATION: Recent prostate biopsy here with fevers, shortness of breath, tachycardia, please assess for PE. COMPARISON: Chest x-ray of ___. TECHNIQUE: Multiple MDCT images were obtained before and after the administration of intravenous Optiray. No enteric contrast was administered and coronal and sagittal reformatted were than derived. FINDINGS: There is no CT evidence for pulmonary emboli. No aortic dissection is demonstrated and there is no evidence for intramural hematoma. There are vascular, including coronary, artery calcifications. There are calcified pleural plaques. Emphysematous changes are seen, and there is bibasilar dependent atelectasis with a small right pleural effusion. Heart size is normal. There is no abnormal bowing of intraventricular septum or enlargement of the right heart. Three hypodensities are seen in the liver, the largest measuring 1.2 cm in the dome of the liver and two in the in the left lobe of the liver, too small to characterize, likely cysts. The visualized portion of the spleen and right kidney appear normal. OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: Mild degenerative changes are seen at numerous levels in the spine with some symmetric sclerosis of the posterior elements superiorly. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus or aortic dissection. 2. Hepatic hypodense nodules of undetermined nature
summary: The patient was admitted to the MICU for respiratory distress which responded to stress dose steroids and inhaler therapy. During a period of high blood pressure and tachycardia, the patient was noted to have a mild NSTEMI which was medically managed. He was also noted to be in acute renal failure, which resonded to gentle hydration. He was also noted to have a pyuria and started empirically on cefepime and ciprofloxacin. He was subsequently transferred to the floor with reasonable control of blood pressure and heart rate. He was started on high dose simvastatin. Cardiology consult recommended 4 week outpatient follow up. His urine culture and sensitivities returned, and his antibiotic regimen was converted to sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim twice daily for a total of 4 weeks given the reduced tissue penetration to the prostate of sulfa antibiotics. Outpatient follow up for his new diagnosis of prostate cancer was to be arranged by his spouse. On discharge, the patient was feeling at baseline without any significant symptoms.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Syncope <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year old female with PMHx syncope presenting with syncope. She attended a concert at ___ the night of admission where she started to feel extremely tired and unwell. Her and her boyfriend went to get water when she felt very uneasy and lightheaded. On the way to get water she had to sit down and she subsequently lost consciousness. A ___ employee saw her looking unwell and believed that the patient did not have a pulse so started compressions. After five seconds the patient woke up. She was then brought to the ED where her initial vital signs were 97.2 63 107/58 16 99%. She recieved 3L IVF, UA not infectious appearing, BMP wnl. She reports that she has felt very stressed due to work for the past week. She woke up very early this morning to drive to ___ from ___, was at work meetings all day, went out for drinks, and then to the concern. She does endorse drinking several liters of water throughout the day, although ate less than normal. While she was in the ED, she had another syncopal episode while walking to the bathroom. She was walking with nurses and started to feel very lightheaded so lowered herself to the ground and subsequently lost consciousness for approximately 10 seconds. Notably she lost control of her bowel movements. Pt reports lightheadedness prior to syncopal episode, as well as change in vision (blackness, speckles of black and blackness fading in). On some occasions she has experienced heart racing, but denies CP or palpitations. She states she had prior episodes with observers reporting to her jerking motions, loss of bowel continence (in ED on ___, bladder incontinence (5 weeks ago). She reports a history of syncopal events since the age of ___ yo, with approximately 12 events in her lifetime usually associated with blood draws. Of note, pt also reports prior history of bulimia from ages ___ with binging, purging, restricting. Reports well controlled. Vasovagal syncope <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure caring for you at ___. You were admitted after two episodes of loss of consciousness. A full work up was completed and fortunately the results were reassuring. We believe your loss of consciousness was most likely a vasovagal syncopal episode, which is a reaction that some people experience when they encounter certain stimuli - stress from fear (for instance your fear of needles) or stress in general. Please follow up with your primary care physician in the next 2 weeks. Thank you for allowing us to care for you
summary: ___ year old female with PMHx syncope presenting with syncope. Pt had 2 episodes of syncope on ___ (one at a concert, one in the ED), with loss of bowel control during her syncopal episode in the ED. Normal EKG, telemetry without significant abnormality, serum and urine toxicology negative, metabolic panel normal, no localizing signs of infection on physical exam, history, or laboratory results. Presentation appears consistent w/ vasovagal syncope given: prodrome of lightheadedness and darkening vision; brief loss of consciousness; and minimal ___ confusion. Neurology was consulted about possibility of seizure disorder and felt strongly that the presentation was consistent with vasovagal syncope rather than seizure. EEG was normal. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - pt to follow up with OB/Gyn, who is currently serving as a primary care physician - pt to continue to maintain adequate hydration and avoid known triggers (needles) - patient counseled about counter pressure techniques to mitigate vasovagal syncope risk

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Left amaurosis fugax <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo RHW, with a MH of left lobular breast carcinoma in situ, was walking down the hallway in the school that she teaches in, and for a minute, around 11: 15 am, she had sudden visual loss in her left eye, while she was turning to face a colleague. It was preceded by floaters, and there was total darkness, as if a darkness had been pulled over it. She felt an odd sensation around her left eye, but could not be more specific about this. Over the weekend, she had been experiencing her typical menstrual headaches which are occipital, and more of a dull ache. She has never had these visual issues before. She did not experience an aphasia, vertigo, weakness on any one side of the face or body accompanying this episode. She did however, feel lightheaded prior to the episode. She called her PCP, Dr ___ at around 12: 43 h, and her PCP recommended that she go to the ER. ROS: no other neurological symptoms. No musculoskeletal pain, no jaw or neck pain, no trauma to the neck. summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old right-handed woman with a history including lobular breast carcinoma in situ who presented to the ___ with left vision loss. She was admitted to the stroke service ___ to ___. . A CT of the head showed no evidence of hemorrhage. There did not appear to be evidence of aneurysm or vessel occlusion on CT angiography studies. Ms. ___ was unable to clearly state whether the vision loss was in one eye or both. Migraine remains in the differential, as she has a history of episodes of gradually progressive hemisensory loss as well as catemenial headaches. However, she does state that the vision loss came on fairly quickly after the prodrome of blurriness, so she has been diagnosed with a TIA (amaurosis fugax). An MRI of the brain was performed and revealed no evidence of acute ischemia. . To evaluate modifiable risk factors for stroke, lipids and glycosylated hemoglobin were measured. The LDL was found to be 108, so no medication changes were made. Fasting serum glucose was 93. Echocardiogram showed no ASD, PFO, or other cardioembolic source. . The patient was discharged home on aspirin 81 mg daily given the diagnosis of TIA. She will follow-up with Dr. ___ in Stroke ___. . CODE: Full

summary: ___ year old hospital interpreter with cutaneous lupus, evolving skin lesions with involvement deepening below the dermal/epidermal layers raising concern for infection vs vasculitis; patient has increasing pain and disability associated with this process. . CUTANEOUS LUPUS LESIONS It appeared to be reasonable to assume that her worsening lesions were the ongoing result of cutaneous lupus, but given her history of healthcare exposures we were especially worried about the possibility of MRSA superinfection. We were also concerned about the possbility of progression to systemic involvement of her lupus, which given her cardiac history seemed likely. A skin biopsy showed the following results: 1. Skin, right palm (A): Lichenoid interface dermatitis with sawtooth epidermal hyperplasia, hypergranulosis, and thickening of the basement membrane zone (PAS stain) - see note. 2. Skin, right flank (B): Superficial ulcer with scale-crust suggesting excoriation, with adjacent focal vacuolar interface change - see note. Note: No vasculitis is seen in either specimen (multiple levels examined). The right flank biopsy is dominated by an ulcer, however there is an area of vacuolar interface dermatitis in adjacent intact skin. Overall the picture is compatible with lichen planus-lupus erythematosus overlap, if supported by the clinical features. . Vancomycin was started on arrival but was discontinued on ___ after it appeared that there was no infectious process. We appreciated the consult services of dermatology and rheumatology who both followed this patient while hospitalized. Dermatology recommended topical antibiotic alone for coverage of possible skin infection, which we did. We provided dilaudid for immediate pain issues and continued careful nursing care for the wound. By EKG and cardiac enzymes and history there was no clear evidence of any cardiac involvement

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> PSYCHIATRY <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> my boyfriend broke up with me, I got drunk and I did a stupid thing <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o woman with no prior psychiatric admissions but a prior diagnosis of mood disorder presents via ambulance with a BAL of 166. Two days prior, the patient states her boyfriend broke up with her and she was extremely upset, as she states she is in love with him. Last night, despite the break up, they had plans to celebrate their one year anniversary together and he stood her up. She was very upset over this and in an attempt to calm down and sleep, took 4 extra 1mg Xanax tablets. Later on, she decided to go out with her friends and she became intoxicated. When she arrived home, she coincidently ran into her ex-BF (they live in the same building), and the patient became argumentative. She admits to questioning him repeatedly, yelling at him, and pulling his hair and punching him. As she gives this history she is sobbing. She states she was so angry with him, but says I wish I didn't do this, now he won't take me back. She then took a knife from his kitchen and states she held it to her body. She decided to call her mother during this time, and although does not remember stating that she was suicidal, believes she could have. Her mother encouraged her boyfriend to call ___ and she was brought to ___. The patient states she just spoke to her BF because she needed to know whether they are going to be together. She states I'm going to go insane without him. She says it is going to be very difficult to go back to the apartment complex where they both live and he also attend the same school as she does, which she finds unbearable to think about. She admits to being very dependent on him and not wanting to be alone. In ___, patient had a miscarriage and required surgery (8 weeks gestation). Patient was unsure whether she was going to have the child. Patient seems unsure of whether this event has affected her. The patient denies current SI and states that she is afraid of dying. She denies ever having SI in the past and has no prior suicide attempts. She states her mother has tried to kill herself a dozen times and believes her behaviour last night was to gain attention. When asked about depression, the patient admits to being depressed always. She has very poor sleep and states she is extremely moody, especially in the mornings. She sees a someone for her moods and is currently on Lamcital, as well as Xanax. Spoke to her family. Mother and father both have concerns for their daughter as she is functioning very poorly and is highly dependent on her boyfriend. Mother says that her daughter told her earlier in the ED that she would continue to have suicidal thoughts if she does not get back together with her boyfriend. However, they deny that she has ever been suicidal before. They suggest that this is the ___ breakup, but even when she is not broken up with her BF, she is depressed and recently during a trip home, could not get out of bed for days. She is also doing poorly in school. Of note, she sees an NP for her psych meds ___ times yearly. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: Diagnoses: Mood disorder Hospitalizations: None, though at age ___, patient became very upset that she was going to die (question of brain tumor) and she was admitted to a neuro-onc unit. Medication Trials: Prozac, oloft - neither worked per patient. SA/SIB: None Outpatient treaters: ___ x ___ years. summary: The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: On POD#2, the patient was sent for a chest x-ray to rule out pneumonia due to a low oxygen saturation and increasing white count. Chest x-ray showed basilar atelectasis bilaterally and her incentive spirometer was encouraged. She was also sent for a left lower extremity ultrasound to rule out a blood clot due to left thigh swelling. The ultrasound was negative for a blood clot. Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral pain medications. The patient received Lovenox daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The surgical dressing will remain on until POD#7 after surgery. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the dressing was intact. The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity with anterior precautions, no hip bridging, no repetitive resistant hip flexion. Walker or two crutches at all times for 6 weeks. Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable condition.

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted and underwent mechanical aortic valve replacement with a 23-mm ___ mechanical valve, model #___ with Dr. ___-CLAMP TIME: 88 minutes.BYPASS TIME:106 minutes. For surgical details, please see operative note. Following the operation, she was brought to the CVICU in stable condition. Within 24 hours, she awoke neurologically intact and was extubated without incident. She maintained stable hemodynamics and transferred to the SDU on postoperative day one. Chest tubes and pacing wires were eventually removed without complication. Antibiotics were continued postoperatively until operative culture returned negative and were discontinued per Infectious disease recommendations. Warfarin was initiated for mechanical aortic valve, and dosed for a goal INR between 2.0 to 3.0. She was supratherapeutic on ___ and received Vitamin K. Coumadin was resumed the following day. Coumadin dosing will be manged by her primary care physician. Despite postoperative anemia, she continued to make clinical improvements. Hematocrit dropped as low as 20% On day of discharge her HCT had increased to 22.7. Her INR was therapeutic and ___ her for discharge to home with ___. All Follow up appointments were advised.

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ and was taken to the operating room. He underwent mitral valve repair with resection of the middle scallop of the posterior leaflet (P2) and a mitral valve annuloplasty with a 32 ___ annuloplasty band. Please see operative note for full details. He tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. He weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and was extubated on POD 1. Beta blocker was initiated and he was diuresed toward his preoperative weight. He remained hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery. He was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. He did not tolerate Metoprolol due to hypotension. By the time of discharge on POD 4 he was ambulating freely, the wound was healing, and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. He was discharged home in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

Of note, patient was recently admitted for a COPD flare ___ (date of discharge) and was treated at that time with IV solumedrol and transitioned to an oral prednisone taper. He also received Doxycycline, Albuterol and Atrovent nebs. With these measures, pt began to return to his previous respiratory baseline, which is known to be tenuous. summary: ___ yo M with multiple medical problems most notable for severe COPD with multiple hospitalizations for flares presents with another COPD exacerbation after finsishing a brief Prednisone taper from last hospitalization two days prior. . # COPD exacerbation: Patient with severe (Stage IV) COPD and many recent flares on 4L O2 at home presents with repeat COPD exacerbation. Most likely cause of flare is insufficient Prednisone coverage on his short taper. Patient received Combivent on the way to the ED, and in the ED was placed on 4L NC, given 60mg IV salumedrol x1, duoneb x3, albuterol nebulizer x1, and azithromycin 500mg x1. On the floor he received Prednisone 60mg, albuterol neb Q4 standing, Ipratropium Bromide Q6 standing, Fluticasone Diskus BID, and albuterol Q2 PRN. Initial blood gas showed a pH of 7.35 pO2 69 and pCO2 58. Patient was also placed on a 5 day course of Azithromycin and started on Atovaquone 1500mcg for PCP ___. His breathing improved to baseline, and patient was discharged on a slow taper of 40mg daily through ___ (1 day, 5 days total) then 30mg once daily through ___ (5 days), then 20mg daily through ___ (5 days), then 10mg daily through ___ (5 days), then resuming his regular home course of 10mg Prednisone every other day. . # Diabetes: Pt's HgbA1C was in the low 7's recently, but sugars were difficult to control on Prednisone with highs in 400's and hyperglycemia overnight despite being on home Metformin and Glyburide, and humalog SSI. Prednisone was decreased to 40mg to lessen effect on blood glucose, and ___ was consulted. Pt's ___ Glyburide was changed to Glimepiride with improvement of sugars. However, he continued to become hyperglycemic with meals and was thus discharged to short term rehab with humalog SSI to cover him until his Prednisone taper was complete. . # Wound

summary: ___ is a ___ with myelodysplastic syndrome who was admitted to ___ with cough and malaise unresponsive to a 5 day course of levofloxacin and with palpitations and new murmur. Chest CT was negative for acute infection as etiology of cough and echocardiogram showed increased pulmonary hypertension, suggesting that cough was secondary to pulmonary hypertension. Patient no longer had palpitations while in the hospital. EKG did show some sinus bradyarrhythmia and premature atrial complexes, which could be responsible for palpitations. Additionally, patient was anemic and received one unit of pRBCs. On discharge, the patient was feeling better and her remaining medical issues could be managed as an outpatient. # Cough: Differential included viral respiratory infection (eg parainfluenza), unresolved pneumonia given persistent RLL opacity on CXR, or increased L heart failure with pulmonary edema. Given lack of resolution of cough with antibiotics, we got a non-contrast chest CT to evaluate for bacterial pneumonia vs fungal infection vs pulmonary edema and respiratory viral panel to evaluate for parainfluenza. Chest CT showed no acute infectious process but did show chronic pulmonary nodules and bronchiectasis unchanged from ___. Respiratory viral panel was negative. Trans-thoracic echo then showed mild R atrial enlargement and increased TR gradient >40 mmHg, consistent with pulmonary hypertension. Therefore, the patient was ruled out for infectious etiology and her cough was likely secondary to pulmonary hypertension. Throughout the admission, she did not have respiratory distress, dyspnea, or oxygen requirement. She will likely need follow up with her cardiologist Dr. ___. # Palpitations/new murmur: The patient complained of palpitations the night before admission, which resolved during the day of admission. During her scheduled appointment at ___ clinic the day of admission, the NP heard a new systolic murmur, not documented on previous notes. During her stay, exam showed a ___ systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur. However, patient was stable, EKG did not show any acute changes concerning for ischemia,

He presents from rehab today with confusion, cough, SOB, and increased leg edema. . He was discharged to ___ after his last admission, and was doing very well per both him and his family, with excellent control of his CHF and clear mental status. He felt that the valve replacement had helped and that he was making good progress with ___, feeling much less SOB and fatigued. He was transferred to a new rehab about one week ago, and since then his condition has been deteriorating. Over the last week, he has developed increased leg swelling, gained about 8 lbs, and become increasingly confused. His daughter and wife describe waxing and waning mental status, with periods where he will fall asleep while talking, start speaking nonsense, or hallucinate. Today, he has developed a slight productive cough and has increaed SOB with exertion. He has not had any fever, chills, sweats, GI symptoms, or urinary symptoms. . Initial vitals in the ED were T 97, HR 92, BP 139/84, RR 16, and SpO2 100% on RA. Exam showed bibasilar crackles on auscultation and pitting edema to the knees. He was comfortable and AOX3 in the ED. EKG was V-paced and unchanged from prior. Labs were notable for Troponin 0.03 x2 and creatinine 1.8 up from 1.3 during his last admission. CXR showed no acute process and minimal signs of volume overload. CT head showed no acute process. Neurology consult was called and EEG showed right posterior temporal slowing and mild encephalopathy consistent with delirium, with no electrographic seizure activity. His family felt that his mental status was currently at baseline. . He was admited to medicine for management of delirium and acute on chronic renal insufficiency in the setting of CHF. Vitals prior to floor transfer were T 97.4, HR 74, BP 109/54, RR 22, and SpO2 99% on RA. On reaching the floor, he was alert, conversant, and at his baseline mental status per his daughter. He denied any current complaints besides a mild posterior headache and occasional cough. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Aortic stenosis s/p Biocor tissue AVR ___ - CAD s/p CABG (LIMA->LAD, SVG->OM, SVG->PDA) ___ - PEA arrest ___ -- s/p permanent pacemaker (___) - Diastolic Heart Failure: RV dilation and hypokinesis - Moderate mitral regurgitation - Moderate tricuspid regurgitation - Pulmonary hypertension -- moderate per recent TTEs - Chronic atrial fibrillation - Hyperlipidemia - Hypertension - Asthma - Obstructive sleep apnea - Fall History -- walks with a cane - Obesity - Prostate cancer -- s/p radiation and pellet implantation - Diabetes Mellitus: on Lantus and Humalog sliding scale - GIB History -- from overdose of Warfarin - Arthritis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - Mother: Died around age ___, patient unsure of cause - Father: Died at age ___ of heart disease, heavy smoking and alcohol - Siblings: no siblings <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: Afebrile, BPs 110s/60s-70s HR ___ 95%RA Weight: 100.1kg on discharge Gen: Elderly male in NAD. Oriented x3. Pleasant and appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. MMM, OP benign. Neck: Supple, full ROM. JVP at mid neck sitting at 60 degrees. No cervical lymphadenopathy. No carotid bruits noted. CV: RRR, soft S1, S2. Blowing holo-systolic murmur ___ at apex. Chest: Respiration unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Bibasilar crackles at bases. Moving air well and symmetrically Abd: Normal bowel sounds. Soft but distended, obese, NT. Ext: WWP. 2 Pedal edema bilaterally up to knee but improved from admission. Distal pulses intact radial 2, DP 2, ___ 2. Skin: Mild stasis dermatitis on anterior shins bilaterally. Neuro: CN II-XII grossly intact. Strength ___ in all extremities. Decreased ___ reflexes but symmetric. Mumbled speech though coherent . <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 12: 00PM BLOOD WBC-4.3 RBC-3.52* Hgb-10.7* Hct-34.6* MCV-98# MCH-30.4 MCHC-30.9* RDW-20.0* Plt ___ ___ 12: 00PM BLOOD ___ PTT-36.2* ___ ___ 12: 00PM BLOOD Glucose-115* UreaN-50* Creat-1.8* Na-143 K-3.8 Cl-100 HCO3-32 AnGap-15 ___ 12: 00PM BLOOD proBNP-2985* ___ 12: 00PM BLOOD Calcium-9.5 Phos-4.4 Mg-2.7* ___ 12: 00PM BLOOD LD(LDH)-259* CE Trend: ___ 12: 00PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.03* ___ 07: 05PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.03* ___ 12: 01AM BLOOD
summary: ___ year old male s/p bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement (25mm Biocor tissue valve) and CABG (LIMA-LAD, SVG-OM, SVG-PDA)on ___ complicated by PEA arrest x2 with pacer placement on ___ and two recent admissions for CHF exacerbation (Most recently he was diuresed 14kg) who presents to ___ with CHF exacerbation and AMS likely ___ medication induced delirium. # AMS: Resolved on admission. He was seen by Neurology in the ED and EEG was consistent with delirium. His medication list from his most recent rehab includes Tramadol, Ambien, and Wellbutrin. This is likely iatrogrenic effect and he has had problems with Ambien in the past. Infectious work up negative so far and CT head was negative for acute process. We avoided sedating medications and initially treated insomnia with seroquel but this was discontinued because of thrombocytopenia. He did have nightly delirium and agitation requiring extensive nursing support. Non-pharmacologic were tried first but patient continued to be agitated. He did not receive Haldol but Geriatrics recommended Haldol 0.25mg Q8hrs prn agitation. . # Diastolic CHF Exacerbation: Chronic with acute exacerbation on this admission, recent TTE LVEF>55%. His dry weight is reportedly about 213 lbs (96.8kg) per his family (Discharged on ___ at 99.6kg). Weight was 100.1kg on discharge though he appears grossly volume improved with improved ___ respiratory status and net negative nearly 6L during admission (1.5L negative on day of discharge). His respiratory status exhibitied bibasilar crackles which improved after diuresis and his SpO2 remained >95%RA throughout duration of admittion, CXR was unremarkable. ProBNP ___ is consistent with prior admission for CHF exacerbation. Patient has been without CP and CEs have been negative and wihout EKG changes. Cause of CHF exacerbation is unclear though dietary/fluid restriction may not have been well controlled at less skilled nursing facility and per patient, rehab

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeon s office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call
summary: The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: POD#0, the patient was straight cath'ed after he was unable to void. POD#1, the patient received a bolus of 500 mL of fluid due to low urine output. POD#2, the patient received 2 units of blood for a hematocrit of 20.4. He was also straight cath'ed due to high post-void residuals. POD#3, he was started on Flomax due to his retention issues. His post-void residuals decreased prior to discharge, but he is to continue with Flomax until his follow-up appointment with his PCP. His hematocrit (post-transfusion) was stable at 30.9. The patient continued to have a small amount of drainage from the incision. He was placed in a compressive dressing from toes to mid-thigh and monitored overnight. POD#4, mild serosanguinous drainage noted on old dressing, which occurred after ___ session on the day prior per patient. An Aquacel dressing was applied. Range of motion restrictions to 0 degrees of flexion with knee immobilizer. Patient worked with ___ and dressing was changed prior to discharge. Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral pain medications. The patient received Aspirin 81 mg twice daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The surgical dressing will remain on until POD#7 after surgery. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the dressing was intact. The patient

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ with PMH of HTN and DM who presents after a witnessed seizure and found to have hypertensive emergency. The ___ SBP when first checked was over 240mmHg. The patient was brought into the ICU at ___ for monitoring. He was given IV labetalol and close BP monitoring with the neurology team consulting. The ___ blood pressure was gradually brought down over his hospital course and he was restarted on some of his home medications and started on new meds (please see list). The ___ blood pressure on discharge was between 140 and 160 systolic. The patient was asymptomatic and had no neurological events once his blood pressure was treated. The patient will have close follow up with his PCP after discharge. ================ ACTIVE ISSUES ================= #Hypertensive emergency Blood pressure systolic of 240 at the scene per EMS. Was mildly altered though conversational on admission. Unclear if this was ___ state vs hypertensive encephalopathy. ___ mental status has improved considerably. MRI brain demonstrated many small chronic lacunar infarcts in the basal ganglia, deep white matter, and left thalamus, but no evidence of acute infarction. There is evidence of chronic small vessel disease. No evidence of PRES. Outpatient note indicates that he was on clonidine, metoprolol, torsemide, and lisinopril, although doses unknown. It appears that he has not filled these medications in some time, possibly months. Started on carvedilol, holding meds that ___ worsen renal function given unclear baseline (lisinopril/HCT). Continued dose of carvedilol to 12.5mg BID. Stopped hydralazine. Increased amlodipine to 10mg daily. Increased lisinopril to home 40mg daily. PCP verified medication list, however patient has not seen PCP for over one year. Adjusted medications to simplify medication regimen. #Acute vs Chronic Renal Failure: Unclear what baseline kidney function is at this time. Outpatient clinic note from the day of admission shows creatinine 3.03, but prior lab results sent from ___ show creatinine 1.9 in ___. No data

summary: PATIENT: Mr ___ is a ___ year old male with a past medical history of HIV (on HAART, CD4=599 in ___, HCV, HL (in remission), poorly controlled T2DM, candidemia, obstructed ureteral stone with associated pyelonephritis s/p cystoscopy and ureteral stent who presents with dysuria and tachycardia. ACUTE ISSUES: # Pyuria: Presented with urinary urgency and urethral irritation. Pyuria with WBC 90 with bacteria and yeast on UA. No evidence of flank pain. He was given vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and fluconazole in the ED for empiric treatment of UTI. Upon admission to the floor, vancomycin and ceftriaxone were discontinued and he was started on cipro 500mg BID and continued on fluconazole. Urine cultures grew yeast, but did not return with any bacteria species. Renal ultrasound did not show any hydropnephrosis or perinephric inflammation. Blood cultures, however, returned with ___ bottles with GPC is clusters (in anaerobic bottle). Given patient's stable vitals, lack of fever, and excellent-appearing clinical status, attributed to contamination. Patient instructed to return to seek further medical care if he developed fever or worsening symptoms. Patient felt much better at time of discharge and had no further symptoms of dysuria. # Tachycardia: Presented to ED with asymptomatic tachycardia to the 140s. EKG showed sinus tachycardia with a new right bundle branch block, but no notable ST changes. Tachycardia was hemodynamically tolerated at all times. Tachycardia resolved in the ED after the administration of antibiotics and IVF. Continued telemetry monitoring showed HR consistently less than 90 throughout the remainder of this hospitalization. Repeat EKG on ___ continued to show RBBB. No chest pain or SOB during this stay. # Cirrhosis: Presented with softly distended abdomen, increased weight. LFTs, coags wnl. Plt at 141, down from baseline of 200s. As there was concern for abdominal distention, and abdominal ultrasound was performed on ___ which showed no evidence of ascites. CHRONIC

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ w/ PMH of afib on xare___ who was involved in a MVC and initially presented to an OSH where imaging revaled a sternal fracture. The patient was transferred to ___ for further care. The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. Pain was managed with tramadol and acetaminophen. Home xarelto was initially held and HCT/Hgb was trended which remained stable. A tertiary survey was done showing no new injuries. She remained stable and was discharged in good condition with discharge instructions for activity precautions and pain control.

summary: Following initial evaluation in the Emergency Department, the patient was admitted to the ACS Team and sent to the floor. Following extensive discussions with the Orthopedic Spine Team, the decision was made to undergo non-operative management of his non-displaced cervical and thoracic fractures. Subsequent MRI and CT Spine demonstrated stable T-Spine fractures without threatened injury to the spinal cord. The decision was made to treat these fractures non-operatively with a ___ J Cervical Collar and Brace (TLSO). There was also initial concern and management for rhabdomyolysis; CK was trended to a maximum of 1352 and downtrended steadily to normal levels prior to discharge. He was treated with aggressive IVFR and his electrolytes and renal status were monitored on lab analysis daily. During the first two days of his admission, the patient became very agitated and given his history of alcohol abuse and dependence, went into alcohol withdrawal and delirium tremens. CIWA protocol was initiated but the patient remained agitated and unstable prompting a transfer from the floor to the TSICU to begin a Phenobarbital drip. Imaging Results and TSICU course as follows. The following images were ordered and reviewed with the results listed below. OSH CT C-spine ___: 1. R T1 superior facet non-displaced fracture 2. R C6 transverse foramen non-displaced fracture OSH CT Abd/pelvis: no renal trauma (laceration/hematoma) no RP hematoma, no free fluid in the pelvis, no free air; no e/o pelvic fx. the duodenum appears inflamed and thickened but with no adjacent stranding. OSH CT Head: no evidence of intracranial trauma or skull fracture CTA neck ___ ___: Right nondisplaced fracture through the right transverse foramen at C6 without evidence of vascular injury. A fracture of the right transverse process and inferior articular facet at T1 is better evaluated on the CT C-spine ___. No dissection, aneurysm or thrombosis. CT L spine ___ ___: No fracture or mal

summary: ___ with HCV cirrhosis who p/w hypotension, VTach, and lateral ST depressions after an epi injection into a duodenal polyp. Acute: # Hypotension/VTach/ST depressions: Likely due to catecholamine surge from epinephrine which was probably injected into a vein and made it's way to the heart. No history of coronary artery disease, though patient may have a fixed stenosis which explains the ST depressions which have since resolved. Her enzymes have trended down during this admission (the most recent being 0.05) and she has had no symptoms of chest pain or shortness of breath. Given that she did have some abnormal EKG changes and enzyme leak, it was reccomended that the patient continue cardiac workup as an outpatient (nuclear stress test) and continue 81 ASA for now. Chronic: # HCV cirrhosis: Followed by GI. Has been stable in house; will continue treatment with OP followup after discharge. # Depression: Stable on home bupropion Transitional: - Pt to follow up with Dr. ___ in order to set up outpatient nuclear stress test.

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service on ___ for observation for heavy vaginal bleeding after a spontaneous abortion. Her vital signs, hematocrit and vaginal bleeding were stable and her pain was well-controlled with oral ibuprofen and tylenol and she was discharged later the same day in stable condition with outpatient followup arranged.

summary: PATIENT SUMMARY: ================ Mr. ___ is a ___ with PMH of NASH cirrhosis (Child C, MELD ___ on admission) currently undergoing transplant evaluation, previously decompensated by ascites, portal HTN, esophageal varices s/p banding, GI bleeding, non-occlusive PVT (on warfarin) and recurrent pleural effusions, who presents 1 day after discharge with hemoptysis. Monitored for 48 hours with no further episodes of hemoptysis, stable Hgb, and stable vital signs. ACTIVE ISSUES: ============== # Hemoptysis Presented with one small-volume episode of hemoptysis after coughing episode, likely due to small pulmonary hemorrhage. No melena, hematochezia, or hematemesis. Hemoglobin at baseline on admission. Recently initiated on warfarin, INR 1.5 on presentation; however, patient underwent 2 days of lovenox bridge prior to last discharge, so likely was therapeutically anticoagulated. Initially started on ceftriaxone and IV PPI due to concern for variceal bleed; ultimately discontinued upon review of EGD from ___ that showed no evidence of varices. No further episodes of hemoptysis. Discharge Hgb 10.6 # SMV Thrombus with extension to right portal vein Discussed at ___ conference on last admission; clot deemed too small for intervention with TIPs, and decision made to manage medically with anticoagulation. Started on warfarin with 2d lovenox bridge. Warfarin discontinued on admission due to hemoptysis. RUQUS with no main, right, or left portal vein thrombus, but extrahepatic main portal vein and SMV were unable to be evaluated. ASA 325mg re-started. # NASH cirrhosis (Child B, MELD 21 on admission) c/b ascites, portal HTN, esophageal varices s/p banding, GI bleeding, non-occlusive PVT (on warfarin), recurrent pleural effusion - VOLUME: No ascites on ___ RUQUS. summary: Briefly, Ms. ___ presented to ___ for planned peritoneal dialysis catheter placement after being seen for eval in transplant surgery clinic. She tolerated the procedure well, was extubated in the OR, and recovered from anesthesia in the PACU without incident. Her home medications were restarted and she tolerated a regular diet. She was transferred to the inpatient floor overnight for observation, and underwent hemodialysis via her tunnedled R IJ catheter that was already in place. Her HD session was uneventful and she was discharged home in good condition with scheduled follow up.

summary: Ms. ___ presented to the ___ ED on ___ as a transfer from ___ in ___ for higher level of care for her small bowel obstruction and RNY gastric bypass. Ms. ___ arrived with symptoms and a CT Scan demonstrating a small bowel obstruction secondary to adhesions or an internal hernia. It also demonstrated impending danger of rupture of her afferent limb and her gastric remnant from her previous RNY gastric bypass procedure. After discussion with Attending Surgeon Dr. ___ was brought back to the ___ on ___ for an urgent Exploratory Laparotomy and Lysis of Adhesions. She tolerated the procedure well. Please see the operative note for further details. She was sent to the PACU with an Epidural in place, which was subsequently removed for hypotension and failure to provide appropriate pain relief. She was provided with IV pain medications, received resuscitative fluid and was sent to the floor once stable. While on the floor, Ms. ___ continued to demonstrate a developing anemia for which she was transfused 1 unit of blood. Her blood levels stabilized appropriately. Her pain medication was transitioned to oral control and her diet was advanced once she demonstrated bowel function. Neuro: Pain was well controlled on CV: Vital signs were routinely monitored during the patient's length of stay. Pulm: The patient was encouraged to ambulate, sit and get out of bed, use the incentive spirometer, and had oxygen saturation levels monitored as indicated. GI: The patient was initially kept NPO after the procedure. The patient was later advanced to and tolerated a regular diet following return of bowel function. She did not experience any pain, nausea or vomiting associated with po intake. GU: Patient had a Foley catheter that was removed at time of discharge. Urine output was monitored as indicated. At time of discharge, the patient was voiding without difficulty. ID: The patient's vital signs were monitored for signs of infection and fever. The patient was started on/continued

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Statins-Hmg-Coa Reductase Inhibitors / Benadryl <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Pre-syncope <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old man with complex PMH including lateral medullary stroke, cardiac amyloid, symptomatic bradycardia s/p dual chamber pacemaker, chronic intermittent SOB and lightheadedness who presents with three days shortness of breath and malaise. 4 days prior to admission, Mr. ___ reports a new sensation of dizziness/lightheadedness. While in bed, he was looking at the wall and saw the room slide back and forth for 2 minutes. He had no weakness, loss of sensation, word finding difficulty, nausea, no change in hearing, nor palpitations. He does have bilateral, baseline, low-grade tinnitus, which has not changed. Reports shortness of breath that is also chronic. This vision change reoccurred several minutes later for a period of some seconds when he kneeled down at home. Over the last three days he has been using a cane for extra support but denies weakness. No fevers, chills, cough, abdominal pain, diarrhea, n/v. He presented to ___ on ___. Workup was notable for elevated troponin t to 0.099 (troponin I of 0.01-0.02). He had a head CT that was negative for acute process. He was given aspirin 325 mg p.o. 1 and Nitropaste. He was transferred to ___ for neurologic and cardiology evaluation. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - HLD - Glucose intolerance. - Bradycardia, PR prolongation and left anterior hemiblock s/p DDDR pacemaker implantation ___ for recurrent syncope (in the setting of vasodilator circumstances such as eating, GI bleeding, and standing quickly). He had further syncope in ___ and his pacemaker setting was changed to include a Rate Drop feature. - Clinical left lateral medullary stroke without MRI correlate ___ felt likely due to small vessel disease. Managed on aspirin. - Patient had complained of dizziness and unsteadiness on his feet from ___ and on examination, there was evidence of a left Horner's syndrome, left gaze nystagmus, ipsilateral facial sensory loss with contralateral arm and leg sensory loss and left-sided dysmetria. MRI/MRA head and neck was negative for an acute stroke but limited in detecting a subacute lateral medullary stroke given onset of symptoms 1 month before imaging was performed. He had a follow-up CTA head and neck which showed mild calcifications at the common carotid artery bifurcations and intracranial cavernous carotid arteries. He was started on aspirin 81mg qd. - Previous significant GI bleeds with angiodysplasia on EGD in ___ and terminal ileum erosions on capsule endoscopy ___ H pylori positive. These were felt to be due to either the nonspecific erosions seen in his ileum and/or more likely acquired vascular ectasia in either the small bowel or upper GI tract as noted. - Cervical spondylosis with MRI C spine showing multilevel degenerative changes particularly at C5-C6 where there is moderate-to-severe bilateral foraminal narrowing and managed with a soft collar but has stopped wearing this as he could not tolerate it. - Arthritis in bilateral hips -PERIPHERAL NEUROPATHY He was seen in the sleep disorders clinic with Dr ___ on ___ for several years of sleep difficulties and was felt to have sleep maintenance insomnia related to anxiety and was advised regarding good sleep hygiene and meditation techniques. He then had a left total hip replacement at the ___ on ___ after being medically cleared and was started on warfarin for DVT prophylaxis. He was transferred from rehab to the ___ ED with increased left lower extremity swelling on ___ and CT pelvis/leg showed a quadratus femoris hematoma and his haemoglobin remained stable. He also had urinary retention and CT showed no obstruction and a urinary catheter as placed with a large post-void residual. He was found to have an enterococcus UTI and was treated for this. He was discharged on ___ to rehab and was seen by urology on ___ with catheter still in-situ. He was discharged from rehab on ___. Past Surgical History: - s/p left THR ___ - s/p dual chamber pacemaker implantation ___ - s/p ___ surgery left lateral lower leg ___ for basal cell ca - s/p hernia repair ___ - s/p appendectomy ___ - s/p tonsillectomy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father died at age ___ from complications of COPD. He was a heavy smoker. Mother died at age ___. Interestingly, in her late ___ had recurrent GI bleeding of undetermined etiology. He has one brother who is well, another brother who had mastoid surgery at age ___ and a half years and died. There is no known family history of colon cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> GENERAL: No acute distress, pleasant gentleman lying comfortably in bed HEENT: NCAT, EOMI, moist mucous membranes, oropharynx clear NECK: supple
summary: PATIENT SUMMARY: ___ year old man with PMH lateral medullary stroke, cardiac amyloid, symptomatic bradycardia s/p pacemaker placement with recent unremarkable interrogations, who presented with shortness of breath, new visual changes, Troponin of 0.04, with negative neurologic workup. ACUTE ISSUES: # Presyncope: # Visual changes concerning for stroke: CT Head and follow-up scan at 24h: negative for acute intracranial process. Neuro exam unchanged from baseline. Neurology evaluated and recommended outpatient follow up with neurology and no change in management. D-dimer was checked in the setting of presyncope and was found to be elevated. VQ Scan (___) low probability for PE. He had an echo which showed prominent symmetric LVH with normal global and regional biventricular systolic function, mild aortic regurgitation, mild mitral regurgitation, and a mildly dilated ascending aorta. He was discharged on aspirin 81 per neurology recommendations. # NSTEMI, type II: likely demand ischemia, unclear etiology, ekg without signs of ischemia, asymptomatic. Monitored on telemetry with no events. CHRONIC ISSUES: # ___ lateral medullary stroke: mild Horner's syndrome with lateral gaze nystagmus. No new neurological symptoms, stable neuro exam per neurology. # Bradycardia s/p pacemaker: paced rhythm with no new changes. Not interrogated in setting of recent unremarkable interrogations. # Cardiac amyloid, biopsy-confirmed in ___ # ___ # HLD # Arthitis TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: [] inpatient neuro consult recommended considering switching Aspirin to Plavix [] F/u with Dr. ___ 2 weeks [] Consider outpatient TTE with bubble to evaluate for PFO/ASD.

summary: #Choledocolithiasis: Mrs. ___ was admitted for evaluation of post-prandial RUQ abdominal pain and nausea in the setting of elevated LFTs and TBili. Patient was otherwise afebrile and hemodynamically stable. In the emergency department, a RUQ ultrasound was performed, which showed mild intrahepatic ductal dilation. A CT abdomen was performed, which showed gallbladder collapse with mild wall thickening and hyperenahncement of the cystic and common bile duct wall, concerning for cholangitis. A PICC was placed on ___, and patient was started empirically on Unasyn and given aggressive IV hydration. An MRCP was performed on ___, which showed an obstructing 5 mm ampullary stone with resultant moderate to severe biliary obstruction. Patient underwent an ERCP on ___, at which time an obstructing stone was removed. Patient tolerated procedure well. Post-procedurally, patient did not have abdominal pain, and her diet was advanced without difficulty. Per recommendations from ERCP, she was seen by general surgery to discuss cholecystectomy. However, patient reported that she would like to have a physician recommended by her PCP. Her LFTs and TBili also downtrended. She was switched to Augmentin on ___ with a plan to finish a 7-day post-ERCP course of Augmentin on ___. Her PICC line was also removed on ___. #Incidental hepatic hemangiomas: Patient was incidentally found to have hemangiomas on CT and MRI. #IPMNs: Patient was incidentally found on MRCP to have multiple pancreatic cysts measuring up to 9 mm, most of which demonstrate connection to the main pancreatic duct, likely side-branch IMPN. It was recommended that she she have follow up imaging in ___ year.

summary: A/P: ___ yo F with hx of DM 2 and nephrotic range proteinuria presents with 1 week of total body swelling and acute on chronic renal failure . #. Anasarca: The patients presentation likely represents end stage diabetic nephopathy with fluid retention and nephotic syndrome edema. This was confirmed by continued nephrotic range proteinuria and shrunken kidneys with medullary loss on the renal u/s. However, an acute on chronic nephrotic process could not be ruled out. However, this would not change our current management as the patient was initiated on hemodialsys during this admission. It is possible that there was a cardiac component to her anasarca, especially given her significant TR. However, cardiac edema in unlikely to cause upper extremity edema. Furthermore, her systolic function was relatively preserved. Her anasarca improved with fluid removal by hemodialysis but she will require continued excess fluid removal to fully regain her dry weight. . #. ARF: The patient was evaluated by the nephrology service who felt that her renal failure represented a natural progression of her diabetic nephropathy, unmonitored for over ___ years. There may be an acute nephrotic process on top as well but again, this would not change management as hemodialysis was initiated by R IJ tunnelled HD line during this admission. Her urine sediment non-inflammattory with no RBC casts and ___ coarse granular casts and her renal U/S was without hydronephrosis. That and a FeNa 1.8% all go against an acute pre-renal or post renal cause. Furthermore, an SPEP/UPEP were negative. Her PTH was elevated at 325, again indicating a chronic process. Hepatitis serologies were all negative. The patient was started on Phoslo and nephrocaps. Vein mapping was also done for further vascular access. The patient tolerated hemodialysis well with no complications. The patient will continue outpatient hemodialysis and will follow up with her outpatient hemodialysis nephrologist for further management. . # SOB

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ YOM with metastatic melanoma to liver and lungs who presented for IL-2 therapy . # Liver metasteses bleed: On treatment day #8 of IL-2 the patient was noted to have a Hct drop from 33.9 to 20. Repeat Hct was 18.5, plt 59, INR 1.3. LFTs were also elevated acutely. BP was 130-140, but tachycardic to 100-120. He was transfused 2 units with resulting Hct of 23.1 and then transfused another 2 units. CT torso revealed active hemorrhage from one of multiple liver lesions. He was taken to ___ where a groin central line was placed. He underwent Angio of celiac and hepatic arteries. No active bleeding was seen and the tumors were actually hypovascular, but some superior vessels of the right hepatic artery were embolized with gelfoam as this was sight of most substantial bleeding on recent noncon CT. There were no complications. He was then transferred to the ICU for monitoring. Serial Hcts were checked and were stable and he was transferred out of the ICU. His pain continued to improve on the floor, though he still required pain medication at time of discharge. . # Metastatic melanoma: The patient finished IL-2 on ___. He was continued on oxycodone PRN for pain. Will follow-up with biologics team as outpatient early this week. . # Myocarditis: The patient was found to have elevated CK, troponin, and CKMB consistent with IL-2 induced myocarditis. He was monitored on telemetry and was found to have a few short runs of NSVT. His biomarkers trended back down over time. # Depression: The patient was continued on his home dose celexa. #Hypoxia: Combination of effusion/splinting/atelectasis. Has small oxygen requirement at time of discharge. Was encouraged to ambulate and use incentive spirometer. #Pleural effsion: Seen previously. Given recent IL-2/volume

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> diploplia, vertigo, dizziness and lightheadedness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> LP ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old male with double-hit lymphoma who progressed through 6 cycles of da-EPOCH-R with a mixed response to 2 lines of salvage R-ICE. More recently, he was planned to enroll on clinical trial using CAR-T cells; however, a recent MRI of the spine was consistent with leptomeningeal lymphomatous disease as well as soft-tissue pre-vertebral lesions. He received HD-MTX 3.5gm/m2. Due to his CNS disease, his HD MTX was increased to 4.8gm/m2. He received 2 doses at this level, he is currently admitted with new diplopia. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HEMATOLOGIC HISTORY: - Presented to his PCP with about ___ months of nagging lower back pain bilaterally, worse with climbing stairs and with prolonged sitting, worse at night and associated with worsening fatigue, drenching night sweats, and occasional low-grade fevers through standing tylenol for his back pain. He had no neurological deficits or bowel/bladder dysfunction. Given his nephrolithiasis hx, his PCP obtained ___ CT scan at ___ which revealed bulky retroperitoneal LAD - this finding prompted transfer to ___ where he was admitted ___. - ___ course was notable for discovery of a normocytic anemia with Hgb 10.5, LDH of 400, b2M of 2.6, uric acid mildly elevated at 7.4, CRP 160, ESR 94, negative HIV/HCV/EBV/CMV serologies. CT imaging revealed diffuse LAD including bulky and confluent disease in multiple areas including RP, pelvic sidewall, inguinal region, axillary, and porta hepatis, along with findings of splenomegaly and moderate right-sided hydronephrosis favored to be due to urothelial thickening from adjacent adenopathy. - Excisional biopsy of a R inguinal node revealed kappa light chain restricted B lymphoproliferative disorder with CD10 expression. Preliminary hematopathology favored follicular lymphoma. - Discharged home after symptomatic improvement with IV fluids and pain control - Subsequent pathologic/cytogenetic work-up revealed a complex karyotype with t(8;22)(q24.1;q11.2) and the t(14;18)(q32;q21 consistent with double-hit lymphoma - Seen in clinic and direct admitted to initiate da-EPOCH-R, C1D1 ___ - ___ - C2D1 R daEPOCH level 2. ANC remained >500, platelets >25k - ___ - admit for C3D1 R-daEPOCH level ___ - hospitalization for R neck swelling, work-up revealed IJ thrombosis associated with port. port remained functional, anticoagulated with lovenox and discharge without need for port removal - ___ - C4D1 RdaEPOCH dose level 4. - ___ - labs with ANC 400, platelets 21k, Hgb 6.0. ___ transfused 2 units pRBCs; therapeutic lovenox had been held when platelets <50k - ___ - C5D1 RdaEPOCH dose level 3 - ___ - C6D1 R-daEPOCH dose level 2 - ___ PET/CT - FDG avid mesenteric adenopathy, focal FDG avid lesion in L3 vertebral body, both consistent with lymphoma. FDG uptake in acromion and left clavicle, likely degenerative. focal FDG avid soft tissue sacral lesion possibly sebaceous cyst - ___ L3 vertebral body biopsy - confirms presence of very high-grade lymphoma - ___ - C1D1 salvage ICE chemotherapy - ___ - C2D1 salvage ICE chemotherapy, ___ dose-reduced by 20% for thrombocytopenia - ___ - ___ collection for clinical trial ___, CAR-T study - ___ - ___ - XRT to right distal femur, total 3500cGy - ___, increasing back pain with MRI showing lymphomatous leptomeningeal disease along with disease of the L3 vertebral body with diffuse bilateral prevertebral enhancing soft tissue abnormalities, with an anterior epidural enhancing lesion traversing the L4 nerve roots. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old male with double-hit bony lymphoma who progressed through 6 cycles of da-EPOCH-R with a mixed response to 2 lines of salvage R-ICE, who was admitted for diplopia. #Refractory DLBCL with CNS involvement: Patient presented with diplopia consistent with CNS involvement. Recent MRI of the spine showed leptomeningeal lymphomatous disease. LP on ___ also showed lymphocyte infiltration in keeping with CNS lymphoma. He received HD (8g/m2) methotrexate treatment (___) during this admission. His methotrexate level was 0.03 on the day of discharge. He still complains of some diplopia, although overall feel improved from treatment. Plan is to follow with Dr. ___ in the outpatient clinic. #Bilateral Shoulder Pain: This is likely secondary to lymphomatous involvement based on recent MRI. Improved upon MTX treatment. He received supportive care with dilaudid/Tylenol prn for pain management. #Vertigo/Lightheadedness/Dizziness: Occurred intermittently with sitting up and lasted few seconds. Likely components of hypovolemia. These symptoms have significantly improved after receiving HD MTX. #Low-back pain: Known leptomeningeal enhancement along the cauda equina and lower thoracic/lumbar nerve roots (improved after first HD MTX treatment). No bowel/bladder incontinence/retention. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES # Medication changes -Leucovorin 25 mg every 6 hours for 2 days # Followup with Rad-onc, Drs. ___ ___ on Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Acyclovir 400 mg PO Q8H 2. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN pain 3. LORazepam 0.5-1 mg PO Q4H:PRN nausea anxiety insomnia 4. Ondansetron 8 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 5. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim SS 1 TAB PO DAILY 6. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain Discharge Medications: 1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 2.

summary: ___ y/o M s/p C3-5 posterior lami/fusion,presented to ED with drainage from wound. He was also found to have elevated WBC and CRP. He was brought to the operating room and found to have purulent fluid in wound. Patient had wound washout, and tolerated the procedure well. He recovered in the PACU and remained hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the floor. Intraoperative samples were sent for culture and vancomycin was then started. Postoperatively he continued to receive IV antibiotics and infectious disease team was consulted. His blood cultures and intraoperative cultures grew Gram positive cocci POD1 and he was started on ceftriaxone and continued on vancomycin (___). On POD 3, ID recommended changing antibiotic coverage to Cefazolin alone and would consider adding in Rifampin (it was later decided not to add Rifampin). They also recommended a TTE which was completed and recommended the patient have a Picc placed. Patient had Picc placed on ___. His OR cultures finalized as MSSA. ID finalized patient's discharge plan and he was ordered for 6 weeks of IV antibiotics (Cefazolin 2g IV Q8hrs). On ___ patient continued to have purulent drainage from his wound that was worse with movement, a dressing was applied over the surgical site. The drainage was improved on ___, and no drainage was noted on exam on ___. It was determined the patient would be discharged to ___. At the time of discharge patients vital signs remained stable, he was ambulating with assistance, he was voiding independently, and was tolerating PO pain medication and a diet. He was discharged to rehab on ___.
