summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the Orthopedic service on ___ for a right hip and right humerus fracture after being evaluated and treated with closed reduction in the emergency room. She underwent percutaneous pinning of the right hip without complication on ___. She was extubated without difficulty and transferred to the recovery room in stable condition. In the early post-operative course Ms. ___ developed low urine output from post operative blood loss anemia. She was treated with one unit of packed red blood cells in the recovery room. Her urine output continued to be low and she was given 500 cc normal saline bolus for post operative fluid volume deficit. Her urine output improved and she was transferred to the floor in stable condition. After being transferred to the floor there were no overnight events. On ___ she was noted to have low oxygen saturation (77%) on room air. Her oxygen improved to 90% on 5l oxygen. She was seen by geriatrics and started on nebulizers with improvement in her oxygen saturation. She was also seen by dr ___ pulmonologist and recs were done. She had adequate pain management and worked with physical therapy while in the hospital. The remainder of her hospital course was uneventful and Ms. ___ is being discharged to rehab. on ___ /10 in stable condition.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> ___ vaccination <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> R frontal strokes <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ (BID #: ___ is a ___ year old woman (male to female transgender) for him a neurology consult is requested due to concern for stroke. She was in her usual state of health at 11 ___, when she went to bed last night. She woke up this morning at around 5 AM and did some reading on her iPad. At that time, she did not notice any problems with her speech or asymmetry of her face, but did not speak to anyone or look at herself in the mirror. She went back to sleep for a few hours. When she awoke again at 8: 45 AM, her roommate noted that her speech seemed slurred. ___ also agrees that her speech was slurred. She denies any paraphasias or word finding difficulty. She states that her tongue did not seem coordinated. She also noticed the gradual onset of a pins and needle sensation on the entire left side of her face, more notable in the V2 and V3 distributions. This came on over the whole face, and there was no ___ with regards to the location of the pins and needles. When she looked in the mirror, she also noted that the left side of her face seemed to activate slower when she smiled. She called a friend on the phone at 9: 30 AM, and felt like her speech was still slurred, although better than before. She did not have a headache during this time. Due to persistent symptoms that worried her for stroke, she presented to the ED. On my interview in the ED, at around 10: 30 am, she states that her speech and abnormal facial sensations are improving, but not yet back to normal. She subjectively feels that the left side of her face is still slower to activate, although has not checked this in a mere. Notably, she does have a history of migraine with aura. Her usual aura is of scintillating scotomas in one or both eyes. This is followed ___ minutes later by headache. She experiences migraines about once per month. She has had headaches in the past with an aura of facial paresthesias, although this is not occurred since her ___ to ___. She also gets frequent dull, aching headaches without any aura. These usually occur 2 times per week. She has never had any difficulty with her speech as a symptom of migraine. On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, dysphagia, lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending speech. Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait. On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or chills. No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Migraine headaches <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father had a stroke in his ___, which she describes as severe. Also had cardiomyopathy. Paternal grandmother had stroke in her ___ Mother had breast cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: 98.8 P: 78 R: 16 BP: 170/102 SaO2: 99% RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity Pulmonary: Normal work of breathing Cardiac: RRR, warm, well-perfused Abdomen: soft, non-distended Extremities: No ___ edema. Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. Neurologic: -Mental Status: Alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attentive, able to name ___ backward without difficulty. Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension. Normal prosody. There were no paraphasic errors. Pt was able to name both high and low frequency objects. Able to read without difficulty. Speech was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: II, III, IV, VI: PERRL 3 to 2mm and brisk. EOMI without nystagmus. Normal saccades. VFF to confrontation. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch. Reports decreased sensation to pinprick (70-80% of normal in V2-3, and 90% normal in V1) on left face. VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric. VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___
summary: Ms ___ is a ___ year old woman (male to female transgender) on hormonal tx with a history of migraine with aura (usually scintillating scotomas) who presented with slurred speech, pins and needles in left V1-V3, and subjective facial droop on admission, found to have new R frontal strokes. #R frontal strokes Ms ___ is a ___ year old woman (male to female transgender) on hormonal tx with a history of migraine with aura (usually scintillating scotomas) who presented with slurred speech, pins and needles in left V1-V3, and subjective facial droop on admission, found to have new R frontal strokes on MRI wo contrast. Most likely etiology of stroke is likely cardioembolic iso estradiol use vs hypercoagulability. NCHCT with no evidence of bleed. CTA head and neck w no evidence of dissection or thrombosis. TTE showed early appearance of agitated saline in the left atrium at rest most c/w a patent foramen ovale but was otherwise normal. LENIs did not show any evidence of DVT. Beta 2 macroglobulin ab, cardiolipin ab and lupus anticoagulant were pending at discharge. Stroke risk factors were LDL 83, HbA1C 5.8%. Patient was started on aspirin and atorvastatin. Patient was also educated about the increased risk of stroke while on hormonal tx with estradiol and was recommended follow up at ___ clinic for further evaluation. She reported that she was taking 1mg ___ of a 2mg tab) twice daily, which is the max recommended dose. Endocrinology was contacted who agreed that there is increased risk, but did suggest that if patient were willing to accept risk of stroke on a lower dose, she could start at same dose at initiation. From the stroke stand point I clearly informed the patient that estrogen increases the risk of stroke and since she had a stroke while of estrogen it

summary: Mrs. ___ presented to ___ holding at ___ on ___ for a right laparoscopic colectomy. She tolerated the procedure well without complications (Please see operative note for further details). After a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was transferred to the floor for further post-operative management. Neuro: Pain was well controlled on oxycodone CV: Vital signs were routinely monitored during the patient's length of stay. Pulm: The patient was encouraged to ambulate, sit and get out of bed, use the incentive spirometer, and had oxygen saturation levels monitored as indicated. GI: The patient was initially kept NPO after the procedure. On post-operative day one to two, she tolerated clear liquids. She passed gas, and she was advanced to a regular diet which she tolerated well. GU: Patient had a Foley catheter that was removed at time of discharge. Urine output was monitored as indicated. At time of discharge, the patient was voiding without difficulty. ID: The patient's vital signs were monitored for signs of infection and fever. The patient was started on/continued on antibiotics as indicated. Heme: The patient had blood levels checked post operatively during the hospital course to monitor for signs of bleeding. The patient had vital signs, including heart rate and blood pressure, monitored throughout the hospital stay. On ___, the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, stooling, voiding, and ambulating independently. She will follow-up in the clinic in ___ weeks. This information was communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge. Post-Surgical Complications During Inpatient Admission: [ ] Post-Operative Ileus resolving w/o NGT [ ] Post-Operative Ileus requiring management with NGT [ ] UTI [ ] Wound Infection [ ] Anastomotic Leak [ ] Staple Line Bleed [ ] Congestive Heart failure [ ] ARF [ ] Acute Urinary retention, failure to void after Foley D/C'd [ ] Acute Urinary

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the Operating Room where he underwent a right video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) wedge resection with lymph node dissection. He tolerated the procedure well and returned to the PACU in stable condition. He maintained stable hemodynamics and his pain was controlled with IV Dilaudid. His chest tube drained minimal serosanguinous fluid and had no air leak. Following transfer to the Surgical floor he continued to progress well. His chest tube was removed on post op day #1 and his post pull film showed no pneumothorax. He was up and walking independently and his room air saturations were 96%. His pain was less following removal of the tube and Oxycodone was effective in relieving the discomfort. His port sites were dry but his chest tube site had some serosanguinous oozing with coughing which was more of a nuisance. A ___ silk was placed after prepping the site which resolved the issue. After an uneventful recovery he was discharged to home on ___ and will follow up in the Thoracic Clinic with Dr. ___ in 2 weeks. She will remove his chest tube suture at that time.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis. You were taken to the operating room and had your appendix removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the following instructions. Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the appointment listed below. ACTIVITY: o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and feel you could respond in an emergency. o You may climb stairs. o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you see your surgeon at your next visit. o Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap. o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you can resume tub baths or swimming. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: o You may feel weak or washed out for a couple of weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. o You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your throat during surgery. o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You might feel somewhat depressed. o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem unappealing. o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon. YOUR INCISION: o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay). o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is normal. o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision. o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area. o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told otherwise. o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call your surgeon. o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may resume tub baths or swimming. YOUR BOWELS: o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule
summary: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain. Admission abdominal/pelvic CT revealed uncomplicated, acute appendicitis. WBC was elevated at 17.9. The patient underwent laparoscopic appendectomy, which went well without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor tolerating clears, on IV fluids, and vicodin for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable. . Diet was progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. . At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

summary: The patient underwent an uncomplicated procedure. She was transfused 1 RBC. She was discharged to rehab about a routine postop recovery. She was given written information and precautionary guidance. MICU Course- Patient admitted to the MICU after developing SVT, delirium and leukocytosis on POD 3. Prior to transfer, EKG obtained showed sinus rhythm with borderline left axis deviation, borderline intraventricular conduction delay with TWF in the inferolateral leads (all changes new since previous EKG on record ___. CXR showed likely LLL infiltrate and increased vascular markings suggestive of CHF. CE's trended with peak troponin of 1.30, peak CK of 508 and peak MB of 37. Diagnosed with NSTEMI vs demand ischemia. Cardiology consulted and recommended medical management as patient could not be bolused with heparin given recent spinal procedure. Therefore, she could not undergo catheterization. She was started on aspirin 325mg, beta-blocker, high-dose statin. She underwent TTE on ___ which showed EF of 25% with septal and apical akinesis. After transferring to floor, she was taken off the heparin. Questionable thrombus in left ventricle was evulated and thought to be old with fibronsis over it, so patient was maintained on a full dose of aspirin. She was not started on warfarin due to her history of multiple falls. She remained afebrile thoroughout her stay. Physical therapy evaluated her. It was thought that her troponin leak is rate related and her poor EF is due to an old MI. This post-op tachyarrhythmia revealed the defect and cause her troponin to raise. She remained in sinus on the floor and was discharged in stable condition. Her PICC line was stopped and her foley was discharged. She does have a residue small apical pneumothorax which we are following with serial CXR. No intervention needed at this point but may need a repeat CXR in about a week. She has to follow up with Dr. ___ ___ ___ 10:40. She also needs to wear TLSO brace while she is up and

summary: ___ male with a history of atrial fibrillation on warfarin s/p pacemaker for symptomatic bradycardia (___) admitted for chronic abdominal pain and rigors at home, found to have elevated indirect hyperbilirubinemia and CT evidence pancreatic lesion of unknown etiology. Evaluated by GI who recommended MRI with likely subsequent EUS with biopsy, however given overall clinical stability this was deferred to be completed as outpatient. Abdominal pain is chronic in nature and unclear to what extent related to new pancreatic lesion. # EPIGASTRIC ABDOMINAL PAIN # PERIPANCREATIC FAT STRANDING Patient has a long standing history of similar abdominal pain dating back many years (patient is unclear how long) though unclear if new imaging findings are necessarily related to chronic pain. Low suspicion for acute pancreatitis given atypical pain, normal lipase. History and imaging is not suggestive of chronic pancreatitis either. New soft tissue is however concerning for malignancy or other unclear process, but patient without recent weight loss, night sweats, or other new symptoms. Patient was monitored for over 36 hours without recurrence of rigors, was afebrile and with normal vital signs, without antibiotics. MRI was ordered as per the recommendation of the GI consult team, but patient required EP eval given presence of pacemaker. It was determined this would more easily occur as an outpatient, and so given his mild and very tolerable pain, benign exam, and desire to have this done as an outpatient, he was discharged home with plan for GI follow up for further workup. Patient was disinterested in obtaining MRI, stating what is the point. Advised him to discuss further with his PCP. However, after discharge, his imaging was reviewed by pancreas conference who advised against obtaining an MRI. PCP was included on these emails. # LEUKOCYTOSIS Presented with chills and associated leukocytosis with neutrophilic predominance. Blood culture, urine culture without growth during hospitalization. No focal signs of infection. CXR normal. UA bland. Patient

summary: ___ M with history of Alzheimer's dementia, HTN, DMII, recurrent syncope, and aspiration p/w vomiting x4 and increased fatigue found to have type II NSTEMI in the setting of SVT. # Type II NSTEMI: He had no ischemic EKG changes and his cardiac biomakers peaked at Trop-T: 0.48, MB 31 prior to downtrending. His SVT resolved with adenosine and he was started on propranolol 20mg BID. He did not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or other ischemic symptoms. He did not have any further episodes of SVT during admission and was discharged on aspirin and carvedilol and his propranolol was stopped. Patient and family is aware that patient ___ have significant coronary artery disease. They did not want to purusue stress test/further work up as he is elderly, has advanced dementia, and because aggressive measures are not within his goals of care. # Vomiting: During his initial presentation, the patient had vomited immediately after eating oatmeal, as witnessed by his son on day of admission. Vomiting resolved on admission and he had no diarrhea or nausea. Also the patient underwent initial evaluation by the speech and swallow team in the hospital who recommended a video swallow testing, the family refused this test and preferred not to change the patient diet despite the risk of aspiration. on discharge the patient did not have signs of aspiration on exam. # Retrocardiac opacity on CXR: Given history of vomiting and aspiration patient was started on CAP/aspiration coverage (ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and flagyl Day 1 ___ for a 5 day course. The patient showed improvement in his clinical condition and remain afebrile during his admission. # ___ on CKD: Cr was elevated to 1.9 with baseline 1.1. Likely ___ to obstructive ___ due to BPH. A foley was placed by urology on ___ with good urine out put resulting in improvement of his kidney function. urology was consulted and recommended that he would be discharged with a foley

summary: ================================ TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ================================ []CRP elevated again to 107.2, unclear if this represents true progression of autoimmune disease or if she was inconsistently taking the anti-inflammatory treatments as an outpatient as there was some concern she may have missed doses and/or ran out of medication. []Changed naproxen to indomethacin for treatment of pericardial chest pain. ================================ BRIEF SUMMARY ================================ ___ is a ___ year old women with a recent diagnosis of autoimmune disease (unclear overlap syndrome of RA and lupus, also known as rhupus) after she was admitted from ___ with a pericardial effusion in the setting of an influenza infection. The effusion was drained of 570cc of fluid on ___ given concern for tamponade (pericardial pressures of 23) and the etiology was unclear (auto-immune vs. influenza infection). She had since been improving on anti-inflammatories under the care of the rheumatology team when she had return of pericardial-like chest pain on ___. While she did have sinus tachycardia, her ECHO had no evidence of constriction or tamponade and the pulsus was <10 with a normal appearing IVC (as such no fluids were administered). She was discharged on a regimen of colchicine and indomethacin taper (25mg TID x 2w, 25mg BID x ___, and 25mg daily x2m). We felt like the description of her chest pain was consistent enough with pericarditis that other diagnoses such as PE did not need to be persued. She has rheumatology and cardiology follow up in the coming months and will have a repeat ECHO next week to be followed up by Dr. ___ in cardiology. We did note that there were some issues with medication adherence, mostly due to financial barriers, and we directed her to the Free Care through financial services.

summary: ___ with PMH including untreated HCV with recent admission to ICU for septic shock of unclear etiology presenting with septic shock. #Septic shock: Unclear source. E coli sensitive to cefepime grew at the OSH. WBC as high as 46K, downtrending. CT Abd/Pel showed new splenic lesions concerning for microabcesses versus infarcts. Also showed loculated ascites that was tapped and was transudative. She was initially treated empirically with vanc/cefepime/levofloxacin. Blood cultures, urine cultures, and ascitic fluid cultures were negative. C diff was negative. The levoflox was changed to flagyl after 4 days due to concern of intraabdominal process. Although she felt better and looked better clinically during her time in the ICU, she had persistently increased bands on her differential, up to 20%. She also continued to intermittently require small doses of levophed to maintain a MAP > 60. Lactate did not rise and good UOP was maintained during these hypotensive episodes. She was started on midodrine to keep her off of pressors. The source of her infection was never determined, but there was a high suspicion for an abdominal source. She completed a 14 day course of cefepime and flagyl. She was then started on PO Augmentin BID as supressive therapy for a presumed intraabdominal source. Unfortunately, there is a high likely hood that the patient will develop another severe infection in the near future, therefore, goals of care discussions were initiated as described below. # GI bleed: Patient had maroon stools on the day prior to discharge. She has a history of ischemic bowel. She was given 1U of PRBCs, but no other intervention was taken given her goals of care. #GOALS OF CARE: Family meeting held ___ afternoon with Primary Team, patient, Step-daughter ___ and ___ of Palliative Care. Pt was switched to DNR/DNI. Also if condition were to worsen, she does not want to be transferred back to the ICU.

summary: A/P: ___ with Coroanry Artery Disease s/p ICD placement, End Stage Renal Disease on hemodialysis (last HD the day prior to admission) found to have diverticulitis by CT scan performed in the ED. Received levaquin and flagyl in the ED and was switched to cipro and flagyl upon coming to the floor. Kept NPO initially with resolution of his left lower quadrant pain and diarrhea. Diet gradually advanced to clears, patient tolerated well with some crampy abdominal pain. . #) Diverticulitis - Appeared acute on CT with left lower quadrant tenderness. Received levaquin and flagyl in the ED and was switched to cipro and flagyl upon coming to the floor. Kept NPO initially with resolution of his left lower quadrant pain and diarrhea. Diet gradually advanced to clears, patient tolerated well with some crampy abdominal pain. . #) Difficulty swallowing - Patient reports long history of burping and difficulty swallowing and having to manually remove food lodged in back of throat, concerning for encker's diverticulum. However, has been evaluated before and is followed by PCP who feels could be neurologic in the setting of TIAs. The patient has outpatient speech and swallow evaluation scheduled for ___. Per daughter, is able to take pills despite this difficulty. . #) Hypertension/Arrthymia - Continued home toprol, lisinopril, mexilitine. . #) Chronic Renal Failure - Dialysis schedule ___. Cautious repletion of electrolytes with goal K around 5 given history of arrhythmia and Torsades. . #) Coronary Artery Disease - Continued Aspirin. . #) Hyperlipidemia - Continued statin. . #) Hypothyroidism - Continued levothyroxine. . #) Factor V Leiden - Continued coumadin, however, had to hold temporarily in setting of supratherapeutic levels.

summary: Mrs. ___ presented to ___ ER after sustaining a mechanical fall at home on ___. A ___ was obtained which revealed right parietal-temporal and posterior fossa vasogenic edema for which neurosurgery was consulted. #New brain metastases Brain MRI was obtained which showed cerebellar lesion and right parietal lesion concerning for metastatic disease. She was admitted to the neurosurgery floor pending possible OR plan. Consults were placed to heme-oncology, radiation oncology, and palliative care for recommendations regarding her care. A family meeting was held on ___ which included Neurosurgery, Hematology/Oncology, Radiation Oncology, and Palliative Care. Three main options were discussed with the patient and her family, which included sole palliative directed therapy, radiation monotherapy, or cerebellar tumor resection followed by radiation therapy. While the family discussed these options, CT torso was obtained to explore the extent of metastatic disease. CT torso was completed on ___ and revealed no new areas of metastasis. After continued ongoing discussions with family, palliative care, radiation oncology and neuro oncology, the family ultimately decided not to proceed with further intervention at this time. They opted to take the patient home on Hospice. Her code status was changed to DNR/DNI on ___. Arrangements were made, and patient was discharged home on hospice on ___. #Rib pain upon admission Patient was complaining of right sided chest wall pain s/p fall. CXR was negative for rib fractures. Pain resolved. #Dispo Patient was discharged home on hospice on ___.

At home, she takes Miralax, dulcolax, fiber, and enemas. She was seen in the ED on ___ for these symptoms. She had a CT scan that revealed an unrelated ovarian cyst and she left AMA. Vitals on arrival to ___: T 98.1, P 80, BP 113/64, 100% on RA. In the ED she was manually disimpacted. Review of Systems: No recent illnesses. No fevers, chills, night sweats. Appetite is good and weight is stable. No bladder difficulty. No new medications. She has three children. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vital Signs: Physical examination: - Gen: Well-appearing in NAD. - HEENT: Conj/sclera/lids normal, PERRL, EOM full no nystagmus. - Neck: Supple with no thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy. - Chest: Normal respirations and breathing comfortably on room air. Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. - CV: PMI normal size and not displaced. Regular rhythm. Normal S1, S2. No murmurs or gallops. JVP <5 cm. No ankle edema. - Abdomen: Normal bowel sounds. Soft, nontender, nondistended. - Skin: No lesions, bruises, rashes. - Neuro: Alert, oriented x3. Good fund of knowledge. CN ___ intact. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 48PM GLUCOSE-85 UREA N-7 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-138 POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-102 TOTAL CO2-28 ANION GAP-12 ___ 07: 48PM ALT(SGPT)-48* AST(SGOT)-46* ALK PHOS-73 TOT BILI-0.2 ___ 07: 48PM ALBUMIN-4.6 ___ 07: 48PM WBC-9.6 RBC-4.73 HGB-12.5 HCT-38.3 MCV-81* MCH-26.4* MCHC-32.6 RDW-14.0 ___ 07: 48PM NEUTS-52.6 ___ MONOS-4.5 EOS-1.4 BASOS-0.9 ___ 07: 48PM PLT COUNT-496* ___T PELVIS WITH CONTRAST: The urinary bladder, distal ureters, uterus, rectum and appendix are normal. Posterior to the lower portion of the uterus is a 5.2 x 5 x 4.0 cm hypodensity which appears homogenously hypodense with internal Hounsfield units consistent with simple fluid. The right ovary is visualized and appears unremarkable, and the left ovary is not definitively visualized. There is no free gas or fluid in the pelvis, and there is no pelvic sidewall or inguinal lymphadenopathy. OSSEOUS FINDINGS: There is no suspicious sclerotic or lytic osseous lesion. IMPRESSION: 5.2 x 5.0 x 4.0 cm fluid density lesion in the midline, posterior to the uterus. The right ovary is well visualized and the left is not, suggesting a possible ovarian etiology. Nevertheless, considerations are broad and would recommend further characterization with a pelvic ultrasound. ___ Ultrasound: FINDINGS: Transabdominal and transvaginal examinations were performed, the latter being done to better assess endometrial contents and adnexa. The uterus is normal in size measuring 9.4 x 4.0 x 5.0 cm. The endometrium is also normal, measuring 9 mm in thickness. The left ovary is 5.5 x 4.1 x 5.3 cm and contains a 4.9 x 4.9 x 3.6 cm smooth-walled cyst with a reticular pattern of heterogeneous internal echoes, overall indicative of a hemorrhagic cyst. Color Doppler analysis reveals no internal vascularity. Appropriate venous and arterial waveforms are seen in the rim of surrounding ovarian parenchyma. The right ovary is normal, measuring 3.4 x 1.8 x 2.6 cm. There is no free fluid in the pelvis. IMPRESSION: 4.9 x 4.9 x 3.6 cm hemorrhagic left ovarian cyst. Given the benign sonographic characteristics and size, no specific imaging followup is indicated. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> none, including no OTC medications <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Polyethylene Glycol 3350 17 gram/dose Powder Sig: One (1) packet PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for constipation. 2. Lactulose 10 gram/15 mL Syrup Sig: Thirty (30) ML PO twice a day as needed for constipation: use as needed if not having at least one bowel movement every three days. Disp: *300 ML(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> constipation abdominal bloating abdominal pain hemorrhagic ovarian cyst <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> see below

DRE without stool in rectal vault in the ED. KUB without obstruction, only constipation. Abdominal exam remained benign with mild distension, no tenderness on day of discharge, active to hyperactive bowel sounds. Pt had 3 small bm during the hospitalization. She was discharged home with instructions and prescriptions below.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Amoxicillin <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> dehydration <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Central Tunneled Line Placement ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Patient is a ___ with a complex PMHx including ___ disease short bowel syndrome secondary to mesh erosion from surgery for MCV, CKD (Cr ___ in ___, s/p removal of Hickman and abscess ID in ___, chronic pain on methadone, recently left AMA from ___ when admitted with renal failure (underwent renal biopsy c/b hematoma), and Stenotrophomonas bacteremia, now presenting with concern for persistent dehydration. To briefly summary his ___ course, patient was admitted ___ with R sided flank pain, found to have acute on chronic renal failure (Cr 8.2) and Stenotrophamonas bacteremia. Patient was seen by renal while inpatient and underwent renal biopsy. There was concern that his renal failure may have been worsened by NSAID and/or anabolic steroid use. CT and renal ultrasound showed2mm non-obstructing, right sided stone and absence of hydronephrosis. Biopsy showed collapsing glomerulopathy, IgA nephropathy and focal global and segmental glomerulosclerosis. Biopsy showed combination of lesions that were most likely related to three different and potentially independent disease processes: collapsing glomerulopathy, IgA nephropathy, and severe vascular sclerosis. He was started on sevelamer during hospitalization. In terms of his bacteremia, source was though to be his port, given that he gives himself TPN and LR at home. ___ removed his port on ___ and ID recommended that he remain line-free for at least one 1 week. He was initially started on ceftazidime then switched to levofloxacin based on sensitivities. TTE was negative for vegetations. Per discharge summary, patient was discharged on IV levofloxacin for 14 day course (last day ___. However, patient states that he was discharged without any antibiotics. He was also found to have anemia consistent with Fe deficiency. U/S after renal biopsy showed stable hematoma. He received 2U PRBCs on ___. H/H could not be reliably trended due to patient's refusal to have blood draws. He was also hypertensive to 200s requiring IV labetalol. He was not discharged on anti-HTN. Care was difficult has patient refused blood draws, frequently left floor with abusive outbursts towards staff, delaying treatment such as blood transufions. He left AMA on ___. He was seen by psych, ID, renal, and colorectal surgery while admitted. In the ED, initial vitals: 98.3 ___ 18 100% RA - Labs notable for: WBC 16.8 (10.5 on discharge from ___), Hgb 9.6, Cr 10.0 - Patient given: 1L LR Foley placement was attempted however patient was unable to tolerate. - Vitals prior to transfer: 98.2 100 130/90 20 100% RA On arrival to the floor, pt reports that he feels like he was getting dehydrated. he states that he feels tired and lethargic, exhausted. Just feels like I'm dehydrated. No confusion, n/v, CP, fevers/chills, abdominal pain. No cough. No dysuria. He notes that the output from his ostomy is slightly looser than usual. He does note a different taste in his mouth than usual. He states that he left AMA because he was losing faith in their care and was hearing different things from different teams. He denies being discharged on any antibiotics. He was not discharged with any IV access. He states that he got dehydrated because he didn't have any access. He has not noticed any changes in his urination. Has noticed some decreased UOP, which he attributes to being dehydrated. He was heavy in to Advil (15 per day), last before ___ hospitalization. He was using these in attempt to wean methadone. He states that he uses anabolic steroids, 200mg per week, injected. He does this because of short gut syndrome - to help retain fluids. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> ___ disease: Dx ___, s/p total colectomy w ileostomy ___ c/b enterocutaneous fistula, perianal fistulas #short bowel syndrome #HTN #chronic pain - states due to nerve damage in extremities (from flagyl use and h/o surgeries) #h/o abscess #vit B12 deficiency #GERD #s/p appendectomy #s/p open cholecystectomy c/b small bowel injury #hip replacement #multiple abdominal surgeries <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father- ___ Brother- ___ vs. IBS Aunt and 2 cousins also w ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> -= ADMISSION EXAM -= Vitals: 98.8 131/83 102 19 97 RA General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, neck supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Chest: dressing over prior port site c/d
summary: ___ year old male with PMHx of short gut syndrome on chronic TPN, ___ disease, CKD (unclear etiology), recent hospitalization for renal failure and Stenotrophamonas bacteremia, now presenting with fatigue and concern for dehydration, found to have renal failure and leukocytosis. ============== ACUTE ISSUES ============== # Acute renal failure on CKD: Patient with known CKD of unclear etiology. Review of OMR and ___ hospital show that he has had multiple episodes of ___. He was recently admitted to ___ where he underwent a renal biopsy which revealed multiple pathologies (collapsing glomerulopathy, IgA nephropathy, and severe vascular sclerosis). In terms of collapsing glomerulopathy, can be associated with infections such as HIV, however his HIV ab is negative. Can also be related to anabolic steroids, which he uses. Vascular sclerosis can be secondary to HTN, however path report states that primary causes are more likely. Primary forms of vascular/endotherlial injury include pro-coagulant state, autoimmune d/o, drug-induced, paraproteinemia. This acute episode is likely related to recent dehydration and lack of TPN (as his central line was removed during OSH hospitalization due to bacteremia), as his Cr started to improve with aggressive hydration and resumption of TPN. # HTN: Patient without a diagnosis of HTN, but with BPs ranging from 130s-170s/60s-90s. He was started on amlodipine while in the hospital which was uptitrated to 10 mg prior to discharge. # Recent Stenotrophamonas bacteremia: Patient presented with WBC 16.8 from 10.5 at discharge from ___. No fevers or no localizing symptoms. His central line, through which he was receiving TPN for short gut syndrome) was removed during his ___ hospitalization. He was not discharged on antibiotics (per DC summary, were planning on discharging on levofloxacin 500mg Iq48h but patient left AMA and did not receive antibiotic script). He was restarted on levofloxacin PO

summary: Mr ___ is a ___ year old gentlman with CAD, HTN, HLD presents with diffuse lower abdominal pain found to have pancreatitis. . ACUTE ISSUES: ============= # Pancreatitis: presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, mildly elevated LFTs and a lipase in the 900s, found to have inflammation of organs surrounding pancreas (duodenum, stomach, general free fluid) on CT abd/pelvis. No gallbladder distention, billiary distention or stones on CT or subsequent RUQ U/S. Triglycerides, calcium with normal limits. Not on any meds known to cause pancreatitis. Does have a higher than recommended alcohol intake; 2 good sized glasses of wine daily, ___ on weekend days. Started on IV pain meds and anti-emetics, IV fluids, made NPO. Course complicated by development of E.coli bacteremia and flash pulmonary edema (see issues below). On ___ able to advanced diet, transition to PO pain meds, and by ___ patient's pain was well controlled on progressively decreasing doses of oxycodone, and he was eating full liquids. Most likely culprit of pancreatitis is alcohol; limiting alcohol intake was discussed with patient prior to discharge. Had planned on keeping patient another day, advancing diet and weaning off narcotics further, however on ___ patient's laptop, which had a lot of business data on it was stolen by his roommate who eloped, and patient wanted to go home to take care of some security issues for his company. Patient was sent home with instruction to decrease pain medication while advancing to a low fat diet. . # E. coli Bacteremia: Patient febrile ___ and ___, GNRs grew from blood on ___, started on IV zosyn. GNRs speciated to E. coli sensitive to ciprofloxacin, transitioned to cirpo on ___. Discharged on PO cirpo, to complete 2 week course on ___. E. coli bacteremia most likely occured from transient translocation of gut bacteria in

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Found down <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ y.o. man with past medical history of traumatic subdural hemorrhage from a bar fight in ___ and right handed boxers fracture during a bar fight in ___ who was brought in on transfer after being found down and taken to ___. Per the patient, he remembers being out to a bar and drinking perhaps 12 beers, which he says is more than his usual. He also admitted to having taken some of his wife's alprazolam for recreational purposes. He was found down with significant facial trauma and then vomited and was intubated for airway protection. Given concern for head injury from the extent of facial trauma, he was transferred to ___ for trauma center services. He was extubated without incident and his mental status resolved to baseline quickly. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -Traumatic subdural hematoma secondary to bar fight -History of boxers fracture <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Notable for diabetes mellitus in his mother. <PHYSICAL EXAM> On transfer from ICU: VS: T 98.7, BP 102/72, P 86, RR 20, O2 96% on RA Gen: Middle aged male with obvious facial contusions and abrasions, NAD HEENT: Multiple facial abrasions w/ dried blood, OP benign w/o lesions (broken tooth not visible), sclerae anicteric Neck: No masses or lymphadenopathy, no thyroid nodules appreciated CV: RRR, no M/R/G; there is no jugular venous distension appreciated; ___ and radial pulses 2 bilaterally Pulm: Breathing is unlabored, expansion equal bilaterally, scattered coarse wheezes Abd: Soft, NT, ND, BS, no organomegaly or masses appreciated Extrem: Warm and well perfused, no C/C/E Neuro: A and O*2 (misses date), CNII-XII grossly intact, strength ___ in all extremities Psych: Pleasant, cooperative, denies any SI/HI or depressed mood, frankly denies any attempt at self harm <PERTINENT RESULTS> LABORATORY RESULTS -= On Presentation: WBC-15.1* RBC-5.38 Hgb-16.2 Hct-46.6 MCV-87 RDW-12.5 Plt ___ PTT-26.6 ___ ___ Glucose-99 UreaN-10 Creat-0.6 Na-138 K-5.3* Cl-104 HCO3-22 ALT-47* AST-26 CK(CPK)-122 AlkPhos-47 TotBili-0.4 Lipase-20 Calcium-7.8* Phos-2.3* Serum Tox: ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-POS On Discharge: BLOOD WBC-12.2* RBC-4.42* Hgb-13.5* Hct-38.2* MCV-87 RDW-12.5 Plt ___ ___ 03: 59PM BLOOD Calcium-9.0 Phos-1.7* Mg-2.2 OTHER STUDIES -== CT Facial: IMPRESSION: 1. Lucency at C2 as indicated above. This finding is not well seen in other planes and my represent a vascular channel ( most likely) and less likely a fracture . Recommend comparison with physical exam and if concern exists for injury at that site, recommend further evaluation with MRI. 2. Extensive paranasal sinus opacification and fluid in the oral and nasopharynx as detailed above. CT Chest, Abdomen, and Pelvis w/ Contrast: IMPRESSION: 1. Bilateral pulmonary consolidations, possibly aspirational in etiology. 2. Endotracheal tube with overinflation of the cuff. 3. Nasogastric tube with side port positioned too high, this tube should be advanced. CT Head w/o Contrast: IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial process. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> None <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> None <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary diagnoses: Alcohol Abuse Aspiration Pneumonitis Mechanical Fall <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Stable, not hypoxic on room air at rest or with ambulation <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted because you were found unconscious and bleeding with injuries to your face. There was concern you had a serious head injury so you were transferred to ___ for evaluation by the trauma services. They imaged your head, chest, abdomen, and spine and found no injuries except bumps and bruises to your face and a broken tooth. You had a tube placed down your throat because of concerns about your poor mental status and vomiting leading to vomit going into your lungs, which can cause a life threatening pneumonia. Unfortunately, you did have some inflammation in your lungs suggesting a degree of aspiration, but as you were not having shortness of breath or needing oxygen this is fairly mild and should resolve on its own. As you had the tube removed without incident and did not seem to have any other major issues your are being discharged to complete your recovery. You have not been started on any medications during this hospitalization. WE STRONGLY RECOMMEND THAT YOU STOP USING ALCOHOL. You have multiple life threatening hospital admissions related to drinking. We strongly encourage you to discuss strategies to reduce your drinking with your PCP ___ in outpatient rehab. Please return to your
summary: ___ year old male with history of alcohol abuse presents after being found down with facial trauma for trauma evaluation. 1) Found down/Facial trauma: The exact events leading to the patient being found down and having facial trauma are unknown as he does not remember them and there are no reliable witnesses to what happened. Given his extensive facial trauma when he was found and his altered mental status there was considerable concern for more extensive ___ intracranial injuries. Extensive imaging here revealed only a broken tooth and no other significant traumatic injuries. Most likely the patient simply suffered a mechanical fall while intoxicated and facial contusions. 2) Altered Mental Status: The patient was not responding purposefully when he was found and was vomiting extensively, therefore, he was intubated for airway protection and transferred to ___ sedated. Imaging revealed no intracranial bleed or skull fracture. After extubation his mental status returned to baseline suggesting that his intoxication was the primary etiology of his altered mental status. 3) Aspiration Pneumonitis: On imaging of the chest the patient was noted to have bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Given his vomiting and intubation this was thought to be most likely due to aspiration pneumonitis. He never developed fevers, O2 requirement, or severe cough so he was not treated for aspiration pneumonia. His pneumonitis should resolve without antibiotic therapy. 4)Alcohol Abuse: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and significant injuries secondary to alcohol use. This presentation occurred with injuries in the context of abusing alcohol and benzodiazepines. When asked, the patient denied any suicidal intent and specified that he only took the benzodiazepines with recreational intent. The patient met with social work twice who discussed alcohol treatment programs. It is unclear if the patient will pursue this. 5) Leukocytosis: The patient had a leukocytosis at presentation presumably due to trauma and pneumonitis. This was improving at time of discharge and there were no signs of another locus of infection. The patient initially received IV H2 blocker for GI prophylaxis

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Codeine / Penicillins / Ketorolac / Tessalon Perles / fentanyl patch / Amitriptyline / Levaquin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Low Back Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with chronic back pain (arthritis and disc herniations) c/b methadone dependence, AAA and right iliac aneurysms who presents with chronic complaints of low back pain, lower extremity weakness and inability to ambulate independently. He reports that his pain is worse than baseline and he has had many falls since he was discharged last (earlier this week). He has refused discharge to rehab facilities twice in the prior 2 weeks but never gave a reason. Now, he would like to go to a rehab facility and says that the reason is because he met with vascular surgeon, Dr. ___ told him how difficult his EVAR will be so now he wants to get stronger in preparation for the surgery. In terms of his lower extremity weakness and chronic pain, he says that there is no change in the ability to walk. He can still only take about 10 steps before he feels that his legs are going to absolutely collapse under him--this is stable from prior admission (many falls ago) and was observed by myself and physical therapy. He expresses remorse that he did not go to rehab in those admissions and that he refused to work with physical therapy. He admits that he would like more methadone but knows that I will not give him this. He does mention in passing that after the surgery he expects more pain medications since he will have a new indication. He reports that a vascular surgeon one previous admission told him he would get more pain medications after a surgery. His respiratory status is improved per patient. He does not have any cough, complaints of DOE or orthopnea, and not using oxygen. He is still smoking. His urinary incontinence is also at baseline, with intermittent incontinence and then back to normal. It is not concerning him at this time. He has not had the dobutamine stress test for pre-op work-up and claims that he did not know about it but is reminded that 4 clinicians have told him it is necessary before EVAR and that it was scheduled but he refused it on prior admission. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -- COPD, used to use home O2, but denies current use -- Cellulitis -- Venous insufficiency -- AAA 5cm ___ -- Hepatitis C -- etoh abuse -- ivdu with cocaine and heroine -- depression -- History of cardiac catheterization showing mild diastolic dysfunction, left main 20% stenosis, hypokinetic anterior wall, left ventricular ejection fraction 50%, otherwise normal. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> father has had anxiety, panic and depression, was hospitalized at ___ and had ECT. Mother died of breast cancer, father died of tongue cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: T 98.3 HR 70 RR 18 BP 128/74 pOx 94 RA GENERAL: Well-appearing in NAD, comfortable, appropriate. HEENT: NC/AT, PERRLA, EOMI, sclerae anicteric, MMM HEART: RRR, no MRG, nl S1-S2. LUNGS: very very poor air entry bilaterally, patient takes shallow breaths, but clear to auscultation bilaterally except for scattered upper lobe wheezes ABDOMEN: Soft/NT/ND, no masses or HSM, no rebound/guarding. EXTREMITIES: WWP, no c/c, venous stasis changes, 1 peripheral pulses. SKIN: No rashes or lesions. NEURO: Awake, AOx3, Sensation grossly intact. Motor exam normal in UE, gives best effort in ___ motor exam ever and able to produce ___ strength hip flexors, knee flexion and extension and ___ strength plantarflexion. Will withdraw legs to pain. Patient refused to walk. Rectal: Patient deferred . IMAGING: ___ LUMBOSACRAL SPINE PLAIN FILM: There is transitional vertebral body anatomy with partial sacralization of the lowest lumbar-type vertebral body. There is mild dextroscoliosis of the lumbar ___ at L3. Severe degenerative changes are noted over all levels with disc space narrowing, osteophyte formation and facet arthropathy. Would recommend MRI for further evaluation if pain persists. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> 1. ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed. 2. fluticasone-salmeterol 250-50
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of chronic lower back pain and methadone dependence, chronic lower extremity weakness with inability to ambulate, chronic urinary incontinence, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), known AAA (largest 5.8 cm) and hepatitis C that presented for rehab placement. . # Chronic back pain: Patient has a history of lower back pain with narcotic dependence and reports that his current pain is worse than baseline but this is because his outpatient methadone regimen was weaned to 2.5 mg BID. He reports that the real reason he came to the emergency room last night was because his dose was decreased and the person who hand-delivers his methadone to his home did not come x1 last night. He has multiple falls per week and these probably continually exacerbate his chronic pain but he has refused ___ and rehab in prior admissions over the past 2 weeks. His neurologic exam is difficult to interpret for signs of new cord damage/compression because he has chronic lower extremity weakness/inability to ambulate and chronic urinary incontinence with high bladder volumes. Within these limitations it seems unlikely that he has had progression of his disk herniations because his motor exam is the best that it has been over the past 2 weeks and his incontinence is at baseline. Although he reports that he can't move his lower extremities at all, he does actually walk when he gets agitated but uses a wheelchair at baseline. . Please see the prior discharge summary for other chronic issues. No changes were made. . # FAMILY CONTACT: Son (___) . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Please provide physical therapy - Please check a lipid panel and start a statin if his lipids are elevated. Also, please consider a beta blocker - Please consider pain medicine clinic outpatient follow-up - Please advise smoking cessation and reassess for need for home O2 - Re: Aortic and right iliac aneurysms. Found on prior admission and vascular surgery consult recommended that he have outpatient follow

You have recovered well and the team believes you are ready to be discharged home. Please call Dr. ___ office with any questions or concerns. Please follow the instructions below. General instructions: * Take your medications as prescribed. * Do not drive while taking narcotics. * Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to prevent constipation. * Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol. * Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs. * No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment. * No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks. * You may eat a regular diet. * You may walk up and down stairs. Call your doctor for: * fever > 100.4F * severe abdominal pain * difficulty urinating * vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr * abnormal vaginal discharge * redness or drainage from incision * nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food or your medication Constipation: * Drink ___ liters of water every day. * Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods include: Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, Legumes, Nuts/seeds. * Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily. * Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed. * Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. * Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools or diarrhea. To reach medical records to get the records from this hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
summary: On ___ Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after undergoing BILATERAL SACROSPINOUS LIGAMENTS VAULT SUSPENSION WITH SYNTHETIC GRAFT, ANTERIOR COLPORRHAPHY AND POSTERIOR COLPORRHAPHY WITH BIOLOGIC GRAFT, CYSTOSCOPY. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately post-op, her pain was controlled with Iv toradol and morphine. On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate and her Foley was removed with a voiding trial, the results of which are as follows: 1. Instilled 300 mL, voided 300 mL with 94 mL residual. By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled. Discharge Medications: 1. summary: Ms ___ is a ___ G2P1 at 28 weeks, transfer from ___ midwifery service with preterm contractions. The patient's cervix was closed upon admission but in the setting of preterm contractions, she was continued on Magnesium tocolysis upon betamethasone completion on ___. She met with the NICU. Her two most active issues related to her Grave's disease and her possible gestational diabetes. The Endocrine and ___ consult service were involved in her care. . In terms of her hyperthyroidism, the patient's thyroid testing revealed inadequate suppression. For this reason, her PTU was increased from 200 to 300mg BID. Ultrasound of the fetus did not show any evidence of fetal goiter. To investigate the possibility of superimposed thyroiditis, the patient's TSI were ordered which will be followed-up as an outpatient. She has been advised to check her thyroid function tests later this week at ___ and was given the fax number of Dr ___ office to send the results. The importance of adherence to medication was explained to the patient as well as the pregnancy concerns relating to active Grave's disease. . Prior to her administration of betamethasone, the patient's GLT was tested and found to be elevated at 136. She had fasting and 1 hour postprandial levels of blood glucose measured during her admission which normalised within 3 days of the start of betamethasone. She was seen by the nutrition service and will follow-up at ___ in one week for GTT testing. . In terms of fetal well being, she underwent BPP that was ___ with normal fluid while in house. The fetus was in breech presentation. At ___ on ___, the EFW was 2lb3oz (61%). .

If you develop fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, abdominal distension then please contact Dr. ___ ___ or go to emergency room. Continue to monitor your ostomy output. If you find that your output has become too much or too little, please call the office for advice.Keep yourself well hydrated, if you notice your ileostomy output increasing, take in more electrolyte drink such as gatorade. Please monitor yourself for signs and symptoms of dehydration including: dizziness (especially upon standing),weakness, dry mouth, headache, or fatigue. If you notice these symptoms please call the office or return to the emergency room for evaluation if these symptoms are severe. You may eat a modified regular diet with your ileostomy. If you have any questions or concerns please contact Dr. ___.
summary: This is a ___ year old male who is status post ileostomy revision. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no complications. His PACU course was unremarkable, and he was transferred to the general surgery inpatient unit in good condition. By POD1, had return of bowel function with gas and stool in ostomy. The diet was advanced from clears to regular which he tolerated without any nausea, abdominal pain, or vomiting. The patient had adequate pain control with oral medication, and he was ambulating and voiding without difficulty. He was discharged home on postoperative day 1 in good condition.

summary: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service for evaluation and treatment. On ___ the patient underwent a robotic-assisted laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy for main duct IPMN, which went well without complication. Post-operatively she was transfered to the floor in stable condition, with NGT/IVF/foley. She had some pain control issues and anxiety POD ___. She was progressing well until ___, when she was found to be tachycardic to 130s, with WBC 40, and Hct drop from 39 to 31. She was transfused 5 units PRBCs, 4 units FFP, 1 unit platelets, DDAVP and transferred to the TSICU. She went to ___ and had a small jejunal branch of the SMA embolized. She was left intubated and subsequently extubated on ___. At that time her CXR looked fluid overloaded and she was given 20 IV lasix on ___ and again on ___. Her pain was well-controlled. HSQ was restarted on ___. Clonidine was also started on ___ due to agitation and hypertension. JP #2 was putting out approximately 200 per day. On ___, JP #1 was found to have an amylase of 4388 with minimal output and JP 2 an amylase of 399. Her WBC increased from 24 to 33. She was started on octreotide tid and her NGT was d/ced. Hcts remained stable and she was transferred to the floor. On ___, her hypernatremia resolved, she was started on sips to clears, which she tolerated well. Her foley was discontinued, and she ambulated and continued to pass gas. On ___ she was advanced to fulls, which she tolerated well. Because of her abdominal distension, the patient was kept in house until ___. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. Staples were removed, and steri-strips placed. The patient was discharged home with services to manage her wound and her

summary: ___ with HTN, HLD, SLE, RA, tobacco abuse who presents with intermittent chest pain for the past 2 months. Symptoms appeared largely consistent with GERD but initial labs showed troponin leak elevated to 0.09. Given her risk factors and lab findings along with her unclear clinical picture, patient underwent cardiac catheterization which revealed multifocal occlusions. The LAD was stented with a BMS and the patient was started on dual antiplatlet therapy. She was observed overnight and reported no further symptoms. She was discharged to follow-up with her outpatient providers. # Chest pain: History was somewhat atypical for angina. Symptoms could also be due to GERD with long-time use of ibuprofen and response to antacid therapy. However, bedside ultrasound in ED showed possible inferolateral hypokinesis, troponins elevated then downtrended (0.09-->0.07). Pt has several cardiac risk factors including current smoker, HTN, HLD, DM and chronic inflammation from autoimmune disorders putting her at intermediate risk given her age and gender. Cath showed multivessel disease including a totally occluded RCA and a focal LAD stenosis. A BMS was placed in the LAD as the patient had concerns about anticoagulation in the setting of lupus. She was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel. She was discharged to follow-up with her PCP and outpatient cardiologist. During admission we continued ASA 325mg daily, increased her atorvastatin to 80mg daily, started her on chlorthalidone 25 mg for her HTN. We maintained her on a GI cocktail as well as a PPI inhibitor and an H2 blocker during admission, then discharged on omeprazole 40 mg PO daily. In the setting of NSTEMI, she was monitored on tele and maintained on heparin drip until PCI, then plavix loaded and started on the dual antiplatelet therapy. # HTN: Known labile BPs both at home and in clinic, but only on atenolol. She stated recently prior to admission BPs 130s. She was monitored on telemetry and her blood pressure monitored. She was started

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to Dr. ___ service after transurethral bipolar vaporization of prostate, bladder stone removal and urethral dilation. No concerning intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. He patient received ___ antibiotic prophylaxis. Mr. ___ postoperative course was uncomplicated. He received intravenous antibiotics and continuous bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1 the CBI was discontinued and his Foley was removed after voiding trial and post void residuals were checked. His urine was clear yellow and without clots. He remained a-febrile throughout his hospital stay. At discharge, the patient's pain well controlled with oral pain medications, tolerating regular diet, ambulating without assistance, and voiding without difficulty. He was given oral pain medications on discharge and explicit instructions to follow up in clinic with Dr. ___ as directed.

summary: The patient presented to the emergency department and was evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found to have a right femoral neck fracture and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for right hip hemiarthroplasty, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. Urology was consulted due to retained urine and inability to pass Foley catheter post-operatively. Patient has history of urethral strictures. Urology passed Foley and recommended 3 day course of Macrobid to end ___ to prevent infection following repeated instrumentation. On the floor, the patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate. The patient's urine was initially bloody and improved to clear yellow urine in the Foley by the time of discharge. Void trial ___ was successful. At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is weightbearing as tolerated in the right lower extremity, and will be discharged on Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ man with medical history notable for HTN, HLD, depression, CAD s/p CABG, CHF, asthma, GERD, CKD who presented from his nursing home with x1 day of chest pain. ACTIVE Issues: #Chest pain: Patient presented with some atypical chest pain symptoms. EKG on admission showed TWI in V2-V5 (previous EKGs from ___ had had TWI in anterior leads). Troponins neg x2. Symptoms were not consistent with typical angina. We continued his home aspirin, metoprolol, and simvastatin. Patient should follow up with outpatient cardiologist. #CHF: CXR with mild congestion. S/p 40 IV Lasix in ED on admission. Patient's ECHO (___) showed: Normal global and regional biventricular systolic function. Mild diastolic LV dysfunction (EF>55%). We restarted his home furosemide on discharge. #UTI: Endorsed dysuria in the ED. No fevers or leukocytosis but urine culture grew E coli sensitive to cipro. We started ciprofloxacin 250 mg q12h; day ___ 7 days total ending on ___. #COPD: Chronic per patient. CXR with mild edema. No evidence of pneumonia. Patient's SOB is at baseline. We continued his duonebs and gave him supplemental oxygen, which was weaned off prior to discharge. #Renal injury: Cr 1.6 on admission and 1.5 on discharge. Unclear baseline but has PMH of CKD. Meds were renally dosed in the hospital and he should f/u with his PCP ___ discharge. CHRONIC: #HTN: Chronic issue. We cont metop, amlodipine #BPH: Patient wears diapers and cannot control urine. We continued terazosin #Insomnia: We continued home mirtazapine and held his trazodone #GERD: We decreased his home ranitidine to qday Transitional Issues: []discharged on ciprofloxacin to complete 7 day course for UTI []patient should follow up with cardiology; please monitor volume status. #CODE: Full (presumed) #CONTACT: ___ (daughter) ___

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> simvastatin / Ciprofloxacin / Glumetza / lisinopril / Methotrexate <ATTENDING> ___ ___ Complaint: Cycle 3 IVAC <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Bone Marrow Biopsy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M w/ Burkitt's lymphoma and progressive disease who recently completed C2 IVAC, IT MTX on ___ who presents now for C3 IVAC. . The patient was recently admitted ___ for subdural hematomas related to thrombocytopenia. Evaucauted by neurosurgery. Course also complicated by norovirus. . Since discharge the patient has been doing well at home. Does describe daily low grade HAs especially at night which he believes is residual pain from his Burr holes that were placed due to his subdural hematomas. No vision changes or otehr associated neurologic Sx. . Also reports new cold sweats over the past 2 nights. No fever or other localzing Sx. . ROS: () as per HPI. Otherwise denies fever, chills. Denies sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath, or wheezing. Denies chest pain, chest pressure, palpitations, or weakness. Denies constipation, abdominal pain, or changes in bowel habits. Denies dysuria, frequency, or urgency. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rashes or skin changes. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: ___: numbness and pain right jaw and chin, night sweats, right neck mass and weight loss. - ___ PET CT with FDG avid R neck mass and numerous liver lesions. Biopsy of the neck mass c/w aggressive B cell lymphoma. ECHO with EF 55%. - ___ BMBx revealed hypercellular marrow with >95% replacement with high grade B cell lymphoma. M: E ratio cannot be assessed. Flow cytometry showed monotypic large B cells, kappa light chain restricted, CD10, CD19, CD20 bright, CD22, CD 38 bright, FMC7, CD5-, CD11c-, CD25-, CD103-. Cytogenetics with t(8: 14) cMYC-IgH. Consistent with involvement by Burkitt's lymphoma. - ___ C1D1 R-CHOP in outside hospital(rituximab 750 mg, cyclophosphamide 1500 mg, doxorubicin 100 mg, vincristine 2 mg, dexamethasone 8 mg) with Neulasta on D2. - ___ IT cytarabine - ___ high dose methotrexate (3500 mg/m2), complicated by acute kidney injury - ___ Rituximab 100 mg - ___ C1 EPOCH (Etoposide 45 mg/m2 D1-4, Doxorubicin 10 mg/m2 D1-4, Vincristine 0.4 mg/m2 D1-4, Cyclophosphamide 750 mg/m2 D5) - ___ Rituximab 375 ___ C2 EPOCH (Etoposide 60 mg/m2 D1-4, Doxorubicin 12 mg/m2 D1-4, Vincristine 0.4 mg/m2 D1-4, Cyclophosphamide 900 mg/m2 D5) - ___ IT cytarabine - ___ C3 EPOCH (Etoposide 70 mg/m2 D1-4, Doxorubicin 12 mg/m2 D1-4, Vincristine 0.4 mg/m2 D1-4, Cyclophosphamide 1050 mg/m2 D1) - ___ IT methotrexate - ___ C4 DA-EPOCH (Etoposide 60 mg/m2 D1-4, Doxorubicin 10 mg/m2 D1-4, Vincristine 0.3 mg/m2 D1-4, Cyclophosphamide 900 mg/m2 D5) - ___ Rituximab - ___ PET-CT disease progression - ___ Rituximab 375 ___ C1 IVAC, IT MTX on ___ - ___ Rituxan - ___ C2 IVAC, IT MTX on ___ . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: DM HTN sarcoid ischemic colitis hyperlipidemia <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Sister with bone cancer, sister with bilateral breast cancer, brother with unspecified cancer, heart disease in father. Son diagnosed with lymphoma. <PHYSICAL EXAM> On Admission: Vitals - 96.9 124/62 83 20 99%RA General - Alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT - Pupils equal at 5mm, EOMI, Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear without lesions, incisions on scalp stapled without evidence of erythema or pus Neck - supple, JVP not elevated Lungs - Clear to auscultation bilaterally, nonerythematous port in right upper chest, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi CV - regular rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly Ext - warm, well perfused, 2 pulses in DP, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema Neuro - AOx3, CN II-XII intact, strength ___ throughout, sensation intact On Discharge: Vitals: 96.5 128
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M w/ ___'s lymphoma and progressive disease who recently completed C2 IVAC, IT MTX on ___ who presented now for cycle 3 IVAC. Found to have lymphoma infiltration of his marrow on BMBx. . #. Burkitt's Lymphoma - The patient had a PET-CT on ___ that showed persistent but reduced disease burden and a marrow that was either hyperactive or infiltrated by lymphoma. Admitted for reduced intensity chemo. On admission the patient's LDH was elevated to 1240 (LDH 260 1 week prior). Also c/o night-sweats and had elevated uric acid level. Bone marrox Bx prior to chemotherapy returned with Burkitt's infiltration of the marrow ___ cytogenetics listed prior). Proceeded with reduced intensity IVAC and tolerated the chemotehrapy well. LDH improved. Continued on acyclovir, vori, and bactrim PPx. Discharged with plans for close follow-up. . # SDH - The patient's prior chemotherapy cycle was c/b severe thrombocytopenia and spontaneous subdural hemorrhage requiring neurosurgical intervention. Platelet goal during this admission was >50. . # Adrenal Insufficiency - Suspected on last admission but incompletely characterized. Started on a prednisone taper and now down to target of 10mg prednisone daily which was continued in-house. . # DMII - Stable. Metformin was held in the hospital and the patient was placed on a sliding scale. . # Hypertension - Continued metoprolol 12.5 BID, amlodipine 5mg Qday, quinapril 20mg qday.
