summary: ___ year old F with COPD, dCHF, atrial fibrillation here with COPD exacerbation. # COPD exacerbation: She presented with evidence of COPD exacerbation from an unknown trigger. She was treated with steroids and nebs with improvement. She completed a 5 day steroid burst while in house. She did not receive antibiotics as no clear evidence of infection and she has a history of c. difficile colitis. With this her breathing improved. She continued to have some hypoxemia (baseline is 2L NC at night and intermittently through the day); however, she was satting well at rest on RA at the time of discharge. CXR showed a small effusion and atelectasis. She was encouraged to use incentive spirometer and was diuresed with her home lasix. # Chronic diastolic CHF: Upon presentation she was euvolemic to slightly hypovolemic. Given this, lasix was held. She later developed small effusion and her home lasix was resumed. # RLQ abdominal pain: Per pt, this was a new complaint for her. She was TTP in the RLQ with voluntary guarding; however, tenderness was very superficial. CT A/P was unremarkable for acute process. Area of tenderness correlated with a small abdominal wall hematoma with overlying ecchymosis. Unclear if this was related to a prior injection site. Abdominal exam remained benign. # Hyponatremia: Likely secondary to over diuresis prior to admission. She was given 1L NS with resolution of hyponatremia. She was resumed on her home lasix course prior to discharge. # Pressure ulcer: On her back. Stage 1 and 2. She had a nutrition, wound and ___ consult. Will focus on improving mobility, nutrition. # Chronic pain: She was continued on her home pain regimen. This was discussed with the family and patient. She is at some risk of complications given her age. # Chronic c-diff: She was continued on oral vancomycin suppression as per her outpatient gastroenterologist. Has PEG tube, continued on tube feeds.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Vasotec <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Left Hip Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old female a history of HTN, hypothyroidism and OA with planned hip replacement surgery in two weeks at ___. The patient has been experiencing severe pain last 3 weeks requiring escalating narcotic dosages. Additionally, she inadvertently doubled her short acting narcotis dose over weekend and took additional long acting meds as pharmacy was out of lower dose, ie oxycontin 20mg tid and oxycodone 10mg 2 tabs q 4 hours. She notes some mild confusion since escalating medications over the last 3 weeks but became very confused this morning and had BP in the low ___ systolic. She has not taken any of her meds (by report) since yesterday. She continued to have intermittent confusion at home, but alert and oriented on presentation to the ED. Per report from her son, the patient is not doing well living at home as she is not taking much PO intake. . In the ED, VS: 98.8, 54, 100/41, 16, 95% RA. The patient had lab work with showed a creatinine up to 2.0 from 0.8, sodium at 127. She received 200ccs/hr of NS for fluid resuscitation. She had a renal u/s which was unremarkable. She had a CXR which was unremarkable. Urinalysis was sent, and revealed an UTI. Case management saw the patient in the ED and attempted to transfer directly to rehab, but unable. The patient received 4 mg morphine in the ED which alleviated her pain. On transfer vital sings were 80, 119/43, 17, 95% on RA. . Currently, she confirms story as above. States pain has been escalating for several weeks and is unlike her pain prior to her last hip replacement. Pain is more 'burning' and involves the muscle in her thighs. Has been unable to walk and debilitated ___ pain, which is quite different. Also notes constipation. Denies dysuria but confirms poor po intake. Also with increased ___ swelling x ___ days. Petechiae on legs noted several weeks ago at a different physician ___. . ROS: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Hypothyroidism Hypertension Hypercholesterolemia s/p CVA x 1, with multiple TIAs Carotid stenosis Chronic diastolic heart failure, EF > 65% s/p right hip replacement in ___ Meniere's disease s/p labyrinthotomy in the ___ h/o GIB requiring ICU stay, 3u PRBC several years ago ADD Anxiety Depression h/o Alcohol abuse <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Patient is adopted, family history unknown. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals - T: 98.8 BP: 126/60 HR: 72 RR: 20 02 sat: 98/RA 195 lbs GENERAL: Pleasant, well appearing female in NAD HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. No conjunctival pallor. No scleral icterus. PERRLA/EOMI. MMM. OP clear. Neck Supple. Fine jaw and tongue tremor (pt confirms present for 20 years but worsening)CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Normal S1, S2. ___ murmur at LLSB, no rubs or ___. JVP = 9cm LUNGS: CTAB, good air movement biaterally. ABDOMEN: NABS. Soft, NT, ND. No HSM. No suprapubic or CVA tenderness. Guaiac negative. EXTREMITIES: No edema, mild calf pain R>L with palpation but symmetric and without erythema. Some difficulty moving in bed but no external rotation of either ___, length appears grossly equal. Pain most notable on L sacroiliac joint. SKIN: No ecchymoses. Trace petechia along ___ bilaterally NEURO: AOx3. Appropriate but intermittently forgets the history she is relating, easily redirectable. CN ___ grossly intact. Preserved sensation throughout. Gait assessment deferred PSYCH: Listens and responds to questions appropriately, pleasant <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: . ___ 03: 25PM RET AUT-1.1 ___ 03: 25PM PLT COUNT-202 ___ 03: 25PM NEUTS-69.6 ___ MONOS-7.4 EOS-1.5 BASOS-0.4 ___ 03: 25PM WBC-5.8 RBC-3.20 HGB-10.9 HCT-31.5 MCV-99 MCH-34.0 MCHC-34.5 RDW-12.8 ___ 03: 25PM calTIBC-243 VIT B12-764 FOLATE-GREATER TH FERRITIN-142 TRF-187 IRON-59 ___ 03: 25PM GLUCOSE-137 UREA N-45 CREAT-2.0 SODIUM-127 POTASSIUM-3.7 CHLORIDE-91 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-15 ___ 06: 45PM URINE RBC-0 ___ BACTERIA-MOD YEAST-NONE ___ TRANS ___ BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-5.0 LEUK-SM COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear
summary: ___ yo F with h/o OA, HTN, hyperlipidemia, s/p R hip replacement admitted for confusion in the setting of escalating narcotic doses for left hip pain, ARF and UTI. . # HIP PAIN: Likely ___ to ongoing, worsening OA but concerning for new process given rapid escalation of pain and now described as 'burning'. No evidence of rash consistent with zoster. Denies symptoms similar to sciatica or other nerve involvement. Hip films were performed to rule out occult fracture. X-ray confirmed left hip osteoarthritis. Patient was started on a regimen of long acting and short acting oxycodone. Regimen was titrated as needed. Patient received adequate daytime pain control with oxycontin 20mg in the morning. Overnight, however, patient would require additional doses of short acting oxycodone with her oxycontin 20mg evening dose. Patient was titrated up to oxycontin 20mg qam and 30 mg qpm on day of discharge. Recommend continuing to offer short-acting oxycodone prn breakthrough pain. Patient is scheduled to undergo left hip replacement in less than two weeks. Recommend continuing physical therapy to prevent deconditioning. . # Confusion: Likely secondary to medications. Patient admits she had difficulty monitoring her intake of narcotics at home and would frequently get the long acting and short acting narcotics interchanged. Confusion resolved on arrival to the medicine floor. She had no further episodes of confusion during her hospitalization. . # ARF: Prerenal in the setting of poor po intake and continued diuretic use, confirmed with urine lytes. Urinalysis positive for infection but no CVA pain to indicate kidney involvement. Renal ultrasound was performed in the Emergency Department which showed no evidence of hydronephrosis. Patient was treated with IV fluids and a three day course of ciprofloxacin. Creatinine returned to baseline and she remained asymptomatic. . # UTI: As above, follow-up culture, Cipro. . # Anemia: Hct on presentation 31.5 appears to be down from baseline Hct ___ in ___. No apparent blood loss. Guaiac negative

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> RUQ pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Laparoscopic cholecystectomy and umbilical hernia repair. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Patient is a ___ y/o F with a history of DM2, HTN, HLD presenting with right upper quadrant abdominal pain. summary: ___ presented to pre-op holding at ___ on ___ for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and large umbilical hernia repair after admission symptoms, physical exam, and diagnostic workup, including ABD US, showed that she had acute cholecystitis. She tolerated the procedure well without complications (Please see operative note for further details). After a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was transferred to the floor for further post-operative management. Her pain was well controlled on IV analgesics which were transitioned to PO once she tolerated PO intake. CV: Vital signs were routinely monitored during the patient's length of stay. She remained hemodynamically stable. Pulm: The patient was encouraged to ambulate, sit and get out of bed, use the incentive spirometer, and had oxygen saturation levels monitored as indicated. GI: The patient was initially kept NPO after the procedure. The patient was later advanced to and tolerated a regular diet at time of discharge. GU: Patient had a Foley catheter that was removed at time of discharge. Urine output was monitored as indicated. At time of discharge, the patient was voiding without difficulty. ID: The patient's vital signs were monitored for signs of infection and fever. The patient was started continued on antibiotics for 24 hrs. Heme: The patient had blood levels checked post operatively during the hospital course to monitor for signs of bleeding. The patient had vital signs, including heart rate and blood pressure, monitored throughout the hospital stay. On ___, the patient was started of her medications and discharged home. At discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, voiding, and ambulating independently. She will follow-up in the clinic in ___ weeks. This information was communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge.

summary: PATIENT SUMMARY =============== Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with PMH of HFpEF, Sarcoidosis, Steroid dependent asthma from EGPA (followed by ___, now off steroids with Nucala injections), HTN, and recent diagnosis of atrial flutter ___ who presented with recurrent tachycardia and atrial flutter. She converted between atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation during her stay. A TEE showed left atrial appendage thrombus so she was discharged on apixaban and beta blocker. ACUTE ISSUES ============ # Atrial flutter # Atrial fibrillation Patient was not symptomatic but ___ found HR elevated to 140s. Found to have recurrent atrial flutter. No evidence of ischemia by EKG or troponin. She was continued on metoprolol. The patient's rhythm converted back and forth between atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation without active intervention. The patient declined pulmonary vein isolation and cavotricuspid isthmus ablation. She preferred chemical cardioversion to electrical cardioversion, given pain after electrical cardioversion in ___. She then underwent TEE which showed a 1 cm LAE thrombus, thus, she was rate controlled with metoprolol rather than starting dofetilide. She was also continued on home apixaban (which she had not been taking), with motivational interviewing to take the medication and new arthritis medications to decrease risk of GI bleeding (see below). # Arthritis: Patient was non-compliant with apixiban, as she was worried about bleeding risk with NSAIDs that she takes relatively frequently for arthritis, primarily in her knees. Alternative pain management plan was formulated in conjunction with PCP ___. Will prescribe low dose oxycodone and asked patient to take Tylenol PRN. Discharged with script for 40 pills of 5 mg oxycodone. # Chest pain: Intermittent chest pain radiating down arm, not associated with tachycardia, no EKG changes, no biomarker leak. Low suspicion for ischemia. Not exertional and not typical of ACS. Ischemic evaluation deferred. CHRONIC ISSUES ============== # EGPA, Asthma Did not require treatment, receiving Nucala

summary: Ms ___ presented to the ED at ___ on ___ for abdominal pain and fever. A CT scan of the abdomen was done which revealed the presence of a fluid collection within the superficial soft tissues of the anterior abdominal wall. The patient was subsequently admitted to the surgery service under Dr. ___, who had been following her as an outpatient. On ___ the patient underwent ___ drainage of the abscess with aspiration of 100cc purulent fluid; an ___ pigtail drain was placed. She tolerated the procedure well without complications. Culture of this fluid grew MSSA. Initially, the patient was placed on IV vancomycin for empiric coverage of the wound infection/abscess and IV ciprofloxacin for a positive UA (urine culture ultimately grew no organisms) On the night of ___ the patient's systolic blood pressure dropped to the 50-60s, she was made NPO, a central line was placed, and she was given a 500cc bolus of fluid and subsequently transferred to the ICU. Her hematocrit had dropped to 22.4 and she was transfused 2 units of PRBCs. Troponins were ordered to rule out a myocardial infarction, they came back within normal limits. Her antibiotics were also broaded to vancomycin and osyn.The patient transiently required pressors for her hypotension as well. On the morning of ___, patient's hematocrit was checked and found to have risen to 30.5. Her diet was advanced as tolerated. She remained stable and was transferred back to the floor. Hematocrit was trended and remained stable. The remainder of her hospital stay was uneventful. Once sensitivities were resulted for the wound culture, she was transitioned to oral Bactrim on ___ ___ anticipation of discharge home. On ___, the patient was discharged home with services for management of the ___ drain. At discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, stooling, voiding, and ambulating independently. She remained afebrile throughout the hospital course. She was prescribed a 2-week course of Bactrim. Her gabapentin dose was also decreased as well (4

summary: *) Elevated Blood Pressure/Headache Ms. ___ was admitted for blood pressure monitoring and 24-hour urine collection, which returned at 291mg of protein. Although at the higher end of normal, in the setting of chronic hypertension with no baseline 24-hour urine protein with which to compare, this was felt to be negative. HELLP labs remained normal, with a normal uric acid, and her blood pressure was well-controlled on Aldomet for the duration of her hospitalization (after the initial elevated value in the ED). Her headache improved with Fiorcet and she reported no other symptoms of pre-eclampsia. Aldomet was changed from 1000mg BID to ___ TID for better blood pressure control, and she was also given Fiorcet on discharge, with plans for close outpatient follow-up. She was discharged home on hospital day #3. . *) Fetal Wellbeing Fetal testing was reassuring, with BPP ___ and EFW 1837g (48th%). Head circumference was noted to be less than the ___ but still within 2 standard deviations of the mean.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> left-sided weakness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Lumbar puncture <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is a ___ gentleman with a history of recently diagnosed large cell lymphoma who presents to the ER with left sided weakness. He was admitted to ___ from ___ to ___ for diagnostic laparotomy and initiation of CHOP chemotherapy. He recalls having generalized weakness towards the end of his hospital stay but does not recall the left side being significantly more so than the right; he has a history of psoriatic arthritis with his left side being affected more than his right for years but without functional impairment. After he received his Rituxan on ___, he had a fever without focal symptoms that resolved spontaneously. After, he noted that his left side was significantly weaker than his right. He has no headaches, nausea, or vision changes. He has to take stairs one at a time, favoring his right side ahd has to physically pick up his left leg to get out of bed. Further evaluation with PET-CT or a bone scan is recommended. 3. Intramuscular edema within the right teres major along scapular insertion, possibly post-traumatic but uncertain. 4. Large predominantly cystic lesion within the head of the right humerus which does not appear to enhance post-contrast. It is possible this represents subchondral cystic change within the humeral head; it appears atypical for both avascular necrosis and neoplastic involvement. 5. 1.1 cm nodule within the posterior aspect of the left lobe of the thyroid gland which appears to be predominantly cystic and likely represents a colloid cyst. summary: # L sided muscle weakness: Pt presented with left sided proximal upper and lower extremity muscle weakness. He note progressive weakness since starting CHOP the week prior; however, he developed acute weakness following rituximab dose on ___. Initial neurology evaluation in ED notable for left sided proximal muscle weakness more consistent with peripheral nerve disease. Aside from weakness, he had no other symptoms. An LP was notable for increased CSF protein but there were less than 5 WBC and flow cytometry and cytogenetics were normal. A brain MRI and Cervical MRI were normal. Brachial plexus MRI was notable for questionable lymphomatous osseous involvement of L clavicle as well as muscle inflammation around R teres major with no nerve abnormalities. A pelvic MRI was notable for two focal lesions within the right iliac wing which appear highly suspicious for lymphomatous involvement. A CK was normal. While the etiology of pt's muscle weakness remains unclear at the time of discharge, it resolved during the course of admission. Differential at the time of discharge includes paraneoplastic syndrome versus underlying autoimmune process given there was some mild muscle edema on MRI. A paraneoplastic panel is still pending at the time of discharge. He will follow up with Dr. ___ EMG and follow up as an outpatient. # DLBCL: First diagnosed following pancreatic mass biopsy in ___. He is now status post first cycle of R-CHOP. He was continued on cipro during hospitalization for neutropenia. Work up revealed no CSF involvement of lymphoma. ___ :Cr initially 1.6 on admission but downtrended with fluids and remained at 1 during admission. His ___ was initially held but restarted at the time of dishcarge. He should continue to have his creatinine trended as an outpatient. #HTN: Pt had asymptomatic bradycardia to the ___ last admission while he was on Atenolol which is now stopped. Pt found to have bump in cr to 1.6 this admission which improved with hydration and holding losartan. His SBP was in the 125-135 range without ___. He was restarted

summary: ___ w/chronic failure to thrive, presents from home for treatment of suspected pneumonia and anemia. #Pneumonia. CXR consistent with retrocardiac opacity concerning for PNA. Treated with 5-day course levaquin for community acquired pneumonia, last day ___. Patient without dyspnea, with O2 sat >95% on RA for 24h prior to discharge. . #Anemia. Chronic. Stable and low HCT of 23 with MCV of 98 at admission. B12 and folate normal, iron studies reveal anemia of inflammation. Two negative guaiacs. He was given one unit of PRBCs. HCT the day before discharge was 27.4. . #Pseudogout: Mr. ___ knee exam was consistent with an inflammatory effusion from psuedogout, which has been documented twice previously on knee tap. He did not have a fever or a white count during this admission. Restarted on colchicine 0.6mg PO BID. His knee exam remained stable during the admission, although on the day of discharge, Mr. ___ did indicate some tenderness with passive flexion that was not appreciated at the time of admission. Colchicine was continued at time of discharge in the context of ongoing joint symptoms; he should be evaluated for improvement over the coming week and decision can made at that point whether to continue low dose colchicine for prophylaxis. . #Hypernatremia: On admission, noted free water deficit estimated at 1.9 liters, with mild hypernatremia. He was given gentle IVF and his hypernatremia resolved. . #Failure to thrive: Lost significant weight over the past year with unclear etiology. He does have difficulty swallowing as was documented during his last admission. During last admission he refused G-tube placement and a decision was made continue taking POs for patient comfort despite aspiration risks. He currently appears cachectic with an albumin of 2.8 on admission. He was given ensure supplements and PO intake was encouraged. Should be on aspiration precautions at rehab. . #CAD/PVD: Not on aspirin, statin,

MRI revealed infarction of the RT caudate and lentiform nucleus, MRA with RT ICA occlusion from the cervical to supracliniod segments, MRA with fat suppression showed T1 bright thrombi (most likely intramural, but may be intraluminal) in the distal cervical and proximal petrous segments suggesting dissection. Etiology of symptoms likely RT ICA dissection given imaging evidence and clinical history. Antiplatelet therapy initiated with 81 mg daily aspirin, with plan for anticoagulation to start on ___ given likely occlusive thrombus at site of dissection. text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abdominal pain and vomiting <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Patient is a ___ year old female with history of  Crohn's disease, previously responsive to prednisone and mesalamine, presenting with 4 days of severe abdominal pain with inability to take anything by mouth due to vomiting. She reports to the ED because her symptoms worsened to a degree that she became concerned. . ___ recently visited Dr. ___ at the ___ Bowel Disease Center at ___ earlier ___. At that time, the patient was doing well with no abdominal pain and 1 bowel movement per day. At the time of that visit, she was taking Asacol 1600mg BID. . She reports that over the past week, she developed symptoms of abdominal pain associated with diarrhea, and nausea and vomitting. The abdominal pain began first located in the lower abdomen; abdominal pain was associated with diarrhea. She has noticed that her diarrhea is a maroon in color. She denies frank blood in her stool. She reports that she may have seen some mucinous material in her stool. Her abdominal pain is worse before bowel movements and then improves with bowel movements. Initially, her abdominal pain involved the lower abdomen, and now it involves her entire abdomen. The pain has become acutely worse in the past ___ days. . Over the week, she reports an increasingly poor appetite. At the beginning of the week, she was able to eat some solid foods, but as the week progressed, she was only able to take sips of Ginge Ale secondary to nausea. summary: # Inflammatory Bowel Disease flare: Patient's constellation of symptoms consistent with flare of her underlying inflammatory bowel disease with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and loose bloody stools. ESR and CRP on admission were elevated suggesting inflammatory process. Her home Mesalamine was continued through the admission. On admission, the patient was made NPO. The patient was started on IV ciprofloxacin and IV steroids under the guidance of Gastroenterology. Stool cultures were obtained and were negative. With improvement in the patient's symptomatology, the patient was transitioned to oral prednisone, with instructions for a long taper. While in house, the patient tried to prep for a colonoscopy; however, she was unable to complete the prep, so a colonoscopy was not done during the admission. As the patient's symptoms of nausea and vomiting improved, her diet was advanced. On day of discharge, the patient was with less nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, and was able to tolerate an oral diet. # Bowel obstruction: Patient presented with symptoms of nausea/vomiting and found to have a possible bowel obstruction on KUB. Patient was made NPO, started on IV fluids, and treated symptomatically with IV anti-emetics. Patient's symptoms overall improved with initiation of IV steroids with no emesis and less nausea. On day of discharge, the patient's symptoms of nausea/vomiting improved, and she was tolerating an oral diet. She attributed her vomiting prior to discharge to taking Oxycodone on an empty stomach, but she did well with actual food. She was discharged home with oral zofran for control of her nausea. # Metabolic acidosis with anion-gap: Patient's bicarbonate was trended through the admission, and she was noted to have an anion gap. A lactate was 1.0 though ketones were present in urine. The acidosis was attributed to starvation ketoacidosis. Bicarbonate and anion gap continued to be trended through the admission and resolved by day of discharge. # Low

summary: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service for evaluation and treatment. She was NPO, on IV fluids, IV antibiotics and serial abdominal exams. The patient was hemodynamically stable. On admission she had a high white count and elevated lactate. His labs nicely normalized over the course of hospitalization. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. An abdomen CT scan was taken findings consistent with extensive atherosclerotic disease of aorta and branches of SMA and Celiac artery and ___. Vascular surgery service was consulted. No signs of acute ischemia. Recommended follow-up with Dr. ___ as an outpatient. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. GI/GU/FEN: The patient was made NPO with IV fluids. Diet was advanced when appropriate, which was well tolerated. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary. Electrolytes were routinely followed, and replete when necessary. ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were closely watched for signs of infection. Urinary culture was consistent with skin/genital contamination , she was asymptomatic. Endocrine: The patient's blood sugar was monitored throughout his stay; insulin dosing was adjusted accordingly. Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined routinely; no transfusions were required. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

summary: ___ is a ___ woman with a history of chronic left foot ulcer ___ year) and chronic lymphedema who presents with acute worsening on chronic wound and superimposed cellulitis. # Cellulitis # Acute flare of chronic foot ulcer. She was Seen by podiatry in the ED and known to podiatry service here. While there is not a deep wound, podiatry recommended admission to medicine for IV broad spectrum antibiotics. She was given IV Vanc and Unasyn in the ED. Podiatry also recommended referral to a specialist for treatment of her venous malformations such as a radiation oncologist or vascular surgeon. After arrival on the floor, she is continued on IV vancomycin cefepime and Flagyl and continue to be followed by podiatry. On the day after her admission, improved significantly, and she was discharged on a course of Augmentin. She will also continue wound care, walk with a medical shoe, and use compression stockings. She will follow-up with podiatry in approximately 10 days. # Acute renal failure # Metabolic acidosis: non-gap She was admitted with mild acute renal failure with creatinine up to 1.2. This improved with IV fluid back to her baseline. summary: #. CAD/NSTEMI: The pt had somewhat atypical chest pain but did have positive cardiac enzymes. She is now s/p cardiac catheterization with balloon angioplasty to an 80% proximal LAD lesion (no stents were placed due to anemia). On discharge the pt denies chest pain, shortness of breath (aside from baseline shortness of breath that the pt uses home oxygen continuously for). She was discharged on aspirin, diltiazem, and an ACE inhibitor. The pt has a statin allergy. . #. Concern for adrenal insufficiency: During this admission the pt had an appropriate cortisol stimulation test. . #. Urinary tract infection: Blood cultures were negative during this admission and TEE did not show vegetations. The pt was treated with meropenem for E.coli infection that was resistent to Cipro, Bactrim and ampicillin. She will continue meropenem until ___. . #. Microcytic anemia: During this admission the pt was guaiac negative. Colonoscopy in ___ showed diverticulosis, and a sinclge angiodysplasia, but the pt did not have bleeding during this admission and hematocrit was stable at 27 for the entirety of the admission. The pt will follow up with GI as an outpatient.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Weakness and falls <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is an ___ right-handed male with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, coronary artery disease (CABG x5, coronary stents placement x6 in ___, kidney cancer, osteoarthritis, and CNS lymphoma who presents from clinic today with weakness and falls at home. Today the patient presented for follow up with Dr. ___ for C1D1 of premetrexed. His wife reports that Mr. ___ legs are weak proximally and she has had difficulty getting him out of the house and into the car. These symptoms started approximately with an increase in his steroid dose and have gotten progressively worse over this time frame. He has also noted an associated weakness in his muscles. No associated rashes. Because of this weakness, the patient has had falls at home, but no headstrikes. He usually falls as he gets out of bed but catches himself. No preceding lightheadedness, chest pain, or SOB. He denies headache, nausea, vomiting, seizure or jerks. Of note, patient was recently admitted from ___ to ___ with unilateral weakness thought to be due to seizure. MRI on ___ showed slight interval increase in the size of an enhancing lesion seen abutting the right posterior falx, but with otherwise decreased vasogenic edema compared to prior study. EEG was done and it was thought that increased lesion was the likely culprit. He was started on keppra and dexamethosone was increased to 4mg BID (from 0.5mg daily). On arrival to the floor, patient confirms the above story. He also notes some persistent right-sided inspiratory pain that began after a recent fall. He reports getting a chest xray recently that was negative for fracture. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria. All other 10-system review negative in detail. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: Per Dr. ___ from ___: CNS lymphoma involving the right parietal white matter. He had: (1) stereotaxic brain biopsy by Dr. ___ on ___ that showed primary diffuse large cell lymphoma, (2) ophthalmology evaluation at bedside on ___ that did not show vitreous lymphoma, (3) started high-dose methotrexate at 3.5 grams/m2 on ___ and had 2 cycles so far, (4) received rituximab weekly x 4 at 375 mg/m2 from ___ to ___, (5) MRI on ___ showed residual disease and some areas with larger tumor, and (6) admission from ___ to ___ to ___ Hospitalist Service after a seizure. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - CABG (___) - Coronary stents in ___ - Hypertension - Kidney cancer s/p L partial nephrectomy; no adjuvant chemoXRT - Osteoarthritis - Bilateral knee replacement - Left hip replacement <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> His mother died of heart failure while his father died of cerebral hemorrhage after a motor vehicle accident. His brother died after a heart transplant after a myocardial infarction. His sister is alive with breast cancer and ovarian cancer in remission, also had lymphoma. He has 3 sons; they are all healthy. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Physical Examination: VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 98.2 F, blood pressure 128/78, pulse 60, respiration 18 and oxygen saturation 98% in room air GENERAL: NAD, appears stated age HEENT: NC/AT, EOMI, PERRL, MMM, no OP lesions LYMPHATICS: no cervical, supraclavicular, axillary or inguinal LAD CARDIAC: RRR, occasional irregular beat, nl S1 and S2, no murmurs LUNGS: CTAB no w/r/rh. Some pain on palpation right lower anterior rib cage. ABDOMEN: BS, protuberant, soft, NT/ND, no r/g EXTREMITIES: No lower extermity pitting edema PULSES: 2DP pulses bilaterally SKIN: Warm and dry, multiple tattoos NEUROLOGICAL EXAMINATION: CN II-XII intact. Horizontal and vertical nystagmus. Strength diminished in proximal muscles of legs b/l with pain experience on knee extension R>L. Sensation to light touch intact bilaterally. Biceps reflexes 2 bilaterally, patellar 1 bilaterally, upgoing babinski bilaterally. Finger to nose with some zig-zagging bilaterally. No pronator drift. Discharge Physical Examination: VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 97.7 F, blood pressure 144/70, pulse 50, respiration 16 and oxygen saturation 96% in room air GENERAL: NAD, appears stated age, rad onc pen markings on face HEENT: NC/AT, EOMI, PERRL, MMM CARDIAC: RRR, occasional irregular beat, nl S1 and S2, no murmurs LUNGS: CTAB no w/r/rh. ABDOMEN: BS
summary: ___ is an ___ male with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, coronary artery disease, kidney cancer, osteoarthritis, and CNS lymphoma who presented from clinic with weakness and falls at home, thought to be due to steroid myopathy. Initially steroid dose not to be lowered so patient admitted for evaluation by radiation oncology. Whole brain radiation therapy was for CNS lymphoma was initiated while inpatient. Received 3 of 14 planned treatments. After initiation of radiation his dexamethasone was lowered from 4mg BID to 6mg daily. He will follow up with Dr. ___, his primary oncologist, for further taper. (1) Pain Control: During hospitalization the patient complained of diffuse arthritis pain that improved with home glucosamine-chondroitin sulfate and scheduled tyelonol. Additionally opiates were increased from oxycodone 5mg BID to dilaudid 2mg Q6 hours prn. Also found to have right lower rib fracture treated with pain control as above and lidocaine patch. (2) Depression: Patient also espousing symptoms of depression and was started on low dose of sertraline. (3) Weakness: Patient evaluated by ___ and deemed patient to require ___ rehab. (4) Constipation: Patient very constipated. Bowel regimen increased. Prior to discharge was given soap suds enema with good effect. CHRONIC ISSUES: (5) CKD: Thought to be due to MTX/HTN. Creatinine baseline 1.4-1.8. Improved at 1.3, not checked on day of discharge. (6) Anemia: H/h stable. Home iron was continued. (7) BPH: continued home doxazosin (8) CAD/HTN/Dyslipidemia: s/p CABG x5, PCI x6 in ___. Continued home asa, atenolol and zetia, statin for cholesterol. Transitional Issues: - continued treatment for CNS lymphoma per rad onc and neuro onc, further steroid taper per Dr. ___. Patient has follow up scheduled. - f/u depressive symptoms and titrate sertraline accordingly - Monitor pain control and titrate medications as necessary. Maintain good bowel regimen while on narcotics and

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ RHW with hx of R thalamic lacune, dyslipidemia and likely TGA where she presented with confusion 6 months ago returns today with similar presentation although much less retrograde amnesia than last time. 1. Confusion. Ms. ___ had a CT and MRI, which showed evidence of an old known infarct, but no signs of new ischemia. She also underwent an EEG, which was preliminarily read as normal. On further questioning, Ms. ___ noted that prior to the onset of her confusional episode, she had been doing Pilates, which involved spending a period of time with her neck in extreme flexion. Of note, her prior episode occurred after she had been at the salon, with her neck in extreme extension. It is suspected that her symptoms were related to hypoperfusion following these positional changes. In an alternative hypothesis, she did develop a headache after both episodes, so this could represent a complex migraine. The patient was instructed to avoid extreme flexion and extension of her neck, to try to avoid onset of symptoms in the future. On discharge she had a normal neurologic exam.

No evidence of blood products are demonstrated at the frontal lobes or areas with abnormal magnetic susceptibility. There is persistent soft tissue swelling with skin laceration at the left parietal and right frontal regions. . ___ MRI ___: Extensive fluid/edema about the cervical ___ including along the anterior longitudinal, interspinous and nuchal ligaments, suggesting ligamentous injury; the posterior soft tissues, within the facet joints and within the atlanto-occipital and atlantoaxial articulations as described above. 2. Subluxations of the C1 lateral masses relative to the C2 lateral masses, and possible subluxation of the left atlanto-occipital articulation, which may reflect ligamentous injury. 3. No associated pelvic hematoma or active extravasation. 3. Fracture of the right sacral ala, extending into the right sacroiliac joint. 4. T1 spinous process fracture, and possibly also T3 spinous process. 5. Endotracheal tube tip at the level of the carina, and should be slightly retracted. . ___ XR R forearm, wrist, elbow: No fracture. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> HCT 12.5', simvastatin 20qHS, lisinopril 30', amitriptyline 10qHS, metformin 1g', zyrtec, nasonex <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS
summary: She was admitted to the Trauma service. Neurosurgery was consulted for the subarachnoid hemorrhage which was managed non operatively. Serial neurologic exams and head imaging remained stable. No seizure prophylaxis was warranted per Neurosurgery. Orthopedics was consulted for the pelvic fracture; she was taken to the operating rom for repair of this on ___. There were no intraoperative complications. She was recommended for Lovenox to continue for 2 weeks. Her ligamentous knee injury did not require acute intervention; she will follow up in Orthopedics as an outpatient. A Vascular consult was requested to asses ABI's given the knee dislocation and no vascular issues were identified. She did have pain control issues initially which were ultimately resolved. At time of discharge she was on Percocet with adequate pain relief. Her home medications were restarted. She was evaluated by Physical and Occupational therapy and was cleared for discharge to home with family.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> fevers, chills <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Balloon dilatation of L biliary stent, Internal-external biliary drain/PTBD placement (___) PTBC removal, anchor drain placement (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with history of cholangiocarcinoma s/p partial resection presents with fever and chills. Patient complains of generalized malaise for several days, constipation, subacute cough for 1 week. Had 1 episode of nbnb emesis earlier in the day after dinner. Of note, most recent admission ___ for fevers with no identifiable source. Admitted for klebsiella bacteremia ___. In the ED initial vitals 102.5 132 123/56 18 96% found to have Elevated lactate of 4.5 and tachycardia which improved after IV fluids started on vanc and osyn for likely biliary source of sepsis (no septic shock). Urine and blood cultures sent. BP downtrended to 86/49 HR 80. ERCP consulted re: downtrending BPs they recommended ___ for perc drain given his anatomy. ___ requested CT to better eval biliary anatomy given complex hx. CT with evidence of left intra hepatic biliary duct dilation compared to prior indicating likely occlusion of the left internal biliary stent. ___ decided to do emergent biliary drain placement. On admission patient reports feeling very cold, denies abdominal pain, chest pain nausea. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: -___: underwent BMBx for anemia, that evening presented to ___ with biliary sepsis. MRCP revealed tapering and diffuse thickening of proximal CBD, liver hilum and distal intrahepatic left right and hepatic ducts s/p CCY. -___: ERCP showed a 1.5 cm stricture in the proximal CHD. The left intrahepatics were not filled. The CBD was 7mm in maximum diameter. No filling defects identified. Sphincterotomy with brushings demonstrating atypical cells, can't exclude reactive. A 5cm x ___ double pigtail biliary stent placed into the right main hepatic duct. Broad spectrum antibiotics narrowed to levo/flagyl x 5d. -___: melenotic, guaiac positive stool, transferred to ___ -___: CT Chest weveral indeterminate pulmonary nodules measure up to 7 mm in the RUL. Right apical nodularity and bronchiolar impaction is most likely infectious or inflammatory in etiology. -___: Ill-defined hypoenhancing mass within the hepatic hilum which extends from the confluence to the right anterior and posterior ducts. The left main duct appears to be spared. This is consistent with Klatskin tumor, type IIIA. No distal metastasis or lymphadenopathy. -___: Admitted for complex surgery including excision of extrahepatic biliary tree, portal and hepatic arterial lymphadenectomy, Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy to extrahepatic common hepatic duct, placement of biliary stent and fiducials for radiation. Surgical pathology demonstrates well differentiated adenocarcinoma, positive magins, extension into periductal adipose tissue, ___ nodes involved, pT2aN0Mx. -___: Tube cholangiogram -___: CT abd/pelvis with stable intrahepatic biliary dilatation involving the right and the left lobes. Ill-defined hypodense area in the left lobe of the liver which may be postsurgical in nature. Recommend attention on followup. Postsurgical changes including a small amount of fluid in the abdomen and in the postsurgical bed without other evidence of complication. -___: MRCP w/ 1. Persistent intrahepatic biliary tree dilatation with discontinuation and amputation at the level of biliary confluence at the hilum. The findings are concerning for residual Klatskin tumor involving the secondary biliary confluences bilaterally (Bismuth ___ type IV). No concerning lymph nodes. Unchanged compression fracture of the vertebral body L3. -___: Right cholangiogram, placement of right internal/external drain -___: Cholangiogram, exchange of right PTBD -___: Right and Left cholangiogram, placement of right posterior drain -___: Wall stents to right anterior and posterior and left biliary drains, balloon dilitation, anchor drains in place, Roux tube pulled. -___: Anchor drains pulled -___: Initial medical and radiation oncology evaluation -___: Transferred from ___ to ___ for what turned out to be Klebsiella bacteremia, LFTs and CT torso stable, deferred ERCP, PICC placed, discharged on ertapenem daily ending -___. summary: ___ y/o ___ male with presumed cholangiocarcinoma, s/p previous extra-hepatic biliary excision with indwelling stents, who presented with fever, chills, leukocytosis, and cholestatic LFT pattern concerning for cholangitis. S/p PTBD placement with ___ ___ for relief, biliary drain cultures sent, and antibiotics de-escalated to PO Ciprofloxacin and PO Metronidazole based on cultures. Transferred to OMED from MICU on ___. # Cholangitis: Had PTBD placement with ___ on ___. Initially on Vancomycin and osyn, and remained hemodynamically stable. He was quickly de-escalated to PO Ciprofloxacin and PO Flagyl, as he looked so clinically well. However, he became tachycardic to 120s-150s, and was re-placed on osyn as well as IVF supplementation. Due to increasing leukocytosis and bilirubin, he went with ___ for adjustment of the L-sided stent; it appeared that flow in that region was adequate, and the PTBD was removed/ replaced with a capped anchor drain, with the contingency of uncapping and placing a bag on the drain if he developed increasing pain or fevers. Over the course of the next 2 days, his cultures came back as pan-sensitive Klebsiella x 2 morphologies, and there was no further evidence of bacteremia. He was transitioned back to PO Ciprofloxacin and PO Flagyl, and monitored for 24 hours. He remained afebrile and clinically stable; he was discharged to complete a 14-day course of antibiotics to end on ___, the evening prior to his follow-up with Dr. ___. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ man with CMML-1 on decitabine C1D20, also CAD and CHF. Presenting with dyspnea and was found to have GGOs on chest CT. #dyspnea, resolved #acute on chronic systolic HF, improving Dyspnea and GGOs on CT. Bronchoscopy on ___ notable for diffuse, frothy secretions consistent with pulmonary edema. TTE ___ showed EF 35%, decreased from prior, moderate to severe MR, and increased pulmonary pressures. These findings in concert with bilateral crackles, JVD, and ___ edema on exam were consistent with decompensated heart failure. Etiology of decompensation unclear. Patient states that he limits his salt intake but he has admitted eating less healthy over the past several weeks, so dietary indiscretion is possible. Patient and his wife state that he takes his medications every day. Could potentially be under-dosed. Ischemic event unlikely given recent LHC without concerning findings. Possibly secondary to worsening valvular disease. While heart failure is almost certainly contributing to the patient's presentation, infection (though extensive infectious workup negative) or pneumonitis secondary to decitabine may also have been contributing. Repeat noncontrast chest CT performed on ___ showed stable ground glass opacities consistent with stable pulmonary edema as well as a new ___ opacity on the right side concerning for irritation secondary to bronchoscopy vs. infection. Now close to euvolemic with resolution of symptoms. Consolidation in right mid/lower lung field resolved on repeat CXR on ___. will hold off on treating possible infection as patient is clinically improving and recently completed a 7-day course of levofloxacin. Repeat TTE on ___ largely unchanged from prior - per cards, this indicates excess fluid still on board. Plan will be to discharge home on torsemide 80 mg qAM and 40 mg qPM so that he can continue to lose weight gradually over the next few days at home with close cardiology follow-up. For management of heart failure, the patient was continued on metoprolol succinate 100 mg

He had a TTE demonstrating multiple moderate-sized vegetations on the tricuspid valve leaflets, causing obstruction of transtricuspid flow, and moderate tricuspid stenosis. CT surg were consulted and determined him a poor surgical candidate given risk of repeat-sternotomy and his current drug abuse <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Tricuspid valve endocarditis ___ MRSA in ___ s/p bioprosthetic TV at ___ MSSA bacteremia/endocarditis, ___ HCV IVDA and polysubstance abuse # Tricuspid valve endocarditis ___ MRSA in ___ s/p bioprosthetic TV at ___ # MSSA bacteremia/endocarditis, ___ # HCV # IVDA and polysubstance abuse # Asthma, mild and not on meds <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> family healthy <PHYSICAL EXAM> (on admission) T 100.8 BP 113/79 HR 96 RR ___ 96% on RA General: sleepy, tachypneic, no distress HEENT: NCAT, PERRL, EOMI, neck supple, w/o LAD, icteric sclera, no hemorrhage CV: tachy  systolic murmur at ___. S4 Pulm: scattered crackles and wheezing Abd: s/nd  RUQ and LUQ TTP.  liver edge, spleen non-palpable. no rebound/gaurding Ext: papular rash on RLE. no petechiae/splinter hemorrhage or ___ nodes <PERTINENT RESULTS> TTE (___): The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF 70%) There is no ventricular septal defect. The aortic arch is moderately dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. A bioprosthetic tricuspid valve is present. The gradients are higher than expected for this type of prosthesis. The leaflets of the tricuspid prosthesis are thickened. There is are multiple moderate-sized vegetations on the tricuspid valve leaflets, causing obstruction of transtricuspid flow. There is moderate tricuspid stenosis (area 1.0-1.5cm2). There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: bioprosthesis tricuspid valve endocarditis; tricuspid valve prosthesis stenosis . CT head (___): No CT evidence for septic emboli in the brain. . CT chest, abd, pelvis (___): 1. Severe multifocal airspace opacities are identified within the lung parenchyma. This may represent multifocal infection possibly from septic emboli. 2. No evidence of intra- or extra-hepatic biliary dilatation. 3. Fusion of the right SI joint for which clinical correlation is recommended as detailed above. Gallbladder wall is mildly thickened and there is splenomegaly, free fluid, as well as enlarged perihepatic lymph nodes, which may all represent a sequela from underlying chronic liver disease. . TTE (___): The left atrium is elongated. Left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%) The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. Mitral valve leaflets are normal, with trivial mitral regurgitation. A bioprosthetic tricuspid valve is present. There is a large (2.0 x 1.1 cm), highly-mobile vegetation on the tricuspid prosthesis. There is no abscess of the tricuspid valve, and the sewing ring appears intact, without dehiscence or paravalvular regurgitation. The vegetation is partially obstructive to flow, resulting in functionally-moderate tricuspid stenosis (mean gradient 15 mmHg). No vegetation/mass is seen on the pulmonic valve. Estimated pulmonary pressures are normal. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Prosthetic tricuspid valve endocarditis with moderate functional tricuspid stenosis. . CT chest w/ contrast (___): 1. Persistent multiple pulmonary septic emboli. 2. Hepatosplenomegaly. Decreased attenuation of the right lobe may represent focal fatty infiltration. 3. Fusion of the right SI joint, unchanged. 4. Increased sclerosis of the left pubic symphysis, unchanged.

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ man with PMHx notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, asthma, hypothyroidism, non-insulin dependent diabetes, and recent hospitalization for traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage admitted for altered mental status. Discovered to have euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis secondary to canagliflozin requiring prolonged insulin gtt in MICU. His course was complicated by severe esophagitis likely secondary to recent SAH with EGD negative for evidence of infection. # EUGLYCEMIC DIABETIC KETOACIDOSIS # TYPE 2 DIABETES - NON-INSULIN DEPENDENT Initially presented to outside hospital for altered mental status, nausea, vomiting, and gait instability. Discovered to have high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hyperglycemia to 308, and ketonuria consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis. Received fluid boluses and admitted to the MICU for insulin gtt with rapid improvement in serum glucose. Course complicated by persistent anion gap and ketonuria despite normalization of serum glucose, overall consistent with euglycemic DKA. Likely medication side effect of canagliflozin. Per ___ recommendations was continued on insulin gtt, D5W, and escalating Lantus doses to ensure gap remained close. Patient was weaned off the D5W and stabilized on a sliding scale and lantus regimen. Trulicity and Invokana were held on discharge. He will be discharged on Lantus 12 units bid, Humalog to ___ units with meals, and insulin sliding scale. Patient received nutrition and diabetes counseling prior to discharge. # ENCEPHALOPATHY Initially presented for altered mental status in setting of recent hospitalization for intracranial bleeding. Workup notable for marked metabolic abnormalities consistent with DKA (hyperglycemia, ketonuria, high anion gap metabolic acidosis). Repeat CT head imaging overall stable; neurosurgery recommended against any further intervention. Encephalopathy also potentially contributed to by Keppra which was started following traumatic head injury. Empirically started on antibiotics for concern of meningitis/encephalitis. LP was grossly

summary: ___ year old previously healthy gentleman admitted with fever and LBP, found to have high grade MSSA bacteremia, transferred to ICU with hypoxia. # Septic shock secondary to MSSA bacteremia: There was initial concern for epidural abscess versus phlegmon as read at ___ ___ suggested this. Neurosurgery deferred intervention as there was no clear collection on MRI. Repeat MRI at ___ did not reveal any drainable abscess, but showed discitis, fluid collection, and findings consistent with posterior disc protrusion. TEE x2 to further characterize high grade bacteremia showed no endocarditis, but a bicuspid valve. CT torso, head, sinuses also negative. Patient was initially on vanc/ceftriaxone/flagyl on the day of admission, which was later switched to cefazolin and clindamycin on ___ because of worsening transaminitis. The clindamyin was stopped after 4 days to cover for toxic shock. He will be treated with cefazolin for 6 weeks given bicuspid valve, and discitis and presumed epidural abscess. Last febrile ___ to 102.9. # Mild ARDS: CXR consistent with developing ARDS related to large inflammatory response to sepsis. Initially, able to maintain on BIPAP with improvement in saturations from 75% on room air, but due to need to complete studies and inability to tolerate lying flat for MRI, patient was intubated. PaO2/FIO2 consistent with mild ARDS. There may have been some cardiogenic component as well, as the patient would become notably more dyspneic when hypertensive with worsening pulmonary edema on chest x ray. However, the primary component due to the patient's illness was thought to be sepsis. Patient was placed on ARDSnet protocol. There was no evidence of pneumonia. He was successfully extubated on HD 4 and diuresed with lasix gtt for worsening pulmonary edema thought to be secondary to flash pulmonary edema in the setting of hypertension/tachycardia. He diuresed a total of 5L with improvement in respiratory status, weaned to 2L NC (from 60% Fio2 and 6

He was not feeling SOB at that time. He called his PCP who told him to come the ER. EMS arrived and found him to have a RA sat in the mid ___. It was on his way to the ED in the ambulance that he felt SOB. Per report, had 200cc hemoptysis in ambulance. Denies CP or palpitations. No sick contacts. Has been feeling generally well. Presented initially to ___ but quickly transferred to ___. . In the ED, vital signs initially were 100.7, 88, 121/59, 96% 4L. He received vanco/zosyn and underwent a CTA which showed no PE but bilateral PNA and large right pleural effusion. No signs of bleeding into effusion. No further episodes of hemoptysis. . Currently, feels his breathing is better and would like to get some rest. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> #. Congestive heart failure - presumably diastolic with preserved EF 55% on Echocargiogram in ___ #. Atrial fibrillation - On anticoagulation #. Hypertension #. GERD #. HEENT: Sclera anicteric, PERRL, EOMI, OP clear, MMM NECK: Supple, no LAD CV: ___, ___ SEM with loud S2 PULM: coarse rales at L base, decrease BS ___ way up on right ABD: Soft, NT, ND, BS EXT: chronic venous stasis changes, 1 ___ edema bilaterally NEURO: AAOx3, CN II-XII grossly intact, moving all extremities well . <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD WBC-5.3 RBC-4.21* Hgb-13.8* Hct-41.4 MCV-98 MCH-32.8* MCHC-33.3 RDW-13.6 Plt Ct-93* ___ 11: 41PM BLOOD Neuts-86.7* Bands-0 Lymphs-5.3* Monos-7.6 Eos-0.2 Baso-0.2 ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD ___ PTT-36.9* ___ ___ 11: 41PM BLOOD ___ PTT-36.5* ___ ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-108* UreaN-32* Creat-0.8 Na-142 K-4.3 Cl-104 HCO3-30 AnGap-12 ___ 11: 41PM BLOOD Glucose-106* UreaN-31* Creat-1.0 Na-144 K-3.9 Cl-106 HCO3-28 AnGap-14 ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD Calcium-8.9 Phos-2.6* Mg-2.1 CXR Study Date of ___ 11: 29 ___ IMPRESSION: 1. Bilateral basilar airspace process, worrisome for aspiration pneumonia. 2. Interval increase in size of right moderate pleural effusion. CTA 1. Slightly limited study secondary to respiratory motion. No central or segmental pulmonary embolism. 2. Large right pleural effusion and mild septal thickening may indicate mild congestive heart failure. 3. Patchy opacities present at the lung base are likely related to aspiration but could also represent alveolar hemorrhage. 4. While no discrete lung masses identified, the study is somewhat limited secondary to acute findings. A dedicated chest CT once symptoms have resolved is recommended as clinically indicated. CXR Study Date of ___ 2: 23 ___ Since yesterday, right pleural effusion significantly decreased status post thoracentesis and is now tiny. Bibasilar alveolar opacities are unchanged, due to aspiration vs. atelectasis. Cardiomegaly is unchanged. There is no vascular congestion. Calcified left axillary lymph nodes are unchanged. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> #. warfarin 2.5mg daily (increased to 5mg if INR low) #. estril 20mg daily #. Disp: *8 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 6. Warfarin 2.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day: Start after discontinuation of Levofloxacin. Then check INR, if less than 2 give 2.5 mg Warfarin. summary: #Hemoptysis The initial evaluation with CXR and CT revealed significant effusion on the right side. The patient's warfarin was held and the INR was corrected with FFP. The patient underwent theraupeutic and diagnositic thoracocentesis and bronchoscopy. The bronchoscopy fluid was analyzed with gram stain to show gr cocci in pairs. The thoracocentesis fluid was exudative in origin and bloody. Unclear if caused by a potentially necrotizing pneumonia or if it is secondary to malignancy. He was started on Levofloxacin and Flagyl to treat for community or aspiration pneumonia. The patient did very well after these interventions and he did not have any more hemoptysis. We strongly suggested outpatient follow up to evaluate for potential malignancy. . # CHF: Received over 2L of NS at during initial recussitation in the ED. Home medications, lasix and lisinopril were continued throught the stay without signs of exacurbation. . # A.fib: Rate controlled without nodal agent. Warfarin was held for the duration of stay and then restarted at discharge. It was started at 2mg givent the concurrent antibiotix administration. WE recommend checking INR after the antibiotics are over and then give warfarin at 2.5 mg (outpatient regimen) to keep INR ___.

You will need staple removal. Please keep your incision dry until staple removal. -Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. -Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple removal. -Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like redness, fever, or drainage. When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for: -Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision site. -Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit -New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.
summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to ___ Neurosurgery service on ___ after he underwent an elective L2 laminectomy for synovial cyst resection. He tolerated the procedure well and there were no intraoperative complications. He was transferred to the PACU and weaned to extubation there. His pain was managed with narcotic and non-narcotic analgesics. His diet was advanced to regular as tolerated. Later that evening, Mr. ___ was transferred to the inpatient ward for further observation and management. On ___ Patient's pain was well controlled. He had one episode of tachycardia to the 120s. He was given a fluid bolus and it resolved. ___ was consulted. On ___ Patient was evaluated by physical therapy who recommended rehab. On ___ Patient is neurologically stable. He was discharged to a skilled nursing facility on the evening of ___. At the time of discharge, he was afebrile, hemodynamically and neurologically intact.

She had a survellience MRI which demonstrated what appeared to be a 4 to 5 mm left middle cerebral artery aneurysm. The aneurysm was confirmed with high-resolution CT angiography. Elective surgery for securing of the aneurysm was scheduled. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> MS, hysterectomy, anemia <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of aneurysms. <PHYSICAL EXAM> On Discharge: AOx3. PERRL, no pronator. Full strength with exception of L triceps ___ <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> oxybutynin, amitriptyline, baclofen, biscodyl, iron, copaxone <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H: PRN fever or pain 2. Amitriptyline 25 mg PO QHS 3. Baclofen 10 mg PO QHS 4. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY: PRN constipation 5. Copaxone (glatiramer) 40 mg/mL subcutaneous ___ 6. Ditropan XL (oxybutynin chloride) 10 mg oral DAILY 7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H: PRN pain RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q6hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Left MCA aneurysm <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse Practitioner if you experience: -Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech or movement -Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision -Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or lethargy -Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit -Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications Activity: -Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start slowly and increase at your own pace. -Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days after your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more detail at the time of your suture removal. Incision Care: -Keep your wound clean and dry. -Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. -When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo run off the incision line. Gently pad the incision with a towel to dry. -Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the incision line. -You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery Post-Operative Experiences: Physical -Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away after about a month -You may experience constipation. Constipation can be prevented by: oDrinking plenty of fluids oIncreasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, prunes, fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements oExercising oUsing over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as needed, stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements or diarrhea -Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time -Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can take weeks or months to fully resolve -Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area -Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can resolve with increased activity Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional -You may experience depression. Symptoms of depression can include oFeeling down or sad oIrritability, frustration, and confusion oDistractibility oLower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges oInsomnia oLoneliness -If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your Primary Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist or Psychiatrist -You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group in your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation oMore information can be found at ___
summary: Ms. ___ was taken to the operating room on the day of admission on ___ and underwent a left craniotomy for clipping of a MCA aneusysm. She tolerated the procedure well and was extubated in the operating room. She was transferred to the PACU as an intensive care boarder post-operatively. Her diet was advanced as tolerated and she was restarted on her home medications. On ___ she was started on a scopolamine patch and transferred to the floor. She remained stable through the day into ___. On ___ she was mobilizing and ambulating in the halls without difficulty, she was tolerating a good PO diet, and her pain was controlled after addition of oxycodone. She was deemed fit for discharge to home without services and was given instructions for followup, prescriptions for required medications, and all questions were answered prior to discharge.

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ yo man ___ alcohol abuse c/b seizures, COPD (active smoker) presenting with COPD exacerbation ___ CAP, improved prior to discharge. # COPD exacerbation # CAP Presented with worsening dyspnea and leukocytosis. CXR with possible infection. Started on prednisone burst, IV ceftriaxone and azithromycin, transitioned to PO amoxicillin with clinical improvement. Last day of antibiotics and prednisone on ___. # Alcohol withdrawal: Tremulous on admission and had a history of withdrawal seizures. Monitored until outside the time window for onset of delirium tremens. Given Ativan for symptom management. No CIWA scoring or Ativan requirement in >24 hours prior to discharge. # Alcohol abuse: continued pre-admission acamprosate and naltrexone. Given high dose thiamine, as well as folate and MVI. Evaluated by ___ who offered contact information of ___ treatment ___ detox where the patient was previously. Patient amenable and has the contact information to schedule an intake appointment. # Transaminitis: Moderate elevation in AST/ALT on admission likely due to underlying alcoholic liver disease. No signs or symptoms of decompensation or acute liver failure. RUQ U/S w/ granuloma otherwise unrevealing. HepBsAb positive. Downtrending without intervention on discharge. PCP made aware to monitor and arrange follow-up as needed. CHRONIC ISSUES: ---------------- # COPD: management as above. Continued home advair and duonebs PRN # Smoking: Given nicotine patch and lozenges PRN while in the hospital # ADHD: held methylphenidate while hospitalized # Psych: continued lamotrigine and paroxetine # Chronic pain: continued lidocaine gel and ointment, cyclobenzaprine PRN, held Celebrex as not on formularly, written acetaminophen instead. Resumed on discharge. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== - Last day of PO amoxicillin, azithromycin, and prednisone on ___ - Please repeat LFTs in ___ weeks to ensure improvement in transaminitis - Please monitor hepatic granuloma and arrange follow-up with hepatology or additional imaging as needed - Continue to encourage

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> abdominal pain from splenic infart, SMV thrombosis <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ man with history of alcohol use disorder and IV drug use complicated by alcohol and HCV cirrhosis (c/b esophageal variceal bleed, HCC), who presented to ___ ___ on ___ with abdominal pain, found to have splenic infarct and SMV thrombosis. He was started on ceftriaxone as prophylaxis for SBP, started on a heparin gtt, and transferred here for further care. CT scan at OSH showed small splenic infarct, moderate volume ascites, left pleural effusion, small hiatal hernia, and 1.6cm liver dome HCC. Surgery and ___ evaluated the patient and determined no intervention. Lactate was normal at 1.1 suggesting the clot is not completely occluding. He was started on anticoagulation with a heparin gtt. They were unable to complete a diagnostic tap but he was started prophylactically on ceftriaxone for SBP. ___ was first diagnosed with cirrhosis ___ when he presented with fatigue, lower extremity swelling, and hematemesis and melena requiring urgent endoscopic banding. Since then he has stopped drinking alcohol. He presented to the multidisciplinary liver transplant clinic ___ for evaluation and was initially declined because he was not participating in relapse prevention programs yet. On evaluation ___ reports the abdominal pain came on suddenly on ___ and has persisted since then. He currently complains of significant pain in his abdomen that is unchanged from earlier today. It is worse in his LUQ and increased with movement. He reports his abdomen is always very large and distended, but it is now rock hard. He feels his abdomen has not changed at all over the past two days. He had multiple bowel movements this morning and is still passing gas. He thinks he has never had fluid drained from his abdomen before. He has no shortness of breath except when he bends over to tie his shoes. When asked about where he is in the transplant workup, he says he's not sure. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ man with history of alcohol use disorder and IV drug use complicated by alcohol and HCV cirrhosis (c/b esophageal variceal bleed, HCC), who presented to ___ ___ on ___ with abdominal pain, found to have splenic infarct and SMV thrombosis, who was transferred to ___ for further care. He was anticoagulated for his thrombus with heparin and transitioned to warfarin. He also underwent further liver transplant workup and an EGD which showed 2 cords of varices which were banded. ACUTE ISSUES ============= # SMV thrombosis # Splenic infarct # Abdominal pain Found to have SMV thrombosis at OSH in the setting of portal hypertension from underlying cirrhosis. Likely acute or subacute thrombosis given presentation with new abdominal pain. ___ deferred intervention and recommended medical management. Patient was anticoagulated with a heparin gtt with improvement in abdominal pain and bridged to warfarin. INR therapeutic at 2 on day of discharge. He will be discharged on warfarin 3mg daily with plan to check INR on ___. # Alcohol and HCV cirrhosis Volume: Presented with volume overload and worsening ascites since ___ imaging. - Dx para on ___ (3.2L removed, no evidence of SBP). - Diuretic regimen: torsemide 20mg daily and spironolactone 100mg daily GIB: has history of variceal bleed - Home propranolol 10mg held iso soft BPs and <60 HRs - EGD ___ showing 2 cords of esophageal varices w/ red ___ sign, now s/p banding HE: has hx of HE,  asterixis on exam here - Continued home rifaximin and lactulose SBP: no history, ___ para no evidence of SBP. - Received empiric ceftriaxone at OSH, discontinued for low suspicion of SBP Screening: known ___ - ___ CT showed 1.2cm lesion in segment 8, ___ Nutrition: Continued low sodium diet Transplant: Not listed. Workup initiated during this admission, awaiting coronary CTA and dental extraction to complete workup # Tooth necrosis Started on augmentin by dentist in preparation for tooth extraction. Will continue treatment with augmentin upon discharge. #

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Bilateral lower extremity weakness and sensory change <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> EMG Thoracentesis <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ year old woman with hypothyroidism, DI, and DMII presenting to the ED referred from neurology clinic by Dr. ___ ___ evaluation of bilateral leg and hand sensory changes with possible associated weakness in the setting of recent cholecystitis with biliary leak, subsequent cholecystectomy, and recent fall. Over past couple of days with numbness and weakness in upper extremities. question GBS. The patient reports her main issue is the numbness, in her legs on the tops not the bottoms. On further questioning notes had cholecystitis followed by lap cholecystectomy in ___. Her course was complicated by pain and leak as above. Immediately post surgically she developed numbness in her lower abdomen like a horizontal band transverse but not reaching her back, subsequently had LT leg (medial thigh and knee) numbness which she describes as reduced sensation, which about 24 hours later involved the RT leg thigh. She was discharged on ___. While she was being discharged she felt severely lightheaded. She was left on a wheelchair in the hallway, and when she saw her ride was trying to go down the stairs. Put her RT leg down on one step and fell ___ steps. She is confused about the cause of her fall as she felt lightheaded but also concerned that her legs gave out. She was readmitted for a NCHCT and EKG, which were reportedly normal. She was sent to rehab facility where she started to walk with a walker due to terrible fear of falling. She reports associated burning in the hands and fingertips like she was on fire. Denies burning sensation anywhere else in her body. Reports was not clumsy but afraid to drop things due to her sensory issues. Described her legs as wobbly but not weak. Able to register 3 objects and recall ___ at 5 minutes. No apraxia. No evidence of hemineglect. No left-right confusion. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Hearing intact to finger rub bilaterally. Palate elevation symmetric. SCM/Trapezius strength ___ bilaterally. Tongue midline. Motor: Inreased bulk and normal tone. No drift. No tremor or asterixis. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ L 5 ___ ___ 3 5 4 5 5 5 R 5 ___ ___ 3 5 4 5 5 5 Sensory: Has deficits to light touch, pin, and proprioception over her bilateral lower extremities up to T6-7, with allodynia in her palms. However, exam is somewhat inconsistent as does not endorse loss of sensation to pin on her back. No exinction to DSS. LT hand difficulty with graphesthesia -DTRs: ___ Tri ___ Pat Ach L 1 1 1 tr 0 R 1 1 1 tr 0 Plantar response flexor bilaterally. Coordination: No dysmetria with finger to nose bilaterally. Gait: Deferred. ===DISCHARGE EXAM=== General: Obese ill appearing woman, appears older than stated age HEENT: NCAT, MMM ___: RRR Pulmonary: breathing comfortably on
summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of hypothyroidism, DI, and DM p/w sensory changes in her bilateral lower extremities, abdomen and hands. #Neurologic Differential was initially broad given multilevel sensory changes, proximal > distal weakness, and decreased reflexes in the ___, including spinal cord pathologies, neuropathy, myopathy. She underwent imaging of the cervical and thoracic spine that did not reveal obvious causes of her symptoms. MRI of the brain was unremarkable. Lumbar puncture was unremarkable. Lab work showed multiple vitamin deficiencies involving B6 and B12, both of which were started. Infectious work up was negative. EMG showed diffuse axonal sensorimotor neuropathy. Overall impression was polyneuropathies due to vitamin deficiency, in setting of gastric bypass surgery and recent complicated cholecystectomy leading to acute decompensation. Her proximal weakness improved in her arms, and remained stable in her legs. This was felt to due to deconditioning, for which she was recommended physical therapy. #Pleural effusion CXR from ___ on admission for cholecystectomy shows no evidence of effusion or intrapulmonary abnormality per report. However, on presentation, patient was found to have significant right sided pleural effusion. CT of the chest revealed a large right non-hemorrhagic pleural effusion with complete collapse of the right lower lobe. She underwent a diagnostic thoracentesis which showed an exudative effusion with elevated triglycerides, felt to be due to her recent surgery and trauma from her fall. A repeat CT after the thoracentesis did not reveal an underlying malignancy. Cytology is pending. She was started on a low fat diet. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed no cardiac abnormalities; BNP was only mildly elevated. She will have follow up with ___ clinic on discharge. #LFT abnormalities Patient had elevated INR, alkaline phosphatase, and total bilirubin. RUQ ultrasound revealed changes consistent with steatohepatitis. Cause of cirrhosis is undetermined at this time, though likely due to steatosis

summary: ___ yo woman with PMHx sig. for h/o ulcerative colitis s/p colectomy in ___ with pouchitis chronically on ciprofloxacin who presents with diarrhea, orthostasis/dehydration, and acute renal failure. # ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: This was felt to be a combination of hypovolemia and ATN. She gradually improved with IVFs initially and then was encouraged po intake. FeNa was 1.7%. Renal ultrasound was obtained and no acute pathology was noted on prelim read. Her Cr had improved from 4.1 to 2.9 upon discharge. She was counseled on adequate po intake and seeking medical assistance if she starts to become dehydrated again. She will have outpatient labs drawn on ___, and follow up with her PCP's office later that week. # DIARRHEA: This had resolved upon admission. It was likely due to a virus. She had no fevers, normal WBC. # PLEURITIC CHEST PAIN: Patient had an episode of pleuritic chest pain during her admission. Her EKG had no ischemic changes. Her CXR showed no acute pathology. This was felt to be related anxiety. # POUCHITIS: She was continued on her home cipro dose and immodium. # INSOMNIA: She was on Ambien here and will return home on Unisom. # HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA: She was continued on ocor.
