Gabapentin 100 mg PO TID ___ mg three times per day for one day, then 300 mg three times per day until otherwise instructed <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ ___ Diagnosis: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor of left peroneal nerve <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane) <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Activity: You may bear weight as tolerated on your left lower extremity. Wear your knee brace at all times when out of bed. Keep your foot brace on at all times to help prevent muscle contractures. Wound: Keep dressing clean, dry and intact. Change daily until 7 days after surgery (___), at which time you may leave the wound open to air and only put a dressing on as needed if the wound is draining. Showering: You may shower starting 2 days after surgery (___). You may take a shower without the dressing in place and just let the soapy water run over the top of your wound. After the shower pat the wound completely dry and apply a dressing as needed. DO NOT submerge the wound in a bath, hottub or pool until otherwise directed. We want to make sure your wound is healed before you submerge it under water. Medications: Take your pain medication as prescribed Drain care/Antibiotics: If you go home with your drain in place, please take the antibiotics as prescribed daily until your drain is removed. Keep the wound covered, clean and dry as long as the drain is in place. Measure and record the drain output daily to help us decide when the drain should be removed. Anticoagulation: Take your lovenox shots as prescribed once daily for one month to help prevent blood clots.
summary: The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic Service following an uncomplicated resection of left lower extremity peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Please see operative report for full details. The patient tolerated the procedure without difficulty and was transferred to the PACU in stable condition, and then transferred to the floor in the usual fashion. Postoperatively, pain was controlled with IV pain meds and nerve block with transition PO pain meds as tolerated. Diet was advanced without complication and the patient made steady progress with Physical Therapy. The hospitalization has otherwise been uneventful and the patient has done well. On POD2 nerve block was discontinued and patient worked with ___ with good pain control. On POD3 at discharge, vital signs are stable, the patient is afebrile, tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, and pain is well controlled. The extremities are neurovascularly intact distally. All dressings are clean, dry and intact. The patient is discharged home with services in stable condition. Patient given instructions for the appropriate post operative care and follow up.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Left Monteggia fracture <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Left Monteggia fracture open reduction internal fixation <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a very pleasant ___ female who reports to the ED today after falling from standing and brace herself with her left arm and noted immediate pain to the left elbow. She originally presented to outside hospital and an imaging demonstrated a left olecranon fracture and possible radial head subluxation. She reports to the ED today hemodynamically stable at ___ but with continued pain in left elbow. She notes that she was walking across the street and tripped on the curb and injury resulted from trying to brace herself with her left arm. Her only other pain or complaint today is in relation to her left knee with this very minor discomfort caused by superficial abrasion from the fall. She otherwise denies pain to other extremities and has her left arm in a posterior slab splint placed at outside hospital. She reports that she has had some pins-and-needles of her hand since the injury but she continues to be able to move her fingers and wrist without issue. She reports that she is healthy and takes Adderall at baseline but no other medications including no anticoagulation medication She reports one time bad reaction to Valium, but no other issues with anesthesia. She is right-hand dominant and works as a ___. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> ADHD <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> NC <PHYSICAL EXAM> Temp: 98.6 PO BP: 125/71 R Lying HR: 92 RR: 18 O2 sat: 92% O2 delivery: Ra General: Well appearing, NAD Respiratory: Non-labored breathing LUE exam: In posterior splint Fires EPL/IO/OP/flexors SILT in median, radial, ulnar and axillary distributions Distal digits warm and well perfused <PERTINENT RESULTS> See OMR for pertinent lab and imaging results <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Amphetamine-Dextroamphetamine Dose is Unknown PO Frequency is Unknown 2. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU Frequency is Unknown <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 2. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY: PRN Constipation 3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID: PRN Constipation - First Line 4. Milk of Magnesia 30 ml PO BID: PRN Constipation 5. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate Reason for PRN duplicate override: Patient is NPO or unable to tolerate PO RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*35 Tablet Refills: *0 6. Senna 8.6 mg PO DAILY 7. Amphetamine-Dextroamphetamine 20 mg PO DAILY 8. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Left Monteggia fracture <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY: - You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal to feel tired or washed out after surgery, and this feeling should improve over the first few days to week. - Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times. ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING: -Nonweightbearing in the left upper extremity in splint, range of motion as tolerated in shoulder, wrist and digits MEDICATIONS: 1) Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is an over the counter medication. 2) Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean off this medication in 1 week or sooner. This is an example on how to wean down: Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day. Then continue with Tylenol for pain. 3) Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic medication. 4) Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 5) Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy. 6) Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers. 7) Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians at discharge. 8) Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed to stop by your surgeon. WOUND CARE: - You may shower, but keep your splint dry. No baths or swimming
summary: The patient presented to the emergency department and was evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found to have a L Monteggia fracture and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for L Monteggia ORIF, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with OT who determined that discharge to home with outpatient OT was appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is nonweightbearing in the left upper extremity, and is ambulatory and does not require pharmacologic DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

summary: BRIEF SUMMARY ============= ___ h/o NSCLC, prostate CA ___ 9) with spinal and brain metastases of unknown primary s/p recent admission to ___ for cord compression now admitted from rehab with worsening weakness. The patient also was treated with a UTI during his hospitalization. He finished radiation for his cord compression and his steroids were increased but his symptoms were largely unchanged. The patient also developed dysphagia and odynophagia, likely as a result of radiation. Additionally, he developed urinary retention and altered mental status, which could have been from a variety of causes, including steroids, increased narcotics, or progressive disease. A family meeting was held with palliative care present on ___. Shortly after on ___, the family planned to take the patient home with hospice due to the patient's progressive decline. Further details of his hospitalization are detailed below. ACTIVE ISSUES ============= # Cord compression: Patient presented with a 2 day history of worsening lower extremity weakness and new truncal weakness with normal rectal tone on admission. The differential included tumor progression vs. transient edema from recent spinal XRT vs. too rapid tapering of steroid course vs superimposed infection given UA on admission. Per radiation oncology, no additional repeat imaging was necessary at the time. The patient's steroids were increased from his taper to 4 mg q6h on admission. He continued his radiation therapy and completed the final fraction of radiation therapy on ___. He was switched to 8 mg Decadron BID for ease. Palliative care was consulted given the limited options for treatment, as the patient is not a surgical candidate per ortho at his last admission and is not a candidate for further radiation treatment. The patient was further decreased to 8 mg qAM and 4 mg qPM Decadron on ___, but developed urinary retention on ___ (see below), so steroids were increased back to 4 mg q6h. The patient was discharged on this regimen. # Altered mental status: Patient developed worsening confusion on ___ after initiation of Diluadid PCA.

summary: ___ hx DM, CKD (baseline Cr 1.5), stage IV pancreatic cancer c/b biliary obstruction recently admitted to ___ ___ with cholangitis s/p CBD stent who presents with RLE swelling and pain found to have a DVT. ACUTE ISSUES: # RLE DVT-Patient will need to be anti-coagulated, lovenox proven more effective than other methods of anti-coagulation in cancer patients but as patient has no insurance she will be bridged to coumadin with a heparin gtt. A social work consult was initiated to help with insurance and it was discovered that the patient actually did have insurance. Once this was ascertained, the heparin drip and coumadin were discontinued and she was discharged on lovenox 1.5 mg/kg qdaily for treatment of her DVT. # Leukocytosis-Elevated WBC count to 11 on admission, likely due to DVT, no infectious workup unless patient becomes febrile. The patient had no fevers while admitted and her WBC count trended down during admission so no fever workup was initiated. CHRONIC ISSUES: # Stage IV metastatic pancreatic cancer-Defer to primary oncologist (Dr. ___. A follow up appointment was made for her to see Dr. ___ discharge. # Depression-Stable, continued sertraline, remeron # Anxiety-stable, continued lorazepam PRN # DM-Stable, held glipizide while admitted, insulin sliding scale used for blood glucose control while hospitalized. # Hypothyroidism-Stable, continued levothyroxine # Nausea-Stable, continued prochlorperazine PRN Transitional Issues: -Ms. ___ was set up with ___ nursing services to assist her with lovenox teaching, please ensure she feels comfortable giving herself the injection or has someone at home to help her with her medication.

summary: This is a ___ old male with past medical history significant for alcohol abuse, alcohol withdrawal seizures, insulin dependent diabetes, subdural hematoma status post craniotomy ___, admitted to the ICU for DKA and ETOH withdrawal on phenobarbital taper, now called out to the floor for further DM management and monitoring during alcohol detoxification. ============= ACUTE ISSUES: ============= # EtOH Use Disorder # Alcohol withdrawal Patient does have history of withdrawal seizures in the past. He was loaded with IV phenobarbital in the ICU (___) and started on a PO phenobarbital taper for withdrawal symptoms. While on the floor, his mental status improved to AAOx3 with only mild withdrawal symptoms primarily on and off headache, nausea, and anxiety. He was treated symptomatically with hydroxyzine, clonidine, trazodone PRN. He was also treated with IV thiamine supplementation x 3 days, followed by both folate and thiamine PO. Phenobarbital taper was discontinued (___), when withdrawal symptoms had mostly resolved. Home gabapentin was continued. Social work consulted, however patient is refusing AA, alcohol treatment programs, and ___ rehab. He will be discharged home to live with his friend, who he says is supportive of his efforts to quit drinking. Continue home gabapentin on discharge, as well as trazodone and hydrozyzine PRN for anxiety. #Insulin Dependent Diabetes Patient has history of IDDM and was found to be in DKA on admission, with bicarb of 17, anion gap of 28, glucose 385. Patient does report running out of his insulin and noncompliance with Lantus at home. He was admitted to the MICU for an insulin drip, then transitioned to subQ insulin ___. Anion gap closed ___. ___ was consulted for further management, and insulin regimen was adjusted to Glargine 30U with breakfast, Novolog 15U fixed with meals and Novolog sliding scale on discharge. Most recent A1c is 10.1% in ___. Patient was given lantus, novolog, glucometer, and test strips during this admission, as he lost his supplies at home

summary: ___ with H/O CAD S/P CABG ___ and PCI ___, diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation on rivaroxaban who presented to ___ with exertional chest pain with elevated troponin indicative of a NSTEMI ultimately treated with stent placement to the LCX/OM1 after demonstrable ischemia on stress testing. # NSTEMI: Peak CK-MB 9, peak troponin-T 0.48. Echocardiogram showed borderline LV cavity size with mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with LVEF 35-40%, mild RV hypokinesis, moderate functional mitral regurgitation, mild to moderate pulmonary hypertension and a mildly dilated aortic root. Cardiac catheterization on ___ showed LMCA 50%, occlusion of the native LAD, occlusion of the mid CX, occlusion of the proximal RCA and RPDA, patent LIMA-LAD, with occlusion of all SVGs. Pharmacological vasodilator nuclear stress test ___ showed reversible moderate perfusion defect in LCX into OM1 territory. On ___, a DES was placed in the proximal CX into OM1. He was continued on ASA 81 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg, metoprolol succinate 200 mg. Patient will need clopidogrel for at least ___ year but likely much longer at discretion of cardiologist. Heparin gtt was initially started, but stopped when rivaroxaban resumed following the PCI. Increased atorvastatin dose to 8 0mg for better secondary control. Lisinopril was initially held for ___ and ___ was decreased to 5 mg daily as secondary prevention post-MI and for newly diagnosed left ventricular diastolic heart failure. Digoxin dose was also decreased given ___. Patient was chest pain free on discharge and was cleared by physical therapy. Cardiac rehabilitation was advised. # Anemia: He was anemic throughout hospitalization without obvious source (CT A/P negative for bleed), but was notably iron deficient and guaiac positive, so was started on iron supplementation. He did not require transfusion and hemolysis labs were negative. Hgb at discharge was 7.2. Has next CBC to be drawn on ___ with results sent to PCP (Dr. ___. Workup of anemia was deferred to outpatient

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Right hip fracture <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Right Dynamic Hip Screw <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo M with h/o CABG, systolic HF with EF 25%, CKD who was admitted to ___ with hip fracture after a fall ___ at his nursing home. Pt's family requested transfer to ___ for surgery, accepted by Dr. ___ are consulted for pre-op clearance. . It appears the pt was discharged from ___ just earlier that day after an admission for lethargy, fatigue, ARF, hyperkalemia and a 3 day h/o diarrhea and elevated INR. After discharge the pt was at ___ with 4 episodes of diarrhea and when he stood up to go to bathroom, fell and landed on buttocks on ___. Went back to ___ with R thigh and R shoulder pain, found to have right hip fracture. No h/o head injry or other pain, no LOC. Vitals looked stable at ___. Labs showing leukocytosis and Cr 1.4-1.6 through that admission. We was given gentle IVF's, Coumadin was held. . There was discussion with the daughter re: surgical repair given his advanced dementia, multiple underlying conditions and frequent falls. No shoulder fracture noted on plain film. She also reported 5 episodes of foul smelling, watery diarrhea in past 12 hrs, and was also present on admission ___. During that admission it appears stool Cx and Cdiff were NEGATIVE. . On inteview with family, he was admitted just 2 wks before the admission for ARF/hyperK/diarrhea with decompensated CHF, volume overload, and they switched his Lasix to Bumex; he was peeing out a lot and lost about 30 lbs of what's felt to be water weight. . ROS otherwise: recent coughing/choking and unable to swallow so recently switched to pureed solids at the ___/rehab. REcently had a cold and congestion; also with recent conjunctivitis. Has been more SOB since the CHF exacerbation and family clearly endorsing orthopnea and PND, BLE edema, and decreased exercise tolerance. No CP, palpitations. Vomited x1 last night but not a recurrent issue, no constipation or abd pain. Diarrhea as above. Also unable to pee recently but this may have been in the setting of volume overload and swollen penis per the family. . Re: exercise tolerance, they note that previously he was able to dry the dishes with his wife and most recently at the rehab his son walked him with his walker around the floor, but he was extremely fatigued with this. He'd be unable to do a city block or flight of stairs, and clearly couldn't do yard work. However, unclear if this is limited bc of baseline back/knee arthritic pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - CAD s/p CABG - Chronic systolic heart failure with EF 25% in ___ echo - AFib on Coumadin - CKD stage III - Per family h/o small strokes but no gross stroke per history - HTN - DM, on insulin - Hip fracture - Colon ca s/p colectomy, no chemo, last ___ ___ yrs ago per family - Dementia manifested by going back to previous years, thinking his family is his mother or sister, not knowing where he is, worsening for the past ___ yrs. Will recognize family and names for the most part, but sometimes not - Anemia chronic disease - Ventral hernia - Leg and back arthritis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> 97.6 96.2 128/70 (128-148) 68 (68-100) 99%1.5L (98RA to 99%2L) 8hr -- 0.2 PO / 0.4 IVF / .2 UOP 24 hr -- 0.2 PO / 0.5 IVF / .2 UOP Elderly gentleman, appears frail, awakens easily. Family interpreting at bedside, answer questions but needs question asked a couple times. Eyes with whitish exudate L > R. summary: ___ y/o M with h/o CABG, acute on chronic HF with EF ___, AFib on Coumadin, advanced dementia, DM on insulin, CKD stage III, h/o colon ca s/p colectomy who presents from ___ for evaluation of R hip fracture. #. R Hip fracture: Patient underwent Right Dynamic Hip Screw on ___ without intraoperative complication. His post-op course was complicated by delirium which lasted for approximately 36 hours. His pain was controlled with tylenol and oxycodone. # Encephalopathy/Delirium: Patient had multiple risk factors for delirium- age, dementia, infection, surgery and was acutely delirious after surgery waxing and waning between somnolence and agitation. A geriatrics consult was called. His haldol and aricept were stopped and seroquel 12.5 mg po BID standing and seroquel 12.5 mg BID prn was started. His foley, telemetry leads and pneumoboots were removed. His pain was controlled with tylenol ___ mg po TID. His mental status was returning to baseline on POD#3. #. UTI: Patient was admitted with pansensitive e. coli UTI. Pt was being treated with oral ciprofloxacin briefly but there was concern that it may have been worsening his delirium. Pt was given Bactrim on ___ but developed hyperkalemia and he was ultimately discharged on cefpodoxime 400 mg po BID until ___ for a 14 day total course of antibiotics for complicated UTI. #. Acute on chronic systolic heart failure. Patient appeared volume overloaded on admission and was diuresed with 40 mg lasix iv prior to his surgery. Post-op he did not require additional lasix as his po intake was somewhat limited with his delirium. Patient appeared euvolemic on discharge and was discharged on lasix 20 mg po daily. He was started on metoprolol 12.5 mg po BID while in house for CHF and was discharged on metoprolol succinate 25 mg po daily. An ace inhibitor was not started due to his stage III-IV CKD but may be reconsidered in the outpt setting. . # Aspiration: Pt was noted to have profuse

Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery Lower Extremity Angioplasty/Stent Discharge Instructions MEDICATION: -Continue to take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily - Plavix (Clopidogrel) is a new medication please take once daily to help keep your stent open. -Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed -You make take Tylenol for any post procedure pain or discomfort WHAT TO EXPECT: It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs: -Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows every ___ hours throughout the day and night -Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your legs elevated -It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time -Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals -It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing -To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool softener while taking pain medication ACTIVITIES: -When you go home, you may walk and use stairs -You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, rinse and pat dry) -Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or band aid over the area -No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) -After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity -After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance walked as you can tolerate -No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications
summary: The patient was brought to the operating room on ___ and underwent left popliteal angioplasty with stent and left calf debridement. The procedure was without complication. A heperin drip was started in the hours post operatively to maximize blood flow to the extremities. The patient was closely monitored in the PACU and then transferred to the floor in stable condition where she remained hemodynamically stable. A regular diet was gradually advanced and tolerated well. The patient remained ambulatory with assistance of a walker. She worked with physical therapy who recommended home with physical therapy and ___ for continued wound care. She was discharged to home on POD #1 in stable condition. Follow-up has been arranged with Dr. ___ on ___ at 8:15am to undergo surveillance the left lower extremity. The patient was transported home via the ride.

Cath revealed occluded LAD and RCA with severe sequential lesions in the proximal and mid circumflex, which are calcified. Lesions did not appear acutely thrombotic. Due to NSVT and possible need for rotational artherectomy or hemodynamic support, he was given ASA 325 mg, loaded with Plavix dose of 600 mg and given Amiodarone 150 mg bolus, followed by a 1mg/min drip. summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to ___ on ___ and underwent a diagnostic LLE angiogram for nonhealing toe ulcer. He was found to have a stenotic and diseased proximal SFA, occlusion of the distal SFA and popliteal artery, and occlusion of the left AT and ___ proximally. The peroneal artery was patent with single vessel runoff to the foot. There was reconstitution of the DP and ___ distally. No intervention was performed. He underwent vein mapping for planning of future bypass. He underwent preopertive testing and was seen by cardiology. Cardiology recommended a stress test, which showed a fixed, severe, large perfusion defect involving the RCA or LCx territory, and no ischemic changes acutely with exercise. He was cleared for surgery, and should remain on his beta blocker, statin and aspirin pre-operatively. He was added to the OR schedule with Dr. ___ next week, and he was discharged in stable condition. Discharge Medications: 1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 2. Atenolol 50 mg PO DAILY 3. text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> inability to speak, weakness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The pt is a ___ yo man well known to the stroke service with a PMH of multiple medical problems including prior infarctions, Afib and AS who was transferred from an OSH as Code Stroke. Per his daughters, he was last seen well around 7: 45 pm when he developed abrupt onset inability to speak and stopped using his R side. He was taken to an OSH where a head CT was obtained that did not show an acute infarct. He was then transferred here for further evaluation. In the ED he was awake, not consistently following commands, aphasic, and with a R gaze deviation. He was plegic on the R arm but moving the L spontaneously. His ___ stroke scale was 12. He was taken emergently to CT and CTA. This showed a large thrombus occluding the L ICA. These findings were discussed with the family who stated that the patient was DNR/DNI and did not want to live like a vegetable, but prior to this evening, he had been independent in most ADLS. They therefore decided that they would try IA tPA in hopes that he might retain some function. The Interventional Neuroradiology was contacted but after reviewing the CT perfusion, it was felt that the area of infarction was so large that IA tPA would not increase the chance of re-perfusion. In regards to his stroke risk factors, his last HbA1c was checked in ___ and was 6.3. He was admitted earlier this week reportedly for chest pain. A discharge summary from this admission is not available yet. During his hospital course, his TSH was checked and found to be 1.8. His LDL was 46 and his HDL was 45. A TTE was also done which showed an EF of 50-55%, severe AS and moderate TR was well as Diastolic dysfunction. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> daughter unable to provide, stating it's all in the computer. summary: In the ED he was awake, not consistently following commands, aphasic, and with a R gaze deviation. He was plegic on the R arm but moving the L spontaneously. His ___ stroke scale was 12. He was taken emergently to CT and CTA. This showed a large thrombus occluding the L ICA. These findings were discussed with the family who stated that the patient was DNR/DNI and did not want to live like a vegetable, but prior to this evening, he had been independent in most ADLS. They therefore decided that they would try IA tPA in hopes that he might retain some function. The likelihood of recovery was explained as low with or without procedure, however they decided to proceed with angiography. The Interventional Neuroradiology was contacted but after reviewing the CT perfusion studies felt that he did not have much viable penumbral tissue that could be salvaged with IA therapy. Over the subsequent day, the patient's cardiovascular and hemodynamic status declined. There was evidence of myocardial infarction and the patient became hypotensive and bradycardic. The goals of care were re-addressed with the family on ___ and the patient was made cmo. Palliative care was consulted and the patient's comfort was maximized. Her became tachypneic and a morphien drip was started. He passed away shortly thereafter on ___.

summary: The patient with history of duodenal adenoma was admitted to the HPB Surgical Service for elective partial duodenectomy. On ___, the patient underwent D3/D4 regional duodenectomy with primary duodenojejunostomy anastomosis and open cholecystectomy with common bile duct exploration, which went well without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor NPO with NGT, on IV fluids, with a foley catheter, and epidural catheter for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable. Neuro: The patient received Hydromorphone/Bupivacaine via epidural catheter with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirrometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO/NGT with IV fluids. On POD # 4 patient underwent upper GI study, which was negative for leak. Diet was advanced to clears ans was well tolerated. Diet was progressively advanced to regular on POD # 5. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary. Electrolytes were routinely followed, and repleted when necessary. ID: No issues Endocrine: No issues Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined routinely; no transfusions were required. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the

We generally recommend taking an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while taking narcotic pain medication. -Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and Ibuprofen etc. -If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), or Plavix (clopidogrel), or Aspirin, prior to your injury, you may safely resume taking this when cleared by your Neurosurgeon. -Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit. -Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while at home, unless you have been instructed not to.

He was transferred to the floor on ___ where he remained stable. On ___ he underwent a diagnostic cerebral angiogram to evaluate the R ICA. The angio was stable. He was discharged home on ___. At the time of discharge he was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating without difficulty, afebrile with stable vital signs.

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ after his abdominal wound was open in clinic and he drained 400cc of old seroma. He was intermittently spiking temperatures overnight, with temps as high as ___. He was pan-cultured at this time, including blood culture, urine culture, and chest x-ray. His chest xray did not show a pneumonia and urine culture was positive for 10,000 - 100,000 of GNRs. A abdominal u/s was performed to assess for paracentesis but no fluid was seen in his abdomen. He was started on empiric vanc/zosyn on ___. He was mildly nauseated during the day. He continued to be intermittently febrile overnight and his wound VAC was taken down and sent for culture. It grew GPCs in pairs and clusters. On ___bd/pelvis was obtained to look for intra-abdominal processes. The CT scan showed a small 2.8x1.5 seroma under his inguinal incision. Overnight, A repeat blood culture and urine culture was sent ___, which showed no growth. His wound VAC was replaced on ___ and has had minimal output. He was ambulating, and tolerated a regular diet. He was ready for discharge home on ___.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Diarrhea, nausea, vomiting <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with history of hiatal hernia s/p repair, GERD, IBS who presented to ED with one day of nausea and several episodes of vomiting. Patient is in town visiting her daughter from ___ and developed URI symptoms a few days ago, with congestion and cough productive of yellow, non bloody phlegm. Reports some intermittent chills but no fevers at home. On the day of presentation patient felt her URI symptoms worsened and she lost her appetite. Around 6pm she felt very nauseous and began having persistent vomiting. Patient estimates she vomited ___ times, mostly bile. Patient reports similar symptoms in the past related to her hiatal hernia. She also endorses worsening of her chronic diarrhea (see below). With regards to patient's GI history, she was diagnosed with IBS ___ years ago and has been debilitated by her symptoms. She wakes up daily with cramps and has diarrhea. She then will intermittently experience cramps/diarrhea throughout the day. She has also struggled with severe GERD in the setting of hiatal hernia and occasionally has bout of severe reflux which trigger nausea and uncontrollable vomiting. Patient says she is nearly homebound because of her symptoms. She had a repair ___ years ago which was complicated by esophageal perforation, but unfortunately the surgery failed and her hernia returned. Patient's current episode is very similar to attacks she has had in the past with her hiatal hernia, however she also describes acute worsening of her diarrhea, which does not typically happen. No hematemesis or black/bloody stool. In the ED, initial vitals were: T 96.2, P 92, BP 176/86, RR 16, O2 100% RA. Exam notable for soft abdomen, diffusely tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Labs revealed WBC 14.9, bicarb 12, lactate 3.4, cr 0.7. AST and AP mildly elevated at 45 and 115 respectively, otherwise LFT's wnl. Lipase normal. Patient had CXR which showed hiatal hernia, but no e/o PNA. CT A/P w/contrast showed  Loss of normal haustra throughout the colon with mucosal thickening and hyperemia, compatible with pancolitis, possibly due to inflammatory bowel disease. Colonic diverticulosis is noted without evidence of acute diverticulitis. Patient was given Cipro/Flagyl, 1L IVF, Pantoprazole, IV Morphine x 2, ofran x 2 and admitted to medicine for further management. Prior to transfer patient's repeat lactate 1.6, VBG 7.39/___/16. On the floor, patient still quite nauseous with some pain in her abdomen, which she associates with retching. No fevers or chills. summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of hiatal hernia s/p repair, GERD, ___ years of IBS with debilitating diarrhea in the morning, who presented to ED with a few days of URI symptoms and then one day of nausea and several episodes of vomiting with CT showing pancolitis. Her symptoms resolved quickly over the next few days with ofran, IV Ativan, Cipro and Flagyl. All stool studies were negative and unrevealing. GI was consulted and felt presentation was infectious. If inflammatory was still considered, recommended outpatient colonoscopy. Her hospital stay was uneventful overall and she was discharged with follow up with her ___ providers for continued management of her IBS. ACTIVE PROBLEMS: ============================= #DIARRHEA WITH LEUKOCYTOSIS AND PANCOLITIS: Patient presented with severe nausea/vomiting in addition to diarrhea with CT e/o pancolitis. Differential included viral vs. bacterial gastroenteritis (shigella, c.diff can cause colitis), vs, inflammatory bowel disease. Reassuringly, lactate improved s/p fluids. CDIFF, NORO NEGATIVE. It seemed that the colitis was infectious, either viral or bacterial, since it improved with time and antibiotics. - GI did not want to scope. Colonoscopy too risky with current inflammation, and they would not do a flex sig with biopsy because a full colonoscopy should really be done to fully rule out IBD in the entire colon. - Treated with Cipro/Flagyl until infectious studies returned negative - CONTINUED PO omeprazole - ___ records found to be really just significant for chronic IBS, had had work up for IBD and not been positive in the past. #NAUSEA/VOMITING: RESOLVING AT DISCHARGE Unclear if related to the pancolitis found on imaging. The patient reported that she had a developing URI for the last few days, and often those same viruses can cause GI upset as well

summary: The patient was admitted on ___ and, later that day, was taken to the operating room by Dr. ___ R ___ without complication. Please see operative report for details. Postoperatively the patient had apnea and despite using CPAP, developed respiratory failure and required intubation. She had some ST depressions on her EKG at this same time. Cardiac enzymes were sent and were negative. She was transferred to the ___ and was admitted to the ICU. She was extubated on POD 1 and had no further respiratory distress. She was treated with CPAP at night. An ECHO was obtained and showed no wall motion abnormalities and a EF of 75%. Repeat enzymes were negative. She was transferred out of the ICU to a telemetry bed. She had no significant abnormalities on her telemetry. She did not have any chest pain or SOB after the ICU. The patient received IV antibiotics for 24 hours postoperatively, as well as lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. Starting on POD 2, the patient was placed in a CPM machine with range of motion that started at ___ degrees of flexion before being increased to 90 degrees as tolerated.*** The drain was removed without incident on POD#2. The Foley catheter was removed without incident. The surgical dressing was removed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean, dry, and intact without erythema or purulent drainage. While in the hospital, the patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was stable, and the patient's pain was adequately controlled on a PO regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. The patient was discharged to rehabilitation in a stable condition. The patient's weight-bearing status was WBAT. The patient is to continue using the CPM machine advancing as tolerated to ___

summary: Mr. ___ presented to the ___ on ___ after a fall while intoxicated. He was evaluated and found to have a left ankle fracture. He was admitted, consented, and prepped for surgery. On ___ he was taken to the operating room and underwent an ORIF of his left ankle. He tolerated the procedure well, was extubated, transferred to the recovery room, and then to the floor. On the floor he was seen by physical therapy to improve his strength and mobility. He was also seen by medicine due to his tachycardia and withdrawal from alcohol, and placed on a CIWA scale. In addition, he was seen by the addiction nurse as well as social work. Over the next few days he had some confusion determined to be related to alcohol withdrawal, which resolved over the subsequent days. On ___, his hct dropped to 25.6, and receiced 2 units of PRBCs, and his hct responded nicely to the high ___. He was also seen by physical therapy during his stay, and required several days of training with crutches to enable his non-weight bearing status. The rest of his hospital stay was uneventful with his lab data and vital signs within normal limits and his pain controlled, he is being discharged today in stable condition.

summary: # Low back pain: Acute on chronic lumbosacral paraspinal tenderness consisent with muscle strain. No focal neurological findings, constitutional symptoms, history of trauma, malignancy or osteoporosis, or infectious risk from IVDU or immunosuppresion. Patients pain was well-controlled with PO dilaudid and cyclobenzaprine overnight; she was switch to naproxen, valium and acetaminophen with oxycodone for breakthrough pain. Evaluated by ___ who cleared her for discharge and recommended outpatient physical therapy. She will also need to follow-up with her outpatient spine specialist. # Syncope: Likely vagal in the setting of extreme pain. No history of prior syncope or palpitations. No evidence of prolonged QT on EKG. Patient reports experiencing a similar feeling from the pain when she attempted to stand up in the ED. No events on telemetry. CT head and cervical spine were negative. # Vitamin D deficiency: Continued home vitamin D, calcium  multivitamin # Anemia: Patient reports a history of anemia. Hematocrit stable as an inpatient. She should follow up with her PCP. # Prophylaxis: The patient received heparin products. # Code: Full code

summary: The patient was admitted to the hospital with right lower abdominal pain. Upon admission, she was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, and underwent imaging. A cat scan of the abdomen was done which showed acute appendicitis. Based on these findings, the patient was taken to the operating room where she underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy. The operative course was stable with minimal blood loss. The patient was extubated after the procedure and monitored in the recovery room. The post-operative course has been stable. She has resumed a regular diet and her pain has been controlled with oral analgesia. Her vital signs have been stable and she has been afebrile. She has reported mild nausea with food, but has had no episodes of vomitting. She has been voiding without difficulty. On POD #2 the patient was discharged home in stable condition. Post-operative instructions were reviewed and an appointment for follow-up was made with the acute care service.

Patient has been having left chest pressure with exertion for ___ years now, always occurs with morning walk and goes away with rest; patient has never taken nitro before. Today, after morning walk, pressure occured as usual, but did not resolve with rest. Pain occurred across entire chest but was more severe on the left with radiation to his left arm and teeth. He also experienced diaphoresis, was very short of breath, and had some nausea/vomiting. Shortly after the pain began, he began to feel lightheaded, then son noticed garbled speech, followed by extremity shaking and eventually syncope. Patient was out for five minutes before EMS showed up and placed oxygen on him, at which point he woke up. He has never had garbled speech or syncope before. When EMS arrived, he received aspirin 325 mg and EKG showed deep anterior ST depressions in LAD territory. In the ED, initial vitals were: 90 141/80 16 99% RA. He denied current chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. Labs and imaging significant for trop 0.03, creat 2.1. EKG sinus tachycardia with left axis and V3-6 ST depressions. Patient was started on a heparin drip with bolus. Cardiology was consulted and recommended admission to ___. Vitals on transfer were 97.9 Pulse: 67, RR: 18, BP: 128/87, Rhythm: afib, O2Sat: 99. On arrival to the floor, patient felt comfortable and remained chest pain free. He has had no more nausea, diaphoresis, lightheadedness, garbled speech or syncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Dyslipidemia, Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: - Atrial fibrillation - Aortic stenosis, ___ 0.8 cm2 ___ - CAD s/p silent MI (though pt denies this) 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: ESRD secondary to hypertensive nephropathy s/p ECD transplant on ___ and s/p nephrostomy tube placements, most recently on ___ had been on PD prior to transplant - Gout - BPH s/p TURP - PVD s/p L renal stents - Hiatal hernia - s/p right TKR - Hemorroidectomy - s/p L carpal tunnel release x 2 - ___ UTI, MDR E. coli - ___ bacteremia, MDR E. coli <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> HTN in multiple family members. ___ creatinine in several children. summary: PRIMARY REASON FOR HOSPITALIATION: ___ with coronary artery disease presents with crushing left-sided chest pain and syncopal episode, found to have a NSTEMI secondary to strain from critical AS. ACTIVE DIAGNOSES: # Aortic Stenosis: Patient had progressively worsening aortic stenosis, recent valve area on TTE ___ was 0.8, and repeat TTE this admission showed valve area 0.5. Had been medically managed thus far. Patient and family say they have never discussed with cardiologist aortic valve replacement options. Critical aortic stenosis can explain syncope as well as strain leading to NSTEMI. Syncope is poor prognostic indicator, and indication for AVR. Patient was evaluated by cardiac surgery, who felt he would be a good candidate for AVR. Patient and family have discussed with Dr. ___ into ___ study, risks vs. benefits. He will be discharged to rehab and get readmitted in a week when his transplanted kidney may tolerate more contrast to get workup and randomization into ___ study. # NSTEMI: Patient has been having stable angina symptoms for ___ years now in the setting of worsening aortic stenosis. Had an abnormal stress echo in ___ and per family, was going to go for cath at some point in the future. On day of admission, angina symptoms did not resolve with rest, and he was found to have lateral ST depressions on EKG as well as troponin elevation to 0.03. Patient had cath in ___ that showed clean coronaries. NSTEMI could be from CAD or from strain secondary to severe aortic stenosis. Was seen on last TTE ___ to have critical AS with valve area 0.8. Was plavix loaded on admission, and 3 sets of cardiac enzymes stable. Cardiac cath showed no significant coronary stenoses, but TTE showed worsening critical AS, valve area now 0.5. Heparin gtt was stopped after cath and plavix discontinued. Patient was switched from crestor to atorvastatin 80mg daily while in house but when CAD was found to be not severe, was discharged back on crestor. He remained on ASA

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Morphine / Hayfever <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abdominal Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Paracentesis (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> TREATMENT REGIMEN: s/p nephrectomy and Whipple for metastatic disease, progression of disease off therapy currently CC: ___ Distension HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS: This is a ___ yo M with metastatic renal cell carcinoma with a porta hepatis mass causing portal vein compression and portal hypertension leading to recurrent ascites. The patient presents from home with 1 week of progressive abdominal swelling and one day of fatigue. The patient has had this before and underwent a paracentesis on ___. Fluid studies showed an ascites albumin of 1.0 and a SAAG of 1.8 consistent with portal hypertension. The cytology was negative for malignant cells. Since that time, the patient has noticed some abdominal distension, however, an abdominal US on ___ did not show enough ascites to tap. For the last week, the patient has noted increased abdominal girth. He also noted some fatigue. He denies fevers, chills, abdominal pain. No nausea or vomiting. He endorses a long history of early satiety. He says that he recently finished a course of ABX for a pneumonia, but now his breathing is stable. No diarrhea or dysuria. No rashes. He has a h/o GI bleeding, but has not noticed any recent blood in his stool. In the ED, vitals were stable. LFTs showed AST>ALT and elevated alk phos consistent with previous. Synthetic function intact, except for low albumin. An abdominal US showed moderate ascites, splenomegaly, and poor visualization of the left portal vein. It is unclear if the patient is cirrhotic. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: per HPI <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY - ___: presented with hematuria, right kidney mass was found. Underwent nephrectomy and adrenalectomy which showed clear cell carcinoma, grade I-II without involvement of the adrenal gland - ___: presented with black stools, workup showed a pancreatic mass. Pt underwent Whipple procedure which revealed metastatic renal cell carcinoma to the pancreas and duodenal wall. Other areas of metastatic disease include pulmonary nodules and pancreatic nodules in the body of the pancreas. - ___: Pt was admitted to a local hospital in their ICU for an acute GI bleed. He had developed melena, and when he went to the hospital, he was found to have a hemoglobin of 6. He was transfused at least six units of blood while in the ICU and underwent an EGD and colonoscopy followed by a capsule endoscopy ___ found that he had blood adjacent to the diverticulum and the jejunum but no active bleeding. A small nonbleeding AVM was also seen in the area of the jejunum. No active bleeding, however, was seen any of his gastroenterology procedures. - in ___, pt was hospitalized at ___ at which time he presented with mahogany colored stools. Source was thought to be a jejunal AVM vs erosion from metastatic jejunal mass. An OSH EGD was negative to jejunum and colonoscopy only showed diverticulosis. Enteroscopy demonstrated no clear source of the bleed. Hct trended up during admission. After much discussion, it was decided to pursue radiation treatment to the jejunal mass. He preferred to receive this near his home, with Dr. ___. Pt completed radiation treatment and tolerated it well. - ___: CT shows interval increase in size of pancreatic tail lesion, but interval decrease in size of lesion in the pancreatic body. Multiple pulmonary nodules stable. - ___: CT torso shows subtle increase in pancreatic lesion, stable pulmonary nodules - ___: admitted to ___ with GI bleed, negative ___, transfused 1 u pRBCs - ___: CT torso shows CT torso shows continued increase in pancreatic lesion with extension to ampulla, stable pulmonary nodules PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - Metastatic renal cell carcinoma, as above - GI bleed due to AVMs - Anemia - Permanent pacemaker for bradycardia - Total knee replacement ___ - Diabetes mellitus <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mom with colon cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission <PHYSICAL EXAM> -========= VS: 97.7, 132/62, 87, 20, 100% RA GENERAL: NAD HEENT: NC/AT, EOMI, PERRL, MMM CARDIAC: RRR, normal S1  S2, without murmurs, S3 or S4 LUNG: clear to auscultation, no wheezes or rhonchi ABD: distended, dull to percussion, shifting dullness, non-tender, normal BS EXT: L>R lower extremity edema PULSES: 2DP pulses bilaterally NEURO: AO x 3, CN II-XII intact SKIN: No stigmata of chronic liver disease <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: -======== ___ 05: 55PM BLOOD WBC-4.2 RBC-3.63* Hgb-9.1* Hct-29.6* MCV-82 MCH-25.1* MCHC-30.7* RDW-19.8* RDWSD-56.0* Plt ___ ___ 05: 55PM BLOOD Neuts-82.9* Lymphs-7.9* Monos-6.5 Eos-1.2 Baso-1.0 Im ___ AbsNeut-3.46 AbsLymp-0.33* AbsMono-0.27 AbsEos-0.05 AbsBaso-0.04 ___ 05: 55PM BLOOD Glucose-309* UreaN-11 Creat-0.9 Na-133 K-4.1 Cl-99 HCO3-22 AnGap-16 ___ 05:
summary: ___ with metastatic RCC causing portal HTN who presented with weakness and increased abdominal distention and lower extremity edema for 1 week. He did not have any F/N/V nor abdominal pain. LFTs were ok. He had a paracentesis that was consistent with portal hypertension and liver dysfunction. Imaging was c/w cirrhosis and stable to slightly increased disease burden. While he was here, he had transient elevated LFTs and one blood culture bottle grew Prevotella sp. This improved quickly with CTX/Flagl. ERCP and ___ were consulted and since the patient improved quickly and his clinical picture did not entirely fit with cholangitis, the patient preferred to have his procedure done as an outpatient. # GNR bacteremia Routine bld cx ___ GNR, subsequent BCx ___ prior to abx NGTD but pt was lethargic and improved after abx thus presumed true bacteremia. Source likely biliary due to bili rising to 2.1 but this occurred after initiation of antibiotics. Other source is gut translocation from portal mass invading jejunal anastomosis. - Empiric osyn ___ - ___ for GNR bacteremia - Narrowed ___ to ceftriaxone/flagyl for Prevotella species - ___ changed to PO Cipro/Flagyl and will continue for ___nd on his last day has f/u with oncology - ERCP deferred to outpatient per patient/family preference # Ascites Ppt underwent his ___ paracentesis ___, cytology again negative. WBC did not meet criteria for peritonitis, cx NGTD. Ab distention improved. He was started Lasix/aldactone with improvement in his ascites and in his lower extremity edema. Likely source from portal HTN. # Cirrhosis/portal HTN This is a new finding on recent U/S also has splenomegaly. Likely due to large porta hepatis mass narrowing portal vein also has intrahepatic met and further may have developed. primarily causing ascites, INR stable, bili mildly elevated. albumin low but also nutritional component. Biopsy deferred as it is risky es

summary: ___ year-old woman who presented from her assisted living facility with chest pain. Chest radiograph showed some bibasilar opacities that could be consistent with infection as well as findings of pulmonary edema with associated small pleural effusions. Cardiac enzymes were negative. She was started on levofloxacin treatment for pneumonia. Her chest pain and mild hypoxia resolved by hospital day 2. On the day of discharge, the patient was found to have mild confusion and agitation early in the morning. This improved later in the morning. She was quite insistent about going home. The patient's daughter said that she would work together with the ___ staff to make sure someone would look in on her with increased frequency. The patient and daughter both understood that we preferred that the patient stay for one more day of observation to ensure improvement in her mild delirium, but they remained insistent about being discharged and understood that it was not the most preferred course of action and that it would put the patient at increased risk of harming herself. PROBLEM LIST # Chest pain. Pt was admitted with chest pain that she reported began under left breast and then migrated to under right breast, relieved with tylenol. EKG did not show ischemic ST changes. Cardiac enzymes were negative x 3. She had another episode of chest pain during hospital stay that also resolved with tylenol; EKG was unchanged. CXR showed bibasilar opacities likely representing atelectasis vs infection. She was treated for CAP with levofloxacin for a planned course of 5 days. She was not febrile throughout hospital stay; WBC peaked at 11. Urine legionella was negative. Blood cultures showed NGTD but final results were pending by time of discharge. # Pulmonary edema: CXR also showed mild to moderate interstitial pulmonary edema with small pleural effusions. She received 10mg iv lasix during night of admission. It was difficult to determine how much urine output she had from this because she was incontinent. She was initially on ___ oxygen by NC but was weaned off it by time of discharge, satting mid

summary: Upon presentation, the patient was therapeutically anticoagulated with heparin. Non-invasive studies revealed poor distal waveforms on the left with an ABI of 0. CTA with runoff demonstrated an occluded left common iliac and left superficial femoral artery. On ___, he was taken to the operating room for further management of his LLE ischemia. In the operating room, the patient underwent a left groin cutdown. The patient underwent thrombectomy, followed by angiography revealing complex stenosis of the left common and external iliac arteries. A left common/external iliac stent was then placed, improving flow through the left iliac system. LLE distal angiogram demonstrated a persistent SFA occlusion not amendable at the time to endovascular management. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was continued on therapeutic anticoagulation with IV heparin. On POD1 he was started on his home medications. Given his continued occlusion of the SFA and poor blood flow to the LLE, he was given aspirin, plavix, and clopidogrel and started on Coumadin. On POD2 he was discharged with follow-up with Dr. ___ his ___ visit and to discuss further management. The patient's coumadin will be followed by his primary care physician.

summary: ___ with stage IV pancreatic Adeno with mets to bone, LN s/p whipple with recurrence, h/o PE and chronic pain, who presents with acute RLE radiculopathy concurrently with her chronic lumbar back pain. Acute RLE Radiculopathy/Lumbar back pain Possible Vertebral metastasis Acute radicular pain consistent with nerve impingement/inflammation at the root. The location of her pain suggests L2-4 region. Her exam findings correlate with the findings of her recent MRI ___ showing abnormal signal at L2-3 suspicious for metastatic dz. She has no signs or symptoms of infection or cord compression. Pain control was maximized, and MRI was ordered to evaluate possible metastatic spread and need for palliative XRT but showed foraminal narrowing with abutment of the L4-L5 nerve roots which likely explained her symptoms. The previously observed changed that were c/f mets appeared to be more c/w hemangiomas. Her pain improved significantly with increased pain control and she was discharged home with Fentanyl increased to 25mcg/hr, oxycodone with more frequent dosing, tylenol standing and gabapentin. She was able to ambulate w/o assistance in the hospital and was cleared by ___. Patient d/c home to f/u with her outpatient providers. Metastatic pancreatic AC: now off chemotherapy due to side effects. Follow-up with Dr. ___ as outpatient. HTN, benign: Continued amlodipine, ASA GERD: Continued Omeprazole h/p PE: No longer on systemic AC, heparin sc was given for VTE ppx Mild Malnutrition: soft diet. Continued home pancreatic enzymes. Tubefeeds were held while in-patient, as pt was taking in tolerable amounts of PO.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> Cipro <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Right knee laceration <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Right knee ID ___, ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ male presents with right lower extremity cellulitis. Patient fell off a bike 4 days ago. He suffered a laceration just superior to the right patella. He was seen at an emergency department and received irrigation and was sent home on oral antibiotics. 24 hours later he developed extensive redness and pain around that area. He was having increasing difficulty walking. He saw his primary care doctor who gave him IM ceftriaxone and sent him home on a different set of oral antibiotics. After he got worse, he presented to our emergency department for further evaluation. He had the stitches removed from the initial emergency department visit, underwent irrigation in the emergency department and was placed in observation overnight for IV antibiotics. He believes that the redness is getting better however he still has extensive redness and pain. He was seen by the ED observation attending this morning who was concerned that he may require a washout. Patient is able to range the knee to approximately 90 degrees of flexion without significant discomfort. He denies any numbness or paresthesias. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -ADHD <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> nc <PHYSICAL EXAM> Right lower extremity: - Soft, non-tender thigh and leg - Fires ___ - SILT S/S/SP/DP/T distributions - 1 ___ pulses, WWP - Improving erythema of thigh and calf <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> adderall <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 2. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 4. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain 5. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Right knee laceration <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY: - You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal to feel tired or washed out after surgery, and this feeling should improve over the first few days to week. - Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times. ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING: -Weightbearing as tolerated right lower extremity, no deep knee bending MEDICATIONS: 1) Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is an over the counter medication. 2) Add [] as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean off this medication in 1 week or sooner. This is an example on how to wean down: Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day, then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day. Then continue with Tylenol for pain. 3) Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic medication. 4) Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 5) Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy. 6) Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers. 7) Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians at discharge. 8) Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed to stop by your surgeon. ANTICOAGULATION: - Please take aspirin 325 mg daily for 4 weeks ANTIBIOTICS: - Finish your home dose of antibiotics (Keflex) WOUND CARE: - You may shower 3 days after surgery. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks. - Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out at your 2-week follow up appointment. - Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape. - If you have a splint in place, splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless otherwise instructed. Do NOT get splint wet. DANGER SIGNS: Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the emergency department if you experience any of the following: - Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications - Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning changes in your incision - Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of sensation - Fever ___ 101.4 - Shaking chills - Chest pain - Shortness of breath - Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, medications down - Any other medical concerns FOLLOW UP: Please follow up with your Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr.
summary: The patient presented to the emergency department and was evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found to have a right knee laceration and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for right knee ID which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is weightbearing as tolerated in the right lower extremity, and will be discharged on aspirin 325 mg daily for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

Renal consult for new renal infarcts suggested possible cardioembolic disease vs renal artery dissection vs intra-renal thrombosis vs acute renal lobar nephronia, and recommends continuing anticoagulation, sending coagulability workup, rechecking UA/UCX, and continuing empiric antibiotics. Last positive culture was in setting of lithotripsy, grew out enterococcus sensitive to ampicillin and ceftriaxone but not to cephalosporins. HEENT: NCAT, EOMI (wandering eyes, at baseline), pupils equal and round but nonreactive to light (baseline). Sclera anicteric. MMM. OP clear. Neck: supple, some L-sided submandibular fullness, JVP 10 (but prior notes also document JVD w/o other e/o cardiac dysfunction). Lungs: CTAB, no wheezes/rales/crackles CV: RRR, normal S1 and S2, II/VI systolic murmur loudest at LUSB. Abdomen: Minimally distended, soft, no focal tenderness to percussion and palpation, normoactive bs. No CVA tenderness, no suprapubic tenderness. Ext: WWP. 2 R DP, 1 L DP. No edema. Nephrostomy sites c/d/i and nontender. No skin breakdown. Proximal RUE palpable cord. Neuro: Minimal blink to threat in any direction, b/l UE with increased tone, L>>R and held in flexion, b/l ___ (proximal and distal) with increased tone, sometimes answers questions, calls for mama when mother ___ in room. . Discharge Exam: PHYSICAL EXAM: Vitals: 99.1, 97.6, 115/85, 73, 18, 98%RA No I/O today, 24 h 2.54L/incontinent many times and 5 soft brown stools Weight: 47.8 kg bed, from 43 kg yesterday
summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with a h/o Hirshprung's disease s/p two reversed colostomies with chronic constipation; ___ nephrolithiasis c/b urosepsis treated with nephrostomy tube placement and s/p laser lithotripsy, bilateral ureteral stent placement, and nephrostomy tube removal on ___ PICC-associated DVT from the ___ hospitalization for the urosepsis; cerebral palsy c/b epilepsy and mental retardation; and stroke w/L hemiparesis. She presented from ___ to ___ with abdominal pain and was transferred to ___ after CT showed new wedge-shaped areas in upper pole of both kidneys and lower pole of left kidney concerning for possible renal infarcts which were determined to most likely be post-nephrostomy tube / pyelo changes. . Aside from her chronic issues, we actively managed the following: # Abdominal pain, likely due to combination of severe constipation (large stool burden) and mild dysmenorrhea. This improved with rectal bisacodyl and oral docusate/miralax/senna, as well as occasional tylenol. . # CT renal findings of possible Renal infarcts. Given absence of leukocytosis, absence of SIRS, relatively well appearance, and supratherapeutic INR (4.4) at presentation, as well as discussions with urology, renal, interventional radiology, and radiology services, the CT findings seemed more likely to be due to her recent urological procedures and resolving pyelonephritis. She did however get vancomycin/ceftriaxone, which were changed over to a 7-day outpatient course of amoxicillin which will complete a total of 14 days given history of ureteral stents / possible pyelo. Urine cultures from ___ returned at 36 hours with <10,000 gram positive cocci (possibly residual enterococcus) and <10,000 mixed gram negatives. . ### TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ###: - Bowel regimen (docusate, bisacodyl, senna, miralax) will need to be continued indefinitely; severe constipation history - consider follow up with congenital heart service for enlarged aortic root diameter

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Oxycodone <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> ERCP stent exchange <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ERCP with stent exchage <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ The patient is a ___ year old female with ___ medical problems including bile duct obstruction s/p multiple ERCP with stent placement, gastroparesis s/p gastrojejunostomy, and carcinoid tumor causing gastric outlet obstruction s/p partial jejunal resection with jejunostomy who had a recent admission in ___ for cholangitis during which time a plastic stent was placed. She had a repeat ERCP on ___ that was aborted due to food in the stomach. She was discharged to rehab where she has resided until today. She was brought back for repeat ERCP with stent exchange. She underwent a successful procedure which demonstrated sludge and stone fragments on dilation. She had her previous stent removed and a biliary drain placed. ROS: Per HPI, mild nausea post procedure, no pain currently. 10 point ROS otherwise negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -right femur fracture in ___ - s/p ORIF -bile duct obstruction s/p multiple ERCP with stent placement -mitral regurgitation s/p bioprosthetic mitral valve replacement -atrial fibrillation/flutter -seizure disorder - has not had seizure in over ___ -peptic ulcer disease -gastroparesis s/p gastrojejunostomy -hyperlipidemia -carcinoid tumor causing gastric outlet obstruction s/p partial jejunal resection with jejunostomy -s/p CCY -iron deficient anemia -cataract -perforated diverticulitis s/p partial colectomy -asthma -hx of C. difficile -incisional hernia <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Heart disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Exam: VS: 98.0, 111/69, 70, 18, 96% on RA Gen: NAD HEENT: anicteric CV: irregular rhythm, normal rate Resp: CTAB GI: Soft, mild epigastric tenderness, colostomy (bag filled with gas) SKin: no active rash Psych: Mood/affect appropriate Neuro: Alert, interactive Discharge Exam: Gen: Elderly, NAD HEENT: anicteric, MMM CV: Irregular GI: Soft, NT, ND - colostomy with gas <PERTINENT RESULTS> ERCP: Findings: Esophagus: Limited exam of the esophagus was normal Stomach: Limited exam of the stomach was normal Duodenum: Limited exam of the duodenum was normal Major Papilla: The previously placed plastic biliary stent was found in good position at the major papilla. The plastic stent was removed successfully using a rat tooth forceps. Evidence of a previous sphincterotomy was noted in the major papilla. Cannulation: Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and deep with a balloon using a free-hand technique. Contrast medium was injected resulting in complete opacification. Fluoroscopic Interpretation of Biliary Tree: Scout film revealed the previous biliary stent and previous surgical clips in the right upper quadrant. The common bile duct, common hepatic duct, right and left hepatic ducts, and biliary radicles were filled with contrast and well visualized. There were filling defects that appeared like sludge and stone fragments in the common bile duct. A severe diffuse dilation was also seen with the CBD measuring 20 mm. Fluoroscopic Interpretation: I supervised the acquisition and interpretation of the fluoroscopic images. The quality of the fluoroscopic images was good. Total fluoroscopy time: 15 minutes. Procedures: Balloon sphincteroplasty was performed successfully. A 12mm wire-guided CRE balloon was introduced and the diameter was progressively increased to 13.5 mm successfully for dilation of the biliary sphincter. A large amount of sludge and stone fragments were extracted successfully using multiple sweeps of the extraction balloon. A 5cm by ___ double pigtail biliary biliary stent was placed successfully in the right main hepatic duct. Impression: Scout film revealed the previous biliary stent and surgical clips in the right upper quadrant. The previous plastic biliary stent was in good position at the major papilla. This was removed using a rat tooth forceps. Previous sphincterotomy was noted at the major papilla. Successful biliary duct cannulation using the balloon. There were filling defects that appeared like sludge and stone fragments in the common bile duct. Severe diffuse dilation was seen with the CBD measuring 20 mm. Balloon sphincteroplasty was performed with a 12 mm balloon that was progressively increased to 13.5 mm for dilation of the biliary sphincter. A large amount of sludge and stone fragments were extracted successfully using multiple sweeps of the extraction balloon. A 5cm by ___ double pigtail biliary biliary stent was placed successfully in the right main hepatic duct. Otherwise normal ERCP to third part of the duodenum. Recommendations: Admit to hospital for post-procedure observation. Hydration with IV fluids as tolerated. Okay to resume solid food tonight. Follow for response and complications. If any abdominal pain, fever, jaundice, gastrointestinal bleeding please call ERCP fellow on call (___). Repeat ERCP in 2 months for stent removal and further treatment.
summary: Ms. ___ The patient is a ___ year old female with ___ medical problems including bile duct obstruction s/p multiple ERCP with stent placement, gastroparesis s/p gastrojejunostomy, and carcinoid tumor causing gastric outlet obstruction s/p partial jejunal resection with jejunostomy who had a recent admission in ___ for cholangitis during which time a plastic stent was placed. #BILE DUCT OBSTRUCTION CHOLELITHIASIS: She underwent ERCP with stent removal and dilation with a large amount of sludge and fragments drained. A biliary drain was placed. She tolerated the procedure well. She was hydrated with IV fluids and allowed to have clears post procedure. Advanced to regular diet. Her labs were followed and were unremarkable. She will need a follow-up ERCP in 2 months for re-evaluation. #RECENT FALL: C/b right hip and humerus fractures. S/P surgical repairs. Continue with ___ and ortho follow-up as an outpatient. She was continued on pain control with tylenol, dilaudid. #ANEMIA: Hematocrit was 31 on admission. #ATRIAL FIBRILLATION: Continued home metoprolol and amiodarone. #SEIURE DISORDER: Continued on phenytoin. Transitional issues: - Follow-up ERCP in 2 months

summary: ___ yo G3P1011 at 28w1d with cHTN, admitted to AP service for worsening BPs, headache, epigastric discomfort. She was seen by ___ (Dr. ___ as well as internal medicine consult. Her Labetalol was discontinued and she was started on Nifedipine CR 30mg PO BID. This achieved adequate blood pressure control. She had a normal cardiac echo on ___. There was no evidence of pre-eclampsia. Her serum labs were normal throughout the admission and her 24 hour urine collection revealed only 147 mg protein. Her symptoms of headache, visual floaters and epigastric discomfort persisted throught the admission. The symptoms were mild and intermittent. Her headache was usually relieved with Fioricet but would recur. She had been evaluated by neurology and had a normal MRI/MRV during a previous admission. She has a few preterm contractions but no evidence of labor. SVE on admission was closed/high and fFN was negative. FWB was reassuring throughout the admission. On ___ EFW was 966g (45%). On ___ BPP was ___, AFI 12.9. She did not receive BM during this admission. As far as her social situation, Ms. ___ lives in a domestic violence shelter. She was seen by our SW while she was here. She was determined to be safe and was discharged back to the shelter when medically stable. Plan for weekly ATU testing and close f/u with Dr. ___ BP monitoring.

summary: ___ yo male with malignant mesothelioma and associated malignant pleural effusions here with worsening dyspnea over several months, despite repeated thoracenteses. Pt's acute dyspnea improved s/p R thoracentesis (500cc) in ED and 105 cc L pleurex drainage on floor, but pt with ongoing DOE. Pt became comfortable at rest, but still with some DOE which takes several minutes to recover. Pt will likely benefit from Pleurex drain placement for R effusions, for which pt has an appointment with Dr. ___ ___. . Discussed goals of care with pt, daughter, and Dr. ___ (___). No chemotherapy at this time. Outpatient Hospice arrangements in progress. . # hyponatremia - Pt was noted to have hyponatremia on presentation, but this resolved the following day. . # Urinary hesistancy - Pt relayed concern that he recently has had difficulty with urinary hesitancy. In further discussion with patient, he is followed by Urology, who is working with pt's other providers to develop a plan for management. He currently states that he is voiding, and symptoms are currently better than they had been. Will defer to pt's outside providers. . # anemia, NOS - slightly decreased from prior, likely due to chronic disease. No evidence of active blood loss. . # code status - DNR/DNI, confirmed with patient. # Comm - daughter ___ is HCP. DISP: discharged to home with sevices.
