summary: This is a ___ year old female with no significant past medical history who presented with new right upper swelling, pain, paresthesias, cyanosis due to deep venous thrombosis of axillary and subclavian veins. Also admitted for work up of OSH incidental CT finding of 7.5 cm liver mass. . # RUE swelling: The patient's symptoms of right arm swelling, pain, paresthesias, and cyanosis are likely explained by subclavian and axillary vein thrombosis. At an outside hospital, patient was begun on heparin gtt and symptoms significantly improved within a 12 hour period. Upon presentation to ___, patient was continued on heparin gtt, and vascular surgery was consulted. Patient did not exhibit any neurovascular compromise, as pulses were strong and equal bilaterally, strength and sensation were intact. In the setting of an incidental liver mass finding on CT, the initial concern was for an occult malignancy causing a hypercoagulable state. GI was consulted. Patient underwent MRI, which showed findings consistent with focal nodular hyperplasia, a benign lesion requiring no follow-up (see below). . Upper extremity deep venous thrombosis is an unusual finding, especially in a young, otherwise healthy female. The exact etiology of clotting in this female is unclear, but there are several potential contributors. Patient reports a history of repetitive upper body weight lifting - the veins in the patient's arms may have become stenotic over time due to repetitive compression of the vasculature. Alternatively, there may have been an innate anatomical abnormality, causing obstruction of the right upper extremity veins. Her long term use of oral contraceptive may have contributed to a hypercoagulable state. A hypercoagulable study (factor V leiden, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, protein C/S deficiency, prothrombin gene mutation) may be considered as an outpatient and conducted by the patient's primary care physician. . The vascular surgery service was consulted, who believed that the decision to perform thrombolysis, venography, and potential

You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc). 8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Xarelto for 35 days to help
summary: The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: On POD#1, the patient had soft blood pressures and was lightheaded upon standing up when getting out of bed. Her hematocrit was 23.4. A NS bolus was ordered. She triggered for orthostatic hypotension. Ms. ___ continued to be orthostatic with soft blood pressures (SBP low 90's). She was transfused 2 units of PRBCs. On POD#2, the patient's hematocrit was 24.5. Ms. ___ was asymptomatic. The patient started complaining of a persistent cough with small amount of productive sputum. Chest x-ray was performed, which was negative for infectious processes. On POD#3, Ms. ___ continued to complain of cough and worsening shortness of breath. Medicine service consult was obtained given the patient's presistent cough and shortness of breath with a negative chest x-ray. The medicine service evaluated the patient and believed this to be an acute on chronic asthma exacerbation. Additionally, the patient had a hematocrit of 22.6. Medicine felt this post-op anemia could have also been contributing to her shortness of breath. Medicine recommended starting the patient on Prednisone 40mg x 5 days. She was also to be transfused 2 more units PRBCs. These were ordered. An EKG was also ordered to rule out cardiac causes of her shortness of breath. EKG demonstrated PVCs. Troponins were ordered which were negative for acute coronary syndrome. Repeat troponins were also negative. On POD#4, Ms. ___ noted improvements in both her cough and shortness of breath. Hematocrit was acceptable at 28.0. Vital signs were stable. Repeat afternoon CBC demonstrated hematocrit at 28.6. Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral pain medications. The patient received Xarelto for DVT prophylaxis starting on the evening of POD#

summary: ___ female with a history of severe aortic stenosis status post recent TAVR, refractory hypertension without heart failure, and chronic hyponatremia admitted for transient visual disturbance and lightheadedness concerning for neurovascular event, then corroborated by small, subacute stokes on MRI. #) Stroke, cryptogenic: small, subacute left temporal and right occipital. No residual neurologic deficit. Distribution suggestive of thromboembolic event; however, MRA neck, brain without flow-limiting lesions. Repeat TTE without atrial abnormalities. AVR unperturbed like prior. No atrial fibrillation captured on telemetry. It is, however, conceivable that she had a paroxysm of atrial fibrillation a few days ago, in keeping with her described symptoms. Known ASD, though LENIS negative. Will continue on DAPT with expedited neurology follow-up in ___ days for consideration of systemic anticoagulation. Should systemic anticoagulation be implemented, it is permissible to stop clopidogrel per structural heart team. A1C within normal limits. No subsequent spells noted. #) Bradycardia, sinus: uncertain if aforementioned symptoms are sequelae of bradyarrhythmia. No evidence of AV block on review of serial ECG and telemetry. No nodal blocking agents. Suspect sinus in nature by virtue of age. CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES: #) AS, severe: s/p TAVR (___). NYHA, class I. Recent TTE acceptable, as above. Continue home DAPT. #) Hyponatremia: 130 at admission; not an excessive deviation from baseline. Euvolemic at present. #) Hypertension, refractory: possibly secondary in the context of hyporeninism and adrenal adenoma as well as 60% right renal artery stenosis. Home clonidine, lisinopril, and chlorthalidone continued after discussion with PCP. #) H. pylori: home triple therapy continued. #) PMR: home prednisone 2 mg continued. #) Leukopenia: at baseline. Presumably idiopathic per hematology. #) Anemia, iron deficiency: at baseline. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES

summary: ___ year-old female with history of CLL with associated malignant pleural effusion (s/p TPC, MT and pleurodesis), ___ s/p resection ___, and recurrent pneumonia/chronic respiratory failure requiring tracheostomy complicated by tracheal stenosis. Admitted following decannulating of ___, complicated by moderate blood loss, hypotension, NSTEMI and question of pneumonia. # Acute on chronic hypoxemic and hypercarbic respiratory failure: history of tracheal stenosis with multiple IP procedures, previous malignant effusion s/p talc pleurodesis, now presenting for elective decannulation ___ tube and transbronchial biopsy of right upper lobe. ABG with borderline pO2 with mild acute respiratory acidosis (pO2 69, pCO2 47, pH 7.33). Transferred to the floor with increased O2 requirement to 4L and intermittently requiring trach mask. Etiology of respiratory failure multifactorial and likely included pneumonitis from aspiration during decannulation, pneumonia, pulmonary edema, atelectasis and lung malignancy. Stable on the floor with increased inspiratory effort without any other signs of distress and stable O2 saturation. Diuresed with IV Lasix with net negative fluid balance. Treated symptomatically with bronchodilators and cough suppressants. Given hypotension during procedure, cough and infiltrate on chest x-ray, she was started on vancomycin/meropenem for HCAP. Transitioned to levofloxacin to complete a 5-day course with BAL/sputum cultures pending. Symptomatically improved with deceased cough and no fevers after starting antibiotics. Monitored with chest x-rays without acute changes. IP continued to follow on the floor. Discharged with plan to follow-up with Dr. ___ ___ 4 weeks with Chest CT and spirometry prior to appointment. [Of note, BAL cultures returned post discharge and were notable for multiple species of bacteria including proteus (previously treated with 10 days of meropenem), E. coli and stenotrophomonas. Discussed with IP and felt to be colonizers. Patient will follow-up with IP.] # Lung adenocarcinoma:

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> vertigo, diplopia, headache <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> N/A <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Dr. ___ is a ___ right handed man with a history of a pontine cavernous malformation, HTN, dyslipidemia and migraines with aura who presented after two episodes of headache with vertigo in the past week. He was in his usual state of health when on ___ he developed acute onset splitting headache over bilateral temporoparietal regions, ___ in pain. A few minutes later he developed horizontal diplopia with room-spinning vertigo and nausea. He went to rest on his bed, with generalized weakness. He took Tylenol ___ hour into the episode with mild headache relief. There was no photo- or phonophobia and no focal weakness or change in sensation. Headache resolved after ___ hours, with diplopia and dizziness resolving over the subsequent ___ hours after the headache went away, such that he was back to his neurologic baseline by the evening. He was subsequently symptom free until day of presentation ___. While reading from his iPhone in a seated position at around 10: 30am, he developed horizontal diplopia, worse on rightward gaze, with nausea and room-spinning vertigo. Over the next hour he then developed a moderate throbbing headache over biparietal regions about ___ in severity. He laid down in bed the whole day with slow improvement in headache, now down to ___, however with persistent diplopia and vertigo, such that in discussion with his wife, he presented to the ED. He also notes being unsteady on his feet, maybe leaning more towards the left. He was admitted to the Stroke Neurology service on ___ for headache, nausea, and then left facial weakness, left arm and leg weakness and numbness, also with vertigo and horizontal diplopia. On examination he had left-sided ataxia, difficulty with tandem gait, and positive Romberg. During his admission, there was a 7mm pontine cavernoma with chronic blood products and no evidence of acute or early subacute hemorrhage. His symptoms resolved by time of discharge and recommended outpatient Neurosurgical follow-up. He was seen by Dr. ___ ___ ___ later in ___, who felt that this anterior brainstem cavernous malformation was likely asymptomatic and did not recommend any additional evaluations or interventions. He has had similar symptoms previously. In ___ he had transient horizontal diplopia while driving. The following day he noticed left facial numbness while shaving. A brain MRI in ___ in ___ showed a brainstem cavernoma. On ___ ___, he had a similar event with a bi-temporal throbbing headache, diplopia, numbness and weakness on left side, and difficulty walking. These symptoms lasted for 12 hours. He was admitted to ___. During that hospitalization he reported symptoms of depression, heavy EtOH use, spending lots of money, and recent behavioral changes. He was seen by psychiatry who diagnosed him with bipolar disorder, began Abilify, and transferred him to the inpatient psychiatric unit for 4 days. There, he felt somewhat hopeless and took a lot of Ativan. He had been recommended by neurology to have a brain MRI for evaluation of his event with diplopia and hemiparesis but this was not done. He has a history of migraines with aura since he was young. He typically gets a headache w/vomiting a couple times per year. He's had a few visual auras, described as color changes, as if looking at everything through a rainbow. This would occur around 20 minutes before his headache. He has also had another type of visual aura with tunnel vision and magnification as if looking through a magnifying glass. Review of Systems: The pt denies loss of vision, blurred vision, dysphagia. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending speech. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. The pt denies recent fever or chills. Denies cough. Denies chest pain or palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Brainstem Cavernoma - History of possible bipolar disorder - Gastritis - L ear hearing loss - Psoriasis - Dyslipidemia - Hypertension <SOCIAL HISTORY> with his wife. Originally from ___, moved here ___. Worked as a ___ in ___, owned his own clinic x ___ yrs though has been doing mostly administrative work and hasn't seen patients in ___ yrs. He has sold his clinic and recently finished a lawsuit regarding this, however he remains financially limited while awaiting compensation from the suit. He lost his parents earlier in the year. He started another business project recently regarding an online portal, however the project fell through. He and his wife report chronically elevated stress. He exercises regularly. - Tobacco: former pipe smoker ___ years old) - EtOH: ___ glasses
summary: ___ year old right handed male with a history of a brainstem cavernoma who presented with recurrent headache, associated with room spinning vertigo, nausea, horizontal diplopia and unsteady gait. On exam, he had horizontal diplopia on primary gaze that worsened on rightward gaze, with a subtle right exotropia (resolved the next morning). He has a positive Romberg and mildly unsteady gait. He had a prior hospitalization for a similar episode. He was admitted to the hospital for stroke workup. Stroke risk factors included TSH 2.3, LDL 87, and Hemoglobin A1c 5.1. He had a CTA head/neck without large vessel occlusion and MRI head w/o contrast which was negative for stroke, revealing only his known, baseline pontine glioma. Overall the most likely etiology was basilar migraine. Cavernoma was thought to be too anterior to explain his symptoms and appeared stable. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Changed Metoprolol to low dose Propranolol (10mg BID) for blood pressure management in setting of headache syndrome (propranolol is more efficacious for migraine) - For abortive treatment, recommend Compazine and Naproxen synergistically. Instructed to limit use to no more than twice per week, and to return to the hospital should symptoms be refractory and not responsive to treatment. - Neurology follow up was not arranged here due to patient planning to move soon, however was given the clinic contact information should he need a local appointment.

summary: The patient presented to the emergency department and was evaluated by the ___ team. The patient was found to have a sigmoid volvulus and taken emergently to the operating room on ___ for Ex-lap, subtotal colectomy which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. Of note, prior to the OR the patient was refusing surgery. Psychiatry evaluated the patient in the ED and deemed she did not have capacity to refuse medical care as she did not have insight into her disease process. For full details of this, please see their separate note. The patient tolerated the operation well and was taken to the ICU in guarded condition post-op. Post-op it was noted she had a large R sided pneumothorax and a pigtail was placed. On ___ she was extubated. On ___ her R pigtail was removed, and her psychiatric medications were further titrated by psychiatry. She was deemed stable for transfer to the floor. On ___, she was started on a diet and progressed slowly. She started to have loose stool that were c.diff negative and was thought to be due to her short colon. During this time, her vancomycin was discontinued and psychiatry suggested haldol, hold amitryptaline, buproprion, benztropine, allow quetiapine (please see their note for more details). She continued to do well and on ___, she was discontinued on her unasyn as well and started on Imodium and psyllium wafers. That afternoon, the patient was found to be unresponsive with an arrhythmia noted on telemetry. A code was called and after 1 cycle of CPR w/ return of circulation and mental status. She was transferred to the ICU and cardiology was consulted, who recommended discontinuing all qTC prolonging medications and aggressive electrolyte repletion. She remained stable in the ICU and after close monitoring, transferred back to the floor ___ in stable condition. Since she was back on the floor, her electrolytes were repleted aggressively and

summary: ___ yo female with ESRD on HD, DM2, HTN, chronic systolic HF, who presents with fatigue, malaise, and cough and has not been to HD in 3 sessions, found to have CONS HD cath-associated infection, MSSA HD cath entry site soft tissue infection. . #. Fatigue/malaise/non-productive cough: no evidence of pneumonia on CXR, has been afebrile throughout hospitalization. No leukocytosis. Influenza DFA was negative. Patient was continued with supportive care with expectorants/benzonatate, and improved with HD sessions and above care. . #. Bacteremia: HD catheter tip with coag positive staph, blood cultures showing coag neg staph on 3 sets blood cultures. Echo negative for vegetations. After discussion with ID and review of MICs, overall assessment was that of CONS HD cath-associated infection, ___ HD cath entry site soft tissue infection. Empiric vancomycin was switched to cefazolin HD protocol. Patient underwent line holiday with removal of tunneled HD line on ___, negative blood cultures x 48 hours, then placement of new ___ tunneled HD line. Per ID, patient will undergo 4 weeks of cefazolin with HD (end date ___. She will have follow-up with ID at the midpoint of treatment. . #. ESRD on HD: received three short sessions of HD followed by line holiday, then subsequently placed on her routine HD schedule. Patient was continued on sevalemer and nephrocaps. . #. Diarrhea: patient had two days of diarrhea (three-four liquid stool per day, non-bloody). Infectious w/u on ___ and ___ was negative for stool cx as well as Cdiff. Per hx, this appears to be a chronic problem (few months), and patient reports that she had GI appt earlier, which she missed. She can have outpatient evaluation arranged, at the discretion of her PCP. Prior to discharge, her diarrhea appeared to be resolving, with only one BM day prior to discharge.

Ms. ___ reports that she was diagnosed with fibroids many years ago and has a history of heavy painful periods. Her periods became irregular in ___. She reports only spotting in ___ followed by another episode of spotting ___. At the end of ___, she began to have intense pelvic pain that was crampy and continuous requiring use of narcotics for pain control in addition to tylenol and motrin. This pain has continued off and on since the end of ___. An endometrial biopsy was attempted in the office on ___ which was insufficient. A pelvic ultrasound ___ showed nl ovaries, no thickening or remarkable echogenicity of a distorted endometrium within an enlarged (14.1x12.5x12.0cm) multifibroid uterus. The dominant fibroid is 10.3x9.8x9.5cm located in the posterior fundus. An office hysteroscopy with EMB was then performed on ___. Biopsy again was insufficient. Hysteroscopy revealed an irregular cavity, and moderate bleeding. Multiple tumor markers were checked and LDH and HCG came back elevated: HCG 28, LDH 415. CEA, CA-125, AFP were wnl. The patient was referred to gyn oncology due to concern for malignancy. She was offered a hysterectomy but declined initially and on ___ she underwent a hysteroscopy, dilatation and curettage. Pathology revealed atrophic endometrium. Hysteroscopic findings revealed an endocervical polyp and a large fibroid obstructing entry into the fundus and the remainder of the uterine cavity but the endometrial lining appeared atrophic. Since her DC she reports she has continued to have cramping pain occasionally requiring narcotics and sometimes waking her from sleep. She also reports increasing fatigue and an increase in abdominal girth. Since her DC her vaginal bleeding has been minimal but she has been having increasing clear, sometimes blood stained, vaginal discharge, soaking a few pads a day. There is no odor to the discharge. She notes increasing constipation and abdominal bloating but continues to have regular bowel movements while taking colace. She does report some nausea but no emesis. She reports early satiety. She denies fevers. summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology oncology service after undergoing total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course is detailed as follows: 1. Routine postoperative care. Immediately postoperatively, her pain was controlled with an epidural and IV Tylenol. Her diet was advanced on postoperative day #1 and the epidural was removed; she was transitioned to oral pain medications with IV for breakthrough pain. On postoperative day #4, her urine output was adequate so her foley cathter was removed and she voided spontaneously. She received lovenox for venous thromboembolism prevention. 2. Ileus. On postoperative day #2, she developed an ileus. She was made NPO and continued on IV fluids and IV pain medications. She improved with expectant management and her diet was advanced on postoperative day #3. She had one additional episode of emesis so was made NPO again and expectantly managed with improvement in her symptoms. Her diet was again advanced on postoperative #4 and was advanced to regular as tolerated. At the time of discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet. 3. Hypertension. In the postoperative period she was noted to be persistently hypertensive, with blood pressures mainly in the 150-160/80-90s but as high as 180s/90s. Her preoperative blood pressure was 150/80. For this likely underlying chronic hypertension she was initially started on metoprolol; however, her blood pressure did not respond. She was switched to IV hydralazine. On postoperative day #4, she was transitioned to oral metoprolol. Her blood pressure was adequately controlled throughout the remainder of her hospitalization. A follow-up appontment was scheduled with her PCP for management of her hypertension. By post-operative day 6, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of HCV cirrhosis, DM, CAD and CVA with a recent admission to ___ for R hepatic hydrothorax s/p thoracentesis who is admitted with renal failure which has corrected since holding diuretics. Acute Issues: ============= #Acute Renal failure: Patient's creatitine had come down to 1.3 at time of presentation to the ED, after stopping her diuretics 3 days prior to presentation. Her diuretics were held overnight, and she was discharged on a reduced dose of 50mg spirinolactone and 40mg lasix daily. Follow up labs will be drawn at ___ clinic this week. # Ascites c/b refractory hepatic hydrothorax: Hydrothorax had re-accumulated since recent pleuricentesis of 1L at ___ ___. Repeat tap was not performed here given likelihood of future recurrence, and the fact that patient was denying respiratory syptoms. She was discharged on lower doses of diuretics as above. She was also seen by Nutrition, who discussed with her how to maintain a low-salt diet. The importance of this was emphasized by the medical team. Chronic Issues: =============== # Cirrhosis: MELD 13 on admission. Review of records showed patient is not a candidate for transplant given significant co-morbidities. No acute intervention was pursued. # HTN. Patient was continued on pre-admission atenolol and amlodipine. Lisinopril was re-started on discharge. # DM. Patient's oral antihypoglycemics were held, and she was maintained on insulin sliding scale with adequate glucose control. # CAD/angina: On discussion with patient her chest pain did not sound anginal in nature. She was continued on her pre-admission beta-blocker, amlodipine, isosorbide, and plavix. She was discharged on her home lisinopril and reduced diuretic dosing as above. # Hepatic encephalopathy: Patient was continued on pre-admission lactulose. She was mentating well without asterixis on day of discharge. # Weight loss

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with history obstructive sleep apnea, and reflux disease who presented with severe burning abdominal pain in the epigastric area associated with food. EGD showed mild esophagitis and she has symptomatically improved. . # Esophagitis: The initial evaluation included liver/gallbladder ultrasound which was negative for acute process, LFTs were normal, lipase was normal, H. pylori negative. She was continued on her home ranitidine 300 mg qhs and omeprazole 40 mg daily. Also, sucralfate liquid was added, however, she did not improve. Because she continued to have severe ___ pain and was not eating any food, GI was consulted. They performed an EGD which showed mild esophagitis. They felt that this most likely represented pill esophagitis from Bactrim recently prescribed for cellulitis. Biopsies were taken of the irritated areas but are pending at the time of discharge. The bactrim was discontinued. They recommended increasing omeprazole to 40 mg BID x 2 weeks then returning to 40 mg daily, continued ranitidine 300 mg qhs. . # Acute kidney injury (___): Likely from reduced PO intake in the past few days due to esophagitis. Her FeNa was 1.23%, suggestive of mixed picture but at least partly intrinsic renal damage (likely from diabetes). She was eating and drinking well before discharge. Her lisinopril was held due to ___, and should be restarted as an outpatient after another creatinine recheck. . # Cellulitis: Recently admitted for cellulitis (___) although no culture data, exam during this admission was resolved cellulitis. Due to ___ and concern for esophagitis, the Bactrim was discontinued on admission. Her Keflex was continued until she completed a ___nd then was discontinued. . # Hypertension (HTN): Currently well controlled, lisinopril was held due to ___. Should be restarted after recheck creatinine. Continued metoprolol tartrate 12.5 mg BID, aspirin 81 mg daily. . # Hyperlipidemia: continued simvastatin 40 mg daily . # Hypercalcemia: Subclinical during admission. Consider rechecking as an outpatient and consider workup if

summary: The patient was admitted and taken to the operating room by Dr. ___ the patient underwent the above surgical procedure. The procedure was well tolerated and there were no complications. Please see the separately dictated operative report for details regarding the surgery. The patient was subsequently transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition and transferred to the floor later that day. Overnight, the patient was placed on a IV and PO narcotics for pain control. IV antibiotics were continued until cultures returned MSSA. ID was consulted and recommended IV Nafcillin for 6 weeks. A PICC line was placed and CXR demonstrated PICC tip in appropriate position. Lovenox/coumadin were continued. The surgical dressing was found to be clean, dry, and intact without erythema or purulent drainage. During the hospital course the patient was seen by physical therapy. The patient was tolerating regular diet and otherwise feeling well. She transitioned to oral pain control and was discharged to acute rehab in stable condition with written follow up instructions and detailed precautionary guidance.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Cephalosporins / sulfur dioxide / hydroxyzine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Altered mental status <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is an ___ year old woman with a PMH notable for dementia, Bell's palsy, CAD (stents, ___, PVD and hyeprtension, who underwent recent ventral hernia repair ___, ___, who presents from rehab after seizure. History is limited from patient, as well as from EMS. The patient was found to be altered the morning of presentation, and observed possible seizure activity, as well as diffuse weakness. It is unclear based on history what type of seizure activity was witnessed. As noted, the patient had a ventral wall hernia repair done at ___ 1 week prior to presentation. This was complicated by postoperative seizures. She was seen by neurology at that time and started on levetiracetam. She was subsequently discharged to rehab on levetiracetam 500 mg BID. Per review of records from rehab, she was administered 250 mg BID. In the ED, initial vitals were: T 98, HR 99, BP 148/82, R 18, SpO2 98% on RA. - Labs were notable for: normal CBC, INR 1.2, normal chemistries (with BUN 5), normal LFTs (with albumin 3.3), normal lactate, negative urine toxicology screen, normal UA, negative flu A/B PCR - CT head notable for: 1. No acute intracranial process. 2. Unchanged 1.4 x 1.0 cm hyperdense lesion in the foramina magnum anteriorly on the left, previously characterized as a meningioma. - CXR notable for: Right lower lung subsegmental atelectasis. Additional opacity at the right lung base may also represent atelectasis in the setting of low lung volumes but infection would be possible in the appropriate clinical setting. - 1 g levetiracetam (17: 20), 750 mg levofloxacin (22: 07), 1 g APAP (23: 17)  25 mg diphenhydramine (02: 17) were given. EEG monitoring revealed periods of delta slow-waves consistent with seizure. Her levetiracetam was uptitrated to 750 mg PO BID with the assistance of neurology. She was also treated for a UTI as below. # Fever / UTI: On admission, she had a new oxygen requirement that likely reflected aspiration in the setting of confusion. She was treated initially for pneumonia with amp/sulbactam and azithromycin; however, UCx grew 10k-100k CFUs of E. coli resistant to amp/sulbactam, and given rapid resolution of O2 requirement, she was felt to more likely have a UTI and switched to TMP/SMX for a toatl ___ysphagia: From brainstem compression due to meningioma. summary: Patient was transferred from OSH for assessment of R hip pain and R hand swelling. Right hip was aspirated on ___ and showed no signs of infection. Pain resolved spontaneously and so no additional interventions persued. Rheumatology was consulted regarding R hand swelling. Hand was aspirated on ___ and showed no crystals. Uric acid was elevated during bood draw so patient was started on prednisone for possible arthritic gout. Six day taper is to be completed on ___ and patient will follow-up with rheumatology outpatient in ___ weeks. The patient was seen by physical therapy during her stay.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> NSAIDS (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug) / Penicillins / aspirin <ATTENDING> ___ ___ Complaint: leg weakness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> right IJ central line ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is a ___ male with history of COPD, morbid obesity, colitis, and presumed high grade lymphoma transferred from ___ to ___ for initiation of treatment and concern for tumor lysis syndrome. Intially, the patient presented to ___ in ___ with bilateral lower extremity weakness and a 70-pound weight loss. He underwent extensive workup including a CT scan of his chest and abdomen along with a neurological workup. He underwent a biopsy of his left supraclavicular lymph node and was thought to have high-grade lymphoma, noted to have approximately 90% cell turnover. However, unfortunately the tissue sample was not enough to make a final diagnosis. The patient had been discharged to ___, from where he subsequently presented to ___ for a 2-day history of fever to 103, hypoxia, tachycardia, tachypnea. At ___, given his presentation and SIRS criteria, he was initially thought to have sepsis, especially since information regarding his malignancy was undiscovered. Blood cx grew grew coag-negative staphylococcus, felt to be a contaminant, so antibiotics were discontinued. A repeat left supraclavicular lymph node biopsy was obtained and the results of this are pending. A CT scan of his spine and brain were obtained which did not show any metastasis; an enlarged retrocrural lymph node measuring 1.8 cm was noted. An MRI was recommended for more sensitivity; however, because of limitations due to his body habitus, MRI was not obtained. An LP was attempted to obtain CSF to evaluate for lymphoma spread to the spine; however, the patient was unable to tolerate an LP because of tachycardia and therefore this was not obtained. He was subsequently transferred to ___ for intiation of oncologic treatment. Upon arrival to the FICU at ___ the patient was somnolent but arousable, answering questions appropriately but slowly, oriented to person, place, and time. He was breathing rapidly but not with labor. He did report mild abdominal discomfort but no vomiting or diarrhea. He denied fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath. It was very difficult to obtain more history from them than this basic review of symptoms, as his answers were quite brief. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. COPD. 2. Obesity 3. IBS. 4. Colitis. 5. BPH. 6. summary: The patient is a ___ male with history of COPD, morbid obesity, suspected high grade lymphoma who was transferred from ___ for treatment intiation and concern for tumor lysis syndrome. The patient was initiated on dexamethasone 40 mg daily upon arrival. His significant metabolic acidosis drove him to be tachypnea, for which he was placed on a bicarb drip and shortly intubated following admission for further respiratory support. He was trialed on CRRT which was limited by his tenuous hemodynamics and his acidosis persisted. He required support with pressors. On ___, his blood pressures continued to drop. CRRT was discontinued and the HCP and family was notified. The patient expired on ___ at 13:15. # High grade lymphoma: Patient with high grade lymphoma, with >90% proliferation on first biopsy. Per oncology, his high-grade B cell lymphoma is extremely aggressive, may represent Burkitt vs large B cell lymphoma, and given his tenuous clinical status, treatment should begin urgently. Combination chemotherapy with agents active against aggressive lymphomas (including doxorubicin, etoposide, and vincristine) is contraindicated in the setting of hyperbilirubinemia and elevated transaminases, so initiation of high-dose dexamethasone 40 mg daily was attempted to decrease his disease burden and improve his end-organ function. Labs were also notable for ferritin > 10,000, which could represent an acute inflammatory reactant, but given his fever, fibrinogenemia, possibility of HLH was also considered. He was given allopurinol ___ mg daily and rasburicase x 1. # Metabolic acidosis: Patient with an elevated anion gap acidosis, with an elevated lactate on admission to 7.2, which continued to increase. He was bolused IV fluids with bicarb and started on a bicarb gtt. He had temporary dialysis catheters placed for intiation of CRRT, which was limited given his hypotension and hemodynamic instability. # Thrombocytopenia/Coagulopathies: hypofibrinogenemia may

summary: ___ YOM w/PMH HTN, DM2, CAD presents with pleuritic chest pain and found to have RLL PNA with effusion. # Pneumonia, RLL, community acquired # Right pleural effusion / # Pleurisy Presented with cough, chest pain, leukocytosis and imaging with RLL infiltrate and right sided pleural effusion. He also required supplemental O2. He was placed on CTX/Azithromycin, as he had no HCAP risk factors. His WBC improved and his O2 requirement resolved. He had significant chest pain, which was attributed to pleural effusion / pleurisy. CTA did not show any acute PE. Urine legionella was NEGATIVE, blood culture is pending but with no growth, as is sputum culture. For pain control, he initially required IV opioids, but was transitioned to a PO opioid regimen for severe chest pain refractory to Tylenol and NSAID's. His pain improved prior to discharge. Consider repeat chest imaging to document resolution of infiltrates at PCP ___. He is being discharged on a course of oral antibiotics, with a 7 day course of Levaquin. # Anemia Hct 40 on admission, now 33. Baseline Hct 38 in ___ per review of Atrius records. No signs/symptoms of active bleeding, including CT Torso. Suspect hemoconcentrated on admission. B12 borderline at 297, does not r/o B12 deficiency. Ferritin 206 neither rules in or rules out iron deficiency, although overall iron panel does NOT seem to be c/w ___, more c/w AOCD. HCT stable in mid 30's. Recommend further outpatient work-up. # HTN #CAD (CABG) #Hyperlipidemia No changes in EKG. Troponin on admission was NEGATIVE. Hemodynamically stable. - continued amlodipine, enalapril, aspirin, statin. Toprol was changed to short-acting metoprolol during hospitalization but resumed Toprol on discharge. - consider reducing ASA dose to 81mg # DM2: Last A1C 6 (___). Held metformin given CT in ED.

summary: ___ s/p car accident ___ on chronic pain (oxycontin, percocet) complicated by PE requiring IVC filter and warfarin presenting with jaundice, fatigue, malaise x 5 days with elevated AST, ALT, and TBili, found to have acute hepatitis C. # Acute hepatitis C. Patient presented with jaundice, fatigue, diarrhea, malaise x 5 days with elevated LFTs and total bili. He was found to have acute hepatitis C, with positive anti-HCV antibody and HCV viral load of 1.3 million. Other workup including Hep A, Hep B, CMV, HIV, C diff were negative. RUQ US showed an echogenic liver with fatty infiltration and normal patent vasculature. Patient's presenting LFTs were markedly elevated at AST 1258 and ALT 1488, with normal alk phos 104, very high total bili of 16.4 (direct bili 13.2), with INR 1.3, showing cholestatic labs with impaired synthetic liver function. Exam notable for jaundice, scleral icterus, and fatigue. An acetaminophen level was negative here, but reportedly elevated at OSH. Patient received 16 hours of empiric N-acetylcysteine. A review of risk factors for Hep C including high risk sexual behavior, IV drug use, recent tattoo, use of herbal supplements, excessive acetaminophen products, steroids, were all negative. He had used only 6 Percocets and 2 exedrins over the past week. Transmission of his acute hepatitis C was thought to be from direct contact from scrapes/cuts on his skin (plumbing work) with dirty surfaces in the homes of his clients vs the cuts themselves (he does not always wear gloves). He was treated supportively, his jaundice decreased, his LFTs, bilirubin, and INR downtrended, and patient was stable for discharge to home. He was prescribed ondansetron 4mg q6hr prn for nausea #30. summary: ___ h/o peripheral vascular disease, gastric bypass, partial colectomy for perforated diverticulitis who presented w left lower quadrant pain and was found to have nephrolithiasis. #Nephrolithiasis: UA showed large blood, and pt had colicky abdominal pain hours before presentation which resolved. CT abd showed 3 kidney stones, the largest being 1.2 cm on the L renal pelvis with mild left hydroureteronephrosis. He tolerated PO and pain was managed with his home dilaudid. There were no signs of infection (he remained afebrile, normal white count) and urology was contacted and the plan was to discharge him with close urology follow up with Dr ___ stone removal. On day of discharge he had no abdominal pain. #Anemia: Ht 36, stable since ___ (before ___ he was polycythemic), MCV 74 most consistent with iron deficiency anemia (iron was 18 last month) ferritin 17. Pt endorsed black stools though he was on ferrous sulfate. There were no signs of active bleeding and his Ht was stable while here. #chronic kidney disease: Cr 1.6 (baseline 1.4 though has been as high as 1.7). On day of discharge his Cr was 1.7 and this will be followed in the outpatient setting. He was given no contrast while here and nephrotoxic medications were avoided. CT abdomen showed mild hydronephrosis with many calculi though no obstruction. He will follow up with urology and his PCP. #HTN: his BP was under good control. He was continued on amlodipine #PVD: He was continued on coumadin, plavix and his INR 2.5 #Wound: RLE with wound (recent pseudomonal infection and debridement by vascular surgery in ___ he completed course of antibiotics). His wound was stable and was dressed daily #Hypothyroid: -continued levothyroxine #Thrombocytosis: plat in 500s-600s since ___ on admission 700s adn on d/c 600s.He has been seen by Dr ___ there was concern about ___

summary: #. Asthma Exacerbation. On arrival to the floor, patient was afebrile and her oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. She was given prednisone 60mg PO daily, and albuterol/ipratropium nebulizer treatments every 6 hours. Her wheezing improved. Ambulatory oxygen saturation was 94-96% on room air. Patient was discharged with a 5 day prednisone burst, albuterol and ipratropium nebulizer treatments, and follow up with her PCP next week. . # Chest tightness. Myocardial infarction was ruled out by EKG and serial cardiac enzymes. Serum BNP was 11. Given patient's hyperlipidemia, and family history, repeat stress testing was recommended, but we will defer this to her primary doctor. . #. Depression. Patient was continued on her home dose of escitalopram. . #. Bladder Spasm. Patient was continued on her home dose of ditropan xl.

summary: Ms. ___ presented to ___ holding at ___ on ___ for a total thyroidectomy with Dr. ___. She tolerated the procedure well without complications (Please see operative note for further details). After a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was transferred to the floor for further post-operative management. Her parathyroid and calcium levels were within normal limits in PACU without need for further intervention. She was started on thyroid hormone replacement on POD 1 as routine. Neuro: Pain was well controlled on Tylenol CV: The patient was tachycardic throughout the admission, she reports that she has always had a high heart rate, is afebrile, denies chest pain, shortness of breath, appropriate UOP. Pulm: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; oxygen saturation was routinely monitored. Had good pulmonary toileting, as early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. GI: The patient was initially kept NPO after the procedure. The patient was later advanced to and tolerated a regular diet at time of discharge. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored GU: At time of discharge, the patient was voiding without difficulty. ID: The patient was closely monitored for signs and symptoms of infection and fever. Heme: Surgery not concerning for excessive blood loss, no clinical signs of anemia. On ___, the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, voiding, and ambulating independently. She will follow-up in the clinic in ___ weeks. Warning signs for hypocalcemia were communicated. This information was communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> PSYCHIATRY <ALLERGIES> Codeine <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> I was suicidal, now they won't give me my Ativan or cigarettes and I'm feeling like I want to get the hell out of here <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Patient is a ___ Caucasian man with self-reported h/o depression, anxiety, chronic cervical pain and multiple past hospitalizations for threats of self-harm who self-presents to ED after discharge from ___ psychiatric service today for resurrgence in SI with plan to OD on meds. On approach for interview, the patient was gruff and irritable over not receiving his Ativan and Vicodin quickly enough, and he perseverated over a desire to leave and smoke cigarettes. He endorses being chronically depressed with intermittent suicidality though doesn't need a trigger or stressor - it just happens. After a brief period of stability following several ___ hospitalizations in ___ (where his mother lives) for SI, he reportedly felt acutely depressed again without stimulus around 3 weeks ago leading to an impulsive OD on all home meds (Celexa, Trileptal, Baclofen, several others) and subsequent brief ICU stabilization. He was then transferred to ___ to address psych symptoms where he has remained for the past 2 weeks. There, he was started on Welbutrin (the only antidepressant I hadn't tried) and was encouraged to attempt ECT for recurrent depression, however he adamantly refused such treatment and today was discharged with resolution SI. He reportedly went straight to a bar and drank 400ml of whiskey after having been sober for ___ years and quickly formed a plan to get new scripts for another OD attempt, particularly Welbutrin which he knows will kill people. He denies any other past or present substance/prescription abuse despite last OMR reports from ___ that indicate frequent drug-seeking behaviors during prior admissions. Endorses frequent insomnia, poor appetite and loss of all interest in pleasurable activities over past weeks, though denies any h/o manic features or perceptual abnormalities. He has upcoming appointments for OP psychiatric follow-up through ___, though would not make it that long.. I know when I feel this way and there's no way I'm safe. He also claims to be socially isolated without supports to help ensure safety, and lost ID recently at ___ so he can no longer cash Social Security check (would also preclude ability to participate in PHP with travel expenses). <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: - Diagnoses: H/o Depression, anxxiety with suggestions in ___ OMR notes of PSA and borderline/antisocial behaviors when hospitalized, often overly flirtatious or attempting to sign out AMA. - ___: No known h/o assault on units. Unable to verify recent hospitalizations at this time, though claims recent discharge from ___. Multiple per year for SI, mostly in ___ where he frequently stays. - OP Treaters: None currently, last was in ___, Dr. ___ who is reportedly now retired (last seen in late ___. Has appts for ___ (therapist) and ___ (psych) after ___ though can't provide names. - Medication Trials: Been on every medication made for depression, bipolar and psychosis but none do much then proceeds to give a large list that supports this, though unclear if used MAOIs, stimulants. - SA/SIB: Endorses chronic passive SI with frequent surges of intent, typically with plan to OD on pills. Most recent as per HPI. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - Chronic degenerative cervical disc disease - HTN <SOCIAL HISTORY> SUBSTANCE ABUSE HISTORY: Etoh: Reports significant past abuse with blackouts, seizures and possible DTs though unclear. Claims sober x ___ years until this afternoon, attends AA three times per week. Tobacco: Denies Illicit Drug Use: Denies all opiates, cocaine or prescription abuse, though suggestions in past of med-seeking behaviors for benzo/narcotics. SOCIAL HISTORY: ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> FAMILY PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: - Biological father: ___ DO - ___ Mother: ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical and Neuropsychiatric Examination upon Admission: GA: well groomed caucasian male, sitting in chair, in NAD HEENT: NC/AT, PERRL, EOMI, oral mucosa pink and moist, no erythema or exudates Neck: no LAD CV: RRR, no m/r/g Lungs: CTA B Abd: soft, NT, ND, BS Ext: no edema, clubbing, cyanosis Neurological: *station and gait: steady and balanced *tone and strength: normal tone, ___ strength cranial nerves: Cn II
summary: #1. Mood with SI - Upon initial presentation to the unit, pt appeared less acute than his verbal report suggests. No thoughts or discussion of SI, and he is quick to affirm no safety risks now that things have cleared up. Verification of psychotropics revealed a more robust regimen. Mildly dysphoric on unit, otherwise no notable symptoms. By the day of discharge, the patient exhibited and expressed no acute mood or safety concerns, agreed to a safety plan both in/out of the hospital, and expressed future-oriented thinking re: returning to ___ to be with his partner and child. #2. Substance use - Upon initial presentation to the unit, no concern for withdrawal, as the patient denied heavy EtOH consumption for a period of time prior to admission that would place him at risk for withdrawal, and he presented to the ED with a BAL=80, otherwise serumurine tox negative. No treatment indicated. Previously-prescribed narcotic regimen continued after it was verified. No withdrawal from EtOH or narcotic noted shortly after admission (before administration of these medications), thus no withdrawal protocols were indicated. The patient declined a referral to local sobriety services, stating that substance abuse is not currently an issue for him. He was encouraged to follow-up with his PCP/psych MD re: the need for longterm opiates and BD, which he agreed to do, and thus was given only enough medication to get him to his next MD appointment. #3. Medications - Shortly after initial presentation to the unit, verification of psychotropics revealed a more robust regimen as reported by pt, including Buspar 20 TID, Remeron 15 HS, Ativan 4xD, Wellbutrin ___ 75, Vicodin ___ q4-6h PRN. Restarted Buspar at lower dose, converted opiate and B to longer-acting equivalent dosing based on presentation. He was encouraged to follow-up with his PCP

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> PSYCHIATRY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> I have been having paranoid thinking <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old asian post-partum x 6 months female who works as a ___ Practitioner who presents with history of paranoid psychosis presents to the ED voluntarily with husband requesting psychiatric admission for worsening paranoia and inability to take care of her ___ month old daughter. I have reviewed Dr. ___ and husband was present in interview with patient. Patient states that she has a history of paranoid psychosis but had been generally functional as a ___ practitioner ___ hospitalization in ___, where diagnosis was made). She had been generally stable on Risperdal but discontinued in ___ in preparation to becoming pregnant. She gave birth in ___ but did not immediately resume paranoia. She notes that even through pregnancy she had some mild amount of paranoia but she was able to reason through the thoughts. However, in ___ while taking care of her child she began to lose sleep and then eventually could not sleep. She found her paranoia increasing and had increased goal-directed activity (lists) which were not fruitful and restless energy. She was hesitant to start medications because she wanted to breast feed. There were several small events of paranoia that eventually led her to see Dr. ___ after ___ year in ___ requesting help. Dr. ___ her then and agreed that she would benefit from restarting Risperdal at 1mg daily and explained that the risks outweighed the benefits at this time. She received some counseling from lactation experts but still felt unconvinced so only has been taking Risperdal 0.5mg. Patient had another visit with Dr. ___ week where she appeared to be doing better. Patient states, however, there are an increasing amount of stressors between work and care-taking for her baby and she has been feeling more symptoms of paranoia (primarily feeling like people are talking about her and that she can mind-read). She has enough insight to realize these thoughts are intrusive but not always in the moment. Patient states she has not been sleeping for the past 3 days and this morning had an episode where she was feeling tingling and numbness in her fingers and was concerned this was catatonia. Overall, patient is feeling that she may not be able to carry on with work in the long-run and currently states she knows she is not able to take care of her daughter because she cannot trust her thoughts if they worsen beyond the point of insight. She has had no thoughts of hurting her baby or herself. Denies SI/HI. She is unsure about AH (sounds may be real). Denies VH. Husband states that he has not concerns about how she has been carrying for their daughter but agrees that patient would benefit from a break. Daughter is staying at patient's mother's place and care taking has been arranged. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: Hospitalizations: 1 in ___ at ___ for psychosis (intrusive thoughts, paranoid ideas, ideas of reference) Current treaters and treatment: Dr. ___ received a second-opinion regarding Risperdal (due to her breastfeeding) by Dr. ___ who felt that the clinical situation warranted the continuation of the risperdal and that very little gets into the breast milk. Medication and ECT trials: Geodon (but was too activating) and Risperdal (which has helped historically) Self-injury: denies Harm to others: denies Access to weapons: Husband has a gun but she does not know how to access it. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: none <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Born in ___ in a ___, patient was only 5lbs and mother only 90 lbs after birth per patient's report. Mother and patient were sponsored by family in ___ to come to ___ ___ and moved there. Later they moved to ___ where she was primarily raised. Generally did well in school. Went to ___ for college but had to take her last semester off due to hospitalization. Returned and went to ___ school and now works as an ___. She is married and has a supportive husband with a 6 month old daughter. <PHYSICAL EXAM> General: Well-nourished, in no distress. HEENT: Normocephalic. EOMI. Oropharynx clear. Neck: Supple, trachea midline. No adenopathy or thyromegaly. Back: No significant deformity, no focal tenderness. Lungs: Clear to auscultation; no crackles or wheezes. CV: Regular rate and rhythm; no murmurs/rubs/gallops Abdomen: Soft, nontender, nondistended; no masses or organomegaly. BS in all 4 quadrants Extremities: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Skin: Warm and dry, no rash or significant lesions. Neurological: *Cranial Nerves- I: Not tested
summary: PSYCHIATRIC # SI/HI: Pt never expressed any thoughts of hurting herself or others (including her baby) during her hospital stay. She did reveal some previous intrusive thoughts about suicide via throwing herself down the stairs which prompted her to seek tx. Pt now finds those thoughts highly egodystonic and has consistently denied any SI throughout the hospital stay. In addition, she has reported many coping skills and given examples of how she will and has used them. # PARANOID PSYCHOSIS Pt endorsed feeling more paranoid and suspicous of people on admission. She felt people were speaking negatively of her or trying to one up her. Initially, on the unit, she wondered if there were cameras watching her. Ms. ___ had good insight into her illness and did not completely identify with her paranoid thinking. As the illness had been well managed on risperdal in past, risperdal was continued and titrated to 2 mg qhs. Ms. ___ reported feeling more open to people on the unit and less suspicious and did not worry about being watched. Pt reported an increase in paranoia and feeling revved up after taking celexa 20 mg for a few days. It was uncertain if the increase in paranoia/restlessness was the emergence of hypomanic symptoms or a side effect of celexa which resolves after a few day. Celexa was decreased to 10 mg daily which patient tolerated and pt experienced resolve of her paranoia/restlessness. # DEPRESSION Ms. ___ expressed feeling ___ and unanimated even when caring for her child, poor concentration/memory and fatigue. Ms. ___ agreed that it was possible she may be depressed as she had not felt these symptoms during her last hospitalization for psychosis. Celexa 20 mg was started after explanation of side effects which included but were not limited to upset stomach, increased anxiety, and

Pt has had a progressive decline in his cognitive function for the last month. He is able to talk, dress himself, eat, but makes up stories, has poor short term memory, does not recall events, does not know year. He recalls the names of his family members. He still goes to work at ___ and goes to meetings but per family he does not know what is going on and just sits there. In the last 3 days he has had 3 falls. None of them were witnessed by family members. The first fall was 3 days ago where he was found on the floor and had a gash on his head. He states that he tripped but it was never witnessed. This morning, his wife heard a loud thump and found him on the floor between the bed and the dressor. He had urinated in his clothes. She helped him up and he was not able to recall what happened. At 9: 30 in the morning he had another fall to the floor, again not witnessed. Family denies any known bloody bowel movements. He has been taking in poor POs lately and has dark urine. According to patient: he has no recollection of the falls, however when it is brought up he says that he tripped on the floor. He has no complaints right now, he knows he is at ___ ___, thinks the year is ___, thinks it is ___. In the ED, initial vitals: 97.5 88 ___ 100% ra CT C spine: no fracture CT head: no acute process Foot, Knee CXR films all neg bedside echo: no pericardial effusion Labs: HCT 26, Na 130, K 5.3, trop neg x1 UA neg Vitals prior to transfer: 98 124/69 16 99% Admit for syncope workup. Upon arriving to the floor, patient said he had to go to the bathroom. He was brought to a commode, stood up, had a bowel movement (formed brown->few clots of blood after) and suddenly syncopized, was not conscious for a few seconds. During that time his HR on tele was 140s. His vitals quickly normalized thereafter and he was brought to the bed. Glucose 160s, BP 140/83, HR 85. EKG without any ST change or t wave changes. Orthostatics were positive with SBP 140->90s from lying to sitting. He was not able to stand because he felt so dizzy. He had 2 peripheral 20g IVs placed, typed and screened and crossmatched, given pantoprazole 40mg IV BID. HCT returned 27->24. He was given 1 PRBC and 1 L IVF bolus. Pt felt improved and vitals continued to stay stable. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> s/p AVR and CABG ___ -Aortic stenosis: echo ___ - severe <0.8. s/p bioprosthetic ___ and CABG x1 -HTN -Recurrent SBO -Osteoarthritis (knees) -Dysthymia -Depression -Varicose veins -Seborrheic keratoses -S/p pelvic fracture in ___ from mechanical fall -h/o squamous cell skin CA -Hemicolectomy ___ c/b infection and prolonged recovery -Multiple bowel surgeries for adhesions/obstruction -chronic pruritis- getting narrow band UVB therapy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father died at age ___ of heart disease, mother died at ___ of lung cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Exam VS - 98.3 140/ 83 85 18 100%ra, 67.8kg GENERAL - NAD, comfortable, knows where he is, doesnt know year or month, does know his name. HEENT - NC/AT, PERRLA, EOMI, sclerae anicteric, dry mucus membranes, poor skin turgor NECK - supple, no thyromegaly, no JVD HEART - PMI non-displaced, RRR, nl S1-S2, systolic murmur left sternal border LUNGS - CTAB ABDOMEN - NABS, soft/NT/ND, no masses or HSM, no rebound/guarding EXTREMITIES -no pedal edema SKIN - no rashes or lesions NEURO - awake, see above for mental status, CNs II-XII grossly intact, muscle strength ___ throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout Discharge Exam O: 98.2 122/59 65 18 98%RA Gen: No acute distress. No rash <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 12: 10PM BLOOD WBC-10.2 RBC-3.13* Hgb-8.9* Hct-26.9* MCV-86 MCH-28.6 MCHC-33.2 RDW-13.6 Plt ___ ___ 05: 40AM BLOOD WBC-9.6 RBC-3.98*# Hgb
summary: ___ with CAD, AS  CABG sp AVR (bioprosthetic valve ___, dementia presenting with 3 episodes of syncope and found to have GI bleed. #Syncope/Orthostatic Hypotension: Most likely etiology is orthostatic hypotension in setting of poor POs plus acute GI bleed. Positive orthostatics on exam. Pt found to have both melena and blood clots in stool. HCT dropped as low as 22 (HCT 26 in ___. He received total of 4 U PRBC and IVF. Orthostatics resolved. Cardiac enzymes negative for ACS, CT head neg for acute process. Patient did have briefly episodes of tachycardia with HR 150s in A fib/A flutter. This was felt most likely attributed to hypovolemia/acute GI bleed. HR improved when adequately rescucitated. #GI bleed: Pt found to have clots of blood in stool after having bowel movement as well as evidence of melena on exam. GI was consulted. Of note, his HCT in early ___ was 34 range and dropped to 26 in late ___. On admission, HCT 26 and dropped as low as 22. He was transfused total of 4 U PRBC. Started on PPI drip. Pt had endoscopy that showed peptic ulcer disease. He was started on omeprazole 40 mg BID. --> Will need follow up of H. pylori antibody and pathology of his biopsy #A fib/A flutter: Early during hospital course pt had episodes of A fib/flutter with HR up to 150s. This was in setting of acute GI bleed. After adequate recuscitation, HR improved to 70-80s in sinus rhythm. #Hyponatremia: Likely hypovolemic hyponatremia from poor POs and GI bleed. Improved to 135 with IVF. Cardiac/HTN: In setting of acute GI bleed, home metop 12.5mg BID was held which was restarted. Continued home ravastatin 40mg and asa 81. GERD: On home omeprazole 20mg. In setting of acute GI bleed he was given pantoprazole gtt. Discharged on omeprazole 40 mg BID.

In BI, t99.9, hr 71, 159/79, r14, 94%ra. Pt given home dose of ropinirole. GI c/s'd: plan for ERCP. . ROS: denies current abd pain. denies n/v/d. denies f/c. denies cp/cough/dyspnea. ROS otherwise negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> diverticulitis anemia RLS PE s/p IVC filter (THIS IS IN THE CHART BUT ___ ADAMANTLY DENIES; we need to confirm) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> no known h/o GI/pancreatic CA <PHYSICAL EXAM> t 98 bp 152/88 hr 74 r14 sat 99% ra gen: comfortable eomi, mmm no ___ neck supple chest clear rrr, ___ sem llsb abd: s/nt, mild distension, bs skin: jaundice ext w/wp without edema neur: non-focal <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 30PM WBC-5.6 RBC-4.30 HGB-12.6 HCT-39.1 MCV-91 MCH-29.2 MCHC-32.1 RDW-13.3 ___ 07: 30PM NEUTS-67.7 ___ MONOS-5.6 EOS-2.1 BASOS-0.5 ___ 07: 30PM PLT COUNT-213 ___ 07: 30PM ___ PTT-42.4* ___ ERCP Report A sphincterotomy was performed in the 12 o'clock position using a sphincterotome over an existing guidewire. Cytology samples were obtained for histology using a brush in the lower third of the common bile duct. A 7cm by ___ Cotton ___ biliary stent was placed successfully with upper end above the stricture and lower end in diodenum. Impression: Limited exam of the esophagus, stomach and duodenum was normal. Major papilla was normal in appearance Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and deep with a sphincterotome using a free-hand technique. Contrast medium was injected resulting in complete opacification. The procedure was not difficult. A single irregular 3.0 cm long stricture was seen at the lower end of CBD. There was mild post-obstructive dilation. A sphincterotomy was performed in the 12 o'clock position using a sphincterotome over an existing guidewire. Cytology samples were obtained for histology using a brush in the lower third of the common bile duct. A 7cm by ___ Cotton ___ biliary stent was placed successfully with upper end above the stricture and lower end in diodenum <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires futher investigation. 1. Ropinirole 1 mg PO QPM ___ notes report pt on celexa and ultram but pt denies (confirm with pcp in the AM) <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Ropinirole 1 mg PO QPM 2. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Please take for 5 days RX *ciprofloxacin 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*10 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Pancreatic mass Restless Leg Syndrome <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were transferred to ___ for evaluation of a mass on your pancreas and jaundice. You had a procedure called an ERCP and had a stent placed in your bile duct to relieve the jaundice. We are waiting results of brushings taken from your bile duct, but we suspect that this represents pancreatic cancer, as discussed with you. You will see your primary care doctor to discuss if you want to consider seeing an oncologist, or if you wish to focus on comfort. Please discuss your safety to drive with your PCP.
summary: ___ year old female with history of diverticulitis and anemia, presented to ___ with painless jaundice and pancreatic mass. Pancreatic head mass/biliary obstruction: Patient had ERCP and tolerated it well. She had a sphincterotomy and biliary stent placement. Brushings were obtained, but there is very high suspicion for pancreatic cancer. ___ staff discussed this finding with patient and her granddaughters, who are her health care proxies. At this time, patient appears inclined to pursue a comfort based approach. She will followup with her primary care doctor on discharge to discuss this further. She has been counselled that given the burden of her disease and her age that she would be a high risk surgical candidate. She will discuss with her pcp hospice as well as inquire into any role for palliative chemotherapy. Her code status should be discussed at her PCP ___. She expressed an interest in meeting with Oncology, if only to determine prognosis, so that she can have some sense of how much time she has left. She was treated with ciprofloxacin, which she will take for five days prophylactically given the extent of the ERCP. Abdominal aortic aneurysm: less than 5.5 cm; given her prognosis from pancreatic cancer, treatment of the aneurysm not indicated at this time. Social: Ms. ___ lost her husband of ___ years in ___ and is grieving his loss and is quite surprised by her diagnosis. She was seen by our social worker in house, and is well supported by her granddaughters. She would benefit from ongoing outpatient counselling/hospice support. RLS: Continued Ropipranole Transitional Issues: - Follow-up with PCP to discuss diagnosis and set-up Oncology to discuss prognosis.

Patient was transferred given concern for tracheostomy problem. Interventional Pulmonary evaluated her tracheostomy with bronchoscopy and found no significant issues, and suggested medical optimization. She completed a course of meropenem which started at her facility for recent PNA. Her pleural effusions are attributed to her CHF and volume overload, so patient was initiated on aggressive diuresis to continue at the facility. Of note, she did have scant GNRs growing from her sputum. # ___: ECHO here showed significant regurgitant mitral and aortic valvular disease as well as evidence of pulmonary hypertension, together with exam and dyspnea suggestive of volume overload. She was initiated on diuresis, to continue at facility for goal weight of 50kg. Pt not on beta blocker due to allergy. Consider ACE-I. summary: ___ year old male with past medical history of diastolic CHF, chronic atrial fibrillation on dabigatran, vascular dementia, recurrent transudative effusions thought to be secondary to CHF, admitted ___ w acute respiratory failure secondary to loculated pleural effusions and acute bacterial pneumonia, now status post chest tube placement, antibiotics, course notable for dysphagia, diagnosis of severe aortic regurgitation, course complicated by new ___, worsening respiratory status, ultimately transitioned to DNR/DNI, CMO, subsequently passing away on ___ # Acute Hypoxemic respiratory failure secondary to # Loculated Pleural Effusions # Atelectasis # Pneumothorax Patient had with recurrent L pleural effusion, attributed to his diastolic heart failure, initially admitted to ___ with newly loculated and enlarged bilateral effusions, prompting transfer to ___. Here he was seen by interventional pulmonary consult service, had bilateral chest tubes placed and received TPA/DNAse. Pleural fluid analysis showed transudative effusion on R side, exudative on L side. Pleural fluid cytology was negative. Given concern for possible pneumonia contribution, patient was treated with empiric antibiotics, but subsequent cross-sectional imaging did not reveal clear infiltrate. Per subsequent discussions with interventional pulm, initial effusions may have been secondary to CHF, with subsequent loculations secondary to prior bleeding/scarring from prior chest tubes. During this time patient's clinical status continued to worsen. TTE showed severe aortic regurgitation, felt to potentially be contributing to his worsening pulmonary edema and pleural effusions. Diuresis was limited by worsening renal function during this time. Given worsening clinical status, and antibiotics were subsequently broadened. Clinical status continued to worsen, thought to be secondary to his ___, underlying aortic regurgitation, and possible microaspirations (see below). Given persistent worsening of respiratory status, goals of care conversation with HCP (wife) and alternate (brother) was held and patient was transitioned to DNR/DNI, comfort measures only. Treated w/ morphine boluses PRN for respiratory distress, and passed away on ___. No

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> hypotension and weakness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None this hospitalization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ history of non-insulin-dependent diabetes, dementia, coronary peripheral vascular disease, poor historian, but complains of generalized weakness and fatigue of unclear chronicity as well as an episode of passing out in a seated position. He denies chest pain, dyspnea, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, cough, dysuria, but again is a somewhat poor historian. EMS found him with a heart rate of 40, and unable to obtain a blood pressure, but he was awake and alert. He reports several days of constipation. . On arrival, the patient was bradycardic at 40, and hypotensive with systolic blood pressure 70. Awake, alert, oriented x2. Neuro nonfocal. Abdomen soft, nontender, nondistended. Patient refused rectal exam. EKG shows sinus bradycardia. He was given 2 L of IV fluid without change in blood pressure. In response to 0.5 mg atropine, his heart rate improved to 60, but without blood pressure improvement. Dopamine at 5 mics per kilogram per minute did not improve blood pressure. Increase to 10 mics per kilogram per minute, went into atrial fibrillation rate 130, same blood pressure, dopamine discontinued. Started on low-dose levophed with improvement in blood pressure. Placed right IJ central line, sterile, a portable chest x-ray confirms okay to use. A foley was palced for urine and he got one dose of hydrocortisone, unasyn, and vancomycin and was admitted to the MICU for further management. . On arrival to the unit he is alert and oriented and mentating clearly on 0.1 of levophed. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Peripheral Vascular Disease Degenerative Joint Disease Dementia Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus Pontine CVA Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation Carotid Artery Disease . RESP: Decreased breath sounds at bases minimally, bilaterally without adventitious sounds. No wheezing, rhonchi or crackles. Stable inspiratory effort.
