DISCHARGE LABS: . ___ 05: 40AM BLOOD WBC-7.6 RBC-3.73* Hgb-11.0* Hct-32.4* MCV-87 MCH-29.4 MCHC-33.9 RDW-13.7 Plt ___
summary: IMPRESSION: ___ with a PMH significant for non-insulin-dependent diabetes (on oral agents), dementia, coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, carotid artery disease (s/p R CEA with 100% occlusion of the L CCA/ICA), CVA (right pontine), paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (on Coumadin) with reportedly chronic low blood pressure attributed to his PVD who presents following a near-syncopal event who was found to be hypotensive and bradycardic. . # HYPOTENSION - the patient initially presented with blood pressures 70/palp. He has had a past medical history of hypotension, with multiple recordings of systolics in the 90-100 mmHg range in the medical record. He was maintained on Levophed gtt briefly and then was stabilized for the medical floor, requiring a short MICU stay. The patient initially presented with near-syncope, but he maintained baseline mental status throughout his hospitalization. Given this elevated lactate, and his elevated creatinine and his leukocytosis, there was concern for sepsis inducing hypovolemia. However, he did not appear hypovolemic on exam and orthostatic vital signs were negative; he also maintained normal urine output. The patient was initially treated with broad spectrum antibiotics, but these were discontinued as it was thought that infection was unlikely. His thyroid and adrenal function were noted to be normal. An infectious work-up, endocrine work-up and Cardiology evaluation were all normal. Following volume resuscitation, his blood pressure in both arms was noted to be discordant. Vascular surgery noted left subclavian artery PVD which contributed to this discrepancy and his right blood pressure was reassuring. We resumed his home ACEI and beta-blocker following discovery of his unilateral hypotension. . # URETHRAL BLEEDING, HEMATURIA - The patient self-removed his Foley catheter on ___ overnight with the balloon inflated. Active bleeding was noted at the urethral meatus following the incident, which resolved with pressure. Urine output

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> seizure <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HPI: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M w/ active IV heroin use and hx of endocarditis in ___ who initially presented to the ED with primary complaint of right wrist pain after a fall. While in the ___ ED he had a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure and was admitted for further evaluation. Mr. ___ tells me that he was in his usual state of health prior to yesterday (the day of initial presentation). He has been using IV heroin regularly recently, injecting in his hands. He says that he used IV heroin on ___ and was feeling his usual self. On ___, he had decided that he wanted to quit using heroin, so he took suboxone, 4 mg SL x1 (acquired from friend/acquaintance, not prescribed to him), to attempt to precipitate rapid detox. He says that he has done this before and was able to detox at home using this method. His last attempt doing this was 9 months ago. He says that for the first hour he was doing OK, but then by the second hour he felt 25 times worse. After the ___ hour, he says he started having whole severe body muscle spasms, resulting in him being contorted into various positions and making his breathing somewhat erratic. He was getting worried, so he tried walking out of his bedroom to tell his roommate, when he has a ___ second muscle spasm/contortion and nearly fell. He then tried to make it to the kitchen to get some fluids to drink, but had a ___ second episode of spasm/contortion and fell, resulting in the right wrist injury that led him to call EMS and present to our ED. Of note, he denies any loss of consciousness during any of these episodes while he was at home. Says he had many more of the body contractions en route to the ED and while in the ED. He reports he wants to quit heroin because he still has a career that he is hoping to salvage and things to live for, that his heroin use is ruining/getting in the way of. He says he was able to be clean for ___ years, from ___. His last attempt at sobriety was inpatient detox at ___ in ___ about 2 months ago. He says he isn't particularly interested in trying either methadone or suboxone for opioid maintenance therapy, but would be interested in vivitrol. Says his usual symptoms of heroin withdrawal are watery eyes, shakes, yawning, aches, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He endorses a history of endocarditis, says it was in ___ and treated at ___. Says he has never had cardiac surgery. Denies recent fevers. Had chills when withdrawing from heroin. Denies HA, neck stiffness, cough, SOB, dysuria, or rash. He does not recall anything regarding the reported generalized tonic-clonic seizure that was witnessed in the ED. He denies any prior history of seizures or any known family history of seizure disorder. Regarding his right wrist, says it is currently in severe, constant pain, pain meds helped in ED, movement exacerbates but it is now splinted. Denies associated numbness or tingling of distal fingers. Of note, he had head laceration (right forehead) that was sutured in the ED. ROS: Reports chronic insomnia, takes trazodone nightly (for the past ___ years). 10 systems reviewed and negative except as noted in HPI above. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -IV heroin use since age ___ (with period of sobriety from ___ --complicated by endocarditis ___, ___  ___, he did not have any additional details PSHx: denies any chest, cardiac or abdominal surgeries in the past <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> denies family hx of seizure d/o <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: reviewed ___ ___ Temp: 98.6 PO BP: 121/65 HR: 89 RR: 18 O2 sat: 98% O2 delivery: RA Gen: NAD but modestly disheveled Head: small, sutured laceration on right forehead HEENT: EOMI, anicteric, no resting nystagmus, MMM, tongue is swollen on the right with evidence of tongue-biting injury on dorsal aspect of right anterolateral tongue without active bleeding or any evidence of purulence/infection Neck: no LAD Chest: CTAB, normal WOB Cardiovasc: RR, no m/r/g, 2 DP and radial pulses, no stigmata of endocarditis, no peripheral edema Abd: S, NT, ND, BS GU: no CVA tenderness to percussion MSK: grossly normal strength in LUE, b/l LEs; RUE in wrist splint w/ normal appearing elbow Skin: track marks on left hand Neuro: awake, alert, oriented x4, clear speech, tongue is midline, no tremor, no asterixis Psych: calm, cooperating <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 30
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with active IV heroin use who p/w right wrist fracture from fall in setting of attempted home detox w/ suboxone and reports of generalized muscle spasms. ED course was complicated by generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Admitted for further evaluation. # Seizure Isolated incident possibly related to drug use and withdrawal. MRI negative. Exam re-assuring. He left the hospital before we could consider EEG but in discussion with neurology we felt it was ok to have this as an outpatient. FOllow up was arranged and strongly encouraged. He was counseled on risks for seizure and to not drive or be in water alone. # Muscle spasms/contortions # Fall w/o loss of consciousness - suspect due to acute opioid withdrawal precipitated by patient's self-administration of suboxone. CK minimally elevated # IV heroin use  dependence: he said he wants to get clean. ___ RN met with patient and he was treated supportively. He chose to leave the hospital before we could fully help him with this issue # HEPATITIS # HCV: mild, hepatocellular, without evidence of synthetic liver dysfunction or hepatic encephalopathy. HCV . It is unclear if he knows about his status. He left the hospital before this could be reviewed with the patient. We would recommend HIV testing as well. # Right distal radius fracture: s/p closed reduction in ED by Hand surgery team - ___ - keep R hand elevated and encourage finger ROM - Hand clinic f/u after discharge - Given a limited course of Naproxen for pain # Right forehead laceration - sutured in ED - if has progressive alteration in mental status, would obtain repeat CT head to evaluate for evidence of TBI Patient found smoking in room with friends trying to distract nursing. On evaluation he is eager to leave. I expressed my overall concern and offered to have him remain hospitalized for further addiction support, which

summary: ___ h/o locally advanced pancreatic CA s/p 6 cycles chemo who presented with bilateral leg pain and difficulty ambulating, found to have progressive metastatic disease, now being enrolled in a clinical trial. #LEG PAIN #Weakness #Weakness #Foot drop MRI in ___ ruled out cord compression, but there was significant amount of degenerative changes and known spinal stenosis with neural formal narrowing at lumbar levels. ___ negative for evidence of DVT. Able to walk but with intermittent subjective weakness, may be related to underlying spinal stenosis (ie, worse with standing up). CK not elevated to suggest a steroid myopathy. TSH slightly high but T4 normal. inc mildly deficient and repleting with MVI, copper/B6 normal. Neurology consulted, EMG completed, and was positive for R foot drop. Obtained MRI pelvis per neuro recs which showed no evidence of sacral plexus compression/involvement by tumor. Gave brief course of rapidly tapered dexamethasone which improved her symptoms. [] Follow-up as outpatient for AFO fitting (order was placed in OMR) [] Patient will need to arrange for follow-up with Dr. ___ in neurology upon discharge # Metastatic pancreatic cancer CEA rising (35 ___ to 50 ___ and has evidence of disease progression on CT ___. Patient made aware of advancement of disease, palliative care involved. Primary team involved and have consented for clinical trial. Obtained CT guided biopsy of liver prior to discharge. Also placed NJ as below to optimize nutrtional status. [] Follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___ # Severe protein calorie malnutrition # Roux-en-Y gastrectomy # Affarent limb sydrome # S/p gastro-gastric Axios stent placement: Malnutrition has been a significant issue She is not a candidate for G-tube due to anatomy. summary: ___ year old female with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, uterine cancer, recent gallstones s/p ERCP p/w R leg pain for the last 3 days, imaging negative, found to have ARF. . #. R Hip pain. A CT of the pelvis was performed which demonstrated no acute fracture. On arrival to the floor, her R hip pain was ___. She was started on her home dosing of ultram. Given her description of pain and negative imaging, this pain is likely musculoskeletal in nature or due to her extensive degenerative joint disease. She also had significant point tn___ suggestive of fibromyalgia. The following morning she rpeoirted an improvement in her hip pain. Her dose of tramadol was reduced to 50mg PO daily and she was started on tylenol 1g PO q8, neurontin 200mg PO qhs and oxycodone 5mg PO q 6 hours as needed. Physical therapy saw her, and she could not walk secondary to hip pain, and rehab was recommended. Patient was discharged to rehab in stable condition. If needed she could benefit from increased neurontin and/or oxycodone prn. . #. Acute Renal Failure. Patient had a history of renal insufficiency with recent treatment with lasix. On arrival to the floor, she had dry mucous membranes, but 2 pitting edema to the knees. She was given 1L of normal saline IV and her creatinine improved to her baseline of 1.5 the following day. Her HCT dose was decreased from 25mg daily to 12.5 mg daily. . #. Hypertension. Well controlled on atenolol, diovan, and HCT. Her HCT dose was decreased to 12.5mg daily . #. Hyperlipidemia. Patient was continued on her home simvastatin. . #. Depression. Patient was continued on her home citalopram.

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with a recent pulmonary embolism in ___ who presented with one week of exertional dyspnea and chest pressure. ACTIVE ISSUES 1. Dyspnea: Patient's difficulty on exertion and chest pressure were concerning for unstable angina given patient's age; however, two negative sets of enzymes and unremarkable stress test in ___ were reassuring. She underwent a repeat pharmacologic stress test and cardiac imaging, which did not show evidence of ischemia. Patient has a recent PE in ___ however, no further PE's were seen on a repeat CTA. We considered an exacerbation of her diastolic CHF, but patient was not clinically volume overloaded. Patient had a repeat TTE (please see results section) and was continued on ASA 81 mg daily and rosouvastatin. Her coumadin was continued. Given lack of evidence of cardiac disease, patient was referred to pulmonology upon discharge. 2. Recent Unprovoked PE: Patient had no evidence of recurrent PE on CTA. She is up-to-date on colonoscopy and mammogram per recent discharge summary. We continued home dose of coumadin (on 6-month course for unprovoked PE). 3. Small pericardial effusion: Patient had a small pericardial effusion on imaging, which was also noted during her prior admission. She had no evidence of tamponade. 4. Lung nodules: Three lung nodules were noted to be stable on ___ CTA. Nodules were unlikely related to current presentation. Patient needs repeat CT for monitoring in 12 months. CHRONIC ISSUES 1. Cardiomegaly: Unchanged from baseline 2. Possible Diastolic CHF: LVEF > 55%. Diagnosis suggested by impaired LV relaxaion on ___ ECHO. Patient was not volume overloaded. 3. HTN: Patient was continued on amlodipine, terazosin, and HCT. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - Needs follow-up CT lung in 12 months to monitor lung nodules - Follow-up with Pulmonary for further work-up of dyspnea

summary: Mr. ___ was a same day admit after undergoing pre-operative work-up as an outpatient. On day of admission he was brought to the operating room where he underwent a mitral valve repair. Please see operative report for surgical details. Following surgery he was transferred to the CVICU for invasive management in stable condition. Later on op day he was weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and extubated. On post-op day one his chest tubes were removed and he was transferred to the telemetry floor for further care. He was also started on beta blockers and diuretics and gently diuresed towards his pre-op weight. Epicardial pacing wires were removed on post-op day three. He continued to progress quite well post-op and worked with physical therapy for strength and mobility. On post-op day 5 he was discharged home with ___ services and the appropriate follow-up appointments.

summary: Assessment/Plan: Patient is a ___ year old generally healthy male who presents with adbominal pain. CT of the abdomen revealed massive mesenteric and intraperitoneal lymphadenopathy concerning for lymphoma. He underwent open abdominal lymph node excisional biopsy given no palpable or easily accessible lymph nodes peripherally. Treatment decisions and appropriate consults depend on pathology results. . #. Acute Renal Failure on CKD stage 1 or 2: Patient's last creatinine 1.1 in ___. Current creatinine may be progression of underlying kidney disease. CT : no hydronephrosis. His creatinine improved with IV hydration. His hyperkalemia resolved. He needs to follow up with his PCP regarding further work up for renal failure if this progress ( related or unrelated to possible underlying lymphoma) . . #Anemia with low serum iron and retic count but normal ferritin and TIBC. MCV low normal: anemia of chronic disease on mild iron defeciency Further work up is needed by his PCP. This could be related to CKD, or chronic mild GI bleed related or unrelated to possible GI lymphoma. . . . This was communicated with his PCP.. . . . Total D/C time of 67 minutes.

summary: The patient was evaluated in the emergency department and found to have a type III dens fracture, so she was admitted to the neurosurgery floor. She was placed in hard collar for stabilization of her neck. Because of her history of neck trauma, her past ___ surgeries, as well as her general bone health, she was converted to a halo crown/vest for definitive stabilization. Repeat imaging confirmed appropriate reduction of the C2 fracture post-halo placement. She worked with physical therapy who determined that she was safe for discharge to home with home ___. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well controlled with oral medications, the pin sites were clean/dry/intact, the vest was on appropriately, the patient was ambulating safely, was voiding and moving bowels spontaneously, and the patient's neurological exam was stable. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis, appropriate use of the halo vest including the need to keep a wrench on her at all times, and expected post-discharge course, and all questions were answered.

The volume of bright red blood he had while EMS was there is unknown and his blood pressure was noted to be in the ___ by EMS. . On arrival to the ICU vitals were ___ 22 98%. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old man with a history of CAD s/p recent DES on ASA and Plavix presents with recurrent upper GI bleed with known ulcer at the site of his anastomosis. He was admitted to the Medical service for management and then was intubated for airway protection. In the MICU he was resuscitated with 11 units of pRBC in the first 12 hours of his hospitalization t maintain a HCT in the low 30's. A Protonix drip was started, ASA and Plavix were held. EGD demonstrated ulcer at the site of anastomosis but no evidence of active bleed. Pt with large adherent clot. Epinephrine was injected. However, he continued to lose blood. He was taken to the Operating Room urgently for an exploratory laparotomy. He tolerated the procedure well and returned to the ICU in stable condition maintaining a stable hematocrit and blood pressure. He was gradually weaned and extubated from the respirator the next day and subsequently developed some throat discomfort and occasional wheezes. He improved with humidified air and nebulizer treatments. ENT was consulted and a bedside laryngoscopy was done which was normal with no edema or obstruction. From a cardiac standpoint given his history he underwent R/O Mi protocol at the time of his admission and post operatively. He had a mild Troponin bump to 0.08 along with lateral ST depression on his EKG which was attributed to demand ischemia in the setting of a GI bleed. He had no chest pain post operatively. Following transfer to the Surgical floor he continued to make good progress. Due to his poor nutritional status prior to surgery he began hyperalimentation but was soon able to tolerate a regular diet and gradually increased his calories. He was having normal bowel movements and his abdominal wound was healing well.with minor redness at the staple sites. He was evaluated by the Physical Therapy service due to his recent multiple admissions and deconditioning and he worked with them daily to improve his endurance. Afre an uncomplicated

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Left arm pain/ weakness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o gentleman w a h/o of ___ LC s/p VATS in ___ removing a 1.4 cm, undifferentiated, small cell lung cancer with negative margins. He also completed 4 cycles of cisplatin and etopaside and cranial radiation in ___. Over the last number of months, his outpatient provider have been concerned about his status because he had not quite fully returned to baseline. He had been having some problems with appetite and weight loss, but no definite evidence of recurrent disease on laboratroy or imaging data until ___ when a followup chest CT scan for surveillance showed a new lytic bone lesion in the right anterior 4th rib with some pleural and possibly muscular extension. In addition, he has new densities in the liver consistent with liver metastases compared to ___. He has a new or possibly increased 6-mm pulmonary nodule in the left lower lobe. He had an appointment with Dr. ___ on ___ to review the results of this scan, but presented to ___ with worse left arm pain and weakness and was found to be hyponatremic to 119. He was placed on a 1L Na restriction and his Na improved to 120, he was started on NaCl tabs 1 gm ___ and transferred to BID. Urine na was 118, serum osm 240, urine osm 529. INR 1.6 at discharge. Coumadin recently held ofr liver biospy and ucfrently being bridged with lovenox. On arrival to the floor, patient was VSS, only complaining of left shoulder pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: - ___: Hemoptysis while on anti-coagulation for AFib, for which he was referred to a pulmonologist. CT chest showed ground glass opacities in the right upper lobe and a pleural-based density in the lingula, as well as a 2-3 mm right upper lobe nodule. - ___: Bronchoscopy negative for malignancy. - ___: Chest CT shows 6 mm right upper lobe nodule and near- resolution of previous ground glass opacities. - ___: Repeat chest CT shows right upper lobe nodule increased to 8 mm in size. - ___: PET-CT shows FDG uptake in a 9 mm right upper lobe nodule, concerning for malignancy. - ___: VATS with RUL wedge resection, followed by right upper lobectomy by Dr. ___. Pathology showed 1.4 cm, undifferentiated, small cell lung cancer with negative margins. Lymph nodes positive at stations 10R, 11R, and 12R, and negative at 2R, 4R, and 7. pT1aN1Mx, limited stage. - ___: MRI brain with no evidence of metastatic disease. - ___: Initial medical oncology visit - ___: CT chest with mediastinal lymph node enlargement (could be post-operative enlargement, but remains suspicious). - ___: C1D1 cisplatin/etoposide - ___: C2D1 cisplatin/etoposide and start of XRT to right hilum and mediastinum. - ___: C3D1 cisplatin/etoposide. - ___: MRI brain normal. - ___: C4D1 cisplatin/etoposide. - ___: Completes radiotherapy. - ___: Admitted to ___ with orthostasis, ___, and neutropenia without fever. - ___: Orthostatic with ___, given IVF and metoprolol dosage decreased. - ___: Continued orthostasis and ___, given further IVF. - ___: PET scan shows mild uptake in multiple mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes, which have decreased in size. - ___: Undergoes prophylactic cranial irradiation. - ___: PET scan shows FDG-avid consolidative opacities in the right lower lobe and paramediastinal aspect of the right middle lobe (likely post-radiation pneumonitis and/or infection), less extensive opacities in the anterointerior aspect of the right middle lobe with low level FDG-avidity (likely post-radiation), and no significant change in FDG-avid right hilar lymphadenopathy (possibly reactive). - ___: Bronchoscopy (performed because of hemoptysis while INR was 4.0) shows no airway lesions. Slight bleeding was identified at the takeoff of the left mainstem bronchus just proximal to the main carina. Electrocautery was performed at the site and the bleeding resolved. - ___: MRI brain shows no evidence of metastatic disease. - ___: CT chest shows no evidence of local recurrence, with smaller mediastinal lymph nodes since ___ and minimal interval increase of the right pleural effusion. - ___: CT torso shows new soft tissue right paratracheal station or non-opacified azygous vein, stable right lung radiation fibrosis, stable small right pleural effusion, mild cardiomegaly with predominantly biatrial enlargement, and no evidence of metastatic disease within the abdomen or pelvis. - ___: Surveillance CT torso shows that the previously-noted soft tissue along the right lower paratracheal station was due to a non-opacified portion of the azygos vein, with decrease in size of a small right pleural effusion. A new 3 mm
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o gentleman w a h/o of ___ LC s/p VATS in ___ removing a 1.4 cm, undifferentiated, small cell lung cancer with negative margins. He also completed 4 cycles of cisplatin and etopaside and cranial radiation in ___. Over the last number of months, his outpatient provider have been concerned about his status because he had not quite fully returned to baseline. He presented to ___ with left arm pain and weakness and found to be hyponatremic to 119. He was placed on a fluid restriction and salt tabs and transferred to ___. Imaging from ___ had revealed a new lytic bone lesion in the right anterior 4th rib with some pleural and possibly muscular extension. In addition, he has new densities in the liver consistent with liver metastases compared to ___, and had liver biopsy that was positive for undifferentiated small cell carcinoma. He has a new or possibly increased 6-mm pulmonary nodule in the left lower lobe as well. He was initiated on carboplat/etoposide ___ and he tolerated the treatment well. His Na trended up with the fluid restriction as well. Warfarin which was initially held in the setting of a liver biopsy was continued throughout the admission with a brief bridge with enoxaparin. INRs were therapuetic throughout his stay in the hospital. Regarding his left shoulder pain and hand weakness he underwent an MRI C spine that confirmed likely metastatic lesions occupying the neural foramen but without cord compression. Radiation oncology was consulted and recommended monitoring on chemotherapy with outpatient consideration for radiation therapy. Transitional Issues -will likely need ___ treatment on ___ -trend Na (on Discharge Na was 123) -Full Code -will need f/u with radiation oncology for consideration of radiation treatment of C6 T1 lesions

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> cdiff colitis <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ yo man, previously healthy, who was transferred from an OSH for CRS and GI evaluation for CDiff colitis, concern for IBD, microperforation and abscess. The patient reports that for the past ___ weeks he has been having cramping abdominal pain, relieved with BMs and diarrhea ___ times per day. About a week prior to admission to ___ (was at ___ for 9 days) he started having severe cramping abdominal pain and diarrhea constant throughout the day, reportedly going small amounts of liquid stool about every few minutes. He presented himself to ___ where he was found to have extensive colitis and concern for microperforation given free air in the peritoneum. He was admitted to surgery where the plan was for explaroatory laparotomy and ___ procedure but the patient declined in favor of medical management. There he was treated with IV Flagly and PO Vanc and GI was consulted. A repeat CT showed extensive colitis and concern for multi-loculated abscess. Again he was offered surgery but he declined. Apparently there was disagreement between GI and CRS at ___ for which the patient was uncomfortable with. Surgery at ___ consulted CRS here and eventually the decision was made to transfer him here for GI and CRS consultation, possible Flex Sig with biopsy to distinguish IBD vs pseudomembrane colitis. Of note, he reports that he has been having cramping abdominal pain and ___ BMs per day for about 3 months though he admits it has probably been longer and his wife indicates it has been ongoing for about a year. Prior to last year normally he would have BMs ___ times per day and he recounts have abdominal issues dating back to childhood. More recently the diarrhea was continuous, associated with severe cripling abdominal pain, fevers, diaphoresis and chills. He reports that over the last 3 days he has been feeling markedly better with resolution for fevers and chills and reduction in BMs to ___ times per day. He reports that this morning was the first almost normal BM, indicates it was soft but not formed, and he has had 3 BMs today. Currently he feels so much better than prior and is eager to get this all treated Review of systems: () Per HPI (-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Looking for rectal stricture or mass TECHNIQUE: Multidetector CT images of the abdomen and pelvis were obtained with intravenous and rectal contrast administration. Sagittal and coronal reformations were also performed. Patient will follow up with Dr. ___ Dr. ___ in ___ for repeat CT, abx management, and colonoscopy. He will be sent home with antibiotics as recommended by ID.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Codeine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> hyperbilirubinemia, cholangitis <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> percutaneous biliary tube drainage <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Attending Admission Note Date: ___ Time: 2230 PCP: ___, ONC: ___ HPI: ___ yo M with pancreatic CA metastatic to lungs, liver with multiple recent admissions and interventions on his biliary tract s/p ERCP with placement of pigtail stent through metal stent on ___ who went to see Dr. ___ yesterday in clinic and was noted to have a rising bilirubin. He was referred to the ED for admission to arrange percutaneous biliary drainage and to initiate discussion about hospice care. He is currently feeling relatively comfortable. summary: Mr. ___ is an ___ with history of pancreatic cancer with mets to lungs, liver with multiple recents ERCPs, recently discharged ___ for cholangitis s/p pigtail drain placed through metal stent to help facilitate flow who is presenting again with rising Tbili and fevers c/w cholangitis now s/p perc biliary drain with anemia of acute blood loss and peritoneal signs on exam, which have since improved. # Cholangitis: The patient is presenting with rising bili, white count, and fevers consistent with cholangitis. He has had multiple biliary interventions in the previous weeks, most recently placement of pigtail stent through metal stent on ___. The patient was initially started on vanc, as well as cipro/flagyl for cholangitis (he has PCN allergy). His vanc was discontinued and he was continued on the cipro/flagyl. He had perc biliary drain placed by ___. After placement of the perc biliary drain, the patient's Tbili started trended down. He was discharged home with another five days of Cipro/Flagyl to complete a ___nd his drains were capped prior to discharge. The patient will have to follow up with an ___ as an outpatient in 6 weeks for drain exchange. # hypotension: After placing of the perc biliary drain, the patient became hypotensive; he initially triggered upon return to the floor for systolic blood pressures in the ___, and was given 2L NS. After getting fluid, the patient's pressures remained stable in the ___ 100s systolic. The patient remained asytmptomatic throughout the episodes, denying any light headednessness or dizziness, and mentating well. # Anemia of acute blood loss: The patient was found to have crit drop from 28 on admission to 22. It was thought that this was in the setting of recent perc biliary drain placement. The patient received one unit of PRBC on ___ and upon discharge his crits were stable and there were no signs of bleeding that were evident. # Peritonitis: The patient had perc biliary drain

While you were here you were worked up for chest pain for possible concern of damage to your heart. All testing revealed that there was no heart attack and further work up is not necessary at this time. You will be discharged home on a new medication called a beta-blocker, Metoprolol, in addition to restarting your aspirin (baby aspirin) daily. You should return to exercise gradually. The beta-blocker slows the heart rate and decreases demands on the heart. However, it can also cause low blood pressures. If you feel lightheaded or dizzy after taking this medication, discontinue use and call your doctor. If you have a return of symptoms, or if you have shortness of breath, sweating, nausea or vomiting in the setting of chest pain, then you should return to the hospital. summary: #Chest pain - Atypical chest pain. No previous events with normal echo ___ and normal stress. Primary cardiac risk factor is DM. Quit smoking ___ years ago. Negative work-up with resting EKG, troponins, ETT, CT chest. However, persistent dull ache in his left shoulder graded ___. 8.4% ___ ___ risk. Discussed role of cardiac catheterization. Given low probability of significant occluding lesion, medical management would be most likely course with or without catheterization. Patient acknowledged understanding of the discussion and agreed with medical management only at this time. He was reassured that pain was atypical, though he was advised to return if worsening symptoms or associated dyspnea, lightheadedness, nausea, vomiting, diahporesis. He was started on beta-blockade and advised to restart taking a baby aspirin that had previously been discontinued during resection of his Rectal Ca. Statin continued. ___ - Chronic kidney disease in setting of sarcoidosis and previously poorly controlled diabetes with baseline creatinine since ___ between 1.1-1.2. Presented with elevated creatinine to 2.0 at ___ prior to transfer. Fluids were started and creatinine decreased to 1.3 suggesting pre-renal etiology. IV fluids were continued and PO intake encouraged. No further work-up for ___. Defer further management of renal disease to outpatient provider. #HTN - Well controlled on this visit on home regimen of ___. #DM - Apparently well-controlled by diet and oral hypoglycemics, having previously been on insulin. Oraal anti-hyperglycemics were held and insulin correction scale was started. No significant perturbations in blood glucose observed on this hospitalization.

summary: The patient is ___ year old female with history of ulcerative colitis status post J pouch and diverting ileostomy who presents with small bowel obstruction. The patient was taken to the operating room. Reader is referred to the operative note for details of the surgery. After recovery in the PACU, patient was transferred to the surgical unit for further monitoring. The patient was slow with recovery, and her bowels were slow to move after the procedure. She required several fluid boluses over the next few days, for decrease urine output.Electrolytes were monitored closely and replaced accordingly. Due to her increase abdominal distension and no flatus she was kept NPO with IVF. KUB was performed which was consistent with postoperative ileus. Patent declined placement of NGT at this time. Serial abdominal exams were continued. Octreotide was started to decrease GI secretions. Due to her persistent symptoms of abdominal distention, patient eventually agreed to placement of NGT. CT scan of the abdomen was obtained which showed no evidence of small bowel obstruction or anastomotic leak. POD 6, patient had decrease abdominal distension and minimal nasogastric tube output. Thus, NGT was discontinued. KUB was performed which showed small bowel dilatation stable since prior study. The diet was advanced to fulls and octreotide was discontinued. However, the diet was not tolerated well due to abdominal distention. Thus the diet was backed down to sips and slowly advanced to regular over the next few days. By POD 8, patient subjectively felt well and was tolerating a regular diet. However,she was noted to have high stool output greater than 1350 cc in a 24 hour period. Therefore she was started on loperamide was started to decrease her stool output. Her stool output was monitored closely and began to taper down to more appropriate volume. Of note during this hospitalization, she was treated for an abdominal wound infection with a 24 hour course of IV antibiotics Cefazolin (discontinued on POD 6)There was some purulence expressed from her abdominal incision and a few staples were

summary: ___ w/PMHx MELAS, achalasia presents with cough x ___ likely ___ viral URI found to desat to ___ on ambulation likely ___ microaspiration due to esophageal dysmotility and possible shunting across PFO. Active issues: # Hypoxia: Patient was noted to desat to ___ with minimal exertion. Patient was not wheezing. Resolved immediately with rest. ABG revealed pO2 of 78 at rest/RA (satting 99-100%). Concern for continued microaspiration events in setting of achalasia (though patient denies symptoms) vs shunting (pt noted to have PFO on ECHO in ___ vs combination. Patient does not desat with standing. With walking, she desats to 70 and feels tired and needs to sit down. With 2L NC, she maintains a sat of 96-100 with walking, though still feels a bit tired. Pulmonology, GI and Cardiology were all consulted to assess this patient as it was unclear why she having such profound hypoxia with walking. CT Chest revealed worsening opacities consistent with microaspiration events most likely occurring at night. Pt underwent esophageal manometry and barium swallow which were abnormal. GI recommended that pt be evaluated as an outpt for ___ myotomy and pt was discharged with appt to see Dr. ___ the surgery department. ECHO revealed similar cardiac function as previously but Pulmonology was still concerned about shunting across the PFO. Plan was made for pt to be evaluated by Dr. ___ as an outpt after obtaining PFTs. She will also follow-up with GI and Pulmonology. Patient was discharged with O2 for both ambulation and to wear at night (pt noted to desat at night on a previous admission). Emphasis was placed on the need to be compliant with oxygen therapy as it was noted that prior to this admission, pt had been unable to establish care with outpt providers as she would show up hypoxic to appts and be sent to the ED. As she is ___ on RA

Cholelithiasis. No intra or extra hepatic biliary duct dilation. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> none <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> none <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> acute cholecystitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Please follow the instructions below upon discharge: <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please resume all regular home medications unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take any new medications as prescribed. Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity restrictions. Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications. Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider (PCP) as advised. Incision Care: *Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision site. *Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment. *You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap and warm water. Gently pat the area dry. *If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up appointment. *If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
summary: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain. Admission RUQ ultrasound demonstrated findings consistent with acute cholecystitis. The patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which went well without complication. The gallbladder appeared severely inflammed, however. After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor with good pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable. The patient was given Unasyn for an additional day given the severe inflammation seen intra-op. Pain was well controlled. Diet was progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

The patients VS were stable in the ED, she was given pain medications and sent to the floor. . On the floor, the patient says her pain was a ___ with dilaudid, but is now back up to a ___. summary: This is a ___ yo F with a PMHx of CCY in ___ who now p/w progressive epigastric pain with a normal WBC, no fevers and a clear CXR but an elevated t. bili with a cholestatic pattern . ##epigastric pain with a h/o CCY. Ms. ___ had a recent cholecystectomy and had elevated LFT's suggestive of an obstructive CBD ___ choledocholithiasis. Lipase was within normal limit and there was no evidence of pancreatitis. She underwent an abd CT - which showed no extrinsic mass or abscess in the RUQ area to account for her symptoms. An ERCP showed small stones with the common bile duct causing partial obstruction. Several 4-5 mm stones were extracted and a sphincterotomy was done. She tolerated this procedure well and noticed substantial improvements in her abd pain with corresponding improvements in her lFTs. She did not require any pain medications or antiemetics on the day of discharge. She tolerated PO solids without difficulty and was discharged in good condition. The liver hemangioma was again noted on the abd CT - and was eval'd by MRI at the OSH. . ##HTN -cont lisinopril 20 QD . ##Depression - continue seroquel. . ##Prophy -heparin sc . ##Code -full . ##Contact -___ ___ .

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the Operating Room where he underwent a right VATS with right lower lobectomy. He tolerated the procedure well and returned to the PACU in stable condition. He maintained stable hemodynamics after fluid resuscitation and his pain was in adequate control. Following transfer to the Surgical floor his epidural catheter was removed on post op day #1 and he was able to cough and use his incentive spirometer effectively but his volumes gradually decreased and eventually desaturated to the mid 80's. He has a chest CTA done to rule out PE which was negative but he had right middle lobe collapse due to secretions. He was transferred to the SICU for close observation and vigorous pulmonary toilet. He eventually required bronchoscopy and lavage to remove his secretions and following that was able to maintain saturations in the 94% range on 2.5 to 3 liters. He remained afebrile and his WBC gradually decreased from 15K to 10K. He was transferred back to the Surgical floor to complete his recovery. He has an effective cough and continues to use his incentive spirometer. Due to his prolonged hospitalization he was evaluated by the Physical Therapy service due to his prolonged oxygen needs as well as his limited mobility. They felt that he was able to go home with ___, home ___ and oxygen. His ambulatory saturations off of oxygen was 85%. He eventually was able to maintain saturations of 96% on 2 liters of oxygen. His right chest port sites were healing well and he was tolerating a regular, diabetic diet with blood sugars in the 170-190 range. His metformin will be restarted. He was discharged to home on ___ on home O2 and ___ services. He will follow up in the Thoracic Clinic in ___ weeks.

summary: ___ is a ___ year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral neuropathy, chronic low back pain, osteoarthritis s/p bilateral total knee replacement, and post-traumatic stress disorder admitted with bilateral lower extremity weakness and polyuria. ACTIVE DIAGNOSES ================ # Lower extremity weakness and pain: She presented with lower extremity weakness and pain, which caused her to fall prior to presentation. This is in the setting of many evaluations in years prior for falls. She had an MRI of the spine which did not reveal evidence of cord compression. She had an elevated CK on admission that trended down, suggestive of muscle injury in the setting of a fall, as opposed to myositis. She was evaluated by the neurology team. As there was no clear organic etiology for the weakness and pain, conversion disorder or factitious disorder were considered possible. Her pain was managed with oxycodone and acetaminophen. She regained strength on motor exam throughout her hospitalization and worked with physical therapy. By the time of discharge she was able to ambulate under her own power. # Type 2 diabetes mellitus: She has a history of type 2 diabetes and had not been taking her home oral medications for the month prior to admission. She had polyuria and glucosuria upon presentation. Her blood glucose levels were in the high 200s to 300s. She had poor glycemic control in the 3 months prior to admission as evidenced by her A1C of 17.1%. We continued to hold metformin and glipizide, which she had not been taking, during her hospitalization. She was placed on a low carbohydrate diet. Insulin glargine and an insulin sliding scale were instituted during her early hospitalization. However, she did not wish to tolerate finger sticks and insulin injections, and therefore began to refuse. Underlying this appeared to be a desire to ignore the severity of her diabetes. She was able to clearly state the risks of

summary: ASSESSMENT  PLAN: ___ y/o female DMII, HTN, spinal stenosis, h/o L breast CA s/p radical mastectomy (___) presents with hypoxia and SOB from rehab after recent ankle/wrist fracture. # Shortness of breath: The patient presented with transient hypoxia from the outside hospital. This lasted for a number of minutes and then completely resolved. Per reports, the patient also desaturated with physical therapy. She presented to ___ and was breathing and satting well on room air. She stated that she was at her baseline. She was initially started on a heparin drip and had a V/Q scan. The V/Q scan was negative. The heparin drip was discontinued and then she was restarted on SC heparin. Her shortness of breath did not come back and the patient continued to maintain good saturations (> 94% on room air). CXR without evidence of pneumonia. She was also ruled out for MI with cardiac enzymes and EKGs which were unchanged. She was discharged back to rehab. # CXR finding: Initial portable CXR in ED showed nodular opacity in lower left lobe. repeat CXR did not show evidence of this lesion. Would recommend repeat imaging (PA and Lateral films)to reassess this lesion in the next ___ weeks. . # s/p recent right humerus fracture and left distal fibular fracture: As per last discharge summary. She is weight bearing on her L fibula fracture and pendulum motions with a sling on her right humerus fracture. Her pain was controlled with lidocaine patch, tramadol, oxycodone, tylenol. She was discharged to rehab for further physical therapy. # Acute kidney injury: She had a creatinine of 1.5 on admission from a baseline of 1.3. She was given some fluid and returned to her baseline creatinine making poor PO intake the likely etiology. She was discharged to rehab and encouraged to take POs. # Diabetes type II: She was maintained on an insulin sliding scale while an inpatient. She will resume her

summary: ___ female with fibrosing mesenteritis, s/p multiple abdominal surgeries with adhesions and SBOs, here with SBO. The following issues were investigated during this hospitalization: . #. Abdominal pain/SBO: SBO suggested on imaging and clinically. Surgery was consulted and felt that the patient was again, not a surgical option. Thus, management was conservative with IVF, pain control, antiemetics and decompression with g-tube placed to suction. Patient underwent a previously scheduled, routine g-tube change while in-house without complication. She was discharged with an extension for her home g-tube suctionining to allow for continued decompression. She was also discharged on TPN. She did have success with a soap suds enema before d/c having a moderate-sized BM. We had her restart her Reglan and misopristol but hold on her senna/colace until she followed up with Dr ___. She will remain NPO except for small amounts of water during the day until she is told otherwise by Dr ___. . #. History of DVT: Patient was maintained on PO Coumadin despite her SBO as this is what she has done with vital medications in the past, being careful to cap her g-tube for at least 30 minutes after taking such medications by mouth. However, the INR continued to decrease, raising the question of poor absorption. Coumadin was thus changed to PR and covered with Lovenox. PR coumadin had no better effect on her INR and she was switched back to PO at an increased dose of 7.5. She will have her INR checked in the next ___ days by her visiting nurse. . #. Mood Disorder: Patient was maintained on Lamictal. . #. Insomnia: This was a significant issue for the patient while in-house, worsened by continued pain. Patient was given IM Ativan ___ mg at night as needed, but this was eventually increased to ___ mg IM with moderate effect. Patient was restarted on her QHS medications on discharge.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Transfer for intracranial posterior fossa bleed and cerebellar mass <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ w/metastatic melanoma with known mets to liver, lungs and duodenum who was transferred from ___ for intracranial bleed and mass after a fall today. He was admitted at the end of ___ for presumed GI bleed and fall with hypotension. Since his discharge he has been feeling shaky and weak. Also has duodenal mass thought to be melanoma metastasis that has eroded into duodenum and pancolitis, which are likely sources for his GIB requiring transfusions. Tonight he felt weak on his way to the bathroom and fell with head strike and went to ___. CT scan showed cerebellar mass and posterior fossa hemorrhage. He had a Hct of 20 and was transfused 1 U pRBCs in route to ___. Hct here one hour after receiving blood was 22. In the ED, initial vitals: T: 97.3, HR 96, BP 136/82, RR 18, sPO2 98% on RA. On exam pt was: AAOx3. Slurred speech and mild ataxia of bilateral upper extremities. Otherwise non-focal neuro exam. Labs were significant for: H/H 7.___, plt 92, WBC 6.1, bands 8%, Na 126, K 4.6, Cl 88, HCO2 21, BUN 36, Cr 1.4, INR 1.2, trop 0.09, AST 72, ALT 57, alk phos 174, albumin 2.4, t bili 0.5. Imaging was significant for: CXR  OSH Impression: Multiple pulmonary masses concerning for metastatic disease. Question of osseous metastatic disease first left rib. CT head  OSH Impression: Slightly hyperdense mass with adjacent edema in left cerebellar hemisphere. Concerning for metastatic lesion. Adjacent hemorrhage may be present just superior to the mass. MRI recommended. Consults: Neurosurgery, Neurology On transfer, vitals were: T: 97.4, HR 88, BP 124/62, RR 20, SPO2 98% on RA. On arrival to the MICU, he endorses feeling weak and shaky since his discharge but denies headache, vision changes, neck pain, chest pain, SOB, abdominal pain, bloody stool or hematuria, diarrhea, dysuria, numbness, weakness, tingling or dizziness/lightheadedness. He denies recent illness or travel. Normal PO intake prior to fall. Chronic RUE edema and DVT. He denies pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: Mr. ___ around early ___ noted a lump on his back. He was referred to surgery for this raised lesion on L posterior shoulder, thought to be infected sebaceous cyst. ID was attempted and clinically the impression was an organized hematoma but due to a question of malignancy the specimen was sent for pathology. Pathology returned as malignant melanoma. The patient went on to have reexcision with 1cm margins around a bluish/purplish nevus about 3 inches away which was thought to be the primary, and excision down to muscle fascia of the large nodule. The nodule on gross pathology is described as measuring at least 4cm in greatest dimension. Pathology from the suspected primary site showed regression changes but no viable melanocytic neoplasm. PET/CT showed a L axillary lymph node with SUV 44. He was referred to ___ clinic. On initial presentation he was found to have a small wound dehiscence but otherwise asymptomatic. We discussed his case in conference and found that the large in-transit nodule had a very close but well demarcated margin. We considered reexcision but given the extent of surgery necessary and possible issues with wound closure, opted against. The patient went on to have a left axillary lymph node dissection on ___ with Dr. ___. There was metastatic melanoma, 1.5cm, in 1 of 20 lymph nodes. There was extracapsular extension in the involved node. Adjuvant radiation was recommended and we referred him to ___ in ___ to complete this closer to home. After the radiation he started IV high dose interferon. He was very depressed and started Lexapro which has helped quite a bit. Due to the severity of symptoms he actually had to take a short break from interferon for about one week. He then restarted at a lower dose which he reports he was able to tolerate much better. He completed one year in ___. - ___ - CT torso showed multiple intrahepatic, pulmonary nodules as well as multiple new parenchymal brain mets. - ___ Completed 5 treatments of WBRT - Started on nivolumab/ipilimumab at ___ (most recently dose #2 on ___ PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - Metastatic Melanoma - Pancolitis with GI bleeding - Hypertension - Hypercholesterolemia - Cyst removal as teenager <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> His father died of a heart attack. His mother died of an unspecified caused, probably related to her chronic alcoholism. He has a brother and a sister; his brother is a chronic alcoholic while his sister has drug abuse with brain damage. He does not have children
summary: ___ man w/PMHx metastatic melanoma w/mets to brain, liver, lung and duodenum, recent ipilimumab colitis, transferred to the ___ ICU from ___ after falling at home, c/b ICH and possible GIB. Found to have C. diff and a poor prognosis. # Metastatic melanoma w/mets to brain, liver, lung and duodenum, possible R subcut cheek metastasis. Prior high dose interferon from ___. Initiated nivolumab/ipilimumab at ___ (second dose on ___, complicated by severe immune mediated colitis requiring prolonged hospitalization and ARF. Had not been on treatment for melanoma since ___, on home prednisone 40mg BID for the colitis. Dr. ___ ___ was involved and talked with the patient and his daughter, proxy, ___, about his prognosis and treatment options. The decision was made to focus on CyberKnife for the brain lesions as noted below. Palliative Care visited him. He developed worsening brain bleeding with edema and effacement of ventricle IV on ___. He was seen by neurosurgery who offered external ventricular drainage immediately, however, given his very poor prognosis from his cancer, he and his daughter (HCP) both declined invasive measures and surgery and patient and family chose to be comfort measures only. # Intracerebral hemorrhage with mild herniation - cerebellar in origin. Fall at home with headstrike leading to intra-cranial hemorrhage with known metastatic melanoma to the brain (cerebellar mass). The bleed was thought to be spontaneous versus trauma induced from fall. MRI obtained, showed dominant cerebellar lesions and associated edema that have progressed in size with evidence to suggest hemorrhage within the lesions. Started Decadron 4mg q 8hrs per Neurosurgery, however final steroid recommendations per Radiation-Oncology/Neuro-Oncology. Bactrim was continued while on steroids. Radiation oncology was consulted as patient had previous WB-XRT ___, recommended Cyberknife therapy (3 sessions). Patient was notably hypertensive as high as 170's

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> simvastatin <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> left hand numbness and weakness and slurred speech <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is a ___ year-old RH AA man with a history of ischemic stroke  TIA, arrhythmia (not definitively afib), HTN, HLD who presents to the ED with abnormal speech since yesterday evening at 5: 45pm. Neurology is consulted in the ED for further management. Mr. ___ was last well yesterday when at ___ he bent down to tie his shoes. Upon rising, he had sudden onset of left lower face numbness and tingling that he describes as tingling like novocaine. Within one minute, he noticed his left thumb, ___ and ___ digits went numb with tingling. The left hand was also weak and he could not hold a pen or objects in his hand. He did not think he was weak in the shoulder more proximal arm. He did not look in the mirror to see if there was facial weakness. No leg weakness. His friend called during this episode and actually thought the patient was drunk although the patient denied recently drinking. His speech was slurred and mumbling but he understood what his friend was saying. His friend urged him to go the ED, but by the time he drove himself there his symptoms already resolved. Duration of entire symptoms approximately 15 minutes. At ___, he was not actually seen because the wait was too long and his symptoms had already resolved. Also no headache or dizziness or neck pain. This morning, he awoke at ___ to his daughter calling his ___. He answered the phone in bed and his daughter thought his speech was slowed and slurred, but better than yesterday. He noticed this as well and thought it was disproportionate to groggy speech that you can get upon awakening. He checked out his left hand and face and there was no numbness, tingling or weakness. No facial droop seen in the mirror. He was urged by his PCP office to come into the ED. He continued to have a feeling his speech was off and somewhat slow but admitted that he others probably could not pick up on it. With regards to his prior strokes/TIAs, he has had at least 2 episodes of neurological symptoms in the past. In ___, he had sudden onset inability to speak and right hand weakness while at a ___. Symptoms lasted 3.5hours. At ___, he was offered tpa (but declined) and his symptoms spontaneously resolved. He was also found to have a PFO (see copy of report below as listed in OMR). His was then placed on aspirin. A second episode was in ___ where he had a ___ minute transient episode of his right hand getting stuck in a fist which spontaneously resolved. No sensory symptoms or speech changes with that. He may have had another episode ___ years ago with sensory changes of the left hand for a few minutes, but he does not remember that in detail. Mr. ___ says he was diagnosed with afib the ___, but was not placed on anticoagulation. After transferring care to ___ in the ___, Dr. ___ this diagnosis further, but could not find evidence of afib on prior telemetry studies. There were multiple PVCs but no actual afib. He repeated a 20day ___ monitor ___ showed Eleven recordings with/without complaints of fast heart rate showed sinus/sinus tachycardia at rates 83 to 158 BPM with isolated APBs, VPBs, an atrial couplet, a ventricular couplet, and 2 runs of atrial tachycardia, 4 to 8 beats in duration, at rates 156 to 202 BPM. No afib on that study. Thus, the diagnosis of paroxysmal afib remains unclear. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Congenital right ptosis s/p surgical repair in ___, still with ptosis especially when tired or stressed. - Ischemic stroke/TIA (see above) - History of PFO - Palpitations and PVCs - per patient he was diagnosed with afib in the past, but when PCP reviewed OSH records there was no afib, but rather 3000 PVCs and couplets. - HTN - recently poorly controlled (150/100) in a ___ PCP ___. - Hyperlipidemia - Prior lipid panel from ___ total chol 228, HDL 114, LDL 81, ___ 156. - Elevated liver enzymes - (NASH vs statin effect) found in ___ in work up of anxiety, weight loss and malaise. Ferritin 1000, ALT 152, AST 119, all trended down with alcohol cessation. MRI liver did not show cirrhosis or portal HTN. - Prior alcohol abuse - History of anemia and elevated CEA - Gastritis, Hpylori seen on stomach and duodenal bx ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> He is adopted. Has one daughter who is healthy. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: 98.9 HR: 83 BP: 149/95 RR: 18 SaO2: 100%RA General: tall black man, NAD HEENT: Right ptosis and
summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to the stroke neurology service. MRI confirmed the presence of an acute stroke in the R frontal cortex in the area of the primary motor cortex control of the hand and extending down into the corona radiata. This is highly suspicious for a cardioembolic process, either due to Atrial fibrillation or known PFO. Given a prior diagnosis of Atrial fibrillation, the decision was made to anticoagulate with apixiban and stop aspirin. His LDL is pending, but he has known HLD. He had some palpitations with simvastatin in the past, so we will try a low dose of atorvastatin (10mg daily). Given known PFO and decision to anticoagulate, TTE will not change management and was deferred. His gait and hand function are back to baseline, so ___ also deferred. Passed bedside swallow without difficulty. He was discharged to home with planned follow up with cardiology and neurology and PCP. Smoking cessation counseling given () Yes - (x) No [reason (x) non-smoker - () unable to participate] 7. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old right-handed man with a past medical history including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, DM 2, and CAD -three days s/p drug eluting stent placement to the RCA and LAD who presented to the ___ with left hand clumsiness and dysarthria in addition to chest discomfort. He was initially admitted to the medicine service, dueing which time his pain was deemed non-cardiac in origin. As his symptoms were considered concerning for stroke, he was transferred to the Neurology Stroke Service from ___ to ___. . ___ As the time of admission, a CTA of the head and neck was performed. The imaging demonstrated right-sided focal lucencies within the centrum semiovale and corona radiata in the setting of an apparent high grade stenosis of the right internal carotid artery. A heparin drip was started with a goal PTT of 50 to 70. . A vascular surgery consult was requested to evaluate the utility and feasbility of a carotid endarterectomy. At their recommendation, carotid duplex studies were performed to evaluate the degree of carotid stenosis with an alternative modality. While the carotid duplex studies showed less than 40% stenosis bilaterally, it was thought to be a falsley low result. Accordingly, the patient underwent a right carotid endarterectomy (CEA). A CT angiogram performed thereafter revealed a widely patent right extracranial internal carotid artery. . Following the CEA, the patient developed a more pronounced dysarthria and left hemiparesis. As the symptoms did not resolve with the optimization of cerebral blood flow, the neurosurgery team was consulted for a potential intervention. The patient subsequently underwent cerebral angiography. As the anatomy was not conducive to the procedures, no stent was placed and no thrombectomy was performed. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for close monitoring. In the setting of persistent symptoms, a CT perfusion scan was subsequently performed. The study revealed global hypoperfusion of the right MCA

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ history of COPD on 2L O2, HFpEF, CKD III, CAD, DM II, HTN, bullous pemphigoid on prednisone, beta thalassemia trait, hard of hearing, recent admission to ___ for COPD exacerbation and hypercarbic respiratory failure requiring BiPAP, presenting from rehab facility with BRBPR and respiratory distress admitted with possible LGIB and COPD exacerbation. ACUTE ISSUES: ============= #Hypercarbic respiratory failure #COPD exacerbation #Multifocal pneumonia Patient was admitted with respiratory distress, thought to be caused by a COPD exacerbation with no obvious trigger. She was initially admitted to the MICU and treated for a COPD exacerbation, then transferred to the floor after one night due to significant improved on BIPAP. Through the course of her hospital stay, she received duonebs, azithromycin x5 days, and prednisone x5 days for COPD. She continued to have tenuous respiratory status and CT chest was obtained which showed multifocal pneumonia. Vancomycin and cefepime were started to treat hospital acquired pneumonia as patient is nursing home dwelling and has had several recent hospital admission. Vancomycin was discontinued upon MRSA swab resulting negative, and she completed a 6 day course of cefepime with clinical improvement in her respiratory and mental status. #Bright red blood per rectum #Melena #Anemia Presented w/ bright red blood per rectum. Pt has history of diverticulosis, gastric polyp and hemorrhoids on prior ___. Bleeding stabilized early in admission but then patient began to have small volume melena. Patient was treated with IV PPI, pRBC x 1, and home ferrous gluconate. GI consulted and considered colonoscopy and EGD, however, upon further discussion with patient's daughter (HCP), the decision was made to defer colonoscopy and EGD due to multiple medical comorbidities and advanced age, and patient's Hgb had remained stable above 7. If she were to have GI bleeding again, HCP would like conservative measures taken at first (transfusions) and the possibility of scope can be discussed

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / morphine / Demerol / Dilaudid / Naprosyn / Relafen / Tetracaine / aspirin / Bactrim / erythromycin base / butoconazole / meperidine / promethazine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Back pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ w/COPD, DM2, who presents with five days of back pain. Pain has continued to worsen over the last 4 days. She has never had pain like this previously, and now she needs to use a cane to walk and has difficulty sitting up from lying in bed. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with a history of chronic alcoholic pancreatitis s/p distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy, OSA, asthma, COPD, Hx of DVT/PE, GERD, DM2, and daily narcotic use of Methadone and oxycodone and a chronic biliary stricture. #Bacterial peritonitis with severe pain: He developed a large volume of ascites in the post operative period. SAAG of 1.4, indicative of portal hypertension. Initially he was extremely nauseous with abdominal pain and several vomiting episodes. An NG tube was placed with return of bilious fluid. Post paracentesis this was able to be discontinued. RUQ negative for new occlusion. Echo was negative for heart failure. TGs in the peritoneal fluids were low (not chylous). His WBC was 5100 initially which improved on repeat (1800) at 48 hours of treatment. Liver, ___ surgery, and ID consulted. He was treated with therapeutic paracenteses and diuretics. Antibiotics were initially cefepime/vanc and it was recommended that he be treated for two weeks which completed ___. He was treated with albumin for SBP on days 1 and 3. He underwent repeat paracentesis ___ with perstitenly elevated WBC in the peritoneal fluid. Given continued symptoms, Vancomycin was added to cefepime to complete a 2 week course. He had 4 paracentesis, the last 3 had no growth. Repeat paracentesis was completed to evaluate for continued improvement in WBC in fluid which showed a WBC of 412. He will have follow-up with the liver clinic and they are arranging outpatient paracenteses. #Biliary obstruction THe patient has a biliary stricture with biliary stent in place. LFTs increased and it was unclear if this is due to biliary obstruction or underlying liver disease. The patient had attempted ERCP for stent exchange which could not be completed due to food in the stomach x3 as well as difficulty with cannulation. He was started on a prokinetic agent, erythromycin with little help. He will follow-up

ARF possibly due to NSAID use for gout complicated by hydronephrosis and hyperparathyroidism. Pt feels significantly improved s/p b/l uretral stent placement at OSH ___. Cr at discharge was ***. . # Hyperparathyroidism and hypercalcemia: Pt with hypercalcemia with Ca ___ at transfer s/p pamidronate and IVF and bumex at OSH. No symptoms (arthralgia, abdominal pain, MS changes, kidney stones) despite elevated Ca. Found to have possible parathyroid adenoma. Consider sarcoidosis as this can cause hypercalcemia and is more common in ___ Americans, but would expect low PTH. Pt was given aggressive IVF and lasix to prevent fluid overload and to facilitate calcium excretion. PTH elevated to 1444 at ___. TSH normal. Per endocrine recommendations, pt received calcitonin 200 units x2. Dr. ___ team recommended *** and performed *** . # HSIL on PAP: Aappears to be done at OSH given uretral obstruction due to concern for cervical malignancy. CT ___ and transvaginal US with results above. Pt did not have vaginal bleeding during her hospitalization and preferred to follow up with her PCP for further workup and gynecologic evaluation. . # Pulmonary opacities on CXR/CT Chest: Pt remained afebrile and without leukocytosis. No pulmonary symptoms. Pulmonary at OSH concerned about metastases from possible cervical ca. Pt preferred to follow up with her PCP for further evaluation and treatment. . # Anemia: Hct 27.6 at ___ s/p transfusion of 3 units blood at OSH for Hct ___ at d/c from ___. Fe studies c/w Fe deficiency likely ___ heavy vaginal bleeding. Pt denied GI blood

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology oncology service after undergoing Exploratory laparotomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, resection of pelvic mass and tumor debulking, bilateral ureteral stent placement. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course is detailed as follows. Immediately postoperatively, her pain was controlled with subcutaneous dilaudid and IV acetaminophen. Her diet was advanced slowly and was complicated by the development of a postoperative ileus on postoperative day 2. She continued to have nausea and vomiting despite conservative management, thus on postoperative day three a ___ tube was placed with good response and was discontinued by postop day 4. Given her preoperative malnutrition, nutrition was consult is recommended early initiation of parenteral nutrition on postoperative day five. Her ileus improved and her diet was advanced to regular by postoperative day 10 and parenteral nutrition was weaned. Given her baseline limited mobility and significant deconditioning, physical therapy was consulted for evaluation and treatment who recommended rehabilitation on discharge. Regarding infectious disease, on post-operative day 9 she became septic with a Tmax of 103 and tachycardic to the 130-140. Supportive care and IV levofloxacin and clindamycin were initiated for a probable RLL pnuemonia. She improved and was transtitioned to po levo/clinda. Regarding her chronic neurologic issues,Dandy-Walker, ventriculomegaly multiple spinal surgeries and parkinsonism, these were felt to be acutely worsened post-operatively. Medicine and neurology were consulted. CT was done which ruled out acute neurologic insult. She was cleared for a regular diet by speech and swallow evaluation with aspiration precautions implemeneted. OT and ___ were consulted for difficulty with self feeding. Sinemet was started and well tolerated, with some improvement in neurological symptoms. By post-operative day ___, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating with assistance, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged to rehab in stable condition

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> fall at home <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Diagnostic Paracentesis (1) Therapeutic Paracentesis (2) Thoracentesis <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo female with history of cryptogenic cirrhosis presents after unwitnessed fall at home. Patient was found on the floor by family yesterday morning. ___ to the ED where she was unable to answer many questions due to altered mental status, but denied head strike or loss of consciousness, stated that her legs became numb and gave out, but she was a bit unclear on the details. Per the family, this has happened before when she is due for therapeutic paracentesis, which she is scheduled to have in a few days at ___. She denies fever, chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, melena, hematochezia. . In the ED initial VS were notable for tachypnea RR 24 O2sat 92%/RA. Per ED signout, she was not initially noted to be hypotensive. She was worked up for infection vs syncope vs mechanical fall, but given her liver history, SBP was high on the differential. She was found to have nontender abdominal ascites with intact sensation and strength in the lower extremities. UA grossly pyuric, so she was given 1 dose cipro and 1.5L IVF. Diagnostic paracentesis demonstrated leukocytosis with ___ neutrophils, consistent with SBP. CXR demonstrated large bilateral pleural effusions, right>left; right-sided effusion was associated with leftward mediastinal shift. CT head was negative, CT c-spine that demonstrated: No acute fracture or malalignment but degenerative changes at C2/C3 and C5-C6, which predisposes the patient to spinal cord injury in setting of trauma. VS at time of transfer were 98.6 60 126/86 18 98%/2LxNC. . On the floor her intial VS were 96 93/51 57 24 96/2L. She was confused, not able to answer questions well, incontinent of urine. For her SBP she was given 50 g albumin with plan for therapeutic tap today. Foley placed; only made 60 cc urine between midnight and 7 AM. BP ran low ___ overnight. She is still in a neck brace, which makes her uncomfortable and she denies SOB or difficulty breathing although she is obviously belly-breathing on exam. MS clarity improved greatly by this AM, AOX3 and able to report that she went into the bathroom at 4 AM last night (by which she means 2 nights ago) and doesn't remember anything up to her arrival here last night. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Coronary artery disease - Atrial fibrillation, noted ___, not on anticoagulation for fear of bleeding from esophageal varices - Moderate MR and mild pulmonary HTN seen on ___ echo - Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia, s/p Rituxan - AV malformation in the cecum - Esophageal varices, grade 3, and portal HTN seen on EGD from ___ - Cirrhosis of unclear etiology. - h/o DVT - Knee replacements - ___ hopitalization, bradycardia in setting of dig tox leading to PPM placement - ___ hospitalization w/ cholangitis, s/p ERCP stent placement that has since been removed. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Exam: Vitals: 96 93/51 57 24, 96 on 2L General: Awake, confused HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: Patient in ___ J collar Lungs: Sharply diminished breath sounds in right lung throughout. Dullness to percussion. Left lung with dullness at base, clear to ascultation above. CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen: Distended, bandage in place. Bulging flanks. Ext: Cool extremities. Patient with erythematous plaque on left lower extremity suggestive of healing wound in combination with mild stasis. Neuro: Patient AO to self. Not able to comply with asterixis exam. Follows very simple instructions but needs multiple reorienting. . Discharge Exam: VS: 96.0 (95.3-97.6) 93/60 100 (80-105 x24h on tele) ___ I/O: 900100/incx8, BMx11 (no cdiff odor) Wt: P, ___ yesterday GEN: well-appearing elderly female resting quietly in bed, fatigued HEENT: soft collar off, no JVD, NCAT EOMI PERRL OP clear CV: RRR II/VI systolic murmur Pulm: not belly-breathing; similar rales/rhonchi  R-sides basilar dullness Abd: soft nontender less distended, typanic to percussion over ___ volume w/shifting dullness Ext: WWP ___ non-pitting edema, L shin granulating ulcerated lesion healing well without bandage, pulses Neuro: AOX3, not waxing and waning anymore; very hard of hearing so sometimes answers inappropriately
summary: Assessment and Plan: ___ y/o female w/cryptogenic cirrhosis c/b diuretic resistent ascited presents after an unwitnessed fall at home, found to have SBP, UTI, ___, and resolving hepatic encephalopathy. . # Cryptogenic Liver Failure. Pt known to have end-stage liver disease, on diuretics at home but also gets periodic therapeutic paracentesis with her hepatologist at ___. Was due for paracentesis 1 week after admission. On furosemide, spironolactone, lactulose and rifampim at home. These were continued inpatient. She also underwent paracentesis three times: for SBP diagnosis in the ED, and twice on the floor for therapeutic ascites drainage. 1.5L were removed during the first paracentesis; further fluid accumulated within the subsequent 5 days, requiring an additional paracentesis for 3L. She received IV albumin after each paracentesis. BP were stable at time of discharge, lasix was restarted at home dose and spironolactone was held. . #Septic shock. Patient arrived tachypnic, tachycardic, infected (see below), with renal hypoperfusion, and hypotension with systolics in the low ___, requiring volume resuscitation with 25% albumin for ___ days. Found to have both a urinary tract infection and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, as described below. Vital signs normalized and pt's mental status improved with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics. She received albumin with each paracentesis and also occasionally for BP in the low ___. She did not require albumin on the day of discharge. . #SBP. Diagnostic paracentesis in the ED showed >2500 WBC with 80% neutrophils, meeting criteria for SBP. She was given 1 dose of cipro in the ED prior to paracentesis, then changed to meropenem and vancomycin on the floor. Her mental status improved markedly within 24 hours and blood pressure stabilized. She did receive albumin for resuscitation daily until BP improved, and after each paracentesis. Therapeutic paracentesis performed <48 hours after admission showed notable improvement, down to 150 WBC. Regarding antibiotic choice: there was
