summary: ___ yo man with h/o diabetes, HTN, Right carotid occlusion with right occipital prior infarct who presented with ataxia and difficult walking. #Ataxia: Brain MRI without stroke, hemorrhage, or mass. MRI C/T spine w/o lesion to explain his symptoms. Copper low in ___, repletion started. Ceruloplasmin was slightly low at 16 as well. This suggest copper deficiency, supplementation was started. This perhaps played some role in his symptoms as this can cause a myeloneuropathy, would not well explain his acute symptoms though. He was monitored as some concern for GBS variant, however the timing did not match well, and his symptoms improved quickly. LP was not able to be done initially due to Plavix. After 5 days off Plavix had exam had improved to the point where it was felt LP was not necessary, he was discharged home with services and neurology follow up. Vitamin E was also low. He was on a MVI w/ minerals for the copper as well. #R carotid occlusion: Followed by vascular surgery as an outpatient, carotid ultrasound was stable. Vascular felt that his Plavix did not need to be continued. This was stopped on ___ ( had been started earlier this admission) #Diabetes - patient initated on insulin this admission. Was followed by ___. ___ set up. Has ___ appointment tomorrow. Inpt diabetes education performed. regimen as follows on discharge glargine 26 units qhs Humalog lispro 9 units qac sliding scale insulin qachs: starting at 150, 2 units, increments of 50 glucose and 2 units of insulin. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES diabetes: follow up insulin regimen at ___ Ataxia: follow up in neurology clinic

summary: ___ yo F with pmhx of CKD, gout, obesity, HTN and chronic pain who p/w dizziness x 1 day, found to have ___. ___ on CKD: Cr 4.5 on admission from baseline 1.7-2.0. Renal u/s without acute abnormality. FENa 1.1% suggested intrinsic renal etiology, but urine sediment bland. Denied nephrotoxins. Suspect pre-renal etiology given recent report of nausea/vomiting/diarrhea and slight improvement with 1L NS in ED. Component of ATN suggested by acute ___ following significant symptomatic hypotension as below. The patient was noted to have brisk urine output and creatinine trended down to 2.5 at time of discharge. She was discharged home with plan for close PCP follow up. #Hypotension/dizziness: Pt reported significant dizziness x 2 days after home atenolol dose was increased. She had also taken tamsulosin for urinary retention. She measured her BP at home while symptomatic and reported BP ___. Atenolol and tamsulosin were held and hypotension and dizziness resolved with 1L NS in ED. She remained normotensive on home amlodipine alone. # R ischial pain: Patient has chronic bilateral hip pain for which she takes oxycodone prescribed by PCP. She reported right posterior thigh pain x 2 weeks and had tenderness to palpation in the area of right ischium. Ultrasound showed no evidence of abscess or fluid collection. Plain films showed increased lucency R ischium on plain film, likely overlying bony prominence. Finding was communicated finding to PCP via phone ___. Outpatient noncontrast MRI was recommended. Patient reported that her oxycodone had been stolen shortly after she filled it. After discussion with PCP, she was discharged with 10 day prescription for oxycodone pending PCP follow up which was planned for the following week. # Leukocytosis: Mildly elevated WBC during admission of unclear etiology. Patient remained afebrile and without localizing infectious symptoms throughout admission. #Anemia: Pt states she has a long h/o anemia, dating back since she was ___. Orig

summary: this is a ___ year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease in the setting of hepatitis C and a prior left-sided stroke with residual right hemiparesis who presents with weakness of the legs. There is some discrepancy in the duration of the current picture (since ___ per patient, though perhaps up to a week or so per wife), but the patient seems to note worsening of the symptoms while walking for some time and when bending forward. He denied a progression of the symptoms this morning. His examination is notable for inattention, bilateral proximal weakness with right hemiparesis, and right-sided hyperreflexia. Our team was also concerned about parkinsonian features including bradykinesia, hypomimia and postural instability. A picture of manganism, which presents with parkinsonian features, may be seen in chronic hepatic disease. His spinal imaging does not clearly support a structural myelopathy. His MRI brain did not reveal any significant acute pathology. Sinemet was not started given his hepatic dysfunction.

summary: ___ w/ CVA (L-sided weakness), ___, HTN, arthritis p/w recurrent vasovagal syncope and unresponsive episode. ACUTE ISSUES: #Syncope event: Syncopated on toilet and had 2 min of CPR for reported pulselessness. Unlikely true asystole since labs and Tn negative. Had teeth clenching and loss of bladder control so concern for seizure. Neuro exam unchanged from prior in OMR. DDx also includes vasovagal (all prior events occur around bathroom) or medication effect (recently increased morphine). Her home morphine was held during her stay. Underwent NCHCT in addition to c-spine CT to r/o acute hemorrhagic stroke or compression fractures which returned negative. She then underwent EEG for 24 hours, which was not remarkable for concerning epileptiform tracings. She did not have acute episodes of neurological deficits during her stay. Discussed case with family including likely vasovagal event and need for close care. Decreased home trazodone to 12.5mg QHS. Per S/S evaluation, did have increased cough at risk for aspiration with mixed tasks of eating and drinking, which would necessitate monitoring while feeding at home with caution. #Dysuria: Endorsed right prior to d/c on ___. Planned for straight cath w/ UA and UCx. CHRONIC ISSUES: #Insomnia: -Decreased home trazodone 75 mg qhs to 25 mg qhs #History of CVA: #Vascular dementia: AOx1-2 at baseline. -Continued aspirin/Plavix -Continued atorvastatin 80 mg qd ___ disease: -Continued home Rytary (carbidopa-levodopa) 23.75-95 mg oral 7am, 1pm, 6pm ___ Disease #Autonomic dysautonomia: -Increased home midodrine from 2.5 mg BID to TID -Continued home felodipine 10 mg qd -Continued home metoprolol 25 mg BID #Code status: Was DNR/DNI at last hospitalization, but family initiated CPR once she became pulseless. Family

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> metformin / morphine <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Elevated creatinine <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ - Sigmoidoscopy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with h/o ESRD due to FSGS s/p LURT in ___, PCOS, and anemia with recent two week admission for acute on chronic kidney disease presumed due to rejection who is sent in for increased creatinine. Her most recent hospitalization for acute kidney injury was though to be due to rejection. She was started on and discharged on prednisone. BK serologies and biopsy stain negative, CMV negative. Renal biopsy x 2 consistent with acute rejection. She received ATG and tacrolimus was increased to 10 mg BID. Cr on day of discharge was 3.0. She was transfused x 1 that hospitalization. In the ED, initial vitals were: 97.0 78 128/54 18 100% - Labs were significant for tacro level of 12.4, normal LFTs, H/H stable from discharge at 7.2/22.1, BUN/Cr 69/4.6, K 5.7, Bicarb 12 - Renal ultrasound revealed mild elevation of the main renal artery PSV and resistive indices, with mild stable hydronephrosis - The patient was given 2L NS, mycophenolate 1000 mg, nystatin, tacrolimus 10 mg and 1300 mg sodium bicarb Vitals prior to transfer were: 98.2 79 125/54 18 99% RA Upon interview Ms. ___ states that she feels fine except for bloated from all the IVF. She notes that she has been having diarrhea intermittently since her transplant, including when she was recently discharged. This persisted until yesterday when she took 2 imodium, and has not recurred. She has hemorrhoids that were irritated by the diarrhea and her BMs were intermittently bloody. She denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, dysuria. She has been being a lot since getting IV fluid. Denies decreased PO intake. Endorses fatigue that has persisted since being in the hospital. Otherwise, ROS is negative. Denies dysuria. She is not pleased to be back in the hospital. summary: ___ with ESRD s/p renal transplant and recent admission for acute rejection presents with acutely rising creatinine concerning for progression of rejection. During hospitalization pt mentioned she was experiencing ___ episodes of bloody diarrhea daily; stool cxs were sent and were negative for CMV, OP or other acute pathology. Diarrhea thought likely ___ MMF, with inflammation and high-flow of stool likely irritating an internal hemorrhoid causing GIB. Pt received 3 units PRBCs w/ improvment in hemoglobin as well as her creatinine. Elevated creatinine concluded to be less likely rejection and more likely dehydration from GI losses. Gastroenterology team and Colorectal surgery team consulted. The Gastroenterology team performed a sigmoidoscopy on ___ which showed nonbleeding internal hemorrhoids. The colorectal surgery team recommended metamucil, and follow up as needed for symptom management w/ Dr. ___. MMF dosing spread from BID to lower dosing QID; pt's diarrhea and bleeding resolved by discharge. Of note, patient seemed oddly apathetic/cheerful regarding the failure of her transplanted kidney, unclear underlying social/psychiatric state. Dr. ___ requested inpatient psych evaluation, which had also been performed at a prior admission when pt c/o manic features and reported nonadherence to meds; at the present admission, pt appeared to have a good understanding of her situation and to have capacity, and the team felt a follow-up outpatient evaluation with a provider who knows her well would be most appropriate. Pt was set up with her outpatient psychiatrist as an outpatient (see below). TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ====================== -Labs to be drawn on ___, to be followed up by Dr. ___ cultures pending at discharge, neg to date -Pt has appt w/ Dr. ___ on ___ will fax d/c summary to ___ office. -Pt will call transplant coordinator with any recurrence of bleeding or diarrhea -If pt has more hemorrhoid pain, can call Dr. ___

summary: ___ year old gentleman with a history of ESRD on dialysis ___ at ___) who presents with a two day history of bilateral leg pain and hematuria, with ED course notable for fever. # Fever: The etiology is most consistent with a viral syndome given his URI symptoms, body aches, and cough. He is reassuringly flu negative. Pneumonia unlikely with clear cxr and absence of wbc elevation. Dysuria/hematuria could point to cystitis, though absence of pyuria on UA makes this unlikely. Bacteremia in the setting of HD also possible but blood cultures negative x2. No GI sx and negative LFTs. No HA to suggest meningitis. No e/o septic hip joint on exam. His systolic ejection murmur has been documented in the past, and although nonspecific body aches are often presenting symptoms of endocarditis, this appears less likely in the context of viral symptoms. Never received antibiotics, viral panel negative. Improved with supportive care. # Bilateral leg pain: Acute on chronic in the setting of fevers may be arthralgias superimposed on OA, discharged with short course of oxycodone and attempted to arrange with outpatient pain management. He was given a short course of oxycodone to bridge to PCP follow up. # ESRD on HD MWF: ___ glomerulonephritis, failed RUE AVF, has working left upper extrem AVF. He missed his HD day of admission and presented with K of 6.7 in the ED. He was seen by renal in the ED and received dialysis prior to admission, K normalized. # Hypoglycemia: Likely secondary to insulin he received in the ED for hyperkalemia vs poor PO intake. He is s/p 2 amps D50 in the ED with blood sugars in 100's. # Hematuria: UA notable for trace blood. No evidence of UTI. History of hematuria dating to ___ on review of OMR labs. Differential includes necrosis or injury to transplanted kidney, though renal team unconerned about further workup. He is scheduled for close followup with urology

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Neck pain, trouble swallowing <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Fiberoptic Laryngoscopy. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a history of type ___ diabetes and hypertension who presented to an outside hospital on ___ for neck pain. The neck pain started on ___ after he carried heavy bottles of water over his shoulder. On ___ at work he noticed that his neck felt stiff, which was worse on the left side near the left Trapezius muscle. He initially presented to the ___ emergency room where it was thought that he had a strained muscle and he was given a prescription for flexeril 10 mg t.i.d. as well as tylenol with codeine for pain. This did not improve his symptoms. The following morning he noticed that when he woke up he felt a tight feeling in his neck and was having trouble swallowing. He was not having frank pain when swallowing. The pain in his neck was worsening, especially with turning his head side to side. He represented to ___ where he had a CT scan of his neck which was concerning for prevertebral swelling. He received IVF and dilaudid for pain control and was transferred to this ___ for further management. On arrival to this hospital his initial vitals were T: 97.9 BP: 159/101 HR: 106 RR: 20 O2: 98% on RA. While in the ER he received 3 liters of normal saline and zosyn 4.5 grams x 2, dilaudid 1 mg IV x 2. Laboratories from the ER showed a WBC count of 12.6 (P71 L21 M5.8), ESR of 25 and CP of 68. Ua was negative. Blood and urine cultures were sent. He was limited to 20 degrees of neck rotation in either direction without pain on flexion or extension. His voice was slightly muffled. He was evaluated by the spine fellow who noticed tenderness to palpation over the left paraspinal/trapezius muscles but no abnormalities on enurologic exam. He was seen by ENT who performed a fiberoptic exam which showed a normal epiglottis, normal vocal cords, and fullness of the pharyngeal walls R > L. He underwent an MRI of the neck which showed a small low T1 signal lesions within the lingual tonsils, left greater than right, that may represent developing abscess as well as enhancement of the retropharyngeal space and extending to the prevertebral space at the level of the C3/4 level. Neither the orthopedics and ENT services felt the collection appropriate for surgical drainage. He was scheduled for an MRI of the c-spine and admitted to the medical service for further management. On arrival to the floor he had continued neck pain. He denied having a sore throat but endorsed s stiff neck. He was able to eat and drink but feels that the back of his throat tightens when he swallows. He denied dysphagia or otalgia. He had no sick contacts. He denied fevers, chills, cold symptoms, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, abdominal pain, leg pain or swelling. H <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Type ___ Diabetes on metformin (started recently) Hypertension Recently treated for a fungal skin infection in his underarms Last dental work 6 months ago <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Dad with hypertension, brother with type ___ diabetes. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Examination: Vitals: T: 98.8 HR: 71 BP: 155/96 RR: 16 O2: 98% RA General: Holding his neck in his hands but otherwise well appearing. Normal respiratory effort, slightly muffled voice. HEENT: Auricles within normal limits, cerumen appreciated, visible portions of tympanic membranes within normal limits. Nose within normal limits per ENT by anterior rhinoscopy and by fiberoptic exam. No pus or polyps. No trismus. Dry mucous membranes. Large uvula that was midline. Small amount of yellow secretions along soft palate. Neck: Limited range of motion. 20 degrees lateral rotation in either direction. No limitation of flexion or extension. Tender to palptation over left paraspinal region/trapezius muscle Cardiac: Regular rate and rhythm, normal s1 and s2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi Gastrointestinal: soft, non-tender, non-distended, BS, no organomegaly Extremities: Warm and well perfused, 2 pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema Neurologic: CN ___ tested and intact, sensation intact across all dermatomes, strength ___ in upper and lower extremities, 2 reflexes throughout. Fiberoptic Exam (performed by ENT): Exam notable for diffuse very thick yellow secretions throughout upper airway. No notable erythema or edema epiglottis, false vocal folds, true vocal folds or posterior cricoid region
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a history of type ___ diabetes and hypertension who presented to an outside hospital with neck pain transferred here for concern for retropharyngeal abscess. Neck Pain/Difficulty Swallowing: Patient developed neck pain, limited range of motion and dysphagia after lifting heavy bottle of water (not an unusual activity for him). He was initially seen at an outside hospital emergency room and was felt to have a muscle strain and was given flexeril and tylenol with codeine without improvement. He represented 24 hours later with worsening pain. CT scan with contrast was concerning for a retrophyarngeal fluid collection and he was transferred to this hospital for MRI scanning and ENT evaluation. On arrival he underwent MRI of the neck which demonstrated a rim-enhancing collection involving the retropharyngeal and anterior paravertebral spaces from the craniocervical junction through C2-6 which was concerning for retropharyngeal abscess. There was no evidence of involvement of adjacent bone or epidural collection. These scans were reviewed independently by the ENT and spine services who did not feel operative intervention was warranted given his non-toxic appearance on exam and morbidity of possible operative intervention. He was evaluated by the infectious disease service who recommended initial treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin and zosyn). On further review of the images it was felt that the appearance would also be consistent with retropharyngeal calcific tendinitis, a condition reported in the literature manifested by neck pain, limited range of motion, odynophagia, and mildly elevated inflammatory markers which can mimic retropharyngeal abscess. On retrospective review of the CT scan he was noted to have a small calcification in the left longus ___ muscle at the level of the atlantoaxial joint which is commonly seen in calcific tendinitis secondary to calcium hydroxyapatite deposition disease. He was monitored on the floor and at no time was he febrile

He consumes alcohol daily and was drinking when he found himself on the ground with multiple abrasions on his legs. At his wife's urging, the patient sought care at the outside hospital. A CT scan of the head showed a right sided subarachnoid hemorrhage and the patient was transferred to ___ for Neurosurgical evaluation. Patient was admitted to the neuro ICU. CTA was negative for any vascular abnormality. He was started on a CIWA protocol and Keppra for seizure prophylaxis. He was given 1 pack of platelets given his plavix use. Plastic surgery was consulted for finding of orbital wall fracture. On ___ Patient was neurologically intact on exam. He was started on a phenobarb protocol for alcohol withdrawal. His diet was advanced. His blood pressure was liberalized. On ___, his cervical collar was removed after CT c-spine at OSH was negative. Optho was consulted for assessment of R orbital fracture for any injury to the eye and he was transferred to the floor with a stable neurological exam. On ___, Mr. ___ was found to be short of breath and had upper airway congestion. A CXR was obtained and was indicative of atelectasis. As he has bilateral rib fractures, he was written for a more aggressive pain regimen (while minimizing narcotics) and pulmonary toileting. His cardiac enzymes were trending down (max 0.04). He electrolytes were repleted as well. ___ evaluated the patient and felt he would require rehab as an outpatient. Over the weekend of ___ the patient remained neurologically and hemodynamically stable. He was being screened for rehab. On ___, the patient was discharged to rehab in stable conditions. All discharge instruction and follow up were given prior to discharge.

summary: ___ year old man with HCV cirrhosis (complicated by HE, varices s/p banding, and ascites) multifocal HCC (s/p TACE x5 and s/p RFA x3, most recently ___, now presenting with right portal vein thrombus. # Portal vein thrombus: Asymptomatic, seen incidentally on liver MRI done after recent RFA procedure. He was started on heparin gtt and was transitioned to PO warfarin. INR was therapeutic (2.7) at time of discharge, goal INR ___. Plan for anticoagulation for at least 3 months for right portal vein thrombosis. ___: He had transient creatinine elevation now resolved. Most likely due to contrast from CT chest on ___. Diuretic dose was adjusted per outpatient cardiology notes. # R pleural effusion: S/P levofloxacin course from prior admission. ___ CT scan slightly improved from scan on ___. Continued diuretics as above. # Cirrhosis: He has hepatitis C cirrhosis (dx in ___ genotype 2b, now cured s/p sofosbuvir and ribavirin). Decompensated by esophageal varices, hepatic encephalopathy, and ascites. He also has HCC s/p RFA x3. No signs of decompensation on admission. Ascites and encephalopathy are well-controlled. ACTIVE ISSUES ============= #Tracheal stenosis: #Hypoxia: Patient with recent inhalation injury about a month prior to admission, s/p intubation and ICU stay at ___. Presented to ___ on ___ with a week of worsening dyspnea. CT chest with inhalation aeration protocol showed significant tracheal stenosis. She was started on IV methylpred 60mg q12h and transferred to ___ for IP evaluation. On 5L NC satting high ___ weaning as tolerated, with audible biphasic stridor on exam. Postoperatively the patient did well and was eventually weaned off oxygen. There were thick mucous secretions noted on bronchoscopy, for which she was started on a 5-day course of cefpodoxime for empiric CAP coverage (___). text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Niacin / Latex / Formaldehyde <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> NSTEMI <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterizaiton <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ Y F w/ hx of HTN, dyslipidemia, CAD s/p NSTEMI x2 in past 3 months, medically managed, systolic CHF w/ EF 25% s/p biV ICD, and hx of GI bleed last year on ASA re-presented to ___ on ___ with recurrent SOB in acute CHF and NSTEMI. At ___ pt had another NSTEMI complicated by CHF exacerbation. Pt is DNR/DNI and had previously not wanted an intervention but after discussion with her physicians at ___ she agreed to reverse her status to perform cardiac cath. She was transferred here for cath on ___ which showed the LAD had a 90% proximal stenosis and a 90% distal stenosis; the D1 had a 70% lesion. The LCX system had a small OM1 with 90% stenosis. The RCA was a small vessel totally occluded in its distal portion. Successful multivessel PCI of proximal and distal LAD and OM1 with bare metal stents (2.0 X 23 mm X 2.0 X 12 mm Vision stents to distal LAD and 2.0 X 18 mm Vision stent to proximal LAD postdilated to 2.5; 3.5 X 15 mm Vision stent to the OM with 3.5 X 12 mm kissing balloon inflation in the LCX and OM1). . On the floor post-procedure, she was maintained on metoprolol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, ASA, and Plavix. Her lisinopril was titrated down on ___ because of systolic blood pressure in ___ which time she also required a 250cc IVF bolus. Her furosemide was held at this point given hypotension. She had a HCT drop from 37 to 31 from ___ to ___, down to 29 on the afternoon of ___. Groin U/S nl and pelvic CT read pending. . On the day of transfer to the CCU team, she complained of abdominal pain/tightness consistent with her anginal equivalent. On the evening of transfer, she became acutely hypoxic with sats to the mid 80's requiring a non-rebreather. Her SBP was in the 150s. ABG done showed 7.34/45/126. She was in acute respiratory distress and uncomfortable, moaning in pain. Her exam had wheezing and bronchospasm. Nebs were given and this improved. ECG showed possible precordial ST elevations possibly changed from baseline. CXR showed increase in vascular congestion. She was given IV lasix 40mg x 2 and 2mg morphine IV. The cardiology fellow came immediately and the attending was consulted. Meanwhile, Nitro gtt, Morphine IV were initiated, as well as heparin gtt. Labs were drawn which showed a slight elevation in troponin from previous (0.43 from 0.36) but flat CK and CK/MB. Discussions with the daughter about code status concluded continued DNR/DNI with possible reversal if catheterization was considered necessary. She is now being transferred for closer observation to the CCU team. . After transfer, she reports improvement in symptoms. She has at this point diureses 165cc from the IV lasix. She denies chest pain/pressure, abdominal pain/pressure, shortness of breath, LH. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> # HTN # dyslipidemia # CAD s/p NSTEMI x2 in past 3 months, medically managed # CHF w/ EF 25% s/p biV ICD # Peptic ulcer bleed ___ on full dose ASA # TIA Cardiac Risk Factors: Dyslipidemia, Hypertension <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> NC <PHYSICAL EXAM> (on admission) VS - 68.8kg BP 109/62 HR 72 RR 18 SaO2 95RA Gen: Elderly female in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. Neck: Supple with JVP of 8 cm. CV: RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. . summary: ___ Y F w/ hx of HTN, dyslipidemia, CAD s/p NSTEMI x2 in past 3 months, medically managed, CHF w/ EF 25% s/p biV ICD, and hx of GI bleed last year on ASA re-presented to ___ on ___ with recurrent SOB in acute CHF and ___ transferred to ___ for cath on ___. PCI here with right dominant system, LMCA without angiographically apparent disease, 90% proximal stenosis and a 90% distal stenosis of the LAD; the D1 had a 70% lesion. The LCX system had a small OM1 with 90% stenosis. The RCA was a small vessel totally occluded in its distal portion. Pt had BMS to proximal and distal LAD and OM1. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed pulmonary hypertension and elevated right heart filling pressures that improved s/p intervention (wedge high 20's to teens after intervention). On ___, she was mildly hypotensive in the 80's, at which time she was given a 250cc bolus. On ___ in the early morning, she complained of abdominal pain and tightness which were consistent with her anginal equivalent. She became hypertensive to the 150's systolic. She was started on a nitro drip, morphine IV, and heparin drip but troponins were slightly elevated (but flat CK/MB). She was transferred to the CCU for monitoring where she was diuresed and again, she became slightly hypotensive and required small fluid boluses. Her Lasix was held on the day of transfer given hypotension. She was transferred back to the cardiac floor after she was stabilized where the team decided to increase ACEi in order to reduce afterload which in turn should actually improve SBP --> blood pressure came up allowing us to again use furosemide 20mg po bid. In addition imdur was added back as it appeared that when she was ambulating with ___ she occasionally had anginal symtptoms that were relived by rest. With this intervention she had no further CP and he sbp remained in high

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ with history of alcoholic cirrhosis, peripheral neuropathy, and low body weight (___ 13) who presented with hypothermia after being found outside wearing less than adequate clothing, with hospital course notable for recurrent hypothermia, worsening pancytopenia and bradycardic epsiodes all likely due to malnutrition from disordered eating pattern. She was started on the eating disorder protocol and gained weight to reach >75% of IBW. Because of her poor judgment and limited insight guardianship was pursued and the court appointed a temporary guardian. Pt was offered voluntary transfer to inpatient psych or discharge to a partial program (___) as options to transition out of the hospital, however patient declined and was discharged home as per her wishes. #Hypothermia: Patient presented after being found outside without adequate clothing, initial temperature of ___. In the ED, the patient was rewarmed to ___ with active external warming, though was ___ on arrival to the floor. ECG demonstrated prolonged QTc with J-point elevations initially, though this improved on repeat once warmed. Lactate initially elevated, though this also normalized after becoming normothermic. During her hospital course she had multiple recurrent episodes of hypothermia despite controlled hospital environment, likely due to her extremely low body weight and her fixation on keeping the room temperature cool (supposedly for her skin condition). After she gained weight she was able to maintain a normal body temperature. Given multiple presentations of hypothermia with little regard for the consequences Psychiatry evaluated patient and decided she did not have ability to leave AMA. Guardianship was pursued and after a court hearing a temporary guardian was appointed until the next hearing which will take place on ___. #Eating disorder/Low BMI: BMI was noted to be 13 on admission. Pt did not think her weight was an issue, stating that she has always been on the thin side. Recently over the last

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> LTM admission for medication adjustment, aspiration <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is an ___ year old right-handed woman with a seizure disorder status post remote traumatic fall and subdural hemorrhage who presents electively for cvEEG monitoring for management of her seizures. Her seizure history begins around ___ when she had a traumatic fall with a head injury in her home. The trigger and mechanism for her fall is unknown. She was hospitalized and was found to have a right-sided subdural hemorrhage which was surgically removed. Her only known residual deficit was left eye ptosis. She returned home and as able to manage her ADLs independently until about six months after the hospitalization when she started having intermittent (monthly) episodes concerning for seizure. She was started on Levetiracetam which seem to reduce the frequency of events and which she tolerated without significant adverse effects. However, partly due to a second fall one year prior to this admission after which she broke her hip, her functional status has diminished and she now requires a walker. She was moved from ___ to a rehab facility closer to her son. In ___, she had a third fall with minor head injury during a fire drill at the facility, after which her cognitive status has been more impaired with intermittent confusion, agitation, and hallucinations. In ___, she started to express suicidal ideation and was admitted to ___'s inpatient psychiatry unit for further management during which topiramate and valproic acid were started. She had a recent admission to ___ in ___ when her anticonvulsants were further adjusted for improved seizure control. Shortly thereafter she returned with coffee-ground emesis and was treated conservatively with PPIs. Her psychiatrist requested expedited admission for medication adjustment on cvEEG monitoring because of her history of multiple admissions in several hospitals with several anticonvulsant and psychoactive medications added. The patient is quite agitated and angry upon this evaluation due to just recently being suctioned by nursing given her SaO2 levels in the ___. On ___ in the afternoon, she suddenly became weak... stopped responding verbally to questions and could not move much and open her eyes with slurred speech. Her son ___ thought that she might have had a seizure. On ___ she was thought to have an aspiration event but the circumstances are not documented in the notes provided by her facility (unclear if this was witnessed). [VII] No facial asymmetry with movement of muscles while talking. [IX, X] Palate elevation symmetric. [XII] Tongue midline. - Motor - Decreased bulk diffusely. summary: ___ yo W h/o prior R ___ c/b seizures here for cvEEG monitoring and improvement in her seizure management. She also had an aspiration event at her rehab facility prior to arrival, so she is being aggressively treated for aspiration pneumonia. Her mental status and pulmonary status have improved considerably on antibiotics. . [] Aspiration Pneumonia/Swallowing Dysphagia - She was noted one day prior to transfer to have developed likely aspiration pneumonia. Two days prior to admission she had an event where she became lethargic and less responsive. In speaking with the ___ nurses, it seems that she may have developed a pneumonia prior to these two observations. She was initially started on Ceftriaxone and Metronidazole. This was switched to Vancomycin and Cefepime upon arrival to ___ as Metronidazole can lower the seizure threshold. She was kept on supplemental oxygen. She had a bedside dysphagia screen which she failed, mostly due to excess oral secretions and agitation/poor cooperativity. She was kept NPO and was given IVF until her mental status and pulmonary examination improved. A discussion re: PEG/GT was carried out, and the family and our team wanted to wait until a Speech reevaluation before any decision was made. She was reevaluated on ___ by Speech who cleared her for a modified diet. She will be continued on Vancomycin and Cefepime for 3 more doses upon discharge to rehab. . [] Seizure Disorder - She has no clinical or electrographic seizures detected during this hospitalization, although her EEG does show frequent epileptiform discharges which were worse during the initial phase of her pneumonia and subsequently improved. . PENDING STUDIES: EEG final reports . TRANSITIONAL CARE ISSUES: [ ] Neurology - Please f/u her seizure frequency. [ ] ___ - Please continue to work with her s/p her recent hospitalization for pneumonia re: deconditioning. [ ] Speech Therapy - Please continue to reevaluate her swallowing and see if her diet can be advanced. Otherwise, please give recommendations

summary: ___ w/ PMH of HTN, T2DM, second degree AV block type I (dating back to ___, hx of penile CA, recurrent UTIs, and atypical chest pain, who presented with dizziness and bradycardia. Interview was conducted with the assistance of a ___ interpreter, and he described episodes of uncertainty as a mild discomfort that comes on and off while walking and standing. He attributed this feeling to variability in his blood pressures and low heart rate, which he only noted after frequently checking his vitals after the onset of symptoms. He noted one episode of feeling lightheaded while standing and looking up. He denied room spinning, fainting, or worsening of symptoms. Orthostatic vital signs in the ED were negative. He was fluid resuscitated with 1L NS. A CTA of the head and neck was negative for acute stroke or vertebral artery dissection. He was evaluated by cardiology and found to have typical AV nodal Wenckebach that was exacerbated by rest and normalized with exercise (while in the ED). On the floor, he had 2:1 or 3:1 at rest with rates in the ___ but his HR increased to the 100s with much less frequently dropped beats on exertion. He had no symptoms during these times. Given that his conduction with exertion and that we was symptomatic with normal conduction when evaluated by cardiology in the ED, pacemaker was deemed to not be indicated at this time. He was recommended to avoid AV nodal blocking agents and to have close outpatient follow-up with his cardiologist, Dr. ___. He was otherwise continued on his home acetazolamide, aspirin 81 mg, cyanocobalamin, felodipine, ferrous sulfate, finasteride, fluoxetine, and lisinopril, omeprazole, simvastatin, and tamsulosin 0.4 mg qhs. He was continued on his home CPAP for OSA. Home metformin, pioglitazone, and glipizide were held overnight, and he was placed on an insulin sliding scale.

The patient was found to have right distal femur fracture above a TKR, left ___ metatarsal fracture, and left distal fibula fracture. She was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for right distal femur ORIF, which the patient tolerated well (for full details please see the separately dictated operative report). The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given perioperative antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patients home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate. Postoperatively, she needed O2 by nasal cannula and slowly tolerated weaning of O2 in the next few days. Her Cr on admisison was 0.9 and increased to 1.4. Medicine was following, who recommended holding ___ for 1 dose and lowering Lovenox. She produced adequate urinary output. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs that were within normal limits, pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient will be discharged on ___ bridge to ___ for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up in two weeks per routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course, and all questions were answered prior to discharge. summary: This is a ___ year old female with PMH of cryptogenic cirrhosis complicated by varices, ascites, encephalopathy, hepatic hypdrothorax, caput medusae, and HCC s/p TACE, refractory iron deficiency anemia requiring IV ferrlecit/outpatient blood transfusions, CAD, diastolic CHF, pulmonary HTN, COPD on home O2, CKI, AAA s/p endovascular repair presenting for elective admission for chronic anemia after multiple failed attempts to place an IV in the pheresis unit for infusion of Ferrlecit and blood. . #. Iron deficiency anemia. The patient has severe iron deficiency from presumed slow/chronic GI losses and is scheduled for blood transfusions and IV Ferrlecit infusions as an outpatient in the pheresis center. She was scheduled for these infusions day before admission, but an IV could not be placed she was admitted to the hospital for IV access and PRBC/Ferrlecit infusions. Hgb=20.9 on admission. IV access was obtained and patient was transfused 2 units PRBCs in addition to IV Ferrlecit. . #. Cryptogenic cirrhosis. Complicated by varices, ascites, encephalopathy, hepatic hypdrothorax, caput medusae, and HCC s/p TACE. MELD=12 on admission. She was clinically volume overloaded with peripheral edema and ascites. She was started on IV Lasix 40mg BID in additino to home regimen of spironolactone, lactulose, nadolol. . #. CKI. Patient Cr is at recent baseline of 1.5. Chronic, stable . #. Hyponatremia. At baseline of 130. Free water restriction of 1L with improvement to 132. . #. Hyperglycemia. Patient has had longstanding hyperglycemia with no A1C. A1c ordered but pending on discharge. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Should discuss the option of a portacath in the future for frequent blood draws and transfusions - follow up A1c level - Consider EGD in her future

summary: ___ yo F with history of chronic diastolic CHF, T2DM, pulm hypertension who presents s/p fall and found to have oblique fracture through the T7 vertebral body. Investigations/Interventions: # Oblique T7 fracture: s/p fall, with ligamentous instability (MRI on ___ showed anterior longitudinal ligament rupture with mild associated prevertebral soft tissue edema). Patient went to OR ___ for the following interventions: 1. Posterior arthrodesis T5 through T7. 2. Posterior instrumentation T5 through T7. 3. Open treatment, posterior fracture, T8. 4. Open treatment, posterior fracture, T7. 5. Autograft, same incision. 6. Allograft, morselized. 7. Laminectomy T6-T7, T7-T8. Post-operatively, pain was controlled with oxycodone 7.5 mg PO Q4H:PRN and she worked with ___ who recommended discharge to rehab. She also had a spinal drain that drained less than 40 cc and was removed on ___. The provided TLSO brace is required when seated, standing, or ambulating. summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the gyn/onc service with an SBO. An NGT was placed for bowel rest/decompression in the ED prior to transfer to the gynecology oncology service. Her abdominal exam showed no peritoneal signs during her stay and she remained afebrile with a normal white blood cell count. She was managed conservatively and began passing flatus and having dropping NGT output. On HD 3, a clamp trial was attempted, however her NGT self discontinued while moving in bed. At that time, she began feeling nauseous and having episode of emesis without the NGT. Thus in the evening of HD3, the NGT was re-inserted. On hospital day 7, she had minimal NGT output and minimal residual after a clamp trial. She subsequently passed flatus and had bowel movements. Her NGT was removed and her diet was slowly advanced. She was seen by a nutrition consult to educate her about a low residue diet to follow for a period of time after discharge. On hospital day 9, she was tolerating a regular diet. She continued to pass flatus and bowel movements, and had a normal abdominal exam. She was discharged home in stable condition with scheduled outpatient follow up.

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the Operating Room where she underwent a VATS right lower lobe wedge resection and mediastinal lymph node dissection. She tolerated the procedure well and returned to the PACU in stable condition. She maintained stable hemodynamics and her pain was controlled with Tylenol and IV Dilaudid. Her ___ drain was on waterseal, had no air leak and minimal thin, bloody drainage. It was removed on ___, which she tolerated and a post pull CXR was normal. On ___, she was weaned off oxygen and was comfortable going home. She was tolerating a regular diet and her pain was well controlled. At the time of discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, her pain was well controlled on oral pain medication, she was ambulating without assistance, voiding adequately and spontaneously, and she was deemed stable for discharge home with appropriate outpatient follow-up. She verbalized understanding and agreement with the plan.

summary: PRIMARY REASON FOR ADMISSION: ============================= ___ with diastolic heart failure, pulmonary HTN (2L home O2), HTN, chronic pain presenting with shortness of breath and shoulder and knee pain . ACTIVE ISSUES: ============================= #) Shortness of breath: Patient reports signficant worsening of her SOB 1 day prior to admission. Likely secondary to ___ and/or pulmonary hypertension. Troponin x2 negative. She did not seem fluid overloaded on exam but did have mildly elevated proBNP at 1549 (1353 during prior admission) and mild pulmonary edema on CXR. She had gentle diuresis with IV lasix (once in ED, once the next day on the floor) with subjective improvement in symptoms. She was also continued on her home dose of sildenafil for pulmonary hypertension. Did not have additional O2 requirements and was breathing comfortably and satting well on her home 2L NC by time of discharge. . #) Shoulder and knee pain: Chronic issue that worsened the week prior to admission. Continued on home dose of vicodin (2 in am, 1 in pm) with good effect and she did not require supplemental pain medication. Takes prochlorperazine and zofran for nausea associated with pain meds. She is scheduled for left knee replacement in ___ and is being followed as an outpatient by orthopedics. CHRONIC ISSUES: ============================= #) H/o substance abuse: Reports last using cocaine 6 months ago. Urine tox negative. . #)Eosinophilia: Has absolute neutrophil count of 1064 --> mild eosinophilia. Has been ongoing since at least ___ with unknown etiology. . #) Hepatic fibrosis:  ___ etoh. LFTs wnl . #) GERD: continued home omeprazole and ranitidine . #) HTN: not on meds, monitor per routine TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ============================= - Will f/u with PCP and pulmonology (missed pulm appt) - Consider outpt hematology consult for eosinophilia - CODE: FULL

CT notable for markedly dilated gallbladder and CBD stones with a lipase of 1292 c/f gallstone pancreatitis. ERCP on ___ showed small filling defect in the mid CBD but no stone. Could be transient blockage of the ampulla by a stone that has now passed. Biliary sphincterotomy and sludge removal were performed. Repeat lipase here was normal. Alcoholic hepatic damage may be contributory given elevated AST and ALT w/ AST:ALT ratio  2. Had fever 100.2 with abd pain 10pm on ___ and was started on IV osyn. Got IV ofran once for nausea. Also had aggressive IVF repletion after ERCP. Had abd pain and nausea post-ERCP but has resolved as of morning ___, so was started on clear liquid diet and advanced as tolerated. Given resolution of symptoms--abd pain/nausea resolved and exam now benign--IV Fluids were discontinued and PO intake encouraged. Abx were discontinued given patient was afebrile and CBD sludge was cleared. To prevent future complications, the gallbladder was laparoscopically removed on ___. For the laparoscopic cholecystectomy patient was admitted under the acute care surgery service. He was taken to the operating room and underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. summary: The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where the patient underwent OPCABG x 2 with Dr. ___. Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. The patient was slow to wean from the vent given her significant smoking history. She was aggressively diuresed and eventually extubated on POD 4. She developed atrial fibrillation and converted to sinus rhythm with Amiodarone. Norvasc was resumed for hypertension as well as Hydralazine. She developed loose stool after her bowel regimen was increased. CDiff was negative and loose stool resolved. Anti-coagulation was initiated with coumadin, as AFib returned intermittently. The patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without complication. The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. Foley was re-inserted for urinary retention. She will undergo another void trial at rehab later this week. By the time of discharge on POD 10 the patient was ambulating, yet deconditioned the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged to ___ in ___ in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

summary: ___ yo male with history of seizure disorder, depression with SI/HI, GI bleed ___ secondary to gastritis, H. pylori positive who presents after falling from bus stop and landing on butt. After fall patient experienced increased testicular pain and bright red blood from his rectum. #Bright blood per rectum: Lower GI most likely given bright red blood in hemodynamically stable patient with stable hematocrit. Given history of prior episodes of bleeding with lifting, we considered bleeding from internal hemorrhoid. No external hemorrhoids noted on exam. Prior colonoscopy without evidence of IBS, AVM, Polyps. He did not have any evidence of rectal bleeding during this admission. #Back pain and perineal numbness: No fracture on CT. Some concern for cauda equina syndrome given his report of saddle anesthesia and accompanying back pain. Plan was to perform a MRI. Given that he was previously shot multiple times in the chest and pelvis, he had screening plain films of chest and femurs to evaluate for bullet fragments which would prevent an MRI. The patient left AMA before MRI was performed, as below. #Pain control: Analgesia was attempted with oral opiates and ketorolac. summary: ___ female history of CKDIII, HTN, Afib on pradaxa p/w ___ noted on outpatient labs. ___ on CKDIII: Baseline creatinine is around 2. Prior to presentation, she had noted cardboard/metallic taste, anorexia, decreased urine output, and sluggishness over the last 2 weeks, concerning for uremia. Outpatient labs were notable for Cr 4.1, which was repeated as 4.3 on admission. ___ was attributed to pre-renal etiology with poor po intake and responded well to IVF. A renal US was done and was unremarkable with no evidence of hydronephrosis. There was an initial concern for ATN given relative hypotension (presented with systolics in 100s-110s from typical BPs in 140s and above). However, creatinine did downtrend to 1.7 (bl 1.5-1.7) with IVF. Home Lasix, chlorthalidone, and lisinopril were held during admission and discontinued on discharge. #Slow atrial fibrillation: ___ hospital course was notable for HR in ___ with EKG and telemetry consistent with slow afib. This may have contributed in part to her relative hypotension. Patient was seen by EP and underwent DCCV with conversion to NSR on ___. She remained intermittently in NSR, sinus bradycardia, and slow afib during remainder of hospital course. After ___, she was resumed on amiodarone after it was initially held during hospital course. Of note, her home pradaxa was held initially given ___. She was briefly started on Coumadin with heparin gtt as bridge but was transitioned to apixaban 2.5 mg BID at discharge as GFR improved. Patient has a history of difficulty maintaining therapeutic INR with Coumadin. # Hypertension: In the outpatient setting, patient's home regimen had been uptitrated to include chlorthalidone in addition to lisinopril. However, throughout hospital course, she remained low-normotensive with systolic BP in 100s-110s, and these medications were held. Her relative hypotension persisted, and it was felt that this may be due

summary: ___ with COPD and history of chronic respiratory failure; s/p recent trach removal at rehab and here w/ increased secretions; now s/p replacement of trach and continued labile BP of unclear etiology. #. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Trach replaced on admission - had been removed 5 days prior to admission. Chest radiograph with white out of right middle and lower lung fields improved on discharge. Mucus plugging was high on differential. Possible pneumonia hidden within white out. Sputum culture grew Pseudomonas and Staph aureus  unclear if this was colonizer or actual infection. COPD exacerbation also on differential given considerable wheezing on admission. Initially treated with vancomycin, ceftaz, and TMP-SMX (given history of Stenotrophomonas). As no clear indication of active pneumonia (afebrile, slightly elevated WBC count which may be due to steroid therapy, and  culture thought to be colonizers), was started on treatment with short course of ceftaz for bronchitis. Tobramycin, which was initially added for double coverage of pseudomonas, and vancomycin were discontinued. Ceftaz day 4 on ___ midline placed for additional 3 days of administration. - Steroids initially increased and tapered to home dose on discharged (hydrocortisone 20mg PO QAM, 5mg PO QPM) - Needs aggressive sunctioning for continued considerable secretions - Staying on vent may be best option given patients level of discomfort off of vent - Flovent started ___ for severe COPD #. Hypotension: Occasionally pressured dropped to MAPs in ___. Thought initially to be related to adrenal insufficiency. No evidence of autopeep, hypovolemia, sepsis, or autonomic insufficiency. Has history of adrenal insufficiency, now on high dose steroids. On discharge decreased steroid dose to home regimen as above. # Schizoaffective d/o vs. schizophrenia: Per psych patient did not have capacity to refuse medical care on admission. Continued effexor, ris

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ for elective diagnostic right lower extremity angiogram. He was consented and all preoperative testing was done. He was prepped, and brought down to the endo suite room for surgery. He was closely monitored and remained hemodynamically stable. He tolerated the procedure well without any difficulty or complications. His sheath was removed without incident and ___ was stable without hematoma or ooze. He was transferred to the floor for observation overnight. The next day, his diet was advanced. He did have one episode of nausea and vomiting. EKG was unchanged and nausea resolved. Preoperative testing was performed in preparation for his upcoming bypass next week. Cardiac clearance was obtained from Dr. ___ cardiologist. He was discharged in stable condition with pain well controlled. His creatinine was at his baseline of 1.3 on discharge. He will stop taking plavix and start pletal prior to bypass.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mr ___, It was a pleasure taking care of ___ here at ___ ___ were admitted to the hospital after undergoing repair of your rectourethral fistula in a combined procedure with the colorectal and plastic surgeons. ___ have now recovered nicely from your procedure and are now ready to tbe discharged to a rehabilitation facility, where ___ should continue with your ongoing recovery. Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful recovery. ___ have a new ileostomy. The most common complication from a new ileostomy placement is dehydration. The output from the stoma is stool from the small intestine and the water content is very high. The stool is no longer passing through the large intestine which is where the water from the stool is reabsorbed into the body and the stool becomes formed. ___ must measure your ileostomy output for the next few weeks. The output from the stoma should not be more than 1200cc or less than 500cc. If ___ find that your output has become too much or too little, please call the office for advice. The office nurse or nurse practitioner can recommend medications to increase or slow the ileostomy output. Keep yourself well hydrated, if ___ notice your ileostomy output increasing, take in more electrolyte drink such as Gatorade. Please monitor yourself for signs and symptoms of dehydration including: dizziness (especially upon standing), weakness, dry mouth, headache, or fatigue. If ___ notice these symptoms please call the office or return to the emergency room for evaluation if these symptoms are severe. ___ may eat a regular diet with your new ileostomy. However it is a good idea to avoid fatty or spicy foods and follow diet suggestions made to ___ by the ostomy nurses. Please
summary: Mr ___ presented to ___ holding at ___ on ___ for repair of a rectourethral fistula. He tolerated the procedure well without complications (Please see operative note for further details). After a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was transferred to the floor for further post-operative management. Neuro: The patient received a dilaudid PCA with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. GI/GU/FEN: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO with IV fluids. Diet was advanced when appropriate, which was well tolerated. Patient's intake and output were closely monitored, and IV fluid was adjusted when necessary. Electrolytes were routinely followed, and repleted when necessary. The patient had a foley catheter placed in the OR, which was to stay in until follow-up with Dr ___ as an outpatient. Perineal drain output was routinely monitored and this was removed on POD#4. Right thigh drain was similarly routinely monitored, and removed on the day of discharge (POD#7). ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were closely watched for signs of infection. Patient received prophylactic antibiotics (Ancef/Flagyl) until discharge. Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined routinely; no transfusions were required. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. To ensure adequate take of the flap, patient was kept on bedrest for 72 hours after surgery. After this period, he resumed activity as tolerated without issues. On ___, the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, he was tolerating

summary: On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the antepartum service with hyperemesis at 8wk3d. She was given IV fluids and IV anti-emetics, zofran and ranitidine for GERD symptoms. She also took reglan fro additional relief. Her labs did not demonstrate abnormalities, She id not have ketonuria. She was continued on IV antiemetics until she was able to tolerate PO and this was accomplished on the second hospital day. For her history of chronic hypertension, she had baseline labs sent, showing a normal creatinine and LFTS.A 24 hour urine was deferred given her symptoms of dehydration. She also had a history of iron deficiency anemia. She had been treated in past and had planned an upcoming iron transfusion. This was ordered during her inpatient stay. By hospital day #2 she was tolerating a regular diet and on PO meds including zantac and reglan for her symptoms. She was then discharged home in stable condition with plan for outpatient follow up in 2 weeks. Discharge Medications: 1. Baclofen 20 mg PO TID 2. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU BID 3. Metoclopramide 10 mg PO TID PRN nausea RX *metoclopramide HCl 10 mg 1 by mouth every 8 hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*1 4. Prenatal Vitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 5. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Followup Instructions: ___

summary: PRINICPLE REASON FOR ADMISSION: ___ y/o woman with history of dementia and non-biopsy proven MDS, receiving transfusional support with 2 units PRBCs every 4 weeks who presented with worsening anemia, increased lethargy, lower extremity edema, and cough. ACTIVE PROBLEMS #. MDS and associated anemia: Nonbiopsy proven for which patient has required a transfusion every 4 weeks. She has not been responsive to ESA. Patient was transfused 2 units pRBC in clinic prior to admission, and 1 unit of prbcs during hospitalization with appropriate correction (hgb 5.1 -->8.6). ___ with Dr. ___ in 3 weeks for consideration of more frequent CBC checks and transfusions as this remains within goals of care at this time. #. Pneumonia. Patient with productive cough and evidence of a right hilar mass on chest x-ray. Patient also has a hx of GERD for which she is no longer on PPI - GERD as a cause of her symptoms is less likely given productive nature of her cough. Sputum gram stain and culture were contaminated. Patient completed a 5 day course of levofloxacin (last dose ___. Patient was administered guafenicin and tessalon pearls for symptomatic control. # UTI: positive u/a with contaminated urine culture. Patient completed a 5 day course of levofloxacin to treat both pneumonia and UTI (last dose ___. #. ___ extremity edema: Improved with gentle diuresis, elevation, and bandaging. Bilateral LENIs were negative for DVT and recent echo unremarkable. By time of discharge, ___ edema had almost resolved. Patient was discharged on 20mg po lasix daily. #. Falls: likely secondary to fatigue in the setting of severe anemia and increased ___ edema which limited mobility. There was no evidence of fractures on rib series. Patient is to be discharged to rehab to regain strength. She was given tylenol with good pain control for rib pain. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES # Please draw CBC, type and screen, and chem7 on ___ and

You are now being discharged with the following instructions: -Do not smoke. -Keep your wound(s) clean and dry / No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your date of surgery. -Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for signs of infection. -Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine (narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while taking narcotic pain medication. -You should not drive or operative heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesics as they may impair your cognitive functioning.
summary: Mrs. ___ underwent her thoracic spine stimulator replacement on the day of admission, ___. Originally, the expectations were that the patient would be discharged from PACU following her recovery. During that process, she required multiple trials of various agents for pain management, including ketamine, fentanyl, dilaudid, oxycodone, acetaminophen, gabapentin and toradol. Due to the difficulty in managing her pain, the patient was admitted to the inpatient ward and Chronic Pain was consulted. Recommendations were appreciated and incorporated in her inpatient orders. On hospital day 2 (POD 1), Mrs. ___ was in severe pain and weeping. Her pain was entirely incisional in nature and had nothing to do with her prior right lower extremity pain. Again, Chronic Pain evaluated the patient at bedside and provided further recommendations. Specifically, they recommended that the patient not have new narcotic agents added to her regimen, i.e. hydromorphone, and that her oxycodone ___ be increased to reflect her acute surgical needs. Her adjuvant non-narcotic agents were assessed and titrated as able, but much were already nearing maximum dosing. On this day, the patient was hesitant to move out of bed, aside from ambulating to the bathroom. On POD 2, ___, Mrs. ___ began to ambulate a bit more, but still stated her pain wasn't well controlled. Chronic Pain evaluated her again and felt that her current regimen was adequate and that she should not receive any further parenteral narcotic agents such as hydromorphone. Ibuprofen PRN was added to her regimen for additional synergistic effects. When this was discussed with the patient, she was angry and frustrated. At this time, it was explained that her current medication regimen was stable and would remain the same upon discharge. As she was ambulating more, she was prepared for discharge. The patient was adamant that she wanted hydromorphone upon discharge, but at the discretion of Chronic Pain, additional narcotics would not be

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> methylprednisolone / nifedipine / lisinopril / levofloxacin / yellow dye / Beta-Blockers (Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agts) / atorvastatin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> dyspnea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year old with a history of CAD s/p DES to ___, and Takotsubo cardiomyopathy who presents with pre-syncope. Starting last night the patient said that she woke up with diarrhea and had about 10 bouts of this over the course of the night. It started out as loose diarrhea and then progressed to watery stool that persisted into the morning with ___ more bowel movements. She denies any associated nausea, vomiting, fevers or abdominal discomfort. Upon waking up to start her day she says she initially felt overall okay other than her above-mentioned diarrhea. She then started doing some housework such as washing dishes cleaning up her home and initially started to feel slightly short of breath. This shortness of breath would improve after sitting down for a moment but would recur. On one episode when she went from seated to standing she felt sudden onset unsteadiness which she described as feeling wobbly. She said that it was if she was swaying back and forth while standing. Because of this she decided to lie down for about 30 minutes. While lying down on her couch she developed some chest pressure centrally located in her chest that did not radiate to her arms or shoulders. While lying down she says she also felt lightheaded and somewhat dizzy. She says that sometimes she has similar symptoms that occur with her panic attacks but this episode lasted much longer than usual. Because her symptoms were not remitting she decided to call the ambulance to get further evaluation. She was recently at ___ last ___ for shortness of breath. She was admitted there for a week, and was treated for an asthma exacerbation with concomitant tracheal bronchialmalacia. She was started on steroids. Initially sent home on a taper of 50 mg that was set to decrease by 10 mg every 3 days. She said that she had taken her dose prior to this episode of symptoms. She was also given a 5-day course of azithromycin for this as well. She says that after going home her breathing had improved and she had a few days then some of her symptoms started to recur. She says that she was using her albuterol rescue inhaler and nebulizers at home and these were helping her symptoms. She is unsure but thinks her weight may have been increasing in the last few days. By EMS was found to be in junctional bradycardia. She was given 3 doses of nitro and aspirin prior to arrival. Aspirin seemed to improve her symptoms but did cause some lightheadedness. In the ED: There was initial concern for pericardial effusion seen on a bedside US with tamponade physiology. However when this was repeated by cardiology they did not see any tamponade physiology and saw only a small pericardial effusion. - Initial vitals: Temp 36.5 HR 50 BP 100/48 RR 16 02 100% RA - EKG: bradycardia in a junction rhythm with ventricular rate of 50, no ST elevation or depressions - Labs/studies notable for: CBC: WBC 16.3 hgb 9.8 Plt 129 MCV 62 BMP: Na 133 K 6.0 Cl 95 HC03 25 BUN 75 Cr. 2.3 LFTS: AST 116 ALT 87 Alk Phos 79 T bili 0.3 Alb 3.6 COAGS: INR 0.9 Trop: Negative X1 CXR ___ IMPRESSION: Persistent marked enlargement of the cardiac silhouette. No overt pulmonary edema. Streaky bibasilar opacities may be due to atelectasis, but pneumonia or aspiration is not excluded in the appropriate clinical setting. - Patient was given: Normal saline Duo-nebs - Consults: Cardiology evaluated the patient and their recommendations were: - Formal TTE in the AM - Monitor on telemetry - Consider EP consult in the AM - K > 4 and Mg > 2 - Correct electrolyte abnormalities - Vitals on transfer: Temp 98.1 BP 137/70 HR 70 RR ___ RA On the floor the patient is feeling much better. She says that her chest tightness is no longer present and she has no ongoing shortness of breath. She otherwise confirms her above history. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Review of systems is otherwise negative or positive per the above HPI <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (diagnosed ___ - Asthma - ABPA on voriconazole for ___ year, stopped in ___ - ___ esophagus - H. Brother died of a cardiomyopathy at age ___. No hx of sudden cardiac death. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: Temp 98.0 BP 150/72 HR 72 RR ___ Ra GENERAL: Well-appearing older female lying in bed in no acute pain or distress resting comfortably HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL,

summary: Mr. ___ presented to the ED with c/o CP and dizziness. He was found to bradycardic in SR with rates ___. He reports that the Propanolol he takes prn for anxiety was recently increased from 10mg PRN TID to 20mg PRN TID. He ruled out for MI by enzyme and EKG. His propranolol was discontinued. His rate continued to be bradycardic during his hospital stay but rates improved to mainly ___'s and ___'s with occasional dips to the 30's. He was discharged back to ___ Shelter with follow up with his PCP in one week. # Sinus bradycardia - Baseline HR appears to be ___. Likely cause of current bradycardia is recent increased propranolol dose. No signs of ACS and troponin negative x2. There are no concerning changes on his EKG to suggest high grade heart block or other unstable rhythm. - discontinue propranolol -Follow up with PCP in one week Chronic problems: # Anxiety: - Continue hydroxyzine prn - Hold propranolol # PTSD: - Continue prazosin #Diabetes: diet controlled - Continue carbohydrate controlled diet #Dispo: Discharge to ___ shelter with follow up at PCP within ___ week

summary: ___ ___ female with PMHx myelodysplasia, CHF (EF 45%), CAD, aortic stenosis, CKD, and HTN, who presented with pre-syncope. In the ED, she was found to have BNP 15000s with pulmonary congestion on CXR, so she was treated for an acute CHF exacerbation with IV diuresis. She was also found to have an elevated Cr at 2.2 (baseline 1.3-1.5) which was thought to be cardiorenal, as it improved with diuresis. Cr 1.7 on discharge. The etiology of her pre-syncope was felt to be from bradycardia, as she was found to have HRs in the ___ while on tele. Her symptoms and HR improved after metoprolol was discontinued. Her problems were assessed, diagnosed, and treated as follows: #Presyncope: Resolved and remained asymptomatic in the hospital. Felt to be due to her bradycardia found on telemetry in the ___, improving once metoprolol was held. Less likely orthostatic given that she was found to be volume overloaded in the ED and diuresed. #Acute on chronic systolic CHF: Patient presented with ___, pro BNP >20000 and pulmonary edema on CXR. Has known valvular disease (MR/AS) and EF 40-45%. Troponin was mildly elevated and stable likely in the setting of CKD. Cr was improving with diuresis in the ED but then unclear whether she received 1L NS. She appeared euvolemic on exam. Last discharge weight 54.3kg. Restarted home torsemide on discharge, continued lisinopril, and held metoprolol. Daily I/Os and weights were checked and discharge weight was 50.3 kg. #Acute on chronic kidney disease: Patient with known CKD, baseline Cr 1.3-1.5. Now 2.2 on admission, improved to 1.9 with diuresis. Likely related to cardiorenal syndrome. Creatinine on discharge was 1.7. #CAD: Chest pain free. - Continued home atorvastatin and aspirin. Metoprolol held. #HTN: - Continued home amlodipine #Pancytopenia: Patient followed by heme-onc at ___, now with

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> codeine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Failure To Thrive, Altered Mental Status <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Intubation ___, extubation ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ male with basal cell carcinoma, hypertension, tobacco abuse, and recent diagnosis of metastatic lung adenocarcinoma who is admitted for failure to thrive and altered mental status. During work-up of facial BCC, patient was found to have a lung lesion which was biopsied and consistent with lung adenocarcinoma. He had several hospitalizations for failure to thrive. He underwent PET-CT which showed multiple FDG avid pulmonary nodules consistent with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. He was seen by Thoracic Surgery and Radiation Oncology who referred him to Medical Oncology. He was seen for his initial Medical Oncology visit today to discuss therapeutic options. Vitals were Temp 98.5, BP 97/50, HR 78, RR 16, O2 sat 100% RA. He was noted to be encephalopathic. Labs were notable for WBC 14.1, H/H 8.3/30.0, Plt 354, Na 155, K 5.4, BUN/Cr 84/3.4, LFTs wnl, albumin 2.5, phos 7.3, and Mg 3.1. He was referred to the ED with plan for admission to see if his performance status is improved after correction of reversible causes to allow for treatment. On arrival to the ED, initial vitals were 97.6 93 76/32 18 96% 2L. Exam was notable for cachexia, diminished strength, and left-sided basal cell carcinoma. Patient was triggered on arrival for hypotension. Labs were notable for WBC 14.6, H/H 8.___.2, Plt 400, INR 1.0, Na 157, K 6.1, Cl 113, BUN/Cr 88/3.8, lactate 1.6, and UA negative. CXR was negative for pneumonia. Head CT showed 4 mm hyperdensity along the genu of the corpus callosum on the left. Neurosurgery was consulted who recommended brain MRI. He was given 1L LR and 1L ___. Prior to transfer vitals were 97.4 78 100/42 16 99% 3L. Dr. ___ (___) and spoke to his RN ___. He reported patient has a waxing and waning mental status but noted to be more talkative and more alert this week than prior weeks. He is wheelchair bound and able to sit at the edge of the bed. He was found on the floor this past ___ without any observable injuries and no imaging was obtained. At baseline he knows his name. He reports the patient has very poor PO intake and often refuses meals. No recent fevers. Notes this BP was ___ yesterday with HR in ___ so his hypertension medications were held. Previously his SBP was 110-120s. He has been using 1L O2. The patient uses morphine for back pain but often has trouble rating the pain. He is a documented full code. On arrival to the floor, patient reports, stable, chronic right shoulder pain and thirst. He denies fevers or chills. No headache. Noted decreased vision bilaterally (chronic). Occasional dyspnea and chest pain which is long standing. Mild abd pain. No diarrhea or constipation. No urinary retention. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: A complete 10-point review of systems was performed and was negative unless otherwise noted in the HPI. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> #Metastatic lung adenocarcinoma Chart review showed that in ___ the patient was initially diagnosed with a 1.4 cm solid nodule in the right upper lobe and a partly spiculated 2.2 x 1.8 cm left upper lobe lung lesion in the setting of workup for basal cell carcinoma. Also there was a 1.9 x 1.1 cm left submandibular lymph node and a 1.1 x 1.0 cm left pre-jugular lymph node. In ___ he underwent CT-guided biopsy of the left upper lobe lung mass was that showed lung adenocarcinoma with TTF-1, Napsin, and CK7; CK20 was negative. Biopsy was complicated by moderate post-biopsy hemorrhage and moderate left pneumothorax requiring admission and chest tube placement. In ___ to ___ his clinical status was decompensated and required hospitalization for failure to thrive. PET/CT on ___ showed a 6.5 x 3.1 cm left facial lesion with SUV of 12.5 representing the known basal cell carcinoma; there were 2 lymph nodes along the left lateral jaw measuring up to 0.9 cm short axis with SUV up to 3.9; there were multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules including a 1.6 x 1.6 cm lesion in the left lung with SUV 8.3, a 1.3 x 1 cm nodule in the left lung with SUV of 8.1, and a 1.4 x 1.2 cm nodule with SUV of 4.0 in the right lung; there were multiple FDG-avid hilar lymph nodes with SUV of 3.5; there were no abdominal, pelvic, or bone metastases. #Advanced left face basal cell carcinoma #History of tobacco use #Possible CAD (based on ECG) #Hypertension #s/p right second, third, and partial fourth finger amputation at age ___ due to trauma <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of malignancy. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: T 97.4 BP 91
summary: ___ man with past medical history of left facial basal cell carcinoma (6.5 x 3.1 cm), and recent diagnosis of metastatic lung adenocarcinoma (multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules, no lesions outside the chest), admitted with significant dehydration, hypotension, ___, and hypernatremia, leading to encephalopathy, as well as severe cachexia. # Acute encephalopathy: This is most likely due to initial dehydration, pain, chronic illness. 4mm lesion seen on CT of the head could be metastasis versus small hemorrhage, but unlikely to account for mental status. Mental status seems improved, alert, but less oriented today. His mental status waxed and waned prior to ICU transfer. # Acute hypoxic respiratory failure: He required up to 6L NC on the floor and CXR showed right mid-lower lung opacity. Given his history of dysphagia, there was high concern for possible aspiration, even though he was afebrile with only slight leukocytosis. He was started on Unasyn 3g Q12H (renal dosing) ___ for suspected aspiration pneumonia. Ultimately he likely had another aspiration event leading to worsening respiratory failure requiring intubation. # Severe dehydration with hypotension # Acute renal failure: This was likely somewhat chronic, with prerenal component as well as possible intrarenal (acute tubular necrosis). Post-renal was less likely, with initial bladder scan was only 223 cc. Renal function was improving prior to ICU transfer. # Metastatic lung adenocarcinoma: On ___, PET-CT showed multiple pulmonary nodules consistent with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. He was seen by Thoracic Surgery and Radiation Oncology who referred him to Medical Oncology. Outpatient oncologists are Dr. ___, Dr. ___. He was planning to get chemotherapy but when arriving to clinic for his initial medical oncology appointment, and the discussion about chemotherapy, he was found to have all the issues that led to this admission. Due to his declining functional status and severe medical problems, ultimately he was not a candidate for therapy for his cancer. # Advanced left face basal cell carcinoma:
