summary: Active Issues: # Atrial flutter - Mr. ___ presenting in a rapid heart rate with a rhythm consistent diagnosed as atrial flutter. He was treated with metoprolol for rate control with heart rates in the ___. Cardioversion was considered, but deferred because he was diagnosed with influenza. His ICD was interrogated with the notable finding of multiple devise firings. Upon further questioning, the patient did agree that he had experienced defibrillation multiple times. He had not informed anyone of these episodes. Based on interrogation, it was concluded that he had been receiving defibrillation shocks for high rates of atrial tachycardia. The need to inform his physicians about defibrillation events was stressed to the patient. He was also restarted on his previous dose of digoxin, but his dofetilide was held until such time as he can be cardioverted. At his request, his anticoagulation was switched from warfarin to rivaroxiban. # Influenza - Acute febrile illness with nasal swab positive for influenza A. With the onset of his symptoms two days prior to presentation, he was treated with five days of oseltamivir. He was also given supportive care with acetaminophen, anti-tussive medications, and oxycodone for rib pain. # Coronary artery disease/ischemic cardiomyopathy - Mr. ___ was euvolemic after initial fluid recussitation and remained so throughout his hospital stay. He had been on triple therapy with aspirin, warfarin, and clopidogrel. As discussed above, he was started on rivaroxiban. His clopidogrel was stopped to avoid the risks of triple anticoagulation therapy as he is greater than 12 months from his last acute coronary syndrome or stent placement. He was restarted on his pravastatin (previous intolerance of atorvastatin). # Non adherence - His lack of follow up and self-discontinuation of medications was discussed with the patient by multiple physicians. A social work consult was also placed. He reported difficulty with paying for medications in the past, however, stated that this was

summary: ___ yo female who presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and cough x 6 days in the setting of influenza A. Patient initially refused influenza testing, but subsequently was agreeable. Influenza PCR was positive. She was treated with CXR revealed evidence of mild bibasilar atelectasis, left greater than right, without convincing evidence for pneumonia. It is possible that patient has concurrent norovirus or other gastroenteritis, but this is thought less likely. Stool cultures negative for CDIFF, but other stool studies pending. Patient discharged without nausea and tolerating oral intake. Patient is advised to hold trazodone given possible drug-drug interaction with ofran. Patient should have outpatient providers review all medications for interactions and dose appropriateness. Ambulatory oximetry equal to or greater than 93% without dyspnea. Patient is educated about and provided resource materials on influenza and infection prevention. Hospital course, assessments, and discharge plans discussed with patient who expressed understanding and agreed with discharge.

summary: ___ who presented with acute perforated appendicitis with a 4cm pelvic abscess. She was initially made NPO and started on IV antibiotics. Her pain improved so her diet was advanced as tolerated. She was transitioned to oral cipro/flagyl for a ___t the time of discharge, her pain was controlled with tylenol. She was voiding, tolerating a regular diet and ambulating. She was deemed stable for discharge on a 2 week course of PO antibiotics with 2 week followup with a scheduled CT abdomen/pelvis prior to her appointment to reevaluate her abscess.

summary: The patient was admitted to the Surgical Oncology Service for port-a-cath removal secondary to hematoma. The port was removed on ___ without complications. The patient was admitted for post op observation secondary to high risk of bleeding. On POD # 1, patient's surgical site was without active bleeding and patient was discharged home in stable condition. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> osyn / ceftriaxone / tuberculin ppd skin test <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Lethargy <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with history of multiple sclerosis, dementia, neurogenic bladder with indwelling foley, right staghorn calculus, left obstructing UVJ stone with nephrostomy tube presented from ___ with worsening lethargy and no output from nephrostomy tube for the two days prior to admission. The patient was also reported to have been satting at 77% on NBR when EMS arrived. The patient has been admitted three times in the past year with urosepsis. In the ER, the patient was febrile to 102.8 and tachycardic. She had a leukocytosis to 16.4. Her foley catheter was exchanged and foul-smelling urine emerged. She had numerous excoriations within and around her vagina and decubitus ulcers on her sacrum. The nephrostomy tube was encrusted, and when cleaned, purulent discharge emerged. She also had erythema and fluctuance with expressible pus around the nephrostomy site. The patient was given vancomycin, aztreonam, and flagyl. She was transferred to the MICU with a systolic pressure of 85 on peripheral low-dose levophed. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Multiple Sclerosis - about ___, followed by ___ at ___ - wheelchair at baseline, lives in nursing home - has no use of her lower extremities, sometimes spastic movements - bladder chronically contracted UTI with ESBL E.coli--sensitive to zosyn, ___, gent in past Chronic Depression Anxiety PVD s/p lower extremity bypass COPD Osteoporosis Hx of PPD bilateral femur supracondylar fractures ___ hx of Urosepsis - hospitalized about once/yr, per husband ___ bladder - indwelling foley x ___ yrs, per husband ___ C. ___ Hx of Sacral ___ ___ spasticity Hx of jaw pain -- TMJ, improved on Tegretol <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family members with Multiple ___. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Exam on Admission: General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, EOMI, PERRL Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no organomegaly GU: no foley Ext: warm, well perfused, 2 pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema Neuro: CNII-XII intact, ___ strength upper/lower extremities, grossly normal sensation, 2 reflexes bilaterally, gait deferred, finger-to-nose intact . summary: The patient is a ___ year old female with history of MS, dementia, neurogenic bladder with indwelling foley, b/l calculi s/p left nephrostomy presenting with fatige and found to have urosepsis. . ACUTE ISSUES #Urosepsis: The patient has long history of urinary tract infections with MDR organisms including ESBL e. coli and pseudomonas due to her abnormal anatomy. She has been considered for lithotripsy of left UVJ stone in past but thought to be high risk due to cardiac co-morbidities. The patient also has a staghorn calculus in the right kidney. She presented febrile to 102.8 and with systolic pressure in the ___. Patient was found to have foul-smelling urine from foley and purulent material emanating from nephrostomy tube in the ER. She was started on low-dose peripheral levophed and transferred to the MICU. She was started on meropenem for likely ESBL E. coli and vancomycin. A Dobhoff tube was inserted and the patient was started on tube feeds. A goals of care discussion was had with the patient's husband, and it was decided that the patient would seek comfort measures only (see below). The patient was transferred to the floor for continued management despite low pressures. On the floor she remained clinically stable without the need for pressure support. Her antibiotics were discontinued upon discharge. . #Goals of care: The goals of care were discussed with the patient and husband in both the ICU and the general medicine floor. After a long discussion, it was decided that the patient would be continued on IV antibiotics and tube feeds while inpatient. On the floor, the patient removed her Dobhoff tube, and it was decided with the husband not to reinitiate it. The patient's husband wished to keep patient comfort at the forefront, but wanted to continue interventions until the patient either declined or discontinued them herself. Palliative care was consulted and it was planned that the patient would return

summary: He was admitted to the cardiology service and remained chest pain free. He underwent routine preoperative testing and evaluation. He developed early signs of gout flare in the right and left hallux. He was treated with two doses of colchicine. Given his history of alcohol abuse and withdrawal symptoms, he was placed on a CIWA scale with good effect. Social work was consulted for alcohol abuse. He remained hemodynamically stable and was taken to the operating room on ___. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting x 4. Please see operative note for full details. He tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. He weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and was extubated on POD 1. He was weaned from inotropic and vasopressor support. Beta blocker was initiated and he was diuresed toward his preoperative weight. He remained hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery. His home medications were titrated as tolerated. He was weak and deconditioned and took a few extra days to be deemed safe for discharge to home. He was tachycardic in the post-op period and his Lopressor was adjusted. His BP is somewhat labile in light of Narcotic use and Tizanidine useage. He I high risk for narcotic abuse and will need to be weaned off Dilaudid as sternal wound pain improves. Alternative with Tylenol for pain management. He was aggressively diuresed and was placed back on HCT at discharge, as he was at his pre-op wgt without significant edema. He was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 6 he was ambulating freely, his wounds were healing, and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. He was advised not to use alcohol. Patient was discharged to home in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

summary: ___ y/o G1P0 admitted at 236 weeks gestation with likely viral URI and gastroenteritis. . Ms ___ was admitted for close observation and IV hydration. Labs were stable and she was afebrile. On HD#2, her cough was worse and her oxygen saturation was down to 92% on room air. On exam, she had some expiratory wheezes and poor air movement. She has no history of asthma but is a smoker. She was treated with supplemental oxygen and albuterol nebulizers. CXR showed no evidence of pneumonia. Medicine was consulted and recommended a steroid taper. She was started on the Prednisone taper and continued on Albuterol and Atrovent nebulizers and was able to wean off the oxygen and maintain a saturation of 98%. Her diarrhea resolved and she was tolerating a regular diet. Sputum, urine, and stool cultures were all negative. In regards to fetal well-being, she starting getting NSTs at 24 weeks and had reassuring testing. On ___, ultrasound revealed a vertex fetus, BPP ___, and nl AFI. . Social services followed her during this admission and will continue to see her. She has no support and has multiple needs. Ms ___ is deaf and ASL interpreter was used during patient interviews and discharge planning and instructions. She has multiple followup appoitments scheduled, see below.

summary: ___ yr old female with compression fx followed by vasovagal syncope. . COMPRESSION FRACTURE: Compression fracture at this age is concerning for underlying pathology. ___ years of prednisone use is a possible explanation for early osteoperosis. Would also consider malignancy, although colon cancer does not frequently metastisize to bone. CEA and bone scan were normal. No evidence of metastatic disease on MRI of T and L spine. Instead, diffuse osteoperotic changes were seen. These findings were all reassuring that the process was related to osteoperosis. Patient was started on calcium, Vitamin D and alendronate. A TLSO brace was placed to be worn when OOB. Her pain was managed with IV morphine, which was converted to PO percocet prior to discharge. Patient will wear brace until follow up with orthopedics. . SYNCOPAL EPISODE: This is most likely vasovagal in setting of pain. No EKG, telemetry, CE, or Echo evidence of heart disease. Echo showed mild pulmonary artery HTN and TR, which would not explain syncope. Head CT normal. No evidence of seizure activity. ___ have been dehydrated. . ADRENAL ADENOMA: An adrenal adenoma was incidentally found on CT scan. She has normal blood pressures and electrolytes. She should have further outpatient workup. . COUGH/URI: Has been inproving, likely viral syndrome - wean O2 as tolerated . LUPUS/RA: currently not on medications. . Comm: Daughter ___ ___ . Code: FULL

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> lisinopril / Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Altered mental status <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease, and cognitive decline who presented with acute onset of confusion and drooling. The patient was in his usual state of health until around 1530 on ___, when he was sitting in the shade next to his cousin in his backyard and started feeling cold and had chills. Per his son's report, he yawned and then his head slumped forward and he was drooling on his right side. He had no head strike or shaking. He initially had difficulty getting words out, but asked his cousin to take him indoors. His two cousins helped him walk up the stairs to the bathroom and thought he was very weak, but not more on one side or one limb. Per the nightfloat note, a cousin noticed that the patient was drooling, confused, and he did not seem to know where he was and his memory just went. There was no facial asymmetry or speech disturbances. 911 was called and measured a fingerstick blood glucose of 204 and a blood pressure of 190/75. Initially the patient refused to go into the ambulance. The patient's wife called their son ___ who drove the patient to the ___ emergency department. A code stroke was called and his stroke scale was 1. Per the son, the patient was at his baseline during the neurologic exam in the emergency department. The son reports that the patient occasionally becomes confused when his blood pressures are elevated. A similar prior episode occurred in ___ when the patient became temporarily disoriented while sitting with the son in a car. In the emergency department, his initial vitals were: 98.4, 85, 190/75, 20, 100% on room air. - Labs were significant for creatinine 1.5 (baseline 1.2), negative urine toxicology, negative troponins x1. - Imaging: Chest x-ray: 1. Lentiform opacity projecting over the left lung base is nonspecific and may represent loculated pleural fluid. Non-contrast head CT: No acute intracranial process. Of note MRI would be more sensitive for detection of acute ischemia. 2. Retrocardiac opacity is worrisome for pneumonia. - The patient was not given medications / intravenous fluids. Admitted for syncope workup, acute kidney injury Vitals prior to transfer were: 98.0 73 164/75 20 100% room air. On arrival to floor, patient denied acute complaints. He reported that he was brought to the hospital because he was outside watching someone he hired fixing the roof, got acutely cold and was out of it after. On the morning of admission, he denies headache, loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, or dizziness. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending speech. Denies focal weakness, numbness, paresthesias. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait. Denies recent fever or chills. No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> poor medication adherence HTN DM HLD Hx colon cancer Hx prostate cancer CKD (baseline 1.2) cognitive decline (undiagnosed - AOx2 at baseline) concern for cerebral amyloid angiopathy on prior MRI <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> His sister had a recent stroke. Family history of hypertension and diabetes. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ON ADMISSION Vitals: Tm 97.9 Tc 97.9 HR ___ BP 175/75-182/71 RR 20 O2 100% on RA General: AAOx1 (to self, not to hospital name or date), comfortable appearing, in NAD HEENT: NCAT, EOMI, PERRL. Sclera anicteric. Neck: supple Lungs: CTAB, no w/r/r CV: RRR, normal S1 and S2, no m/g/r, delayed radial pulses Abdomen: soft, nondistended, nontender. Vertical midline hypertrophic scar. GU: no foley Ext: WWP. 2 peripheral pulses. No edema. Neuro: CNs II-XII intact. Oriented to self, not to hospital or date. Symmetric face. Speaking in full sentences, but tangential. No word-finding difficulties. ___ strength in all upper and lower extremities. ON DISCHARGE Vitals: Tm 98.0 Tc 97.6 HR 53-61 BP 166/86(peak 170/74 overnight) RR 18 O2 100% on RA FSBG 160 Orthostatics: 163/65 sitting and 138/71 standing, asymptomatic General: Elderly gentleman in NAD sitting in chair, AAOx1 (to self, not to hospital or date), wants to go home HEENT: EOMI, PERRL
summary: Mr ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease (baseline creatinine of 1.2), cognitive decline, and medication non-adherence who presented with acute onset of confusion and drooling, found to have hypertension (blood pressure to 190/75), acute kidney injury (creatinine up to 1.6) and with resolution of altered mental status in the ED. # Altered mental status: He presented to the ED following a transient episode of confusion. Given the absence of lateralizing deficits, spontaneous resolution of symptoms, a negative non-contrast head CT, and reassuring exam, there was very low clinical concern for acute ischemic stroke, despite the patient's multiple risk factors. Hypertensive emergency given his SBP>180 in the setting of medication non-adherence may have manifested as altered mental status and acute kidney injury. Alternatively, his acute kidney injury, hyperglycemia, and hypertension all could have contributed to some transient encephalopathy. The neurology team evaluated the patient and did not feel that an cerebrovascular event or transient ischemic attack was likely. We gradually lowered his blood pressure with hydralazine and labetalol. His blood pressure was well-controlled with systolics in the 140s to 160s on discharge. # Hypertensive urgency vs emergency: His blood pressure of 190/75, altered mental status, and acute kidney injury were concerning for hypertensive emergency if his confusion and new acute kidney injury were secondary to his hypertension. We treated him with hydralazine, which was discontinued prior to discharge. We continued his home amlodipine 10mg daily and started him on labetalol 100mg twice a day before discharge. We stopped his home hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg twice a day once due to his acute kidney injury and poor oral intake. # Acute kidney injury: His creatinine rose to 1.6 in the ED from a baseline of 1.2. His urine electrolytes were not concerning for dehydration. We gave him fluids ad after his creatinine normalized, he was discharged home

summary: Ms. ___ presented with chest discomfort of ___. She had a troponin elevation of 2.54, BNP 236. There were new EKG changes. She was transferred for coronary angiography with revascularization. She reports recently being restarted on her Spironolactone at 25 mg twice daily. This was stopped last hospitalization for hyperkalemia. She reports having bradycardia on metoprolol in the past, but now has an atrial lead. Her sotalol has been changed to amiodarone. She is tolerating this well. She feels her fluid status is okay despite post-cath. She is due to get her torsemide this morning. She any orthopnea, PND, palpitations, current angina, history of syncope recently. Cardiovascular Testing: Coronary angiogram ___: Patent left main stent into Diag, LAD proximally occluded filled by SVG with 90% stenosis s/p DES, LIMA-Diag patent, patent ramus stent, circumflex occluded, RCA occluded, SVG to PLV occluded, SVG to OM occluded TTE ___: dilated LV, ischemic CMP EF 15%-20%, 2 TR # CAD/NSTEMI: She was accessed through the left radial artery and had PCI for NSTEMI with drug-eluting stent of the SVG to the LAD coronary artery. She received 130 cc of contrast. Post interventional recommendations included Plavix daily, ASA daily and switching Metoprolol to Toprol XL. summary: ___ male with a history of EtOH abuse who is s/p MVC vs. tree and was found to have evidence of cirrhosis on CT #Hypotension - The cause of his hypotension is not entirely clear, although may have been related to the sedation used for sedation while intubated. There was no evidence of bleeding on his imaging. He was initially on pressors and intubated while in the trauma ICU, these were weaned on the second day of admission and he maintained a BP in the 100-110s systolic. #Cirrhosis - He was formerly followed by a hepatologist at ___ and has received a work-up for his cirrhosis in the past. Other causes were ruled out and he was determined to have alcoholic cirrhosis. He required periodic paracenteses for tense ascites. Hepatology was consulted as an inpatient. Initially, his Lasix, propranolol and spironolactone were held because he was hypotensive upon admission after the car accident. These were slowly re-introduced and at discharge, he was tolerating spironolactone 100mg and lasix 40mg. Propranolol continued to be held at discharge. He has been arranged follow-up with a hepatologist and a new PCP as he does not currently have a regular PCP. #EtOH - Precontemplative/contemplative on alcohol abstinence. Declined getting help with services, was seen by social work while in the trauma ICU. He states that he will try to attend AA meetings near is home. He was kept on a ___ protocol for withdrawal during this admission. #Hyponatremia - Thought to be related to his cirrhosis and low ECV. Hepatology recommended against a fluid restriction and his Na remained >130. #Code status this admission - FULL CODE #Transitional issues -Will need propranolol, spironolactome and Lasix up-titrated as his BP tolerates -Has been arranged for follow-up with hepatology at ___ after discharge -Has also been given an appointment with a new PCP at ___ as he

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to Urology after undergoing RIGHT radical nephrectomy. No concerning intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable condition. On POD0, pain was well controlled with epidural and she was hydrated for urine output >30cc/hour, provided with pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis, and ambulated once. On POD1, the patient was restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel and complete blood count were checked, pain control was transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a clears/toast and crackers diet. On POD2, JP and urethral Foley catheter were removed without difficulty and diet was advanced as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course was relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition on POD3, eating well, ambulating independently, voiding without difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. The patient was given explicit instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. ___.

summary: ___ year old woman with a history of recurrent multi-drug resistant urinary tract infections who was admitted to the hospital with a possible urinary tract infection as her UA was concerning for infection, although it had large amounts of epithelial cells. She had a history of UTIs (proteus) resistant to fluoroquinolones and all cephalosporins (including ___ and ___ generation) in the past. She had 2 urine cultures. The first was negative and the second was pending at the time of discharge ( initial: Alpha hemolytic colonies consistent with alpha streptococcus or Lactobacillus sp). She was treated empirically with Bactrim because of history of proteus. The patient is known to have bilateral staghorn nephrolithiasis requiring left ureteral stent placement. She was supposed to have ureteral stent removed, but she has missed her appointment. We contacted urology who rescheduled her for an earlier appointment for stent removal ( not good to manipulate a stent with possible infection). She had a renal U/S without change in her hydronephrosis. During this hospitalization, she was noted to have severe and progressive anemia that goes back for at least last ___ years. She has Sickle cell trait which does NOT cause anemia. Iron studies revealed significant deficiency which was consistent with her prior tests. She stopped taking her Iron supplements, and had no external bleeding except for regular periods. She had one colonoscopy long time ago. She was asymptomatic except for significant tachycardia on ambulation ( HR 135; resting HR of 85). She denied SOB or palpitations. She had no history of cardiac disease but long standing anemia is associated with cardiomyopathy. The patient was never seen by a hematologist. Her kidney function was borderline and may or may not explain anemia of chronic disease. She had unremarkable echocardiogram and lung scans. These were done to exclude structural heart problems or PE to explain the exertional tachycardia (other than anemia). She received one dose of IV Ferrlecit in the hospital

summary: Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old female who is s/p 2 kidney transplants (___) who was seen in ___ clinic ___ and found to have Cr 2.9 (baseline 1.7). A renal biopsy was taken and the patient was found to have acute humoral rejection. #. Acute humoral rejection - The patient was found to have an elevated creatinine at ___ clinic on ___. She was admitted to ___ and a renal biopsy was performed to evaluate for the possibility of rejection. The renal biopsy showed e/o acute humoral rejection and the patient was started on a course of plasmapheresis and steroids. A tunneled catheter was placed for the pheresis. DSAs were sent. Over the course of her hospital course, the patient underwent multiple pheresis sessions. Over the first 3 days of her stay, Ms. ___ also received 500mg solumedrol which was tapered over her stay to 20mg of prednisone. Her creatinine remained elevated (>2.5) and the decision was made to start ATG. Ms. ___ received 4 sessions of ATG treatment. On discharge, the patient's creatinine remained elevated. She is otherwise asymptomatic and will follow-up with her tranplant nephrologist. #. Hypertension - The patient has baseline HTN which is treated at home with amlodipine, lisinopril and labetolol. Lisinopril was held in the setting of high Cr. During the ___ hospital stay, she was noted to have high BPs (in the 160-170s systolic). It was believed that the elevated BPs were secondary to steroids and fluid overload from pheresis. She was started on a course of diuretics and her labetolol dosage was increased. The patient's BPs improved and she felt subjectively less fluid overloaded with decreased SOB and edema. The patient was discharged on 600mg labetolol 3x daily and 20mg furosemide. Lisinopril was not restarted. #. High ___ - The patient had elevated ___ while in house. Likely ___ steroid therapy. She was started on glipizide 2.5mg BID while in house and will

summary: Global Assessment: ___ years old female with self reported depression, anxiety, multiple prior psychiatric hospitalizations and 1 prior SA, also with PMH of multiple sclerosis, L sensorineural hearing loss, migraine headaches, and HTN presenting with several neurovegetative sx of depression and SI in the setting of financial and psychosocial stressors. Etiology of presenting sx was unclear as clinical picture was complicated by patient's affective lability, hypervigilence, and preoccupation with injustice/persecution. Ddx was initially broad, but the pt did very well during her stay and appeared to suffer from complex PTSD w/ co-morbid depression and personality d/o traits. #. Complex PTSD / Depression / Personality d/o traits: On admission, she reported sx of depression and anxiety, was passively suicidal and very irritable, with affective lability and demonstrated pervasive distrust and preoccupation with injustice and feelings of persecution. This persistent during first couple of days of hospitalization, but seemed to improve some after team started antidepressant medication and helped to address some psychosocial stressors. Patient was medication compliant, though complained Celexa caused sedation and this medication was subsequently administered at night. Patient began attending groups and found them helpful, but on multiple occasions felt violated or provoked by staff and become very upset, perseverative and difficult to console. Overwhelmingly, her initial sx of irritability/lability subsided and so did her paranoia. She was able to make good relationships on the unit w/ others and was very positive w/ staff and primary team. Safety: Patient remained in good behavioral control throughout this hospitalization, except for outbursts in response to feeling persecuted or violated by staff, but she did not require physical or chemical restraint. The patient remained on 15 minute checks, which

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Status Post ERCP with Ampullectomy <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ERCP with Ampullectomy ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ male with history of eosinophilic esophagitis who was recently found to have an ampullary adenoma presents after planned ERCP for ampullectomy and admitted for routine post-ERCP monitoring and care. He underwent successful and uneventful ERCP with ampullectomy and PD plastic stent placement (to decrease risk of pancreatitis). He did have some post-procedural pain described as bloating / gas and pain across mid-abdomen and improved after IV dilaudid in the recovery room. Per ERCP signout, he could potentially develop pancreatitis, will keep NPO overnight, hydrate and manage pain as needed. Will reassess in am to decide whether he warrants further workup to assess for pancreatitis. On arrival to the floor patient denied active pain, nausea or vomiting. He further denied SOB, palpitations, reflux, or chest pain. ROS: Pertinent positives and negatives as noted in the HPI. All other systems were reviewed and are negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Eosinophilic Esophagitis Scombroid poisoning History of depression, none currently. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother has type 2 diabetes. Father has no chronic problems. Paternal grandfather had prostate cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VITALS: Temp: 97.7 PO BP: 125/78 HR: 69 RR: 18 O2 sat: 97% O2 delivery: RA Dyspnea: 0 RASS: 0 Pain Score: ___ GENERAL: Alert and in no apparent distress EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. Oropharynx without visible lesion, erythema or exudate CV: Heart regular, no murmur, no S3, no S4. No JVD. RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation with good air movement bilaterally. Breathing is non-labored GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender to palpation. Bowel sounds present. No HSM GU: No suprapubic fullness or tenderness to palpation MSK: Neck supple, moves all extremities, strength grossly full and symmetric bilaterally in all limbs SKIN: No rashes or ulcerations noted NEURO: Alert, oriented, face symmetric, gaze conjugate with EOMI, speech fluent, moves all limbs, sensation to light touch grossly intact throughout PSYCH: pleasant, appropriate affect DISCHARGE EXAM: GENERAL: Alert and in no apparent distress EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. CV: Heart regular, no murmur RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation with good air movement bilaterally GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender to palpation. Bowel sounds present. GU: No suprapubic fullness or tenderness to palpation MSK: Neck supple, moves all extremities PSYCH: pleasant, appropriate affect NEUROLOGIC: MENTATION: alert and cooperative. Oriented to person and place and time. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ERCP Report Medications: Cipro 400mg IV Glucagon 0.2mg IV indomethacin study dose Monitored care anesthesia Procedure: The procedure, indications, preparation and potential complications were explained to the patient, who indicated his understanding and signed the corresponding consent forms. A physical exam was performed. The patient was administered MAC anesthesia. The patient was placed in the prone position and an endoscope was introduced through the mouth and advanced under direct visualization until the third part of the duodenum was reached. Careful visualization was performed. The procedure was not difficult. The quality of the preparation was good. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no complications. Findings: Esophagus: Limited exam of the esophagus was normal Stomach: Limited exam of the stomach was normal Duodenum: Limited exam of the duodenum was normal Major Papilla: The previously described bulging 1cm papilla was seen. Cannulation: Cannulation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts was successful and deep using a free-hand technique. Contrast medium was injected resulting in complete opacification. The procedure was not difficult. Biliary Tree/Fluoroscopic interpretation: The scout film was normal. A 1 cm mass was seen at the level of the major papilla, compatible with the previously diagnosed ampullary adenoma. The pancreas duct was successfully cannulated using a Rx sphincterotome preloaded with a 0.035in guidewire. A small amount of contrast mixed with methylene blue were then injected into the PD to improve post-ampullectomy PD orifice visualization. A 15 mm snare was then used for endoscopic mucosal resection of the ampulla in a en bloc fashion. The whole mass was removed. The ampullary mass specimen was suctionned into the stomach and then retrieved at the end of the procedure. The specimen was sent for pathology. The CBD was then cannulated with the sphcterotome and contrast was injected

Cardiac enzymes peaked at Trop-T: 5.08, CKMb 129, CK 1495. Started on ASA 325mg PO daily, Plavix for at least one year, atorvastatin 80mg daily, metoprolol 25mg BID. Echo showed preserved EF. Lipids showed HDL 36, LDL 54, Trig 130, cholesterol 116. HgA1C showed 6.0%. . #Atrial fibrillation - CHADS2 score is 1 (HTN) and he is anticoagulated with Pradaxa at home. He was recently diagnosed with AF within the past year and is s/p DCCV in ___, although he is currently in AF at admission. Rate control with metoprolol. . # Concern for Peripheral vascular disease: pt endorsed claudication, ABI was done and was pending at time of discharge. . # HLD - On simvastatin at home, LDL was 78 and HDL 40 in ___. Change ocor to Lipitor 80mg in the setting of STEMI. Continued gemfibrozil. . # HTN - He was somewhat hypotensive in the cath lab with systolic BP in the ___, possible history of HTN per report. Continued metoprolol as above for rate control and to reduce myocardial work. . # Alcohol abuse - Drinks ___ drinks per day and reports no prior withdrawal symptoms. The patient did not score on the CIWA scale and did not require ativan for sx of withdrawal. . # Tobacco abuse - Patient is currently working on quitting smoking. Tobacco cessation counseling, nicotine patch PRN. . #BPH - On dut

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o fire-fighter with no significant PMH found to have 2-vessel coronary disease and NSTEMI, admitted for therapeutic cardiac catheterization. . #.NSTEMI/CAD: patient found to have 2-vessel CAD on catheterization at OSH. His only risk factor is extensive family history of CAD, including an MI in his mother at age ___. On re-catheterization at ___, he had drug-eluting stent placed to OM1, and balloon angioplasty to left circumflex. He was on heparin drip until catheterization. He had no complications post-catheterization. Patient was started on post-MI therapy: ASA 325mg daily, atorvastatin 80mg daily, metoprolol succinate 25mg daily, and clopidogrel 75mg daily. He was also started on amlodipine 2.5mg daily because there was a question of diffuse coronary vasospasm during his cardiac cath. Because he is on two antihypertensives (amlodipine, metoprolol) an ACE inhibitor was not started at this time. Patient will follow up as outpatient with his cardiologist ___, and his PCP ___. ___. . #.DJD: not on medications.

While on the floor he had no further bleeding episodes. Because he had 7 bleeds in the last year, he was evaluated for a TIPS. Echo showed no R heart dysfunction and RUQ US showed no PVT. He underwent TIPS procedure and his portosystemic gradient was lowered to 12mmHG. After the procedure, he exhibited mild asterixis and mild difficulty concentration, but this resolved after increasing his lactulose dose and he was discharged with intact mental capacity. # Anemia - Patient received 20u PRBC at outside hospital and hemolysis labs were positive on transfer with his Hgb in the 7___s. They remained stable on the floor with no further evidence of bleeding and did not require any further transfusions. Hemolysis labs trended down in the Hemolysis workup showed no autoimmune process and therefore prednisone initially started at OSH was stopped. Transfusion medicine evaluated his bloodwork and determined that he is not making antibodies to either his own or others' blood. Therefore it is likley due to something in the environment. Heme/onc was involved but a diagnosis was never given. It was thought to be due to splenomegaly, G6PD, or some other environmental factor. He is to follow up with Heme/Onc in 3 weeks. # cirrhosis - Due to Hep C and ETOH, but abstinent from drugs and ETOH for years now. Not a transplant candidate at this time due to low MELD (8). # diabetes - manage with home dose of insulin

summary: ___ y/o lady with AFib on coumadin, CKD ___ Cr 1.7), chronic diastolic and systolic ___ failure admitted for altered mental status in the setting of worsening kidney function and CHF. . 1) Acute on chronic systolic and diastolic ___ failure: Patient has a history of both systolic and diastolic ___ failure (LVEF 55%), with signs of fluid overload on initial physical exam and CXR. This was felt to be secondary to acute renal failure and insufficient diuresis. Patient's weight upon admission was 425lb (bed weight), with unclear baselne weight prior to recent fluid accumulation. Patient was started on a lasix drip at 20/hr, with a goal urine output of 200cc/hr. Digoxin, diltiazem and ace-inhibitor were held in the setting of the patient's ARF. Patient was rate-controlled with a beta-blocker, with HR within ___ during hospital stay (intermittently in atrial fibrillation). Patient was net negative 1.5 to 2liters every day. Oxygen saturation steadily improved throughout hospital stay; with noon oxygen saturations of 96-98% on room air since ___ (patient with unrelated persistent desaturations overnight - see #3 below). CXR obtained on ___ showed improved pulmonary edema from admission study. On day 7 of hospitalization, lasix gtt was stopped. She received 2 doses of 100 IV lasix and was net negative almost 4 liters. She was then transitioned to 80mg po BID of lasix and continued to diurese well. On discharge patient was still mildly edematous with faint crackles on anterior exam and stably off oxygen and creatinine down to 1.5. Patient's lisinopril was restarted at low dose (2.5) and her BB was continued -Please keep foley in place to monitor Is and Os until patient stabilized on diuretic regimen -Please titrate PO lasix as needed, patient responds to 100 IV lasix if needed -Please uptitrate lisinopril as blood pressure allows. -Please check electrolytes weekly while on lisinopril . 2) Acute on chronic renal

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Cough Dyspnea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Right throacentesis <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (GOLD stage III), diastolic heart failure (LVEF >55% in ___, moderate pulmonary hypertension, and schizophrenia who presents with cough and shortness of breath. Patient is a poor historian with limited medical insight. He has experienced chronic cough for many years, but reports progression of cough beginning 4 days prior to admission; production of white phlegm is unchanged from baseline. When asked about chest pain or shortness of breath, he responds, Yes, that's why I came in, but on further questioning, reports that chest pain and shortness of breath occurred 6 months prior to admission, without recent recurrence. He denies paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, or peripheral edema and does not use oxygen at home. He does not appear to be aware that he carries a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He denies fevers/chills, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, myalgias, or pain of any kind. He describes difficulty sleeping, which he attributes to insomnia, acknowledging significant anxiety. In the ED, initial vital signs were as follows: 99.6, 95, 109/61, 16, 95% 3L. On exam, he was noted to have poor air movement bilaterally, coarse bibasilar crackles (left > right), left-sided expiratory wheeze, and 1 pitting edema to calves bilaterally. Mild erythema also was observed surrounding a left lower extremity eschar. Admission labs were notable for leukocytosis to 14.1, proBNP of 12141 (up from priors of ___, creatinine of 1.4, and potassium of 5.5. EKG was negative for acute ischemic changes, with the exception of new T wave inversion in V1 of uncertain significance. CXR demonstrated right-sided pleural effusion and lower lung atelectasis, as well as mild pulmonary edema. Blood cultures were obtained, and UA was unconcerning for infection. He received albuterol/ipratropium nebulizers and 40mg IV Lasix, with 1000cc urine output shortly thereafter. He also was started on vancomycin and cefepime. His breathing seemed to improve, and he was able to eat lunch comfortably. On arrival to the floor, he triggered for hypoxia and reported some difficulty breathing. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (GOLD stage III) status post intubations - Diastolic heart failure (LVEF >55% in ___ - Moderate pulmonary hypertension - Schizophrenia - Alcoholic cirrhosis complicated by portal hypertension, splenomegaly, and periportal varices - Pyruvate kinase deficiency complicated by splenomegaly and macrocytic anemia - Prostate cancer status post Lupron therapy - Mediastinal lymph nodes on CTA in ___ - Inguinoscrotal hernia - Compression fracture status post vertebroplasty - Aspiration risk per video swallow in ___ - Basal cell carcinoma - Small bowel obstruction in ___ - Anemia <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No known family history of coronary artery disease. <PHYSICAL EXAM> On admission: VS 97.4, 111/58, 96, 22, 88% 3L NC GEN: Alert, oriented, mild respiorty distress HEENT: NCAT, MMM, EOMI, sclerae anicteric NECK: supple, no JVD, no LAD PULM: Poor aeration, diffusly ronchorous with expiritory wheeze CV: RRR normal S1/S2, no m/r/g ABD: soft, NT, ND, BS, midline scar healing well EXT: WWP, 2 pulses palpable bilaterally, mild resting tremor. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (GOLD stage III), diastolic heart failure (LVEF >55% in ___, moderate pulmonary hypertension, and schizophrenia who presented from a group home with cough and shortness of breath. Active Issues: (1)Presumed pulmonary malignancy/goals of care: Massive right hilar, mediastinal, subcarinal, and right supraclavicular lymphadenopathy coupled with near complete right lower lobe collapse on CTA ___ was highly suggestive of metastatic pulmonary malignancy. Pleural fluid cytology was ultimately suspicious for non-small cell carcinoma by the time of discharge. Following palliative care consultation and extended goals of care discussion with the patient's health care proxy, it was decided that bronchoscopy with endobronchial ultrasound transbronchial aspiration and systemic antineoplastic therapy, if indicated, would be contrary to his goals of care, and definitive diagnostic evaluation was not pursued. DNR/DNI status and wish for no rehospitalization was confirmed with his health care proxy on the day of discharge. Close oncology follow-up with Dr. ___ is being arranged to review cytology results and discuss further therapeutic options, likely palliative in nature. (2)Pneumonia: Given cough increased from baseline and possible fever in the setting of hypoxia, leukocytosis, and equivocal CXR (right-sided pleural effusion with possible underlying consolidation) on admission, empiric healthcare-associated pneumonia coverage with vancomycin, cefepime, and levofloxacin was initiated on admission, with subsequent transition to vancomycin, osyn, and levofloxacin, for a planned 14-day total course ___ - ___. He remained comfortable without subjective shortness of breath on stable supplemental oxygen requirement (4L) and without fevers or leukocytosis by the time of discharge. (3)Pleural effusions: Following admission CXR with right-sided pleural effusion and subsequent CXR with right > left effusions, he underwent right-sided diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis (1.4L) on ___, with pleural fluid consistent with exudate and ultimately found to be suspicious for non-

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> UROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> L atrophic kidney, recurrent infections <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> s/p L nephrectomy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ woman previously seen in clinic for recurrent UTI and for left-sided kidney stones. She is status post left antatrophic nephrolithotomy for left staghorn calculi in ___. At the last visit a CT scan was ordered and she was sent home on suppressive Macrodantin. She returns today for discussion of her CT scan and review of her symptoms. Per her she has had some urinary tract infection since she was last seen, however, we do not have any urine cultures, since then her last urine culture and on previous cultures have grown e-coli pan susceptible except for ciprofloxacin. She continues to have bothersome frequency up to and worsen every one hour and nocturia ___ times at night. There is no dysuria no hematuria. There is some urgency. She notes that she has left-sided back pain, this is somewhat lower than her costovertebral angle, but that it moves upwards and gets worse whenever she has urinary tract infection. We reviewed her CT scan today in the office. The CT scan shows atrophic left-sided kidney, normal right-sided kidney. There are multiple small stones inside the left-sided kidney, some of these may be outside her kidney and may be surgical clips related to her antatrophic nephrolithotomy, however there are at least some stones within the collecting system. Her ureteral anatomy appears normal and bladder anatomy appears normal. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Significant for anemia, asthma, rosacea, lower back pain, insomnia. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> PE AVSS Gen: NAD Abd: soft, NT Indicion c/d/i <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 45AM BLOOD WBC-9.8 RBC-3.61* Hgb-10.7* Hct-33.3* MCV-92 MCH-29.7 MCHC-32.3 RDW-12.6 Plt ___ ___ 07: 45AM BLOOD Glucose-136* UreaN-5* Creat-0.8 Na-136 K-4.3 Cl-105 HCO3-21* AnGap-14 <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> -You may shower but do not bathe, swim or immerse your incision. -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids -Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up -Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4. Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. Max daily Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also contains Tylenol (acetaminophen) -Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics -Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. -Resume all of your home medications, except hold NSAID (aspirin, and ibuprofen containing products such as advil  motrin,) until you see your urologist in follow-up -Call your Urologist's office today to schedule/confirm your follow-up appointment in 3 weeks AND if you have any questions.
summary: Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing open Left radical nephrectomy. No concerning intraoperative events occurred, but the patient required a chest tube postoperatively as the pleura was entered durign the cae; please see dictated operative note for details. The patient received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The patient was transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable condition. On POD0, pain was well controlled on PCA, hydrated for urine output >30cc/hour, provided with pneumoboots and incentive spirometry for prophylaxis, and ambulated once. On POD1, the patient was restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel and complete blood count were checked, pain control was transitioned from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a clears/toast and crackers diet. Foley was removed. The chest tube was placed first to water seal and then removed on POD#1 with post-pull CXR negative for pneumothorax. On POD2, the patient was passign gas and diet was advanced as tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course was relatively unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition, eating well, ambulating independently, voiding without difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, incision was clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of hematoma collection or infection. The patient was given explicit instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. ___ in 3 weeks and with her primary care provider for postoperative check and chest tube ___ removal. Discharge Medications: 1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours). 2. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as needed for pain. The pain was well controlled on oral pain medications, and your distention improved with rectal suppositories that resulted in appropriate bowel movements. You are not to engage in any heavy lifting (>15 lbs). Do not strain yourself, get plenty of rest, and stay well hydrated. Contact a physician or return to ER for the following: - Chest pain - Shortness of breath - Nausea/Vomiting/Dehydration - Abdominal pain that is worsening - Bloody bowel movements - Constipation - Diarrhea - Dizziness - fever > 100.1 degrees F - redness, swelling, pain around surgical incision site - any form of drainage from surgical incision site.
summary: Mr. ___ underwent lap umbilical hernia repair on ___. This procedure went well without any complications. Post-operatively he was very distended and his bowel function was slow to return. This abdominal distention caused him to have supplemental O2 requirements at rest. His distention improved with an aggressive bowel regimen including suppositories. He was weened off O2 once his distention improved. On POD 5 he is stable, with no O2 requirement, and appropriate for discharge home.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Sulfasalazine / Cephalosporins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> ___ ADMISSION HISTORY AND PHYSICAL . . PCP: ___. ___ . . CC: MENINGITIS . <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> LUMBAR PUNCTURE IN ER ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ old male with h/o remote staph infection in infancy, S-J syndrome to either bactrim/cefixime many years ago, recurrent strep throat is here with headache and fever. Pt has been stressed out due to finals and had some intermittent HA for past couple weeks. However 3days ago he came home from school with severe HA and fever of 102. He went to sleep and felt better the next day. Yesterday afternoon, the HA returned and was very severe. Described as head fullness worse than he has ever had (has had mild HA with fevers in past) and also had eye pain (with movement, not photophobia). Also had fever again yesterday to 101-102. Had mild sore throat but nothing like his usual strep symptoms. Took tylenol and went to bed. Woke up this am with persistant HA and fever so came to ER. No sick contacts. No neck stiffness. No confusion/lethargy. No travel. No skin rash or joint complaints. No sore throat or cough today. Other than HA and fever, no other complaints. Called PCP this am, ___ to ER for LP . In ER, underwent LP, c/w viral meningitis. Started on Abx for concern for early bacterial meningitis as well. Given possible Cephalosporin/sulfa allergies, given Vanc/Doxy with plan to add chloramphenicol. Is sad about missing school and review for his finals. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> staph skin infection in infancy S-J syndrome to either bactrim or cefixime recurrent strep throat ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> no FH of recurrent infections <PHYSICAL EXAM> <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals on arrival to ER: 97.7 111/62 80 18 100%RA Vitals on arrival to floor: 97.8 ___ 64 16 98%RA Gen: pleasant, thin male, in NAD Eyes: EOMI, anicteric ENT: o/p clear w/o exudates, mmm Neck: no LAD CV: RRR, no m, nl S1, S2 Resp: CTAB, no crackles or wheezes Abd: soft, nontender, nondistended, BS, no HSM Lymph: no cervical, axillary, inguinal LAD Ext: no edema, good peripheral pulses, no cyanosis Neuro: AOX3, CNII-XII intact, normal gait, strength equal b/l ___, intact sensation, reflexes 2 ___, neg Kernig/neg Brudzinski Skin: warm, NO rashes and no petechia psych: appropriate . . On discharge Vitals: Tm 99.4 Tc 97.9 ___ 18 98%RA Pain: ___ eye pain Access: PIV Gen: nad HEENT: anicteric, o/p clear, mmm Neck: no LAD CV: RRR, no m Resp: CTAB, no crackles or wheezing Abd; soft, nontender, BS, no HSM Ext; no edema Neuro: AOX3, remains at baseline-nonfocal Skin: no rash psych: appropriate . <PERTINENT RESULTS> wbc 5.8 wiht 64%N hgb ___ plt 158 . Chem: BUN/creat ___ LFTs wnl . INR 1.4 . LP wbc 110, 90 with 8%PMN, 84%Lymph, 8% Mono RBC 3, 3 Gluc 51 T pro 50 Lyme pending*** CSF ___ neg CSF Cx NTD Blood CX X2 NTD . . Imaging/results: NONE <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Preadmission medications listed are correct and complete. Information was obtained by Patient. 1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H: PRN fever <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H: PRN fever <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Aseptic meningitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted for fevers and headache that ocurred over a couple days. You underwent Lumbar puncture which showed you had meningitis. Initially we covered you with IV antibiotics in the case this was early bacterial meningitis (which can be dangerous). However, your cultures from the spine fluid and blood remained negative for 48hours, so this was more likely ASEPTIC (aka Viral) meningitis. This is treated with supportive care like any viral illness with rest, fluids, tylenol as needed. You will not be discharged on any antibiotics
summary: ___ old male admitted with 3days of HA and fever. Underwent LP in ER with findings of meningitis. LP showed lymphocytic predominence and patient clinically looked very well so likely aseptic meningitis. However, there was concern that this could also represent early bacterial meningitis, thus he was covered empirically with Abx. Pt had a h/o severe allergy (S-J syndrome) to either cefexime/bactrim so after discussion with ID, we covered for bacterial meningitis with vanc, doxy PO, chloramphenicol IV q6. No evidence of encephalitis so less likely HSV so acyclovir not started (and we did not check for this). The ER sent off lyme serologies in CSF fluid and this is PENDING at time of discharge (communicated to PCP). Our suspicion for this was low. After the cultures were negative for 48hours, these were stopped. Pt was told to continue supportive care for his Aseptic Meningitis with rest, fluids, tylenol. He remained afebrile here. He had a mild HA that was better with tylenol and mild eye pain w/o evidence of conjunctivits/episcleritis. He was discharged in good condition.

You were started on IV antibiotics for your infection and you remained afebrile. You had both tuboovarian abscesses drained and had bilateral drains placed. The team recommended you remain in the hospital for continued drainage of abscesses, however you preferred to have the drains removed and be discharged. The drains were removed and you were transitioned to oral antibiotics. Please call the office with any questions or concerns (___). Please follow the instructions below. General instructions: * Take your medications as prescribed. * Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs. * You may eat a regular diet. Incision care: * You can remove the tegaderm plastic dressing and cotton gauze in 24 hours. * You can shower and let water run over the drain sites, but please do not scrub them. Call your doctor for: * fever > 100.4F * severe abdominal pain * difficulty urinating * vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr * abnormal vaginal discharge * redness or drainage from incision * nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food or your medication To reach medical records to get the records from this hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
summary: Ms. ___ was admitted due to abdominal pain and fever. She was transferred from ___ after imaging findings were concerning for bilateral tubo-ovarian abscesses. On admission, patient endorsed 2 weeks of malaise, abdominal pain, and flu like symptoms. She presented to the ED due to worsening abdominal pain. Upon evaluation, she was febrile and tachycardic, and labs were notoable for leukocytosis with a left shift. She was started on IV levo/flagyl. CT abdomen and pelvis showed Markedly abnormal adnexae, with multiloculated thick-walled flagyl were discontinued and she was started on gent/clinda. She was made NPO for ___ draining the following day. She had a CXR obtained that showed no acute process. Of note, she did endorse crack, marijuana, and klonopin use. She was began on a CIWA protocol. On HD1, she underwent bilateral ___ guided drainage of ___, with drainage of 55cc purulent fluid from left side and 10cc purulent fluid from right side with bilateral JP drains placed. She was also broaden to include vancomyacin. On HD2, patient endorsed loose stool and thus a c-diff was collected. On HD3, patient remained afebrile but her right HP with minimal drainage overall. Discussed with patient the utility of repeat imaging in order to assess collection resolution and possible need to reposition R JP if collection has not adequately drained. Patient strongly declined possibility of repositioning R JP and refused continued inpatient stay and refused leaving hospital with JP drains in place and ___ assistance. Discussed with patient the option to repeat imaging and plan for longer course of PO ABX if collections have not adequately resolved. Discussed importance of returning for followup visit in 2 weeks and repeat imaging before that time. Patient stated she agrees with plan of care. Will order PUS and touch base with ___ to remove JP drains. She was then discharged AMA with po doxy/flagyl. Of note her HCV,

Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day: hold for loose stool. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> acute appendicitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain. You underwent a cat scan of the abdomen which showed acute appendicitis. You were taken to the operating room where you had your appendix removed. You are recovering from the surgery and your vital signs are stable. You are preparing for discharge home with the following instructions: You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while taking these medications. Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you have any of the following: * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. * New or worsening cough or wheezing. * If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your medications. * You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. * You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a bowel movement. * You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) degrees or 38(C) degrees. * Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you. * Please resume all regular home medications and take any new meds as ordered. Activity: No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises. Wound Care: You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with clean, dry gauze. Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery. Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
summary: Admitted to the acute care service with abdominal pain. A cat scan was done at an outside hospital which confirmed appendicitis. Upon admission, she was made NPO, given intravenous fluids, and was started on ciprofloxacin and flagyl. On HD #1, she was taken to the operating room where she underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix was found to be bulky but not gangrenous. The operative course was stable with minimal blood loss. The antibiotics have been discontinued. She was started on a regular diet on POD #1. Her vital were stable and she has been afebrile. She is preparing for discharge home with follow-up in the acute care clinic.

summary: ___ yo F with PMH bipolar disorder presented to OSH with 6 week history of jaundice, lethargy, and abdominal pain found to have worsening liver function, transferred to ___ for liver biopsy for liver failure of unclear etiology, possibly drug-induced acute liver injury given unusual combination of psychiatric meds which were discontinued 6 weeks PTA when LFTs first noted to be abnormal (depakote, seroquel, prozac, topamax). Percutaneous liver biopsy showed acute hepatitis with portal and lobular mixed inflammation, hepatocyte swelling, and confluent parenchymal collapse/necrosis involving approximately 40% of the sampled parenchyma, reactive bile ductular proliferation at interface of parenchymal collapse and regenerating parenchyma with prominent associated neutrophils, no evidence of advanced fibrosis / cirrhosis, most likely acute viral vs drug-induced liver injury, favoring drug-induced. Transjugular biopsy had been attempted initially however her hepatic veins were unable to be cannulated. MELD was in the high 20's and transplant surgery was consulted with concern for possible need for transplant. She was started on prednisone 40mg and ursodiol with the intent of improving her cholestatic liver injury/inflammation. Her LFTs continued to worsen with a hyperbilirubinemia (level 30) and development of asterixis and mild confusion on ___. She was transferred to SICU for observation overnight. Her neurologic exam was noted to be stable and her LFTs finally started to trend down on ___. She was transferred back to the liver service on ___ for worsening mental status/encephalopathy. Psychiatry was consulted and recommended continuation of conservative management. Ativan was discontinued for diminished mental status. Mental status worsened and MELD increased. She was listed for liver transplant and received a donor liver offer on ___ which was accepted by her family for her. She was taken to the OR and underwent liver transplant on ___. Surgeons were Drs. ___ ___ and ___. Intraop course was difficult with copious

She was initially admitted ___ with fevers at home to 101.9 without localizing symptoms and was admitted overnight, labs drawn, negative CXR and discharged on ___ apparently without intervention. She was home for 5 days and continued to have fevers up to 103, and re-presented to ___ on ___. Again she had no localizing symptoms. On the day of admission her WBC was found to be 21.8 (50% PMNs, 13% bands) up from WBC 0.8 two days prior. She was started on vancomycin and cefepime. She had a CXR on ___ which showed bilateral intersititial opacity slightly worse on the right. She was additionally found to have elevated LFTs with Tbili 2.4, Dbili 2.2, ALT initially 188, AST 130, increasing to 245 on day of transfer. Alk phos 521. Given the LFT abnormalities she had an abdominal ultrasound, which showed gallbladder wall thickening, distention of gallbladder and multiple 10mm mobile gallstones, trace pericholecystic fluid, but no CBD dilatation (4mm). This was thought to be consistent with cholecystitis. After the RUQ ultrasound, this was changed to osyn and vanc was dc'd. On exam she had a positive ___ sign was tachycardic and initially borderline hypotensive (unclear exact pressures), however, received fluid resuscitation with an unclear amount of fluid and blood pressures responded, by report systolics in the low 100s (105/68) upon transfer, HR 140s regular sinus tach, RR 20, 95% on RA. On arrival to the MICU, patient's VS. T 97.8 HR 134 BP 85/58 RR 24 94% 2L NC Review of systems: () Per HPI, as well as nausea, new nonproductive cough, slightly short of breath (-) Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies wheezing. Denies chest pain, chest pressure, palpitations. Denies constipation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dark or bloody stools. Denies dysuria, frequency, or urgency. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rashes or skin changes. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> ONCOLOGY: ___: Screening colonoscopy negative. ___: Screening PET showed no avid lesions though some low avidity uptake at surgical margins. ___: Abdominal discomfort. ___: CT demonstrated new liver lesions. A biopsy was performed which demonstrated a lymphoma. Limited tissue, a clear diagnosis was not possible but pathology was consistent with Hodgkin lymphoma. ___: Staging PET showed enlarged right subocciptal node, intensely avid, with avidity of the posterior paraspinal musculature. Multiple enlarged right supraclavicular nodes. Asymmetric thickening of right supraspinatus muscle. Multiple intensely avid masses within the liver. Enlarged and intensely avid aortocaval node and multiple enlarged left midabdomen mesenteric nodes. Circumferential masslike thickening of a portion of small bowel with an expanded lumen. Bone marrow biopsy demonstrated no disease. ___: Right-sided neck pain; right arm pain, numbness and weakness; night sweats. Given rapid progression of symptoms, a second biopsy was performed on the neck lymph node and she was started on treatment with steroids and ABVD. Pathology from lymph node demonstrated a peripheral T-cell lymphoma. Chemo was changed for her second cycle to CHOEP. She received 3 cycles of CHOEP. CT following those scans demonstrates progression. ___: ICE cycle #1. ___: Admitted for neutropenic fever. ___: ICE cycle #2. . PMH: - Colon cancer s/p right hemicolectomy ___. 2 tumors. One 5cm, low grade through the muscularis propria into the pericolonic adipose tissue (t4), no lymphatic invasion. second tumor 4cm with some lymphatic invasion. 25 negative nodes. Microsatellite instability negative. No adjuvant treatment. - Celiac disease, dx at investigation of weight loss following colectomy. Managed with diet. PSX: - Hemicolectomy as above. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother died of breast cancer at ___. Grandmother died at ___. Father died in ___ with CAD. 2 healthy sisters. Daughter has celiac disease. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission: Vitals: T 97.8 HR 134 BP 85/58 RR 24 94% 2L NC General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, EOMI, PERRL Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD CV: Tachycardic, reg rhythm, normal S1  S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Lungs: Crackles at bases bilaterally, breath sounds decreased ___ way up right lung field, no wheezes Abdomen: soft, minimally tender to palpation diffusely, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no organomegaly, no rebound or guarding, no ___ sign GU: no foley Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2 pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema Discharge: Deceased <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission: ___
summary: Brief Course: ___ female with ___ transferred from ___ ___ for fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, elevated LFTs with suspicion for cholecystitis vs. cholangitis. Patient developed septic shock and required 3 pressors. She also developed respiratory failure and was intubated and ventilated. She was covered broadly with antibiotics. She underwent ultrasound guided cholecystoscopy and catheter placement, however her lactate continued to increase and the patient continued to clinically decompensate. Her family was made aware, and decided to pursue DNR code status with comfort measures only. Patient was taken off pressors and antibiotics and was extubated. She expired the follwing morning. Active Issues: #Septic Shock: Patient was hypotensive requiring 3 pressors, tachycardic, and febrile with leukocytosis. Source is most likely acute cholecystitis. Patient underwent ultrasound guided cholecystostomy with catheter placement, as she was not stable enough to undergo cholecystectomy. Despite intervention and broad spectrum antibiotic coverage with meropenem and zosyn, patient's lactate continued to trend up to a peak of 15 and she continued to be tachycardic, hypotensive, and acidotic despite optimizing ventilator settings. In light of clinical decompensation, the family decided to make the patient DNR, with comfort measures only. Therefore she was extubated and pressors and antibiotics were stopped. She was made comfortable with morphine drip until she expired. #Respiratory failure: Likely secondary to fluid overload or flash pulmonary edema which is supported by bilateral pleural effusions seen on CT and crackles on exam. PE was ruled out with CTA. Patient's oxygenation was maintained on the ventilator, but she continued to be acidotic despite maximizing her settings. She was subsequenty extubated for comfort per the family's wishes. #Metabolic acidosis: Secondary to lactic acidosis in setting of sepsis. Patient could not compensate respiratory wise initially and was subsequently intubated. Acidosis could not be corrected despite optimizing vent settings and patient was subsequently extubated per family's wishes as mentioned above. #Coagulopathy: INR 1.5. No signs

If there is a high clinical suspicion for ligamentous injury, an MR is suggested. MRI Lumbar ___ ___ FINDINGS: There appear to have been recent injuries to the L2, L4, and L5 vertebral bodies with increased signal intensity at each of these levels on the STIR images. The L2 vertebral body is slightly anteriorly wedged. There is no encroachment on the spinal canal. No intradural abnormalities are detected. The distal thoracic spinal cord and conus medullaris appeared normal. There is no evidence of cauda equina compression. There are mild degenerative changes with sclerosis, irregularity, and tiny Schmorl's nodes involving the inferior endplates of L4 and L5. There is bilateral neural foraminal narrowing at L5-S1, more severe on the left than right. Axial images from L1 through L5, reveal no evidence of canal or foraminal narrowing at these levels. CONCLUSION: Wedging of the L2 vertebral body and increased signal at L2, L4, and L5 compatible with recent trauma. Bilateral foraminal narrowing at L5-S1. Return to the Emergency room if you develop any fevers, chills, shortness of breath, chest pain, increased leg swelling, nausea ,vomiting, diarrhea and/or any other symtpoms that are concerning to you.
summary: He was admitted to the Trauma service. Orthopaedics and Orthopedics ___ surgery were consulted given his injuries. He was taken to the operating room by orthopedics for irrigation and debridement left open calcaneal fracture, open reduction left subtalar open dislocation and closed treatment bilateral calcaneus fractures. There were no intraoperative complications. His L2 compression fracture was confirmed to be acute by MRI and it was recommended by Orthopedic ___ surgery for a TLSO brace to be worn when out of bed. He was fitted for the brace and evaluated by Physical therapy. Because he was non weight bearing on both lower extremities he was taught how to do slide board transfer to wheelchair and became independent with this. His pain was managed effectively with Percocet and he was also started on a bowel regimen. There was concern for risk for thrombus given his orthopedic injuries and discussions took place with patient for placement of an IVC filter. He underwent an IVC gram which revealed a wide IVC; Interventional Radiology was consulted for filter placement. It was determined that the type of filter that could be used given the size of the IVC was not the retrievable type and so the decision was made to use Lovenox for prophylaxis. He was taught how to self administer the medication successfully.

summary: PSYCHIATRIC #Depression/Anxiety: Patient's distress appears to be due to combination of depressive and anxious symptoms. She has had trouble adjusting to being at a larger school and felt betrayed and abandoned by the friends she has made. Her feelings of isolation led to suicidal thoughts. Upon admission to the unit patient was already starting to feel better as these issues were being addressed and she had communicated her distress to her boyfriend and parents which improved feeling of isolation. Her wellbutrin was discontinued as she did not feel like it was helping her and she was started on oloft 50mg which she tolerated well. Due to her current lack of insurance, she will be given a month supply of oloft on discharge and will f/u with ___ student counseling until her insurance starts and she can see a private therapist and psychiatrist. GENERAL MEDICAL CONDITIONS No acute issues during admission PSYCHOSOCIAL: #Collateral: The therapist at ___ that ___ had seen prior to admission was contacted and agreed with dispo plan. Boyfriend ___ came in for meeting. Her family also visited her on the unit and she was discharged with her mother. #Groups/milieu: Patient was visible in the milieu and interacted well with other patients and staff. She appeared to have good mood. She participated in groups. LEGAL: ___ RISK ASSESSMENT: Likely low risk for suicide. Risk factors include depression, age, and passive suicidal thoughts prior to admission. Her mood quickly stabilized in the hospital, though, and on discharge she clearly denied any suicidal thoughts/plan/intent. No prior suicide attempts or substance abuse.

summary: ___ is a ___ man with Asperger's spectrum and recurrent CNS lymphoma, currently in remission, admitted for cycle 27 maintenance HD-MTX therapy. ACTIVE ISSUES: ================ 1. CNS Lymphoma: First diagnosed with CNS lymphoma in ___ following progressive right-sided neurological symptoms that led to a stereotactic brain biopsy. He is s/p 10 cycles of induction HD-MTX in ___ and 10 cycles of maintenance HD-MTX in mid-to-late ___. MR in ___ showed possible recurrence in the right insula for which he received 5 cycles of reinduction HD MTX from ___. MR in ___ showed complete remission. He is now receiving monthly maintenance HD-MTX therapy. This cycle pt tolerated chemotherapy well except for mild nausea that improved with anti-emetics. Urine alkalinization with sodium bicarb 150meq/L IVF  sodium bicarb 1300mg PO q6hr to maintain urine pH >8.0 to enhance MTX excretion. Leucovorin rescue starting 24 hours after MTX. MTX levels were followed starting 24 hours after infusion; 48 hour level was 0.11, 60 hour level was 0.04 and pt was discharged. Pt was instructed to take leucovorin and sodium bicarbonate for 3 days after discharge to help clear the methotrexate. CHRONIC ISSUES: ================ 2. Hypertension: Pt takes combination lisinopril-HCT at home. In hospital continued lisinopril and held HCT combination given affects clearance of MTX. Restarted combination pill upon discharge. 3. Seizure Disorder: No recent seizures. Continued outpatient levetiracetam. 4. Aspergers/Autism: No current medications, in therapy. SW support for pt. 5. Seasonal Allergies: Not at issue this admission. Uses cetirizine at home (not on formulary here). 6. History of Insomnia: Gave Trazodone PRN for sleep. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ================ - Patient will return on ___ for Cycle 28 of HD-MTX - Consider outpatient social work counseling for coping

summary: On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service for heavy vaginal bleeding in the setting of anti-coagulation for deep venous thrombosis. She underwent hysteroscopy, dilation and curettage, and Mirena intrauterine device placement on ___. Please see the operative report for full details. . She received a total of 3 units of packed red blood cells during her hospitalization due to ongoing heavy vaginal bleeding. Her vaginal bleeding decreased significantly following her procedure. . Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. The medicine service was consulted during her hospital stay for management of her anti-coagulation in the setting of active bleeding and surgical procedure. She was bridged to a heparin drip before and after her procedure and was discharged to continue her home dose of rivaroxaban with close follow up with hematology and gynecology outpatient. . By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, significantly decreased vaginal bleeding, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.
