OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Severe 10. Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg PO BID: PRN back stiffness 11. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY 12. Glargine 40 Units

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> amoxicillin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> LLE: distal tib-fib fracture <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> LLE external fixation <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> none <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY: - You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal to feel tired or washed out after surgery, and this feeling should improve over the first few days to week. - Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times. ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING: - NWB LLE MEDICATIONS: - Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians at discharge. - Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed to stop by your surgeon. - Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers. - Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener (colace) to prevent this side effect. ANTICOAGULATION: - Please take ASA for 4 weeks WOUND CARE: - You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks. - Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out at your 2-week follow up appointment. - Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is visibly soaked or falling off. - Daily pin site care with water and hydrogen peroxide (50: 50 mixture) clean pins with q-tip
summary: The patient presented to the emergency department and was evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found to have L distal tib-fib fx and was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for LLE external fixation, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is NWB in the left lower extremity, and will be discharged on ASA for DVT prophylaxis. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge. Discharge Disposition: Home Discharge Diagnosis: LLE distal tib-fib fx Discharge Condition: AAOx3, mentating appropriately NVI Followup Instructions: ___

Mr ___ was found to have a pancreatic mass in ___ in ___ when he presented with pruritus, chills, and abnormal LFTs. He was then seen in ___ and underwent ERCP with stent ___. Biopsy confirmed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. He returned to ___ and a PET-CT done ___ demonstrated locally advanced pancreatic cancer. He was recommended for neoadjuvant chemoRT. He received 4750 cGy with sensitizing capecitabine from ___. A follow up ERCP w/ metal stent placement was done ___ for obstructive jaundice in s/o clogged plastic stent. On ___, he started FOLFOX vs FOLFIRINOX (not sure which). He received 3 of 12 planned treatments before stopping for cytopenia, weight loss, and anorexia in ___. He moved back to ___ due to the expense of medical care in ___. He was evaluated at ___ in ___ ___. A CT and MRI redemonstrated locally advanced disease. A PET scan ___ reportedly also showed locally advanced disease (mass measuring 2.1 x 2 cm), no metastases. He was offered FOLFIRINOX, port placement, and TPN initiation, but declined as he and his sister had been hoping for Whipple and resection. He therefore moved to ___ to live with his sister ___. He was admitted here ___ after presenting with acute on chronic nausea and request to initiate therapy. He was evaluated by palliative care, started on antiemetics, and referred to oncology. He was discharged to ___. After discharge, he saw Dr ___ and Dr ___. His imaging was reviewed and notable for small liver lesions c/f metastasis. He was referred for liver biopsy, scheduled ___. Further treatment plan is to be determined pending the results of this. In the interim, he has been discharged from ECF (several weeks ago) and started on dronabinol last week. He and his sister report that he has had ongoing malaise, poor appetite, and uncontrolled anxiety. He estimates he eats a little bit of Corn Flakes in the morning, half a sandwich, and picks at his dinner. His nausea has been reasonably well controlled, but his nutrition has been limited by poor appetite and early satiety. He has also had dizziness and lightheadedness with standing. Earlier this week, Mr ___ took a valium in the setting of anxiety attack and fainted. His sister caught him in her arms. Today, he woke up and felt normal. However around noon, he began to feel more anxious and confused. His sister reports he did not know what was going on and answered questions inappropriately or made replies to questions that had not been asked. He only took his morning medications as usual and did not take any of the PRN Xanax, valium, or Percocet prior to this event. He has been tolerating the dronabinol over the last week well otherwise. In the ED: T 98.8 F  64  112/72  96% RA. CT head was normal. Basic labs were unremarkable. A few hours after arrival, his mental status returned to baseline. He received 1L LR prior to admission. On ROS, he denies chest pain, trouble breathing, chronic or new cough, fevers/chills, abdominal pain. Nausea at baseline, no vomiting. No headache, vision changes, focal weakness/numbness/tingling. All other review of systems are negative unless stated otherwise <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Locally advanced pancreatic adenocarcinoma diagnosed ___ and now suspected to be metastatic. Oncologic history reported in HPI. - Bilateral DVT diagnosed ___, on apixaban - HIV on ART, with reported history of multiple retroviral resistance - Anxiety/Depression - HLP - GERD <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of pancreatic cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> === ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM === VITALS: T 97.9 F  109/70  67  97% RA Orthostatics on admission: 129/70, 58 (lying)-> 110/69, 63 (sitting)-> 98/71, 85 (standing)  Dizziness Weight: 115.4 lb. 118 lb (___). Reports was 175 lb last year. (Baseline BPs 87/53-100/66) General: Thin, cachetic Caucasian man, sitting up at edge of bed, pleasant and conversant Neuro: - Cranial nerves: PERRL, EOMI, Facial sensation equal bilaterally, resists eye opening ___, hearing intact to finger rub b/l, palate elevates symmetrically, tongue midline, shoulder shrug ___ - Motor: ___ deltoid, bicep, tricep, handgrip bilaterally
summary: ___ yo man with hx of locally advanced pancreatic cancer diagnosed ___ and now suspected to be metastatic to liver, HIV on ART, bilateral DVT on Eliquis (dx ___, who presented with failure to thrive and severe anxiety with orthostatic hypotension. # Failure to thrive # Poor PO Intake, weight loss # Orthostatic hypotension Describes markedly poor appetite, weakness with concern that he cannot climb the 1 flight of stairs required to get into sister's apartment, fatigue. Orthostatics positive during admission. Received multiple liters of IVF with transient improvement but persistent symptoms. Unclear if symptoms related to anxiety or symptomatic orthostatic hypotension. Started fludrocortisone daily with good response and an improvement in orthostatics. However, they remain occasionally positive. The patient was instructed to stand up slowly and walk cautiously. Started dronabinol for appetite stimulation. # Anxiety/depression Patient reports confusion on admission which was thought to be very related to anxiety. He did not take any anxiolytics or medications prior to his confusion episode. Continued home fluoxetine. Diazepam discontinued given somnolence noted with doses at home. Decreased alprazolam. Started olanzapine with some improvement. # Locally advanced pancreatic adenocarcinoma, now suspected to be metastatic to liver # Malignancy associated pain Underwent liver biopsy in house to eval mets. Will follow up for  systemic therapies with Dr. ___. Continued home creon, reglan, ofran PRN, oxycodone PRN # Severe malnutrition Nutrition consulted, started dronabinol. # Opiate induced constipation: Colace and Senna BID PRN # COPD: Hyperinflated CXR, CT with moderate diffuse centrilobular pulmonary emphysema. Asymptomatic, denies SOB/DOE or chronic cough. Can consider initiation on inhaler in future if pt becomes symptomatic. - Chronic Issues - # Bilateral DVT dx ___: Held apixaban for 48 hrs prior to biopsy and 24 h after then restarted # HIV on ART w/ hx of resistance: Continued darunavir, dolute

summary: ___ w/ schizophrenia and hyponatremia due to polydipsia p/w LLE cellulitis refractory to 14 days of keflex. . # L lower leg cellulitis: Keflex failure as outpt (2 week course) now on IV vancomycin, afebrile and wo leukocytosis on presentation. Portal of entry thought to be small lesion on large L toe versus scabbed lesion on knee. Given mental illness decompensation over past couple months there was concern that the pt perhaps had difficulty w medication compliance vs. infection resistance to keflex. Clinically her leg appearance and tenderness improved with vancomycin which was switched to bactrim (2DS tabs BID) w plan for 10 day course - 14 days of total coverage for her cellulitis. She had negative ___ negative on admission. She was able to ambulate w ___ who cleared her discharge to home wo need for home ___. She had pending blood cultures at time of discharge that were NGTD from admission. She was encouraged to remove hip brace at night and elevating leg to help w/ swelling however pt felt very anxious about this idea and refused. Plan for outpt f/u at ___ clinic (scheduled to see Dr. ___ on ___ to monitor continued improvement on bactrim. . # Schizophrenia/anxiety/depression: She was continued on her outpatient psych meds: buspar, clonazepam, divalproex. Given her extreme emotional lability, anxiety and insistence of a nervous breakdown for the past 2 months psychiatry was consulted with question of medication optimization. She refused any antipsychotics. Her Depakote level was checked and found to be subtherapeutic - her dose was increased to 1750mg qhs. Her outpt oxycodone and clonazepam dosages were continued in house. She was trialed over the weekend on trazodone per initial psych recs which the patient felt really helped her anxiety and disposition. Follow up psychiatry recs advised against trazodone with concern for her fall risk given current hip instability. Plan for pt to continue attendance at day program in ___

Initially, he was continued on osyn, which had been started at ___ for undifferentiated GNR bacteremia. However, on ___ he was switched to meropenem after cultures grew a highly resistant strain of Klebsiella. Blood and urine cultures from ___ and ___ at ___ were also positive for Klebsiella. By ___ he was no longer spiking fevers and WBC was normal. A midline was placed for continued IV abx therapy and he was transitioned to ertapenem at discharge. ___ #R hydrohephrosis s/p nephrostomy placement Patient presented to ___ with ___ and Cr elevation to 4.6, found to have R hydronephrosis on imaging (thought to be most likely due to an obstructing blood clot or edema from recent bladder tumor resection). He also likely had a simultaneous prerenal insult in the setting of sepsis, also contributing to his ___. Cr improved to 2.7 with IVF at ___. Upon arrival at ___, Cr was 2.5. The morning after transfer to ___ a R nephrostomy tube was placed by ___ at the recommendation of his urologist at ___. The day following drain placement, Cr decreased to 2.3 and then was down to 1.5 on ___ and 1.4 on ___. He had a small amount of blood in the nephrostomy bag on ___. Per ___, intermittent mild hematuria is not uncommon in a nephrostomy. #CAD/NSTEMI #HFrEF (newly diagnosed) #Severe aortic stenosis On

Initial labs showed Na 134, Cr 1.2. Glucose was 552 (no ketones on UA and nml AG); he received 10u Lispro with improvement of his FSBG to 405. ALT/AST were wnl and AP of 131. proBNP was 243. summary: The patient is a ___ gentleman with a history of type 2 diabetes and history of stroke with residual right upper extremity paralysis and expressive aphasia, who developed bilateral lower extremity venous stasis ulcers. He was admitted with a large left lower extremity nonhealing ulcer. We obtained venous and arterial studies. The arterial studies suggested fem-pop occlusive disease and tibial disease, and the wound appeared grossly infected. The patient was placed on IV antibiotics and underwent excisional debridement of the left leg ulcer down to and including fascia involving a 100 sq cm area. The patient tolerated the procedure well and without complications. The next day the patient underwent a left lower extremity diagnostic angiogram. It was found that the patient had patent bilateral iliac systems with evidence of a previously placed IVC filter, and a patent left common femoral artery, profunda, and SFA. The angiogram also showed popliteal artery occlusion behind the knee with reconstitution of the posterior tibial artery in the mid leg and which continues patent into the foot. The anterior tibial artery also reconstitutes via collaterals proximally, however, occludes again at the level of the ankle. The peroneal artery was occluded and not visualized. The patient also tolerated this procedure well and was extubated without incident and brought to PACU, where he remained stable with subsequent transfer to the floor. The patient continued to receive wound care and IV antibiotics. Cardiology service was consulted for risk stratification in the event of surgical intervention and ___ was involved in glycemic control. Augmentin was initiated for pan-sensitive enterococcus based on culture data and a wound Vac was placed to his LLE wound. The patient at times became confrontational and refused nursing care but was mostly cooperative after dialogue with house staff. After extensive review and discussion of the patients clinical status, noninvasive data, angiogram, and wound progression with VAC and wound care, it was determined that no endovascular or vascular surgical intervention would be beneficial for

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ under the Acute Care Surgery service for management of his abdominal abscess. He was taken to the operating room and underwent incision and drainage of the abscess. Postoperatively he was hypotensive ___ the PACU prompting transfer to ___ for resuscitation and close monitoring. He was transfused 1 unit of pRBC's for a postop hct of 23.5 with hypotension. On POD#1 he was normotensive and otherwise stable and was transferred to the surgical floor. His hospital course is detailed by systems below: Neuro: He remained alert and oriented throughout his hospitalization. His pain level was routinely monitored. His pain was mainly episodic with vac dressing changes and he was medicated appropriately for this. Cardiovascular: As noted above, he was hypotensive initially postoperatively with a systolic BP ___ the 70's. This resolved with colloid and crystalloid resuscition. His hematcrit responded appropriately from 23.5 to 27 with transfusion of 1 unit of pRBC's. By POD#1 he remained normotensive with otherwise stable vital signs. Respiratory: Pulmonary toileting and incentive spirometry were encouraged. He remained without respiratory compromise. GI: He was initially kept NPO. Gastroenterology was consulted for question of need for endoscopic intervention of gastrocutaneous fistula. On ___ he underwent endoscopy with OTSC to attempt to close the opening of the gastrocutaneous fistula and placement of NJ tube for enteral feeding past the point of the fistula. Tube feeds were started and advanced to goal rate on ___. On ___ he had a CT scan to evaluate for resolution of fistula, which showed a small residual fistulous communication (see pertinent results section for details). Therefore, he was kept NPO with tubefeeds. CT scan was scheduled for 2 weeks from discharge for re-evaluation of closure of the fistula at that time. GU: He had acute kidney injury initially with elevated creatinine to 1.3. He was hydrated with IV fluids and urine output was monitored closely. His creatinine normalized at 0.9. MSK: Physical therapy was

His history and interpretation is provided by ___, his daughter, who can be reached at ___. He was in his normal state of health today. He reports no being dehydrated or taking in less fluids than he normally does. He was walking his grandchildren home from school when he suddenly noticed at about 4: 30 ___ that his right arm and leg became weak and felt numb. He was able to walk home on his own. His daughter noticed that the right side of his face was weak and that his voice did not sound normal when he arrived him. EMS was called and he was brought here. ED activated code stroke for NIHSS of 8 with points scored for facial weakness, dysarthria, and right sided weakness. He had a NCHCT which did not show bleed and CTA head and neck which redmonstrated prior left MCA M1 severe stenosis. By the time I examined him he was back in his room and had been flat for some time. He told me that he was feeling close to back to his baseline. His daughter said that his voice still did not sounds quite the same. I gave him an NIHSS of 1 with a soft call for dysarthria. We elected against TPA given the low NIHSS and because his neurologic deficits were likely because of hypoperfusion. summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old right handed man with past medical history of left MCA M1 severe stenosis with previous presentations with transient ischemic attack in ___ with right sided weakness who presented with acute onset dysarthria and right sided weakness which rapidly improved from NIHSS 8 to 1 (just dysarthria) found to have left MCA M1 stenosis that looks worse compared to previous. #Left M1 stenosis, likely inchemia vs. TIA CTA showed left M1 stenosis worsened from prior. Given concern for atherosclerosis as etiology and NIHSS 1, he was loaded to Plavix and started on maintenance Plavix in addition to aspirin per POINT trial. Initially, he was made HOB flat and fluids, but activity was liberalized as his exam was stable with sitting up. His exam remained stable with only subtle dysarthria, right facial droop and slight right pronator drift. MRI showed acute left basal ganglia infarction without evidence of hemorrhagic conversion and likely thrombosis in distal portion of left M1 segment. Risk factors were notable for HgA1c 6.1, LDL 47, and TSH 4.0. He was discharged with speech and swallow followup for his dysarthria. #Mild thrombocytopenia: During admission patient had mild thrombocytopenia 140-133. Patient will follow up with PCP and have CBC re-checked to ensure platelets are stable. #Pre-diabetes: Hgba1c checked on admission was 6.1, patient pre-diabetic. Will work with PCP for lifestyle modifications and will monitor as an outpatient. #Chronic Hepatitis B: Patient was continued on home entecavir during admission. Transitional Issues ===================== []PCP: please ___ CBC at appointment on ___ to check plates. At discharge mildly decreased to 133. []PCP: ___ HgbA1c 6.1, suggestive of pre-diabetes. Please monitor and encourage life style modifications [] Patient discharged on aspirin and Plavix for 3 months. Should continue until ___ then take aspirin only after this. [] Discharged with outpatient speech follow up

summary: ___ year old female with h/o undifferentiated autoimmune disorder and secondary adrenal insufficiency presented after nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and lightheadedness for one day, concerning for norovirus infection. She was admitted for IV hydrocortisone given her adrenal insufficiency and inability to tolerate PO. # Norovirus infection: Her symptoms, the onset, and the sick contacts all point toward a norovirus infection, which improved. She was maintained on IV fluids until she was able to take PO, to replace her GI losses. Her initial tachycardia improved. She also recieved metoclopromide to treat her nausea. # Secondary adrenal insufficiency: Due to prior prednisolone treatments for her autoimmune disorder. Secondary insufficiency confirmed with ACTH testing. Seen by endocrine consult team and treated with stress dose hydrocortisone now while she is having acute GI illness. She was given hydrocortisone 100 mg IV q8H and then 50 mg IV Q8H x 3 doses. She was then discharged on PO hydrocortisone at twice her home dose (20mg QAM, 10mg Q4PM) for 2 days. The quick taper is to allow her natural adrenals to return. She will follow up with Dr. ___. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - F/u with Dr. ___ adrenal insufficiency

Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five (5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at least
summary: The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: 1. POD 1 - HCT 23.5, asymptomatic -> transfused 2 units PRBCs Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1. The patient received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable condition.

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a pmh CABG, recent admission and pacemaker placement for Mobitz II w/ severe AV blockade approximately 1 month ago who was discharged to rehab presenting with DOE and fatigue. 1. Afib, mobitz type II with high grade AV block s/p PPM, now with further DOE: His evaluation with labs and imaging were unrevealing. He walked the floors with a walker and ___ and was deemed safe for discharge home with ___ ___. He had no further dyspnea on exertion during his stay. This was likely persistent deconditioning from recent hospitalization, acute heart failure exacerbation, and PPM implantation. 2. Lymphocytosis and thrombocytopenia: chronic, concern for low level heme process (cll, myeldysplastic disorder). Hematology is evaluating a smear and he was set-up with outpatient follow-up. 3. CKD: Creatinine stable at baseline. 4. CAD s/p CABG. Chronic dCHF not in exacerbation: Dry weight 80.2, admit weight 78.9. Continued home regimen with diuretic, metoprolol, aspirin. 5. Elevated DDimer: Aged matched allows to 940, value 664 with low likelihood. No hypoxia, no tachycardia. Will not pursue further.

Unlikely PE given lack of tachycardia, pleuritic component to pain. A major component to the pain is consistent wiht her previous odynophagia, although some of it is associated with nasuea and is exertional, concerning for a cardiac cause. Elevated AP in context of R scalpular pain concerning for biliary pathology, although pt s/p CCY. CT scan w/o signifcant stranding in that area. Her trops were negative x 2 and no EKG changes. Her esophgeal stent was in appropriate position by CT scan of chest. # ESOPHAGEAL CANCER: s/p stenting confirmed in appropriate position on imagining. After discussion with patient she was amenable to hospice services to optiomize her symptom control which was arranged prior to discharge. # Ecoli UTI: Tx with macrobid x7 days for complicated UTI # HYPOKALEMIA: on admission, resolved by discharge d/t likely due to poor PO intake # CAD: On ASA/Plavix. No BB, no statin. Trops neg x 2. # T1DM: Per pt is on 20u Glargine at home, although last d/c summary with 5u. Continued on 5 units glargine qhs. Refused diabetic diet in house. Continued to drink regular coke for breakfast. Met with nutrition. # ANXIETY: stable cont Klonopin 2mg TID Transitional issues: [ ] f/u pain control --FYI presribed 5 tabs of methadone as patient said she did have her prescription at home. Last BM yesterday was normal. VS in triage, 97, 142/111, 88, 20. Looked uncomfortable. Abd was ttp in epigastric without rebound or guarding and was soft. Guiaic negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Past Oncologic History: Ms. ___ was well until ___ when she had a self-limited episode of pancreatitis. In ___ she was again hospitalized for the same reason. On ___ as part of the work-up for recurrent pancreatitis, she underwent ERCP and an abdominal CT that demonstrated mildly dilation of the pancreatic duct with an area of narrowing at the junction of body and tail and an ill-defined low attenuation in the mid pancreas concerning for primary malignancy. The CT also showed a 8-mm noncalcified left lower lobe pulmonary nodule. . She underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy followed by an open exploration of the retroperitoneum that proved it to be a unresectable pancreatic body adenocarcinoma with invasion of the stomach at the lesser curvature and envelopment of the celiac plexus and axis. 2 lymph nodes that were assessed did not show signs of tumor. Cyberknife radiotherapy fiducial seeds were placed. She received two cycles of gemcitabine chemotherapy (started ___ without progression of disease and therefore was treated with CyberKnife radiation from ___ to ___. . She began to experience problems with anemia and thrombocytopenia such that her dosing schedule was changed with cycle 23 from 2wks on/1 wk off to every other week. summary: # Abdominal pain/leukocytosis: Pain improved with iv fluids and being NPO for 24 hours. It was felt to be related to her underlying pancreatic disease. She was started on pancreatic enzyme replacement at meals. Given elevated WBC count, lactate, and vomiting, transient infectious or embolic source may have also contributed. CT showed stable disease with invasion into splenic vein. At discharge, she had mild abdominal discomfort but was not requiring pain medications and was tolerating a regular diet. #Pancreatic Cancer: stable disease on recent CT abdomen. She will follow-up with outpatient oncology. # HTN: well controlled. Continued on metoprolol, HCT held while hospitalized given hypovolemia and restarted at discharge.

summary: ___ yo male with history of AML, s/p cord blood transplant who presented ___ early ___ with ARDS of unclear etiology requiring intubation. He was called out to the floor after stablilization. Floor course was complicated by increasing hypoxia so he was readmitted to the ICU for increasing respiratory distress/ARDS, found to have BOOP, treated with high dose steroids after which he made steady improvements and continued to make progress on the floor. Hospital course by problem: # ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME: Upon admission, the patient was started on broad spectrum antibiotic treatment ___ order to treat an infectious process responsible for a clinical picture consistent with ARDS. Antibiotics included vancomycin, cefepime, levofloxacin, as well as bactrim and voriconozole. The patient was followed by infectious disease during this course, with coverage of antibiotics eventually being changed to vanc/meropenem/levofloxacin/flagyl as well as prophylactic doses of voriconozole and atovaquone. The patient underwent a bronchoscopy, and BAL was sent. All work up for infectious etiology was unrevealing. There was some concern that the ARDS was secondary to rare cyclosporine toxicity, which had been intiated 3 days prior to presentation, however this was later felt not to be the case. This medication was weaned, and ultimatly discontinued. The patient was noted to have pleural effusions and gross body volume overload ___ the setting of ARF with an elevated BNP upon admission, but was an unlikely primary source of patients respiratory decompenstation. Patient remained intubated from ___ to ___. Patient was difficult to wean from the vent, possibly due to a VAP, but process was facilitated through continued diuresis and adjustments ___ antibiotics. Since extubation patient breathed comfortably on NC. Prior to transfer to the medical floor vancomycin and cefepime had been discontinued. He completed an empiric course of levaquin on ___. He was volume overloaded on transfer and diuresis was continued with 100mg

Carotid duplex ultrasound demonstrated left ICA 80%-99% stenosis. CTA angio of the neck demonstrated high bifurcation with lesion extending to mid C2. MR evidence of chronic stroke, but no evidence of any symptoms, stroke or TIA. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMHx: HLD neuropathy, HTN, NIDDM Renal insufficiency SHx: ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother with AAA s/p repair <PHYSICAL EXAM> Exam on discharge: VS: T=97.6 BP=128/86 HR=64 RR=16 O2 sat=97/RA GENERAL: WDWN in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. NECK: Supple CARDIAC: RR, normal S1, S2. No murmurs/rubs/gallops. LUNGS: CTAB. No crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. groin incisions intact NEURO: CNII-XII intact, sensorimotor function in all extremities intact PULSES: Distal pulses palpable and symmetric <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 05: 26AM BLOOD Glucose-199* UreaN-23* Creat-1.5* Na-135 K-4.6 Cl-100 HCO3-22 AnGap-18 ___ 05: 26AM BLOOD Calcium-9.4 Phos-3.7 Mg-1.7 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 2. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 3. Gabapentin 300 mg PO BID 4. Gabapentin 900 mg PO QHS 5. glimepiride 2 mg oral DAILY 6. Labetalol 150 mg PO TID 7. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 8. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 3. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 4. Gabapentin 300 mg PO BID 5. Labetalol 150 mg PO TID 6. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 7. glimepiride 2 mg ORAL DAILY 8. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H: PRN pain RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Asymptomatic carotid stenosis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ ___, You were admitted to the hospital after placement of a stent in your carotid artery. The stent will help keep the artery open so that blood can flow to the brain. To perform the procedure, a small puncture was made in an artery in your groin, he puncture site heals on its own. There are no stiches to remove. Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery Carotid Artery Stent Discharge Information Preventing a Blood Clot in the Stent -After getting a stent, you need to take aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) medicines that work to prevent blood clots from forming on the carotid stent. -Important: Do not stop taking aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) without discussing it with the doctor who did your carotid stent procedure. Puncture Site Care For one week: -Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot tub. -Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around the puncture site. -Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. -Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the puncture site. You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the procedure. You may leave the bandage off. You may have a small bruise around the puncture site. This is normal and will go away one-two weeks. Call your doctor right away if you have swelling, bleeding, drainage or discomfort at the puncture site that is new or increasing. Call if leg or foot where the puncture was done feels cold, or if you have a temperature of 101 or more. Activity For the first 48 hours: -Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure For the first week: -Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 pounds -Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles. Take care not to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, or moving your bowels. After one week: -You may go back to all your regular activities, including sexual activity. We suggest you begin your exercise program at half of your usual routine for the first few days. You may then gradually work back to your full routine.
summary: The patient presented as a same day admission for surgery. The patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for left-sided transcarotid artery revascularization, which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by the evening. The patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ receive a carotid duplex in one month. He will be discharged on lifelong aspirin 81mg and 30 days of Plavix 75mg for antiplatelet therapy. A thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions were answered. The patient was also given written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

The pain was worse when she had to void, but no hematuria or fever. She also began having worsening shortness of breath on exertion and decreased energy. She reports nausea and vomiting after eating; after vomiting, she notes central substernal/epigastric pain with radiation to the jaw and left arm (non-exertional). In addition, she has noted increased leaking around her g tube side for the past few days. She was seen on ___ in ___ clinic where she had a negative renal US and a foley was placed. That evening, had onset of chills, generalized malaise and increased left side flank pain in addition to a sense of doom. She says she feels like she did when she was septic in ___. Labs were significant for WBC of 13, lactate of 1.6, unremarkable UA, normal electrolytes and negative troponin. CXR showed no acute process. Exam notable for pus draining from around GJ-tube site. Patient was given ceftriaxone and vancomycin and admitted to medicine for further work-up. summary: In summary, Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with history of neurogenic bladder, gastroparesis with GJ tube, prior CVA, COPD, and chronic abdominal pain who presents with 2 days of acute-on-chronic abdominal pain, found to have no intraabdominal process but RLL infiltrate. ACUTE ISSUES: ============== # Acute-on-chronic abdominal pain: The patient presented with acute worsening of her chronic abdominal pain. Her pain was diffuse, worse in the RLQ and LLQ, with some radiation to the left flank. She had a normal UA (though pretreated with one dose of cipro). There was no evidence of an intraabdominal process on CT, and no evidence of infection of her G-J tube site. Her pain was was likely attributable to chronic gastroparesis, GERD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. Pain may have been exacerbated by straining in the past few weeks since her SPT was removed. She was treated with tylenol and her home pantoprazole, with home odansetron and lorazepam for nausea. # Aspiration pneumonia: The patient presented with no increased cough, sputum production, or worsening of her chronic dyspnea. However, a RLL infiltrate was noted on abdominal CT. In the setting of chronic vomiting, gastroparesis, and likely esophageal dysmotility, this infiltrate most likely represented an aspiration pneumonia. CAP is also a possibility. In the absence of any evidence of intraabdominal or GU infection, this infiltrate represented the most likely source for the patient's initial fever and leukocytosis. Accordingly, the patient's antibiotics were switched from vanc/unasyn to levofloxacin, to complete a 5 day course (day ___. She was afebrile throughout her hospital stay. # Anaphylactoid reaction: The patient underwent CT scan with PO and IV iodine contrast. She was premedicated for IV contrast given known dye allergy following our emergency protocol: Solumedrol Q4H standing at least 2 doses until contrast given, and Diphenhydramine 50mg IV once 1 hour before

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> R foot wounds <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with history of RLE lymphedema and venous stasis with chronic RLE plantar ulcer c/b osteomyelitis, HLD, CKD, paroxysmal Afib, PVD, chronic anemia, dementia who presents with worsening of R leg wound. Patient was seen today in ___ clinic where she was noted to have new redness/swelling as well as purulent drainage from R plantar wound, with failure of outpatient antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin x 7 days (___), Augmentin x 7 days (___) as well as visible extension to the bone concerning for osteomyelitis. She was subsequently referred from ___ clinic to the ED for IV antibiotics. Otherwise, no new pain in the R foot, fevers/chills, nausea or vomiting. She is currently receiving wound care at ___ where she resides. In terms of her chronic RLE wounds, she has had a right lateral plantar ulcer since at least ___ with multiple admissions for R foot osteomyelitis and recent progression over the last year. Wound cultures have grown MSSA (___), MRSA and enterococcus (___), Citrobacter (___), and most recently Klebsiella (___). On her last admission, ___, she was also noted to have MSSA bacteremia and ultimately treated with 6 week course of IV antibiotic therapy (cefazolin/cipro, last day ___ followed by PO Bactrim for suppression x 6 weeks. Podiatry recommended BKA at that time for definitive treatment. However, after extensive consideration of BKA by family, the procedure was ultimately deferred based on patient's goals of care. In the ED: - Initial vital signs were notable for: T: 97.2, HR: 83, BP: 114/41, RR: 16, 98% RA - Exam notable for: Alert and oriented x1 (self) RRR CTAB soft, non tender, non distended R lower leg with multiple ulcers and obvious deformity. Foot is inverted. Multiple ulcers on leg, most prominent with a base with some clear exudate and visible bone. Surrounding edema, erythema, and warm to touch. L lower leg with some hemosiderin deposition, no signs of ulcers. - Labs were notable for: - WBC 12.0, HgB 8.1, Plt 519 - ___ 26, PTT 37, INR 2.4 - Cr 0.8, BUN 21 - Lactate 1.8 - Blood cultures pending - Studies performed include: R foot x-ray: Limited study given poor patient positioning. Diffuse soft tissue swelling without soft tissue gas or convincing signs of osteomyelitis. Please note the lateral midfoot is poorly assessed given patient's position. - Patient was given: ___ 11: 09 IV CefePIME 2g ___ 11: 31 IV MetroNIDAOLE ___ 12: 40 IV Vancomycin (1000 mg ordered) - Consults: Vascular surgery: Seen and staffed. In short, Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F w chronic venous stasis ulcers, lymphedema, and osteomyelitis who presents with worsening cellulitis/osteomyelitis. HCP refusing BKA as is consistent with prior discussions per OMR. Recommended admission to medicine with IV antibiotics and wound care. Vitals on transfer: T: 98.5, HR: 78, BP: 115/49, RR: 22, 97% RA Upon arrival to the floor, patient is AAOx1 (to name, not place or month). She denies any pain, fevers/chills, N/V. Per Palliative Care, hospice will be covered by Ms. ___ insurance and can be provided at ___ through ___ Care. Overall plan of care includes finishing a course of PO Bactrim DS x14 days for current acute skin and soft tissue infection noting that curing the chronic osteomyelitis is no longer within goals of care. After this, the plan includes palliation with pain medicine and wound care with potential for more PO antibiotics if indicated for acute skin and soft tissue infection flares surrounding the osteomyelitis. # RLE plantar ulcer # RLE cellulitis # Osteomyelitis Admitted from ___ clinic with new redness/swelling as well as purulent drainage from R plantar wound, with failure of outpatient antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin x 7 days (___), Augmentin x 7 days (___) as well as visible extension to the bone concerning for osteomyelitis. He has no pain there. He has a markedly Trendelenburg gait. Walking helps. He has weakness of his abductors in particular and distribution of superior gluteal nerve in L5 distribution. It has been going on for a few months since ___. Really, he had some buttock and hip pain, but has resolved. He has weakness when he loads his right leg. A walking stick helps. The EMG nerve conduction studies were not impressive, not exactly consistent with the picture of isolated gluteal atrophy. Very mild L5 radiculopathy. The radiculopathy may not completely account for presenting syndrome. There is incidental support for generalized motor sensory polyneuropathy, axonal demyelinating features, no evidence of myelopathy or myopathy. An MRI of his right hip showed significant atrophy of the right gluteus medius muscle, nothing else noted. An MRI of his lumbar spine on ___, shows multilevel spondylosis with severe stenosis at L4-L5, worse on the right than the left as well as moderate foraminal stenosis. summary: Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.Refer to the dictated operative note for further details.The surgery was without complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU in a stable ___ were used for postoperative DVT prophylaxis.Intravenous antibiotics were continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol.Initial postop pain was controlled with oral and IV pain medication.Diet was advanced as tolerated.Foley was removed on POD#1.The patient was ambulating with his cane independently. Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.On the day of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.

Patient has a history of GERD, and takes omeprazole intermittently at home. CT abdomen/pelvis also negative for any acute intraabdominal source. No evidence of pleural effusion on CT or CXR. CXR unremarkable. Pain not reproducible on palpation. Most likely ___ to GERD or pill esophagitis as patient has a daily high pill burden. She was continued on omeprazole while inpatient and had Maalox available PRN. Chronic Issues: # ESRD on HD. ___ schedule. She continued home calcitriol, calcium carbonate, vitamin D, nephrocaps, sevelamer # HIV. CD4 count was 853 on ___. summary: Mr. ___ was admitted for antibiotics, IVF resuscitation, and bowel rest. His symptoms improved and he was evaluated for laparoscopic cholecystectomy during this admission. He was taken to the operating room on ___ by Dr. ___ the details of the operation can be viewed separately in the operative dictation. In summary, it was a difficult dissection with evidence of a necrotic gallbladder. A drain was left in the gallbladder fossa which drained serosanguineous fluid. He did well postoperatively, voided on his own, tolerated advancement of his diet, and his pain was well controlled with PO pain meds. His drain with scant fluid was removed prior to discharge and prescriptions with instructions provided on ___.

She underwent cholangiogram which was negative for any anastomotic or other stricture. Biliary drain was removed with improvement in pain. Elevated alkaline phosphatase thought possibly related to drain. She will need repeat LFTs checked within the next week to ensure that they are downtrending. She was discharged on a three day supply of dilaudid until pain improves/resolves Transitional Issues: - needs LFTs rechecked in one week > 30 minutes spent on discharge communication/planning

summary: Mr. ___ presented to the ___ ED on ___ after a motor vehicle crash as a Trauma Basic. He was unrestrained and had unknown loss of consciousness. He was in visible distress, complaining of severe pain and agitation, dry heaving and having difficulty breathing. Due to imaging from the outside hospital that found left diaphragmeatic rupture with stomach and liver edge in the thoracic cavity, he was taken to the OR emergently for operative repair. In addition, he had a left pubic ramus fracture, and had cortical irregularities on left anterior ___- 5th ribs that could represent fractures. He had refused a C-collar on scene and CT C spine and CT head were negative per report. He was taken to the operating room by Dr. ___ Dr. ___ an exploratory laparotomy, repair of ruptured left diaphragm, and left tube thoracostomy. Please see the operative report for further detail. He was taken to the TSICU postoperatively as he remained intubated. His chest tube was put to water seal after his chest x-rays found only small apical pneumothorax.Orthopedic trauma evaluated him and recommended no operative intervention for his left inferior pubic ramus fracture, with weight bearing as tolerated and follow up with orthopedics. He was extubated and transferred to the floor on ___ with the chest tube in place on water seal. Pain control was managed, with the addition of Lidoderm patches and Dilaudid IV for breakthrough pain. He continued to have serosanguine output from his chest tube. He was given a cough pillow and encouraged incentive spirometry. Overnight, he developed sudden onset of acute left chest pain and dyspnea. He had sinus tachycardia to 160s, with pain in his left chest similar to his initial presentation with lesser severity. He had 95% oxygen saturation on room air. No air leak was noted for his left chest tube, which was placed to suction. AN EKG found sinus tachycardia, which improved upon further IV Dilaudid pain control.

summary: ___ y/o diabetic man with recent hospitalization for RLE cellulitis, DVT, and right knee gout flare admitted with recurrent right foot pain. . # Right foot pain - The patient was admitted with ___ days of worsening right foot pain with weight-bearing in the setting of known recent cellulitis, right lower extremity DVT, and severe gout. He localized tenderness to base of digits ___ on dorsum and plantar surfaces of right foot. On admission, cellulitis had resolved. OSH records were obtained from recent hospitalization, that showed equivocal right foot MRI findings for osteomyelitis, untreated. The patient underwent repeat MRI that showed no evidence of osteomyelitis, but non-specific inflammatory changes and evidence of inactive gout in the right first MTP (not a true flare by patient symptoms). The patient's antibiotics for cellulitis were discontinued. He was seen by podiatry, who recommended moisturizing lotion to his legs and a topical antifungal to his feet. He was provided teds for chronic edema. His pain resolved. Given the patient's history of recurrent severe gout, a prior authorization was submitted to the patient's insurance company for febuxostat (patient with allergy to allopurinol). Pending prior authorization, the patient may start febuxostat as an outpatient. PCP was notified of prior auth. . # Right lower extremity DVT on coumadin - Diagnosed on recent admission in ___. On admission, the patient's INR was 3.3 in the setting of antibiotics for cellulitis. Coumadin was held for 1 day, and the patient's antibiotics were discontinued. On the following day, his INR was subtherapeutic to 1.4. The patient was started on a heparin drip and warfarin was titrated up to 8.5 mg daily. The patient was discharged with a therapeutic INR on coumadin. He will follow up with his PCP for INR monitoring. . # Eosinophilia - Patient with persistent significant eosinophilia up to 21.4 throughout admission. Eos have been chronically

summary: This is a ___ woman with history of migraines, chronic inactive gastritis, and history of H. pylori infection who presents with headache and LLQ pain found to have diverticulitis. #Uncomplicated diverticulitis: Patient's LLQ pain and imaging findings are consistent with uncomplicated sigmoid diverticulitis given absence of abscess or other concerning findings on imaging. Patient remained afebrile and without leukocytosis throughout hospital course. Patient started on 7 day course of cipro/flagyl. Patient able to tolerate oral intake prior to discharge. #HEADACHE: Patient's headache unilateral most consistent with her history of previous migraines. Patient did not have eye lacrimation and was rather crying at the time of her headache onset. Her headache is now markedly improved with fiorocet. Initial concern for GCA in ED due to language barrier however on review of patient's symptoms headache thought to be more consistent in characteristic to past migraines though more severe this time in setting of stress in the ED. Headache improved with fiorecet. CRP elevated though likely secondary to diverticulitis above. Patient also received 40 mg prednisone given initial concern over GCA. Prednisone was not continued. Patient's headache resolved prior to discharge. #GERD: Currently stable -continue home omeprazole and ranitidine TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: =================== -patient noted to have hepatic steatosis on CT abd. -please follow up diverticulitis signs and symptoms to ensure improvement/resolution

summary: ___ year old female with history of HLD and recent fall with rib fractures in ___ presented with cardiopulmonary arrest in the setting of massive PE s/p ECMO and CRRT, course complicated by VAP, ___ and pancreatitis. ACUTE ISSUES ============================ #s/p PEA arrest: #massive PE Patient had two cardiopulmonary arrests in the setting of bedside echo report as well as CTA confirmation of PE. Given hypotension and RV strain, patient with submassive pulmonary embolism. Likely cause of the pulmonary embolism was immobility in the setting of healing from a recent fall. Upon arrival, ___ ___ MASCOT team was notified and helped with management. The patient was not started on heparin due to TPA administration at outside hospital. The postarrest team was contacted and recommended targeted temperature management at 35C with continuous EEG monitoring. The patient required epinephrine, norepinephrine, and vasopressin, as well as initiation of Fem-Fem VA ECMO: ___ venous, ___ arterial via 8mm Dacron chimney graft). she was given inhaled nitric oxide and followed by pulmonology for recommendations on ventilation settings. Her pressors and ECMO were weaned and the patient was able to be transitioned to the floor with stable hemodynamics. She was continued on a heparin drip and transitioned to warfarin. She was briefly supratherapeutic, and warfarin was held. Patient then became subtherapeutic requiring re-initiation of heparin bridge. She will need daily INR checks to determine when her heparin can be discontinued. #L lower extremity DVT: Patient with non-occlusive thrombus in L popliteal, gastroc, and posterior tibial vein. ___ have been related to PE and possible source of extensive clot burden. She was treated with heparin and then eventually switched to warfarin which she should continue as an outpatient indefinitely. #Lactic acidosis #Acid/Base disturbance: The patient had persistent acidemia refractory to amps of sodium bicarbonate

summary: ___ is a ___ year old woman without prior regular medical care and a history of tobacco abuse who presented to an outside hospital with acutely worsening shortness of breath, found to be hypertensive with flash pulmonary edema. She was temporarily started on a nitroglycerin drip, given morphine, failed a trial of BiPAP and was intubated. The nitroglycerin drip was stopped after intubation and her blood pressure was well controlled while on propofol for sedation. After initiation of diuresis, she was transferred to ___ for further management and anticipated cardiac catheterization. . Flash pulmonary edema: The patient's flash pulmonary edema was addressed with continued diuresis with IV furosemide upon admission to the CCU. Repeat chest x-rays at ___ demonstrated improving pulmonary edema. Her flash pulmonary edema was thought to have been caused by her acutely worsening hypertension in the setting of chronic diastolic dysfunction. The morning after admission ___ she was extubated successfully and her breathing continued to improve. . Coronary Artery Disease and Cardiac Function: Intial ECG upon admission showed q waves in V1-V2 along with early repolarization changes in V2-V3, no concerning ST/T changes, most consistent with an old anteroseptal infarct. An echocardiogram was completed and showed global left ventricular systolic dysfunction (LVEF 40%) with some regionality which could be consistent with multivessel coronary artery disease and mild MR. ___ then received a cardiac catheterization that showed two vessel coronary disease (ostial RCA 80% and LAD with 95% mid vessel stenosis involving the major diagonal but with a small distal vessel, LCx has a 30% mid vessel stenosis) along with moderate pulmonary hypertension and biventricular diastolic dysfunction. She received a successful DES to the RCA. The LAD was not stented to due prediction of poor benefit secondary to the thought that her small distal LAD vessel did not cover much perfusion territory. She was continued on a heparin drip (started at outside hospital) for a total of 48 hours. Additionally, she was started on a full dose aspirin daily, atorvastatin

summary: ___ yo male with HIV CD4 380 not on HAART with recent MRSA cellulitis and abscess now presenting with bacterial vs fungal LLE cellulitic superinfection. . #. Cellulitic Superinfection - The rash appeared consistent with a mild bacterial or fungal cellulitis. The rash did not appear to be consistent with MRSA skin infection. The patient was afebrile and without leukocytosis and his rash seemed improved from his description of its character prior to bactrim treatment. He was therefore treated with bactrim and topical antifungal cream. . #. HIV. Stable. Outpatient follow up. . #. Substance abuse. The patient did not demonstrate any signs of withdrawal during his brief hospitalization. It was unclear if this is truly an active issue. . On ___, the patient was felt stable for discharge to home with PCP ___. He was discharged with a prescription for a 14 day course of Bactrim along with instructions to apply a topical anti-fungal to the affected area.

summary: ___ w/ PMH of GIST tumor resection/partial gastrectomy and past admissions for intraperitoneal bleed ___ omental metastasis while on coumadin (now stopped) presents from rehab with anemia. #Macrocytic anemia -Pt received 1 unit of PRBCs on admission with appropriate response and stable hct thereafter. Anemia panel not c/w hemolysis or occult blood loss. No evidence of acute bleed during hospital stay. Anemia likely due to malignancy and recent sunitinib. Normal iron levels as well as B12, folate, retic count and TSH levels. . #GIST with metastases to the omentum Treatment on hold for now until wound improves. Ct of abdomen showed stable disease. . #Chronic diastolic heart failure - Patient with increase in ___ edema over the past few days and increased DOE with evidence of vascular congetsion on cxr.Cause of decompensation unclear; possibly sunitinib,infection,anemia, or diet. Given 2 doses of IV lasix with good response. Breathing improved significantly and also improved lower extremity edema. TSH wnl, echo -unchanged. UTI possibly contributing to decompensation as well as sunitinib and anemia.Pt's weight and lower extremity edema to be monitored as an oputpt and lasix to be given accordingly. Pt also to follow a cardiac healthy diet with salt restriction. . #AFIB: Rate controlled with diltiazem. Pt not on anticoagulation given h/o GI bleed in the past.Aspirin held initially because of concern of possible bleed , but since pt without evidence of bleed aspirin 81 mg resumed. Pantoprazole started for GI prophylaxis. . # HYPERTENSION: Continued Diltiazem. BP well controlled throughout hospital stay. . #DM2: Continued to manage with Humalog insulin sliding scale in the hospital.Januvia held on admission and resumed upon discharge. . #Surgical wound: Cont dressings per wound care nurse. Surgery consulted and did feel that there is any need for additional debridement at this time. Pt also seen by

summary: The patient was admitted for the above surgery. She tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the regular floor post-operatively. On POD#1, she was transitioned from PCA to oral pain medications and was comfortable. She worked with physical therapy, weight bearing as tolerated on her left lower extremity using crutches/walker for balance and support. Her foley catheter was removed on POD#2, and she was able to void on her own. By POD#3, she was cleared for home by ___ and was deemed medically stable for discharge.

summary: Ms. ___ was admitted s/p lap chole with increasing abdominal pain and elevated transaminases concerning for a retained stone in the biliary tree. She was made NPO, given IVF and taken for ERCP on ___. In ERCP, she was noted to have a small retained stone which was extracted and a sphincterotomy was done as well. She tolerated the procedure well without any complications. The following day. she was advanced to clear liquids and then a regular diet which she tolerated well. She was stable for discharge with the appropriate follow-up. Of note, there was a 5mm pancreatic lesion seen on CT scan which may require an outpatient MRI for further evaluation. The ERCP also showed an incidental periampullary divertuiculum.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> back pain, right foot drop <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> L4-5 Laminectomy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> He has low back pain and some foot pain, but nothing in between. It has been going on for approximately one year. I do not see EMG and nerve conduction studies. He has undergone physical therapy, no injections. Symptoms are ___ with activity, ___ with rest. His medical history, he has high blood pressure. He has had right meniscal surgery. His medications include lisinopril, Lipitor. No known drug allergies. He is a ___. He has a partner. He does not smoke. Review of systems and family history noncontributory. Notes from ___ were reviewed. He was seen in ___ clinic on ___ with a history of 7 months of subacute onset of right foot drop, marked compression of the right L4 nerve root on imaging. An MRI was reviewed from ___, shows multilevel degenerative changes, mild spinal stenosis at L3-L4 with mild-to-moderate spinal stenosis at L4-L5, right foraminal narrowing at L4-L5 with disc protrusion contacting the exiting right nerve root. On physical examination, he is an otherwise healthy gentleman who is in an AFO, which we removed. He does have a marked footdrop with ___ and anterior tibialis weakness, his quadriceps seems to be well maintained, his left are ___. Specific testing of his anterior tib showed at most ___ strength. His ___ was similar. His calves were soft. His reflexes were intact at his quadriceps tendon and were not decreased. He had decreased sensation of paresthesias on the lateral aspect of his right foot, otherwise intact. No gait asymmetry otherwise. He has negative Spurling's, negative Lhermitte's. In summary, this is a patient with chronic right foot drop. He has back and leg pain, but it is primarily the foot drop that is worrisome. I discussed with him the possibility of doing surgery and the unpredictive nature of recovery after such a surgery. This would be an L4-L5 decompression with an aggressive L4 foraminotomy and discectomy at that level. I would e-mail Dr. ___ whether an EMG and nerve conduction study would be helpful. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> see med rec <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 3. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 4. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 5. Multivitamins 1 CAP PO DAILY 6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q3H: PRN Pain <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> spinal stenosis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression Without Fusion Immediately after the operation: - Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more than 45 minutes without moving around. - Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: ___ ___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. ___ Limit any kind of lifting. - Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this issue. - Brace: You may have been given a brace. This brace is to be worn when you are walking. You may take it off when sitting in a chair or lying in bed. - Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 5 days. If the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing and call the office. - You should resume taking your normal home medications. - You have also been given Additional Medications to control your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___ 2. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the date of surgery. - Follow up: 2 weeks ___ Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been done already. ___ At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start physical therapy. ___ We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation and at that time release you
summary: Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure. Refer to the dictated operative note for further details. The surgery was without complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU in a stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for postoperative DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop pain was controlled with a PCA. Diet was advanced as tolerated. The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when tolerating PO diet. . Physical therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate. Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.

General instructions: * Take your medications as prescribed. * Do not drive while taking narcotics. * Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to prevent constipation. * Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol. * Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs. * No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment. * No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks. * You may eat a regular diet. * You may walk up and down stairs. summary: On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after undergoing supracervical abdominal hysterectomy. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately post-op, her pain was controlled with IV dilaudid PCA, tylenol and toradol. On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her foley was removed and she voided spontaneously. Her diet was advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to oral dilaudid and motrin. By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

summary: ___ was admitted on ___ with L lower extremity claudication, agreed to have an elective surgery. Pre-operatively, was consented. A CXR, EKG, UA, CBC, Electrolytes, T/S - were obtained, all other preperations were made. It was decided that he would undergo: OPERATIONS: 1. Ultrasound-guided puncture of the right common femoral artery. 2. Contralateral second-order catheterization of the left external iliac artery. 3. Abdominal aortogram. 4. Serial arteriogram of the left lower extremity. She was prepped, and brought down to the endo suite room for surgery. Intra-operatively, she was closely monitored and remained hemodynamically stable. She tolerated the procedure well without any difficulty or complication. Post-operatively, transferred to the PACU for further stabilization and monitoring. Her sheath was pulled wihtout sequele. She was then transferred to the VICU for further recovery. While in the VICU she recieved monitered care. When stable she was delined. Her diet was advanced. When she was stabalized from the acute setting of post operative care, she was transfered to floor status On the floor, she remained hemodynamically stable with her pain controlled. She continues to make steady progress without any incidents. She was discharged home in sstable condition. She did recieve preoperative hydration. On DC her creatinine is stable. 1.4 pre and 1.4 post operative.

However, the future liver remnant of segments ___ is currently at 19% of her total liver volume, obviously insufficient for adequate liver function. Therefore, it was recommended to the patient to have a right portal vein embolization by interventional radiology, which is the reason for her direct admission to the hospital today. Extrem: no edema Neuro: grossly intact Psyc: appropriate mood/affect <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 09: 30AM BLOOD WBC-14.0* RBC-3.93 Hgb-11.9 Hct-36.2 MCV-92 MCH-30.3 MCHC-32.9 RDW-12.2 RDWSD-41.3 Plt ___ ___ 09: 30AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 05: 56AM BLOOD Glucose-91 UreaN-14 Creat-0.7 Na-142 K-4.9 Cl-102 HCO3-29 AnGap-11 ___ 09: 30AM BLOOD ALT-24 AST-39 AlkPhos-116* TotBili-0.4 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Drysol 20 % topical solution. every other week PRN AELAIC ACID Finacea 15 % topical foam. every other day azelastine 0.15 % (205.5 mcg) nasal spray. 2 spray BID Pulmicort 0.5 mg/2 mL suspension for nebulization BID Cleocin T 1 % topical gel once a week Restasis 0.05 % eye drops in a dropperette BID montelukast 10 mg tablet' Compazine 25 mg rectal suppository q6h PRN Ambien 5 mg tablet QHS <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Omeprazole 20 mg PO BID dyspepsia 5. olpidem Tartrate 5 mg PO QHS insomnia <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure taking care of you here at the ___ ___. You were admitted to our hospital for your intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. You had a portal vein embolization on ___. You tolerated the procedure well and have recovered well from some mild post-operative issues, that resolved prior to your discharge. You are now ambulating, stooling, tolerating a regular diet, and your pain is controlled by pain medications by mouth. You are now ready to be discharged to home. Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful recovery. ACTIVITY: - Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and feel you could respond in an emergency. - You may climb stairs. You should continue to walk several times a day. - You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you see your surgeon at your next visit. - You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. Slowly increase your activity back to your baseline as tolerated. - Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common sense and go slowly at first. - No heavy lifting (10 pounds or more) until cleared by your surgeon, usually about 6 weeks. - You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you otherwise. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: - You may feel weak or washed out for 6 weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. - You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your throat during the surgery. YOUR BOWELS: - Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medicine such as oxycodone. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these medicines without a prescription. - If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement,
summary: Patient presented for right portal vein embolization in setting of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. For details of the procedure, please see the operative report. She tolerated the surgery well and was supervised in post anesthesia care unit post-op. Patient was transferred to ___ floor where she continued to recover from surgery well. Interventional Radiology service also followed the patient along during her admission and deemed her stable for discharge to home on ___. Her laboratory blood tests were all normal including CBC and Liver Function Tests. She will need another lab draw once she is discharged including CBC and LFTs. She was able to ambulate, tolerate a regular diet, voiding well, and his pain was well controlled. She was discharged home with close follow up and appropriate post-operative care instructions.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Procardia / Hytrin / potassium sorbate <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Dyspnea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with a hx of CABG x 3 (___), prolonged ICU course with post-op complications s/p trach (___), CHF, a fib, moderate AS, AAA s/p repair in ___, and CKD who was brought in from Spauding due to AMS and hypoxia while on the ventilator. The pt recently presented to ___ in late ___ with a 3 wk hx of worsening DOE, PND, 3-pillow orthopnea, lower extremity edema and mild exertional chest pressure radiating to the R shoulder/jaw relieved by rest. He was found to have elevated trops (.30) and an elevated Cr (6.9, baseline ___. He was found to have multivessel coronary dz on catheterization and underwent CABG x 3. The procedure was well tolerated, however the pt developed signs of graft dysfunction post operatively. He required pressors and multiple blood products and was started on CVVH therapy due to worsening kidney function and the development of uremia. He also developed post-op a fib requiring IV amiodarone. Days later he developed hypoxic respiratory failure requiring ventilator support and was found to have Pseudomonas Aeruginosa and Klebsiella PNA, managed with cefepime and meropenem. He was unable to wean from the vent and required trach placement. He also developed b/l transudative pleural effusions thought to be ___ CHF. The pt was d/c to rehab on POD 38 on abx, coumadin, and amiodarone. The pt has been in rehab since hospital discharge on ___. He completed a course of cefepime for pseudamonas/klebsiella PNA yesterday, however a CXR done at ___ yesterday was concerning for a new PNA. Rehab staff reports recent confusion that worsens with HD, episodes of desatting despite ventilation, and intermittant fevers. Most recent dialysis yesterday, diuresed x 2L. There are no reported falls. In the ED, initial vitals: Temp: 99.9 HR: 81 BP: 107/67 Resp: 26 O(2)Sat: 100. Vent settings upon arrival were Invasive Mode: A/C FiO2: 50 PEEP: 8 RR: 12 Vt: 450. The pt appeared ill with crackles on exam. He denied chest pain. CXR revealed interval worsening of pulmonary edema, confluent opacity in the left mid lung suspicious for superimposed infection, and stable moderate bilateral pleural effusions. Labs were notable for trop-t of 2.51, Na 127, K 4.2, Cl 95, HCO3 21, BUN 50, Cr 3, Gluc 127, Lipase 107, lactate 1.7. CBC revealed a WBC of 21.2 (92% PMNss), H/H of 8.3/26.5, plts of 245. Coags notable for PTT of 52.5, INR of 4.5. Serum tox screen was negative. Flu swab was negative. Given fever102, hypoxia and AMS, ED was concerned for a new PNA. Bcx were sent and the pt was started on vanc/zosyn/levoquin. He was admitted to the MICU for further management. On transfer, vitals were: HR: 80 BP: 103/59 RR: 20 O2 sat: 100% vent On arrival to the MICU, vitals were T: 98.5 HR: 87 BP: 117/73 RR: 16 O2 sat: 100%/.5 FiO2. The pt was conversant, not able to speak but able to mouth words. Sleepy but rousable. HDS, afebrile. Reports feeling confused. summary: ___ with a hx of CABG x 3 (___), prolonged ICU course with post-op complications s/p trach (___), CHF, moderate AS, AAA s/p repair in ___, and CKD presenting with confusion and hypoxia despite ventilator and found to have intermittant fevers, leukocytosis, and CXR c/w infection superimposed on worsening pulmonary edema and preexisting pleural effusions, concerning for a new PNA. #HCAP: The pt presented with AMS, fever and hypoxia despite CMV with FiO2 of 50% in the setting a recent prolonged ICU stay c/b pseudomonas and klebsiella PNA. Given findings of significant purulent secretions upon trach suctioning, presention is most c/w recurrent PNA. Recent hx of prolonged hospitalization as well as ventilator dependence raises concern for HCAP vs. VAP. Patient was started on antibiotics of vancomycin, meropenam, and ciprofloxacin. ID was consulted, agreed with continuing meropenam and considering switching ciprofloxacin to tobramycin should he clinically worsen. His gram stain was notable for GNRs so vancomycin was stopped. He was continued on meropenam and ciprofloxacin. Sputum culture from facility on day of transfer grew pseudomonas and klebsiella sensitive to cipro and meropenam. Antibiotics were narrowed to meropenam as per ID recs. He will continue on meropenam 500mg q24h until ___ to complete a two-week course. The rehab facility will be called if sensitivities reveal pseudomonas that is resistant to meropenam. # Respiratory failure: trached in the setting of recent prolonged hospitalization s/p CABG. Patient was alternated between PSV ___, Fi02 40%) and trach mask, only tolerated trach mask for ___ at a time due to tiring out. He was noted to have copious secretions requiring frequent suctioning by RT. PS level increased to 8 on day of discharge. Pneumonia treated as above. #CKD: Pt's elevated Cr is c/w his baseline since his recent admission. He continued HD

After admission IV diuresis was attempted but in the setting of contrast to rule out type B dissection after echo findings and vancomycin in the setting of GPC positive blood cultures she developed ___ with creatinine from 0.9 -> 1.8. Diuresis was held, she had lower blood pressures, mildly cool extremities and was found to have lactate of 5.2 for which dobutmaine drip was started however she developed tachyarrhythmias. Given her dyspnea remained uncontrolled and there were no feasible long term options for improving her cardiac function/dyspnea, after discussion with family, Dr. ___, Dr. ___, Dr. ___ Dr. ___ changed her code status to DNR/DNI and then decision was made to aggressively treat her symptoms as comfort measures only. She died comfortably, surrounded by her family. Autopsy was declined.

Of note, thought process was notably linear, goal oriented on examination and he did not appear to be responding to internal stimuli. Of note, he does have some medical comorbidities including untreated hypertension and other vascular risk factors (cocaine use in the past, overweight, poor self care) that may have contributed to his current presentation. . #.
