summary: 1. Bilateral Pulmonary Emboli: Patient initially evaluated at ___ where she was found to have positive D-dimer; CT scan done showed bilateral PEs. Patient recieved Lovenox at approximately 5pm on ___. Lysis was deferred because she was hemodynamically stable and there was no evidence of either significant clot on ___ ultrasound or PFO or significant right heart strain on TTE. Patient was put on a IV heparin drip in the unit rather than Lovenox due to her body habitus. Warfarin was started with a goal INR of ___. She was kept on a heparin drip until her INR was therapeutic. She was discharged on 5mg Warfarin daily with instructions to have her INR checked on ___ (2 days after discharge) and to have her primary care physician follow up on her anticoagulation. The cause of her pulmonary emboli were not clear, but her risk factors included family history of blood clots (cousin), recent oral contraceptive use, and smoking. While lower extremity U/S during this admission showed no evidence of DVTs, per report there was some evidence of a small DVT on previous ___ U/S at an OSH a few months prior to the current admission. Further work up of potential coagulopathies was differed to after discharge given her current clot burden. 2. Respiratory Failure: Patient was initially admitted to the MICU on a non-rebreather with respiratory failure due to her pulmonary emboli. PNA was considered to be unlikely given her lack of fevers, lack of crackles on exam, and lack of clear evidence of PNA on imaging. Asthma was also considered unlikely given her lack of wheezing. She was given nebulizer treatments to help with subjective shortness of breath and cough. She was then successfully weaned to room air and remained stable, without labored breathing or other signs of respiratory distress, and saturating > 95% on room air for the remainder of her hospitalization. 3. Hypothyroidism: Patient was admitted with PMH of hypothyroidism but with current and recent non-compliance on levothyroxine and uncertainty about

summary: This is an ___ year old female with CAD and chronic episodes of chest pain who presents with chest pain. . # Chest pain: Her chest pain has been extensivly worked up. She has known CAD, but seems unlikely to be causing her symptoms. Her chest pain is not associated with activity. She seems to have a large component of anxiety which makes interpreting her pain very difficult. As she has known CAD she was admitted to rule our an MI. Her ECG was unchaged (stable LBBB) and she had three sets of cardiac enzymes that were not elevated. She had an episode of chest pain on the morning of her discharge. An ECG obtained at that time was unchanged with her prior ECGs. An echo was performed that showed no evidence of a focal wall motion abnormality, but did show evidence of chronic hypertension. At this point her chest pain was attributed to a non-cardiac cause with a high probability that there is a large anxiety component. Patient may benefit from outpatient phyciatric work up for anxitey. . # HTN: Patient noted to have severe systolic hypertension in past. Patient very fixated on HTN. Checks BP multiple times a day. Unclear if ever having symptoms of hypotension. Per patient she has had recordings of 70/40 at home. Usually she is hypertensive but only takes her medication if her SBP is > 135. Her outpatient blood pressure medications were continued. She may benefit from not checking her blood pressure as much and taking her blood pressure medications on a regular basis and not titrating to her BP readings. . # Seizures: Unclear history. Continuing dilantin. Dilantin level not elevated. . # GERD: Continue nexium. . # Chronic pain in back and legs: Patient not specifically complaining about that at this time. Continued patient on home pain regemin of darbocet. . # Anxiety: Clear portion of patients symptoms due to

He continued to have pain in the ED; the pain had peaks and valleys, and finally resolved about ___ hours after it started while in the ED. Since then he has had short bouts ___ minutes) of ___ CP. Currently without CP. While in the ED the pain radiated down his left arm and into his back. . He states that the quality of the pain was very similar to his GERD pain, but that the intensity and speed with which it came on where different. Also he states that he never has GERD pain in the am and that it generally responds to mylanta. He states that his CP is usually not associated with exertion. This CP is not like the pain he usually experiences with esophageal spasms. . In the ED: The patient had a EKG showing old infarct but no new ischemic changes. summary: ___ yo male with pmh of extensive CAD s/p several stents, htn, hyperlipidemia, DM, and OSA now admitted with chest pain concerning for acute coronary syndrome. . #. CAD/CP - Patient with extensive CAD s/p multiple stents and many cardiac risk factors. TIMI score of 4 - 5 places him in the intermediate to high risk category. Patient does have a history of GERD pain, but this is somewhat different from his normal GERD pain and the fact that it was exertional and accompanied by dizziness makes it seem more likely cardiac in origin. Other less likely causes for his chest pain could be PE (however by Wells criteria he is low risk) or pneumonia. . Due to concern for acute conronary syndrome he was started on a heparin drip upon admission. He was continued on 325 mg ASA, plavix, a B-blocker, and a statin. His acei was held to due his elevated Cr for cath. He went for cardiac catheterization the next day (___) and was found to have 3 vessel cononary artery disease. The LMCA had a 20% distal stenosis. The LAD had moderate diffuse disease. The Diagonal-1 had patent stents with an 80% stenosis at the distal edge of the most distal stent. The LCx had patent stents. There was a 50% stenosis in the mid-LCx. The RCA had a total occlusion with left-to-right collaterals. . Successful PTCA of the distal Diagonal-1 using 2.0x12mm and 2.25x12mm Voyager balloons was completed. Final angiography revealed TIMI III flow, no dissection, and a 10% residual stenosis. The patient was discharged home the day following catheterization without event. . #. Pump (EF of 30%) No past clinical history of heart failure; Had crackles bilaterally up his lung fields and no edema. We continued to control his htn with the B-blocker

summary: The patient is an ___ yo female with a history of HTN, HL, CAD, CHF, severe AS, and AFib presenting with increased dyspnea and ___ edema. She was recently discharged to rehab on ___ after vertebroplasty. . # Acute on Chronic Diastolic CHF: The patient has evidence of decompensated heart failure based on exam, pulmononary congestion on CXR, and elevated BNP (no prior for comparison). Her home Lasix had been held on her recent admission due to acute renal failure presumed due to prior overdiuresis. She appears to have a tenuous volume status, which may be due to her severe AS. She also has AFib but is rate controlled. She denies any recent CP, but has not been very physically active since her vertebroplasty. She was kept on a low sodium diet (<2g) with fluid restriction to 1.5 L. She was diureses with individual doses of Lasix 20 mg IV with close monitoring of her electrolytes, blood pressure, and creatinine. By the time of discharge, she was approaching euvolemia with stable labs. She was seen by Surgery to have an initial evaluation for possible aortic valve replacement, and this can be continued as an outpatient if she elects to persue valve replacement. Patient was discharged on five times weekly lasix dosing skipping ___ and ___. . # Cough: Likely related to CHF. No fevers or leukocytosis. CXR on admission showed no evidence of pneumonia and CXR on ___ was essentially unchanged on preliminary read. She was treated with Guaifenesin PRN for symptomatic relief. . # Atrial Fibrillation: Her CHADS2 score is 3. She remained well rate controlled on her home dose of Metoprolol succinate 100 mg PO daily. She was continued on her home dose of Coumadin 2 mg PO daily. Her INR was therapeutic at 2.4 on admission and remained therapeutic during her stay, with INR 2.5 on discharge. . # Hypertension: Her BP was fairly well controlled on her home regimen of Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO QHS

summary: Patient is a ___ year old male with no significant PMHx who presented to OSH with complaints of weakness developing acute respiratory failure found to have a saddle PE started on heparin gtt trasnferred to ___ for further management with MRI findings suggestive of ADEM treated with IV steroids/IVIG, whose mental status and neurological function improved. # Respiratory failure: Multifactorial; etiologies include saddle pulmonary embolism with infarction in combination with profound weakness from ADEM. The patient was difficult to oxygenate at times initially. Patient underwent trach and PEG placement in light of prolonged intubation. Improving currently, he is tolerating trach collar at times up to 30 minutes. Speech and swallow are also working with him. Be sure to look for signs of carbon dioxide retention if mental status worsens on PSV as patient could tire out at times. He is usually arousable to voice, alert and can nod to yes/no questions, oriented X3. # ADEMS: Patient underwent head MRI as well as full spine MRI as part of work-up of his clinical picture, and Neurology felt that the findings were consistent with ADEM. He was treated with 5 days of IV steroids and five more days of IVIG. The patient's exam improved along with repeat MRI imaging showed progression of the lesions, but this was in the context of improved exam clinically, and no further interventions were done. His diaphgram has improved function with today's NIF of -43. He has slowly regaining strength in his extremities with ___ UE and ___ strength (R > L). Please continue to ensure he has ongoing physical therapy. # Pulmonary embolism: Patient with saddle embolism at the OSH. Patient was hemodynamically stable upon arrival to ___ with SBP 130-140s. Patient was evaluated for thrombectomy at OSH and it was felt that pulmonary embolectomy would be counter productive. Patient was initially continued on heparin gtt, at one point being transitioned Lovenox /coumadin

summary: Patient presented to ___ agitated and recieved Ativan. CT head showed a left temporal IPH. She was sent to ___ for further management and care, intubated in the emergency department for a GCS of 8 and admitted to the intensive care unit. She was seen by the neurology service ___ recommended an EEG as well as MRI and TTE. She remained stable overnight into ___ and her ventilator was weaned over the course of the day, and she was ultimately extubated the afternoon of ___. On ___, she was breathing comfortably extubated and was alert. She continued to have slurred speech and was oriented only to self. She failed her bedside swallowing exam. Her EEG continued to be free of seizure. ___, the patient was more alert and interactive. She was re-evaluated by speach and swallow who cleared her for a regular diet with thin liquids. At the recommendation of neurology, a MRI was completed which showed the known left temporal lobe intraparenchymal hemorrhage. There was no evidence of stroke. ___, Ms. ___ potassium was low and was appropriately repleated. On ___ patient was stable and discharged to rehab.

summary: Patient was admitted to the OMED floor at ___ s/p G-tube placement for decompression of partial small bowel obstruction. Patient tolerated the procedure well, however POD#1 (HD#1) and POD#2 were complicated by frequent emesis ___ QD) and retching. There were trace amounts hematemesis, which resolved after HD#2, HCT remained stable. Patient was placed on an anti-emetic regimen that included compazine IV, zofran IV, ativan IV and reglan IV and promethazin IV prn. She was placed on continuous IVF of NS and NPO. For pain, patient was treated initially treated with dicyclomine PO 20mg QID, liquid morphine ___ PO PRN and a fentanyl patch 25mcg. This regimen, along with connection of G-tube to suction, improved n/v, however did not eliminated it completely. Patient's electrolytes were replaced as needed. For heartburn, Mrs. ___ was placed on Pantoprazole IV 40mg BID and maalox/bendadry/lidocaine cocktal prn. By HD#4, the abdominal exam was significant for increased distention and pain on palpation. Patient continued to suffer from N/V at ___ daily despite the antiemetic regimen. Change of ofran IV prn to Q8H offered some, but incomplete relief. Due to abdominal cramping, dicyclomine was held and patient was given a trial of Levcin, w/o good effect. Throughout this time patient had poor tolerance of PO intake, and had abdominal cramping/nausea even with ice chips. Patient remained moderately sedated ___ benzodiazepine use. A discussion with Dr. ___ the patient was held regarding hospice. It was felt that since the options of efficacious chemotherapy regimens were exhausted and based on the prognosis and patient's current condition, home hospice would provide most adequate and situation sensitive treatment option. This discussion was also held patient's husband over several days. Over HDs

summary: ___ y/o woman with PMHx CAD s/p CABG ___ - unknown anatomy), CKD, ___ Disease, HTN and HLD who presented from ___ ___ home w/ mildly elevated troponin. . # Atypical chronic chest pain: Pt has history of CAD w/ CABG in ___, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. She reports chronic intermittent chest pressure, but her symptoms seem unchanged from prior. Her daughter states that she believes that her symptoms are very much related to stress. She states that she has had chest pain like this for months. Pt was referred to ___ because of mild troponin elevation at her SNF. EKG showed lateral lead T wave flattening but no other evidence of ischemia. Her troponins and CK-Mb were checked three times in the hospital; her trop was stable at 0.02-0.03 ___KMb. It was thought that this was due to her kidney injury and hypertension. . # Hypertensive Urgency: Per outside records her hypertension was difficult to control. She was ordered for Valsartan with a PRN order for nitro paste for sbps above 180 at her SNF prior to admission. Her daughter confirmed that her blood pressure was very labile and would often be sbp >190. She had a maximum BP 210/110, but she was anxious because her daughter had left her in the hospital earlier in the day. She was given two doses of hydralazine 10mg and her blood pressure became normotensive. She was asymptomatic with no headaches or vision changes. Please consider starting and uptirating Imdur for improved blood pressure control. . # CKD: She presented with a creatinine of 1.3 with CKD w/ baseline Cr 1.0-1.2. She was dry on exam and very thirsty. She was encouraged to drink fluids and given IV fluids briefly. Her creatinine on d/c was 1.2. Her sodium and potassium improved. She was thought to have mild prerenal effect. . # Hyperkalemia: This was thought to be due to slight rise in creatinine. She

summary: Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ to the vascular service. He was started on iv fluids, preoped and consented for angiogram on ___. Renal transplant, podiatry and hepatology were consulted and managed his transplant medications while in house. He remained on his home medication regimen, although coumadin was held for pending angiogram. He was also started on vancomycin, cipro,flagyl. On ___ Mr ___ was taken to the endo suite and underwent: q. Ultrasound-guided puncture of the right common femoral artery. 2. Contralateral third-order catheterization of the left anterior tibial artery. 3. Serial arteriogram of the left lower extremity. 4. Balloon angioplasty of the left popliteal artery. 5. Balloon angioplasty of the left anterior tibial artery. 6. Stenting of the left popliteal artery. 7. Perclose closure of the right common femoral arteriotomy. He tolerated the procedure well and was transfered to the PACU for recovery. When stable he was transfered to the floor where he remained hemodynamically stable throughout his hospital course. The vancomycin was stopped and Mr ___ on cipro and flagyl. He was restarted on his home dose of coumadin, 7mg qhs. His L foot ulcer was debrided at the bedside and dressed by podiatry on ___. Mr. ___ was evaluated by ___ and found to be independent. On ___ he was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating w/o assistance and voiding without difficulty. Thus he was discharged to home with family assistance. Mr. ___ return to his home in ___ where his wife will assist him. He will be on cipro and flagyl for 2 weeks and will f/u with his podiatrist in ___ days. He is advised to f/u with Dr. ___ a duplex of his LLE and clinic visit in the next month or two, and he will call to schedule this on his next trip to ___. He will continue on coumadin, as he was taking prior to this admission and will follow up in ___ with his primary physician

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> intermittent vaginal bleeding, dysuria <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Examination under anesthesia, placement of fiducials into the vaginal cuff and around the vaginal tumor, and insertion of interstitial catheters for high-dose rate brachytherapy. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ female with a history of CIN3 status post total laparoscopic hysterectomy in ___. She started having intermittent vaginal bleeding, dysuria, urinary frequency and urgency earlier this year. CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast on ___, for flank pain showed nonspecific bilateral perinephric inflammation. She was diagnosed with pyelonephritis and admitted and treated with antibiotics. Followup CT of the abdomen and pelvis on ___, revealed decreased bilateral perinephric stranding. Her intermittent vaginal bleeding continued and she was seen by her primary care provider and eventually ___ urologist who noted a growth at the vaginal cuff on exam. Vaginal Pap on ___, showed HSIL, positive for high-risk HPV. Exam on ___, revealed a 3-4 cm firm, friable nodular mass at the vaginal cuff. Biopsies of the vagina and cuff showed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Pelvic MRI on ___, demonstrated a 2.9 x 4.7 x 3.8 cm soft tissue mass arising from the superior left vaginal cuff extending into the mid vagina. The mass abutted the sigmoid colon with loss of the normal fat plane, suspicious for disease extension. The mass also abutted the posterior bladder wall with loss of the fat plane and subtle T2 and hyperintense signal enhancement within the muscularis propria consistent with disease extension. The mass abutted the left levator ani muscle without definitive disease extension. She was referred to Dr. ___ of ___ Oncology on ___, and refused an exam at that appointment. However, based on imaging, an exenterative surgery would be required to completely resect her disease. Therefore, she was referred to Dr. ___ of ___ Oncology at ___ on ___, and underwent CT simulation that same day, with a plan to receive external beam radiation therapy to the pelvis to 45 Gy with concurrent chemotherapy. PET-CT on ___, revealed an avid 6 x 4.5 cm pelvic mass at the vaginal cuff contacting the left levator ani muscle and resulting in new mild left hydroureteronephrosis. There was a new avid peripheral airspace density in the right lower lobe, and no evidence of distant metastases or lymphadenopathy. When we saw her on ___, we discussed interstitial brachytherapy following completion of her external radiation. She now returns in follow-up. INTERVAL HISTORY: Since we saw Ms. ___, she received pelvic radiation to 45 Gy from ___ to ___ with concurrent weekly cisplatin. She was seen by urology and as her hydronephrosis was mild and kidney function was normal, no stent was needed for the left ureter. Her radiology was also reviewed at the tumor board at ___, and the right lower lobe lesion was not concerning for metastasis, and therefore there was no need for a biopsy. She had an MRI earlier today at ___, results are pending. Physically, she is experiencing 10 loose stools/diarrhea per day over the last 2 days, and has stopped her stool softener and miralax as of 4 days ago. She has severe urinary urgency and frequency, for which she is on some type of medication. She needs to urinate every ___ hours during the day, and due to her insomnia, she wakes up every ___ hours at night, and urinates each time as well, although states it is not urinary urgency that wakes her up. Her vaginal bleeding has completely stopped, and the rectal pressure and vaginal pain have completely resolved. She now only takes Tylenol prn for her headaches. She occasionally has nausea, and takes an antiemetic prn, approximately 1x/day. Her appetite is decreased, but she denies weight loss. She has severe fatigue and has been told that her blood counts are extremely low. She is slightly light-headed with rising, and has dyspnea with exertion. Her last chemotherapy was ___. She denies any pelvic or abdominal pain, constipation, rectal bleeding, dysuria, hematuria, urinary hesitancy, or lower extremity edema. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: As per history of present illness. The patient also denies any fevers, chills, blurry vision, double vision, hearing changes, chest pain, palpitations, cough, shortness of breath at rest, focal muscle weakness or paresthesias, recent falls. She has ongoing issues with anxiety, depression, and insomnia, all of which are currently managed well. All other systems are negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST MEDICAL AND SURGICAL HISTORY: 1. OCD. 2. Anxiety/depression. 3. Hypercholesterolemia. 4. Pituitary adenoma, status post excision in ___. 5. CIN3 of the cervix, status post TLH on ___, at ___ by Dr. ___. 6. GERD. 7. Chronic back pain. 8. Multiple incarcerated abdominal hernias, status post repair. 9. Cold knife cones in the past. 10. Arm fracture status post ORIF of the left
summary: Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecologic oncology service for vaginal brachytherapy. She underwent placement of an interstitial implant on ___. Please see operative report for full details. She received treatments from ___ until ___ for a total of 6 sessions. She was maintained on bedrest, a clear diet, and loperamide throughout this time. Her pain was controlled with a dilaudid PCA and oral acetaminophen. She was seen by Social Work during her admission. After removal of the implant on hospital day 4, her diet was advanced without difficulty. Her Foley catheter was removed and she voided spontaneously. She was transitioned to oral acetaminophen for her pain. By hospital day 4, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and she was no longer requiring pain medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

summary: ___ year old man with history of hiatal hernia and severe GERD s/p Nissen fundoplication in ___, ___ gastroparesis s/p gastric stimulator placement in ___, and anxiety, who presents with acute on chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea. This was his third presentation in the last 3 days (he had gone to urgent care the 2 days previous), and thus he was admitted. His symptoms were somewhat consistent with his chronic gastroparesis pain, but described as more constant, sharper, and overall worse. The diarrhea was described as normal appearing loose stool, 3 times per day. He had no fever or chills or urinary symptoms. He underwent CT of the Abdomen which was unremarkable. His diarrhea had apparently resolved by the time of admission, so he was unable to provide a stool sample to look for C-Diff or other infectious process. He was treated with IV fluid hydration, x2 doses of IV Ketorolac (one in ED, one on the floor), and x1 dose of 2mg IV Morphine. With that, he felt much better and asked to go home. He ate his entire lunch on the day of discharge, which included ___ fries. The team (resident, attending, and RN) all separately discussed with the patient the importance of strong outpatient follow up his gastroparesis, and the importance of avoiding chronic narcotics for pain control. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ============================ - No changes to his chronic medications were made - Continue multidisciplinary follow-up with PCP and GI regarding his gastroparesis and chronic abdominal symptoms. He is scheduled for PCP and GI within the next 2 weeks. He is scheduled for an EGD in 10 days.

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> L hip pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Left hip aspiration <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o F with HCV c/b cirrhosis and HCC s/p liver transplant in ___, s/p L hip arthroplasty in ___ p/w L hip pain of 1 day duration. . Pt states that she woke up yesterday morning around 5am to use the restroom and experienced pain in her L hip. She decribes the pain as a sharp, muscle pain that radiated down the left leg. She states that the pain was bed enough that she was not able to get out of bed. The pain was worsened with movement and relieved with rest. She stayed in bed all day under her daughter returned home at which time she called EMS and came to the ED. She denies previous episodes of pain, trauma or falls, rash, numbness or tingling, back pain, dysuria, abdominal or liver pain, nausea/vomiting, fevers. . In the ED, she was given morphine and zofran. Ultrasound was negative for DVT and left hip x-rays were also WNL. Of note, on arrival to the floor, the patient was noted to have coffee ground emesis with specks of bright red blood (approx. 100cc). She statted that she had had a nosebleed in the ED and had also had an episodes of emesis in the ED. . She underwent a CT guided aspiration of her left hip today. Minimal fluid was obtained, and gram stain/culture are currently pending. . Upon arrival to the floor the patient was stable with vitals listed below. She notes the above history with decreased leg pain secondary to getting pain killers. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - HCV c/b cirrhosis and HCCA s/p OLTx ___ - recurrence of HCV tc with infergen then IFN alpha-2a and ribavirin - coronary artery disease - hypertension - hyperparathyroidism - osteoporosis - renal stones s/p lithotripsy - peripheral neuropathy - spinal stenosis - left radius fracture s/p ORIF - right foot drop <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Denied any family history of liver or other GI problems. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: Tm 100.0 Tc 98.3 BP 127/55 HR 67 RR 20 SaO2 100%RA UOP 650 General: elderly women, non-jaundiced, NAD HEENT: PERRLA, nonicteric, EOMI, OP clear without lesions or erythema, no visible evidence of blood in nares or oropharynx Neck: without LAD, no JVD Pulm: CTAB without wheezes or crackles CV: regular rhythm, normal rate, II/VI holosystolic murmur heard best at LLSB Abd: Soft, nontender, nondistended, BS, well healed scar, no HSM appreciated Extrem: Left leg pain with palpation of anterior hip, no pain on lateral hip, pain with movement especially external rotation. ROM limited by pain. No erythema or edema noted. Right leg normal range of motion without erythema or edema Neuro: AOx3, no focal abnormalities, no asterixis <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 05: 40PM SED RATE-65* ___ 05: 40PM ___ ___ 05: 40PM WBC-1.3*# RBC-2.91* HGB-8.2* HCT-25.5* MCV-88 MCH-28.1 MCHC-32.0 RDW-17.2* ___ 05: 40PM NEUTS-56 BANDS-2 ___ MONOS-6 EOS-0 BASOS-0 ___ MYELOS-0 ___ 05: 40PM ALT(SGPT)-128* AST(SGOT)-147* ALK PHOS-229* TOT BILI-0.4 ___ 05: 40PM CALCIUM-9.3 PHOSPHATE-2.5* MAGNESIUM-2.0 ___ 05: 40PM GLUCOSE-153* UREA N-16 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-106 TOTAL CO2-22 ANION GAP-16 . ___ Hip Xray: FINDINGS: Stable relative to the prior examination, there is an indwelling left total hip arthroplasty. The acetabular cup is secured by a single oblique screw. There is a similar rim of lucency noted medially with no evidence of periprosthetic fracture or loosening. The alignment of the acetabular cup is stable. The femoral prosthesis is well seated with no periprosthetic loosening identified. There is no periprosthetic fracture. No dislocation is evident. The pelvis is intact. Mild degenerative disease is seen in bilateral sacroiliac joints and in the included lower lumbar spine. The sacrum is intact. The proximal right femur is grossly unremarkable. Extensive vascular calcifications are incidentally noted. IMPRESSION: Stable x-ray examination with no fracture identified. There is a total hip arthroplasty in stable position with no radiographic evidence of loosening or other complication. Please note, not mentioned above, incidental note is made of chondrocalcinosis at the pubic symphysis consistent with calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease. . <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> 1. Valganciclovir 450 mg Tablet daily 2. Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole 80-400 mg Tablet daily 3. Fluconazole 200 mg Tablet daily 4. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet daily 5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule BID 6. Amlodipine 5
summary: #. L hip pain: The patient presented with left hip pain. Due to immunosuppression and recent neutropenia it was worrisome for infectious etiology despite no fevers, erythema, edema, warmth or other signs of infection. X-rays were taken which were negative for fracture. A fluoroscopic guided aspiration of the L hip was done. Gram stain and culture were negative. The patients pain largely resolved and the patient needed minimal pain medications for pain control. ___ also saw the patient and cleared her for home. She was discharged with an appointment for outpatient orthopedics to further evaluate her left hip. . #. HCV s/p OLT: The patient is being maintained on immunosuppression with sirolimus. Her rapamycin level was found to be elevated so her sirolimus was decreased to 1mg PO daily. She was continued on her treatment of peg-interferon and ribavirin. Her valgancyclovir, bactrim and fluconazole prophylaxis were continued. Her LFTs remained stable throughout her hospitalization. . #. Pancytopenia: Likely secondary to her interferon and ribavirin. She was continued on her outpatient epo and neupogen regimen. She was transfused 1u pRBCs. . #. GI bleed: The patient had one episode of hematemesis in the emergency department. It was likely related to a nose bleed with swallowed blood. She was hemodynamically stable, without evidence of bleeding with a stable hct. . #. Delirium: The patient sun downed having delusions and auditory hallucinations. She was re-oriented often. She was scheduled with a psychiatrist as an outpatient. . #. Depression: The patient was maintained on her citalopram. . #. Code status: The patient was made DNR/DNI after a discussion with the patient and her family. This will need to be readdressed the next time she presents due to her recently receiving a liver transplant.

Course complicated by acute hypoxic respiratory failure, found to have acute on chronic CHF exacerbation s/p diuresis, as well as multifocal PNA s/p antibiotics. After seizure patient was sitting down and began to feel sharp retro-sternal chest pain that was non-radiating. It is associated with N/V/SOB. It has been ___, constant, and improves to ___ with diazepam. She has never had this chest pain before. Last admission was ___ to MICU, here for 2 weeks in ___ of this year for EtOH withdrawal, was on phenobarb protocol. She is socially complicated, with a reportedly abusive domestic partner of whom she is very afraid, and has a ___ year old child who she reports is with her mother and is currently safe. Pt states that her abusive boyfriend has been in jail for ___ years for assaulting her and that he has not tried to contact her. Pt sts he has been abusing her for years. Patient has a ___ year old son who lives with her mother, pt sts he is safe. Pt denies SI/HI at this time. In the ED, initial vitals: 97.6 ___ 16 99% RA Patient refused imaging. No EKG done. Serum tox negative, utox positive for benzos and opiates but negative for cocaine. Was on ___ protocol Q2h in ED with diazepam ___ for CIWA > 8. Patient has received 75mg diazepam within 24 hours after admission and was switched to phenobarb protocol 600mg IV with scheduled taper. Psych and social work was consulted as patient has several prior admissions for same issue. On the floor we continued her phenobarbital taper and also continued her on methadone 30mg qd, prazosin 7mg QHS, hydroxyzine ___ Q4H PRN, and dicyclomine. She was accepted by a substance abuse program called Women's ___ and will receive methadone at ___ ___ (___). # Chest pain: Etiology was unclear, however the patient has a low likelihood of having a cardiac etiology. Her troponins and cardiac biomarkers were negative and her EKG was unchanged from prior. Her chest pain was not associated with increasing activity and was likely secondary to withdrawal. It resolved at the time of discharge. # Syncope: Likely secondary to a withdrawal seizure as the patient bit her cheek and tongue at the time. Patient denies hitting her head but had LOC. Head CT without contrast did not show any acute intracranial process. # Anxiety/Depression: Patient denies HI/SI. Psych was consulted and recommended increasing her home venlafaxine to 75 mg PO daily. # History of Seizures: Continued on home keppra, which was determined to be ok to give while on phenobarb protocol as per pharmacy. She will follow up with outpatient neurology to be reevaluated for the need for keppra long term. # Anemia: Her iron was low at 21, and

summary: Patient is a ___ with history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus on insulin, HTN, dyslipidemia, insomnia, EtOH use disorder, gout, restless leg syndrome, insomnia, and depression who presented with persistent abdominal pain after a recent EGD/colonoscopy ___, found to have acute kidney injury. ACUTE ISSUES: ============= # Acute kidney injury - After calling patient's PCP's office, it seems that patient's Cr was .___, no documented history of renal disease. Cr improved 2.8->1.9 since initial presentation after receiving IVF, suggesting renal hypoperfusion. Patient may have decreased PO intake iso acute GI symptoms and he continued to take all his BP meds including ___. No signs of obstruction or evidence of hydronephrosis on CT A/P. Given underlying anemia without signs of GI losses, also consider multiple myeloma, SPEP/UPEP sent for f/u with PCP. Patient remained HD stable without any signs of volume overload. Cr improved to 1.1 with a second liter of intravenous fluids. Patient was encouraged to eat/drink, he was tolerating a diet well. Home losartan/chlorthalidone were initially held, restarted at time of discharge given significant hypertension. # Abdominal pain - Acute onset pain after EGD/colonoscopy ___, though patient has recently been worked up as an outpatient for epigastric pain. Crampy pain after insufflation during colonoscopy was possible as was postpolypectomy syndrome (patient had multiple polypectomies). No chronic source of pain on recent EGD/colonoscopy or CT A/P performed in ED. Hb remained at recent baseline, no concern for ___ bleeding. LFTs were not consistent with hepatobiliary obstruction and lipase is wnl. Of note, patient has significant constipation at baseline and required laxatives during admission. Patient was administered IV morphine for pain control while in the ED. Given APAP/tramadol and a dose of intravenous hydromorphone on the floor in addition to supportive treatments with Maalox and simethicone. Constipation was managed with MoM and senna/

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> PSYCHIATRY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> I can't be here <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Briefly, Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with no clear psychiatric history, medical history of gastric cancer and lymphoma (per her fianc) and endometriosis and cholecystitis each requiring surgical intervention who came to the ___ after vomiting following drinking 2 bottles of cough syrup. On arrival to the unit the patient is fearful, tearful, and very anxious. She was unable to be engaged in meaningful conversation regarding her care or admission as she vehemently disagreed with hospitalization. She repeatedly stated I have a job You can't keep me here Who's going to pay for this breathing rapidly and sobbing. She perseverates on her fianc, ___, questioning why he left her at the hospital, seemingly fearful that he had abandoned her. Her mother, who accompanied her from the ___ given concern for patient's potential to escalate in transfer, was instrumental in calming her. Having received Ativan in the ___ she was offered Ativan 1 mg PO which she accepted reluctantly but with good effect. She was allowed to sleep in the quiet room given her inability to maintain her composure. Unable to receive further history at this time. After her departure from the unit the patient's mother remarked I don't know who that is- that's not ___. She agrees with her daughter's admission given her inability to manage her stresses outside. The patient's mother had previously stated that she ha[d] always worried about ___ adding, if you had a room full of people, and something bad was going to happen to one of them, it would be ___. She likewise describes ___ as some who lives under a black cloud. She says that ___ has never been even, describing her oscillation between highs and lows. Per Dr. ___ in the ___: The patient reports she was in the car going to an appointment when she started vomiting. She reports she has been very stressed and anxious lately due to financial problems, starting a new job which she fears losing, trying to plan a wedding and having four miscarriages. She states she drank the cough syrup to get high in order to briefly escape her stressors. She reports she does have a therapist, but isn't able to see him regularly and isn't scheduled to see him again until ___ which is also distressing as she was finding him helpful. She did not mention any medical problems aside from endometriosis and having her gall bladder removed, however, her fianc when interviewed said that she was diagnosed with lymphoma a month ago and had stage 3 gastric cancer ___ years ago which she underwent chemo and surgery for. He reported they were on the way to get treatment at ___ when she started to vomit in the car. He reports she got the diagnosis a month ago but keeps getting sick so has not been able to get treatment yet. The patient denied to the ___ that she had lymphoma and did not endorse it to this interviewer. Her mother also did not seem to know about any cancer diagnosis. On ROS, patient endorsed poor sleep, depressed mood, normal appetite, anhedonia and denies SI. Denies HI and AVH. Denies manic symptoms. Patient endorsed a history of bulimia which she asked for her mother not to be told about. She said she typically vomits ___ times a day on the weekend. Reports she is seeing someone at ___ for this. Collateral from ___, ___ is on edge all the time. Stress and anxiety level are to the top. Not the same person that she was. Medical issues which lead to a lot of medical bills. Had a few operations in ___ for endometriosis and gall bladder surgery but no insurance so huge bills. Always worried about ___, she is a full time plus job. Didn't hear from her today which is strange when she texted her today. ___ was very surprised she took the cough syrup though said that many years ago she did take extra cough syrup. Always on edge and always has a problem. Very emotional and very insecure. Never has made statements about not wanting to be alive. Has encouraged patient to seek psychiatric help but only recently has patient started seeing a therapist. Often is secretive and hides a lot of things. Has not taken medications for mood but did take meds for ADD which was helpful. Was offered antidepressant from outpatient therapist but didn't want. ___ said patient is afraid of loosing ___ which is why she wouldn
summary: HOSPITAL COURSE SECTION OF DISCHARGE SUMMARY 1. LEGAL  SAFETY: On admission, Ms. ___ refused to sign a conditional voluntary agreement and was admitted on a Section 12b. She was also placed on 15 minute checks status on admission and remained on that level of observation throughout while being unit restricted. 2. PSYCHIATRIC: #) Unspecified Mood Disorder When Ms. ___ arrived to the unit, she was labile and irritable, anxious, argumentative, and unable to engage in discussions surrounding her care. She staunchly opposed hospitalization, denying that she had attempted suicide via overdose. She eventually calmed with Ativan 1 mg PO and retired to the quiet room for the evening. She arose in the morning equally labile and was given an additional Ativan 1 mg PO with good effect. Upon meeting with the treatment team, Ms. ___ was able to engage in interview (although became tearful at several points) and stated that she has felt very overwhelmed lately; when she drank the bottle of cough syrup she did not do so with suicidal intent, but rather to momentarily escape the stress of her life. She underscored several times that she has never done anything to harm herself and has never been psychiatrically hospitalized before. She identified finances as a primary stressor in her life; she stated she owed her fianc 6500 but could not afford to pay him back. Their relationship is good apart from financial stress. She recently got a new job, another source of stress, and cites that overall she feels that while she is an adult she does not feel like she has her life on track. Furthermore, she later clarified that she does not in fact have gastric cancer or lymphoma and it remains unclear her motives for stating as such - patient stated that she was talking with her friend

summary: Mr. ___ was a same day admit after undergoing all preoperative work-up following his cardiac cath in early ___. On ___ he was brought to the Operating Room where he underwent coronary artery bypass grafts x 4. Please see operative note for surgical details. Of note, during intubation he had ischemic changes on the EKG and became hypotensive. He was given Neo Synephrine while the central line was being placed and his blood pressure came up. The Neo Synephrine effect was short lived, he became hypotensive again and chest compressions had to be instituted. He was quickly draped, incision made, open cardiac massage started and immediately placed on cardiopulmonary bypass. Following the surgery he was transferred to the ___ for invasive monitoring in stable condition. He remained stable, weaned from the ventilator after several attempts and with the aid of Precedex. The Neo Synephrine weaned off and he remained stable and intact. CTs were removed on POD 1 and low dose beta blockade started. He was diuresed towards his preoperative weight. Physical Therapy was consulted for strength and mobility. Pacing wires were removed per protocol. Arrangements were made for follow up. He continued to make steady progress and was discharged to home with his family and ___ on ___.

summary: ___ yo Male with cognitive impairment who p/w parasymphyseal and subcondylar fractures of the right mandible, mildly depressed blow-out fracture of right orbital floor. Patient to go to OR on ___, felt unreliable to go home and return for procedure given cognitive impairements and psychosocial situation. . # Parasymphyseal and subcondylar fractures, blow-out right orbital floor fracture: Patient went to the operating room on ___ without issues. He did not require blood transfusions and his INR was normal. His pain was initially controlled with percocet 1 tablet every 4 hours but became constipated, requiring a rigorous bowel regimen. He was transitioned to tylenol and sparing oxycodone. Post-operatively, patient did not require much pain medication. He was discharged on tylenol liquid only, given family member with known substance abuse history and history of taking patient's SSI checks. Pre-operatively, patient was maintained on head of bed elevation to 45 degrees and sinus precautions: * Avoid blowing nose, sucking on straws, smoking, rinsing mouth vigorously * Hold mouth open when sneezing. Patient used Chlorhexidine oral swish/spit BID for dental hygeine and Clindamycin 300mg q6 hours X 5 days prior to surgery. He was also maintained on a soft diet (did not tolerate pureed diet). Post-operatively, patient was maintained on sinus precautions, HOB elevation, clindamycin, chlorhexidine oral wash. Given that his jaws were wired shut, patient was maintained on liquid diet (milkshakes okay) and liquid medications. He also had wire cutters at his bedside at all times. Of note, plastic surgery also noted a number of loose teeth and so Dental was consulted. After review of patient's panorex, they recommended that a number of his teeth be extracted.

[] Per records, was ordered for first dose of hepatitis A vaccine ___. Please clarify if this was administered, and complete vaccine series [] Small cystic lesions in pancreas noted on MRI ___. Should be followed up with subsequent imaging (can be same follow up as MRIs for ___). Discharge MELD: 17 Discharge Weight: 219.6 lbs Discharge Cr: 0.9 Discharge Tbili: 2.8 Discharge INR: 1.6 ACUTE ISSUES: ============= #Fever of unknown origin #Right pleural effusion Patient was recently admitted in ___, found to have enterococcus bacteremia and completed daptomycin treatment ___. He presented from outside hospital with ongoing fevers. Patient not treated with antibiotics at OSH despite ongoing fevers. Patient on arrival only had low-grade temperature with T-max of 99. His lack of leukocytosis was reassuring against infection. Full infectious work-up was done which was all negative. Patient had no ascites on imaging and bedside ultrasound. His recent bacteremia with new pleural effusion was concerning. Interventional pulmonology was consulted who felt that the pleural effusion was too small to safely be tapped. And given the ultrasound appearance, it was unlikely to be the focus of infection. Patient remained afebrile and hemodynamically stable throughout the admission. Patient's pleural effusion was ultimately felt to be due to hepatic hydrothorax. #ETOH/HCV Cirrhosis (MELD 19, CP C), decompensated #Hepatic encephalopathy #HCC #Listed for Transplant Initial presentation with confusion was likely due to hepatic encephalopathy likely from not taking his medications complicated by a higher predisposition to worsening encephalopathy given recent

summary: On ___ Mr. ___ underwent an emergent replacement of ascending aorta and hemiarch with resuspension of the aortic valve performed by Dr. ___. Please see the operative note for details. He tolerated the procedure well and was transferred in critical but stable condition to the surgical intensive care unit. The renal service was consulted to manage his dialysis needs. On postoperative day one, he awoke neurologically intact and was extubated. CVVHD was initiated for volume management. He was dialyzed via an IJ catheter to remove excess fluid and improve respiratory status. His blood pressure medications were uptitrated. He was placed on antibiotics for sternal erythema. He was transferred to the step down floor. A tunneled line dialysis line was placed. Transplant surgery was consulted and a plan was made to remove the PD catheter and create a left AV fistula as an outpatient. On post-operative day ten was dialyzed and then sent to ___ in ___. All follow-up appointments were advised.

summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male who presented with RUQ abdominal pain, jaundice and low grade fever and was admitted for cholangitis. ACTIVE ISSUES ------------- # Cholangitis/cholecystitis: Patient presented with signs/symptoms concerning for cholangitis (fevers, jaundice, RUQ pain, leukocytosis). RUQ ultrasound revealed a gallstone at the gallbladder neck in addition to gallbladder wall thickening. He was started on IV ciprofloxacin/metronidazole in the ED and was admitted for further management. He underwent an uncomplicated ERCP on ___ with stent placement. He received aggressive post-ERCP IV fluids. General surgery was consulted for cholecystectomy and the decision was made to pursue procedure as an outpatient. LFTs continued to downtrend throughout his admission and at discharge were AST 31 ALT 82 ALP 123 Total bilirubin 2.2. Patient tolerated a clear diet and was advanced to a regular diet prior to discharge. He will follow up with general surgery in two weeks for cholecystectomy evaluation. He will complete a two week course of ciprofloxacin and metronidazole (end date: ___ and will need to undergo a repeat ERCP for stent removal, to be scheduled by Gastroenterology. # Microscopic hematuria: Admission urinalysis revealed an incidental finding of 12 RBCs. Repeat UA the day of discharge was significant for 3 RBCs. Would recommend repeat UA as an outpatient and further work-up for microscopic hematuria. # Hypophosphatemia: Admission labs revealed a low phosphate at 1.3 of unclear etiology but possibly due to malnutrition surrounding acute illness. He received phosphate repletion during admission with discharge phos of 2.1. Recommend repeating electrolytes as outpatient. # Indirect bilirubinemia: Fractionation of the bilirubin illustrated an indirect bilirubinemia which was unusual in the setting of cholecystitis/cholangitis (Total 3.7, Direct 0.7). Hematocrit and haptoglobin were wnl. Bilirubin appropriately declined following ERCP to a total bili of 2.2 at discharge. Recommend repeating labs as outpatient. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - will need repeat ERCP for stent removal - general surgery evaluation for cholecystectomy scheduled

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Division of Otolaryngology  Head and Neck Surgery Post-Operative Instructions Free Tissue Transplant ACTIVITY -Go home and rest today. -You need to avoid strenuous activity for 2 weeks -Do NOT lift any weight greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. -Make sure you exercise your shoulders and arms gently to keep them from getting stiff -It is important for you to walk to improve any swelling in your legs. FLUIDS  DIET -Start with liquids and, if tolerated, you can eat normal foods. MEDICATIONS -Take pain medication as prescribed. -Resume other medications as prescribed except any aspirin or aspirin containing products unless cleared by your surgeon. CARE OF PROCEDURE SITE -Some swelling of the neck incision and graft donor site is expected. -You may note some bloody looking drainage from the region where the plastic drain was removed for up to 5 days. -Apply antibiotic ointment to your incisions twice a day for 7 days after surgery, then use Vaseline only. -Keep incision dry for 7 days from date of surgery. You may be able to take a bath from your shoulders down as long as the incision stays dry. -If there are any crusts/clots on your wound you may gently clean them with a Q-tip and Half strength hydrogen peroxide (10cc water  10cc peroxide) as needed. Do not be too vigorous or your stitches or staples may break -The staples/stitches will be removed on your first post-operative visit (usually in ___ days). -If a skin graft was taken from your thigh then there is a dressing over this that will fall off over the next few weeks. Just trim the edges as it separates from your skin. If it is itchy then apply a liberal coating of Vaseline twice a day over this site -If a graft was taken from your arm or leg then cover this site with Vaseline twice a day and apply a clean gauze dressing over it. WHEN TO CALL YOUR DOCTOR -Excessive redness of
summary: The patient was admitted to the Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Service after composite resection of floor of mouth, bilateral neck dissection, tracheotomy, and posterior leg (med sural artery) reconstruction buy plastic surgery. Please see the separately dictated operative note for details of procedure. There were no significant intraoperative complications. Post-operatively, patient underwent an ___ hospital course. ENT: The patient had a composite floor of mouth tumor resection with posterior leg free flap for reconstruction. Patient underwent 72 hours of Q1Hr flap checks in the ICU, his Doppler pulse remained robust throughout. Neck drains were sequentially discontinued once they met drain criteria. Patients trach was downsized to a Portex 6 cuffless on POD#5. Patient subsequently underwent a capping trial that the patient tolerated and was therefore decannulated. Neuro: Patient received parenteral and then enteral narcotics as needed for pain control via his NG tube. The patient was at baseline neurologic status. Patient is to continue his pain regimen and wean narcotics as tolerated. CV: Patient was on home medications throughout the hospital stay. Vitals were monitored while the patient was hospitalized. Patient's vitals were within normal limits on discharge. Pulm: Patient was breathing comfortably on RA at the time of discharge. GI: Patient was NPO postoperatively and received all medications and nutrition through NG tube. Patient had a swallow study postoperatively on *****. Patient was subsequently started on ***** diet. Pt tolerated PO intake well and NGT was therefore discontinued. Renal/GU: Patient was on IVF as needed with electrolytes repleted prn. Heme: Pt was on ___ and compression boots for DVT prophylaxis. Patient is to continue ASA 325mg QD for the free flap. ID: The patient was on perioperative antibiotics and remained afebrile otherwise. Endocrine: The patients blood glucose was checked and was well controlled throughout the hospital stay. Physical therapy: Patient was seen by physical

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> ___ <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Poor food intake, Dehydration, Confusion <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old female with metastatic cervical cancer and presumed pulmonary involvement most recently treated with XRT in ___ who is admitted to ED with dehydration, weakness, abdominal pain, and likely UTI. Pt's family stated she has had decreased PO intake over the past few days and day prior was more confused and weak (could barely get up on her own). Also has had dysuria and had been on 3 days of macrobid empirically for UTI (c/o dysuria). Pt had not had BM in several days. Reported intermittent abdominal pain but no diarrhea. Endorsed decreased appetite but no fevers or vomiting. Denies CP/SOB. In the ED T 97.5 HR 92 BP 153/91 92% RA. Labs suggested possible UTI on UA, chem unremarkable. Hct stable at 29. WBC 7 with 81% pmns. LFTs/lipase WNL. Abd CT showed no acute findings to explain pain but did show moderate right and small left pleural effusions, mild intra-abd ascites and anasarca. She got 2L IVF, 2mg IV morphine and 1g IV CTX. She was also noted to have urinary retention and was ultimately straight cathed for 250ccs out. Also, after getting the morphine she became confused combative and agitated. On the floor at the time of this interview she was calm, sleepy, oriented only to self, family was at the bedside stating she is much more calm and less agitated. She states she has mild abd pain but breathing feels well and endorses feeling sleepy. Endorses continued dysuria. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: Ms. ___ is an ___ female with a history of grade III DCIS of the left breast status post mastectomy on ___, who called her primary care provider's office with blood on the toilet paper on ___. She saw her primary care provider and ___ gynecologist on ___, and they noted that a speculum exam caused increased bleeding. Endometrial biopsy that day revealed clear cell adenocarcinoma. Transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound on ___, showed a 5.4 x 2.9 x 3 cm uterus with a 13 x 19 x 13 mm calcified anterior subserosal fibroid and an 10 x 11 mm cystic lesion in the posterior myometrium. The endometrium was difficult to evaluate, but in a few areas appeared heterogeneous with cystic spaces, measuring approximately 6 mm. CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis on ___, showed a calcification within the uterine fundus that was likely fibroid and a stable 6.2 cm right renal cyst. There was multilevel degenerative disease of the spine and stable left apical pleural thickening of the lung, but no lymphadenopathy or distant metastatic disease. The patient saw Dr. ___ in consultation on ___, who noted no abnormalities on pelvic examination. He performed a total laparoscopic hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy on ___, and noted some scar tissue at the vaginal apex involving the cervix, and inflammation of the bladder. Pathology showed a clear cell cervical adenocarcinoma involving the cervix circumferentially, with a depth of invasion of 7 mm. There was no lymphovascular invasion or parametrial involvement. However, the inferior cauterized cervical resection margin was positive. PET-CT on ___, showed uptake in the vesicorectal pouch at the site of the hysterectomy that was possibly postsurgical in nature, but no FDG-avid disease elsewhere. The patient decided to not pursue adjuvant treatment due to her age. On ___, she started having vaginal spotting again. She saw Dr. ___ in followup on ___, who noted scar tissue and bright red blood at the vaginal apex on physical exam. CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis on ___, showed a 1.1 cm hypodensity at the left vaginal cuff and no lymphadenopathy. There were multiple new or enlarging bilateral pulmonary nodules. It was discussed with her that this is likely metastatic disease and any further treatment was palliative. She is not interested in any chemotherapy. Due to persistent vaginal bleeding however she initiated radiation to the vagina and vaginal cuff mass. This was completed ___. OB/GYN HISTORY: G5 P5 with menopause at age ___. She took oral contraceptives for one year many years ago, but denies any history of hormone replacement therapy or sexually transmitted diseases. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Left breast grade III DCIS, status post mastectomy ___, by Dr. ___ at ___. 2. Essential thrombocytopenia, being followed by Dr. ___ ___. 3. Anemia. 4. Hypertension. 5. Hypercholesterolemia. 6. Hypothyroidism. 7. Spinal stenosis and chronic back pain. 8. Carpal tunnel surgeries. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of cancer. Mother died of TB. Father died of an MI. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission physical exam: VITAL SIGNS: T 96.8 BP 120/90 HR 102 RR 20 93% RA General: NAD, lethargic but arousable HEENT: MMM, no OP lesions, no cervical, supraclavicular, or axillary adenopathy, no thyromegaly CV: borderline tachycardic, NL S1S
summary: Patient passed away at 13:20 on ___, soon after admission, most likely due to a cardiac arrest. This is an ___ year old woman with a history of metastatic cervical cancer s/p recent admission with abdominal pain and liver failure who came in with dehydration, failure to thrive, weakness, and abd pain/UTI. # Cardiac arrest: team notified at 13:00 for a HR drop from ___ to ___. Patient examined and found to be in PEA arrest. Patient was DNR/DNI so limited amount of interventions could be done. Medical interventions attempted without success. # Abd pain - recent admission for liver failure but on this visit, were LFTs were within normal limits. On arrival to the floor abd was benign, and abd CT did not suggest any acute process either. There was concern for recent UTI and SBP given minor ascites seen and pateint was started on ceftriaxone. Patient had no abdominal complaints and later on during the day, passed away. # UTI - pt was being treated w/ macrobid at home empirically for UTI starting ___. She had urinary retention in ED and was straight cathed. Was treated with ceftriaxone in the ED and on floor. # Constipation - per family no BM in several days. Ccontinued home colace/senna # Altered mental status - occurred in setting of being administered morphine for abd pain in ED. Pt was very agitated on floor and pulling wires and lines. Calmed down with 2x 1mg doses of Haloperidol in the morning. # Moderate right and small left pleural effusions - likely malignant. Pt had borderline hypoxia with O2 sats 89-93% on RA. Declined wearing NC and respiratory status was comfortable. However was placed on 2L of oxygen during period of agitation in the morning. # Metastatic Cervical Cancer: Completed vaginal radiation in ___. Had presumed pulmonary metastases. Not biopsied, patient was not interested in chemotherapy. Pulmonary nodules at lung bases stable on CT. # Hypothyroidism: Was continued

text: <SEX> F <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> Oxycodone <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> back pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> L2 to L4 posterior spinal fusion  ICBG <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> As you know, she is a ___ female with history of breast carcinoma who presents today for evaluation of a large lytic lesion within the L3 vertebral body causing concern for potential spinal instability. The entire office assessment and plan has been dictated under a separate letter by the ___ nurse ___. In summary, however, ___ is a ___ female who presents with syndrome consistent with metastatic breast carcinoma. She was initially diagnosed in ___ with T2, N3, M0, double hormone receptor positive and HER-2/neu amplified infiltrating ductal carcinoma, according to ___ recording of her medical records. She has undergone wide excision with positive lymph nodes treated with chemotherapy and secondary total mastectomy in the past. Recently imaging shows progression of a previously identified L3 vertebral lesion, encompassing more than 50% of vertebral body, raising concern for increased likelihood of pathologic fracture and consideration of prophylactic management recognized by the evaluating radiologist. For that reason, she presents today for evaluation and consideration of surgical treatment. Today we reviewed the remainder of her history, physical exam, prior imaging studies, and new imaging studies. Her past medical history, surgical history, medications, allergies, social history, family history, and review of systems are included in the intake sheet as part of the medical record. I reviewed this with the patient for accuracy. Imaging: I reviewed the MRI of the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine as well as the radiologist's report, dictated by Dr. ___. This demonstrated a 3.7 x 3.3 cm vertebral body mass within the L3 vertebrae. This is compatible with metastatic focus. It also demonstrates mild left paravertebral soft tissue infiltration. There is also abnormal signal in the superior anterior corner of L4, concerning for metastatic disease as well. There are no cervical or thoracic metastases observed on the MRI study, however. There are multiple pulmonary metastases, denoting a known history of metastatic disease as well, better observed on the ___, CT of torso. I also reviewed the CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis performed on ___, I also reviewed the radiologist's report of that study dictated by Dr. ___ and Dr. ___. This demonstrated an increased size of lytic component of the L3 vertebral body lesion. Given that it encompasses over 50% of vertebral body cross section, the radiologist's recognize that likelihood of pathologic fracture has increased and consideration of prophylactic management be advised. Impression and Plan: ___ is a ___ female with a lytic lesion within the L3 vertebral body, progressive despite ongoing treatments, not causing risk for fracture. I discussed with her at length the alternatives, risks and benefits of both surgical and ongoing nonsurgical care in the setting of metastatic disease with pending instability. I explained to her that surgical treatment can be helpful, by providing fusion across the lesion, in preserving the stability of her spine, and also preserving her neurological function, which currently is excellent. We discussed the technical details of the operation as well as the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the operation. I did make an ink drawing for her today to help explain the technical details which would be a posterior instrumented spinal fusion. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1) right breast CA 2) s/p gastric bypass 3) hysterectomy 4) longstanding essential HTN 5) radiation induced cardiomyopathy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> mother with MI at ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> see HPI <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 05: 45PM SODIUM-137 POTASSIUM-5.1 CHLORIDE-105 ___ 11: 30AM GLUCOSE-189* UREA N-13 CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-138 POTASSIUM-6.2* CHLORIDE-108 TOTAL CO2-20* ANION GAP-16 ___ 11: 30AM estGFR-Using this ___ 11: 30AM PLT COUNT-414 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> lisinopril 40 mg Tablet 1 Tablet(s) by mouth ___ carvedilol (Prescribed by Other Provider; Dose adjustment - no new Rx) 25 mg Tablet 1 Tablet(s) by mouth twice a day lapatinib [Tykerb] 250 mg Tablet 5 Tablet(s) by mouth daily Take on an empty stomach. summary: Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure. Refer to the dictated operative note for further details. The surgery was without complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU in a stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for postoperative DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop pain was controlled with a PCA. Diet was advanced as tolerated. The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when tolerating PO diet. Foley was removed on POD#2. Physical therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate. Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. On the day of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet.

summary: Ms. ___ is a ___ Farsi-speaking female with a history of dementia, diabetes, hypertension and complete heart block, s/p PPM admitted with acute onset dyspnea and cough, with a clinical picture consistent with pulmonary edema in the setting of new heart failure with preserved EF. During her hospitalization, she transitioned to hospice care at her SNF and is DNR/DNI/DNH. ACUTE ISSUES ============ # Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure # Acute heart failure with preserved EF # Severe Secondary MR ___ presented with a new O2 requirement with evidence of volume overload. No prior history of CHF. She had worsening dyspnea, cough, and orthopnea, with an elevated BNP, consistent with a new heart failure exacerbation. CXR was consistent with pulmonary edema and acute cardiac decompensation. Etiology of her CHF exacerbation was most likely secondary to moderate-severe mitral regurgitation as seen on TTE. Additional work up was deferred due to her goals of care (see below). She was given diuresis with IV furosemide with significant improvement in her respiratory status and transitioned to oral torsemide prior to discharge. She was also given captopril for afterload reduction, which was converted to Lisinopril prior to discharge. Her cardiopulmonary symptoms resolved by discharge. # Goals of Care: The ___ had been DNR/DNI/DNH at the end of last hospitalization. However, when she began developing worsening dyspnea, her daughter was concerned that she was suffering , and the decision was made to bring her to the hospital. Here, the daughter confirmed that the ___ will remain DNR/DNI/DNH/No ICU/No BiPAP going forward. Palliative care was consulted and agreed with plan for symptomatic focused care as above. Disposition plans were made for home (at her assisted living facility) with Season's hospice. CHRONIC / RESOLVED ISSUES =============== # Cough ___ had a non-productive cough without fevers for >1 month. CXR without clear evidence of pneumonia. Influenza A/B PCR negative

summary: The patient is a ___ man with a complicated medical history that includes ERSD with cadaveric renal transplant, coronary artery disease with multiple interventions, sCHF with ejection fraction of 20%, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gout, spinal stenosis, atrial fibrillation who recently underwent amputation of his second right toe, fifth right ray and debridement of right heel who is presenting with hypotension. The patient's hypotension is of unclear etiology, but was supected to be secondary to sepsis. He had not been febrile or had a white count. He has a recent intervention to his right foot that may be a possible site of infection, although his wounds currently do not have obvious visual evidence of infection. His urinalysis has small leuks and few bacteria (but no pyuria). CXR and CT abdomen not suggestive of specific He has been on longstanding prednisone. SVO2 not suggestive of cardiogenic shock. Due to a CVP of around 30, no additional fluids were provided. The patient was started on broad-spectrum coverage with vancomycin, levofloxacin, and aztreonam. (The patient once had an anaphylactic reaction to penicillins.) He was also placed on stress-dose steroids. Vascular Surgery was consulted, but intervention would likely have been a below-the-knee amputation. On ___ in the early afternoon, the patient's pressor requirement suddenly increased. He then developed a wide complex bradyarrhythmia with poor perfusion and mottling of his appendages. In keeping with his wishes against aggressive resuscitation, the patient's family was informed of his grave prognosis. No additional pressor was added, and the patient expired in the early afternoon of ___, likely secondary to a cardiac event caused by the strain of his likely sepsis.

summary: Mr. ___ was an ___ man with multiple medical problems who presented with hypoxia, increased work of breathing and cough. CXR reviewed likely pneumonia. He was treated with levofloxacin and metronidazole, the latter of which was for concern of aspiration pneumonia. His clinical status quickly improved on antibiotics with adequate oxygen saturation on room air. He was discharged to finish a 7-day course of oral levofloxacin and metronidazole. He was also seen by the wound care team and was discharged with skin care instructions.

summary: The patient was brought to the Operating Room on ___ where the patient underwent redo sternotomy, removal ___ with Dr. ___. Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. POD 1 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and breathing comfortably. The patient was neurologically intact and hemodynamically stable. Beta blocker was initiated and the patient was gently diuresed toward the preoperative weight. She will be anti-coagulated with Warfarin for AFib. AICD was interrogated. She developed leukocytosis post-operatively. She remained afebrile. Urine culture was negative and WBC normalized prior to discharge. The patient was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without complication. The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 5 the patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. The patient was discharged home in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

text: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Allopurinol / lisinopril <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Right sided rib pain after a fall <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year old male with history of DMII, ESRD on HD, Barretts esophagus, prior CVA, PMR, gout, HFrEF (LVEF 40-45%) s/p Bi-V ICD placement, GCA, and HTN presents 2 days after a fall at home complaining of continuing right-sided rib pain. Patient reports 2 days ago he tripped over a stool in his kitchen and fell against a wall. Denies head strike or loss of consciousness. Since then has had pain on the right side of his chest wall. Denies dyspnea or chest pain except for in setting of pain from rib fx, and R chest pain does not increase on exertion or improve at rest. Denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, lightheadedness, headaches, numbness or paresthesias. He has been experiencing orthopnea but no PND. He normally ambulates with a cane. Reports that he saw his primary care doctor the day of the fall, who ordered x-rays. Patient reports he has been using Tylenol at home without relief. Rib series plain films done yesterday show a new small right-sided pleural effusion, no displaced rib fractures, however pacemaker limited evaluation of portions of the right chest wall. In the ED, CT chest shows mildly displaced right seventh and eighth rib fractures and bilateral pleural effusions right greater than left. Patient noted to be hyperkalemic. Received 10 units IV insulin and half amp of glucose (given his hyperglycemia). The ED consulted hemodialysis, who noted that the patient has missed multiple dialysis sessions recently. He received HD in the ED, and per renal note his outpatient HD unit stated he frequently gives excuses for not attending dialysis. Of note, patient had very similar admission in ___ where he presented s/p mechanical fall w failure to thrive and hyperglycemia. He did not qualify for rehab, despite concerns about his ability to managed medications and care for himself at home. He was discharged w ___ and home ___. Additionally, he presented to the ED on ___ after a visit to ___'s office where he had asymptomatic hypotension to ___. He was treated for hyperglycemia and then discharged as he had no infectious, cardiac, or pulmonary symptoms. In the ED, initial vitals: T 98.6 HR 105 BP 178/82 RR 18 98% RA - Exam notable for: On exam, patient is awake and alert, in no acute distress. He has tenderness to palpation of the right lateral/posterior chest wall. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdomen is soft, with tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. Radial pulses 2 and symmetric. - Labs notable for: -- 132/96/68 -----------< 370 AG=19 6.1/___/8.1 -- Ca 8.6 Mg 2.3 Phos 8.4 -- Trop 0.33, BNP > 70,000, CK 613, MB 17, MBI 2.8 -- UA w sm blood, >600 protein, 1000 glucose, trace ketones -- WBC 11.6 -- VBG 7.27/50/___, K 4.9 - Imaging notable for: -- NCCTH: No acute intracranial hemorrhage, infarct or edema. No acute fracture. -- CT C-SPINE: 1. No acute fracture or change in alignment. 2. Moderate degenerative changes unchanged from prior CT C-spine dated ___. -- CT TORSO: Bilateral pleural effusions right greater than left with associated compressive atelectasis. Small pericardial effusion. Multiple well-circumscribed hypodense lesion in bilateral kidneys, some are indeterminate with densities of greater than 25 Hounsfield units while other hypodense lesions are simple renal cysts. Follow-up non-urgent ultrasound is recommended to further characterize the renal findings. There are mildly displaced fractures of right posterior ribs 7 and 8. - Consults: -- Renal-Dialysis: ESRD HD TTS. Last HD was about a week ago since he did not feel well. He had a fall 3 days ago, states he was dizzy. He was brought to ED today. Work-up is ongoing. No ICH bleeding from CT. AAOx3. Clear lungs. Edema 1 both legs. LUE AVG  bruit and thrills. K is 6.2 Will need HD today. Please request bed as OBS or ADMIT ASAP. We will bring him to HD unit for HD. Natanong ___ - Pt given: ___ 10: 45 IV Morphine Sulfate 4 mg ___ 13: 02 IV Insulin (Regular) for Hyperkalemia 10 units ___ 13: 02 IV Dextrose 50% 12.5 gm - Vitals prior to transfer: not recorded Upon arrival to the floor, the patient reports the above history. States he is has been in pain for the past three days, which has been limiting his ability to carry out ADLs. Has not taken any of his home meds for about 3 days. Has skipped dialysis because of this. Normally gets to dialysis thru volunteer sen
summary: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with extensive PMH including IDDM w ESRD on HD TTSa, HFrEF s/p BiV ICD, CVA, GCA and PMR, HTN, and several recent falls who presented to ED three days after a fall, found to have rib fractures and volume overload in setting of missing several days of HD. Volume status improved with HD. ACUTE ISSUES ============ # Right posterior rib fractures # Recurrent falls The patient has had a history of recurrent falls that appear mechanical in nature. He has not been seeking care in the outpatient setting, reliably attending HD, or taking medications. Social work, physical therapy and occupational therapy were consulted who recommended that the patient be discharged to a facility for further rehabilitation. The patient's pain from his fall was treated with APAP and oxycodone as needed. # Altered mental status Throughout admission, he had episodes of altered mental status, felt to be multifactorial related to medication effect, delirium, electrolyte and blood sugar derangements. He also endorsed intermittent visual hallucinations that appears to be chronic (generally occurring during hospitalization, likely related to delirium). Trazodone was discontinued. Hypoglycemia was treated as below. There was low suspicion for acute neurologic process as his neuro exam remained consistently nonfocal throughout. He will follow up with cognitive neurology as an outpatient. # Volume overload # BNP>70K # Electrolyte abnormalities # ESRD on HD ___ On presentation, the patient was found to have hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and evidence of volume overload with bilateral pleural effusions and lower extremity edema. Notably, he had not attended HD for several sessions prior to admission. The patient underwent HD sessions as per his usual home schedule with ultrafiltration to offload fluid. He was continued on his home torsemide, sevelamer, nephrocaps, calcitriol and vitamin D. # Pleural effusion A CT chest on admission showed R>L pleural effusions that were felt to be most likely secondary to volume overload in setting of missing

summary: ASSESSMENT: ___ yo woman with a history of mild dementia, Hypertension, hypothyroidism, cyclothymia, who is admitted with severe nausea, dry heaving and inability to take po. She does not have adbominal pain at this time. # Nausea-- etiology unclear, possibly secondary to partial obstruction from constipation. Per daughter, the patient had not had access to her stool softeners recently. There may also be a component of gas, has not been taking her simethicone. She improved with zofrana nd was tolerating food without any pain or nausea prior to discharge # acute renal failure- suspect ___ decreased po intake, will give additional liter of iv fluids and repeat in am. Patient was discharged back to her assisted living
