summary: ___ yo M with multiple medical problems presents with headache and facial numbness/tingling. NEURO: Patient presents with new left frontal headache, then developed gradually. He then developed left facial numbness and paresthesias. On initial evaluation in the ED, he was felt to have L nasolabiofold flattening, decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in V1-2, decreased cortical sensation in left hand and left upgoing toe. He was admitted to stroke service for concern of acute stroke. Head CT and MRI were negative for acute ischemia or hemorrhage. There was notably right frontal atrophy, and upon furhter examination patient was noted to have diminished size and bulk of the entire left side. This may be due to childhood polio, and is regardless a chronic process. Patient was re-evaluated on the morning following admission and found to have a normal examination with resolution of above mentioned deficits. Headache was resolved. Based on his presentation and negative imaging, we felt this was tension headache. It remained unclear why he developed sensory symptoms. There were no changes to his medications and no neurology follow up is necessary unless symptoms recur. He is already on maximal stroke prevention regimen with full dose ASA, statin and plavix. CV: Patient had recent echo showing ischemic CM with EF ___. Patient appeared euvolemic and CXR was clear. He was continued on antihypertensives, ASA, Plavix and Crestor. Fasting lipid panel was at goal. Acute on chronic renal failure: Baseline Cr approx 2.0, and wa 2.6 at admission, trended down to 2.2 before discharge wihtout intervention. Will follow with PCP ___ 1 week.

summary: Patient is a ___ year old man with DM, history of CAD, s/p MI in ___ and CABG in ___, h/o pAF, tachy brady s/p permanent pacemaker ___, EF 42% and fixed anteroseptal defect on stress test ___ admitted with 25 minutes of sharp, ___, substernal nonradiating CP at rest associated with afib on rhythm strip in EMS, both resolved on arrival to the hospital. #. Chest pain: Patient's history and previous history of chest pain associated with afib in past (___) c/w chest pain secondary to afib, possibly rate related demand ischemia. Likely precipitants of afib include anxiety, not taking am meds, and decreased PO intake. Could also have been vasovagal precipitated by swallowing. Other possible etiologies include ACS given nonspecific ECG changes, PE, esophageal spasm. ___ interrogated pacer and found pt was in afib for approximately 50 minutes which correlated with patient's symptoms. He has had several episodes of afib since last interrogated but is in afib<1% of the time. Pt had VQ scan that was low probability for PE. Symptoms are unlikely ACS since occurred at rest, dissimilar from prior MI, and ETT with fixed defect in ___. He had 2 sets negative biomarkers. He remained chest pain free during admission. He was continued on ASA, statin, and his BB was uptitrated. . #. CAD: Stable. CP dissimilar from prior MI. Continued BB (increased from 25 daily to 50 daily), statin, ASA . #. Pump: Euvolemic on exam. Last EF 40% . #. Rhythm: Appeared to be in Afib in EMS but remained in sinus here. EP interrogated paer and confirmed afib. Since has had multiple episodes, would recommend initiating anticoagulation as an outpatient. We recommended that he discuss this with his outpatient primary care physician and ___. Metoprolol dose increased for improved rate control. . #. DM: Euglycemic in house. Continued home regimen and sliding scale. . #.

Midline incision was opened in clinic and noted to have pus and yellow film that may require debridement. Upon examination the patient is asymptomatic, hemodynamically stable with an open midline incision not actively secreting pus. Patient states she has felt malaise and dizziness the last 2 day. The wound has been opened and a special VAC dressing placed to help keep the wound clean and encorage it to close slowly over time. If ___ notice any of the following signs of infection please call the office: increasing redness of the incision lines, white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or swelling of the area. It is important to monitor the output from this stoma. It is expected that the
summary: Mrs. ___ was admitted from clinic for management of a wound infection and malaise. On arrival to the inpatient unit, she was given intravenous fluids. The wound was evaluated and dressed with a saline gauze dressing and overnight, the wound improved greatly and was clean, a VAC dressing was applied with a white sponge dressing over the mucus fistula in the inferior pole of the wound. The patient was doing very well, she was much improved. It was decided she would be discharged home with a VAC dressing and follow-up in clinic. On ___, the wound VAC could not be delivered to the hospital and the patient was too anxious to return to home with a large open wound. She was quite upset therefore discharge was postponed until ___ and she went home with the wound VAC in place.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the ___ service after having jaw surgery for a broken mandible (the lower part of your jaw). You will need to take oral antibiotics for one week (including the time you took these medications at the hospital when they were given through the intravenous line in your arm) You will also need to perform a chlorhexadine rinse twice a day for two weeks after the surgery. In addition, we are writing you for a prescription to take liquid pain medications. Wound care: Do not disturb or probe the surgical area with any objects. The sutures placed in your mouth are usually the type that self dissolve. If you have any sutures on the skin of your face or neck, your surgeon will remove them on the day of your first follow up appointment. SMOKING is detrimental to healing and will cause complications. Bleeding: Intermittent bleeding or oozing overnight is normal. Placing fresh gauze over the area and biting on the gauze for ___ minutes at a time may control the bleeding. If you had nasal surgery, you may have occasional slow oozing from your nostril for the first ___ days. Bleeding should never be severe. If bleeding persists or is severe or uncontrollable, please call our office immediately. If it is after normal business hours, please come to the emergency room and request that the oral surgery resident on call be paged. ___: Normal healing after oral surgery should be as follows: the first ___ days after surgery
summary: Mr. ___ was admitted to the ___ service on ___ after being punched in the jaw and suffering an open mandible fracture. A panorex xray showed a fracture of the right angle of the mandible and the left body of the mandible. His surgery was delayed because of difficulty with OR booking. He was initially made NPO with IVF and given ancef q8 hours and peridex mouth wash BID. He was advanced to a full liquid diet in the interim which he tolerated well. He was taken to the OR on ___ for closed reduction and maxillomandibular fixation by OMFS of the mandibular fractures. He was given instructions on care of his fixated jaw, including to carry scissors at all times in case of emergency. He is being discharge on 1 week keflex peridex BID x2 weeks for an open fracture. He will follow up with OMFS and they will call regarding his appointment. He was voiding freely, ambulating, and is pain was well controlled on an oral regimen.

Patient was given ciprofloxacin for possible UTI for 3 days, then antibiotics discontinued for no growth on urine culture. BK virus negative. We started solumedrol 500mg iv x 1 for a total of 3 days(Day ___, then prednisone 60 mg PO for 3 days (Day ___, then plan for 40 mg PO for 3 days, then 20 mg PO daily there after. We increased tacrolimus to 4 mg PO bid and continued cellcept 1 gm bid. We also started valgancyclovir for CMV prophylaxis. #ESRD s/p status post DCD kidney transplant on ___ and angioplasty/stent of transplanted renal artery ___. We continued dapsone and sodium bicarb 1300mg PO BID. #RAS: s/p angioplasty/stent in ___ was on DAT for one month then managed on aspirin alone which has been held for the procedure. We continued aspirin 81 mg after the procedure. # HTN: We increase dosages of labetalol to 400 mg BID and amlodipine to 10 mg daily. #GERD: We continued omeprazole. ***TRANSITIONAL*** -F/U final result of kidney allograft biopsy -Ensure patient has steroid tapering: prednisone 60 mg PO for 3 days (Day ___, then 40 mg PO for 3 days, then 20 mg PO daily there after -Monitor blood pressure and heart rate and adjust dose of amlodipine and labetolol accordingly -F/U blood culture x2, quantiferon gold, HbA1c

summary: Assessment: The patient is a ___ year old male with h/o odontoid fracture, cognitive deficits, worsening neurological function in the setting of multiple abx courses who presents with fever and diarrhea. Primary Diagnosis: 009.3 DIARRHEA OF INFECT ORIG/FEVER Given the recent antibiotic adminstration this was concerning for cdiff. He was empirically started on flagyl and in fact returned positive for Cdiff so this was continued. An abdominal CT had the unexpected finding of diverticulitis at the sigmoid colon, and so he was also given ciprofloxacin as part of his regimen, and kept on a clear liquid diet. The patient had a known history of diverticulosis At the begining of hospitalization he was having as many as five BMs per shift; this has decreased to ___ per shift and he has been afebrile. Secondary Diagnosis: 438.0 COGNITIVE DEFICITS, NOS Secondary Diagnosis: 311 DEPRESSION, NOS Secondary Diagnosis: 293.0 DELIRIUM, NOS It was felt that the current infectious illness supoerimposed on his chronic cognitive deficits was causing some delerium He was continued on his prior regimen. His orientation appeared to improve in the hospital, especially for longer term events. His neurologic condition was characterized by mild rigidity, cogwheeling, and tremor, although his strength was normal and symmetric. A Head CT revealed chronic small vessel ischemia, but no acute injury Secondary Diagnosis: ___ FX C2 VERTEBRA-CLOSED Secondary Diagnosis: ___ ATAXIA Secondary Diagnosis: 784.3 APHASIA He was evaluated by neurosurgery and felt to be at his baseline in terms of neurologic functioning, and as above head CT was without acute injury. He has scheduled follow-up with Dr. ___ with regards to removal of the colllar at the end of ___. IN the meantime he was maintained on the ___ collar. Secondary Diagnosis:

summary: Mr ___ is a ___ y/o patient with a medical history of CAD, HTN, HLD, Diabetes, COPD and recent hip replacement on ___ who developed chest pain on ___ and was found to have a NSTEMI (anterolateral ST depressions on EKG, Trop 4.4-> 6.2)in the setting of post-op blood loss anemia(Hgb 11->8). He was given heparin and plavix at the OSH and his symptoms improved with blood transfusions(2 RBCs). He was transferred to ___ for left cardiac catheterization which revealed three vessel CAD (LAD: 70% stenosis in the origin LAD,distal 60% stenosis; Circumflex: 50% stenosis proximal, 80% mid circumflex; RCA: 90% stenosis proximal, 80% MID RCA). #Coronary Artery Disease : Patient with known CAD and multiple cardiac risk factors developed chest pain on ___ and was found to have a NSTEMI provoked most likely by blood loss during his hip replacement surgery. His ECG showed ischemic changes and a nuclear study showed a moderate reversible anterolateral and inferolateral perfusion defect consistent with focal ischemia. He received Plavix 300 mg and heparin at OSH.LHC was notable for -LAD: 70% stenosis in the origin LAD,distal 60% stenosis; Circumflex: 50% stenosis proximal, 80% mid circumflex; RCA: 90% stenosis proximal, 80% MID RCA. The patient was evaluated by cardiac sugery who recommened a Plavix washout prior to CABG. The patient subsequently had a TTE which was most notable for preserved LVEF 55-60% with no areas of hypokinesis or akinesis. As part of the pre-operative workup, the patient had a carotid series which demonstrated less than 40% stenosis in the carotid arteries bilaterally. The patient was continued on Aspirin 81mg daily, Atorvastatin 80 mg daily, Metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily, and Isosorbide Mononitrate 30 mg PO daily. The patient ultimately had Coronary artery bypass grafting x4 with a left internal mammary artery to left anterior descending artery and reverse

summary: The patient is s/p a R TMA on ___ who developed increasing swelling and erythema on the lateral aspect of her right foot. Below is a by system report of this patients hospital stay. Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization; pain was managed with by mouth medication. CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. The patients systolic blood pressure reached 190s several times and the patient received hydral at this time which corrected it appropriately. Also, the patient has to be straight cath'd and her blood pressure would become elevated when it was time for her to void. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. GI/GU/FEN: The patient was maintained on a regular/diabetic consistent diet which she tolerated well. As previously mentioned the patient has known urinary retention and was straight cath'd during this hospital stay. She has good follow up established with the urology team for ongoing management. ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of infection, of which there were none. Due to the erythema and wound on the lateral aspect of her R foot near the TMA sight, the patient was started on a broad spectrum antibiotic regimen of IV vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and flagyl. This was continued for two days until the patient was then transitioned to PO bactrim which she was prescribed to take for a 2 week time period. HEME: The patient received sub cutaneous heparin during this hospitalization and was transitioned back to her home dose of eliquis prior to discharge. Ext: Patient is s/p R TMA performed ___ who presented for increasing redness and swelling on the lateral aspect of her right foot as well. She was started on broad spectrum antibiotics and will continue on by mouth antibiotics for two weeks after discharge. Podiatry recommended off loading with a CAM boot and follow up as an outpatient. The

Patient underwent stress testing on ___ without reproduction of his symptoms and his maximal heart rate reached was only 150. Reassuringly, the patient has been able to tolerate these symptoms previously without loss of consciousness. In the ED at the OSH, patient was given 10 mg PO Vitamin K, 4 units FFP, 3 L NS, 2 grams Mg, started on diltiazem gtt, and sent to ___. In the ED, initial vitals: Temp. 97.6, HR 118, BP 130/50, RR 20, 95% RA WBC 14.5, Hg 13.1, Hct 39.5, plts 153, chem-7 Na 135, K 2.3, Cl 85, Bicarb 29.5, BUN 54, cr 0.9, glucose 112. ALT 13, AST 16, lipase 15, T bili 1.6, Albumin 2.7, lactate 7.6, trop < 0.01. INR 2.5. The patient was given 40 mEQ PO potassium and transferred to the ICU. Neurosurgery consulted on patient in ED with review of CT head showing small R. acute SDH with no mass effect or midline shift. Recommended to reverse coagulopathy, Q4 hour neuro checks, Keppra BID, and repeat head CT in the morning. After arrival to the MICU the patient denies any particular complaints. He does not recall the events leading up to his hospitalization. Notes he has been weak for a few days. Denies any abdominal pain, fever, chills, cough, dysuria, chest pain, or seizure like activity. summary: ___ year old male with history of atrial fibrillation, hypertension, diastolic dysfunction, and alcohol abuse found down at home in feces/urine with supratherapeutic INR to 24 with subdural hematoma and elevated lactate, who was found to have C. difficle infection, suffered massive aspiration event leading to severe aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia and ARDS, culminating in his death. # Aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia. Patient has >2L emesis event during which he aspirated and shortly thereafter developed aspiration pneumonitis and respiratory distress requiring intubation. He decompensated despite broad spectrum ABX for aspiration pneumonia, developing 3-pressor shock, leukocytosis and resistent fever to 41.3C. He was eventually transitioned to CMO and expired shortly thereafter. # Elevated lactate Patient with markedly elevated lactate of unknown etiology. Patient also found down raising concern for possible seizure activity contributing to elevated lactate particularly in setting of alcohol use. Will also proceed with infectious work up, IVF rescussitation, and trend lactate. C. difficile PCR positive. # R. small acute SDH: small R acute SDH, no mass effect or midline shift. Held coumadin. INR reversed with FFP and vitamin K. Keppra 500 mg BID X 7 days. # Leukocytosis. Found to have C. difficile infection, as well as aspiration event leading to pneumonitis and pneumonia and severe 3-pressor refractory septic shock. As above. # Atrial fibrillation with RVR. Required diltiazem gtt and AC.

summary: This is a ___ year old female, who was sent to ___ by her gastroenterologist secondary to a positive HIDA that was done. She has a PMH significant for anxiety and left ureteral damage during cystoscopy. She has had one year of abdominal pain worse in the last three months with unclear etiology, and was being worked up as an outpatient. It was decided that she be admitted for further workup of her abdominal pain. Abdominal U/S upon admission showed a non-distended gallbladder with no evidence of acute cholecystitis. She was made NPO and maintained on IVF, although she was allowed to eat dinner on HD1. Gastroenterology was consulted to see if they could provide further insight into the cause of the patient's abdominal pain. They recommended an EGD to rule out PUD. This was done on HD2 and results showed normal mucosa. Urology was also consulted. They believe that her abdominal pain is not urologic in nature due to her extensive urologic workup in ___. There was a question whether the outpatient HIDA was done correctly. Thus on HD3 the patient was sent for a repeat HIDA. This came back as a normal study. Therefore, a discussion was had about the utility of an exploratory laparotomy. This was deferred to the outpatient setting, as the patient was hemodynamically stable with normal labs and vital signs. She was tolerating a regular diet, though she did still continue to endorse RUQ pain. During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge

summary: In the ED, initial vital signs were T98.8 P60 BP119/67 R14 O2 sat.98% Patient was given IV morphine for pain. ECG and troponin were neg for ACS. She was admitted for management of her leg swelling and pain. # LEG PAIN AND SWELLING: Given her chronic diastolic HF, congestion on CXR, her progressive SOB with exertion and her 6 lb weight gain, she was felt to have worsening CHF. Her last ECHO was in ___, found to have EF >55%. She missed her dose of Torsemide the day prior to admission which may have acutely worsened her volume status. She admits that she misses doses occasionally if she won't be near a bathroom for several hours. The patient was restarted on torsemide and realized a net 1.5L diuresis on HD#2. Her torsemide was continued through the visit which improved both her lower extremity edema and SOB. She was provided with additional counseling about the importance of limiting salt and fluid intake and medication compliance. . # CHEST TIGHTNESS: Patient developed chest tightness while lying in hospital bed, and reported that she has had it intermittently over past few days, not associated with difficulty breathing, SOB or chest pain. She received an albuterol nebulizer with relief of symptom. Cardiac enzymes were neg X3. ECG had T wave inversions with some mild ST depressions, consistent with LV hypertrophy. She remained without chest symptoms the remainder of her hospital stay. The patient was questioned about her history of chest tightness, pain, or pressure. She reported that she does occasionally have tightness with and without exertion as well as episodes of shortness of breath and diaphoresis. After discussion with PCP, it was determined that patient would not remain inpatient for stress testing and instead pursue testing as outpatient per PCP. . # WHEEING, SOB: Symptoms are exertional and had been getting progressively worse for past week. CXR showed evidence of

summary: Pt is a ___ yo M with PMH DM type 1 and pancreas/kidney transplants, ___ (pancreas has failed; kidney still functioning) who was recently admitted with MSSA bacteremia and R foot ulcer s/p six weeks of antibiotics with course complicated by ___, metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia. . # ___: This was attributed to poor po intake for several weeks plus possible effect of linezolid. Linezolid was stopped. Pt received D5W and 2L IVF for volume depletion and his creatinine improved from 2.4 on admission to 1.6 on discharge. . # Hyperkalemia: Lisinopril was stopped and pt received kayexalate, insulin, and D50 for hyperkalemia. There were no EKG changes. His hyperkalemia normalized overnight from 6.2 to 4.7. It was likely secondary to his ___ plus lisinopril. . # metabolic acidosis: This was attributed to pancreatic duct anastomosis with bladder. Pt given IV bicarb and acidosis improved from bicarb 17 on admission to 24 on discharge. He was restarted on sodium bicarbonate 650mg, three tabs (1950mg) three times a day. . # nasal congestion/post-nasal drip: pt c/o nasal congestion and post-nasal drip in hospital. Was given saline nasal spray and guaifenesin for symptomatic relief which helped greatly. He was recommended to try these over the counter if his symptoms persisted. . # MSSA bacteremia/chronic right foot osteomyelitis: pt was s/p six weeks of abx, so no additional treatment was given. . # s/p pancreas/kidney transplant: pt was continued on cyclosporine 200 mg po BID and prednisone 5 mg po qdaily. . # Type I DM: Continued home lantus 28 units qhs and covered with humalog sliding scale. . # Hypertension: Stopped lisinopril. . # Hyperlipidemia: Continued lipitor 20 mg po qdaily. Continued aspirin 325 mg po qdaily. . # BPH: Continued tamsulosin 0.4 mg po qhs

Keep your wound(s) clean and dry / No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your date of surgery If you have steri-strips in place, you must keep them dry for 72 hours. Do not pull them off. They will fall off on their own or be taken off in the office. You may trim the edges if they begin to curl. No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending or twisting. Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day. Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for signs of infection. Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, and before bed for sleeping discomfort. Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. unless directed by your doctor. Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine (narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while taking narcotic pain medication. Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit. CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE FOLLOWING: Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain medicine. Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities. Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, tenderness, and drainage. Fever greater than or equal to 101 F. Any change in your bowel or bladder habits (such as loss of bowl or urine control).
summary: The patient is a ___ female with severe left S1 pain. An MRI done showed a large L5-S1 disk herniation compressing the exiting nerve root. Failure of conservative management led to surgical options and the patient decided to go ahead with that. She was taken to the OR and she tolerated the procedure well. She was taken to the PACU and recoverred well. Her pain was well controlled. She was tolerating a regular diet prior to discharge. She was seen and evaluated by ___. She was cleared for independent activity. She was discharged home on post op day 2.

summary: ___ F w/ hx of DM type 1, afib not on AC, cerebral ataxia, HTN, CAD, treated NHL, ___ esophagus, recent laparoscopic cholecystectomy (___) presenting one day after discharge with abdominal pain and intractable N/V, found to have DKA s/p brief FICU admission and insulin gtt, transferred to floor on ___, s/p EGD ___ showing esophagitis, gastritis, duodenitis. # Abdominal pain: # N/V: # Esophagitis, gastritis, duodenitis: # S/p lap CCY: Presented ___ with a week of N/V and abdominal pain, found to have possible cholecystitis for which she underwent lap CCY on ___. Discharged back to ALF on ___ and returned within 24h with recurrent abdominal pain and N/V. LFTs, lipase, lactate WNL. Initial CT A/P in ED negative. Briefly treated for DKA, with no improvement in symptoms. GI consulted and underwent EGD ___, showing esophagitis, gastritis, duodenitis - likely explaining her symptoms. Path showed severe esophagitis. High-dose PPI initiated. Given ongoing symptoms and leukocytosis, CTX initiated and repeat CT A/P obtained ___, showing bowel wall thickening, submucosal edema, and serosal enhancement of the gastric antrum and ___ portion of the duodenum with small crescentic focus of air along the duodenal bulb and no e/o bowel obstruction or abscess. ACS consulted and recommended NGT to LWS given initial concern for contained duodenal perforation. CT A/P w/PO contrast subsequently obtained ___ showing no e/o extraluminal gas or oral contrast to suggest perforation. Lactate WNL. Wall thickening and surrounding inflammatory changes around pylorus and proximal duodenum thought most c/w post-surgical changes per radiology and ACS. NGT d/c'd ___. Diet was advance and she was tolerating soft diet at discharge. She will be discharged on PPI BID x 4 weeks, with plan for repeat EGD in ___

summary: Patient underwent Incision and drainage of perirectal abscess at bedside x 2. Treated with IV antibiotics and hydration. Labwork and vitals stable. Pain controlled with IV and oral pain medication. Abscess site packed with gauze strips for a few days. Minimal improvement with pain and induration. Patient taken to OR for exam under anesthesia and drainage of abscess. 2 drains sutured into abcess cavity, and ___ sutured distally to drains to promote drainage of abcess and prevent re-accumulation of fluid. Patient tolerated procedure well. Continued with regular diet post-op. Antibiotic switched to oral Augmentin. Tolerated well. No signs of allergic reaction (there was a question if patient allergic to amoxicillin. Tolerated IV Unasyn-no reactions). He will continue with PO colace, and PRN percocet. Instructed on constipating effects. Instructed on ___ baths and perineal care. He will continue with Augmentin for 2 weeks, and will follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___, and Dr. ___ to discuss starting Humira. . Patient confirmed that he is no longer on Prednisone (tapered off), and not on Imuran as well.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 2. Avoid lifting weights greater than ___ lbs or lifting that requires you to strain until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity restrictions. 3. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise and take any new meds as ordered . 4. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do not take these meds with additional Tylenol. 5. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by tylenol. 6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking the prescription pain medication if you are experiencing constipation. You may use a different over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that are high in fiber. 8. Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider (PCP) as advised. . Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the nearest ER if you experience the following: *You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. *New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze. *If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your medications. *You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. *You see blood or dark/
summary: The patient presented to the ___ on ___ and underwent the above procedure, performed by Dr. ___. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was subsequently admitted to the ___ General Surgery Service. Neuro: Postoperatively, the patient was treated with IV dilaudid and tylenol, with continued complaints of pain, primarily related to baseline musculoskeletal pathology. She was subsequently switched to IV morphine, to good effect. On POD1, she was transitioned to oral percocet, as well as her home pain regimen. CV: Vital signs were routinely monitored and the patient remained hemodynamically stable. Pulm: The patient had no respiratory issues. GI: Intraoperatively, an NG tube was placed and the patient remained NPO overnight. The NG tube was removed on POD1 and the patient was started on a clear liquid diet, advanced to regular diet later that evening; the patient tolerated diet advancement well without nausea or vomitting. GU: Foley catheter placed perioperatively was removed early on POD1 and the patient subsequently voidid without difficulty. PPX: The patient received subq heparin and wore SCDs. On the morning of discharge, POD2, the patient was afebrile, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding spontaneously, and had good pain control. She will follow up with Dr. ___ as an ___.

summary: Mr. ___ was evaluated by the neurosurgical service in the emergency department and found to have weakness in the bilateral triceps and MRI evidence of post surgical fluid collection, likely epidural hematoma. It was felt that compression from this fluid collection was the cause of his weakness. He was subsequently admitted to the neurosurgical service. Dr. ___ attending neurosurgeon who performed his C4-C6 laminectomy and fusion on ___, planned to manage this fluid collection non-operatively with observation. On ___ ___, he had q2h neuro checks that demonstrated stable weakness in the bilateral triceps and with grip. He was also started on dexamethasone 10 mg IV q6h. On ___ Patient had improvement in tricep weakness. Dexamethasone was tapered to 4mg Q 6H. A ___ consult was placed. On ___, patient's tricep weakness was confirmed by Dr. ___ to be at pre-op baseline. His exam remained unchanged to slightly improved. His dexamethasone was discontinued along with insulin sliding scale. His primary complaint was of paresthesias in the ulnar nerve distributions of the bilateral, likely secondary to nerve regeneration. His gabapentin dose was increased. Physical therapy saw the patient and recommended rehab. Patient had at least 5 large watery bowel movements on ___ and 2 on ___, so c. diff was ordered; however no further bowel movements occurred on this day. On ___, Mr. ___ exam remained unchanged. He had 1 loose BM in the morning and was tested negative for c. diff. On ___, the patient's neurological examination remained stable. It was determined he would be discharged to rehabilitation.

summary: ___ w/ ETOH cirrhosis who presented to liver transplant clinic on ___ and was found to be hypotensive to 85/50 and dizzy so transferred to ___ ED for further management and initiate liver transplant work up. Patient's blood pressure improved with IV fluids. He was noted to have a 5 point hct drop so EGD and ___ were performed. EGD showed a few cords of grade 1-II varices were seen in the esophagus. The varices had no stigmata of recent bleeding. He was noted to have portal hypertensive gastropathy. Colonscopy was normal. He was started on tube feedings which he tolerated. He was set up to see his PCP and liver doctor as outpatient. ##Hypotension: Patient presented with SBP in the ___ in the ED and felt light headed he was given IVF and his symptoms resolved. Patient not symptomatic when he reached the medicine floor. Although he continued to have systolic blood pressures in the high ___ to ___ and it is likely that he has a lower resting blood pressure at baseline. Patient was stable and asymptomatic during his hospital stay. The patient did have a drop in his hematocrit from 28 to 23.The patient had no evidence of bleeding. No dark stools. The patient underwent an EGD and colonoscopy during his hospital stay. EGD showed grade ___ varicies with no evidence of bleeding. Colonoscopy showed three polyps two of which were removed. See full attached reports for details. He required 2 units of FFP prior to colonoscopy due to coagulopathy. He will require another colonscopy in ___ years pending pathology results. Patient was stable on discharge. ## Alcoholic Cirrhosis: thought to be reasonable liver transplant candidate but not on list as pending medical evaluation. MELD: 26 on admission now 18. Patient underwent EGD and colonoscopy as a part of screening for transplant as well as an MRI. See reports attached. ## HEPATIC ENCEPHALOPATHY: patient has baseline confusion low grade. On admission he was alert and oriented by 3. He was continue Lactulose on home dose

summary: ___ The patient presented to ___ emergency room with right lower extremity rest pain with a nonhealing first metatarsal head resection site. He was admitted to Dr. ___ and started on broad spectrum antibiotics. He was consented for an angiogram and premedicated with bicarbonate for renal protection. On ___ the patient underwent a right lower extremity diagnostic angiogram which showed mild to moderate calcification at the bilateral common and internal/external iliac arteries. There was also complete occlusion of the anterior tibial artery at its mid length with almost immediate reconstitution from collaterals derived from the peroneal artery and in-line flow to the dorsalis pedis artery and posterior tibial/plantar vessels. There was also complete occlusion of the posterior tibial artery at its origin with reconstitution from collaterals derived from the peroneal artery. The patient tolerated the procedure without complications. ___ Stable without acute events. Continued on IV antibiotics. Monitored for infection and increased pain. Non weight bearing to the RLE. The decision was made to bring the patient back to the OR for a possible angioplasty and stent placement. ___ The patient was taken to the OR and underwent a RLE angiogram with a SFA angioplasty x2 and Right AT plasty and peroneal angioplasty. Had adequate flow from the AT  peroneal through the foot. He was transferred back to the Vascular floor. Bedrest overnight. ___ Self discontinued Foley overnight. VSS. Physical therapy examined patient and recommended Rehab to maintain non weight bearing status. He was fitted for a orthowedge shoe by Orthotist which he will take with him to Rehab. ___ Discharged to Rehab in stable condition. Patient is DNR/DNI. Will follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ weeks with an arterial duplex. He will be discharged on 1 week of augmentin.
